text:
I actually had to come here twice in order to their delicious shrimp poboys. The first time was around 11:30pm on a Saturday night, but they had ran out of bread for the night. We decided to try again the next day for lunch and was able to order a shrimp poboy.

It took them about 20-30 minutes to make 10 orders of shrimp poboys, but that meant it was a perfect time to grab a frozen irish coffee from the bar. 

The shrimp poboys reminded me of vietnamese sandwiches. Same type of bread with lots of veggies, but the key ingredient is the fresh shrimp. Every time I've had shrimp poboys, the shrimp has always been fried, but this time I was pleasantly surprised to see the shrimp without batter. 

The sandwich was quite delicious although quite expensive at $14.

The 4 stars is for the burger - I did not try any other items (Fries, mayo or shakes).
I got soggy sweet potato fries at L'il Dans - FAIL.  (But that's another review.)

The burger itself was on the rare side - and I had the special with a fried egg (perfectly done - a bit runny but not raw) and cheddare cheese (subbed for swiss), lettuce tomato and scallion mayo.

Perfection!   (And a calorie bomb.)

Can't wait to visit again - but not for at least 4 weeks.

$9 for just the burger.  (That can really add up if you get a $3 soda or $4 fries)

This is like a Denny's, in that they offer a huge variety of foods, but in no other way - it is one hundred times better than a Denny's. When you walk in you see a wall of cheesecake and you pretty much know it is going to be a fun experience. We were fortunately seated near the HDTV at the back of the restaurant as we watched the Jets fail their faces off against the Steelers - that part sucked, but even that sucking moment was still fun since we were hanging out at the diner. We were in a big group and we also were sitting right next to another big group, the Duke University fencing team. This place draws big groups in because it has a legit reputation among everyone, locals and those from far away who had a great meal here once a long long time ago.

The big guy (4u) waiter right off the bat was friendly, gracious, and funny - top notch staff here for sure. The water was not exactly refilled at a regular pace but I guess it was pretty busy. It was really hard to choose a dinner since everything sounded so good. I finally settled on the open faced Monte Cristo, longing for 'ye olden days when that deliciousness of the Monte Cristo used to be available at Bennigan's before their shenanigans shuttered their doors across the country. Penrose does not make 'yo daddy's Monte Cristo and that is not an entirely bad thing.

This is french toast as the base, two pieces and very moist and eggy. Not fried like Bennigan's. Just french toast that is AWESOME. Then meat piled on top of the french toast. Then some cheese on top of that. And a big helping of fries. The fries were solid, the good diner kind, not the shoe string or crinkle cut or that other junk places try to pass off.

I will be back for more Penrose.

My favorite day of the year is Labor Day, when I attend the Reno Rib Cook-Off. This year we actually were there the day before Labor Day. It was a little bit more crowded at the event but the drive back to the Bay Area was much faster than doing it on the holiday.

Parking is generally very easy. It can take a minute, but there are several locations that are closeby, if you're patient. The streets are closed for the event and lots of stands to choose from, selling ribs and roasted corn, or other fried, delicious foods. 

Sampler plates (3 ribs) are about $7 - though this year we saw one as high as $9 (and it wasn't very good). and one that gave us 4 ribs for $7 (from Memphis.... served dry, without sauce - they were the BEST ever!!!)

Two restaurants local to our home make it to the Cook-Off every year: Kinders and Back Forty Texas Barbecue. Both are really good but obviously I am not going to stand in line to try them at the cook off when I can get them at home.

Lots of vendors sell jewelry, clothes, popcorn, etc behind the street. There are also rides for kids. 

The BEST thing is that there are lots of porta-potties, and they are super clean! They even smelled good... at the end of the day! In the HOT HOT HOT sun. It was nice.

So next year: save up your money, hit up the fest, and try like 5 different rib places and then some corn... get some sodas or stop at one of the bars on the street, ...maybe do a little gambling -- and you'll definitely have a new favorite day of the year! 

[Make sure to get a hotel room in advance because this weekend is always booked in Reno! Completely! From Motel 6 to Grand Sierra Resort to the Nugget - everything!!]

Right to it: The Yelp Indy International Supper Club rolled in 26 deep for a full dinner on a Wednesday night at 7. Over in the other corner was a party of 10. I was blown away by Peter & Co.'s service.

This was my first sit down, full meal at Saigon. Expectations: High. Reality: Really High. 

This place is exactly why I travel. Nearly every city in America probably has something similar -- a strip mall tucked away in a unsuspecting area -- that is thriving with authenticity. Especially here, the Banh Mi & Pho! 

Now... that's not all they have... their menu is, well, how do I say it, um... HUGE!

From lemongrass beef wraps to catfish in a clay pot. I went with the finest soup & sandwich of my life: bbq pork banh mi & Pho Special of flank steak, beef brisket, beef meatballs and tripe in classic Pho fashion. 

My first visit I thought I was eating bbq beef banh mi, I was incorrect -- it's some stellar bbq pork that is spot on.

The bean sprout & fresh basil side plate with the pho was a supreme touch. 

The service was pretty remarkable considering he's serving a party of 26 in a restaurant that seats about 40 at most. Um, the Yelp Supper Club came through -- big time here. At the other end of the table, I salivated, and salivated, for the Vietnamese Coffee that Jessica  & Rodney were having. My lord, I have to return midday before my coffee cut off time of 3pm. 

And then, something historic happened. There it was, the banh mi bbq pork (re: photo)... it sat there with it's open profile of pork, cilantro, cucumber, carrots & jalapeno on a french roll; she just couldn't resist. She, whom is anti-pork as my Inner Rabbi, my LP, took her first banh mi bite, and I have a Sakijewa golden dollar on it that she'll return for more!

As will I!

Note: Amazingly classy touch of the sides of beer six packs cut out and taped above each booth in a row to display what beers are offered (which includes 3 Viet beers!)

Oh, Billy Bob's, I really wanted you to be more than three stars.

When I went here for lunch today, I was pretty excited.  I had been looking forward to checking this place out since it had opened a few months ago.  I like BBQ and sandwiches (although I'm no BBQ aficionado) and I went in with an open mind.

As soon as I walked in, my friend and I were greeted by the manager and were immediately seated.  We then met our server who was extremely friendly, attentive, and helpful.

For an app we ordered the fried pickles which came with ranch dressing and another dipping sauce.  They were really good and got me excited for the meal.

I ordered the hamburger, only because I wasn't in the mood for a huge meal and my friend ordered the brisket.  I got an order of mac and cheese as my side.  When my burger came, it was dressed pretty basically with lettuce, tomato, onion and pickles.  The burgers aren't cooked to order, and the one I had was pretty dry and over cooked.  It wasn't juicy at all and I didn't even finish it.  The mac and cheese was good, but it wasn't overly spectacular.  My friend ordered potato salad with the brisket, which I tried, and could tell that it was likely store bought (which isn't horrible, but I've had better).

All in all, the place was a solid three stars.  The staff was amazing, the atmosphere is nice and the food came quickly.  I was sad to see that there weren't more people in here.  I really am rooting for this place, especially because I think the Westbank needs an "authentic" BBQ place.

As old school as it gets. The register is from the 1930s or maybe older and it actually gets used. It's amazing, worth the price or admission alone. Key copies are a couple of bucks, and they'll be accurate as hell. Don't waste your time at Home Depot or Lowe's folks. These keys will last you. 

Aside from the keys, they have a bunch of hardware for your quick fix/job home improvement needs. I found myself purchasing things for jobs I wasn't even planning on doing because it was just so cool to be in there. I'll definitely be back and you should be checking this place out. 

Just to watch that register work at the very least. 

It's old school baby, but not in the hipster way. 

Ring it in baby...

Have been here twice - both time for work-related happy hours.
Good service from the sweet Irish barkeep - Connor - and a good big shot of Tullimorew Dew.  (Sweet and smooth.)

Food is just OK.

Love the witty quotes/sayings on the blackboard that changes every day.

First time in any Dollar Tree and won't be my last.

Lots of good bargains and a tremendous variety of merchandise.

Store was maintained better than I expected as there was clearly an effort to keep shelved stocked and aisles from looking cluttered.

Apparently, this used to be a "Deal$" store operated by Dollar Tree where items for slightly above $1 were also available. That would explain the large amount of square footage, but all signs for this location, both inside and outside, clearly show this is now a Dollar Tree.

Also, any store where an employee sees a long line at one register and announces he or she is opening another register to move customers along gets my approval.

I would not recommend parking in the front row of spaces just outside the front door/windows because it can be dicey backing out of those spots when leaving because it is so close to a high traffic entrance/exit to the nearby road. Use the lot away from the front of the store and you can get in and out without any trouble.

Located near the Books-A-Million in Embassy Crossing.

I make this the opening line because when I searched on my Waze app for nearby post offices, it directed me to a delivery location, not a retail outlet where one can make purchases and send mail.

Typical post office with long lines. But the people were friendly, and got my stuff shipped.

I'm loving Northwest Coffee even more now since they started serving eggs several days ago.

Plain eggs, eggs with cheese, eggs in a tortilla, eggs on a bagel, eggs on an English muffin... you get the picture.

They actually steam their eggs under one of their espresso machines! So, they come out extra light and fluffy, and the water expands them nicely. No butter or oils necessary! 

And, their eggs are locally-sourced from the River Hills Poultry Alliance. They're 'happy eggs', as they come from free-range chickens that are free of antibiotics and humanely raised. And yes, you CAN taste the difference.

They still make the meanest latte ever here, too! Try 'em.

It's weird: Much of what's going on with my life is a complete surprise to even myself.  I wasn't supposed to be in New Orleans or be staying with my friend whom I hit up last minute, but somehow we ended up here when I was already pretty shithoused, running with our umbrellas trying to beat the impending storm that never came.  The outside area upstairs is cool with a view of the Mississippi River (always makes me think of Tom Sawyer or one of those books).  However, there is only one dingy table outside AND, it's the target blasting area of some sort of restaurant ventilation so if you look cute, keep in mind that you will leave smelling like greasy french fries which makes you less cute.  

Drinks are like $10 each.  EXPENSIVE!  And small sized like but I was drunk already so no harm no foul.  Mojitos are better than margaritas.  It's a huge space inside but not many people upstairs.

For my Two Hundredth review I give "The Block".  Cute name cute inside cute little meat case with cute little chunks of meat.  The service was not so cute.  The server wished she was anywhere but here waiting on us.  I feel your pain it is hard to work for a living.  But if you are not a people person than maybe you need to sit in a cube somewhere and not waiting on people with your lousy attitude and pathetically slow to non existent service.  What saves this place from something less than 3 stars is the food was very good.  I had their steak sandwich..  It was very good.  Odd instead of one slice of steak it was pieces of steak placed on the bread.  I almost felt it was leftovers from the butcher shop.  But style or not the steak was very good.  It had a nice punch to it from the pepper they seasoned it with and the gardinaire it was served with.  The steak sandwich came with fries so I asked for some ketchup.  It came out in one of those little stainless steel cups that was about 25% full.  So after about 2 fries I needed more.  Good luck with that.  Refer to server section of the review. 

My son The Famous Chip K. was with me anid told me he had this server before and she was bad.  Oh well.  So go for the food not the service.  Really it is cute in a cute way

I'm going to be a straight up tourist about this! This is Panera, what what?! Ok, so I didn't eat here, but I did go through the drive through. My friends got salads to go for the plane ride. They seemed to be very pleased with their orders from Saint Louis Break Co. / Panera. I can't believe I went here, Panera is blowing up everywhere... I've only been to one Panera in New York and I didn't think much of it.. but I still think it's cool that I got to visit here. If you have friends in town you should definitely take them here. Saint Louis pride. 

Fast service at the drive through! Great for a meal on the go.

This is not my regular Schnucks. However, whenever I am heading home from Costco and cutting down Loughborough to Hampton, I stop by for items I just cannot buy in bulk at the warehouse store for a single man. 

In my original review, which is now several years old, I complained about the produce department. Wow, things have really changed. I will now say this is one of the better produce departments in STL. It's always fresh, organized and well stocked.

I've also gotten use to the lay-out and can shop the aisles with ease. Another area that is pretty good, is the butcher counter. Give me those pork steaks for that backyard grilling. 

The staff has done a full Three-Sixty on their attitudes. Even during this pandemic when everyone seems to be on the edge, they were upbeat and positive.

While shopping during the COVID pandemic, I felt safe with all the safety precautions this store had in place. 

Will I return? - For, sure. 

When: June 4, 2020
Why: Grocery items I cannot buy in bulk.

Cozy & dark hideaway feel. A mix of music videos play throughout the lounge. Beautiful water-fire pit. Bartenders are great. I like this place to relax, gamble & enjoy their wide variety of mixed drinks. Pleasant little nooks to unwind throughout the lounge.

My sister brought me to Katie's
For my last meal in NOLA. 
I was craving something local. 
Like a PoBoy and a cola!

Like many places around town 
There's a plaque showing the water line. 
But one big, nasty hurricane 
Won't squash peoples desire to dine!

From pics, I knew I wanted to try
The yummy crawfish beignet. 
The dough was flaky, the seafood fresh,
The cheese sauce spicy like Kimye!

But what I really came here for
Was an authentic NOLA PoBoy. 
Sadly, I was disappointed. 
It was more like a So-So Boy. 

The breading didn't have much flavor
Most of the shrimp still had veins. 
But I just asked for remoulade and ate it. 
I'm usually not one who complains. 

My sis really liked her crab cakes. 
Garnished with more lump meat on top. 
Overall, I enjoyed my experience,
I was happy to have Katie's as our last stop.

I wasn't really expecting to love Hablo Taco based on the mixed Yelp reviews, but I actually really liked it!

Upon arrival, I noted a very touristy vibe in here (daiquiri machines on the walls, over the top decor, etc).  I was a bit nervous about the food due to this, but the food was actually very very good.

I started with a sangria rita (2 of my favorite things mixed together).  It was a very large drink and for the size, I don't think that the $9 price tag was too bad.  We started with the sriracha guacamole (YUM) and the loaded queso (it had bacon in it) and both were very tasty.  For my meal I had the grilled avocado (filled with fresh ahi tuna and crema sauce) and the Mexican street corn.  The ahi tuna was SO incredibly fresh and the avocado was just perfect - highly recommend this dish.  The Mexican street corn was also very well done and quite scrumptious!  Everyone at my table was happy with their meals from tacos to salads.

Our server was very sweet and was prompt on refilling our chips and getting us anything we requested.   Honestly, I had a very good experience here and I look forward to coming back in the future.

If it were in Virginia, it'd be VA-Chinatown. And I'd come here even more. So to speak.

One thing I am certain of, is that it's more exciting that the largest city in Saskatchewan. Without doubt, you're better off in Chinatown than Reginatown.

Philadelphia has a beautiful Chinatown with little alleys and a crisscross of roads that reminds me a little bit of a slightly larger Boston Chinatown, and it's significantly better than the one in DC, but what isn't.

It's a traditional Chinatown with a big gate right in the heart of the city, which makes for a great tourist attraction. There is some really great Boba around here too, as well as some not-so-good Boba.

But I would say some of the best Boba in the Philly area is within 4 blocks of this gate, and there's plenty of amazing food located right here in Chinatown, which makes it a real destination for us, and we like it. Parking is an issue though, like at your mother's place.

For Boba try Mr Wish, KFT, Mr Camp, Tsaocaa, Tea Do (open later), and more.

My old review said:

A lot of people think of NYC and San Francisco as the Chinatowns of the USA. But cities like Boston, DC, Houston and Philadelphia have wonderful Chinatowns of their own, complete with the "gate" and all.

The Philly Chinatown is much smaller and less-frequented than the one in NYC, but it's absolutely wonderful. It's mainly just 1 street, although technically it's several square blocks. The one street is like being in China itself, but in a Philly terraced row-houses neighbourhood setting. There's a little of everything, and if you like Chinese food and goods, you'll never get tired. There are some nice dessert and bubble tea shops along here too.

Perhaps the best part is that Chinatown Philly is close to everything. It's about 10 minutes walk from the Liberty Bell and 5 minutes walk from Reading Terminal Market, which has much of the best food in town. It's one of the most notable and enjoyable little Chinese neighborhoods in North America.

So if you feel saddened or down
I know just what will erase your frown
We'll both strip down naked
Steal a car, and take it
Out joyriding in Chinatown.
Lives up to the hype. Thank you. I do wish the portions were a little more "shareable" on some of the small plates.

IT has a beautiful exterior and that's all I really got to see. I played in the fountains in front of it and I must say that is a beautiful add to make this area even more serene. I'd like to go inside to tour it since I know this place is very old and historic, and ideally if I could I'd like to visit the top of the tower to get a good view of downtown Philly.

Table 3 is an excellent French restaurant in Nashville! 

Nashville is rather limited if you are looking for a French meal, so I'm so glad Table 3 took over the large restaurant space by the movie theater that seems to rotate restaurants frequently. I hope it is here to stay! 

The duck confit appetizer is incredible with capers and goat cheese on the side. It's cooked crispy and tender, and is just as good as I remember it from my first trip here! The cheese board is a great option as well, they feature different cheeses and provide great sides to accompany the flavors. The board included apple slices, buttered toasted baguette slices, red and golden raisins, and these wonderful candied walnuts. YUM. 

I had the pan roasted lemon sole with potatoes and my BF had the duck breast with sweet potato hash. The fish was very good, but the duck breast was incredible. The waiter told us the duck is smoked and you could tell in the outstanding flavor. It was so good!! For dessert we tried the salted dark chocolate mousse with these cinnamon cookies on the side. The perfect end to our meal!

Great service, great food, I'll be back!!

Ok this time i did order the alligator cheescake and you will lick the plate!!  Jacque himself was there walking around talking to guests and I thought that was cool.  I had the stuffed pork chop and it was amazing.  Rich in sauces, this is not light.  My mom had the grouper and it was really good and bf had mahi mahi with pistachio sauce, amazing.  They send out this corn bread with garlic that are to die for.  Honestly everything on the menu is $20 and up but worth it because all entrees come with a salad and 2 sides.  We too the trolley from canal street on St. Charles so it was great to see all the mansions and the Universities.

It was a great little find on a simple summer getaway. Thanks yelp app!

We ordered a half dozen donuts, a bagel w/egg & cheese, another with cream cheese, a corned beef & cheese sandwich and I believe a coconut mocha frozen drink (can't really remember). Overall everything was good and the staff really knows how to handle a crowd as the line moved fairly quickly.

While I can't say anything in particular was outstanding, I can say it's a solid place to get your morning started!

2021 / 97
Shortn'Sweetseries

this was our last meal in Nashville before we came back to Ny. it did not disappoint. I didn't get to try a burger since I was still full from breakfast. I did have side orders of fries (yums) and mac&cheese (double yum) it's also cool the waiters there also sing/play guitar on stage. it was a great last stop and very close to our hotel. great place to go after exploring the orpyland hotel with the gardens & not wanting to spend $$$$ to eat there.

This place has the best location of all the restaurants in Clearwater Beach and is always crowded.  They have live music and is a good place to see the sunset on the beach.  

The food was okay.  I ordered battered shrimp and my husband ordered shrimp flat bread.  The flat bread might be the best thing they have for the price and taste.  Our waitress was attentive and fast. 

Overall it was an acceptable experience at this place.

This was easily the highlight of our recent trip to New Orleans. Our tour guide was fun, knowledgeable, and easy to follow. We loved walking around the city at night and learning about the history. I wasn't expecting to enjoy the ghost tour as much as I did, but I would recommend it to anyone! 

The only bad part was the actual buying of the tickets. We stopped by throughout the day and no one was there at the ticket stand. When we arrived at the tour time, the woman siting there told us not to tell anyone that she wasn't there throughout the day. Then, she refused to take our credit card. Thank god we had cash. 

All in all, minus this minor mishap, check them out. Hopefully the woman who gave us so much trouble is no longer working here.

The Sail Pavilion serves as a great place to watch the sunset with a view of the water and harbor of downtown Tampa! Sail Pavilion can be a great stop for anyone biking, running, or walking the Tampa Bay Riverwalk.  This place is dog friendly with plenty of dog water bowls available so bring your furry friends! However, the service is terribly slow. Drink prices are a bit pricey at $5-7 per beer and $8-12 per mixed drink. They have a wide variety of tropical drinks including: the blue crush, pina colada, strawberry daquiri, rum runner, coco loco, mud slide, margarita, sex on the beach, mai tai, and mojito. I had the burger and shrimp wontons and they were both awful. They only have 1 waiter and 2 bartenders for the whole place.  I got tired of waiting and went up to the bar and that took over 10 minutes in a 4 deep line just to get a drink.  They need a better menu and more staff on the weekends. Especially if there is an event at the Convention Center. Sail Pavilion has food trucks almost every Friday and is a local crowd favorite gathering spot for residents of Downtown and Habour Island. Boaters can dock their boat at the marina in front of the restaurant, take a boat tour from the marina, rent water bikes, rent boats, and soak in pretty views of the boats in the marina, Jackson's Waterfront Bistro, Harbour Island, Davis Island, the Hillsborough River, and even Bayshore!

Meh.
They were out of "Republic of Tea" Ginger Peach - so I had the Mango Ceylon (you gotta check out Repulic of Tea's website - good stuff). 

They seem to have remodeled a bit and things look brighter and there is less crowding at the front of the store during the lunch "crush".  Also now they give you a buzzer so you can get a table and site while you wait for your mediocre salads, sandwiches and salty soups.

Sorry - but the food is not that great, to me.  Soups are all very salty.
Beet salad had great toppings but the base was raw kale and arugula - did not thrill me.  Next time I will see if they will make it with some romaine in there.

Good news!  You can choose an apple instead of chip or a baguette.  (Guess what I got.)

Too caloric for a "healthy" choice fast food.
Yet, still, my company gets LOTS and lots of lunches catered from here.

Not going to lie, I was a little hesitant about going here. But man am I glad I did! Their happy hour is a hidden treasure. From what I saw it goes from 3-7 &10-12 and it's 1/2 off drafts and long neck bottles. We got there around 10 on a Friday night and there was plenty of seating. We were served right away and the waitress was so friendly. First, I was shocked by how many beers they actually offer. They had about 5 different IPAs just on tap. Then, I was even more shocked by the prices! Since it was happy hour, our beers were only $2.50! I haven't been able to get a nice IPA in Nashville for less than $6. After several beers we got a little hungry and checked out the late night food menu. It was impressive. Reasonably priced bar food at its finest. I ordered the Queso chips and was not disappointed. Homemade queso, sour cream, and salsa. I mean, it was nothing fancy but for a dive bar it was pretty delicious. Overall, our tab had 5 beers and Queso chips...the total was about $19. I mean, come on! You can't find a better deal than that in Nashville. Sure, it's a dive bar in a quieter area, but hey, if you're in the area and looking to for cheap drinks, Jonny's is the place to go. Be warned, people are allowed to smoke inside so it does get to be a little much.

I was referred by someone I work with and knows the area pretty well. I had been on vacation and very busy during the week so I needed a close by salon to visit during lunch break. I walked in and was initially told there was no opening for an hour. Which is fine I work close by I would have just came back. In the middle of booking my appointment the waxer became avilable and I was able to be serviced right away. Yay!

The techichian (Tina) was very friendly and listened to my needs. I wanted my eyebrows cleaned up being this was my first time and did not want the tech thinning them out too much. She trimmed them and cleaned them up without affecting my shape. Perfect! The wax felt a little too warm and I was a little worried it may irritate my sensitive skin but it did not.  

The interior is so spa like and clean. Parking is a little weird as you have to drive on the lot and down a sltight space that only accomodates one vehicle at a time so make sure you proceed with caution as there could be a vehicle trying to come out while you are trying to enter. 

They also gave me a nice gift bag for being a new customer with a full sized hair product and nail polish. That was a nice touch. I would say it is on the pricey side but on a day that I need to be seen right away i will definately stop in again.

More about the view / being on the pier than the wine, which was all kind of just okay and pretty forgettable.  We shared a tasting and considered dumping half of it.  They don't serve on the pier, and you can't take all your glasses with you to the pier, so that means going back and forth to the bar.  Great views, but you can get that from anywhere on the pier.

My Yelp friends Coty and Paul asked me to join them one evening at Mei's World Pizza and Salads along Bearss Avenue, near Bruce B Downs, in the USF area. I wasn't quite sure what to expect, as the name of this place seems to imply a pizza shop, and yet Coty told me that they serve very good Taiwanese food. Hmmmm, well, she has never failed me with her selection of restaurants, and so I was game to give this place a try.

Sure enough, this little restaurant on the north side of Bearss Avenue looks like a pizza / sandwich shop from the outside, but inside, the place was packed with college students in the know, as well as folks looking for good Thai food. 

The first thing you should know is that nothing on the regular Thai menu is priced over $10. That includes rice bowls, noodle bowls and platters, traditional Thai appetizers, and a great mix of entr√©es. Secondly, they DO serve pizza......and apparently you can have them put Thai or Chinese / American food on top of your pizza. Finally, if you are so inclined, they do serve pig's feet, chicken feet, chicken lips, chicken butt, and a whole lot of things that will never go into my mouth. Sorry, but I just can't picture a chicken walking around on a pair of crutches because someone wanted to eat chicken feet! Nope, it's not gonna happen.

Coty ordered a number of very tasty dishes for the three of us to share, and so we enjoyed Mei's pan-fried pork buns, pepper-seasoned fried chicken (no feet, please!), hand-cut Zha Jiang noodles in a black bean sauce, and a sliced, boneless pork chop served with a tea egg. The egg was awesome, so we ordered some more of them. Mei, is of course the owner, and she & Coty got in to a very fun discussion about Coty's upcoming trip to Taiwan as well as her experiences with enjoying Taiwanese food in New York City.

I really enjoyed my meal, but was glad that I went there with people who were more experienced in ordering this cuisine. The wait staff at Mei's was super-friendly, and very helpful about making recommendations about the menu.

I liked this place a lot, and will gladly go back when I'm in the neighborhood.

Terrible customer service. I could feel the thickness of bad attitude immediately. It was cold out & I needed a warm place to wait for my Lyft sooooooo.....I waited in the non-existent line for one of the 3 non-busy employees to acknowledge me. I ordered a Pike because I didn't twist then to craft my usual espresso with care. The young man placed my coffee on the counter & walked away. 

I had to ask him, "Excuse me, are you ready for me to scan?" 

Nonverbal gesture of a head nod was given. 

I scanned and walked away disgusted. 

Counter, nasty. Floors, nasty, display case, nasty. Service, nastier. 

~Christy

I've only been here twice and I already love this place.  I saw the sign for a bakery out of the corner of my eye as I was driving down Bearss Avenue and was curious what the place was like. La Familia is a charming Mexican bakery. While there are two small tables outside you can sit at this is more of a place where you grab your items and go. There are display cases to your front and left as you walk in showing all sorts of wonderful looking treats. There are donuts, conchas, muffins, cookies, cakes, just to name a few. My favorite dessert I've tried so far was a rectangular slice of vanilla cake with peach and guava waves decorating the top.  It was delicious!  Their cuban sandwich felt like a brick in my bag it had so much weight to it.  The cuban bread was excellent also.  I've also tried their ham and egg sandwich, which also was a substantial amount of food. Their prices are also great!  I was very surprised that every dessert in the side display cabinet is only 99 cents. The people that work here were very patient with me with my endless "What's that?" questions. I'm looking forward to coming back and trying many different things!

My good friend was providing us a tour of the Santa Barbara County Courthouse which is located at 1100 Anacapa Street, in downtown Santa Barbara. If you are a lover of architecture, this Spanish Colonial Revival style building is quite an enjoyable visit. I always was in great belief that Greeks had a hand in some way in almost every new architecture structure that exists and they definitely did with this structure. The new building replaced a smaller Greek revival courthouse at one time long ago.  

We visited the clock tower, which has many views from all directions. The clock tower mechanics some levels below was surely quite impressive engineering. I also enjoyed reading the history painted on the walls in the beautifully architected main court room. This is an active court house to this day and it is surely worth the visit and especially for those love creative architecture.

Highly recommend Magic Tours! Wish I had booked them for more during my visit to New Orleans. The company books their tours in small groups so that it's more of an intimate learning session. Well worth the price because other people who had booked in advance canceled and we got a personal tour! We reserved the Garden District tour on a Friday morning.

We were fortunate enough to get Nancy as our guide. She isn't a born and raised NOLA resident, but that didn't stop her from being able to answer all our questions. She would have made American History fun and memorable back in grade school. She knew everything from Civil War history, to celebrity residents, to top eateries, to why chicory is the thing in local coffee. Nancy made the two hours go by quickly and was very interactive. 

I took two other tours on this trip, one of which had signs to courtesy tip, and the other flat out asked for a tip. Nancy didn't expect anything or ask if anything (but of course we did). If I ever return, I will most definitely use Magic Tours for a St. Louis cemetery tour.

We stopped in for a drink before heading to El Charro for dinner a night last week.  The pub was great - cool, dark and relaxing.  The bartender was nice and quickly helped us with our drinks - sangria and beer.  Definitely a fun place to stop in for drinks and play some games too!

It's been open a week on the loop, but there is no grand-opening sign. This just replaced St. Louis Bread company. It's looks pretty similar inside, except they now they a private room in the back for guest and plenty of outdoor seating. It's not as cozy as STL Bread company but there is wifi, food, coffee, and most importantly dessert (they have fruit tarts!) to do some work. Why did I not know about this place early this week?!

Horrible customer service. I was pressed for time and came in with a simple requirement: a matte and frame that would fit a 16' X 20' print. The two women behind the desk were extremely unfriendly, unhelpful, and went so far as to laugh in my face. I would recommend Aaron Brothers over The Frame-Up.

I went to Aradia Fitness at the weekend with a private group for stagette party. Chantel was our instructor and she did a great job planning the lesson so at the end we would all be able to do a short routine. 
The facility is right on Whyte Ave and it's a nice space with room for 10 poles and a little waiting area. 
We arrived a little early to put up some decorations and we spent a long time taking videos, pics and played a little game at the end too. Chantel was accommodating which was great as it was the start of a really fun night.
I'd go back for fun and certainly recommend as a group activity. My leg are wrecked after it so defo gives the body a work out if you are considering a different kind of fitness activity.

The food here is pretty good. I waited an HOUR AND A HALF for a table! We had a large group sure and they gave us a 35-40 minute wait, but after that time had passed they told us it would be another 35-40 minutes. I think it's just standard operating procedure for restaurants in New Orleans to have huge waits. 

The waiter, Charles was friendly but I think things slipped his mind-it could've easily have been a double shot of Wild Turkey he admitted to taking because he was working New Years' Eve. He passed me a cup of gumbo I didn't order and forgot my buddy's side of black eyed peas.

I liked the food-the gator sausage was delicious it was spiced right, fried up and the sauce was tangy. The meatloaf, was okay but the greens and mac and cheese were kind of eh, tons of hot sauce and salt barely saved my mustard greens. I love Frenchmen street though but I wouldn't frequent this place again.

Weekday dinner buffet is exactly what you pay for. The food selection is actually not bad as you get a fairly good variety of things to eat, but nothing stands out too much. I will give them the prime rib though--get the medium rare slices and you will have an amazing dinner (don't forget the au jus!) Fruit is also sweet, but everything else was rather forgetful. If you are staying here, it's definitely a good location to go if you have a bunch of picky eaters (something for everyone), but don't expect Vegas style quality.

Came here after fishing with my brother. The bagels are definitely good but maybe we came too late in the day. They definitely tasted like they've been sitting out a while. I'll definitely ask for less cream cheese next time. It was probably half an inch thick of cream cheese - a bit too much for me!

Orange Sun Tan attendant: Are you sure you don't want to do 15 minutes? We are currently running a sale on our Magic Diamond Triple Golden Lotion - it's 50% off - only today. 

Me: Oh, yeah? So, how much is it now? (only to humor myself). 

Orange Sun Tan attendant: It's now only $49.95! Have you checked out our new spring OPI colors? 

Me (in my head): Damn, can't a girl fake bake without a 1,000 sales pitches each time I walk through the door?

Orange Sun Tan attendant: Okay, it's going to be a 35 minute wait. Would you like to upgrade for $9.95 - it would only be a ten minute wait.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
And this, my friend, is the conversation that occurs 9 times out of 10 when you enter Sun Tan City - be it on Keystone, in Avon, East Street or wherever. I must admit, I was apprehensive of admitting my sinful use of cancer beds from time to time but my dismay with Sun Tan City was worthy of candor. I give it two stars for their overly-aggressive sales tactics and disorganized timing of bed slots. Don't get me wrong, the employees are super-friendly. There is just something bothersome about someone smiling while questioning the fact that you only want to tan 10 minutes in an attempt to save your skin from premature wrinklage and excessive freckles.

As I get older, I have trouble keeping up with all the fads in dining.  So when I heard about a "Paleo" diner, I wasn't sure what it meant.  But, being a fan of good food, I thought I would give it a try.

Nook has expanded their hours to include lunch, so I went the day after their first lunch serving.  As my waiter arrived, he explained how people should eat like "cave men":  no artificial sugars, no gluten, and no dairy.  Now, I have no animus against any food group, believing in the basic food groups and moderation to be my golden rule of dining.  But any given meal for me may step out of the pyramid.

So I gladly accepted the complementary sip of olive oil to start my meal.  It is supposed to be good for digestion.  I noted a hint of peppery flavor which was actually rather pleasant.

I started my meal with a beef broth bowl.  The bowl is huge!  They start with 200 pounds of beef bones and slow cook it down to extract the rich flavor from the marrow.  The broth has daikon radish, shiitake, shredded beet noodles (yellow), onion, shredded cabbage, and topped with fresh herbs.  Yum!  Note:  You can make this a full meal by adding beef to the bowl for an additional $7.

I also ordered a side of Brussels Sprouts which are shareable in size and un-shareable because the flavor is so fantastic!  I devoured the whole dish by myself.  The sprouts are halved and are grilled with shishito peppers, candied (turbinado brown sugar) bacon, and topped with a smokey paprika aioli.  The flavors were nicely layered and makes me wonder if people who say they don't like Brussels Sprouts had any idea how much they are missing.

As an entree, I ordered the short rib taco.  Instead of a flour or corn tortilla, they use ground almond which adds a nice flavor and a bit of crispness.  The short rib beef was juicy and tender, but maybe a tad under seasoned (they do have salt and pepper on each table, but I refrained from using it since I wanted to see how the flavor combos worked without it.)  The taco also has scallions, shredded napa cabbage, teriyaki, and sriracha (not very hot with all the other ingredients).  They also added shredded carrots and herbs on top.  The herbs were fresh and gave a pungent fragrance as I folded and lifted the taco for a bite.  Note:  although the tortilla holds up to the juices, some will drip out onto your plate with the orange color of the sriracha....be sure you have your napkin in place so that you don't get stained. (Whew!)

The staff was very friendly and even though they left an iceless carafe of water on the table for me, frequently did the pouring when they passed.  The front manager stopped by to see how I was enjoying the meal and even the owner came by.  I like when the folks who are supposed to be overseeing the operation actually care about listening to my feedback and don't just go through the motions.  Everything ran smoothly and the waiter even checked on a couple things for me with the kitchen to answer my curiosity.  (Note:  I go at non-peak times, so staff may have a little more time to answer.)

I doubt I will switch over to becoming Paleo.  But I will definitely be back to try some of Nook's other options soon.

Review #689

This is still a really new place and they definitely have some kinks to work out with service and keeping the buffet stocked.  It was taking upwards of 20 minutes for items that had run out on the buffet to get restocked so certainly that is an area for improvement.  The service was also very inconsistent and it took quite a while to get a drink refill.  The food was very well spiced and at a generally higher level of spice than the other area Indian food restaurants in the area.  

Overall I enjoyed the food but for the moment I would advise to order off of the menu if you are in any kind of hurry.

Luke is a causal John Besh restaurant located in the CBD. It was one of the few good restaurants open for lunch on Saturday. 

We had the corn and crab bisque to start and it was very good. For entrees we ordered the burger and stuffed shrimp. 

The burger costs $16 which seems expensive for a burger (its the most expensive buyer i have ever had), but it was really good. The burger is huge and is topped by a wonderful cheese and smoked bacon. I am not a bacon fan, but apparently John Besh knows how to procure incredible bacon. The burger comes with some really good fries that are placed in a mint julep cup wrapped with paper. 

The stuffed shrimp was really good and came with vegetables. 

The wait staff was very attentive and friendly. I will definitely go here again. 

One word of caution. We at at Luke for lunch and La Provence for dinner. I would suggest only one Besh restaurant per day. There is no way to eat that much food in a day.

We stopped by Sun King and thought we would check out the new Oca restaurant/shop inside. Oca, meaning "Goose", is a spin-off for Goose the Market that opened inside the public area of the brewery. Although they hadn't "officially" announced they were open, I had heard that they were open in the evenings and were working through a soft opening process. So glad we stopped by!

My wife and I both tried one of the bundled French Bread sandwiches. Tonight's featured City Ham and Gruyere with Dijon mustard, tarragon, and mini sweet pickles (cornichons). I placed our order at the counter, paid, and gave my name. They asked if I wanted the sandwiches toasted (yes!) and that allowed me time to pick up a couple drafts at the Sun King counter. As soon as I was making my way back to our table, the Oca staff called out my name and I was good to go.¬†

I loved the crispy crunch of the bread and the toasting brought out the flavors of the ham and cheese. Excellent pairing for the spices too. Can't wait to come back to try some of the sausages and charcuterie.¬†

*****update******
I made it back one evening and decided to try the Choucrote Garnie which may as well translate to "meat lover's dream!"  Actually, it's a "traditional dish of France's Alsace region bordering Germany" and the Choucrote is fermented cabbage while the Garnie means it is dressed with Riesling (white wine), herbs, potatoes, and charcuterie.

 This huge option is brought out in a roasting pan.  My eyes started to glaze over at all the meats.  In the center was a large peppery Knack(wurst) nestled over a large serving of the Choucrote.  To the left was a thick (a full inch) smoked rib chop that was the most tender pork chop I've had.  In the upper left corner were two Nuremberg sausage (technically much larger at about 5 inches instead of the 9 cm traditional).  The Nuremberg have a thicker casing and more in the Bratwurst family.  To the right of the Knack were a couple slices of Pancetta that looked like American bacon, but have a higher salt content.  Just below that, there were two Strasbourg frankfurters.  Oh, and there were two potatoes that were halved and roasted.

The Choucrote itself was a great surprise at how much I enjoyed it.  My mother used to make a really nasty version of sauerkraut and dressed it with white vinegar.  I hated it!  But here, the pungent odor of vinegar is replaced by the pleasing notes of the Riesling.  The sour of the dish is tempered as well, so the overall taste is quite pleasing, especially since it is warm and served thoroughly tender. (I am not a fan of the sometimes rubbery and tough texture of raw cabbage.)

The portion size suggests it is for two to four people.  They mean it on this dish!  I made really great headway on devouring the dish, but common sense struck me before I was stuffed and decided to get a to go box.  Not for the picky eater, this is a dish that goes great with a dark beer (I went with the Sun King "Stuck in the Middle" Milk Stout option. Yum!)

*****back to the original review*****

As if I didn't have enough reasons to stop by Sun King already, now I can get great quality sandwiches while there. Note that Oca sells packaged meats to take home if you stop by to fill your growler.

Tech stuff: They are open generally the same hours as the brewery.  Parking is free in the Sun King lot.  A number of platters are meant for 2 to 4 people, so bring friends!

Review #439
Rev #30

I love the atmosphere at Gelateria Del Leone. In the evening it's dimly lit, has plenty of comfortable seating, and it's as much of a coffee shop as it is a Gealteria. 

On my most recent visit I enjoyed some of their gelato on their adorable patio out back. They have cafe tables with a fountain in the middle and lights strung above. The patio feels like one of the best kept secrets of Tower Grove. It's a hidden little bungalow. It's getting a bit chilly so you might have to wait until spring to check it out. 

The staff is all friendly and the patrons seem to primarily consist of students studying away for their next exams. This is a great place to go with a couple friends, a date night, or even just to study alone. 5/5 would recommend.

Setting:
-Very classy yet chill
-Great for hanging out with a small group of friends 
-Also great if you just want to sit there by yourself to be all pensive and shit

Service:
-Major kudos to the counter boy for letting me sample all the gelato flavors because I was indecisive/curious/fat. Yes I sampled all the flavors, judge me all you want.

Gelato:
-Too bad that none of the gelato flavors really stood out to me. And you've gotta have an acquired taste for London Fog.

I thought that I was well-versed in Middle Eastern cuisine since I know my way around the menus at Greek and Mediterranean restaurants, but clearly I was wr.....wr....ummm, "mistaken".

Petra is an authentic Middle Eastern restaurant located in a small strip mall, just east of Busch Gardens along Busch Boulevard. If you're not paying attention you'll easy sail right past this spot -- and that would be a mistake. The restaurant is very popular with people who are familiar with this cuisine, as well as students from the nearby University of South Florida.

The food is very fresh, and cooked to order, with fresh vegetables and ingredients bought in daily from the local markets. Petra also imports some of their specialized ingredients from the Mediterranean to supplement what they can't find locally. The pita bread is baked fresh on a daily basis.

It takes a bit of time to sort through all of the great options on the menu. Your server won't rush you, but they'll gladly answer questions and make suggestions. Appetizers include some outstanding hummus and Foule, babaghanoush, falafels, stuffed grape leaves, Nabulsi fried cheese, and all kinds of other fun things to try and pronounce.

You can order a traditional Greek or cucumber salad, but they also have Fattoush, Tabouli, and Tahini salads. You'll honestly have to read through the descriptions on the menu (or beg Tiffany H to go with you) to make up your mind. I saw the puree of lentil soup on the menu and decided to give that a try. It was seasoned with cumin and other herbs along with saut√©ed onions and a splash of olive oil. My soup arrived at the table along with a basket of freshly-baked pita bread, and a bowl of spicy pickled vegetables. YUM!!!!!

They have a number of different sandwiches on the menu which are stuffed with shawarma or kabob meats, or you can skip right to vegetarian heaven and order falafel, hummus, or babaghanoush sammies.

If you prefer a heartier entr√©e you'll find platters of beef or chicken shawarma, along with saut√©ed diced lamb, served with a ring of homemade hummus, almonds, onions, and parsley. Petra also features daily traditional specials, and all of these entr√©es are priced under $15. For bigger family gatherings you can order their grilled skewers of lamb, chicken, or beef, with a variety of sides.   

I had the grilled beef shawarma plate which was served with a ring of hummus around the edge of the plate, and then then diced beef piled up in the middle. That was served with sliced pickles, onions, and tomatoes. Very delicious, and plenty of food for leftovers.

I was craving Pho yesterday due to the beautiful weather and my go to place is closed on Sundays.  Thanks to Yelp I know that Pho An Hoa was close and that other Yelpers enjoyed it so I decided to give it a try.

Upon entering, I was impressed with how nice and clean it was.  We asked if we could put in a take out order and upon ordering were told it would be ready in 5 minutes and it WAS.

Let me tell ya, the Pho was delicious.  It was the perfect spicy meal for a chilly day.  We were given a very hearty portion for $8 a piece, which is insane.  I look forward to coming back and trying some of the other dishes.

Probably the best liquor store I've been to in Edmonton. The variety is outstanding. Sometimes I can get overwhelmed when faced with the decision of which wine to buy. This place has handy stickers on wines that are staff top picks. It's a nice way to try new wines and find new favourites. I normally go for Aussie wines because I know more about those but this place is breaking me out of my comfort zone and allowing me to confidently try some Canadian wines.
Hubby loves this place for the beer selection. Quirky beers from all over the world, some gimmicky bottles with dinosaurs or James Bond (that he can't resist). Sherbrooke Liquor also stocks cans of Tennants Lager, which is bog standard in Glasgow and a little taste of home for us.

Russell Gardens Center in Churchville, Bucks County, Pa., may not be the largest nursery garden plantation in the region, but in my estimation it is one of the best. I have been shopping here since moving to Bucks and starting a garden around the house (The enterprise is never done).  Originally, I was tipped off to its existence by a nurseryman friend who helped me with design and bare root tree planting.  He swore by Russell's for perennials and colorful annuals and shrubs that most other dealers either lacked, or only possessed in inferior quality.

As an example, twenty years ago I bought a small pot of Coreopsis, a hardy fern-like leafy base with yellow star flowers that bloom in late June/early July, and spread to fill any space they are in.  Yesterday, I returned to see what was new in this native American beauty.  Now, they are available in a few shades of red/orange, and most strikingly, in a red/yellow flower that is breathtaking in its simplicity and kinship to its elder cousin.  Love at first sight. It is now planted across the walkway from the original, and it is easy to imagine its growth over the coming years.  

We purchased 3 other low growing, shade loving varieties to replace the old builder's grade junipers that had run their course.  Three Heuchera with rich dark maroon/gray foliage, two Veronica (Speedwell) that push up spikes of pale blue to indigo flowers in early June, and three low dark green/purple grasses that spread through their roots to cover bare soil and need little maintenance. They are all happily in place beneath the living room window. 

Always more work to do.  Plans call for a redo of the west side foundation plantings.  Russell Gardens will get the call as we lay out our plans.  Their inventory, knowledge and understanding of gardens and gardeners, makes it the place I trust most with suggestions and products. Prices are about the same as the other shops. 

Russell Gardens is why we dig in the earth.

Not as good today - but still a classic.
I still prefer Oregon over the Melrose and Penrose diners.

I am grateful to be able to find a few good "old school" diners.

DD had chicken fingers 'n fries (theirs are very fresh and crisp), DH and I had breakfast.

OMG, I love having 5-ways with you Skyline.  5-way chili that is: spaghetti, chili, red beans, cheese, onions, mmmmm. 

Why aren't you in my hometown.  I guess I have to wait until next year when I make the annual Christmas family visit to get some more of your goodness.  Cincinnati style chili rocks and I believe the secret is cinnamon.  If you've never tried it, you must at least once.  This is one of my shameful Midwest obsessions, along with White Castle!  

Sadly, I must admit to smuggling some cans of Skyline home in my suitcase- not even close to the real thing.  Yuck, stick with the restaurant.

I've been here 3 times.
First two times were duds.  Slow service and nothing stand out good.   It was a place to get food into my face and into my belly.

But this last time it was different.  I just got the wrap.  I just got the lamb.  I just got a side of falafel.  I just really really enjoyed my food.  The falafel was crispy and way better than any other falafel I have had in town.  The bread I had was soft and didn't take up the whole wrap.  I've come to realize I don't really get the shawarma thing.  The flavors just don't make me go, oooo.  But the lamb sure did this time.  All the flavors and textures were balanced.

Price wise these guys are right on.  I would have no problem adding them to my rotation if I worked close by.  Prices wont kill you, but they definitely aren't fast food.  Plan ahead or call ahead.  This is good everyday food.  It wouldn't be a place I take a guest from out of town.  It's not a must do...it's a should do if you are nearby.

Oh and being next to the best coffee place in Nevada doesn't hurt either.

This was my first visit to the French Quarter and it was nice to have a market close by. The prices are a little high, but it is the only full size market in the quarter.  My first stop in, I was able to find everything I needed for breakfast in the morning.  The cashier was really sweet!  I wish I remembered her name.  However, on my second visit, just to pick up a gallon of water, something shady happened...

Now, maybe it was an honest mistake, but I had been drinking and was feeling pretty good.  The cashier was friendly.  My water was under $2 and I gave her a twenty.  I watched her grab my change, but when she handed it to me, she just said "thank you."  Luckily I took a look and counted, because $10 was missing.  I hadn't left the lane and just turned to her and said "I gave you a twenty" (it was even on the receipt).  She apologized and said she thought she gave the correct change.  She couldn't open her drawer because she rang the next person up.  

But funny thing, when she handed me my ten, she wouldn't look me in the eye....

So I'm just going to say, BEWARE...count your change if you pay cash or use a credit card!

JD has made a big comeback thanks in part to a dynamite Groupon deal that was available this past week. My father and I went with my friend and his wife and since this was my father's first time here in years we decided to split a plate of seafood. I ordered the fried oyster and red fish platter. JD is one of the few restaurants that serve fried redfish as a replacement for the standard catfish. The plate was outstanding except for the size as it was much smaller than my friend's wife who ordered catfish which they give you much more of. It really wasn't big enough to share. There was a long wait but Groupon will fill a place especially seafood on a friday night in New Orleans.

Despite its name, this cute little shop didn't look cluttered to me.

You'll find a variety of neat classic and vintage items when you stop in here. And there's really no reason not to pop in...after all, it's right in the center of town!

If you're a globe lover and collector like me, you're in serious luck. I found one from the 1950s for $25 that I desperately wanted, but since I'm in the process of clearing clutter ahead of my move back to Collingswood, I resisted. It was so hard! They also had a bunch of big ones in stock.

Right now, they're selling banners depicting the PATCO stops. They're pricey at $59, but otherwise really cool. I would've loved to splurge on one, but again, stopped myself!

If you're looking to add some quirky or elegant items to your home, this is a good spot to look. I'll certainly be back for a serious browse session once I'm settled in my new place.

Just visited yesterday. They have a Tuesday special I didn't know about before. 2 for Tuesdays. $2 bowling games. $2 bowling shoe rentals. Quite a deal considering this place is expensive on other days. We had some food while we were bowling and their fries are pretty good, but not with the chive dip...I like them better with some ketchup. Their mini-sandwiches are alright. Waitress was pretty friendly, I think her name was Jenna. Look her up if you visit. Overall still pretty much the same place it was before, just giving you guys the heads up on a special. Enjoy.

On our way home, my wife asked if I would stop at this local alterations shop to pick up a garment she had adjusted.  I will be the first to admit that I don't personally know much about sewing and alterations, but my wife does and she couldn't say enough about how reasonably priced this place is.  The woman who does the alterations is very friendly and my wife has been very pleased with the results.

Understand that you can't usually drop off some intricate garment and expect her to drop whatever she is doing to fix it.  But my wife was in no hurry and the garment was ready in a couple weeks.

There are a couple changing/dressing rooms for visitors to try on their garments for marking and reviewing.

Note that the owner only accepts cash or checks, NO Credit Cards.

My wife found the place through the local grapevine, so when I saw it was already reviewed on Yelp, I was pleased to see the reviews echoed my wife's opinions.

If you are in the area, stop by this small shop just south of the Casey's at the intersection of Bridge St and Indianapolis Rd.

Review #3653

I had a great experience with Assurant. I purchased my old Google Pixel phone from the Google Store (online). One of the options I could add to my phone was Device Protection for $99. Device protection is the same thing as phone insurance and Assurant was the provider.

The coverage I purchased was good for two years from the date I received my phone. The maximum number of accidental damage repairs or replacements under Device Protection was two during the coverage period. My Pixel's camera lenses, both front and back, got scratched. The scratches caused light streaks in my photos and videos so I decided to file a claim and get a replacement.

Per the Device Protection welcome and terms and conditions email I got from Assurant, I filed my claim at https://mydeviceprotect.com/. It was really quick and easy to do, especially since Assurant had most of my information on file from my phone's IMEI/serial number. I filed my claim on a Friday night. In less than 24 hours, someone from Assurant called to verify my information and approve my claim. I received a claim approval email after the call and a shipping notification that Monday (first business day after my claim was approved). I received my replacement Pixel on Tuesday afternoon; basically, in two business days. Fast!

I did have to pay a $79 deductible, but it was totally worth it to me. It was like I got a brand new Pixel for only $178 ($99 for Device Protection + $79 deductible). Technically, the phone was refurbished, but it looked and worked like new - the battery too, which was huge, since my old battery was on its way out. Considering my particular phone model at the time, a 32-GB Pixel 1, originally retailed for $649, I thought this was a good deal. Plus, I had one more replacement remaining on my contract before my two years were up. It was nice to have that peace of mind.

Google made it easy to transfer all of my apps and data from my old Pixel to my new Pixel. I just connected the two phones with a USB-C cable and followed the prompts. The entire transfer took about an hour (my new Pixel had to download and install almost 100 apps). I was really pleased with how simple and seamless the transition was. My old phone was essentially mirrored to my new one which was exactly what I wanted. I did have to set up new fingerprint recognition and log in to all of my apps again, but that was it. I was back up and running with a "new" phone with hardly any interruption.

I returned my old Pixel in the same packaging that my new Pixel came in. Assurant emailed me a shipping label to print and tape to the outside of the box. I had to return my old Pixel within 14 days from the date my new Pixel was shipped. Otherwise, I could've been charged an "unrecovered equipment fee" of up to $2,000.

In the end, I am very happy with the Device Protection I purchased from Assurant. I already bought it again for my latest phone, the Pixel 3, for $129 (unsurprisingly, the insurance price went up).

Ryder's can be a bit quiet. but the staff is nice and fun, the food is good, the hokey old jukebox is cheap and obscure, they have a full bar, a few cheap food options, a good beer selection and a rear patio.  I'm in!

Moving some of my old reviews over to Yelp. This review was originally written/posted on 20 Dec 2007.

I've been to all three Natural Way locations. This location seems a bit smaller than the Webster Groves location (Webster Groves is my pick out of the three). Regardless though, they have a lot of good vegetarian options, but I feel that they lack variety and could carry more vegan products. Nonetheless, the employees are really nice and *always* extremely helpful!

My first time with Afghani food, though the dishes we tried seemed very familiar.  Prices were a bit on the higher side, but this isn't a doner kebab takeaway!

You will need a group of six people at least to reserve the spot where you can all sit around a low table with your shoes off. Good to know in the future!  We were miffed to know we were short one person to get it and we almost considered dragging someone off South Street to join us - hahaaha.

The ambiance was lovely - our table of five could easily chat and hear each other. It's definitely a white table, candle light and clinking glasses kinda place. We shared a number of different dishes, none of which I care to attempt to spell out, but everything was delicious.  I loved my Afghani meatballs, my sister loved  her kebab (not the most appetizing looking thing, but it was spiced well), and the four different appetizers we tried out were all gone quickly (they were on the smaller side, so we could each only have a bite or so each).

Wow - this unassuming restaurant was inside of the Hilton where I stayed at for my conference.  I wasn't sure how the food would be but their charbroiled oysters were something out of this world!  They have this oyster bar where you can watch the whole process of them being shucked and then, charbroiled.

They're then, covered in butter, garlic, herbs and parmesean cheese on top.  OMG - dellicious.  After devouring a dozen of those delicious oysters, I had some catfish that was pretty good, too.  But this place - Drago's - you have to get the charbroiled oysters here - yum.

I am pizza... Pizza is me!!!! That being said, this place gets it all the way right. $7.95 plus tax gets you a whole pizza pie, all to yourself. The menu calls for the standard for $5 & some change; or $7.95 to build your own. 

I crafted my own with Garlic Basil as the base, ALLLLLLLLLL the cheeses in the building, add in a few jalapenos & HAPPY HAPPY AM I!!!! Then to top it off, literally and figuratively, at the end, I added oil and balsamic vinaigrette drizzle to my pizza once it edited the oven... OMG!!!! Sheesh!!! My only disappointment was that I couldn't eat it all in one setting.  

For my beverage of choice, I opted against the water, soda, coconut water, juices options... Bring on the NOLA Beer on tap. It was my first time trying it annnnnnnnnnd I was pleased. 

Start to finish, this process took about 12 minutes. That's novel for pizza making. What's the secret? Is it the massive fire oven? Or the thin, flaky, buttery crust? Or the super efficient restaurant workers? Idk, whatever the reason, it happened and that made the difference. 

The only draw back for THIS location, is the lack of parking. Truly this location caters to the CBD/downtown crowd and that's super cool. And since I know parking is the challenge I will face, I'll be prepared for it HEAD FIRST. And speaking about head first... Did I mention there's an option to call ahead??? I saw it, it happens and then so now BLAZE has been added to my list of places for one of my infamous #stickandmovecapers!!!! Great, Great, Great!!!!

Have an infatuation with Mexican food? Crave perfectly roasted chicken? Adore delicious cocktails? Love really amazing locally owned restos in crazy cool spaces? If you answered yes to any of the above, I have the perfect spot for you: Rostizado! 

This roasted chicken-centric brain child, from the delightful men of Tres Carnales fame, have carved themselves out a neatly packaged niche in the Mercer Wear-house building. With smart, sexy cocktails (that do take a bit of time to arrive at your table, so be patient), and a truly unique menu (there is no guacamole and salsa here, this is grown-up Mexican with thought and flavour) that is unlike anything else in the Province. 

I love the decor, the chill couch-lounge with vintage red TVs. The staff is incredible (especially those sporting 'man-buns', wink, wink) and the stand-outs food wise, for me, the sandwiches for lunch! - either the rosti pollo or rosti puerco. Do get the rosti papas (best roasted potatoes EVER!) and roasted cauliflower as sides, so good! And I quite liked the roasted romain hearts salad. If you like mushrooms get the queso fundido. And of course, the roasted chicken! 

As this is still a very new restaurant, there are bound to be bumps and bruises, and learning curves. That's why I gave it 4, not 5 (because I know it will improve, I can't wait, and my re-review a few months from now will show that!) And I urge you disregard quick-to-judge early reviewers that may "loose their internet cool" after minor meal mishaps that they may portray to look like Moby Dick size mistakes.

Blink, and you might miss this little storefront.  Just look for pale green paint. 

The staff was not very friendly at all.  No greeting, smile, or acknowledgment of the order in which customers are in line.  I expect more from a cupcake shop, any shop for that matter.  Especially a tiny one that's recently opened and should be trying to attract business.  The two staffers weren't very efficient in providing service either.

Tried the red velvet elvis (not sure why it's called this; wasn't Elvis' thing peanut butter and bananas?), peanut butter chocolate, boston cream, and lime coconut varieties.  Of the 4, I'd recommend the boston cream - rich, ganache-like fudge frosting and cream filling - but each of the cupcakes were underbaked and crumbled in your hand.

So, today I jumped out of my car and left my keys in the car and locked it ! SMH :-(  So, I called my insurance company and they put me in touch with Pop-A-Lock .  They tried to triangulate my GPS location but that didn't work but I gave them the address where I was located so that worked out fine.  The estimated time of arrival was 45 minutes and they sent several texts just updating me on the location of the technician. They ended up coming in 20 minutes!  I was so surprised! Jamie was the technician and he was professional  and popped my lock open in no time!  I am so happy that they came out and if I'm unfortunate enough to lock my car keys in my car again, I will definitely call Pop-A-Lock!

I'm from SoCal and have been to very, very hipster places (including PDX), but Milktooth might actually take the cake. It's in a converted seven-bay garage and is influenced by all types of cultures - Spanish on the wall directing you to the bathroom, traditional Jewish cuisine with a twist as well as miso soup on the menu) But, I really enjoyed it even though we waited a little over an hour. 

We had the: 

*potato & rutabaga latke (acorn squash butter, green harissa cream, scallion) - this was SO good. I don't think I've ever had a latke, but it was tasty. Not too oily. The flavors will the butter, cream and scallion were perfect. 

*cranberry walnut & geneva & raclette grilled cheese (black truffle honey, local sunny duck egg) - Whew, I'm glad I shared this dish because it was very heavy. Extremely delicious but if I ate the entire grilled cheese myself, I'd definitely fall into a food coma. 

*indiana hot chicken wings (dried chiles & crystal sauce, bleu cheese dressing, carrot & celery slaw) - this was SERIOUS business. I've had seriously hot nashville chicken, but damn this was SO spicy. I loved it though!

The only thing I didn't love was the camellia drink I had (apple, matcha, pistachio and steamed milk). It was grainy from the pistachio maybe? and just an interesting but not that tasty combination of flavors. Also, a small cup was $6!!! Ridiculous.

Small but worthwhile. When I was there, they had a large Buddhist art exhibit, which included a beautiful mandala created by Buddhist monks, an exhibit of photographs by Irving Penn, as well as a small exhibit of works by a contemporary sculptor. The building itself is a draw -- it's a repurposed post office, and a gorgeous example of art deco architecture. There is also a very nice museum store full of interesting gifts and jewelry.

We've been meaning to visit Pontilly coffee after realizing it is our closest coffee shop. Service as very friendly. It's a cute but simple shop with decent parking. We had a cafe au lait and hit chocolate which were both good and very hot. I tried a NOLA-che. So many flavors that sounded intriguing but I went for a standard egg, cheese and sausage as a first venture. It was really good: fresh, warm with soft, slightly sweet bread. I can't wait to try more flavors! My small friend had a butter croissant and chocolate chunk cookie and he raved about both. Everything looks handmade and fresh here. Bit your ordinary chain coffee fare. 

We are excited that we have found a new morning hangout!

I wasn't feeling well... and if I had my choice it would have been a matzo ball soup type of night. Or I may have just skipped dinner and gone straight to bed, but felt like I needed to eat something while pregnant. 

My colleague and I opted for dinner at Wildflower Grill, conveniently located within the Matrix Hotel we were staying at. We made our way downstairs and were seated immediately (no reservations necessary on a Tues night).  

By no fault of Wildflower Grill, but thanks to my stuffed up nose, there wasn't much on the menu that sounded appealing, but I finally settled on a caesar salad. And of course I couldn't pass up on ordering the bread appetizer that so many yelpers raved about.  Both hit the spot, especially the very warm bread that practically melted in my mouth.

I'm sure there's even better food on the menu that my bread and salad, but I"ll have to wait until my next trip to Edmonton when hopefully I'm feeling 100%.

Admittedly not the best first impression. I walked in to find a harried scene: tables were littered with plates, napkins and other debris; tables were out of sort; and the staff behind the counter were excitedly talking at one another (I'm neglecting to call it 'shouting'). In the midst of all of this, the manager/owner/woman in charge, took a deep breath, smiled, welcomed me in Spanish and English, and asked if I was eating in or needed to take my order to go.

'To go.'

I'd studied the menu online (well, pictures of) but it looks like those menus may be out of date. The menu I looked at was smaller and had been edited down. No matter, I had an idea of what I wanted: tacos and a papusa. There was a 3 for $4 taco deal* I was going to take advantage of and papusas are always a good idea. I ordered... and waited. In the time I waited, the tables weren't bused, a woman came in with a slightly unruly child to pick up a take out order, the TV showed various barely clothed men and women writhing about Miami Beach, and an older man entered sat down, got annoyed at the wait time, waved his hands, banged on the table and shouted 'Estoy aqui!' I just sat there. After more waiting (and more TV jiggling) my order was finally ready. When I got up to pay for it, the woman put her hands together and thanked me for my patience. My annoyance melted away then and there. Chismes is a small space, packed with seating. She was, obviously, in the weeds and doing several jobs at once. Sometimes all the mierda hits the fan at once. She acknowledged it and thanked me. Done. I wasn't going to belabor her agony. Besides, my food smelled great.

I got home and tore into my tacos. Ridiculous. So so good. Seasoned, shredded meat, cilantro and onion never tasted so good. Add in fresh lime and Chismes' thick, green hot sauce and you have a party. The papusa came with curtido (good). The texture/consistency of the papusa was a bit tough and off-putting but I don't know if that's because I ordered a Salvadoran dish at a Mexican place. It wasn't terrible but didn't top the papusas at my local fave Salvadoran spot. The curtido didn't have the vinegar-y kick I was looking for, so I just added some green sauce and kept it moving. For as tough as the papusa was, the inner beans and cheese were very good. I'd return to Chismes but I am sticking to getting my food to go. 

*Seriously: why do you pay so much for tacos. You know you're ripping yourself off, right?

mmmm...a choc-work orange, so good.  Flavors to please everyone in the family from the gourmand to the 6 year old.  

This ice cream parlor does traditional bar service in the location of the original McKenzie's Bakery location (and they've left the old neon sign earning eternal love from many New Orleanians).

Came here for an AYCE Sushi date night with the hubs a few months back.

The buliding is a bit weird in that you essentiall go into a basement but once inside it's decorated nicely and the atmosphere is inviting.

Staff were friendly and attentive on our visit.

The food was pretty good - nothing to knock your socks off.  We were both pleased with the sashimi quality given that it's AYCE on this particular visit.

We weren't able to finish our food and had to pay a small surcharge but our server graciously boxed it to go for us without even being asked.

I would come here again but I think I'd rather venture and try a different AYCE Sushi next time.

P.S. The location leaves a litlte to be desired if that kind of thing bothers you.

We finally made it to Vetri, a first for both my fianc√© and me (with the exception of a preview night for their fabulous upstairs renovations). Of course, the entire evening was absolutely wonderful. 

I'm the kind of person who checks out a menu before I go to a restaurant, and I typically know exactly what I'm going to order. At Vetri, you are presented with a menu of possibilities and asked simply to mention anything that you definitely do not want, or even that you definitely do want. Despite my Type A tendencies, I absolutely loved sitting back and letting the kitchen run the show. 

We opted for the lesser of the two wine pairings, which was still very pricey. The pairings were spot on and every wine was terrific. I was impressed. I'm sure the higher-end pairing is mind blowing. 

Course after course arrived during the evening, and everything was perfectly paced. I can't recall every single thing that I ate but every course was exciting. My favorites were the pastas, and there were lots of them. Another big standout for me was the antelope. I had no idea what to expect but I was really pumped to try something new. The meat was absolutely delicious -¬†tender and lean and super flavorful. I was pretty full by the dessert course, and I'm not a huge sweets person anyway, so I mostly focused on my dessert wine, which was great. 

As for a return visit, of course, I'd absolutely love one. However, with the cost for two topping out around the neighborhood of $600, it's going to be a while (or an unexpected financial windfall!) before it will happen again. Until then, I've got my memories!
