Solid standard Chinese. And they deliver. I ordered chicken and broccoli one weekend when I had the craving but didn't want to eat anything too heavy. Lots of tasty white meat (nothing scary), and lots of slightly crunchy broccoli (just the way I like it). The sauce wasn't too heavy and the rice was perfectly cooked. I also liked the wonton soup. Definitely interested in giving this place another shot sometime soon!

Another review that I should have updated a billion times over by now! and not just because I scored an amazing hard cover illustrated copy of Don Quixote in it's book swap drawer (which reminds me if anyone knows a good bookbinder let me know!)!

I was won over the moment that I tried the Serenitea. And I've continued to be won over with every variety of tea that I've had since. and since it has your standard flavors, a shit ton of specialty blends, and a number of bubble teas that's quite a lot.

But Tbar also has plenty of extras. It's book swap has gratuitously hooked me up with some good new reads. I have played plenty of close scrabble matches here. And I've even seen some good plays and open mic nights (hey Darnelle!). So Tbar clearly has a lot going for it!

Our tour guide Rich (look for the guy in orange shirt)was extremely knowledgeable as he took us around & pointed out murals, historic houses, areas & places.

The Independence hall tour that Free Tours by Foot does not include a tour of the inside of the famous Independence hall. 

You will have to go to the Independence hall visitor center in the morning to request the Free timed tickets in order to visit the Independence Hall. 

Or you can go online to request tickets but there's a processing fee.

This 2.5 hour long tour was very informative & gave us a nice overview of the historical points of this area. 

If you had any extra questions of places to visit, the tour guide would be happy to help you out.

I will definitely try out the other tours which Free tours by Foot offers in other cities. 

TIp: You can book their tours online on their website / thru the yelp app. 

Pro tip: bring: comfy walking shoes, water, hat, sunscreen & a good attitude.

Layla's is probably my favorite bar on Broadway. It's non-pretentious, and doesn't get *too* full, though it can get a good amount of people on the dance floor.

They don't do draft beers, only bottles. They have a decent selection though, which is nice.

There are tables along the walls, and some bar seating.

I saw the Eskimo Brothers here, and they were one of the best live acts I saw that week in Nashville.

I was only here for a few days and went to Layla's twice for drinks and live music. Couldn't help but come back a third time to pick up a t-shirt. It was the last one in my size, so the bartender just plucked it off the wall. It had a staple hole in it, cost $20, and smelled like beer, but it's probably the most authentic souvenir I brought back with me.

Wow! My lips just stop tingling from the spicy awesomeness that was the chili noodle.  Delish! We also had the Panang Curry and the fried spring rolls.  All the food was fresh and yummy.

The atmosphere was really light, airy and open.  I guess I haven't been inside this space since it was a coffee shop over a decade ago and it still had a house configuration back then.  So the renovation may not be new to this restaurant but I really like it.

The menu has a lot of variety without being too long. And they state that they will customize any dish even making stuff vegan.  The Chili Noodles normally have chicken or beef, but I got them with fried tofu, but I also could have picked soft.

It looks like they have a liquor license now since behind the bar they're was the biggest bottle of knob creek that I've ever seen. mmmm bourbon.

Also, the name is really Singha Song Thai so I'm guessing they aren't affiliated with the Singha downtown. I submitted the change to our Yelp overlords so I guess it will changed eventually.

Holla, back to Pi almost exactly one year later! Because I'm all about devout worship of the thin crust I went for that this time, although fond memories of the deep dish almost made me choose otherwise.

Glad I went for the thin crust, as it too is cornmeal and perfectly crispy. For saucy me, I got extra sauce, plus mushroom, kalamata olives and spinach. Damn, that is some good pizza! 

Damn Damn DAMN that is some good pizza!

I'm staying in the Moonrise across the street and I have a feeling I'll be looking at all of these vintage moon photos that are everywhere, but instead of moons, I'll be seeing some Pi pizzas with big smiley faces in them. Maybe it'll be *me* transposed in Gibson girl attired in the photo as well, sitting on the pizza moons, gazing up at the pizza moons with love. Falling OFF the pizza moons. Fondling the nose of a pizza moon. OK, that's kind of creepy. But hilarious. Yup, I'm creepy, hilarious and I love Pi pizza.

In fact, I am going to make certain that I dream of Pi tonight as well. 

Love this place! Can't you tell?

Now that I've been here for a few concerts, it's time for a review. I can't give it 5 stars because it is an arena. I much prefer a smaller to medium size venue when I see live shows. Lucky for me that most of the bands I see play in the small to medium-sized venues. 

There are occasions where I do have to venture into a large space to see some of my favorites though. 

The shows I've been to here are Tool, A Perfect Circle, and most recently, Florence + The Machine. 

The first thing to be said for this arena is the size of it. Yes... it's an arena so it's large. Most arenas are built for NBA teams or college basketball teams. I'm not sure of the exact reason this arena was built but it seems to have been built for the local hockey team and as a concert space. Since that seems to be the case, it's somewhere in between a medium and large arena space. I don't love it but it's okay when seeing larger acts.

This last experience here, I had to take advantage of the First Aid station. I was starting to get a headache. I went straight to Bridgestone's website, found where the First Aid room was with ease and went there to get an ibuprofen. Kudos to the arena for making it easy. 

In closing, if you love smaller acts but they grow to support a venue like this and they play there... you'll have a good time I believe. Buy the tickets and go have fun.

August 23, 2014 Saturday - 5 PM VIP Ticket

Atmosphere - 4.5 stars
Beer - 4 stars
Service - 4 stars 

Background - Thanks to Yelp I got to go to another amazing beer festival.  Thanks Michael T! 
 
Soup Box - They did not list the designated driver option at all on their website for ticket sales.  I would have loved for my wife to go but to pay for a full price ticket was pointless as she was not going to drink.  After I was there I did find out that there was an option to buy.  The other thing I did not like about the website was that they did not describe what the difference between a regular ticket and VIP was.

Atmosphere - Peppermill's Tuscany Ballroom which is a huge ball room that was the home to the event this year.   Which I found made moving from one station to the next with ease even after the place filled up with all the participants.  The only thing I disliked was the darkness, it made picture taking of the beer cans difficult and to the point I just gave up.

Beer - The can beer has really taken off for the craft beer industry.  The two biggest advantages of a can is that it prevents light from destroying the beer.  Yes light hurts the beer, just like our skin is affected, kills cells.  The other big thing is the distribution cost; beer cans are much lighter then glass.  For me I think that some cans are more artistic, the imagery is amazing.  21st Amendment Brewery is leading the way with their clever beer names with art to match.  My favorite is Brew Free! Or Die IPA.  http://21st-amendment.com/beers/brew-free/
    There were several breweries listed on the website that were not in attendance.  I was disappointed as the breweries I did noticed missing from the activities were the ones that do not sell in the Reno area.  
  The best part of the night was the accessibility of some of the brew masters.  It was great talking to them and hearing the pride they take in their work.

Service - Thanks to all the volunteers working the event helping some these small breweries pour the beers for us.

Yelp's Booth - That place was rocking with a steady group of people checking the stuff out!

Future - Beer and lots of choices that you cannot get in Reno, yes I will be back.

This was our very first meal upon arrival in New Orleans and the French Quarter. We decided we wanted to check something off the list right away and have some Po Boys. Fried shrimp Po Boys ($9.95) to be more specific. 

We went this past Friday afternoon around 4 pm. We were seated quickly and ordered the Po Boys. The service certainly left much to be desired. The young lady who was our server couldn't have been much more disinterested in being there if she tried. She very much "mailed it in".

Lackluster service aside, the food actually quite good and the portions very generous! Even the fries were pretty damn good!

The food was very enjoyable, but service does count. Based on my experience here, I would Mahony's  3 stars. I would definitely go back and hope I had a more engaging and friendly server next time.

3 stars.

It's not everyday you find yourself in New Orleans on a bayou tour. But when you do, make sure it's Cajun Encounters Tour Company. 

There's something to be said for the brave folks that tour the bayou in early August. When humidity and the ambient temperature are about the same there's only so much you can do. But making the most of the experience with a smile and good attitude will never do you wrong. 

I spent a good month researching all the things to do on our NOLA bday trip. Every day we filled it with things to do, places to be, and foods to eat. After much research I found Cajun Encounters was an absolute necessity. 

First, know that the bayou isn't anywhere near NOLA. You'll board a nice bus that will transport you about 40 minutes north/north-east of NOLA to the bayou. From there you'll wait some more. By the time you return to your hotel it will be well into the late afternoon. So expect that this will take a good chunk of your day. 

With that said, make time for this experience. I can't guarantee you'll have a similar experience to ours as every guide is unique in their presentation. But it'll be fun for sure. 

I was super pleased with our tour guide (his name escapes me) but he was a retired conservation officer. His tour was fantastic - we learned about the flora, fauna and all kinds of conservation efforts. No cheap photo ops with hot dogs on a stick here. I appreciated his natural approach to the tour! We saw plenty of gators in their natural habitat which (trust me) was more than enjoyable. 

The only thing that could have made this experience even better was if they didn't cram so many folks into the boats. We had several large people and packing 20-something guests into these tin cans (shoulder-to-shoulder) meant very little air-flow. And of course, very little opportunity to social distance. I would have paid double for half the number of people. 

Definitely take the weather into account. Bring your camera. And enjoy!

Why 5 stars? Because I already know I'll be a regular.

   ---   ---   ---

I didn't know much about Sprouts, but I read a few articles about it as they prepared to open, and I knew I'd be visiting as soon as I could. If a place near my house opens that has groceries, especially specialty and/or healthy groceries -¬†I'm going to be there really often.

My first visit was the third day of Sprouts being open. If I was claustrophobic, I may not have made it out of there alive. I don't think I've ever seen this many people in a grocery store. But I pushed through the crowd and definitely saw plenty of great stuff! Whether you're looking for specialty groceries, organic produce, or fresh meals you can simply heat up - you'll find it worth your time to fight through the new store crowds.

I ordered the italian trio sandwich and was a bit off put when I got home to see that it was on very basic wheat bread, and that it included mustard, which was not noted on the menu board. My wife ordered a panini, and I was so jealous, that I returned the next night to order one of my own.

This time, I went with the caprese panini, but I added the meat from the Italian trio. I can't recommend this combination enough - it was amazing.

I do want to point out that the sandwich ordering process seems a bit convoluted. There are little ordering sheets for when you order something custom, which is confusing and definitely seems like what you have to use for any sandwich. There are different types of these sheets, which adds to the confusion.

When the sandwich maker is putting your order together, they don't do it in front of you. They take your order, and head to the back, and out pops your sandwich a few minutes later. They did not ask me for any clarification on my order during either visit, hence the unwanted mustard and bread on my first round. Also, it took an inordinate amount of time to make my sandwich on the second night, but I'll chalk that up to it being their first week open. It was just frustrating to see 10-15 employees on the other side of the counter, but only one making sandwiches. Again, we'll chalk these issues up to the first week blues.

In the long run, the only bad thing about Sprouts opening is that I feel like there's going to be a casualty in the neighborhood. Between Publix, Whole Foods and even Abby's... can all of these survive in such a small area? I don't know, but I'm going to enjoy them all as long as I can.

Working on the Eastside of Indy, I've received b-e-a-utiful arrangements from George Thomas on birthdays or "just because" occasions.  All have been vibrant and ever-so lovely.  Now, if I have a reason to give someone flowers, George Thomas is the first place I visit.  The staff is friendly, the prices are reasonable (even with the delivery charge), and the arrangements bring smiles to everyone's face.  It's a win-win-WIN situation for me!

I had a good experience with Baileys' Range - it's a "burgers and shakes" joint that is actually trying to do quite a bit more. 

While dining with my teammates last March I started with a Bourbon Maple Sour that was delicious and a bevy of snacks and sides - the loaded fries and the Brussels sprouts were my favorite among them. Don't sleep on those sprouts - garlic and asiago were meant to be friends with those babies. 

I got the Whiskey BBQ burger - a tasty combo of smoked beef, smoked gouda, caramelized onions, whiskey barbecue sauce, and the ringer that drew me in - sweet potato chips. I was never a "potato chips on my sandwich" kind of person, but this was a great combo. 

The biggest disappoint came with my meal-ending splurge of a scoop of ice cream. The hot chocolate and marshmallow variety caught my eye, as those two elements are two of my favorite things. Unfortunately the end product was very icy and crunchy - not what I was hoping for. I come from the dairy state so maybe I'm spoiled, but for me a smooth, creamy texture is crucial in a premium ice cream. 

All in all it was a fun night and I'd return, if only to shove some more of those Brussels sprouts in my face.

Not sure if the puppies here are puppy mill puppies - but if they are that is SO WRONG on so many levels.

Our dog is a rescue dog.  We come here because of its convenient location and because they stock Eukaneba small breed senior food which is what my pug eats.

The prices are average and service is your basic disinterested and clueless minimum wage staff.

i am glad they are here though - because I needed a hew harness and they had just what I needed.

I discovered Lilly's Cafe in Yelp and Urbanspoon and am thankful I did! I've been there three times in the past two weeks and have eaten in twice (during lunch diring the week and then dinner on a Saturday night) and ordered takeout once. As an Asian-American I'm very picky about my Asian food and have to say that Lilly's Cafe has one of the best combination pho around! I also enjoyed their eggrolls (with homemade plum sauce) and crab Rangoon! Both times I dined in I had NHI as a waitress who was quick, friendly, and efficient. Also, the owner, Lilly was very professional and pleasant! I'm a regular now and will keep driving from Mid-City to the Lower Garden District for awesome Vietnamese food!

Alas, I'm ready for my Union 72 review. I've been here at least three times. That never happens, but it's so close to home, it's a different story. I've tried a good number of items on the menu.  I've finally figured out my favorite!

The sandwiches are where will get the extraordinary flavor. They mesh different flavors and they work pretty well. My favorite is the banh mi. It's not traditional by any means. It's a great fusion and I love it. I also ask for a side of Asian and Sweet barbecue sauce to dip it! I love dipping!! 

Far East is my second fave! It's with the Asian Bbq sauce. If u can't handle a little bit higher level of spicy. Ask for the kimchi on the side and test it out! 
I also tried the Conquistador, but that was the least favorite. If you like a sunny side egg on a sandwich that's your go to!

For their sides, their fries are the best! They are not too salty! Their mac and cheese is quite smokey(not my thing). Their corn on two occasions were good with the cheese, but overcooked & small kernels. If the kernels shrivel up, they r over cooked in my eyes. The fried okra is a close 2nd favorite but the ends r kinda hard. The potato is small. Half the size of your fist.

If You Are going to get brisket, get sliced so it can be moist. The chunks were dry and hard. The favorite meat of choice is pulled pork.

I do want to try the wings which seem to be a special on Tuesdays. I also want to try their ribs! 

Excited to have a new non chain spot in Wesley Chapel! Thank you for being in town!

[1016]

10/13/2019

This Fresh Market location is located in a strip mall with plenty of parking on Baltimore pike. 
 
I like coming here because I can find unique items such as whole wheat organic flour, Manchego cheese, gluten free items and Ton more of unique items.   Tons of bulk coffee and candy and olives. 

Staff was very friendly.  I picked up a ton of items including a warm
Pumpkin pie which my husband loved 

I'll definitely be back

This is Marble Slab Creamery (They Bought out Maggie Moo's) and for $2.99 your kid under 12 can get ice cream in a cup or cone with unlimited "mix ins".  My kid opted for 99 cents for a waffle cone dipped in chocolate.

Sugar overload.

Meanwhile I tasted the ice cream (Sweet Cream vs. Vanilla vs. Butter Pecan and it was "just OK".

Give me Hagen Daaz or Ben & Jerry's over this any day.
Fun taco shop with friends.  Come and get your classic favorite dishes.  Good seating for a quick bite in downtown Tucson.

This is a beautiful expansive property with a massive center of pools and hot tub features. We enjoy the Tuscan towers wirh their Italian feel and large jacuzzi tub. The 2 hand sinks keeps things clean. Their beds come with 4 comfy pillows. There is an empty fridge to use and no funny items for sale that can get charged when accidentally being bumped. A+ for the fridge.

Got to mention noteworthy bartenders that stand out in such a large establishment as this. Troy in Fireside lounge, Vanessa in Terrace lounge, Rachel in Biscotti's and Eric at Back Bar. Haven't been dissapointed by other bartenders, but the above mentioned provided  special concoctions for my whims for that day.

Foodwise. The Cafe Milano and Biscotti's serve huge portions and also offer YELP CHECK IN offers. The comfort M-F specials at Milano is always something to look forward to.

I love Priya Hot Yoga and am officially hooked. While I've enjoyed yoga in the past, I've never felt so excited to go to class and felt so good afterwards.

While I still don't have any other hot yoga classes to compare it to, I've now taken classes with several instructors and really have been enjoying my experience overall. 

A few weeks after the grand opening trial class, I came back and got the new client package. For $40, I get 30 days of unlimited yoga. It's been great because I've been able to practice with several of the instructors including Julia, Ashley and Liz.

Several classes are offered each day and it's really easy to work them into my schedule. I love the fact that classes are offered at 6am on Tuesday and Thursday! 

All of the instructors have been great and have had similar philosophies on yoga- they really encourage you to practice at your own level. The classes have been challenging but I've really been comfortable knowing my own limits and not fearing judgment. 

I'm especially enjoying the class with Julia and most of my visits to Priya have been with her as the instructor. I've found her classes to vary from week to week, but still have a consistency to them. I like that she offers corrections and pose variations without drawing from the class or overall flow. She's friendly and has a great sense of humor which makes the class even more enjoyable. And as much as the core work hurts at the time, I know I am getting a killer ab workout. 

Everyone at the studio is just so great and the environment is very welcoming. I'm also really finding myself liking the music they play and I'm definitely able to recognize some tunes. For example some Jack Johnson music was playing at class the other day. While it's not the music I'd traditionally think of for yoga, it adds an extra fun element to my experience. 

With the winter months among us, the 95 degree heated room feels absolutely amazing. I've never felt more relaxed in Savasana in my life. 

Looking forward to many good times to come at Priya Hot Yoga.

A couple of "ho-ho-holiday" tips about take-away meals and good gift ideas all in one because in addition to baked goods - and excellent English Muffins (see first review) - Certified has prepared meals and soups to go in the freezer case in the shop.  Good prepared food makes a welcome gift any time of year: think as for working parents with school age kids, parents with a new baby, neighbors who just had surgery, your host and hostess who probably don't need another bottle of wine but who can always use a frozen meal to heat and eat next week, senior aged friends and family who have trouble cooking for themselves... The opportunities to share these - and to buy them to use at home - are boundless all the time including holidays.  

That's the top line.  Details follow.

ALL THE TIME OPTIONS:  You'll find in the freezer case. (Have tried them all.)

*Certified Lasagna with beef, Italian sausage, pancetta of The Wylder recipe - this is the same family that owns that downtown area eatery (in small and large sizes to feed from 6 to 10 I think - $39 & $78)
 
* Mac n Cheese in super cheesy four-cheese style using penne (in small and large sizes to feed from 4 to 8 I think - $12 & $24) 

*Chicken Pot pies (to feed 1 or 2 with lots of tender chicken, peas, carrots, potatoes in delicious sauce and excellent crust -  $14)

*Vegetarian Enchiladas (small - 3 enchiladas fed 2 at our house- and large sizes - filling may change seasonally but our winter purchase was cubed roasted sweet potato and pintos with just enough chili kick - yummy - $12 & $24)

*Assorted 32 oz soups - we picked up Tomato Bisque (still in our freezer) and Pumpkin Curry (delicious) and also saw Potato Leek and Veg Chili in the case.

(12/27 update - Certified offered wild mushroom VEGETARIAN LASAGNA as an option on order in advance Christmas holiday menu - I ordered a couple.  A bit much cheese for us but glad we tried it.  If you enjoy super-cheesy style lasagna this is a fit for that preference.)

SPECIAL HOLIDAY MENUS 2019:   This year they offered holiday specialty take out menus for Thanksgiving and Christmas, both of which required placing orders several days in advance by email or phone and picking up orders in a specific time window on a certain day.  Convenient if you're hosting or being hosted to be able to pick up good food to go and if they expanded the pick up day and time options that would be even more swell.

FRIDAY SURPRISE I HOPE THEY'LL CONTINUE:  As "What a GREAT idea", for a couple of consecutive Fridays Certified posted on FB that they were offering rotisserie whole chicken, roasted veg and ciabatta one week (biscuits the other) as take out for $35 (+/-...the price varied).  Limited amount, pick up starting at 5:30ish.  The first week was first come, first served and they sold out quickly.  The second week they offered 'call to reserve' option for the 5:30 - 7:00 pick up window.   PS - being the "Portlandia" type I am I did ask where the chickens come from and the answer that they are Mary's organic - a very good brand - makes this all the more excellent. 

SERVICE:  Friendly, friendly, friendly.

PARKING:  A considerable challenge in the North End and in particular for people like me who need accessible parking.  (I have had MS since college days.)  So it goes.  For anyone who doesn't live walkable distance from Certified, this North End neighborhood parking is a bear.  That is what that is.  And it is what keeps me from being a regular here.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Newly opened as remodeled from a building that was once Certified upholstery and rug cleaners, this is one of the few businesses in the North End that has tried to be equally accessible for people with mobility limits. ADA met for entry the door, standard height seating availability and the loos too.  Good for them for those minimums met.  The Civil Rights law of ADA is 30 years old so they should be no surprise to a building designer.  Yet I saw a wheelchair parked outside on snowy day because path of travel when people are inside was too narrow for minimum passage required.

A NOTE ON SEATING IF YOU'RE EATING IN:  Seating at low tables is convenient for eating a bakery item or sandwich.  But it is not particularly comfortable as seats themselves are smallish round stools.  This is probably a "perch and go" even for someone of my size 2 frame and maybe really not comfy for larger folks to be a "linger and nosh" kind of place for that reason.  But it is a pleasant space with lots of light and sparkling clean decor.  For me it will be all about the take away I think.

Listen. As healthy as we all try to be, there's nothing wrong with waking up on a Sunday morning craving a freshly-baked donut. It happens to me quite a bit (probably way more than it should), and when the feeling hits, Donut Drive-In is where I go. I can confidently say that they have the best donuts anywhere in St. Louis, hands down. 

Heads up, the parking lot is a little small and can be interesting to navigate if it's busy inside. That brings me to my next point, which is that the inside of Donut Drive-In is smaller than you can imagine. As in, if there are more than a handful of people inside you'll have to wait out the door small. Which is something I'll gladly do, but I would've liked knowing that before my first visit. Third note: bring cash. You won't need a lot... if you're buying for less than three or so people, five bucks should cover it. On my most recent visit I had a chocolate long John (oh my God, drool-worthy) and a vanila custard donut for a grand total of $1.89. I felt like I was stealing. 

The donuts here just taste fresh and have the perfect texture and consistency... and I love seeing all the action behind the counter! The young girls that work the register are as sweet as can be, too. Just a wonderful, tiny, thriving local business. I'm a huge fan and there's a big chance you'll spot me if you stop in on a Sunday morning. Hooray for donuts!

Great indoor/outdoor flea market and artist space, they have all kinds of things including clothing, jewelry, masks, antiques, signs, plaques, metal and wood work, furniture- it's a collective space showcasing multiple collectors and artists items. I found lots of unique items, but ended up taking home a spooky looking fella made with natural materials found in the Amazon. He's gonna make a great Halloween decoration :) Staff was sweet, prices were fairly reasonable.

Overall I feel that Philadelphia Weekly is far superior to City Paper when it comes to our weekly papers. I love both, I know plenty of people who have been involved with both, and both definitely have their strong points and imperfections. But when it comes down to it, City Paper is something that I tend to flip through, whereas I actually tend to stop and read a lot more things in PW. it really knows how to draw you in.
I also feel that PW does a better job of sponsoring events. They were one of the major backers for this things like Popped Fest and realizePhiladelphia. and you can't go wrong with what they've done with Rittenhouse Square's Concerts in The Park series over the past few years.
City Paper does have the better entertainment section by far though.

Whoa. I don't understand all of the low reviews for this TJ Maxx!

This is a fairly new store- I think they built this new one at the same time that they built the new TJ Maxx on the Westbank. I stopped in here with a friend who was looking for some luggage that wouldn't break the bank. She ended up finding a nice piece of luggage that was perfect and well priced.

I browsed the women's clothing and housewares, but didn't find anything that I absolutely needed, but I found that they had a nice selection of seasonal clothing and a lot of good deals. We went in the middle of a weekday, so there weren't a lot of people in the store and the check out was easy. The cashiers were nice and we had no issues.

I'd return if I found myself in the area and in the need of a deal.

We went in for a bite to eat and see what the hype was about.  The rolls were very expensive, but they were also very tasty.  The chef was generous with the fish, afterall it was $16 per roll.  Sushi grade fish is in the range of $20-$30 per pound, so no matter how you cut it, sushi is going to be expensive.  

Each roll was lightly seasoned with vinaigrette and a touch of sesame oil to bring out the natural flavor of sushi grade fish.  Too many restaurants in Santa Barbara overwhelmed their rolls with cheap fillers such as mayo and cucumbers, but not here.  The SB roll was the best roll I had in Santa Barbara.  It was covered in huge satisfying pieces of albacore that was flavorful, light, and not over seasoned.

I feel bad leaving two stars for this place because my lunch partner recommended it, but I wasn't impressed. 

The restaurant was nearly empty at lunchtime on Friday, which seemed odd. There was one server working and he was running around the whole time so we didn't see him very often. We had to call out for water refills and flag him down for the check. 

I ordered a special roll with spicy tuna inside and torched salmon outside, plus a king crab roll. It's pretty unlike me to not plow through my sushi, leaving no trace, but I actually didn't even finish my rolls. They were fine, but not exceptional. My friend had a few of the larger special rolls and the pieces were cut so large she actually ended up choking on one -¬†thankfully, she was fine.  

The final nail in the coffin was when I went to wash my hands in the restroom and saw how filthy it was. I will not be returning, or ordering from this establishment, again.

We have been to their other location on Victorian Avenue in Sparks several times and always enjoyed it. Because of that we purchased their gift cards at Costco.

We were in the area and thought we would stop here for lunch. We arrived shortly after they opened at 11am and it was not busy at all. ¬†

We were seated right away and our drink orders were taken. We were also given chips and salsa while we looked at the menu.

My wife chose the fajitas and I chose the macho burrito which I've had before and enjoyed.

The interior is very clean and stylish with large wooden slab tables and a nice bar area which looked to have slot machines. We also noticed what looked like a large space for bigger groups.

Our food arrived and looked great. Several other people were also seated during our time there and it was starting to get busy by the time we left.

We both enjoyed our meals and would recommend to others. This location would be a great idea for dinner and a movie as well due to its close proximity to the IMAX theater.

Wow this place has nearly totally collapsed from what it used to be at its prime.  This used to be a really amazing mall and had lots of fantastic stores.  Unfortunately this place has been on hard times for a long while now.  I never go to this mall anymore and I rarely did before as its waaay out in the suburbs.  I was really shocked at how deserted its gotten when I made my last visit out here.  Back in its prime it did have a lot of hot ladies dressed to impress which it certainly doesn't seem to have anymore but I guess the same can be said of the bygone glory days of Canal Street...

Love this place. Delicious coffee and tasty baked goods.

I tried the Lavender Latte and Almond Maple Latte, both were great but the Lavender was better, as the Almond Maple was a bit too sweet.

They had a nice selection of baked good, I got the Chocolate Bread Pudding. They hooked me up and gave me a big slice. Unless everyone is special and get's the hook up. Anyways, this was some great and perfectly soft pudding and made me happy. 

The atmosphere here is cool and I like the indoor and outdoor seating options.

This Federal Donuts is located inside Whole Food's, in their new food court, also has been referred to as "restaurant row". 

While I was shopping at this Whole Foods, I decided to try Federal Donuts. I came around 1:30 pm. There was no line but had to wait as 2 employees were busy filling an order for the woman waiting near the register. After that, this male employee took my order. I decided to get:

Strawberry Lavender, $1.75- This was served warm and had a nice flavor of sugar strawberry. The lavender was subtle.

Peach Ricotta, $2.75- I was curious as to what this would taste like and decided to order this. This donut has a glaze of peach and the middle is filled with ricotta. The peach is a little too sweet. Please note that this donut was not served warm and is considered a fancy donut, thus a higher price. I did not know this since there was no sign on the display case to indicate these are fancy donuts (I don't eat donuts often). 
---------------------------
(Total= $4.50, tax included)

I was disappointed that the donuts fell apart too easily and made for a mess. They just didn't hold up, compared to other donuts that I have had before. 

I was also very disappointed with my visit when I came here. After I made my order, I gave the employee my credit card and he gave me a pager. After waiting 14 minutes with no buzzing or lights on the pager, my husband walked back up to the register to ask the employee where our order was. He apologized and said he completely forgot about us. Please note that after my order, there was only one other person who was waiting for their chicken sandwich. Then the place was empty. The 3 employees behind the counter were just talking to each other. This employee began placing our donuts in a bag and said he would give us extra as an apology for making us wait. I didn't know why it took so long and just assumed they making my donut fresh or something. 

I don't get what all the hype is all about with Federal Donuts. Is it because they sell chicken too? 

This place really was just average for me. But with the long wait time (if my husband had not inquired, then who knows how long we would have waited. And we were sitting at a table right in front of the register so the employee must have known we were there waiting...). I would not come back here. 

Please note that this location only takes credit and debit cards are payment.

Two Words: Later Vons

I came in last night around midnight.  As soon as I stepped inside, I paused. I shouted, "WHAT!" A worker came by to laugh at me and to inform me that there is no more VONS. I must have stood there for about a minute in shock.... 

Anyway, the feel is much different than Vons. This reminds me of a Ralphs back in the late 80s(I wasn't born then, but hey I've seen pictures ;). 

I agree with my buddy, Justin. It is barren, and I was sad to see that the McConnell's fridge is gone.... :'(  It actually seems like there is more room. They have their own deli with Haggens baked goods, soup, etc.  I actually made a few rounds and I do think that their prices are similar. I spoke to a customer and she believes that their prices are similar, but they do not have deals.  

I believe Haggen has a lot of potential and I am curious as to what they have to offer in the future. 

Maybe they should have a grand opening party ;)

For some odd reason, I don't find myself at Chatham Tap as much as I should. 

They have a TON of TVs, so if you're looking for some sport to watch, I'm sure they'll have it there. 

Reasons I love this place: 
1- The outside patio in the warmer months. it's along the Cultural Trail, so you get to watch passersby and enjoy the sunshine/weather. 
2- The large amount of beers. They've got tons - try something new! 
3- The staff are always diverse and very friendly. I haven't had any issues. 
4- The food is pretty good. I can't say, personally, it's anything more than normal bar food for vegetarians, but it's still pretty good and hits the spot when you're looking for something greasy!

This small wine bar, tucked away beside larger bars and businesses in the north downtown area, is an Edmonton gem.

A massive selection of wines, and a very friendly staff that will help you pick a wine to suit your tastes, or challenge you to step outside your wine boundaries a bit!

Food here was deelish, too. The cheese plate was a great treat, although I wish 4&V's menu was more specific about the ingredients in each dish. I was unaware that the cheese plate would come with kiwi fruit, which I'm mega-allergic to. I couldn't enjoy any of the cheeses next to that delicious but devilish fruit! Still a very enjoyable outing overall!

This really is the true definition of as good as it gets, especially if you get lucky enough to land a slot during the bi-annual spa week specials. Do not let the small entrance fool you, there is a full spa with 3 lounges, multiple massage rooms and more all awaiting. 

I came here as a Girls Spa Day hearing from the rave reviews a few friends had in a prior experience. The customer service really is exceptional from the moment that you step in the door which is what really gives them 5+ stars. We were walked into the main lounge area and offered cranberry sangria and snacks....which was sweet, but we brought about 5 bottles of liquor and truffles of our own....so we were ready to rock!

They gave us all robes, which normally I do not think is a big deal, but after reading another reviewer be so appauled about not getting one, I kinda feel extra special now. lol

We were in the back private lounge for most of our time, so when half of our group was getting massages the other half was loading up on wine. They had soothing music playing in what looked like your grandmother living room. I unfortunately do not relax with waterfall music, it makes me want to pee, so we changed it to a regular station and they were cool with it. 

My massuese Ellis and I had a great convo as he worked on my therapuetic massage with refreshing citrus oil. It was fabulously relaxing and ended it with a hot towel and off to the lounge for more wine!

I highly recommend doing this anytime, but Spa Week is a complete steal! We had a 1 hr massage and the  works for a measely $50. Otherwise, please get here, for a Girls Night, Bachelorette Party or a couples retreat...just make sure you get here!

Finally i was able to try the cheese curds at the tall ships festival. Wow these little battered balls of cheese really are amazing! A little pricey at $12 but i get it. I tried the sriracha mayo and honestly should have skipped it. 

My only complaint is that I like my food HOT! By the time i arrived it looks like the crowds were on their way out and there may have been sometime between them coming out of the fryer and me recieving my order.

Please share - one order is too much even for two people. I got a slight stomach ache from over indulging but it was worth it :).

What an overall enjoyable experience. The kind of parade experience where, if you pick the right spot, you get a full view of everything without battling the masses. It's in the Marigny, which is definitely my favorite place to watch a parade. 

So, no surprise here that you're going to see the likes of Star Wars, Star Trek, and other science fiction characters that MAY, I ain't gonna lie, have gone over my head. But if you're a fan of such things, you will adore it. There are throws, sure, not of the quality and quantity of the big parades, and some of them are adult-oriented (I got some pills, lol), other things like roses and toys. The party in the Marigny surrounding this parade is also not to be missed. You can tell the folks in this parade are diehards and put a lot of time into their costumes and floats. Nothing like certain other krewes where some masked members just want to be dicks and throw bags of beads at people's heads. Here we've got nice, creative people just coming together to celebrate their nerdly love for sci fi (I'm a nerd too, I don't judge) in a parade is a wonderful thing to witness.

Pro Tip: Catch it on St. Claude for better viewing, or if you prefer to be amongst the partying crowd around Franklin, that's a great option, too.

I would say Tucson in general does not do Asian food very well.  Mae's Chinese food is about as good as it gets around these parts.  

We started with waters and egg rolls.  The appetizers arrived quickly and were like lava on the inside!  It was clear that all of the dishes are made-to-order.  For our entrees we had the orange chicken and Mongolian beef, our go-to selections.  The orange chicken had a great crunchy batter and was covered in just the right amount of orange syrup.  The beef was oddly tender, almost like tofu.  It had a bit of spice and laid on a bed of crispy white noodles.  

Service was overall quick and very friendly.  Our sever (possibly Mae herself?) even boxed our food for us.

We had an appetizer and two generously sized entrees with rice for under $30!  Not a bad deal!  This restaurant is definitely one of the better Chinese restaurants in Tucson.

Lobster Haven Shanty and Market needs to rename themselves Lobster HEAVEN because this place is phenomenal for seafood lovers! This place looks and feels like a little Maine lobster shack -- not too fancy on the outside, but incredibly delicious food on the inside.

Lobster Haven is located in a non-descript little strip mall along W. Hillsborough Avenue in Oldsmar. You'll find the restaurant / seafood market in between the shopping center with the Super Target (Montague Street) and the shopping center with the Lowes, Publix, and Cracker Barrel (Race Track Road). It's best to use your GPS the first time you visit as you can easily sail by without spotting the sign.

I remember this store from years ago when they were in a small standalone building directly across the street from the Oldsmar Flea Market. They've now moved south just a bit, and set up shop at this new location.

Lobster Haven is both a seafood market as well as a seafood restaurant, and it is a great place to find fresh shellfish and seafood in the NW corner of Hillsborough County. You'll find live Maine lobsters, shrimp, clams, mussels, oysters, crawfish, and crab (Dungeness, Snow, King, and Stone). Sometimes they also have blue crabs and garlic crabs, but you should call ahead to double check. You'll also find fresh and frozen seafood ready to toss on the grill. The lobster is flown in LIVE from Maine, and you can walk over to the tanks to see the happy little crustaceans scrambling around for your viewing pleasure.

Now in addition to that, Lobster Haven is an outstanding little seafood restaurant with Lobster and Clam Chowda (New England style, of course!), crab cakes, smoked fish spread, shrimp cocktail, shrimp baskets, peel 'n eat shrimp, Ahi tuna, scallops, salmon, fish tacos.........and then we have the lobster...... *insert choirs of singing angels here*

You'll find lobster rolls made with huge chunks of lobster meat in a top-split bun, lobster (or crab) wraps, Lazy Man Lobster (hand picked lobster meat spread out on top of crackers), and then you've got your choice of 4 different styles of Lobster Haven Shanty Buckets o' Lobster with ever-increasing amounts of shellfish to go along with your freshly-steamed lobster, ear of corn, seasoned red potatoes, and a fluffy Parker House roll.

Now by freshly-steamed lobster, I mean that the guy came out of the kitchen, picked the lobster out of the tank, walked it back into the kitchen, and a bit later out came my Bucket of Steamed Shellfish.

I had the Silver Bucket which was a steamed 1 1/2 pound Maine lobster, Middle neck clams, saut√©ed Black Mussels, Steamed Shrimp and Crawfish along with the corn, potatoes, and a roll. I forced myself to start the meal with a cup of their amazing lobster chowder which had big chunks of potatoes and lobster in a thick & creamy New England style stock.

You can buy everything live and take it home to cook it, or you can kick back with a nice cold beer and let them do the work for you. Make it a point to go visit these folks soon!!!

Formerly the Red Lion Resort, then until 6 months ago, the Fess Parker Resort, Hilton has licensed from the estate the original Daniel Boone as a partnership where so many instances of Fess still remain.

It has a grand entrance and extravagant lobby that features a $29 breakfast buffet (it's good), coffee caf√©, and Fess Parker wine tasting room (reservations required).  The best feature is the location -- right across the street for the beach.  If you lucky enough to have that view from your room.

The rooms are decorated nicely with modern furnishings, but it feels more like an apartment than ritzy hotel resort.  No getting around that, as the property design is sprawling 2 story buildings.  The $407/night price-tag got me a beach view, which I appreciated, but was far from elegant.

Anthro is definitely one of my all time favorite stores EVER! Their entire collection of home decor, accessories, candles and clothes is so thoughtfully curated with a certain bohemian-esque, naturally chic, trendy, yet classic aesthetic. 

This location also carries bridal! And oh my goodness it is all so gorgeous! I adored my wedding dress but dang, I wish they had their BHLDN label available back then! Every dress is super romantic and feminine. They also have bridal lingere, swimsuits, veils, shoes and headbands. I always find myself drifting to this section when I'm shopping here. They politely ask me if I need help and I get embarrassed as I'm an old wifey at this point and quickly walk away with flushed cheeks. Brides, run here!

I truly cherish every piece I purchase here. All so unique and definitely more special pieces versus run of the mill department store items that everyone will have. You just feel a little extra special wearing something form Anthro. I still have the 1st dress I ever purchased here and that was for the first wedding I attended with my husband, then BF 10 years ago! I'm definitely not one to hold onto clothes that long, but I still love it as much as the day I bought it. 

Anthro has also been know to collaborate with designers from all over the world! They partnered up with one of my favorites Mara Hoffman. You never what's around the corner....

Their housewares are possibly my favorite! Ordinary items absolutely beautifully designed. Kitchen Goods, planters, candles, linen napkins, throw pillows, comforters. It's all so lovely! Anything from here makes a truly lovely gift. In fact, I hit Anthro up every holiday season! 

Prices can be a bit much but really, quality is key. 

Customer service is top notch. You will be greeted the second you walk through the door. They will start fitting rooms for you so you don't have to carry your goods around. They communicate via walkie and will contact someone on another floor to help you find what you're looking for. They also offer personal shopping! 

As a former visual merchandiser for years I can certainly appreciate not only the ever changing amazing window displays, but the carefully merchandised products, as well as the seasonal displays! They are on top of everything! I mean I most recently visited on a Sunday then two days later and everything was fresh and re-merchandised. 

This building alone is absolutely STUNNING! For those who remember way back to the 90's this was the flagship location of Urban Outfitters, who is a sister to Anthro. I used to sneak down here in middle school and blow my entire allowance on one awesome item! From the entrance to the decorated elevator, to the spiral staircase, to the faux fireplaces, hanging mobile and stained glass Tiffany-esque rotunda! Wow! That space alone is worthy of a visit. Being situated across from beautiful Rittenhouse Square Park isn't too shabby either! If you're from out of town and have never been to this gorgeous location, I highly recommend it!

Anthro, along with Free People, Urban Outfitters, BHLDN, and Terrain are all owned by the same company which goes by URBN. Their headquarters are right here in Philly! I absolutely LOVE this! In the last few years they moved offices from Columbus Blvd to a beautiful space in the Naval Yard. Their company is very laid back, allowing their employees to even bring along pups to work! So cool! I can certainly get behind a company like that!

*If they don't have something you're looking for in stock they will ship it to your house free of charge. 

*Sign up for their emails. They run great sales around the holidays and their catalogs make for great coffee table browsing material.

Cool new bar in st Pete where Crowley's used to be. Decorated like a mellow Miami bar from back in the day. Full liquor bar and plenty of craft taps. Awesome specials such as $3 mimosas, $4 bloody Mary's, $3 bud light on the weekend. Plenty of TVs so you can catch your sporting events. Kylie was our awesome bartender and was super friendly! Will be back!!

My family got all dysfunctional after my grandma passed away in 2008, so Thanksgiving and Christmas really circled the drain.  Eventually, my older brother gave up and started heading to his in-laws for the holidays.  For me, sometimes I spend the time with La Chica's fam or I will go eat some dinner at a restaurant with my introvert mother.  Well, in 2016 introverts united the latter scenario played out this year.  

I checked the interwebs for restaurants that were open, but they were all chains.  Denny's, IHOP, Ruby Tuesday, Capital Grille and Flemmings.  Of these, Capital Grille was the most intriguing.  They were running a turkey day special that sounded on point, but momski wasn't feeling the fancy vibes.  She just wanted some grub in a down-to-earth atmosphere.  At that moment, I had an idea.  Why not drive down Main Street and see if anything is open?  She was game, so off we went.  

Enter Bascetti's.

The place is quaint, and it was busy.  We had an advantage though--a party of two.  Walked right in and got a table.  Ordered up a cinnamon-free white sangria, some bread that was served in a mug and the antipasto misto appetizer.  Everything was perfect.  

For dinner, I wanted the shrimp scampi, but their shrimps aren't local, so I went with plan B, the chicken parm.  I could see from the Yelp pics that it is served on a bed of linguine and red sauce, so I altered that to a side of Alfredo linguine.  How was it?  I am certain I've never had such a thick, tender and juicy chicken breast.  For real, it was cooked perfectly.  I'm convinced that It couldn't have been better.  Unfortunately, I found the linguine to be a little weak in the knees.  It lacked that pungent, sharp, cheesy oomph that I expect in an Alfredo sauce.  It wasn't bad though, just a little bland.

My moms ordered the bolognese pappardelle, and it was a weeener for sure!  Big-ass bowl of ribbon pasta mixed up with thick, hearty Italian meat sauce.  What kind of meat, you ask?  Veal and pork, that's what kind.  

Next was dessert, and since it was Thanksgiving, we had to do at least one traditional thing.  You guessed it, pumpkin pie and whipped cream.  Probably wasn't the best pumpkin pie ever, but I was just happy to be eating the stuff.  It's one of those tasty food things that always makes me wonder why it's glory is limited to one day per year.

The staff was extremely attentive and friendly.  My only beef was that they were really grabby.  One guy snatched up our loaf of half-eaten bread, which I definitely wanted to keep.  Another woman kept taking our flatware, and a third employee grabbed my mom's white Russian before she got the last 2 or 3 sips from it.  None of that is worth docking a star though.

So yeah, in summary, this place is legit.  The 3 star Yelp rating shouldn't steer anyone reading this away.  Both of our dinners were, as the young kids say, on fleek.  I'm going 4 star for round 1, but I'm not ruling out the possibility of a 5 star on a future visit.

Conventions are the only reason I stop in Indianapolis these days, so I know the ICC fairly well. 

Convention centres run from backwater warehouses to impressive glass and steel complexes. Though always large and fairly modern, the ICC has undergone a transformation in the past few years. This behemoth sprawls over several city blocks in the heart of downtown, connected by skybridges and underground walkways to hotels, parking, and a 30+ store shopping mall. Make sure to review the many diagrams and maps posted around the convention hall to find your way, otherwise it's easy to end up roaming in circles.

Clean spaces, technological features like wi-fi, and a wide, airy design are definite pluses. The central atrium and its wings are brightly lit with skylights. The rooms range in size from smaller meeting rooms like you'd find in a hotel to the massive exhibit halls used for everything from doctor's meetings to one of the largest gaming conventions in North America. Staff is well-equipped to help direct people. 

On the downside, navigation can be difficult, there are too few numbers of couches or chairs outside the meeting rooms -- especially during busy conventions, when it can be impossible to find a spot to sit except the floor -- and the washrooms leave a lot to be desired. The ladies' rooms feel old and inadequately serviced. During the peak of the season, be advised locker space and other security measures are pretty limited to non-existent.

Onsite eating options include pizza, hot dogs, sandwiches, cafe food, and coffee. However, going two blocks in any direction opens up wider options for an expected upcharge, but you can find bagels, upper-end steak (Ruth Chris), bar fare (Champps) or Chinese (PF Chang's) all without too much of a walk. The ICC is well-served by public transportation, though I advise anyone to park their car at an adjacent lot and walk. It's otherwise very expensive.

Maybe be I'm just a straight up meat eater... I had some time to kill around noon today, so I figured that I'd head to this place after work to see what has everyone so excited about the tofu hoagie.... I eat a lot of Vietnamese food each month. It's something that I just tried about two years ago and love it. But have never gone with the tofu hoagie...It was pretty good and tasty.. It's something that I'd have again.. The store itself is a store that I wish that I had in my neighborhood.. They had a variety of drinks and snacks that you just don't find at your local convenience store.. The service made a good first impression... It's a nice change from the convenience store norm these days, which has no  problem having the register counter full of blunts and wrappers, legal pipes, condoms, and "energy" (stamina) pills... All of the shit that most people don't want to have in reach of their kids, when there should be candy and gum there for them to reach for.... Hell, even Wawa has stooped to selling blunts....
Good job Fu-Wah... If I didn't live across the bridge, I'd be a customer of yours daily...

I never knew this place existed until I tried it one Tuesday afternoon for lunch with my co-worker. The place is small with only a couple of tables but has a very warm, inviting feeling to it with the stoves burning brightly behind the counters.  They have lots to choose from so we ordered:

- Tandoori chicken flatbread ($6.33) - comes with tandoori chicken, cilantro, cheese, lettuce and tomato. Baked fresh and was very light/refreshing. Not the biggest but it hits the spot for lunch.
- Beef donair ($6.33) - my buddy had this one. Pretty much same toppings as mine except for beef donair meat.
- 2x Zaatar deluxe ($3.95 each) - we both tried out their zaatar which was a Lebanese style wrap with tomatoes, cucumbers, mint and labneh ($1.25 extra). It was an interesting taste.

Overall, cool place on the northside. I didn't realize that they are the ones that make the pita bread you see in the grocery stores! Will have to try their baklava and fatayer next time I drop by.

As a vegetarian for a few years now, I can't say I ever crave the taste of meat, including burgers. 

Burger Study offers the Beyond Beef veggie burger that "bleeds" (from the use of beets) and was created for omnivores to give it a shot in the hopes that it'll convince them to not eat as much meat. I was excited, at first, to see that this place carried this. 

Now that I've tried it, I hope that Burger Study will look into creating their own veggie burger, in addition to the Beyond Beef patty that they currently use. I feel that the Beyond Beef burger option was an "easy way out" for them. Put it on the grill and it's done....not much effort involved. It tastes eerily a lot like meat and the bleeding part is just weird for me.

I tried a few of the sides while dining here (all of which come separate). They were all a-okay but the portions are way too small for the price tag that comes along with them. I honestly don't remember which apps we tried as nothing left a major mark for me.

My biggest issue with Burger Study: the price tag + the small portion sizes just don't add up. I always create two meals when I dine out. I ate all of my burger (and sampled a few apps) and was still hungry.

My favorite part of the dining experience was the bourbon milkshake.... now THAT was yummy and worth the price tag. They bring out the milkshake and then pour the bourbon into the milkshake in front of you. Pretty neat. 

In terms of decor and interior: it could use some work. It takes the restaurant name fairly seriously. Books around and some random photos and that's about it. 

Burger Study has the potential to be a great place; however, at the time of this writing, there are other, better burger spots around Indy that I'd recommend checking out before this place, especially for you vegetarians/vegans.

FINALLY I can say I've been to Nada.  It took me long enough!

I echo many other reviews in saying that the space is beautiful.  It's so swanky and vibrant inside in both parts of the restaurant.  As for the food, I think you could have quite the taco party with all of the options Nada has.  I've had bites of the Hongos and Senor Mu Shu, and I'd recommend both to anyone.  There's also the lunchtime Taco Lunch Box, which includes a side and a doughnut.  I say include the Santa Fe cowboy beans if you're going to go that route.

My experience revealed that I need to return to Nada with an army of friends because I have a feeling it will be nada problem to handle a large group.

This hotel is amazing.  Straight out of my dream home board on pinterest.  The decor is so funky and chic.  Bright colors and intense modern designs throughout the entire hotel.  They supply complementary iced tea and fruit flavored water in the lobby.  My friends and I had to do a taste test of each, delicious!  The lobby is beautiful!  Fancy couches, you feel like royalty upon entering.  I will admit, I didn't stay here but I did plenty of exploring and the ballrooms are gorgeous and huge!  This hotel is connected to the Red Owl bar which is convenient.  Next time I am in Philly I am definitely staying here!  There's also a rooftop deck lounge, awesome!

Disclaimer: I only recommend dining in at this restaurant. Takeout incurs additional charges (.25) per container, now posted at the register. In addition they've raised prices on the most popular dishes as well. Read my previous reviews to see my issues with takeout here.

While prices are rising, portion sizes are still enormous. The lunch special is now $9.00 but you get a magnificent bowl of food. I get the shrimp and grilled pork bowl with cold vermicelli noods (had to say it). Their fish sauce dressing is a little sweeter than I'm used to so I add a little fish sauce from the table to salt it up. They've got the best chili oil too, which I apply liberally to each bite! MMM! 

You really can't go wrong with this dish or anything on this menu. Just plan to enjoy it there. I highly suggest the Dry Noodle Combination and Bahn Xeo when they serve it.

I think I have a mild obsession with La Colombe. Anytime I find that they are where I am visiting, I have to go there almost every day and then buy a bunch of cold brew to come home with me.

I first discovered them in SoHo in NYC and loved their delicious coffee in a no-nonsense style. They don't do almond or soy here because they believe in the integrity of the original latte, cappuccino or what have you. I like this.

In my almost week long excursion out in Philliy, I was able to visit all of their three locations. I even met one of the co-owners and boasted that I had visited all the locations at the time (they had a few in NYC, all the ones in Philly, and one in Chicago ...) only to find out that they had just opened a location in ... Seoul. Yes. Korea. 

Wot?

Well ... at least I can finally say I have been to ALL the La Colombes in North America! The co-owner is also a huge skater and owns his own skating company so I got an awesome skateboard deck out of it. Love this place!

Vegetarian local chain in Nashville serving up yummy Caribbean inspired dishes.

I have mad respect for vegetarians because I think it is so much better for our bodies and our planet to eat this way.  I am proud of Nashville for having such a chain.  

Though the dishes are geared vegetarian you can order meat.  The day I went their soup of the day was a hearty type of 3 bean that was outstanding.  

This place is affordable, healthy, and has a nice menu.  It is worth checking out.

U-Haul rental only review. 
My U-Haul experience yesterday began poorly. The prior day I went to my local gas station and reserved a 10 footer for the next day. The young employee who helped me there was very nice and assured me that it would be waiting for me. But early in the morning I received a call from U-Haul saying my reservation was ready, but at another location that was much farther from my house and the major highway I needed to drive on. I was not happy with the change but needed to utilize the truck so I journeyed deep into the heart of Trenton to pick it up. 

This business has a large semi secured lot in an industrial area,  it seemed pretty safe so I felt somewhat better. When I entered I was greeted by William, who processed my reservation and diffused my annoyance, first with a personal antidote, and then by knocking my mileage rate from .99 to .79 to make up for having to drive out of my way. I wasn't expecting that but it actually made the total cost less than had I picked it up in the burbs. Now that is customer service. And it serves to illustrate that  good CS can be demonstrated in many situations, provided you have happy and well trained employees to give it. 

The checkin and checkout process moved quickly and details were well explained( even on the trip back to return it, with a different employee ) The truck itself was ok, no hand truck but I had my own. Also no ramp on this model but it was suitable for my task. It drove well and even though the suspension was like a bucking bronco, the seat was comfy and cushioned the ups and downs. I came away feeling that U-Haul as a company did pretty well by notifying me early and providing another location to get what I needed, and that by having employees like William, they do care about CS.

Attended a seminar here and the event facility itself was decent although the temperature was either too hot or too cold.  The hotel itself seemed rather cramped and a bit disorganized in its layout (bathrooms on alternate floors, towel carts in the middle of practically every hallway).  The attached parking lot is a nightmare, though.  It is 5 stories of narrow spots and narrower navigation lanes, which basically turns the experience into a nightmare on Elm St.  The location is nice (right in Midtown) but the venue is almost subpar.

We had a fine experience here with our (then) 3 year old - but it was about a year ago so maybe since then it has gone downhill?  We had burgers and chicken sandwiches and my daughter's kiddie meal came in a paper car.  She loved it.

We had a nice lunch here and would go back.

Interesting place with enough that made it "interesting" that I can't see a four star rating.  No bathroom for customers.  None of the variety of Thai pepper offerings (typically dried, ground, in oil and as a sauce) but they did offer a homemade version that was pretty good.  No limes available with their Thai dishes.  

I had the Pad Thai and thought it was a bit strange.  I opted for the vege option and it came out with a visible amount of broth on the plate...thus making me nervous that I would wear some spatter.  The flavor was good but not what I was expecting from a Pad Thai and I just could not get over the amount of liquid on the plate which made me incredibly nervous about wearing the dish.  

I am glad I tried the place but really can't see myself going back there anytime soon.

had high expectations
every thread, post, review 
i read before our mini santa barbara getaway
mentioned cn'c
i wasn't very impressed
the service wasn't very friendly
and for some reason i was under the impression
that there would be food
but there wasn't
my mistake
the wine/beer flights were okay
but nothing special

We try to stay at a different place every time we visit NOLA. So while booking our last trip H decided we should try Hotel Monteleone. We arrived late afternoon and upon entering the lobby I felt like I took a step back in time. There is a gorgeous antique Grandfather Clock in the middle of the lobby (which by today's standards is a bit small but oh so elegant!) There was another couple in front of us so I sat with the luggage while H checked us in which did not take long. We were directed to a set of elevators. I asked H which floor we were on & breathed a sigh of relief when it wasn't 7 or 14 (these floors boast the most ghost encounter with 14 having the most activity). Like the lobby & elevator our room was small but beautiful. Gorgeous drapes, bedding, wallpaper, furnishings....and the bathroom which was tiny but had quality fixtures, towels & toiletries. I immediately went to the bed to check the pillows out. I spied them in the lobby gift shop on the way to the elevator & just knew they would be heaven. And they were! My sleep experience in the bed was wonderful. The mattress was very comfortable, linens soft and pillows cloudy-ecstasy! 

Understated elegance would describe this place to a tee. The staff were courteous,exceedingly nice & unobtrusive. To date the best hotel experience in the French Quarter and the next time we visit NOLA it will be very hard not to repeat my hotel experience here.

They say the French Quarter starts in the lobby of Hotel Monteleone. And what a nice welcome this place is & a great start your adventure.

This bar was recommend by a local. If you like the tiki bar feel this place reminds me of Trader's Vic from the vibe of the place and the drinks. The staff was nice, however the only option you really have is drinks. 

If you want food, they have a menu for the Mexican restaurant downstairs. You have the ability to order food and pick it up from the bar. There was no music or entertainment, just drinks. 

If you're looking for an intimate place to go, this is your place. However, I was looking for more of a fun vibe with music and food options. I may have been looking for that Trader's Vic vibe with food, music, and drinks. Definitely not a bad place if you're looking for the intimate Tiki environment. It might get rowdy later, I was day drinking...

After we parked around South Grand, my crew decided to go to here instead of King of I because it was a block closer, but I don't think we'll be lazy bums again after learning our lessons from Basil Spice.

Food: A few hits and a lot of misses
-Appetizers: the Satay Gai was good
-My friends ordered the generic stuff like simple Pad Thai/Curry/Stir Fry and they weren't pleased.  I tasted one of their noodles dish and it completely lacked flavor as well as moisture.  I can usually tolerate a lot of food but that was just gross.
-I decided to venture out of my comfort zone (aka ordering Pad Thai at every Thai place I go to).  I got the Rahd Na (stir fried baby corns, broccoli, and carrots in soybean gravy sauce. Served over stir fried rice noodles with black soy sauce), and the flavor was just right and made my daily intake of veggies go down easy.
-Desserts: SKIP THE DESSERTS.

Seriously, SKIP THE DESSERTS!
I was looking forward to my Khao-Nuea Sunka-Ya (steamed sweet sticky rice with coconut milk topped with Thai egg custard) and Glua Hom Sa-Bai (fried banana crepe) because they sounded really good in descriptions and I usually have good experiences with Thai desserts.

However, I was super disappointed when my dessert plates came up.  I felt like a kid who was expecting a giant/delicious black forest cake but got a tiny gross muffin instead.

The fried banana crepe was literally just banana in egg roll wrap with some honey on top, nothing special at all.

The steamed sweet sticky rice dish was sweet in a disgusting way, and the egg custard on the side looked like a pile of poo and tasted like play-do.


Service:
-Nice people, but also VERY SLOW people.  Our server was also a bit forgetful and forgot about the chicken dumplings we ordered so now we'll never know what they taste like since we don't plan on going back again.

Scenario: You've put down earnest money on your first home and said home is broken into just a few weeks shy of closing day. Said intruders aren't just here to steal, they're here to be assholes. They steal vessel sinks on the top floor and let that running water run, run, run throughout the walls, down to the first floor onto those precious wood floors that were installed just a few days before. 

What do you do?
Well, you can start with thanking God that Kate Fry is on your side.

I ended up backing out of the deal and purchasing a different home but that's not what this review is about. This review is about the force that is Kate Fry with Everhart Studio Real Estate. This was all such a learning process for me and thanks to her, I was able to have it all broken down in Layman's terms for easier digestion. Kate and I hit it off and I think that's due in large part to her no-nonsense tactics that for a lack of better terms "get shit done" in a professional and prompt manner. I know I was definitely on the bottom of her totem pole as far as dinero to spend goes, but she never treated me any differently for it. She even took the time to meet with me in person to go through the mortgage documents step by step.

Kate is especially knowledgeable in the downtown and historical home markets. Which, fortunately for me, my final home purchase fell into both categories. 

Consider this my second "thank you" note if you see this, Kate!

We came for the Boo-tastic event. The place was nicely decorated. We arrived at 12-noon and we were the first ones in. Lots of candy and cupcakes. I think may people decided to stay in due to the rain but it was a great afternoon. We had the course to ourselves and played at our leisure. The light rain didn't hamper our spirits! boo :)  Overall, great effort on City Putt to add another family friendly Halloween event.

*** 3.5 stars ***

Super long wait in line (even though the line was not that long it moved at a snail's pace) and for food once seated (another 20 - 30 minutes - yikes). The food is probably four stars but not worth the price and the wait. Not a huge menu and nothing stands out as particularly unique (just your standard brunch fare). Probably would not come back.

The Pros.

The restaurant decor & overall eye appeal was
beautiful.  Table settings with flowers in a vase, glass water decanters & mason jars to drink out of.  The view from the 2nd floor looking down on both the kitchen & the busy street corner was great for former cook slash tourist enjoying that beautiful spring day.  

I was easy amused by the menu for the colas, as 
Baileys offers a large variety of locally made beverages.  We ordered the Million Dollar Orange made with real cane sugar from just across the river in Illinois. We also tried a cold one from Fitz's root beer bottled in St. Louis (my favorite this meal) & and a cold long time Classic Coke a in a bottle from Mexico.

The food was fun, and tasted as good as it looked.  
They have a wide variety of unique toppings paired with different ingredients making for some great burger combinations.  The toppings range from guacamole to Camembert cheese. They offer pretzel & gluten free buns.  A few things that peeked my taste bud's intrest were Fontina cheese, the pablano sour cream, the tomato jam and a few other ingredients.   

I like the option to build your own burger or substitute pork, chicken, bison, lamb or a veggie burger instead of beef on your burger.  I was kinda surprised they didn't have a turkey burger option though. House made ketchup, nice touch

Service was great. Our server was very helpful & I love it when a server is knowledgeable of the menu.  Last but not least.... the house made pickles were addictive. Zesty pickles with a little bit of heat, definitely one of a kind.  My taste buds will hold that memory tight for years 

The cons

The burgers were a little small for 8-10 dollars.  Which is fine, I enjoyed every bite. We were so full and hopped up on all the sugar from the pop we didn't have any room to explore the shake menu.

We really enjoyed our lunch at Baileys and we all agreed that if we lived in town this would not have been our only visit.  We were so into the burger battle my son & I decided to have our own. I got the Carolina with pulled pork, coleslaw and BBQ sauce.  He got the ABC Burger with roasted (A)pples, (B)acon & (C)amembert cheese.  So be sure to check out my photos & vote for your favorite.

If you love the casino life, you will probably love the Peppermill. I am not a fan by any stretch, so for me, everything looks gaudy and over-designed and looks like it would've been luxurious in the 80s, but not in 2016. Or like the designer is Donald Trump's interior designer. I'm in the Tuscany Tower. When the furniture is lush, the walls (not wallpaper, not paint, but texturized walls) AND fixtures, AND bedding, AND lamps, AND everything in eyesight does not need to be lush, too. Too too much, and not at all contemporary. I get that the theme is Italy. I've been to Italy. It doesn't look like this.

The casino furniture also looks like it hasn't been updated since the 80s. That said, nothing is in disrepair. Everything is functional. When I got to my room, I was actually about to call down to the front desk to see if I was in the right room, because I have two TVs (one in the bathroom), two sinks in the bathroom, two shower heads in the shower, and a jacuzzi tub for two. Apparently, all rooms are similar. Some others on this trip with me noted that they have a jacuzzi SPA that could accommodate four in the MIDDLE of their room. This is very 80s, Peppermill! No one thinks that's cool anymore. Well, no one outside of the casino life and under 50, anyway.

I was surprised that the rooms didn't come with refrigerator or microwave. It's a resort, so I understand that they make their money on incidentals. So they have a mini fridge and snack bar in each room to keep you from bringing in your own stuff. Further, as a resort, all of the restaurants are grossly overpriced. Again, you're paying for the convenience of having everything right here. And it seems a lot of the food is the same regardless of where you're eating, especially the desserts.

Once my eyes recovered from bleeding and my wallet stopped screaming, I can say that the Peppermill is very accommodating. The fitness center is more than adequate, complete with numerous treadmills, elliptical trainers, free weights, weight machines, a studio for calisthenics, a steam room... and they give free bottled water.

All of the staff is super nice and accommodating from front desk to housekeeping to the many restaurants. They understand service.

If you want to get married, they even have two wedding chapels here. Gotta love Nevada.

This is just a shout out for Sabrina and her wonderful team of dedicated therapists. Last Friday they threw a Christmas party for their clients! There were tables of yummy food and wine and soft drinks. They also had live music for us to enjoy. The place was packed with happy people, enjoying good food and music. Thank you all, it was a great party!

Went here to check out the world-famous cannolis--the line can be long sometimes, but everything moves so efficiently.

Definitely a must stop at the Reading Market as they are very tasty and only $3 a pop.

This place opens in the evenings when the block off Bourbon Street for the night partying. I don't know what other people talking about but 10.95 (before taxes) for a gyro, fries, and a drink is a rip off.  The food is decent. It was somewhat cold despite the fact that it was wrapped in aluminum foil. Obviously, this hole in the wall is not so hole in the wall when the place is very clean and adorned with flat screen TVs. They must be doing well with all their drunk patrons.

Franco's Tomato Pies on Main Street, Yardley, PA, has been around for a long while doing mostly take out pizzas from their small shop right next door to Bagel Train. There are only two booths in house, so they don't get much dine in business. Still, I was there around 2:30 in the afternoon earlier this week, and wanted carbs to help finish my long day into night schedule. 

I asked if I could eat there, and they were totally accommodating. I ordered penne aglio olio with saut√©ed spinach in a lunch portion, and they knew what to do.
