After about 5 minutes I was called to the counter to pick up a side salad and bread basket. The greens were plentiful, with tomato wedges, iceberg, red onion, cukes and sliced carrots. Actually, took me by surprise. The four slices of Italian loaf were fresh and ready for dipping into balsamic vinaigrette and the garlicy broth to come at the bottom of the pasta bowl. 

A few minutes later, the white soup bowl of pasta was on the counter calling my name. I walked over to get it, and enjoyed the hot garlic breath of the dish wafting into my face. Smelled so good. The taste was about right, too. Plenty of pencil points under a nice load of soft spinach. The garlic could have been more golden, but no biggie.

The only difficulty I confronted was the large pond of garlic water under the pasta. No matter how long I waited to allow the water to drain from each forkful, it was still dripping onto my shirt, pants and tie. I was careful, but all will be visiting the cleaners to get the stains out. My bad for not bringing a long bib. 

The store needed a strong cleaning, too. The floor looked grimy from lack of care, and the kitchen area visible from the counter failed the visual inspection test. Looks like the boss doesn't stop in often enough.

There's often a line but I don't mind the wait.  There's an army of teens working inside so the order do come out fairly fast once you placed it.  

Their regular ice cream includes strawberry, vanilla and chocolate.  You can also order from a few dozen of specialty flavors, like pina colada, blueberries, espresso, etc.  They also have twirls which is like Dairy Queen's Blizzard.  They have several cones to choose from.

I love their ice cream, it's very creamy and smooth.  I usually like to pay 50 cents more for the specialty flavor, there are so many to pick from I always have a hard time deciding.  However, I don't know if it's the lack of consistency with the staff about how much syrup to add.  One time my espresso is really flavorful, another time I can hardly tell the pina coloda in mine.

We had a great first experience with Carmel Dads Club with boys soccer, and I can see us coming back to play soccer and other sports with CDC again. 

The communication is excellent, and I always felt like I knew what was going on throughout the season. A couple of times, we had to reach out to the commissioner with questions, and they always got back to us very quickly.

The coaches for all Carmel Dads Club sports are volunteers, and many of them are parents of kids who are on the teams. We have nothing but great things to say about the volunteer coaches. They went above and beyond, and they were very supportive and not super pushy. We joined Carmel Dads Club because we wanted a fun, recreational experience for our kid that wasn't too competitive, and that's what we got. 

Carmel Dads Club uses Shelborne Fields for soccer games. Head's up: If you're at Shelborne Fields during game time and you want to buy a snack at the snack bar, be sure to bring cash! No credit or debit is accepted.

I love Daredevil's beer -- it's one of my go-to choices when I want a great local Indy beer. I also love that I can enjoy their beer outside on the patio on a nice day, with some tasty food. 

We visited on a Saturday after the lunch rush, and we were able to get a table outdoors with an umbrella. They have several tables for outdoor seating, but they also have indoor seating if that's what you want. They require masks be worn indoors (and outdoors when you're not eating). When we visited, it was a nice day and they had the doors open, so there was a lot of fresh air circulating indoors.

Mostly the food here is burgers and fries, and we ordered the Chi-Town Loaded Frittes, which was a big basket of fries topped with shaved roast beef, beer cheese, horseradish sauce, and bits of carrots and celery. At first, I was puzzled as to why they included the carrots and celery, but as I ate, I came to the conclusion that they were going with a theme here: roast beef and vegetables! It was like a pot roast dinner on top of fries. That's actually pretty clever. 

So we split the loaded fries because they were a lot of food, and we also got salads: the Daredevil Chop (a chopped salad) and the Wedge Romaine. Be aware that the wedge is made of romaine lettuce, not iceberg! It's a different take on the classic.

The beer here is killer, but they also have several ciders to choose from, as well as wine by the glass and by the bottle.

And lastly but not leastly: They serve their water with rabbit turd ice! That crunchy, pellet-like ice that is the best ice.

Came here based on the reviews and was staying in a hotel just a few short blocks away, also: Korean BBQ!

The place was surprisingly almost empty for 9pm on a Friday night. Good for us, as we could get fast service. 

Seated in the back corner the place wasn't much on decorum but the food looked good. Surprising beers served, and an extensive menu. The chicken wings were spicy and the kalbi bbq was okay.

Only qualms - service could be a little better, drinks took a very long time to be served (especially considering almost no one was there). Also we were seated next to the karaoke room, which doesn't keep the sound out very well.

All in all not a bad place, but could use some improvements and it may be a bit pricy for the quality of food.

I have wanted to check this place out for quite some time. During my recent self-proclaimed "Discover Carmel" adventures, I decided it was finally time to pull the trigger. The location in the Arts & Design District gave me an extra excuse to see what this man made fantasy of a "small town" village was all about. 

On first hearing TeaBuds Brewing I have to admit that my first thought was: "oh! Tea-infused beer? Brilliant! Yes!" Not that the actual tea brewing, bubble teas and sweets was a let down - just not what I expected upon first hearing the name. Thanks to the reviews of fellow Yelpers I didn't walk in blindly. Instead, I found a spot at the window, tapped into their fast wifi and tipped back a coconut green tea with tapioca. Mmmm one of the best I have ever had. The ordering process allows you to pick a base tea, followed by flavors and tapioca/boba/pearls. 

My review would be lacking if I didn't mention the vast selection of tasty sweets and quiches. Think red velvet cookies, scones, etc. I fought the urge knowing that I was about to head to a gut-punching spin class, but next time, next time, dear reader...

I liked it at a 3.5 stars since I got myself a hook up. 

We came here on a whim right before heading back home from a mini vacation in Reno. I wasn't really feeling all the cafes around town and I wasn't really excited for brunch, but I opted in to the Buffet because right outside on their menu, in the tiny font that it was, my eyes zoomed in on the CHORIZO. 

By the time I got up to the tv menu, it already shifted to a different page, but I already decided that we're eating at The Buffet.  

It was a Wednesday morning (borded line 1130), so we got to pay the breakfast price of 8.99 per person, drinks included ALL NON ALCOHOLIC, for breakfast. On coincidence, we stayed late enough (about half an hour in) for them to start changing from brunch to LUNCH! It was two meals for the price of one, and a cheaper on at that. LOL, so if you're feeling lunch food but lost enough at the tables and slots and trying to get a good deal, that's one way to hit up this buffet. I wasn't even trying to do it on purpose, but it just happened. 

The waitress was such a troll. I was so used to that Vegas buffet, so no matter the time or the day for an extra little bit, we get unlimited mimosas, but NAH. It doesn't work like that here in Reno, CA. It's only on Sundays and you pay a hefty price for it, so I stuck with OJ instead. 

The food at The Buffet was decent. Lots of bread choices, the omlet station closes really early, and chorizo with cheesy potatoes are the win. They have your classic make your salads, fruits, sausage and polish kelbias, amongst a bunch of other varieties that I can't name off the top of my head. But as for breakfast, it's an extensive combination. When lunch rolled along, you had your chinese and your mexican choices and some other american choices. It was a pretty decent amount of food difference for each meal, it wasn't like they kept what they had out for breakfast the same thing for lunch. 

Then comes the gelato station- which didn't taste like gelato. Melted, slighty frozen yogurt, but the portions were huge and not your typical flavors. There's also giant marble pound cake- which was dry and different pies on display.

I do most of my shopping at Costco, but occasionally I go to Kmart for that one thing, and every single time I leave feeling exasperated.  It is not at all surprising that Sears/Kmart are in big trouble financially.  The shopping center is confusing and could really use a few stop signs here and there to improve traffic flows and safety.  The store is disorganized and not well lit.  You often find an item with no price tag anywhere.  Was it suppose to be here or was this lonely object randomly placed here by employees or shoppers?  Who knows?  There are a lot of stuff on shelves/racks in the middle of the aisles. There is no logic in how the items are organized.   Its like a thrift shop, the dollar store, or a garage sale.   The lines are long and the cashiers move like molasses.  Just think of the efficiency you see at Costco, and now picture the exact opposite happening at Kmart.  

The so call shop your way reward system is just more trouble than it is worth.  If you have credit in the account, It is not automatically credited toward your purchase.  You have to ask everytime and you have to input a pin number just to use it.  Anyone remember that?  I don't think so since no sane individual would regularly subject herself to the Kmart shopping experience.  

Once, I even had a cashier who specifically ask me if I want to know how much is in my rewards account.  She then looked it up and told me the number, something like 15 cents.  When I looked at my receipt later, the credit was not applied to my purchase.  Well, why the hell did you go through all that trouble if it is not going toward my purchase?  Oh yeah, she would need the stupid pin number to use it.  Along with the question of "would you like me to see how much is in your account?", this particularly friendly cashier also had a repertoire of other questionnaires.  "Would you like the receipt printed or emailed?", "Would you like just the receipt or the receipt with all the coupons?", "Would you like to donate to St. Jude?", "Would you like to apply for a credit card?", "Would you like this in a bag?"...Gahh, maybe that's why the line moves like molasses.

For dimsum outside of Center City's Chinatown...AWESOME!

This is closer to my house then driving to center city, and I truly can appreciate that. It seats a decent amount of people (~50) and although I've only gone on weekends at lunch time, the place is pretty packed all the time. The patrons are mainly chinese, and you'll hear the chinese chatter around you all the time mixed with some english. The servers pushing the dim sum cart speak limited english but there is always the art of pointing or calling over the owner/manager who speaks english well. 

This is the type of establishment that only gives you tea, and water upon request. Service is fast and efficient, and the food served is hot and fresh. The dimsum they have is an OK selection, I've been to ones that have worse and better, but for what they do serve, I believe the quality is pretty good, esp since this strip of asian businesses is located in a unusual place in northeast philly. 

The parking is always kinda rough, but I've never had to look for more than 10 mins before something popped up. Other than that, the standard noodle dishes are traditional and not fakey american. I love dry (no gravy) chicken chow fun. They do a good job here on the noodles in general, probably have tried 5 different varieties and never been disappointed.

Def somewhere to check out if you live nearby and dont like going to the city for some authentic chinese food/dim sum. It's cured some of my homecooked cravings from my childhood while living away from home, so I will continue to be a patron.

Really good food and great Iced Coffee - pus decent service (but it was really hot in there this last time we went for lunch.

The Chicken over broken rice (or banh) is great and the Chinese broccoli  in garlic sauce was crispy and tender and cooked to perfection.

And you can get flaming rum drinks, too - though we never do.

Love Vietnam for a quick comforting meal.

Penang is a Malaysian place in Chinatown, and part of a chain.

The decor was unusual, there were metal fixtures in the ceiling serving a purely ornamental function. The restaurant was divided into two sections, a ground floor and slightly elevated platform. I had a window seat with a lovely view (of the street - this is Philadelphia, after all).

Service (Ha) was attentive, they came by to check to see if we had ordered and filled our water glasses repeatedly. The wait staff was ever-present, delivered food quickly, didn't mind taking pictures, and even walked over when I gave a thumbs-up sign (which was surprising).

The penang poh piah (steamed Malaysian spring roll stuffed with jicama, fried tofu, eggs and bean sprouts) was light and sweet. The Mee Siam (stir-fried rice noodles with tofu, shrimp and bean sporuts in a tangy sweet (they say "spicy") Thai chili sauce, sprinkled with ground peanuts and sliced hard boiled eggs on the side) was fine, too. Not terribly expensive, and credit cards are accepted now (minimum purchase of $12).

Noise level was acceptable, though I had to strain somewhat to hear my fellow diner (she's soft-spoken, so that didn't help). Worth a visit if you've never been.

UPDATE: February 22, 2008 - went here with a large, raucous party - food was delicious - management and service was patient with our group, considering how drunkenly rowdy many of our group was... also, the interior has changed since the last time I was here, and renovations are still happening.

Where else can you get mouthwatering Indonesian served with a smile? This eatery offers a bright and colorful space, modest, but with room to spare.

Their menu's full of affordable entrees, including noodles, fried rice, and curries, all in shareable portions. Flat rice noodles (kweitaw goreng; N8 on the menu) are pan-fried yet moist, made even more flavorful by mixing in red chilies from the condiment rack. The Medan-style chicken soup (R15) is soothing, sporting a curry-like coconut broth, plus a side of shrimp crackers and sweet sauce. For best results, pair the soup with a plate of house-style fried rice (R3; nasi goreng), served with an egg on top.

Thanks to low tabs, their cash-only policy isn't much of an issue.
Fancy place, nice decor, good food, unassuming location.

No anchovies is a staple pit stop on game day. Order beer by the pitcher and all the pizza! The classics are my favorite, their veggie pizza is pretty good too. You can wrong with a giant slice of pie.

My favorite planet fitness that's worth the extra 20 mins of driving. It's right outside of NE Philadelphia. This location is filled of friendly staff. It's very clean and you don't have people who hog machines at this location. I go in, get my workout done and leave. They have a lot of machines to choose from, and I especially love the circuit machines. You can work out for 39-45 mins and work out your entire body! This location beats any of the locations in Philadelphia.
Love the fact that I pay only 20 dollars a month and I get to bring a guest with me every time to the gym. I also save on drinks and can buy them for half off compared to the other members who pay 10 dollars a month. I also can utilize the tanning beds and massage chairs as much as I want to. Overall I'm glad I joined planet fitness and I am happy with my results and weight loss since joining.

I took my daughter today for toddler time. As you can imagine the crowd was mostly toddlers, moms, and a few dad's here and there. 

My toddler had a great time and I will definitely take her again. As someone has already stated the more people you bring the more fun you will have. We made the best of it but next time will definitely bring along some people. 

To describe the experience when  you walk in through the doors and on the left are the registers where you pay. I was instructed to sign the waiver as I hadn't already. There are about 4 or 5 computers to the left of the registers where you do this takes about 5 minutes.  I then paid ($5 per toddler) I received stickers one more me and one for my daughter.Mine said "pads only" I was confused until I went to the trampoline area. Also. Paid $1 for each pair of socks but they are reusable. Before heading to trampolines there is a quick orientation on the bleachers to the right of the registers. Lol! My daughter tried jumping but mostly just had fun toddling around. After a little over 30 minutes she was exhausted.

Overall great experience with all of the staff and the venue. I want to come back for their fitness classes. Check out their website for more info!

One of the busiest places on a Friday night in Reno that you find in the summer.  A spot for everyone and any one- all ages and families.  Although it was my understanding this year you aren't allowed to bring dogs, but I did see plenty there. So be aware they maybe enforcing that more as summer goes on. Also you are not allowed to bring in any alcohol- they sell it there.   Bring lawn chairs and/or a blanket and stake your area in the very large park.

There are up to 20 food trucks and small tent vendors that offer BBQ, burgers, schnitzel, bah mi, and desserts.  So one should go home hungry.  I prefer to go right at 5 when it opens to beat the longer lines than form around 6-6:30 and so my favorite spots don't run out of the item I want.

I do wish the organizers would space the trucks out just a little more so the lines don't meld together and the walk way would be more open.  

Over by the train is a small stage set up with a different music act each week.

It's a nice venue to enjoy various foods and hang out with friends on a Friday night

The Stones River Greenway is a great paved trail for anyone biking, walking or running. I saw a lot of pets here since the Bell Road trailhead off of Stewart's Ferry Pike also has the Stones River Dog Park. There are restrooms (not just port-a-potties!) right by the parking lot. The walkway is paved and starts right at the foot of the J. Percy Priest Dam. The greenway winds under I-40 and once you get away from that noise it becomes very peaceful and nice. I could see the Stones River from the majority of the path which made for nice scenery. The greenway connects to the Shelby Bottoms Greenway, which makes it accessible from different trailheads as well. Although it's not as convenient for me as other greenways in Nashville I still think it's very nice here and if I lived a bit closer I'd be over here often!

I've now been twice here to dinner and can say that Earnest is a stylish restaurant to celebrate an occasion or have a nicer meal or maybe just have drinks and an appetizer at their bar in the back of the restaurant. I love the space more than anything because it just has a great ambiance. Service has always been good and I have had good dining experiences. The first dinner I had was fabulous. It was a vegan chickpea curry and the flavors were spot on, paired with a Brussels sprouts dish that was delicious. Since they will rotate their menu items a bit I didn't see the curry on the menu the next time I returned. Second time we got a smoked tuna dip as an appetizer which we both enjoyed. For our entrees my boyfriend got the Korean fried chicken and I got the grilled halibut. He said the chicken was pretty good although he loves spicy so he wanted more of a kick. I thought my entree was tasty paired with the green chimmichuri sauce on top but I wasn't sold on the tomato farro that was underneath the fish. The dishes were all visually appealing but the second visit didn't wow as much. Overall I think this is a nice place and I'd love to come back for a cocktail sometime as well. Highlights for me are service and ambiance.

I am a loyal customer of a coffee shop near Three Brothers Coffee and I was convinced that I needn't go anywhere else. However, TBC  makes me want to be a new regular patron! I saw all the awesome reviews and I thought (somewhat guiltily) that I should try it out. The bottom line is that the ambiance, food/drinks and staff are all on point here. If feel obliged to give your business to the same regular place I urge you to try something new here!  

Three Brothers Coffee have the same owners as the next door Cumberland Transit, specializing in outdoor apparel/gear. I like supporting places that fuel my love of the outdoors so TBC melds well with that. Looking around the cafe, it is nicely decorated and has a hip/modern vibe with the artwork that is displayed. 

I ordered a Golden Axe ($5.25) which is one of their seasonal drinks. I asked the barista if it was better hot or cold and she said she liked it both ways so I got it hot. The Golden Axe is a Vietnamese inspired iced americano, brewed with a coconut-ginger syrup and topped with a coconut sweet cream. It is only slightly sweet but has an usual depth of flavors. Really unique and great drink! 

They have a case with freshly baked goods and when I saw they had goodies from Dozen Bakery I knew I had to get something. I am more of a savory breakfast eater so I got the ham and cheese croissant ($4.50). This was a big croissant and I tried to eat it as slowly as possible to enjoy it but it still disappeared. 

A couple of minor weaker areas of this cafe. Prices were too high for my liking. I didn't like spending $9.75 on breakfast when I felt like it was a dollar more expensive for each item than it should be. Parking can be tough if the rear lot is full. There are a few metered spots outside the front as well. 

Overall, a quality cafe with many boasting rights. I can imagine this being a treat once in a while for me as I did enjoy it.

Don't let roadside appearances fool you. This fish shack serves great tasting fresh caught fish, at decent prices. The lines are long and the parking lot full on the weekends. So call ahead if you just want carry out. Otherwise plan to wait maybe 10 minutes in line, and 10 more minutes for them to cook your food fresh to order. Then you can sit in one of the many picnic tables outside and eat there, or in your car, or take it home. 

I would say this is a small hidden secret with great food, but the secret is already out, and all the locals know how to find this off the beaten path place. The food, service, portion size, taste, and set up is all great. I like this place and eat here often.

Changing your name does not automatically improve your food.  Why work insists on holding company lunches here is beyond me...  See my review for the Italian Bistro as this restaurant is not worth repeating myself.

Great place to grab a cold draft of your favorite brew and something to eat. This is attached to the Drury Hotel which makes it convenient if staying here.... although the Drury has a free evening happy hour! Great place for Jaye's retirement party!

1st Saturdays holds THE RITUAL! Its a fun club playing goth club music and I danced myself crazy.

The venue has a couple of areas to sit, talk, drink, admire and dance. One can explore and make new friends.

I like that their mixed drinks contain alcohol in them. They make a tasty Negroni complete with a square ice cube. Good selection of Nevada and Cali beers.

I come here for the chicken. 
It's tasty and it's cheap. 
I sometimes get the mojo pork 
I love the rice and black beans. 
 
I've never been inside 
So I can't comment on the decor. 
But the cheap and tasty chicken
Is what I come back for.

This Starbucks is not a great location if you come with someone else (or more).  There are only about 4 tables inside and they are all pretty small.  There are a couple tables outside, but in the summer, who wants to sit outside!  There are only a couple of big chairs that you can lounge at in the front.  However, even though there are not many tables, I have never had a problem getting one (although a couple times I snagged the last one).  There is even a bar that you can sit at and watch the baristas make the coffee (which I find a little creepy, but would be great if you're friends with the baristas and feel like sitting and chatting).  

The baristas are really friendly.  No matter who is working here, I always hear them chatting and laughing.  They are pretty quick too.  Since this is a small Starbucks there never seems to be a long line.  

What is kind of funny is that parking here is the easiest, since it shares a lot with Publix and a few other stores.  We need to switch this parking lot with some of the busier Starbucks locations!

There is no drive through at this Starbucks.

Meh.
You get what you pay for and they do go crazy with the Kewpie Mayo here - so either avoid rolls with mayo or ask for sauces on the side.

I had seen the place (walked by) and read the other yelp reviews - but for $8 (2 maki - you can get 3 for $12) I figured I'd give it a shot.

Service was icy-cold at first (one lady was kinda mean - she was prepping a table for a large party that was not there yet and clearly did not want to stop to help another table) but then my "real" server showed up and was very sweet. Vibe is kinda icy too - with colored LEDlights that change color and rock-hard banquettes that are straight up & down and not that comfortable to sit at.  Water was brought instantly (YAY!) and green tea (which I had to ask for) was free.

I ordered a yellowtail scallion roll (had decent yellowtail but hardly any scallion in it) and a roll with salmon and grilled onions (loaded with mayo blobs on top which I scraped off - seriously, at least 3-4 tsp. of mayo.  Eew).  It was also supposed to have masago but there was NOE in there - and when I asked the (sweet) girl about it she said they don;t include masago on the lunch special.

These people are certainly cost consious - as the lettuce & dressing salad indicated (no tomato, no nothin').

I am in absolutely NO HURRY to come back here - yet - oddly enough - I ran into a friend here with another aquaintance and the LOVE it here.

Meh. Meh. Meeeeeeh.

Sorry.

Doma and Vics cost more - but are sooooo much better.

Nope.
You have to go to the cashier and ask for help. There's almost no one in the store to help customers. Not sure where they are...Be patient
A hotel so charming, I wish I could put it in my bag and take it home with me.

Staying in the Gulch and heard this place was good. Home football game today, so of course it's going to be busy. Dropped by around 10:40am on a Sunday and waited in line awhile to check in. When we got to the host stand, we were told 1 hr 15 min wait for a party of 2. We put our name in. The host was very kind and said we could actually text back and forth with him, regarding any questions or changes etc. 
Nearby, we grabbed a couple Lime scooters and toured around for an hour. When we came back, we waited a short while and then a text came to say our table was ready. It was 12:00. 
We stood by the sign that says wait here when your table is ready and we were greeted and seated within seconds. 
Our table was outside; beware the bird crap. It was on the chairs, but it was dried. But that was our sign that birds may be an issue. 
Our server was super nice. He told us some funny dad jokes and made some recommendations. We started with waters, the cold brew and a dirty London fog, which was delicious. The burrata and fig appetizer was large enough to be shared among four people
 They had differing levels of toast on their bread- some very toasted and some minimally toasted. I think this was on purpose and I appreciate it. Some people like crunchier, some like softer! The burrata was a small serving but there was a TON of prosciutto, fig jam and arugula on the plate. I did wish for a little more cheese and blue cheese crumble. Just as we were finishing up, our plate was decorated with fresh bird crap from above. Yuck. Good thing we were pretty much done with that plate. 
For breakfast, we should have shared. The hodgepodge hash was a huge plate and we added an extra egg. I think it's chicken sausage pieces? But there's a lot going on there and it was hearty and good. The mushroom omelette was full of cheese and mushrooms.  Pretty standard. We did appreciate we could get egg whites for that entree.  We kept an eye on the birds above while we ate, which is bit annoying. I'd like to eat without supervising. Next time I'll wait longer for an indoor table. 
Everything was great with breakfast except two things- we were not asked which side we wanted with the omelette so I guess the default is fruit, which we didn't want, we wanted the potatoes. I wanted a biscuit with a side of gravy, but instead of charging the biscuit and gravy as an added side to the omelette, we were charged the actual biscuit with jam /honey entree plus a side of gravy. Obviously that made more money for the restaurant, but it did not have to be ticketed that way. The biscuit was crunchy on the edges and soft in the middle. The country gravy was thick and delicious. Lots of large pieces of sausage inside. Yum. 
In the end, I asked for the check and two salted caramels to go. Our server brought the check but forgot the caramels. When prompted, he apologized and brought back two caramels, no charge. So that sorta makes up for the above issues. The caramels are delicious, btw. They're individually wrapped too, so you can take them to go very easily. 
Outside there are no TVs. I'm not sure about inside? So don't bank in catching the game while you eat. Inside, the line for the restroom was LONG. Plan accordingly. 
They have a little bakery and coffee shop inside, with store merchandise for sale as well. You can place to go orders, which take about 20 min. If you don't wanna wait for a table. 
There is a parking lot across the street from them, but you gotta pay to park. I'd eat here again, but not on a busy day. I'd prefer to be inside, safe from the bird crap.

I am rating the Hutton Hotel based off of my experiences with them from an event planning perspective.

Sometimes, I wonder if it is normal to spend as much time at a hotel that is based out of your own city because I am ALWAYS at the Hutton. I was just involved in a fundraiser event there last weekend, will be there all this week to host some out-of-town co-workers, and am also co-producing another large-scale event there on Thursday evening. Maybe I should just forgo my home in East Nashville and just live in a suite on the 10th floor?
How very Chateau Marmont of me.

Part of the reason that event planners such as myself like to host events at the Hutton Hotel is because they are just THAT good. Seriously.
The location is central and close to everything. The staff is always friendly and the service is excellent. I also love the chic' interior design and always refer all of my out-of-town guests to book here. 

Their Director Of Events J. Curtis Hinton is very patient and offers up fantastic solutions for your event. You may utilize/book their conference rooms or ballrooms for virtually any size event.

If you're looking for me this week, you know where to find me!

Such a letdown. I had been wanting to try Undrgrnd for at least a few months now and finally found them last week at the Manayunk StrEAT festival. Unfortunately, since we got to the event late (thanks for that, SEPTA) we also got to the truck late. The line was cut off right in front of us after we had waited for several minutes.

Not giving up, I located their truck at today's Flight Market. Again, since I ate first, the line was quite long. Maybe this is just a thing at food truck festivals? It was the longest line of my day, though. When I [finally] reached the front, I paid my $4, waited some more, and alas, was handed a French Toast and a Captain Cranky.

My first thought was that they were smaller than anticipated -- especially for that price tag. Still, I was excited, happily shot a photo, and bit into the French Toast.

Aaaand all I could taste was grease. I understand they had just come out of the fryer, but... what? It did not taste like French Toast in the slightest bit, which was a bummer.

Next up, the Captain Cranky had a strawberry glaze and captain crunch on it. I told my friend that the topping was the best part. This one was otherwise just as greasy.

I realize they were likely overwhelmed by the number of people wanting their donuts, but I do wish this had been a better experience. If I ever stumble upon them in the city, I'll give them a second try, but I certainly won't go out of my way to wait in a crazy long line for them again.

"Asian food" for non-asians...seriously.

From the trendy logo to the electronic screens displaying the menu to the white peach tea in silk bags and absolute lack of chinese characters, this place screams "unauthentic". 

The first time I came here, I just ordered the green tea. It was around $2. They have a decent selection but green was one of my favorites. Their tea is all organic. The infuser is made of silk which isn't necessary and the tea didn't taste like green tea. The next time I went, I decided to try their food. I ordered the sweet and sour crispy chicken with white rice. The food arrived in a reasonable amount of time and didn't taste too bad, however the price was too much and the food wasn't authentic.

The atmosphere was great. Everything seemed rather clean.

The service was ok. The food arrived in a few minutes.

In short: the food, though unauthentic, was edible. The tea was disappointing. The price was too high. I won't be back.

I've given this Rouse's location several chances to impress me like their stores on Baronne and Tchoupitoulas consistently do, but it continues to fall short.  It's fine for the basics, but if the groceries you're "makin" include anything remotely gourmet, head to the CBD or Uptown.  No grass-fed beef, here!  

Even the customer service is in a different league.  You're not likely to be greeted with the familiar, "Welcome to Rouse's" here, nor will you be offered the great paper bags with handles you've come to expect from the other locations.  They may, or may not have them (depends on the day), but they'll default to the crappy plastic bags that you get at lessor grocery stores.  

What gives, Rouse's?  If I wanted mediocre, I'd go to Winn Dixie.  I expect more, based on the shopping experience that i know you're capable of delivering.

This mission has been in Santa Barbara since 1786. Has beautiful grounds gardens activities tours as well as a gift shop of course. It has been a landmark here for over 200 years & I would suggest coming and seeing the beautiful architecture landscape and views if you come to Santa Barbara.

A cool park situated in the Pinelands. I might even be persuaded to go close to 5 stars if not for the fees. The $2 per person beach fee is not bad to be honest, but I'm not sure why there needs to be launch fees and others. Canoe and kayak rental is a plus, but again at higher than normal rates for a small lake. Snack bar was priced as you might have expected too. But really, just pack your own and enjoy the fresh air.

We walked a part of the free trail that skirts around the lake. Cabins are located here and at $50 a night seem like an inexpensive family overnight trip. These are situated overlooking a smaller body of water, there are grills outside and a small kitchen as well. Showers were available on the swimming beach, not sure if in cabins. I will definitely return this summer for more piney fun.

We stayed for two nights and had a pleasant stay. The beds were comfy with a nice soft feel, and the TV and AC worked well. The staff here are great!  The gentleman at the breakfast counter was really friendly serving us quickly and doing it with a big smile.

The only problem we had was that the fan in the bathroom was super loud, rattling like crazy.

Why 5 stars? Because I can't believe it took me so long to visit.

   ---   ---   ---

I love ice cream and I live nearby. I've driven all over Tampa Bay to visit various highly rated ice cream shops. But for some reason, I just have never once found myself at Tanya & Matt's until now. I feel like I've done myself a great disservice! 

I was incredibly stoked about the flavor selection - there must be about 30 to choose from. I went with a very odd combination of three flavors that do not go together whatsoever but are things I just like individually: cotton candy, pumpkin pie and cookies-n-cream. Super weird, right? I'm sure I'm the first person in Tanya & Matt's history to go with that combo, but I really just tried to eat one at a time and not mix them with each scoop - it worked out! I really loved the cotton candy and the pumpkin pie, especially. The cookies-n-cream was solid too. I also really appreciated that you could order a cone bowl because I wanted to take mine home and a regular cone would have been quite messy and difficult to transport.

My wife ordered a chocolate covered cherry shake and loved it, despite having low expectations for whatever reason. 

We really dropped the ball by not coming here sooner and will definitely be visiting regularly moving forward!

Why 5 stars? Because this is the best lobster in Tampa Bay, and for the best value.

   ---   ---   ---

Ever since experiencing the best meal of my life (a hot Lobster Roll at Neptune Oyster in Boston,) I've been on the hunt to duplicate that feeling of ecstasy. This was as close as I've come taste-wise, but it's definitely the best value I've ever seen for lobster. I had so much, I could barely eat it all, and it was under $20. This cannot, and will not ever be beaten.

It's a laid back vibe, with a decent beer selection, and excellent service. Our server, Megan, was a little ball of energy from the moment we arrived. She was so entertaining, it was like we had dinner and a show, but just for the price of dinner. It was a fun night.

I chatted with the owner afterward, and he said he prides himself on having a more casual restaurant so that he can charge less for the lobster. I'll take a pile of Lobster for $20, over a white tablecloth any day of the week myself.

So, if Lobster is you thing, there's nowhere else to look in TB. The hunt is over, and a champion is crowned.

The United Artists Galaxy Theatre is certainly one of Central Indiana's older "contemporary": theaters with stadium style seating and a sound system that reminds you how much technology has advanced in the last 20 years. 

That's not a compliment. 

It's a go to movie theater for promotion screenings, however, because it also tends to have larger auditoriums and is a great choice for those screenings expecting high attendance. If there's one thing I love about it, it's that they do offer very limited "single" seat options. That is, I can actually go into the auditorium and find a seat where I don't have to sit next to someone else by getting out of my wheelchair. The majority of theaters tend to have companion seating. 

The seats are older and tend to be less comfortable than what you find in most theaters. They aren't horrible, but they definitely aren't plush. Prices tend to be a tad higher here due to tax issues related to the downtown stadiums, but the prices are still on par with most area theaters. 

The staff is friendly, though they can be a bit "in your face" at times if they are unfamiliar with you. This is definitely one of my least favorite theaters in Central Indiana, and I can't say I'd recommend it for a film that utilized high special effects. They do offer special film series offerings throughout the year, especially during the Summer months, and despite my reservations I would note that it's still pretty consistently crowded.

I've been seeing ads on ABC for weeks on the west coast for Ruby Tuesday even though there aren't any RTs on the west coast. Well tonight I was finally able to satisfy my need for the shrimp po'boy flatbread! It was everything I'd hoped for and more. Service was great and my friend and baby were accommodated with the stroller etc. The food came out fresh and hot and beforehand we were served cheesy herb biscuits - yum!

New fro-yo location opened up near my house. They have a large selection of flavors even though many of them are variations of chocolate. A couple of things I didn't like was that the yogurt consistency comes out too soft even a little watery which is done to add to the weight. The higher the temperature of the yogurt the heavier it is when it is weighed. Unlike my favorite Yogurtland they have an employee give you samples instead you sampling yourself. The toppings are cut heavy also to boost the price. 

Overall the yogurt itself is pretty tasty but the fact that they try to cheat you on the little things to boost the price will keep me from coming back. Don't try to take this stuff to go or it will be soup before you get home.

I've probably been to a dozen or so concerts and shows here in the Grande Exposition Hall at the Silver Legacy.  There are some good seats and some bad seats but the BEST seats are reserved for the "high rollers" for the Silver Legacy.  So you might wanna be a gambler there if you really want to get super close.

Most of the time we have the "bad" seats and still find a way to enjoy ourselves at most shows.  The security staff does a great job in keeping the crowd from getting out of hand.  They also have huge screens if you just are unlucky enough to get stuck behind that 350lb 6'7" guy with the pimp hat.  You can still catch most of the best parts of the show.  

They have lots of bars out front too.  The alcohol prices are a bit gougey but not sports stadium level.  Last concert we went to was 311 and they even had the smarts to do a 311 drink!  Love that kind of creativity.

Most shows wont go past 10 because they need to get people out gambling.  Parking at the Silver Legacy sucks...I suggest just parking at the Circus Circus and walking the nice walk from that parking garage.  Unless you are driving a smart car, then go ahead and park at the Silver Legacy.

Cool unique location. I loved my meal - had the chicken pesto - and was very impressed with the dessert!! Service was good and we didn't have to wait to long on a Saturday night.

I would recommend this place! But I'm not really sure what to compare it to because I haven't eaten out much in the downtown St Louis area (I was only in town for a few days). If I came back I'd probably want to see what else was out there.

I came here on a Thursday morning for brunch around 10 AM and it's your typical average brunch spot. The menu is quite small and doesn't have many options- you can't customize much other.  They do not have avocado toast on the menu which is a huge disappointment. The young man taking our order was friendly and recommended to get toast and just pay extra for the avocado on top. 

My friend ordered a breakfast burrito. I took a bite and it was good, but just nothing out of this world for me. The one thing that stood out to me is the freshly squeezed orange juice. Oh, and apparently they are known for their hash. Not a budget friendly brunch spot either- we spent about $50, and I only got a piece of toast with some avocado on it, an orange juice and my friend ordered a breakfast burrito.

A few sounds that would be synonymous with my experience: hmmm....ehhhh..mmehhh...gaaahh..bllahhh....geglasdsdfjk. 

Most of those sounds would be in relation to the service rather than the actual food. Let's approach this review chronologically:

12 noon: lunch date and I arrive at First Watch. Surprised by the interior - if Denny's and a food court's fornication resulted in a baby, it would be First Watch. A baby that looks like all the other babies. You say it's cute because you feel like it's the nice thing to do, when in reality it's just your average bebe.
12:01 p.m.: seated immediately - but in the depths of the restaurant at a 6-person circular table...for two. (I title this complaint: "white girl problems")
12:15: orders were finally taken (I know, I know. 14 minutes doesn't seem like much but in the world of lunch breaks its the difference between life and death.)
12:39: food arrives - presented nice-looking meals - I'd give the food four stars. I had the veggie burger with a cup of the tomato basil soup. I was surprised that the veggie burger didn't come with cheese, so I opted for a slice of Swiss. 
12:55ish: Brittany's sloth-like eating habits continue. Decision is made that I will return again and try one of their breakfast options: fun variety of pancake and hash options.

You know the saying "bless his/her heart" and how it's sometimes comes off as more of a "damn. that poor thing can't seem to get their shit together" than an actual blessing? Well, bless our waitress' heart - it took three tickets for her to get the order correct and figure out which standard dressings go with which salads - she asked us. The business is still fairly new, so I'm going to go out on a limb and guess she's new to the profession. Nice menu/tasty food, First Watch. Hope you can get the kinks out of the service side of things. As for the DennysFoodCourt Baby that is your interior, well, I have a feeling that won't be changing any time soon.

WHAT A GREAT FIND!!

Ever get that sharp pain in your stomach, the one that almost makes you double over and cry out for mommy? Ahhh!!! An empty stomach having a canipshin because you have been neglecting it far too long. Either that, or the Scooby Snack you had on trail has since wore off. The latter is what happened with me and The Crew. Our morning stroll through the Coronado Monarch Butterfly Preserve and along the beach left our tummy's HANGRY!

Thanks for the mighty Yelp app. we found ourselves here. The filters on the app are a god send when having to find eateries extensive enough to accommodate preferences, food allergies, and wallets, Siam Thai met everyone's criteria.

Located on the main drag in the charming little beach town of Carpenteria, Siam Thai's interior is modest in size but their newly added back patio is grand and a great place to enjoy yummy eats while soaking up some Vitamin D. The interior is decorated with gold colored elephants, statues, and figurines.

With so many peeps in attendance, I'm not going to list the dishes ordered, however, I will say we ordered a few appetizers, soups, entrees, including curry's, fried rice, noodles, and vegetarian dishes. Entrees, curry's, and, noodles come with a choice of chicken, beef, pork, or tofu, up-charge for shrimp or seafood.  Not only was everyone WOWED! by the friendly staff members ability to take our orders expeditiously, but also deliver each dish quickly and accurately. And let me tell you, some folks order the an item straight from the menu, only to ask to hold this or that, this or that on the side, and substitute this for that. Oy!!! We did not receive one dish incorrectly. Portions were plentiful and all hot dishes were served hot, all cold dishes, served cold, and beverage glasses were kept full. 

STAFF EARNED IT!
Free public parking lot nearby, as well as, free street parking, as it should be, Siam Thai was such a great find.  Our server was so accommodating, instead of one long arse check, she combined four orders per check. Phew!! That many peeps all on one check can be an accounting nightmare. Server and her staff so deserved the well over 20% tip we left. Great place, ya'll should check it out. Hopefully, you will have the same experience me and The Crew did.

The Rules of having a Great Experience at the Well:

1. Arrive Early
2. Go on Pint Nights where pints are $2.75 or Fridays for Bluegrass
3. Order Domaine Dupage or Loose Cannon IPA.
4. Order homemade walnut bread with Humboldt Fog chevre.

I mean, really, you must follow these rules. They're very specific...because any sort of wavering will deter you from returning. That is of course if: you don't like smokey tiny rooms the size of your walk-in closet that are too-loud and stuffy. 

Showing up at opening on a weeknight...yeah..go ahead...accept your existence of being a yuppie who likes to go places other than your balcony. It's okay...really...you like to drink beer. There's nothing wrong with it. 

The wait staff here is just...plain...kind. They answer your inquiries about what song is playing. They just like you. Really...people like you. I promise. 

Plus, they won't make you feel bed for ordering the good beer (ahem...local brewpub who can't stand it when you order beers that aren't their own...). In fact, they love you for it. And, I love you Wellington for having Domaine Dupage on tap.  You're not going to find better beer on tap for that price anywhere in the city. Everywhere else it's either $2 domestics or $5-6 micros. Cheers to this anomaly!

The new bar food menu is refreshing to see. Cheeses, meats, soups, salads. A bit too decadent maybe for Broad Ripple? Ahhhhh patooey...call it "chevre," simply out of spite of what's down the block! 

If you're running late and you show up at 6, be prepared for smoke -- a lot of it. And somehow the Wellington convinces me I like to watch folks play darts. 

Then, on Fridays in the basement the bluegrass...the coziest party in Broad Ripple. Just arrive early to get a table...if not you'll be that casual couple that thought they just could pop in, walk down stairs to find 50 people stomping, clapping and quaffing, and you're left only to retreat to the same ole, same ole.

If only we could convince them to open the basement on pint nights for those not inclined to smoke....

O, and don't be alarmed there's a security camera in the joint...it's gotta be for these amazing tables that seem like they're right out of a Victorian mansion. Good form!

I met someone amazing at this club so I can't not give it a great review! But aside from that serendipitous moment, I like the layout of LEX with their pool, multiple bars, and spacious walkways. Nothing about a club annoys me more than narrow walkways/chokepoints that just make it harder to get around and gives you some claustrophobia. Maybe just because it's Reno or the Saturday I went wasn't the busiest, but I liked how it wasn't so crowded, yet there was still a good group of friendly folks! It was easy to get a drink (not a 10-minute wait) and the prices don't break your wallet. Since I met someone so awesome here, this is the best club in Reno! I guess also I haven't really been to any other club in Reno unless you count Brews Brothers. So if you find yourself at the GSR on a weekend, LEX has a high potential to be super fun with great music and a chill atmosphere.

So it's the day of NYE and just about every restaurant in the French Quarter has a line of 20 people out the door. Lucky for us, we came across Desire at just the right hour because we were immediately seated - almost window-side - in a packed house. 

With 127 reviews and counting, let me break it down for you...

Start with oystas! The raw oysters were incredibly fresh, chilled, and served with plenty of lemon. And they their house-made cocktail sauce has strong bite - or should I say a giant smack? ...because that was spice-ay! 

We also got the barbecue oysters. They're fried, glazed in a wonderfully sweet and smokey barbecue sauce, sitting over individual shells and topped with crumbled bleu cheese. I didn't snap any pics, but you gotta check out this photo snapped by another yelper... http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JvawJ9bSr22xn4R9oLvl_w?select=VL23qeOnZHumSnISqQ0uXw

You can't get wrong with the gumbo, with its rich, thick roux. Probably the best I've had in a while. I also ordered the crawfish ettoufee. it was good, but I had plate envy for my friend's shrimp and grits. 

The bloody mary I ordered was alright. Not the best. It was a tad too thick and had the consistency of ketchup. The flavor and spiciness were there, but I should have ordered another shot of Tito's and thrown in some more Worcestershire to thin it out. 

Service was great. I appreciate how it was so busy, and yet our server kept reminding us to "take our time" and "enjoy your food." Love the Big Easy mentality. 

I'll totes come back. But probably stick with a dozen or two oysters and a nice cold beer.

I could have sworn I reviewed this particular location but after checking my Center City review, I realize...I never did. 

When this was considered the newer 'Pavilion' side of the mall (I'm not sure if that word even exists for this mall anymore) I used to walk by Morton's on the first floor when I was trying to get to XandO (or I think it was called Cosi by then.)* It was just a solid closed door and for some reason, I was intimidated by this. So when one of my co-workers way back when asked if I would like to join her and another co-worker here for dinner on her gift card, I jumped at the chance to finally walk through that door. 

The three of us managed to grab a nice leather banquette and I'm pretty sure everyone surrounding us was male, in suits, settling in after a long day of work. I'm happy to say we were doing the same, and it felt good. 

Even better, a friend was our server for the evening, and she made sure we were well taken care of. One of us ordered Steak Diane, a filet mignon, and yes, I had chicken. We split three sides and pretty much demolished everything in sight, if not daintily. I do believe we ordered that hot chocolate molten lava cake (I can't even get the name correct but we enjoyed this) and we sat back and relaxed after we feasted. 

Damn, I miss the days when I made good money, even though this was on a gift card. 

*I should point out the time line for this visit was 2004-5 or so when I know these places existed.

May 17, 2019 Friday - 4:30 PM for a drink
2 adults

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - 5 star
Service - 4 star

Background - I have been watching the build out for some time and been waiting for this place to open.

Atmosphere - Sixty plus taps.  That is what is great about a beer bar.  Furniture is mix of styles, kinda crazy, but in a good way.    The bar matches the length of taps, the line bar was three people deep while we were there.

Food
  Drink - Sixty plus choices is awesome.  I had one beer from their taps, Homestyle by Bearded Iris Brewing.  I was a little disappoint in the flavor.  I also filled my free growler that they handed out when you entered the store.  We will see how that Stone Brewing's Stone ///Fear.Movie.Lions Double IPA tonight.  

  Food - I was surprised they actually serve food, so that is a plus.  My wife had the kettle chips that were not anything special but the pizza looked great.

Service - Greeted by the staff warmly.  I know the place is new and a lot of training is going on but my growler was not filled to 64 oz. line.  Most places fill it beyond that level to remove the air which is a beer killer.  Bonus for small little sample glasses, love the idea.

Future - Of course, and the Beer Club UYE is already setup.

Well, there's nothing really special about this Dunkin Donuts. It's pretty much just like every other DD I've been to. 

That being said, I do like DD's coffee and the service here is really friendly -- probably friendlier than the other locations I've frequented. There's another location just down the road on Gandy but their employees aren't as warm so I generally just go here instead. 

There is sadly no free wifi here which is a total bummer, but if you're looking for a quick cup of joe served with a smile, this Dunkin Donuts isn't a bad bet.

Hey Blue Ribbon Meat & Butcher Shop,
I'm so happy with you.
Your meat I use for stew
and I appreciate the good customer service that you do.

A third generation local family owned and operated Meat Company located in the heart of Sparks, Full-Service Butcher Shop Blue Ribbon Meat & Butcher Shop has a large variety of quality meats.  The business was clean.  They gave us a Veterans Discount once they saw our Veteran's hat.

Place is new and clean in the neighborhood. Restroom also clean to use. We stop here after pumping my gas station next door. The Dunkin is connected to plaza. Easy access fro US 301. Their coffee was on sales that day. We walk on the right time. 

I have blueberry coolata. It is a bit sour but bearable. Is is sweeter will be nice. I like it to be refreshing. My wife have coffee with hazelnut flavor. It is also good enough for just a fraction of price.
Friendly service. Contemporary decor. Had the salmon nicoise salad, which was good, except it didn't need the haricot vert or marinated olives.

Me: Good morning. Can I get a bacon, egg and cheese on Cuban bread?

Owner: No.  (Long pause)..... 
But we can make it on a bagel.

Me: Okay, no thanks. 

Why is this unacceptable?  Because they make breakfast sandwiches and they also make Cuban sandwiches. This place is never busy, so why they would let a potential customer walk out is beyond me. 

I went up the street to Bayshore Breezes and got the sandwich I wanted, and will never step foot on this shop again.

Probably closer to 4 stars overall, but rounding up to 5 for their awesome BBQ Shrimp!! They were super busy when we went on a Monday night around 6:30pm, and it was about an hour wait for a party of 5. I would highly recommend making reservations ahead of time. We tried:

-Poached Pear Salad (Port Wine Poached Pears, Dried Cranberries, Bleu Cheese, Port Wine Vinaigrette, $12, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_7ncMPpgmjbz9HnraegzsA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok for me, but I'm not a big fan of fruit in my salad or bleu cheese. The salad was really fresh, but I could've done without this- skip!
-Bacon Wrapped Shrimp & Grits ($30, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=BFBoC5nym8ckY-ef3aqm9A&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- the bacon wrapped shrimp were delicious (and the shrimp were gigantic), and the grits were nice and creamy. Recommended!
-Mr. B's Barbequed Shrimp ($31, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=19JMuCqrQSLLd8hXf9_X2Q&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): This is THE dish to order here, but only if you're ok with getting down and dirty with your dinner. The shrimps come in the shell and with the head on, and you're going to have to peel away. They do give you a bib and extra napkins, and this dish is definitely worth the extra work! The sauce was amazing, and the shrimp were all really fresh. Make sure you use the garlic bread to soak up all that delicious sauce!
-Lemon Ice Box Pie ($9, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=vnFhuYVRHUjwJdOok1f22w&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Not what I was expecting. I thought this was a pie made with lemon wafers, but we received an actual slice of pie that resembled key lime. The lemon flavor was very prominent and fresh, and I would recommend ordering this if you want a tart dessert.
-Profiteroles & Chocolate Sauce ($9, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rQROo8t_KIPWrbJLA9Hhkg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- it's hard to go wrong with cream puffs filled with vanilla ice cream and drizzled with hot fudge. The fudge sauce was amazing, and I could've just had a scoop of vanilla ice cream with the fudge.

The servers here all have that Southern charm, and were very helpful and attentive. I would definitely come back here for their BBQ shrimp if back in New Orleans, and will also make sure to order their pork belly appetizer!

this is the most horrible meal i had in new orleans, the most horrible pho i have had in my whole life, the the sorry excuse of the strawberry spring roll is just terrible. the pho is flavorless and noodles limp. just terrible!

Ahhhh the park where I first learned to ride a bike. We used to come here all the time growing up and as a family. We loved it because it's small enough that you can see all around it, but big enough to allow kids of all ages to play on the different equipment and run around free. It's wedged in next to a neighborhood and the park even has a paved trail that goes around it in a loop (hence it being the best place to teach a kid to ride a bike!). 

They also have a covered picnic table area which makes it a great place to have a picnic, meet up with friends, etc. Now go get outside!

Back in the day, I remember my Mom taking me to JC Penney for school clothes. It's kind of amazing how the commerce landscape has changed since then. Now I basically buy everything online or at Target. I literally had no idea JC Penney was still in business. 

Then the holidays rolled around and someone gave me a JC Penney gift card, so JC Penney wound up on my radar.  I Googled it and found out that yes, they are still in business after exiting bankruptcy. Anyway, that prompted me to go in store to check out the merchandise and use my gift card. 

My first impression was that the store looked a bit dated and generic, like a TJ Maxx and Kohl's mash up that was stuck in the 90s. Their merchandise is wildly overpriced. Like $20 for a generic kids t-shirt (vs $6 in Target) and $69 for kids sneakers that I saw on Amazon for half that price. 

I ultimately blew my gift card on some luggage, but a quick price check online showed that it was also overpriced, just like the shirts and shoes. Oh well. I figured it was better to use the card ASAP in case they file for bankruptcy again. 

Three stars. They're hanging in there it seems, but just barely. I hope they make it.

Only one other review that's over 3 years old? Uncalled for!

This is such a cute little jewelry shop. They carry all kinds of handmade jewelry like bracelet cuffs and necklaces.  The stuff they carry is extremely unique and I could see how a lot of this stuff would make great gifts.

Jen L. was right when she said that there is something for everyone here. They have cute little post earrings that would be perfect for a little girl who just got her ears pierced. They also have pretty little rings that any girl would love.

My visit here was so much fun!  The zoo is huge with so many different animals and they have a huge breeding program.  There were so many babies!  Best part was the polar bears and the red pandas.  They were so cute and entertaining to watch.  I had no idea that the Philadelphia zoo was the first in the country!

I felt like the orangutans were sad looking though... If only they had more space and entertainment.  And the zoo was really busy, but there was a lot of traffic in particular near the red pandas.  The zoo was crowded, which surprised me since its $18 per person... I guess it's not too high for people. I really wished that I saw some pandas, koalas, and elephants though... But I really appreciate that they don't have elephants in the zoo since the lack of space causes stress to the elephants.

There were a lot of picture opportunities such as various animal statues, peacocks running loose and picture friendly animal exhibits.

The zoo could use more benches and food vendors though.

Returned to Aldo's for dinner for the first time in more than a decade. At one time it had been a regular stop in my rotation when I lived right across Buck Road in Holland, PA. It was good to be back. 

The menu offered a broad swatch of Italian cuisine, mostly of the red sauce variety, but with enough variation to keep it interesting. We went with the Calamari appetizer, and entrees of Veal Parmesan and Chicken Francais, both with sides of pasta, minestrone soup and side salad. We were quite happy with our meals. 

They started off on an off note with a luke warm minestrone that had not been sufficiently reheated, nor tested. The early salad was satisfactory, if less than imaginative. Things improved from there. The Calamari was perfectly prepared with tender squid wrapped in a tasty bread crumb dredge and a thick marinara dipping sauce. The veal was delicious with two thin filets, breaded and pan fried in extra virgin just right to maximize its delicate texture and finished with melted mozza and more chunky red gravy. The three Francaised chicken breast medallions were pan sauteed in butter, lemon and white wine. They were fork cuttable and the interplay of the lemon and wine played tartly and smartly on the tongue. We used the crusty bread to sop up as much of the reduction as possible. My request for the pasta side bowl to be penne aglio olio rather than more tomato sauce was a good call because I loved the well browned garlic and black pepper mix. 

Aldo still does a solid traditional Italian American dinner in an attractive dining room. It was nice to know that for the most part they hadn't lost their touch.

Layla's is, simply put, a great classic honky tonk bar. The elements of such a bar are simple but hard to pull off: classic honky tonk music played by expert bands, an intimate atmosphere that's the opposite of the 6-story tourist traps around it, and some down-home folks who just love to drink and mingle. You'll get it all here. 

I walked in to listen to the band and ended up sitting at the bar and drinking local beers while admiring the enthusiasm the crowd had for some good music. there were more boots and cowboy hats in here than any other bar on the strip, if that tells you anything. They have an upstairs, too, but the long back bar is all you need to make your own good time. 

I would easily recommend Layla's to anyone trying out Nashville and looking for a classic experience. It's a honky tonk to remember!

Deviate is one of Indy's best breweries in town in terms of both quality and creativity.  I've never had a beer I didn't thoroughly enjoy.  If you're on a beer tour, you must, must, MUST stop here for a flight!

Historic coffee shop focusing primarily on two menu items: coffee and beignets!

I read some of the negative reviews for this location and wondered why this place would have a less than perfect stars since everyone raves about their beignets. I get it that it's a new location and maybe have to work out some kinks to get that perfect 5 star ratings? was it the beignets themselves? the service? 

For me, I was just happy that I was able to try their beignets since the more popular historic open-air coffee shop (located on Decatur Street in the heart of the French Quarter) was always crowded with a long wait. Their menu included beignets, coffee and a variety of other drinks. I was second in line from their take-out window (which was nice since we didn't have a lot of time)... ordered a couple of frozen mochas and one order of beignets (came with 3 pieces) that hubby and I shared and it was delicious, not overly sweet! I have nothing to compare it to as far as other beignet shops but I've heard that you have to eat these delicious fluffy desserts fast while it's still hot otherwise they become really hard as a rock so I slowly scarfed it down -LoL- and I enjoyed it very much! Yummy deep-fried pastries that are very similar to doughnuts but not really.

Eating beignets at Cafe Du Monde was one of the top suggestions from my friends for things to do in NOLA (thank you, Yelp friends!) and I'm glad I was able to fit it in our two days in New Orleans. Hope to return next year and hit up the one at the French Quarter. Oh yah, I bought a box of beignet mix to take home and I'm going to try to recreate their famous treats! [with emphasis on "try"]

Review #1488

I like the Neuvo-Latino-Americano grub here.  The place has moved locations and is now a bit larger.  Chips & Salsa are always fresh 7 tasty, too.

I wish I could give a more substanital review but I ate here so long ago - and at the old location - so I'd better just keep my mouth shut.

Those who say the best Italian in STL is on, "The Hill" is totally wrong. This place in Clayton is amazingly delicious. It is tucked away at the  back-end of a small strip center just off Wydown. The small boutique size makes it intimate and almost romantic. 

I meet up with fellow Yelper, Christal for lunch on the Tuesday after Labor Day. Our luncheon was 12:30pm, towards the end of their lunch rush. I arrived first and selected a table on their small patio. Being a dog dad, it was nice to see they had water bowls making the patio pet friendly. 

We started out with some Cauliflower Hummus. In addition to the crostini, they offered a basket of soft Italian bread dabbed with garlic butter. This worked out great, because I preferred the crostini and Christal wanted the softer bread. I enjoyed the uniqueness of the cauliflower hummus. In addition to the hummus, the plate had a small spinach salad with pine nuts and balsamic dressing. It was a nice touch. 

For my entree, I channeled my inner child and ordered a half order of spaghetti and meatball. I choose the chicken.The ground chicken was blended with breadcrumbs. It was moist and tender. Noodles were prepared to a perfect al dente. I don't think Italian food can really be classified as a comfort food, but this Southern Italian Southern food, brought me comfort this afternoon. 

No booze for me, I enjoyed a tall refreshing glass of ice tea. Christal was having a rough day at work and enjoyed a glass of red wine. I found it odd that it was not served in a traditional wine glass. It was served in a small juice/water glass. I thought it was perhaps because we were on the patio.  Then the table next to us ordered a bottle and did have a traditional steamed glass. Just weird. 

Our server was professional and very knowledgeable. He described their food and recommended wines for Christal like a true pro. 

Will I return? - Most definitely. 

When: September 5, 2017
Why: Italian lunch with a friend

Not too much more I can add about this quaint custard shop! It does what it does and it does it well. 

I ordered up a News 11 concrete which had their Scotch Oatmeal cookie and Reese's peanut butter cups blended in. My brother got the Apple Pie concrete which was delicious and my grandma got an apple cobbler drenched in caramel and custard. My grandpa went with his favorite dessert- a banana split and although it was huge, I'm pretty sure his empty container suggests it was tasty! 

We got here right when it opened and got our dessert right away to enjoy on the benches. It'd be nice if they had some tables set up but the absence kind of adds to the novelty of the place. Like many others, this will definitely be a go-to whenever I am back in St. Louis.

The company I work for in Somerset ALWAYS brings Top Hat in to make our blitzing days here on the sales floor more bearable.

Everything I've tried of theirs has been delicious, and they always have a new special every time they come in! I've tried their caramel latte, frosted mint mocha, and their cinnamon bun latte (all made with almond milk) and I've loved them all. They even create beautiful latte art!

I look forward to trying more of their concoctions!

Oh my Gosh, this is one of THE best meals that I have ever eaten at a restaurant, and I have returned over and over again to savor the moment.

Mr. B's Bistro is located on Royal Street at Iberville, and it is another member of the famed Brennan family's fine dining establishments. This is a very classic white tablecloth, tuxedoed waiter type of restaurants, but amazingly it is not stuffy or pretentious.

Once you arrive at your table, the waiter appears with a loaf of freshly-baked bread and lightly-salted butter as he takes your drink order.

Having been at Mr. B's many times in the past I went straight for my favorite things on the menu. To start I had Mr. B's Crabcake, which was a pan-sauteed jumbo lump crabcake served with their classic ravigote sauce. The crabcake was mostly big chunks of lump crabmeat with very little breading or filler. Following that I had their incredible seafood gumbo which was a classic New Orleans gumbo with Gulf shrimp, crabmeat, oysters, and okra served in a dark roux sauce.

And now for my entree (pardon me while I wipe the drool off my mouth).... I ordered the legendary Mr. B's Barbequed Shrimp which is their signature dish. Head-on Gulf shrimp barbequed New Orleans style, served in the shells with Worcestershire-spiked peppery butter sauce and French bread for dipping. The recipe for this amazing dish can be found here:  http://www.mrbsbistro.com/recipes_shrimp.php

To finish this amazing meal, my lovely friend and I split an order of the Brennan family's Creole Bread Pudding. The recipe is rich in eggs, cream and butter, served warm with Irish whiskey sauce. Oh, and THAT recipe can be found here:  http://www.mrbsbistro.com/recipes_breadpudding.php.

Seriously, one of the best meals on the planet!

We were actually going to the sushi place down the street but saw this on the way and decided to walk In and see the menu. The menu was just burgers and fries and it didn't seem like much.. But we stayed and I ordered the blue bayue? Something like that. And it was absolutely AMAZING. The burgers LOOK small, but halfway through, I just couldn't finish it, I was so full. The ice cream is really good! One scoop was pretty big! So if you're already full, just get one scoop! They give ice cream samples too! Loved this place. friendly service too!

MD is definitely one of the best Chinese grocery stores in the area.  This place is very big and sells varieties of stuff.  Although the majority of their stuff is Chinese, they do carry enough Japanese and Korean food too, especially their candies and condiments.  The price is not the cheapest but definitely not overpriced.  

They carry fresh seafood (they literally grab live one from the tanks and kill it with a hammer right in front of you....It was brutal and I got traumatized lol).  They also have meat, and the majority are not regular types of meat you see at Publix.  They have intestines, stomach, chicken feet, pig feet, pig ears, and uterus.  I gagged when I was looking at those so if these are not the things you are looking for, stay away.  If you are interested in something you can't get from regular supermarkets, then go for it!  

They also have bread from Fortune Star Bakery all the way in the back of the building, along with some fresh produce and instant food like ramen noodles.  This place is definitely one-up on Oceanic Oriental in downtown Tampa.

Well, let's see. I got to watch people dancing, which is always fun. I ran into a couple of people I haven't seen in a long time (I think I used an alias with one, so the re-introduction moment was awkward), so that was amusing. One of my friends was really drunk and acting silly, so the entertainment factor was high. 

But uhh, then there were some other things that weren't so fantastic. Like the broken glass on the floor (which lodged itself into two different feet of our party). Or the menacing looks from some of the booth-dwellers. Or the prices. 

I get what they are striving to achieve; it's just not my scene, man. Look for me at Silk, Barbary JB's, etc. I'm not shiny enough to hang here.

The Seminole Hard Rock Casino of Tampa has a lot activity. It has the biggest hotel in the Bay Area. I am not much of the gambler but I come here often for their restaurant. 

The casino is not smoke free place. As a result, it is stink to walk at the casino floor. Your cloth also will be stink due to the trap cigarette smoke. Ventilation has to be improved to improve the quality of the air. 

If you feel lucky at night. Put some bating on slot or table games. Or you can test your skill of card games, poker or pi gau the Chinese domino. 

The bars is every where. Drink never be a problem in this place. There is live performance on the casino floor or restaurant. But compare to Vegas, they need to have big auditorium for show. I think this is the area they have lack off.

I love Macy's...I love their sales and the holiday decorations!!
It is always crowded but it is worth it...
Especially during the holiday season with the Christmas music...

When I walked by this place once I read, "fish in a bag," on their sandwich board; that's not going to draw me...if it draws you...please let me know who you are, and what you are. Nor does it jive with the 90210 (the show) feel. It looks like a place that asked themselves, "would Kelly & Dylan dine here?"

Finally the cocktail of life shook just the right way to get me here...jet lagged, late Friday night dinner, and this place's "jerk chicken," got me in the door. 

The environment is vastly more comfortable than expected -- space in Broadripple is limited & they don't mind putting in half the amount of tables they could...plenty of elbow room. 

Now...that patio is another story...seems stuffy like a twice-baked potato out there. 

The service was as dry as the chicken. The server was just all business...I don't know...it's around 9pm on a Friday...you'd think the service would be, if not steady, just in good spirits...instead he was all business. Granted, being all business has its benefits of taking care of it all, but it was just boring -- compared to the lively atmosphere. 

The server's values are murky: he offered us oil & hot sauce plate amazingness with our pita/hummus, and I made sure it was at no cost, then he brought out more pita and it was eventually charged on the bill (though I had to ask to not include it; sure, call me Stickler). 

The jerk chicken was a husky, dry, giant steak. To me, Jamaica-traveled, should be on the bone, and far from dry. This was Hoosier-ized with sides of beans & carrots & potatoes that no one would eat. It's these veggies that give kids reasons to never eat a healthy diet.

Now...having said this...the place really is a beautiful balance of liveliness and romance for dinner; and that's hard to find. 

I'd be back to this place, around the same time too (bordering late night bar crowd) to keep it casual. However, I'd make sure I don't have the same server, because well he reeks of midday workday all-business attitude, and that frustrates a Friday night diner.

And, go late to see the Dylan McKay wannabes -- it's funny -- when they know their infinitely, always Brandon Walsh that may as well be showing up with Brenda.

This is a review of the Knitting Factory as a venue for live theater, which I didn't know they were capable of doing until a week ago! It's great to see them really expanding the type of entertainment they're offering. 

Here goes...

When I saw Avenue Q was going to be playing in Reno, I was giddy with excitement about an opportunity to see a live musical performance here in Reno. Then I realized it was at the Knitting Factory, a black box type venue known more for hosting music more than any other type of performance art, and I was all of a sudden hesitant. I had no fear the actors would put on a great show, but I wasn't sure if the venue could keep up with them. 

Three cheers to the Knit for setting up seats with great viewing angles of the stage. There wasn't a bad seat in the house, and we were just about front and center. I loved the show and my time watching it, but as I've experienced here in the past, the sound leaves a little to be desired. There were many times when it was hard to hear the voices of the actors on stage over the music, and I don't know if that's a sound board error or an acoustics issue.
