Either way, I found myself leaning over to my fiancee, like an old man losing his hearing, asking her what they'd just said. Sometimes she knew, and sometimes we both guessed until we figured it out through context. 

While the guessing game and acoustic challenges were annoying, I'd say my experience at the Knit was A-OK and I would not hesitate to see another live theater performance there again. I'm glad they're bringing a variety of acts to the venue, and I look forward to what comes next.

I've been wanting to try VV for several months, I finally had the opportunity to do so and I know I'll return. The things I loved about it were as follows:

Amazing customer service by Jill. She had some help running food out but she was the most knowledgeable about the restaurant. She gave very good wine recommendations and knew this current  list. She seemed to be passionate about this place and her role in it. 

I loved the modern industrial feel with lots of open space, and the uncluttered display of bottles to go. While the bar is not large, it seemed to be a popular place for locals to meet up after work. And with options to taste up to 40 different curated wines before deciding on which to further enjoy, I'd be a regular here for sure. 

I love the business model too. Where else can you sample this many distinct wines to aid in the decision to bring some home? Even restaurants that have vast cellars keep the wine by the glass list relatively short. Then if you did find something you loved you'd have to find it on your own. I found the prices to go to be pretty moderate, I think some bottles were under $15 and with the highest one being just shy of $100. I kind of regret not tasting that one;) 

I'm sorry to say I did not love the food, nor did my dining companion. It wasn't bad, but just not up to the standards of the wine I tasted. I think we enjoyed the fig flatbread the most.( half price during happy hour or if on Yelp, half off with check in) Jill also recommended the chicken one but we ordered other items. The poutine was decent, long fries which were very crisp in a tasty brown gravy, maybe too much gravy to fry ratio. Nice size serving for the price too, I took half of it home. The salad was plated beautifully and the beets themselves were perfectly cooked. It was also the most generous amount of burata I've ever seen on a restaurant plate. But the overdressed greens kept this from being great. The mussel small plate was a good size entree for smaller appetites, but broth was very salty. The lager base was ok, but had the broth been tastier, more would have been needed. The shellfish itself seemed a bit dry from lack of broth, and not the plumpest or tastiest we've had. I had the skirt steak main, the meat was done to a perfect medium, nice, and even in this cut was still pretty tender. But the onions were not really caramelized as they had been for flatbread, the broc rabe was very good, just slightly charred but only 3 twigs. The rice was ok. To me the dish was competent in components, but they did not really enhance each other. Lastly the chocolate cheesecake was just ok. The homemade whipped cream helped a little, but I'd pass on this unless you like less dense versions of this dessert. Of everything we tried, I'd probably only reorder the flatbread or poutine. 

I think the wine tasting part of this experience is 5 stars. I tried 10 wines in total, half of which I'd consider full pours of if not a to go bottle. For the whites my fav was the Chablis(sadly this was not available to go) but I also enjoyed trying the NY Chard and pitting it against a twice as exp Napa one. For the reds my clear winner was a Portuguese blend that I almost purchased, a reserve from 2013. Second place was a Cab Franc, recommended by Jill. 

A return trip will be focused mainly on the wines, and I plan on checking their website to see as new things are added. I'm not giving up on the food here though, but will likely not try to make it into a meal just yet. 4.25 first real wine tasting post Covid Yelps

Target carries a much smaller supply of DVD's, than Wal Mart, but after a very frustrating and fruitless hour plus, search for a particular movie at Wal Mart, I headed straight to the electronics desk and asked if they had the movie I needed.  His quick search came up with the answer no.

Target has one of the best selections of greeting cards I have found.  The very first one that caught my eye, I picked up and read it, laughed out loud and bought two, one will be on hand for another time.

Target does not carry everything that Wal Mart does, but I do like it so much better.  This Target has an in house Pharmacy and a small eatery with mostly junk foods.

My only gripe with Target are the few check outs open and the long lines.  

So anyway, I'm standing in line to buy this freakin birthday card and the line is like seventeen billion people long, because the only thing the dumb teenage boy at the register is thinking about, is the dumb teenage girl at the other register and some lady is turning her purse inside out to come up with the exact change, like she is going to win some kind of "exact change trophy" or something and then some idiot starts up with his "this item was marked with the sale price" crap...  

So I do hope that Bob really likes his card...  'cause I stole it!   ( j/k )

We first started out with the complementary tostada and salsas that also came with a bean mixture that was pretty tasty. Great way to start off the meal. I shared the elote which came whole so I'm assuming you just chomp your way through - we asked them to cut it in half so it was easier to eat though. It was pretty good but nothing exceptional. 

We got the shrimp and fish taco which were both pretty fresh! I liked the shrimp over the fish a bit because it had more flavor, but at least they didn't give us a shortage of lime! 

Churros were what we ended the night with and it came with 3 sauces - dark chocolate, raspberry and a white chocolate. The raspberry one was my favorite. The churros were tasty but a tad stale. I don't think they make them fresh? They weren't as soft as I was hoping.

Seems awkward to sample olive oils, to be honest.  I always thought oilive oil was just olive oil, but no.  We've got to have flavor-infused olive oils now.  That's just great.  More delicious items to spend money on, as if there wasn't enough already.  

My suggestion here, grab a sampler pack up by the register first.  They're made with the previous week's best sellers.  This will give you a solid idea of what works vs. what doesn't for you palate.

Also, I highly recommend checking out some of the interesting cheeses in the cooler.  We scooped up strawberry & champagne cheddar last week and it is fantastical.  It is made by Yancey's out of NY, and their stuff is legit.  Yancey's is also available at Costco and Winn-Dixie, and if I was a bettin' man, I'd say they get their stock from Costco.  I don't mind paying the higher price and supporting the local mom 'n pop shops though.

I love the Howlin Wolf.  They put on fantastic shows from Burlesque to brass bands and everything in between.  It's a great atmosphere and always a good time.  The staff is always nice and friendly and I always end up having a good time here.

The Howlin Wolf den is also located right next to the main Howlin Wolf.  In this dimly lit bar, you can get a drink before you check out your favorite show, you can order food, or you can even see one of the shows that play regularly in the back of the den.

The last time I was at the Den, I had a cuban sandwich with fried pickles.  It was so good!  Way better than your average bar food.

My recommendation would be to check this place out for the "must see" events that they have here, get some food at the den and have a good time.

My husband is a fan of Yuengling beers, so when I drove by this factory not knowing about the existence of the place, I immediately thought of going to the tour.  

When we went to the tour, the tour guide was a trainee.  So she was probably not as knowledgeable as she should be and it was a little awkward.   However we all know how it feels to be a newbie and how hard public speaking is, so no big deal.  Tough they were not making any canned beer that day, we were able to see the bottle beer being made.  It was very cool.  We were able to question the person works in the lab too.  

At the end of the tour, they will give you a generous portion of their products.  From the tour to the sampling, everything is free!  It is definitely something to do when you have seen all the major tourist spots in Tampa.

Zeppoli is definitely my favorite place for dinner in Collingswood. This is a small intimate place for a quality dinner.... and it's BYOB. Major downer for myself it's not on the main Haddon strip and it's hard to get an earlier reservation.

Anyways foods amazing, definitely a place we're you want to get a 4 course meal, which is probably about $40-$65 per person if you like to eat. My favorite pasta is the limone pasta, which is citrusically unique. For my entree, everything is great, swordfish, rabbit... but I usually go with the steak $30. It's a very fatty, large  portion which is served medium. 

Zeppoli is definitely a great place for a special occasion or a special lady.

This is a review specifically regarding COVID vaccinations. This CVS is pretty busy with drive-thru COVID testing and COVID vaccinations as well as their other business but they appear to have everything running seamlessly. I booked my appointment online. It was pretty simple to use but for some reason it couldn't find my insurance information. Nonetheless, I was able to book my appointment. There were a lot of appointments available as well just none in Brandon. The website shows you which cities have availability, so I advise being flexible if no COVID appoints are available in your city or town. Luckily, this location is only 15-20 mins away from Brandon. 

When I arrived, there is signage everyone instructing you what to do. If you have COVID testing, stay in your car and drive to the pharmacy. If you have a COVID vaccination appointment, go inside the store. You have to check-in on the text message link they send you just prior to your appointment. Then they give you your vaccination card and direct you to a certain portion of the store. 

I wore short sleeves and had drunk the 16 ounces of water that was mentioned in my appointment confirmation email. I sat down in the chair and probably within 2-3 minutes the shot was over. The lady who did the injection was personable and kind and even tried to chat through the short experience. I know this can be nice for people who don't like needles or getting shots as it's sort of a distraction. Then you move on to the chairs they have lined up down one aisle and you wait for 15 minutes. There was a staff member walking the aisle just to make sure you were doing okay and didn't have a reaction. Then you take you vaccination card and coupon for 20% off a purchase and "I got vaccinated" sticker and leave. It's very simple and easy. I just wish they had appointments closer to my house. I also thought that there was too much signage. Signs stuck in the grass, signs on the front door, signs taped to the columns in front of the store and the light poles. Too much signage can sometimes be confusing.

Run of the mill yogurt place, really. No special flavors in particular, but the toppings are great and you can have basically whatever kind of toppings you want on your yogurt. The service isn't necessarily exceptional since it's a basic froyo place, but I don't really expect a lot if I'm pouring my own yogurt and putting on my own toppings.

I can't speak to the smoothies, but they've got a wide variety of options for smoothie lovers. They just seemed a little expensive to me.

I selected Aqimero for a 'fancy' dinner.  Walking in, I was a bit underwhelmed as the restaurant is basically the hotel lobby!  However, I did make reservations in advance and we were promptly seated in a slightly more private area.

Aqimero describes their food as a type of Latin Fusion.  Overall, I'm not sure that is a great description, although I did see a mix of Latin and Asian influences.  Our serve took the time to describe a few of the offerings and offered to grab us drinks.  A yelp photo convinced me to order a Tamarind Fizz and it held up nicely.

We started with the Chifa ceviche and table bread.  The ceviche was a smaller portion than I imagined, but was full of Salmon.  I wouldn't say it was a unique flavor, but it was good.  The bread is probably better described as slices of pita, but with more flavor.  Unfortunately, I wasn't paying attention when it was described so need to gloss over the details here, but would call it very good, especially with the spreads that accompanied it.

For our main, we split the Pescado Zarandeado for two and a side order of Kale.  The Pescado was ok.  I was disappointed when I found numerous bones still in the fish and wasn't wowed by a portion that was supposed to be designed for two.  Still, it also came with a few plantains which I enjoyed. The kale may have been the best of the evening.  It was sauteed with murshrooms, onions, and topped with pig skin flakes.  Again, my description may not do it justice - order and enjoy.

We ended by splitting the strawberry ginger ice.  A good dessert and palate cleanser.  Service was great throughout the night, locking an overall experience in the 3.5 star range.  I'd be willing to go back to give them a chance to differenate themselves into that 4 or 5 star range.

Why 2 stars? Because this was some of the snarkiest service I've received in a long time.

   ---   ---   ---

I hate to kill a place based on one, young employee that probably doesn't even work there anymore, but... this just couldn't go any other way.

You know those people that sense a younger, laid-back customer, and feel that they can be a bit snarky because of it? Hey, I'm all about that... and that's what I thought I was experiencing here at first. But then after about 6-7 comments, I was pretty sure that she was just incredibly rude, and not worthy of employment.

Condescending, impatient, treated me like a child, complained loudly about other customers, etc, etc, etc. If only I could remember her name, she would be "on blast," as the kids say.

Now... back to not killing a place just based on one bad customer service experience. One of the things I love about traveling new places is trying their local coffee shops. Apparently New Orleans is not a coffee city, as it seemed CC's and PJ's were the best two options. Both served terrible coffee. Like gas station quality. 

New business idea: hipster coffee spot in NOLA. Feel free to steal that one from me, because you'll have no competition. 

Or, I'm just a dumbass that managed to miss these places after much research.

I totally get the cult of Federal Donuts; the lovechild of Zahav and Percy Street BBQ.  

The old corner shop is in a warren of narrow old streets in Pennsport, and the space itself has a tiny charm that could easily be a time warp to the 18th Century.  Standing in line or waiting for an order creates a sense that time has slowed down, and even the dust in the sunbeams may have danced for our forefathers. The combination of Korean style double fried chicken and deep dive dough balls is a natural fit for preparation, but I am not yet comfortable eating both at the same seating. The double dose of fats challenges my guilt. 

When we arrived mid-Saturday afternoon, all of the fancies were gone, but the 3 daily offerings were available.  Folks were gnawing on their chicken bones at the counter, blissful in their enjoyment.  We ordered a half doz mix of Vanilla Spice, Maple Brown Sugar and Strawberry Lavender to take with us on the drive home.  They were individually bagged while hot, and placed in a larger paper bag, and ultimately triple bagged in a plastic take out carrier.  

Opening the package, the heat and moisture has made the paper sacks damp, but still held in plenty of the essence of the dough wheels. We tried a Vanilla Spice.  It was covered in sugar and cinnamon, cake-like, and uber sweet. The bite and chew was pleasant, but there was no crispness due to the water vapors.  Very tasty.  A very good donut.  Over the next day, the rest were devoured, and although the taste varied with content, the general experience was the same.  A nice round piece of cake with a hole in the middle. 

Federal Donuts deserves another house call earlier in the day when the fancies are in stock, and again for a unique fried chicken experience, which seems as varied as the sweet fat tires. 
After those ingestions, an update will be in order. 

Until then, the consumed donuts themselves were not life altering, but were certain A-Okay!

There's a reason people don't mind waiting long lines for this place and once I had my taste of the raved about sweet potato pancakes I knew exactly why this place was so solicited.The line will seem long, but it moves. These people are pumping you in and out so don't be discouraged!

It isn't the cute and quaint decor or the friendliness of the servers that put these people on the map, it boils downright to its breakfast and it ain't healthy and probably not organic. If you're here for the coffee or an option less mainstream you might be disappointed.

So the pancakes are light and fluffy- with amazing flavor and then there's what they call a cinnamon cream syrup. Don't know what it has in it, don't care what it has in it but it NEEDS to be a part of my pancake experience for the rest of my life. I wasn't a huge fan of the hashbrowns and everything else may be a little hard to mess up on but what they do good they do GOOD and I was definitely a fan of my pancake experience.

I was really surprised by how much there is to do at this park.  There are baseball and basketball areas, an aquatic center, a few shelters, a playground on the north end and a Play 60 Colts inspired playground/fitness equipment area.  But try as it might to be inclusive, the park needs some capital investment in basics like walkways that aren't broken and sadly, more surveillance in the parking areas.

I had been here before about a year ago to take photos of the Thomas Taggart Memorial.  Taggart was the Mayor of Indy from 1895-1901, became a Senator in 1916, and founded Riverside Park.  The Memorial was built in 1931 and was thought to be a treasure of Center Township, but has fallen into disrepair and has been closed off by fences to prevent further vandalism.  A study was done around 2005 to spend $1.3 million to restore the stability of the Memorial, but even now there is little evidence that anything is happening.  This could be a great location for all types of events if restored.

There is another building that hosts functions, but it seems rather mundane compared to the Taggart.

One of the newer additions to the park was the Play 60 inspired playground/training equipment that is on the 24th street end of the park.  Colts logos and colors are prevalent throughout the area since the NFL is behind the Play 60 (minutes of exercise/activity each day) program.

I will admit that most of the equipment and shelters appeared to be in pretty good shape.  But like I've seen mentioned in reviews of other city parks, the convenience of having parking lots away from busy streets can attract adults engaging in inappropriate activities.  As I was driving by on a Sunday afternoon, a group of men had gathered in one of the street side lots and their behavior was offensive enough to keep me from stopping.  There is no way I would have wanted to take my grand kids to the park after seeing that behavior.  I can only hope it was an isolated event, but the fact that none of the other men stopped the offending individual was deterrent enough for me.

I truly believe this park has the space and basics for becoming a really good park.  But in the meantime, a little more police presence might be needed to make the park a bit more family oriented.

Review #714

Dr. Fontana's eye care practice is located in the offices above the shops at Hampton Village.   He is an awesome Optometrist.  He is very thorough and knowledgeable and just the sweetest guy ever.  His front office staff are professional and courteous.  A basic exam is $100, which is a little higher than some of the discount eye centers, but they work with most insurance companies and I feel that I am in competent hands here.  Great operation.  Highly recommended!

There was really one main reason for planning our trip to New Orleans and that was for the crawfish. I scoured the internet for some boils prior to our trip and we ended up at Urban South Brewery for theirs one evening. It turned out to be the best meal we had in NOLA! It was about $27 for 4 pounds of crawfish, corn, potatoes, and mushrooms, which was enough for me and my boyfriend to share. I probably could've eaten another serving because it was so good. The seasoning was amazing and everything was flavorful. I sucked all the heads! Unfortunately we don't get much crawfish in Michigan so I'll have to go back again.

The space at Urban South is very open and industrial with communal picnic table seating. The taproom is super kid friendly with books and activities available for kids. There's a retro airstream camper inside and a ton of very cool, unique merch. I loved the t-shirt with the sequin sleeves! I ended up getting a sticker to take home as a souvenir. The guy helping us with beer was great - he recommended the lime gose to pair with the crawfish and gave me a sample to try. It was a spot on choice and it went perfectly with my dinner. Can't wait to go back!

I don't feel any shame in admitting that this was my first experience with this chain. That is not to say that I was unfamiliar with it, but opted for more "authentic" spots when burrito etc. needs arose. After dining here I can better understand their popularity though.

Trish's steak burrito was huge and like everything else here, made to order. I found the beef to be a bit tough and am always turned off when protein is cubed into such consistent pieces. My chicken bowl was perhaps better. The poultry was tender and nicely seasoned with a Tex/ Mex blend. Again another great portion and more suited to a dinner than a lunch. A side of guac was ok, definitely not on par with most Mexican spots.

I would be all in favor of returning if convenience and serving size was my main concern. C's is definitely a good option in comparison with chains that serve similar grub. Maybe even the best option. I prefer to seek out more independent establishments where this type of food is not part of a business plan, but instead the backbone of their food culture. 3.25 still thinking about that whole cilantro fiasco Yelps

This warm and inviting space was exactly what we needed before starting our day each morning at the Don Cesar. Located on the ground level of the beautiful Don Cesar Hotel, this oasis of goodies and coffee is exactly what we needed and when we needed it. When you walk by Uncle Andy's Ice Cream Parlor, you can't help but feel pulled in by the sights of the brightly highlighted coffee and ice cream bar.

Once inside the shop, you're immediately surrounded by shelves and tables of snacks and goodies. They have just about everything you would need in one spot from breakfast and lunch sandwiches, which they heat up for you upon request, to chocolates, liquor, and snacks. There's definitely something for everyone at Uncle Andy's! 

The folks there are so helpful and accomodating, as they even offer to allow you to place your order with the restaurant next door and take it to go from Uncle Andy's! Right outside the doors of this amazing coffee shop is the courtyard leading to the beach. We carried our breakfast and coffee out toward the beach to the couches, where we enjoyed the sunrise and breakfast with a view. 

I highly recommend the Don Cesar, and frequent Andy's Ice Cream Parlor while you're there!

I've been here for conventions, volunteer events and for a stay-cation with old Marriott points (excellent rewards system- look it up) and I've been wowed every time. 

It's fun for conventions, as it has views of Victory Field and Lucas Oil (and I love when people from out of town get to take advantage of that!). Every event I've attended here has always run smoothly and without confusion. The hotel feels luxurious and I've been well taken care of each time.

The rooms are comfy and I've never had a problem with it being too noisy, despite all the events they host. The parking can be quite expensive, so be aware of that beforehand. 

Definitely recommend to your visitors!

For some reason I have to preface this with "we're only talking about a bar here"...
I haven't been to Skeeter's a lot. But I have been going for roughly 30 years... Enough to remember when it was no larger than a two bedroom, 1/2 bathroom little building!! Always a great place to fall into. But not the big bar with the large deck that it is now..
There's plenty of craft beer here, drinks and specials are worth the stop.. The menu.... Let me just say that these are probably the best cooked wings in South Jersey. The rest of the menu, by bar standards is very good. I've tried several items without being disappointed yet. 
The scene... You have the midweek, which is cool and laid back. You have your game nights.. Expect the place to be crowded. Then you have the weekend nights. I recently went on a Saturday just expecting to have an order of wings, a beer or two, then head home. I think people were parking at the Wawa across the street... Let's just say that after being carded and staring at the security for a few, I stepped into the joint, I entered to find a couple hundred of my kids inside... After making my way through my spawns dancing on every inch of space inside, luckily I found a seat at the bar... For the amount of people waving for drinks, the bartenders were doing an amazing job. I wound up having a drink or two with my wings before leaving after about an hour or so.. I told my oldest daughter about my brief stop to eat... She said "The older folks night is on Sunday, Dad"!! Okay, Okay... I got it. 
Not the same Skeeter's from years ago. But much better...  If I'm hungry for wings, it's Sunday nights from now on for me!!

The Tampa bay Rays are an excellent organization with many great players as well as coaches and front end staff. The Tamp Bay Rays, formerly known as the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, play at Tropicana Field. They are in the AL East Division of the MLB. Currently, the Tampa Bay Rays are 2nd in their division, just 1.5 games behind the New York Yankees. That indicates that they are a worthy team of having a large fan base. Unfortunatel, due to many people who live in Tampa being transplants, a large number of people come out to see and support their home teams which is evidenced by games against the Yankees, Red Sox, and the Orioles. Being a fairly new team, there aren't ideally as many loyal, dedicated fans.

This team may struggle with attendance at games due to the location of the Trop, being in St.Pete, however proposals to move the stadium to a more suitable and accessible location have been futile. Some people do not like the domed stadium but in and of itself it is a marvel and has no obstructing not columns and the seats all are positioned for optimal viewing experience. Being a New Englander the air-conditioned, astro-turfed venue creates a different experience however not a necessarily bad one. When you take the stadium and team for what they are The full baseball experience itself is great, the staff of Tropicana are very accompanying and pleasant and really put a solid effort into making sure that you enjoy your time and have a great experience. The staff really cares about kids and the team itself has kid-geared activities that will keep the little ones happy. Be sure to check out the sting ray tank, you can get up close and personal and pet sting rays in a tank which is a cool bonus. 

The Tampa Bay Rays organization and staff at the Trop work to ensure that their consumers have a great time and I appreciate that. Go Rays! #RaysUp

Strolled over on a lazy Saturday afternoon for some pub grub & to enjoy some outdoor seating in their cute side alley way. 

The Line Up:

Burger
Mozz Sticks
Sweet Potato Fries
Beer

The Verdict:

THE BURGER WAS SO GOOD. Homemade, cooked just right, nice fresh produce and a grilled bun...oh yes. yesssss.

Mozz sticks were awesome, marinara very good. The stick was ample and filled with no shortage of cheese. Yummy & hit the spot. Apparently, Mozz sticks are pretty easy to  screw up in my experiences.

Sweet Pot fries were delish. 

The beer selection was decent & I had a few samples. Our server was excellent and exhibited an awesome personality worth noting. 

Overall a very positive experience in every capacity.

Our waitress was great, helpful, always smiled, and always checked on us.  The restaurant is nice, and has a nice dog friendly patio.  But, I am sorry to say that I am a pizza snob. I'm from chicago, and I love pizza - deep dish, pan, thin crust. I love it with tons of sauce and flavor in the crust.  It's fine for me to ask for more sauce on the side. I just feel like the crust was nothing special to me. 

It's hard for me to find that in FL. I have found a couple places, but I can not say that this is the place.

Dropped off our car without an appointment (our bad) on a Friday AM for state inspection but did not get the car back until 4:30 PM on Sunday.  Youch.

Meanwhile they made all the minor repairs we needed and charged an OK price (Not great, not horrible).

Wish they were more timely.

Pizzzza Pizzza Pizzzza! For my friend's birthday, I got him a shirt that says "I run because (and theres a picture of Pizza)" because we both started running recently and he loves pizza. This is his favorite Pizza place. He goes at least once every couple weeks. So when I visited, I finally got to experience it after hearing about it all the time! I can see why he loves this place. The pizza really is amazing. I created my own pizza with Chicken, Sausage, and basil and it was amazing! I got the new york style with a thin crust and it was a great balance of crust and pizza. My friend got his usual: Pepperoni New York Style pizza. Both were actually super different, but great in their own ways. We each got smalls, so we had enough for 2 more pizza meals!

The inside has a great atmosphere with arcades and random retro fan collectibles on the walls. The servers were super nice and everyone is wearing masks with limited tables.

There is no better feeling than leaving Aldi with a sh*t-ton of groceries for less than a hundred bucks.  

This place keeps the costs low by doing a couple of unique things....the first is you have to "rent" a shopping cart if you want to use one...so be sure to bring a quarter.  Don't worry, you'll get your quarter back when you take your cart back to the front of the store and connect it to the other carts.  I freakin' love this because it is MY BIGGEST PET PEEVE at other stores when lazy-arse people leave their carts right next to their car when the cart corral is RIGHT BESIDE their car.  It really grinds my gears. 

The second thing that saves you dollars is they do not give out plastic grocery bags for free.  You can buy paper bags for 6 cents each or bigger plastic bags for 10 cents.  They also sell the reusable bags for like $2 I think.  You are welcome to bring your own bags from home, too.  After you check out they have a nice big counter where you can sort and bag your items before you head out to your car which is nice.  

They don't really have nationally-known brands here with the exception of Coca-Cola.  Every item I have tried is high quality and comparable to main brands, however.  The quality is high enough that you most likely will not miss your brand name items.  

Their produce is ridiculously cheap and makes it really easy to eat heathily on a budget.  They have a great meat selection, dairy aisle, bakery section, canned goods, dry goods, beverages, and a lot of hygiene items as well.  

I like keeping my dollars!  And I like high quality foods!   It's a win-win.

I was seriously intrigued to visit this little cafe because of its classic name & fashionable social media pics & posts, however I cannot strongly say that it lived up to the name. 

For starters "the breakfast culture club" has no real breakfast options. There are a couple delectable treats in their display case but nothing you could call a substantial or even healthy breakfast meal choice. 

The coffee was definitely fresh and did hit the spot but not my favorite by any means and really just an average Cup o Joe.

If you're looking for a totally rad hipster joint to spend an extra buck for a mediocre latte & get some cool pictures & free stickers in the process then this is your place.

Stadium Ranking: #13 out of 30.
 
   ---   ---   ---

Philadelphia was a unique stadium visit for me, in that, the game we attended was one that clinched the division for the Phillies. Maybe a sold out crowd and an electric atmosphere would make any venue better, but I do think Citizens Bank is a solid place to catch a game.

The only things I didn't like? I've never liked the video board out in the left field corner.

There's a lot more outfield seats, and not much of a view outside the stadium.

That's about it. 

Philly is the only city with all 4 sporting venues essentially sharing the same parking lot. I would imagine that all cities wished they had this luxury, as parking can be a major problem in some areas. Not in Philadelphia though... one gigantic parking lot for baseball, football, basketball, and hockey. And during our cool, September visit, it definitely felt like more of a tailgate for an Eagles game than anything. We threw the football with people in the parking lot, and crashed a few cookouts. Good times.

The outside of the stadium is full of baseball statues and team decor. Inside, this park has bette food options than I remember at most parks. I indulged on the Schmitter, which will basically guarantee me a heart attack by age 45.

The list of negatives is shrinking with every review as we approach the top of the rankings. CBP rounds out the 4-star stadiums!

Yes, it's adorable, but I've just gotta get this off my sugary chest: the cinnamon roll fell flat. Horribly flat. Pumped up to deification, with talk of being iced to order and comic strip steam swirls rising from the fresh-baked good. And it's not that it just wasn't legendary, it was actually extremely average.

Ok, bitter truths in the rearview, my breakfast bowl with house-made yogurt and granola, fresh seasonal berries and a drizzle of honey was top notch - tangy, sweet without being saccharine and those nutty, toasted grains balance the whole thing out. Nine bucks is a bit steep for a continental offeringm but I get it: you're artisan.

Also, the iced soy chai latte is better than most. Low water, quality soy milk, compostable cup with the most rigid straw X I've ever encountered. It actually broke two sippers before chipping a piece of itself into the drank. Fort Knox of lids.

Id been to the coffee shop next door a year ago and recently the desire for wings and pizza hit. Ao we dropped in for a few bites. Angey pig which had a load of pork and the baked wings were the fare. Pepperoni, salami, bacon, sausage goodness. The one problem was the outer crust was good but the center was a tad soft in the center. I think the cooking style has to adjust for this i think. Aside from that it's a solid pie and wings. Next time i try the hidden pig which has a garlic sauce instead

40 Minute Cleaners has been my go-to spot since I moved to Indy.  They're always timely and reliable, even when I bring in larger orders.  The prices are as good as they can be. (Question: has dry cleaning ever been cheap?)  I pay $6.50 for scarves, $20-$30 for blankets and comforters, and $13 for dresses.  I don't mind shelling out the cash knowing that things will look crisp and as-good-as-new when I when them up.  If you're looking for a fine dry cleaning place, you have my recommendation.

Five stars for the pasta, two stars for attention to detail.

Let me set the scene, we went to Indian Rocks beach for a socially distant two-year-old photo shoot for my son (gotta capture the memories). Since the shoot ended at 7 p.m. and my son goes to bed at 8:30 p.m., we decided we would grab takeout near the beach and feed him in the car on the way home. My son is on a solid diet of french fries. 

Instead of going to McDonalds (why support chains during this time), I looked up locally owned restaurants. That's how I came across Da Pollani's. I skimmed the menu and saw that their kid's meal chicken cutlets came with french fries. Forget the chicken cutlet, they had french fries so I was sold. 

After showing the menu to my husband, we decided that for three adults (my dad included) and one super picky eater, we would get: appetizer of Baby Octopus, Chicken Marsala, Fettucini Alfredo, Penne alla Vodka, Margherita Pizza, Eggplant Parmesan and the kid's meal Chicken Cutlets. Yes, we were expecting leftovers. 

I called the day of at 4 p.m. and put in the order to pick up at 7:15 p.m. 

I love that they have a pickup window. It was super easy to swing up and pay/grab the food. I did notice that none of the staff in the kitchen were wearing masks. The employee that handed me our bill was wearing gloves. 

Here's where things got a little dicey. The meal, plus tax and tip, came out to around $150. My husband said at that price he experts great service and I tend to agree (although I wish I could expect great service at any price point). They didn't give us an itemized bill so I was checking everything off the top of my head. 

First of all, they didn't give us the Margherita Pizza or the fries. Luckily I checked before leaving, so we swung back around. We found out that they no longer serve fries (I wish the woman on the phone told me that when taking our order, because that was the main reason we chose this place. Although I understand this isn't as big a deal for other people). They did give us the Margherita Pizza. However, upon leaving the second time, I realized they didn't give us our side caesar. 

I wish they paid more attention to our order to make sure we got everything. Since we live 45 minutes away, there was no point in going back for that caesar. Three things wrong with our order is a pretty high percentage. 

Onto the good things, the pasta is amazing. My favorite was the Fettucini Alfredo, which yes, I've since eaten cold and for breakfast. The Penne alla Vodka was also very good. My husband really liked the Chicken Marsala. It was hard to judge the pizza since it was lukewarm by the time we got home, but I love the thin crust and the seasoning. The baby octopus is a must get for me, it was tender and grilled perfectly. I wasn't a huge fan of the Chicken Cutlet, but it's made for kids, so that might be why it lacked more seasoning. 

Overall, the food is delicious, but like I said, the attention to detail is definitely missing. I would recommend this place, but you need to be on top of making sure your order is correct.

Um, yeah.  Still friggin' delicious.

Justin and I stopped by Pi before the Neko Case show at The Pageant (located conveniently across the street for all you concert-goers) this week and *finally* tried the deep dish pizza.  Now here's the thing--I grew up eating Chicago-style deep dish and I think I'm supposed to have some sort of loyalty to it because it's my home 'za, yo.  Kinda like so many St. Louisians inexplicably love Imo's.  Anyway, the point is, I've never been a huge fan of the belly bomb that is deep-dish pizza.  Too doughy, too much freakin' cheese (yes, indeed--there IS such a thing!)--I've just always preferred thin crust.

Well.  Smack my ass and call me a convert.

"It's the crust!"  I kept saying.  "No, it's the sauce!"  Justin countered.  Whatever it was, the deep-dish pizza at Pi is by far, hands down, the best thick crust I've ever eaten.  And I have eaten my fair share of it, people, usually begrudgingly.  No more.  I'd happily hightail it back to Pi to build another custom 'za... This time we enjoyed a pizza with the prerequisite tomato sauce and mozzarella, to which we added zucchini, tomatoes, feta and garlic.  Now, when we got the pizza I thought I spied a mushroom (which Lulu W. so aptly calls "slugs with gills" - yuck), but upon closer inspection it turned out to be a whole roasted clove of garlic!  Ohhhh, foodgasm.  So yeah, basically, this was the best pizza ever.  The cornmeal crust is crisp enough to stand up to the delicious sauce and just-right amount of cheese, and you can actually eat more than one slice (this I've not done before).  

Yup, I'm changing my tune on the whole deep dish issue.  Sorry, Chi-town.  You still rule my heart, but Pi holds a special place in my belly.

Since we had a full lunch, decided to stop here.

Just ordered the Caesar salad, and the hubby got a tuna  melt.

Staff is always attentive, today we had Josephine.

We also have had Wes, who is just as attentive.

It's close, clean and Covid compliant.

There are a lot of shops in this mall but only on the second floor.  The first floor seemed to consist only of the restrooms (which were run down).  The shops had some cute items but were over priced!  There was also a food court but no one seemed to be eating here.  There was one lady, that managed one of the food court shops, that was throwing lettuce onto the tables to feed the birds (a few birds had flown into this building and are basically trapped).  We were thankful for the use of the free public restrooms, but that was pretty much the reason why we came and did not stay here.

Sometimes the big box home improvement stores don't carry the parts or tools that I need, and when that's the case I will often stop by Ace Hardware.

This particular store is located on Gunn Highway, north of Sickle High School, and in the shopping center at S. Mobley Road. It's north of Westchase and the Citrus Park area by 5 - 10 minutes.

The store is not huge, but they manage to have the right size of socket wrench for fixing my car, or the right shade of gold paint to cover the stripes on your mailbox post (Helloooooooooooooo Westchase Homeowners' Association members!!!), or the correct type of sprinkler head to replace the one that the lawn maintenance guy broke off.

Great selection, with wonderful customer service!

I've thought long and hard for the past 3 years about my most recent hair decision - that is longer than I've thought about any one of my tattoos, or purchasing my car, or going to college out of state. I say all of that to make the point it was a big deal that I finally just went for it and...drumroll...permed my hair.

To preface the rest of this review, I will say I had zero color on my hair when I did this, which allowed the perm to take really well. I showed my stylist, Tisha, dozens of photos of perms that I loved and plenty of photos of what I did not want (I was terrified of looking like I stepped out of a 1980's rom-com). She knew exactly what it was I was going for. She incorporated lots of different size rods throughout the perm to give it a really natural look, which totally worked. I didn't expect it to turn out exactly like I wanted...but it did!! And I am so excited about it.

The whole appointment took about 2.5 hours and consisted of getting my hair washed...A LOT. As she styled and dried my hair, she gave me the full scoop on how to care for my perm (what shampoos/conditioners to use, how to blow-dry it,  how often to get a trim, and when she thought I should come back to touch it up.) I'm so thankful she did, because I'm already finding that curly hair is a heck of a lot different to care for/style than my natural locks. Her perms cost $140, which is a price I am more than happy to pay for her experience and expertise (she's been doing hair for over 30 years and did perms when they were in style).

I left the salon giddy about my new hairstyle. I'm so glad I finally did this and I am SO thankful I came to Tisha for it. It turned out better than I could have ever hoped for! Thank you, Tisha!

An interesting attempt at an urban park, this space of riverside New Orleans starts just downstream of the French Quarter and extends a substantial distance down, containing a path bordered by some greenery and various abandoned warehouses and docks, some of which have been retrofitted into event/workout spaces, and others of which are still abandoned.

What's odd about it is that train tracks run parallel to the river, so one has to cross a bridge over the tracks to get to or even see the park. The Western bridge has elevators, but the central one does not (still haven't gotten to the downriver end). There are lights, one set of bathrooms and other modest amenities, but the park doesn't quite seem to be flourishing, if I compare to what's been done with riverside spaces in other cities I've lived in. It also seems a tad scary to me that if you were here at odd hours and had to call the police, they'd have a heck of a time getting to you. I'd stick to scheduled events and clear daylight hours.

I don't think anyone would accuse this stretch of the Mississippi river of being exceptionally beautiful, and the park has some work to do to offer more for visitors, but there is definitely value in being able to catch the breeze off the water and doing so somewhere quieter than the touristy areas upriver.

Quite possibly the best photographer you'll find in the St. Louis area. Joel Conner has photographed many events for me in the past and has been incredibly reliable and consistent -- he usually shot the events himself, but if he was already booked, he would gladly send someone else in his spot. Photos turned out brighter and better than the others, and I'm not sure how he gets such great shots but I wasn't ever let down! I always had the photos in hand less than a few days later in easy file formats.

No strings photographer willing to shoot weddings, kids photos, events, and pretty much whatever you need. Plus he's an all-around great guy! Give Joel a shout for all of your photo opportunities.

Sonam is definitely a cool enigma. It's tucked away in part of South Street that I've been going to for years (right where a horrible CD store used to be. But it's like nothing else on South Street that I've ever experienced making it stand on it's own.

After having a super sized sampling of their menu last night I definitely having a craving more. there were some things like the goat cheese smores that scared me a little. But the Hamachi Nachos, Gumbo Spring Rolls, and Chicken Sliders were nothing short of amazing. throw in the posh decor and attentive service and you have a winning combo. I really can't wait to go for a meal and find out what it's like with tables.

The place that I works for owns the building that Jones is in. So they have an agreement where all the people who work here get a meal every month that's paid for by the company. otherwise I don't think I'd ever eat here.
Stephen Starr restaurants are all top of the line, and it's usually no exception here as far as the ingredients. But Stephen Starr's take on mashed potatoes, meatloaf, turkey sandwiches, and other traditional meals are a little too much for me. If I want to go for a Starr Restaurant , I'll go for the flair and spice of Morimoto or Buddakhan any day of the week. But if I want a chicken sandwich and a bowl of French onion soup I'll go to a diner or somewhere like Silk City at the very highest. Jones' seafood selection is pretty damn good though. 
and while Alex M. is right about the staff being attractive (I think it must be an unspoken requirement judging from all the Starr restaurants), the service is usually hit or miss with here.

This has been one of my favorite stops in St. Louis. While in town for a work conference my manager arranged a family-style dinner at Reeds. We were seated upstairs in a dimly-lit room that conveyed cozy despite us having ample space. Our group had a case of the giggles and a touch of the ridiculous about us so it's best for all involved that we were seated away from the main dining area downstairs. 

Everything I tried was amazing (really), so I'll just go ahead and walk you through our menu:

+ Bacon-fat-fried cornbread with thyme butter and honey: we could have stopped here with a pan of this cornbread and I'd have slapped a five-star rating on it

+ Veggie toast: I can't remember what all was on it, but it was so tasty. My coworker was kind enough to split his with me because the toast for the table had mushroom and bone marrow, neither of which I was interested in ingesting. I'm not a vegetarian [as evidenced by my ode to that bacon fat cornbread above], but I'm sure if I had spoken up when we received our menu for the evening they'd have happily made me the veg alternative. 

+ The best salad of all time: kale, roasted squash, pepitas, bacon, feta, and maple juniper dressing. When I read the description I was kind of "meh" because in general I'm not a big fan of kale, maple, or things that taste like gin. This combination though - I can't. They brought us an enormous bowl and we had more than enough so I wish I'd taken more. The chew of the squash with the crispy, salty bacon and the sweetness of the dressing was perfection. Hot tip for other kale salads: chiffonade your leaves so it can be chewed in a reasonable amount of time and effort. 

+ Roasted cauliflower: simple, delicious.

+ Polenta with goat cheese, honey, and toasted walnuts: basically a dessert before dessert. The polenta was perfectly creamy and the nuts added the needed crunch. It came in a huge bowl and I could not stop laughing at how it jiggled when moved. 

+ Chocolate tart with brown butter caramel, hazelnuts, and fresh whipped cream: so rich, and so delicious. I have a major sweet tooth but I couldn't finish my slice. If I hadn't had the polenta I probably could have done it. I was full by the time dessert rolled around but I wasn't about to pass up such a lovely end to the meal. 

A beet salad and porchetta were also served but I did not partake - they both looked beautiful but I was maxed out on food and I don't think I'd be able to handle the fattiness of the porchetta. We also had our choice of wine. 

Reeds helped set the stage for a perfect dinner with my coworkers - they took what was sure to be a good evening and made it excellent.

I love this park!

My son has a summer birthday and I knew I wanted a park with a splash pad to help beat the heat.  I called the city and the parks and rec employee recommended Ballast Point Park.  Great recommendation!

It's only $50ish to rent the shelter for the whole day.  They have grills at each shelter and they are in close proximity to the playground and splash pad.  There are also bathrooms at this park - a must for toddlers.

The playground is pretty large and has some fun slides.  The splash pad is pretty nice too.  This park also has a restaurant with fresh seafood and ice cream.  The views can't be beat here as it is right on the water!

Ballast Point is a beautiful park with a lot of amenities to enjoy!  Check it out.

I'm not a fan of the Tampa Bay sports teams - Buccaneers, Rays, Lightning - but I thought I'd stop by here and see what they have. And they do have a lot of those teams and also the local college teams. 

Stock is good, prices are clearly marked and cheaper likely cheaper than what you'd pay at the game though I am sure they are less expensive elsewhere. Still, if you need a hat or a tshirt or a sweatshirt with your team's logo all over it, this is the spot.

[Review 10425 overall, 192 of 2019.]

Delicious, fun and way too much food. Pho Street is a cafeteria style self serve self clear Vietnamese fast-food restaurant featuring the classic Vietnamese favorite dishes of pho, broken rice and bun style dishes. They don't serve classic Vietnamese coffee just the ice coffee pre-mixed version.

Service - automated 4/5
It's a little confusing b/c the entire menu isn't posted anywhere and the payment process is a bit awkward. You order through a kiosk and then wait for your number to be called. I recommend staking out the tables closet to the serving area because those bowls of steaming soup are huge and the ramp taking you to the main dining room is daunting especially when attempting to walk the gauntlet with a giant slipping around bowl of boiling hot pho!

Human Service :) 5/5 
The human part of the service is when they call your number and you pick up your order and they're very nice there. 

Food...
Pho with eye round & meatballs 4/5
The soup was flavorful and the eye round was good. The meatballs are quite tough and rubbery. I'd probably not order the meatballs again.

Pho with brisket, eye round & sirloin 4/5
Work bestie ordered the above and she enjoyed everything except the brisket which was well overly brisket-y.

Ice Vietnamese coffee 3/5
The cup is only filled halfway and at $4/serving that's like a $1/1.5 oz which is steep especially since it's not made to order and reminded me of melted coffee ice cream good but not $4 good. We could have gone across the street to Trader Joe's and purchased a pint of coffee ice cream for the same price. 

If we go again we will share one order of soup. It was more than enough for two people and at $11/bowl I'd rather share it. 

In summary:
So if you avoid the brisket, meatballs and ice Vietnamese coffee and stick with the other options you'll have a 5/5 experience.

Thai Orchid of Blue Bell is a beautifully appointed Siamese restaurant on DeKalb Pike in the wonderfully named town of Blue Bell, PA. It is one of those places where the environment is so rich in southeast Asian colors, textures and artistry, that it is possible to eat the atmosphere. From woodcuts to tapestry the space is relaxed and mellow enough to have you believing you've stepped into a palace in Chiangmai. 

I was there for late lunch after a meeting in Norristown. The shop sits in a strip center, the last door on the far right. Don't be put off by that or you'll miss all the magic. There was only one other customer dining when I arrived and was taken to a table on a raised platform that held most of the tables. The menu was full of Thai delights, and lunch combo specials that included soup, appetizer and main entree, for around $10 and change. That seemed the way to go to sample a few things and get more bang for the buck. I went with the Thai Ravioli Soup (wonton), Veggie Roll and Drunken Noodles. 

Believe me, it was a huge amount of food. The soup was vegetable based broth with fancy goldfish wonton filled with ground shrimp and chicken. It had a mild sesame oil flavor and tasted fresh and pleasing. The roll was deep fried with a filling of mixed vegetables, glass noodles and a small dish of sweet & sour dipping sauce. It was good, but a tad over fried.

 The drunken noodle was a large plate full of medium width noodles (not jumbo), loaded with chunky onions, bell peppers, green beans, fresh basil, thin sliced beef and moderately hot Thai spices. I asked for it to be very chilified, but it was still pretty tame. It seems that regardless of what you ask for on the heat scale, it is interpreted as only moderately spicy. How you actually get the "Very spicy yet Bearable," fire level is beyond me. Here, it cost them a star for failing to honor my clear direction. 

Aside from the width of the noodles and the lack of burn, this was a very satisfying meal, and enough to keep me sated for the rest of the day. The decor and food together make Thai Orchid of Blue Bell a worthy stop for quality exotic cuisine. It would be even better if they paid closer attention to what was being requested.

This nearly 100-year-old bakery serves very good cannolis! The chocolate chip ricotta cannolis are freshly piped into the shells, which sit in a pile waiting to be ordered and served. It is definitely quite sweet, but the shells are nice and crunchy. The ricotta is super creamy, and even a little dense, especially with the chocolate chips. It is on the expensive side, $4, but it is a big, hefty cannoli. You might want to share it. I'd definitely come back to try some of their other baked goods lined up beautifully behind the display case.

For nine years St. Pete Beach has been the Florida beach of choice for my family in the Spring. Usually the trips are for swim meets that my son participates in. Sometimes I can sneak in a trip in between and that was a recent treat. It's one of the nicest family friendly beaches in the country in my opinion. 

I typically park at North Shore Park. Plenty of space on non event days and it's FREE! It's directly off the beach and well maintained. 

So why a 5 stars? Because it has everything you could possibly ask for in a perfect beach. Gorgeous sunrises, clean water and beach, restrooms, volleyball, concerts and of course fishing. If there is a drawback it's lack of lifeguards in all areas. Parents supervise your children at all times. 

If you have been to St. Pete Beach you understand my excitement. If not I would recommend you plan a visit. Even during the Winter temps are wonderful. I plan on making this a 10th this year.

I was invited to someone's house for brunch.  The host made all this great food.  I got there and it looked like a house in the neighborhood.  After walking in, someone asked me to sit at a table and was told,  "help yourself".   There was crunchy yummy fried chicken, batter fried catfish and remoulade, vegetables,  mac n cheese,   supreme seafood gumbo (it was so supreme I went back 4 times, ha ha ha, yummy), tasty rice and beans with andouille and a bread pudding.  I had 3 pieces of chicken, Lil Dizzy's hot sauce, lots of rice n beans, lots of mac n cheese, 4 bowls of seafood gumbo, veggies, bread, biscuit, catfish and remoulade sauce and 2 servings of bread pudding.  Like Thanksgiving,  I ate like there was no tomorrow.    How did I eat that much I dunno.   Like Thanksgiving, I paced myself and my politeness overcame my desire to take a nap in the back somewhere. In the end when I was about ready to leave,  someone gave me a bill.  I couldn't believe it.   I sat in disbelief, I pinched myself to make sure I was not dreaming.  What?  A Bill?
  
I've never had an experience where the food was homestyle  Louisianna kick me in the pants good.  I was appalled I had to pay because I honestly swear I was invited to this house, LOL  This place is not a restaurant it looks like  a house in the neighborhood.  It's just not right to be invited to the best meal at someone's house  and have to pay.  Life is not fair.  What a great experience this was, LOL,  I was a Li'l Dizzy walking outta there.

This ballpark is spacious, and an improvement over Veteran's Stadium. It's clean, there are plenty of seating, lots of bathrooms, screens are clear, there's a selection of eateries and bars, plus easy access from the highway.

During sold-out events it gets PACKED, so be sure to give yourself time and arrive early. Traffic can be murder before and after events.

Of course, all the concession stands are expensive (I guess you're making concessions by using them), and generally not very good. On the bright side, credit cards are pretty much accepted everywhere, so getting ripped off is streamlined.

Last May, my buddies and I were treated like kings at this French Market nugget. When I returned to New Orleans over the weekend, there was no doubt in my mind that we would return. And as no surprise to me, the food was absolutely dynamite. 

Thousands of locals, tourists and foodies stroll by Mother Nature's Cupboard every single day missing out on a flavor ecstasy for the ages. I had to convince travelers to dine here. There are only five seats at the counter, but it's located at the heart of the French Market. You can easily walk and talk with your meal. Scratch that, eating here is like attending church, it's a sacred experience.

I'm flabbergasted that most people decide on the rather Americanized meals, instead of indulging the local flavor. C'mon tourists, you can eat a hamburger and fries anywhere, but can you get Crawfish Mac n' Cheese or Deep Fried Corn anywhere? No, not like this.  

Hands down, the most flavorful Mac n' Cheese I've ever eaten. Large, meaty pieces of spicy crawfish fill the cracks of the tender pasta, which is completely smothered in a creamy, rich cheese sauce that will resurrect your taste buds. And Deep Fried Corn? But, how? There are no time for questions folks, just time to munch on crunchy fried corn that will make you as ecstatic as a kid in a candy store. 

I remembered the man behind the counter from last year. I'm not sure he remembered me, but we did share a look. One of those looks where you can tell he appreciated your business, because he could tell you were humbled by a great New Orleans meal. Maybe I'm crazy, but maybe you should unstrap your visor a bit, take a deep breath, and experience true local essence. Mother Nature's Cupboard won't be on a Best of New Orleans Food List, but go out of your way to find this pearl.

Why 5 stars? Because it's a shame it took me so long to come here.

   ---   ---   ---

After restaurants reopened, I've made a concentrated effort to visit places that I've had bookmarked for years and just never went to for some reason. 1200 Chophouse was the final local bucket list spot to check off. Don't get me wrong, there are still places I want to visit, but I'm talking about only the top, top tier of restaurants that I've really always wanted to check off. Other new places will open, but as of now, I feel like I've pretty much been everywhere. And I saved a good one for "last".

This time around, Anna M made sure to set her alarm properly, so we arrived a few minutes before 5pm on a Saturday when doors open. We were the 2nd people in line, but by 5:00 on the dot, there were several other customers ready to enter. After only a few minutes of being seated, pretty much every table was occupied. We arrived at 5p because I have a young child at home and I wanted to help with bedtime, but I'm glad we came when we did, because otherwise we would have been in quite the wait. When we walked out around 6:30p, there were many people waiting - some sitting on the couches outside near the road.

This part of my review is not an indictment of 1200 Chophouse - they are simply following the rules. The rules are 10/10 silly. You must have a mask on inside, unless you're seated at the table. The dining room is not large at all -¬†it was about 8-12 feet from the doorway to our table and another 8-12 feet from our table to the bathroom. So we put on our masks, took about 6 steps, sat down at our table and talked/ate/drank for 90 minutes with no mask on -¬†like every other patron. When I got up to the bathroom, I had my mask on for the 6 steps in route to the single person toilet room. Again, mask on for the 6 steps back to the table. And finally, mask on for the 6 steps out the door. At one point, a server asked a man to put his mask on. The man said, "what about all of these people?" The server said, "they are seated and dining. So he literally grabbed the bar chair that was within arms reach and sat down. Standing? Mask needed. Sitting down, 10 inches to the left? No mask necessary. Again - nothing against 1200 Chophouse, they don't want to get shut down. But the rules themselves? It's just good science.

Onto the food...

We started off with steak frites and bacon wrapped scallops. The scallops were the highlight of the evening. The smokiness of the bacon complemented the bacon perfectly - I wish I could eat these every day. The streak frites were delicious and the sauce was ideal, but the bacon wrapped scallops stole the show.

Anna and I shared the prime bone-in ribeye special and upgraded to oscar style. This worked out well, as they evenly split the plate for us and removed the bone, but still brought it out for us. We both enjoyed the steak very much. The only gripe I had is that oscar style kind of overwhelmed the flavor of each bite and took away from the natural steak flavor. If I were to return, I'd maybe do a traditional surf and turf where the seafood is separated from the steak.

The bread and honey butter that came with it was amazing and the salads were great too. I opted for a loaded baked potato as my side dish, which came with big clumps of butter and sour cream to add at my leisure. I added. A lot.

I'd definitely love to come back again, especially for future special occasions. This was definitely one of my favorite dining experiences in the St. Pete Beach area!

Why 2 stars? Because the menu change is for the worse.

   ---   ---   ---

I really love Oxford Exchange.

And I really loved OE Market.

But this new Mexican theme is just.... rough. Here's how it works:

As we're used to know with a lot of taco/burrito places, you pick the type of tortilla, the protein, and the veggies in a 3-step process.

One problem right off the bat is that only the most sophisticated produceista would know what the ingredients are, and what they taste like. I'm a pretty darn adventurous eater, so it's not so much the mystery, but more that I have absolutely no idea what any of these items are. A brief description on the menu board would go a long way. Here's the current process without menu descriptions:

-Walk up to counter

-Have absolutely no idea what you want because the menu is confusing

-Ask the girl behind the counter about 2-3 ingredients

-Feel unsatisfied as you still want to ask about several more items, but don't want to be that dumb that you don't know basically all of the items

-Feel pressured to hurry up and make a decision

-Eventually make a choice, albeit rushed and uninformed

So the ordering process isn't great, and I'm sure the employees get tired of defining what "Ancho Creme" and "Bustered Shishitos" are. But how's the food?

Maybe combining the preceding two ingredients with pork in a corn tortilla was a bad choice? But this was probably the worst tasting meal I've had in at least two months. Unfortunately, the flour tortilla was no better.

I just don't get the angle unfortunately. It's near UT, so they want to appeal to college kids... but the menu says hoity-toity. Still, the tacos are affordable at $3-$4, so I guess that makes sense. What doesn't make sense are the $10-$12 juices that are still being sold here. I tried one because, well, I figured a $12 juice had to be pretty amazing. Instead, it was unfortunately the opposite. Kind of watery, and hard to finish. I would have felt that I overpaid at $2.

I hate giving negative reviews, but I just can't really avoid it in this situation.
Leave the gun, take the cannoli...

On a flight my seat mate told me about Pub & Kitchen. The name stuck, so I grabbed a friend and gave it a go.

A "no reservations" policy meant a small wait before we were seated.

Even during the day, the Pub's darker than I'd like, but there's sidewalk seating for the nyctophobic. Besides a gigantic bar, this restaurant has comfortable stylings, subtle rabbit and pig imagery all about. Despite the crowd inside and out, server Laura managed to keep us buzzed.

We shared fresh kusshi oysters (at market price, which we all know is scary markup), before moving onto a bowl of Thai basil mussels. For an entree, I had a pan-fried pork cutlet, not bad, not too dry, with a decent amount of flavor. Table bread was so-so, but we spent more time on their other yeasty treats: a Yards "brawler" pub ale and a pint of Sly Fox served nicely.

What a disaster!  Absent effective management, the majority of the staff were hiding in the kitchen doorway and doing nothing to help one waitress who was struggling to keep up with the lunch crowd. Pure laziness!  

Both of our meals were prepared incorrectly. My burger showed up without the spread mentioned in the menu and the wife received cold fries. Both corrections took forever. We were sure that our poor waitress had to go peel some potatoes for the replacement fries based on how long it took. 

Once the hot fries arrived they tasted pretty good. Once a small cup of the sauce for their signature burger arrived it also tasted pretty good, although it was cold by that time. 

Yes, they share a name with two pretty good places I frequent. No, this location doesn't have any business being associated with those other two brewpubs. 

Final note: we asked for the manager to deliver our check so we could rip his/her head off for the crappy experience. Guess what...no manager around because he/she was attending to some other location at the airport. 

Our poor waitress got a decent tip because it very clearly wasn't her fault. Disengaged management and a complete lack of employee motivation made this an expensive place to have a crappy experience.

This place is not the worst option..BUT wouldn't be my first choice.

Came here for a business launch with coworkers for Cinco De Mayo. They did a great job accommodating our group of 10. The service was slow in the beginning but later picked up. They started us off with the typical complimentary chips and salsa. Chips was fresh and hot and the salsa was great. It tasted authentic with the right amount of heat. I like that they gave each person their own salsa bowl.  

I ordered the Fajitas Mariscos. (tilapia, shrimp, and scallops)  I really didn't enjoy it much. They over saut√©ed the veggies making them all brown and mushy. It's was also saturated with the "sizzling" oil on the hot skillet causing it to cook further and even burn the bottom pieces a bit. This place was given a solid 3 star consensus around the the table.  The group did order a few pitchers of margaritas that seem to be a hit.

My favorite meal in NOLA.

Came with a group of 10 and had Gara as our server.  Gara was delightful - dropping little nuggets of information about the restaurant, the town, and the menu items without being intrusive.  

They have a 3 course prix fixe for $39 that's an amazing deal given the portion sizes.  I had the gumbo, pecan crusted baby drum and tried the creme brulee and bread pudding.  Everything was delicious.  

Also, if you have a sweet tooth and want to try what's essentially an alcoholic milkshake, you have to try their brandy milk punch.

It's very centrally located to go out and have fun afterwards.  The restaurant is supposedly haunted, as well!

Visiting Santa Barbara was just about the best thing we needed after being cooped up, quarantine style, for months. 

Santa Barbara was quite busy on a Saturday in August. Apparently other people had the same idea about getting out. The weather was warm, but the cool beach breeze made up for it. We opted for Bluewater Grill due to the reviews and the amount of outdoor seating available. 

We were lucky enough to get the second story terrace spot which gave us beautiful views of the Pacific Ocean and beach. The sun was hot, but the multiple umbrellas provided a nice respite. 

I opted the for Lobster Roll. They asked if I wanted it chilled or warmed, being that it was a hot day a chilled lobster roll hit the spot. It came brimming with succulent lobster on a toasted roll. Paired with a spicy bloody mary it hit the spot!

I'm constantly on a diet.  It is so-called the "See-Food" diet. Healthy food and I are not good friends whatsoever! 

At work, when we order pizzas, we always order a ton. Top Tomato serves fresh and tasty ingredients on the traditional and more creative pizzas.

The usual: One Buffalo chicken, one Philadelphia steak, one vegetarian delight, and one meat Lover's (not my favorite but loved by everyone else). Each one of us can probably eat 6 slices in one sitting. That's how much everyone enjoyed the pizzas. Very much!!
Another thing you don't want to miss by not ordering is the cheesesteak. Personally, I think they make the BEST cheesesteak, and I blame them for every time I crave a delicious cheesesteak. Luckily, I live close by, even though my waistline keep screaming. 



Pro Tip: 
**This is an excellent to-go/ delivery pizza, I never dined there. The customer service is a hit or miss. Improvement needed. 
** In my opinion, don't get a slice of pizza. I prefer the fresh, made-to-order pizza. Don't forget this is my under-the-radar cheesesteak spot, so give it a try!

Three and half Yelps

We were in Wesley Chapel for a gymnastics meet and thanks to Yelp we found the Noble Crust.  I'm not really big on chain restaurants but this location is great.  We made reservations for a table of 10 and when we arrived our table was ready with a "reserved" sign and we had no wait. 

All of the items we had on the menu were really great.  We started with the meatballs and were really impressed.  They are a beef and pork blend and they were so juicy and savory especially with a dollop of ricotta on top.

The fried green tomatoes and crispy brussel sprouts would make any kid eat their veggies.  Both were excellent.  Of course the kids did devour the truffle fries but who wouldn't.

Being in a Pizza place of course we have to order their pizza so we got the Noble Pig which came topped with pepperoni, sweet fennel sausage, spicy soppressata, pickled peppers, caramelized onions, tomato sauce, fontina, parm, and sunny side up egg.  All i have to say is WOW it was a cornucopia of 2,000 calorie deliciousness.  

Overall the service and food here were awesome. I would definitely recommend coming here for a great meal if you are in the Wesley Chapel area.

Ahh...I absolutely love coffeeshops!  It brings me back to my graduate and undergraduate days as well as high school!

Anywho,living in Mid-City I try to support local (although Starbucks your soy chai lattes are pretty friggin awesome but CC's has changed their chai and it's driving me nuts!).  This is my idea of an eclectic coffeeshop.  I remember when Rue de la Course is where the Rum House currently resides.  People were allowed to smoke and there were banker's lamps on each table.

Well, Fair Grinds, you had me at banker's lamps.  Plus, they have an outdoor seating area which I have yet to try.  I'm a night owl so you won't see me out and about before 11am on a weekend unless I'm going to church or forced to leave puttering in my apartment.  Plus, bonus that they are open later than PJ's so I'm all about it!  I even ran into my favorite waitress from Nonna Mia there (ok so I eat at Nonna Mia alot to have a relationship with the waitress, manager, and other waiters! hehe).  She also gave me the FYI that Zotz on Oak is open even later if I can't get everything done in time.  Good to know!

I also enjoy that Fair Grinds is located in the mix, it's on the same street as Cafe Degas, Canseco's, Maple Street bookstore, Swirl, and a salon that I haven't frequented yet.  There is street parking.

Also, the staff are friendly, there is only one unisex bathroom, adorable outdoor seating, free wifi, and a delicious soy chai latte!

Am happy to have found a neighborhood! 

Happy coffee coffee drinking!

Chose Retro, because its one of the closer full size gyms in my hood. 

I did plan in going in and purchasing a membership, but saw there was a groupon deal; I believe it was a little over $200 for a year. Been pumping iron at retro for about a month and I really like this gym. People keep to themselves and are polite with machines and weights. 

There are plenty of free weights and usually not too many people. Also there are tons of cardio machines, I have never had to wait. 

As an added bonus this gym has a movie cardio room, its a nice and darker less people to look at you running on a hamster wheel.

Worst hotel I've ever stayed at. The hallways are very depressing. The layout of the hotel is very odd, it took 10 minutes to get to our room from the lobby. We were happy to see a Starbucks inside hotel next to lobby, but sad to find out they clise at 1pm. 

The housekeeper was fighting verbally with soMeone on her phone and as were walking to our room, you can hear EVERYTHING thru the door, and the door was closed. The smell was unpleasant all the way from the hall and in our room. 

The views are amazing as we did have a corner unit, but it was very sad staying there. The tub was oxidized,  the towels had holes and showed lots of wear and tear. I was disgusted to even take my shoes off. 

Luckily we were just passing thru on our way back to Dallas from Chicago and only needed one night, but NEVER ever again. 

The valet was a joke. The young guys they have are nice and we're very polite, but the way the system works for valet is unbelievable. When you want to request your car, you cannot call or text, you actually have to take the elevator DOWN one floor to the hot stuffy basement and hand your ticket to the guys working there. Then it gets WORSE, they ask you to wait in their "waiting room" which is disgusting, smells awful and has rust and sticky stuff all over the floors. 

Plus it's $40.00 for this overnight so called valet service. This side of St. Louis looks run down, old, abandoned and very depressing. The only thing good is the view of the St. Louis Arch but for $360.00 a night it is not worth it.

Everything is dated.

Tucson, AZ:  Sonoran Desert immersion, YESS!

First time visiting. Despite the forecast in 90sF, and a late start, we loved our drive along the eight mile, paved Cactus Forest Drive. Limited pullouts and parking along this road. Too hot for hiking but the scenery is outstanding for the rich variety of local cacti and wildflowers, set against the Rincon Mountains. The unique Saguaro Cactus is only found in the Sonoran Desert.

The Visitors Center is located outside the park gate with free parking. Wonderful short video, and informative displays provide an overview of the park. Rangers available to answer any questions. A must stop for visitors visiting Tucson.

I visited Uptown Car was on my lunch break. I was out of there in 20 minutes. 

I treated my vehicle to a basic wash $14 well worth it. The system that they've implemented for detailing cars seems to work well during slow peak times i.e. 1p-3p. 

I am sure the weekends are pretty jam packed but that should be expected.

This was another great location.  It's definitely a larger-sized one with plenty of equipment and a nice sized room for classes.  I'm not sure how old this location is but everything still looks almost brand new.  The equipment here is the Precor brand.  I counted around eight treadmills.  For cardio they also have a stair climber machine, which isn't common at Anytime Fitness locations.  The dumbbells and fixed weight barbells go up to 110 pounds instead of the standard 100 pounds.  There's a smith machine and a power rack in the free weight area.  The large room for group classes had multiple cycles for spinning classes.  These Riverview Anytime Fitness locations are the only ones I've seen that have that option available for people.  Pretty cool considering that many Anytime Fitness locations don't have a separate room like this in the first place!  Little things this location has that I wish every one would have: vending machines that take credit cards and a way to recycle your water bottle.  It's located two miles from I-75 so it's another convenient option for me when I'm passing by here.
