Uber thanks to Bridgette C. for organizing a fantastic Happy Hour Party at William Collier's just before the Yelp Spring Break Event: It's Spring Break Y'all Party next door at Marathon Music Works. There was ample seating, 2 for 1 draft beer specials, and for the hungry & tired like myself, an amazing soft drink, fancy hot dog & chip special for only $8!  

It was really great to mix & mingle with many Yelpers from across the country in a quiet atmosphere with no worries about missing the #1 YSB huge event because it was just thru the VIP entrance to the left of the bar.  We Yelpers pretty much took over the entire bar area, closest high top tables, and of course took all available outlets to plug in our phone chargers to do our real time Yelp check-ins & photo uploads.

Decent food & drink specials, really fun times, and meeting superb new friends, all with our fabulous hostess  - Bridgette C!!!!

Maybe it's because I'm not a morning person. But after paying for my Apple Kale Smoothie, I expected it to take the same amount of time as the other customers. I paid for my smoothie and bag of chips and a bottle of water, then proceeded to wait for my smoothie while munching on the bag of chips. I noticed the girl finished making the smoothie for the flight attendant ahead of me, then started washing the used items. I figured she was just cleaning when I realized that she had no intention of making my smoothie. She then started to clean around the cash register and restocking donuts. As I finished my bag of chips and had been waiting 5 minutes, I finally asked if my Apple Kale Smoothie was ready. The blonde girl making smoothies seemed to have heard this order for the first time and asked Marlene at the register if she had heard about this. Excuse me??

She finally made my smoothie and I assumed she was multi-tasking because she began tidying up around the register again. As soon as she came out from behind the counter and started tidying up the snack display when I snapped. The smoothie was sitting untouched in the blender. I asked whether my smoothie was ready basques my flight had started boarding. Finally, the lady manning the register finally poured it into a cup and handed it to the blonde girl to hand to me. 

I don't understand whose responsibilities are what but what happened is not ok. Unfortunately, a survey was not available to me on the receipt, otherwise I would have made sure the young blonde's behavior was not acceptable in any situation. 

In other news, my smoothie was a little sweet but tasted fine.

So far, I have not been too impressed with the food trucks in Nashville. So, with no real expectations in mind I went over to The Hot Spot trailer while they were parked at Turtle Anarchy. I had never heard of them before this so with the 'deer in the headlights' look I approached cautiously. The person behind the counter offered some suggestions. Their Twisted Chicken, with Jamaican jerk spice and Asian hot sauce, it's Sriracha. I don't know why they don't mention it by name, it's like calling Guinness 'Irish stout from the St. James brewery.' I don't think I've met someone who doesn't love Sriracha so no need for euphemisms.

Anyway, it was $7 for two big pieces of their chicken, spiraled with Sriracha and a separate container containing their fennel slaw. I've been similarly unimpressed with hot chicken but once I sat back down at the bar and opened the container it was a flaky, spicy, but still tasty piece of chicken. The hot chicken I've gotten was just heat but with very little flavor. The chicken, while sweat pouringly, mouth burningly spicy was still really tasty. I kept biting into it thinking 'oh man this is good' while wiping my face on my sleeves, careful to avoid rubbing my eyes with any heat. The random smoothness of the Sriracha with the spice in their batter was awesome. Their fennel slaw, was also really tasty with plenty of fennel seed in the mix and it was basically the only thing that could keep the heat down-too bad that there was so little of it.

My friend came later and I got her the patty melt as a belated bday dinner. She really seemed to like it and it's probably the only thing on the menu that doesn't have spice on it. He was even nice enough to walk it into the brewery when it was ready. 

He eventually left because of the lightning that came in "me in a little metal box with lightning around, I'm leaving" and as my friend and I were thinking of eating again we told him how sad it was that he was wrapped up to go. He gave us what he had left, a huge basket of fries and three big pieces of chicken for free. He's changed my mind about food trucks and hot chicken, but more slaw please!

One of the most amazing clarinetists I've ever seen play, classical, jazz, anything. She hits high notes that send the angels scattering. New Orleans and traditional Jazz, the joyous sounds that fill the French Quarter, are inseparable. If you come to NOLA, then you need to hear Doreen. On her corner in the Royal Street Performing Arts Zone at Royal and St. Peter she holds court and it's just amazing. Someone told me that they had come from New Zealand to New Orleans and she was the main reason they flew all that way. I read that 25m people have seen her on YouTube and Facebook and all that and she's never actually recorded a video of herself for promotion. I've seen her since then at the tents at Jazz Festival and Satchmo Fest and she's where the love and the party's at. People, young people, who wouldn't know Sidney Bechet from Beyonce, just adore her. So cool!

More of a 3.5 stars in my opinion but I really loved the nostalgia of the place so have no problem bumping it up. 

I've never really had Chicago deep dish style pizza before so my husband and I were on mission. We ordered our food to go. And were really surprised that it was cash only. Not really understanding the concept here other than service fees to the restaurant when using debit or credit. Luckily we had a bit of cash on there and I do believe they have an ATM on site. 

We enjoyed a beer while we waited, only about 30 mins on a Friday night.  The pizza was so pretty when we got home and opened the box.  I really really enjoyed the sauce and toppings.  It was packed full and one piece was all I needed.  The crust on the other hand tasted like baking soda.  Very bitter. Not sure what went wrong there. 

Even though it was not pizza perfection and I doubt it's the best representation of this style of pizza, I would absolutely give this place a shot again.

Crappy filthy sorry excuse for a Dairy Queen, got ice cream here anyway thinking the chain ice cream would taste the same no matter how gross the location but I was wrong, the ice cream was icy and watery and down right garbage. First time I've ever thrown away ice cream in my life. A representative from Dairy Queen seriously needs to visit this location and shut them down. By the way the service was just as bad.

I didn't expect my crab to be cleaned of all the insides- that would have changed my entire perspective on dining here. I've gone to Redondo pier and aside from cracking the shell open, they give you the rest of the crab in it's entirety (dungeness).

We got a fried sampler appetizer and that was pretty good- don't get too much fried stuff as most things come with their onion rings.

Just a place to check out if you're hanging near the pier but I wouldn't highly recommend it - maybe stick with their lobster roll, seemed like everyone was ordering that.

P.S. there is a to go window on the side of the restaurant if you prefer eating at a designated outdoor seating area that is first come, first serve.

I stayed here in August or September 2007 when I had to go to Tampa for some training.  

Due to the proximity of this hotel to the Nielsen Company location on Brooker Creek, this place should just rename itself "The Nielsen Dorm Facilities."

Alpine Lock and Key A-Okay.

What Alpine Lock and Key does well is that tried and true Magic Formula For A Successful Business, and that is: day in and day out they do what they are in business to do and do it with gracious treatment of their customers.  Alpine Lock and Key's Customer Mindset is to: Greet every customer.  Respect every customer.  Value every customer.  Help every customer.  Listen to every customer.  WOW  every customer.  Invite every customer back.

Just to clarify:  According to the Yelp ratings' definitions, Three Stars is A-Okay.  That to me is an acceptable rating of a business that does day in and day out what they are in business to do.  It is certainly NOT a negative rating.  Four and Five-Stars to me is when a business goes over and beyond what they are in the business to do.  One and Two-Star Ratings are for when a business fails to do what they are in the business to do.

It's been a moment since I've left a restaurant with a foodgasm smile and hot damn, Morrow, y'all have reinvigorated my foodie cravings and excitement.

I'm still processing the wonderful meal (linner to be exact, lunch + dinner) with my friend and we both left proclaiming our love for Morrow's. Morrow's is neatly tucked on the corner and upon entering you are immediately given warm and woodsy vibes with all of the stained wood and the bar, oh my goodness, is it gorgeous.

"Morrow of the story..."

The fluorescent neon pink sign with a backdrop of foliage is stunning. In a pre-COVID world, I could picture myself being at the bar having multiple cocktails taking plenty of photos for the 'gram.

Reality currently had us waiting patiently for a table since they are really implementing social practices! THANK YOU. You have to wear a mask upon entry, they have a table blocking the entrance so folks can't simply go in-n-out, and there is a host to greet and make sure everyone is practicing safety and social distancing. Plenty of hand sanitizer all around.

We were eventually seated and absolutely no anxiety because they are so conscious about spacing of the tables. It honestly felt a little exclusive tbh. All of the staff was wearing masks and very, very friendly.

Onto the dishes we ordered...

Crawfish Bread: I literally wanted to cry tears of happiness because it was so good that I would've allowed someone to throw water in my face if it meant I would get a second plate of these for free. JUST GET THE DAMN APPETIZER.

Fried Chicken: Every crunch had the most flaky bite of fried chicken, I've had in SUCH a long time. I was sad when we realized we ate all of the fried chicken.

Charbroiled Oysters: Piping hot with the cheese drip. So fresh and the seasonings were divine. ORDER A DOZEN.

Crawfish Pasta: We asked for extra bread to slop up the sauce. ORDER EXTRA BREAD and you too will be happy you did. I legit had to make sure our server didn't take the dish until everything was eaten. I don't even like catfish, and I ate one of the two strips so fast I forgot to mention I hate catfish to my friend. The crawfish sauce had a nice spice (but not too spicy) and the pasta was al dente and cooked perfectly.

10s 10s 10s across the board. Make a trip to Morrow's ASAP!

A suburban bar that I actually wanted to take back to Philly with me. Who knew other than the friends I was visiting that showed it to me? McGillicuddy's is a pretty chill bar tucked on an unassuming nook of Ardmore. It's a little bit of a franchise, but it's not as bad as Great American Pub. It's not too Sport's Bar, even though it has it's ample share of big screens tuned into various games. It's not too much of a dive, even though it has the weekly specials, quizzo, and karaoke that make it pretty equal to one. It's pretty much the perfect in between bar.

After my friends jammed at Milk Boy Coffee we took it to JD's for the after party. When I saw the 5 big screen TVs and a DJ starting to spin some bad hip hop that I wanted to continue forgetting about I initially stifled a groan. But I picked up some reasonably priced beer and mock danced with some friends. And as the night and beers progressed it got better.

The DJ had his manic moments like mixing Snoop Dogg with New Order. and he even tried to scratch to -say it isn't so- Phil Collins??? But when he had his good moments he was pretty flawless. If he controlled those off moments he could be kicking it at Silk City (especially since he was better than most of the DJs who spin there when he was good). The only flaw to the dance floor? Not enough dancing. Wake the fork up suburbia! Some of my friends and I held it down though.

Saving the best thing about the bar for last. They had a movie style pop corn machine that hooked up free pop corn to the masses. Sounds like a winner that's worthy of being in Philly to me. and after scoping up the web site it looks like one is moving into the spot that used to be Whiskey Dix. Interesting.

Just received a VERY nice piece of jewelry from David Kodner (ahem!) and I'm very satisfied with his work... getting all sorts of compliments and attention on this piece.

What really bumped him up to a five star review was his easygoing attitude. Went in there to have my ring sized down and he asked the inevitable question, "Did you set a date yet?". Being a tad wedding phobic and way too busy these days to even THINK about picking a date, I immediately tensed up and got defensive. His advice was to stay engaged as long as possible, and to just "enjoy the ride".

So, rather than try to pressure us into getting married as quickly as possible so he could sell us some more stuff, this guy just offers some sound advice. How cool is that? Oh, and the jewelry in his shop is gorgeous, one-of-a-kind pieces, so I assume that I will be coming back to shop anyway :)

Guys - take note!

Umami is a newly opened pan-Asian restaurant serving authentic Japanese, Korean and Thai food. I live in Chicago, but I go to Nashville often to visit family and friends (I stayed in Brentwood area), so it was nice timing for me to try out this new restaurant and I got to try a lot of their menu items with our group. They've got a great variety of dishes on their menu, and everything we had was delicious. You can tell that everything is made from scratch here, as well as using fresh, authentic ingredients. Here's my review on each item, in no particular order:

Kimchi fries: This is a fun take using a Korean classic (the kimchi) and an American snack (cheese fries). I loved all the flavors and textures on this dish: crispy hot french fries topped with ooey, gooey nacho cheese, sauteed kimchi, scallions, and a white sauce that I can only guess is mayo (or sour cream?). I will try to update this when I find out. 

Korean Fried Chicken: One of their more popular items (according to our server). You can select the soy garlic or the spicy sauce, or go half and half with your order (6 pcs, 10 pcs, 20 pcs, 30 pcs). I wanted my son to be able to try it, so I opted for the soy garlic. That did NOT disappoint! It's the perfect blend of that umami flavor that comes from soy sauce paired with the garlic flavor. It comes with a side of pickled radishes that is the perfect complementary crunch with your chicken. This is actually how fried chicken is served in Korea, and it's excellent. No need to travel all the way to Seoul!

Tuna poke: this is your classic tuna poke (pronouned poh-kae), which is a salad of raw tuna, cucumber and avocados. There were large chunks of fresh tuna, marinated and seasoned well (not overpowering the tuna or anything). 

Speaking of fresh...can't get any fresher with the sashimi plate! We got a variety of sashimi to share, and I seriously loved every type of fish! If you're adventurous, you can try the freshly fried shrimp head if you order the sweet shrimp sashimi. The kitchen basically deep-fries the actual shrimp head that's taken off the body of the raw shrimp. For some of you, that sounds like something that could be shown on Andrew Zimmern's show, Bizarre Foods. But like he says on his show...if it looks good, eat it!!!!!!! Ahng!!!!! 

Mango Tango Maki Roll: one of the recommendations from our server -- did not disappoint! I asked for this roll without cream cheese (I just do not prefer to have any cream cheese in any of my rolls) and it was not even an issue (I mention this, because some restaurants don't like to customize the maki roll orders -- "no substitutes" policy at those places). I don't think I've ever had a "sweet" maki roll before, and I was pleasantly surprised with the flavors of this roll. The spicy crab and mango/strawberry actually went really well together. I'm glad that they can be inventive with their maki rolls, as well as serve the usual crowd favorites. 
Side note: I love the fun names of the maki rolls -- ranging from "Pokemon Go", "Music City", and "the "OMG Roll" (I imagine this one will make you say OMG haha)

Korean Chicken Tacos: You can choose from beef, chicken or pork for the Korean tacos. My son loves chicken, so we just went with the safer option (still delicious). I guess we could have tried the combo, I think that comes with one of each taco, maybe? This is also a very fun take on some classic Korean flavors with a little Mexican twist: the chicken has a Korean marinade, topped with Asian pickled radishes and cilantro, served in a warm corn tortilla.

Seafood Ramen: If you're familiar with and (like me) LOVE the Chinese-Korean noodle dish called "Jjam-bbong", then you will equally fall in love with this dish! The noodles are obviously the ramen noodles, but in the spicy seafood broth that is used for the "jjam-bbong" dish. I can tell that they use fresh seafood for the broth, because it's spicy and refreshing, not fishy at all! I was actually thinking about this bowl the next day...and how much I wanted to eat it again. The next time I'm in town, I will definitely be coming back to get this dish again!

Beer Selection: They have an AWESOME beer selection, with some local and international beers. I love checking out local beers wherever I go, and the ones I tried were awesome. They also have some great ones on tap. 
Fun tip: Order a large pitcher of beer, and it comes out in this REALLY fun pitcher that has dry ice and flashing lights -- so flashing smoke from your pitcher. It's not just for funsies, though...it keeps your beer nice and cold so that every pour is just as refreshing as the first.

I saw a lot of people coming in for pick-up orders, so if you don't have time to sit down in the restaurant, you could always call ahead and pick up on your way home (or wherever you're headed).

Overall, a wonderful meal and experience at Umami. Keep it up, guys! I'll be coming back soon.

This is a great place that you most certainly would never stumble upon accidentally. It is far from the action in New Orleans, but it is worth the short Uber ride from the French Quarter. You first walk into the wine shop. There you can purchase bottles to enjoy or order some food. They have a good selection of wines from all over the world. The staff is knowledgeable too so they can help you make the right choice.

Once you have your wine you can head outside to the garden area where there is a lot of seating options. While we were there they also had live music. It was nice because it was not overpowering so you could enjoy it and still have a conversation.

There is a bar area upstairs if you prefer the more traditional route for your alcohol consumption. There are bathrooms just off the garden area and a set up in the bar area.

We were full so we did not try any food. The wine though was very good. The prices were fair too. We will definitely be back here on our next trip to the area. It is a great place to enjoy some drinks and get a few minutes away from the awesome craziness on Bourbon Street.

I came in yesterday to get a haircut with one of the senior stylists and had an overall great experience service-wise. From the shampooing to the cut to the blow drying, I felt like my stylist moved swiftly and expertly. However, I was a bit disappointed this morning. Even though my hair had looked fine yesterday after styling, today it looked chunky and uneven. Perhaps my stylist may not have been very experienced with Asian hair (she seemed very experienced from the bio posted on the ARS website). I will have to go get that fixed because I have a dressy occasion to go to later this week. A bit painful to have to shell out another $50+ to correct this, but good thing I got this haircut earlier in the week!

Small froyo shop in the cute neighborhood off of Delmar and North & South. There were 2 vegan options: cinnamon and banana. I liked neither.  They had a watermelon flavor, but it contained dairy. WHY??!! The kids loved their flavors, which included salted caramel, chocolate, and cheesecake.  They offer 2 cup sizes here: large and larger. So no matter how little you put in even the smallest cup, it's gonna cost you $5. I'm not a fan of this money-grabbing practice.

I hear that they rotate the flavors often, so I wouldn't be against returning to see if they have more appealing vegan options next time.  However, in general, they are over-priced and would not be my first choice for dairy-free dessert. 

Also, if the cramped little parking area on the side of the building is full, there is more parking in the back, off of North & South.

SHRS was originally a sanitarium, using the natural spring waters to heal all sorts of ailments. The springs are now covered up, but the resort still maintains a 20's era spa feel. Take a moment and browse the old black and white photos and paintings in the grand salon. 

Front office staff is very friendly and helpful, they even upgraded us to a balcony room just by us asking. The rooms are gigantic, and ours had a view of the bay. Free self-parking is a plus, although technically you're paying for it with the $15 resort fee. 

There are plenty of shops and restaurants within walking distance of the resort, although we found many of them closed on Sunday. 

Breakfast is either buffet ($14) or a la carte, with some healthy "spa" options available, like yogurt parfait or egg white omelets. The pancakes are awesome, as were the oatmeal and coffee. 

One issue we found was a shortage of towels and chairs at both pools. The website photos are very deceiving, making the pools look huge, when in fact they are very small. Not nearly large enough to accommodate a resort with this many guests. There is also no breeze whatsoever, making it unbearably hot. People were basically just hanging out in the water, eating and drinking inside the pool, which was gross. 

Overall a relaxing stay and a great value, if you prefer a quieter area and venue.

I finally got to try District Donuts. After seeing them on my Instagram for some time, the time finally had come! Yay! I'm glad I tried them. Their donuts are good and taste homemade. What I also like about their donuts is that they are thick and have a nice chew. I ordered the Hibiscus Donut and the Cinnamon Roll. Both were really good but of course lent different flavors. One was more fruity and light and the other more cinnamon and warm. The hibiscus was my favorite. I loved the fruity notes that came from this donut. It even had a candied orange on top. The orange was a nice addition. The cinnamon roll donut was good but for me a little too much. It just seemed heavy. While the flavors were different they were good to try. Overall, I enjoyed District Donuts.

My first time here was this past Saturday night. Was only here about an hour. I was impressed from the moment I walked thru the door. Touted as a "conversation bar" because it is free of all other distractions like tv, loud music, games, crowds, etc. It is a civilized lounge in a quite unique and creative atmosphere. It resembles a library in furnishings and in the quiet, subdued tone. Opened books make up one of the walls from floor to ceiling. They have the old card catalog filing system pieces of furniture from back in the day! Upside down lamps hang from the ceiling for lighting. The bar is beautiful. 

They offer local beers, have a nice wine selection and a focused selection of spirits. The emphasis as far as spirits go is on the whiskey.

This is basically a very small shopping mall.  There's a rotunda that you can see pretty much every store in the place standing in the center.  It's 2 floors and although the mall appears small, some stores are actually quite large.  There's a food court which is pretty basic, but had more than some of the larger malls I've been to.  The anchor store seemed to be the Bloomingdale's outlet, while the other mall staples like Victoria's Secret (it's not so secret anymore), Claire's, Bath and Body Works, and Auntie Anne's were present as well.  Stores probably change so check the website if you're looking to pay a visit.

A nostalgia-laced icon,  this branch of Ted Drewes is my favorite. It's located on Route 66 in a very pretty neighborhood and part of the experience is enjoying the ambiance as you stand outside waiting to order.

This is the first place I ever had frozen custard, that luscious concoction that is richer than ice cream and usually prepared soft serve style to lend itself to all sorts of invention.   The richness is due to high butterfat and egg content and minimal air.

Important term:  "concrete" - the frozen custard equivalent of a Dairy Queen Blizzard, you pick your mix-ins and they blend it up into decadent goodness.

One of my favorite items at Ted Drewes is the Christie, which is actually a sundae:  a brownie, frozen custard, hot fudge, and caramel ($5).  Great diet food!

Highly recommended to any frozen confection lover visiting St. Louis!!

Three words: funnel cake fries. I was so excited for a bar in the area to have something completely different from all the rest.

Whole lotta tvs positioned to give the feel you're in a theater. Couple of bar tables with a small dance floor near main bar. I saw a pool table and some pinball machines too. 

I did start to question this place when my first time walking in Sisqo's Thong Song was blasting..but it's a fun place for happy hour.

Keke's new location at USF area is less than 1 year new. We been want to visit for some time. Parking is very convenient. The line for weekend breakfast is not bad. At 8:20 am, there was no line at all. Lighting design and space is very welcoming with bright to see your food. 

We got Pina Colada with egg and bacon. The pi√±a colada French Toast is French Toast stuff with pineapple, cream and spread with powder sugar and coconut flake. The food presentation is very nice. Colorful. The bacon is thick enough with good quality. The sunny side up egg was cook to order. Food is delicious. 

The food is a bit pricey. But it does show the potential for good food. Service definitely excellent in this place. The waiter is knowledgeable to recommend a dish.

Such a fan of this place!!! I'm not a big chocolate fan, however I love Godiva Chocolatier!!! I'm picking up Valentines treats for the kiddos and mom. This place is great for stocking stuffers and any holiday during the year. It comes with a hefty price tag. It sure does make people smile. Staff is friendly.

I like this Jamba Juice location in Pennsylvania; it's nice and clean and customer service is friendly and service is fast.  The night before coming to this Jamba Juice location, I ate something that didn't agree with me.  I woke the next morning and my lips were burning (I thought they were just chapped from the cold weather).  I decided to look in the mirror at the hotel room I was staying at and my lips were enormous (naturally I freaked out)!  I contacted my sister who is in the medical field and lives in Philly and she suggested I take a Benadryl.  My husband left the hotel to buy me some Benadryl ; by the time he came back, my tongue expanded and I could not talk; I was having an allergic food  reaction to something I ate the night before. I couldn't eat because my tongue was so big so I had to chew the Benadryl on one side of my mouth (talk about disgusting)!  The Benadryl knocked me out for five straight hours and when I woke up, I was starving!!!  My husband drove me to Jamba Juice and I got a pomegranate paradise smoothie; at that point in time, my tongue and lips were back to normal. The smoothie was delicious and my husband got a smoothie too; a razzmatazz.  This was the first time I had the pomegranate smoothie (which is now my favorite smoothie at Jamba).  The workers were really friendly and helpful as we drank our Jambas at a table inside the shop.  I obviously won't be back here anytime soon since I live in California but, this was definitely one of the nicer Jamba Juice locations I have been to in the more recent years.

I may be a local type of guy when it comes to most things in my life I shop, but this chain has my admiration. I have never written lower than a 4 stars at the half dozen or so stores I've visited. This was my first time at this Tampa store located four miles from the airport. 

Right off the plane and practically to Total Wine prior to closing on a weekday evening. I only needed one bottle of wine, but it needed to be a great one and I planned on being picky. However I also had little time. 

What many customers may not know is the secret behind the staff knowing how to make recommendations. The receive a case of wine and beer a month to try, write notes and then make recommendations to customers. Throughout the store you will see this on shelves with the face of a staff member. This is legit if you ever wondered. I went right to work and asked a staff member to help me with a high end NAPA Cabernet that would be similar to a Caymus, but not priced at $80. 

The staff discussed options and ultimately called the manager Doug to come over. After around 10 minutes of deciding on three choices I settled on a hard to keep in stock 2013 Baldacci Fraternity. It's a bold red blend with cherry and tobacco flavors. The maker even designed sediment to be in the pour like an old aged wine would be. The bottle was taken to a group dinner in St. Petersburg. I actually had this wine maker before and was excited. The wine proved to be marvelous at the $44 price point and opened beautifully in the glass. 

I will continue to shop Total Wine for the selection, price and more importantly the knowledge that staff have about products. Thank you Doug.

You know the "Tell me about the chicken" scene from Portlandia?*  Well. That's us.  Hubby and me.  So a drive through burger kiosk in a strip mall parking lot is a highly unlikely place to find us given we have long been of the "know what is in your food and where it comes from" types.  To make it even more unlikely that we'd end up placing our order at a kiosk with "Burger" in the name, I share the "he" of we won't eat beef in any form and the "she" won't eat it ground - unless "she" sees it ground in a butcher shop from a range raised cattle cut of her choice. 

But here "we" ended up at a drive up burger kiosk after reading about the owner, Shad Cupp, who range raises the Scottish Highland cattle at his BVR Highland ranch and who started the ranching enterprise after having an epiphany about the flaws in our food supply when he saw "Food, Inc." and was then wrestling with his own health problems being compounded by a fast food diet.

Learning he also had pork products from his pasture raised hogs, this kiosk was a destination dining choice even though we knew the only place to eat would be at picnic tables in the parking lot given we didn't think our "little piggy" brats would hold up all the way home.

THE EATS:  Eat the brats we did at that picnic table, every single bite - the "he" in a spicy Italian rendition (he is Sicilian after all) and the "she" in the classic with mustard and kraut - and licked our fingers clean of the yummy black pepper rich salt on the french fries too.  Another unlikely sighting for us given except for the true pommes frittes at Bacquet's in Eagle or Petite 4 on the Bench we don't eat french fries either.  And given both "he"' and "she" are lighter eaters with a lifetime of weight control challenges in the mix it is also unlikely to see us eat an entire dish of anything - sharing being usual MO - but a whole brat each was consumed with gusto.    Fresh made sausages using BVR ranch raised pork are served on local baker Gaston's buns and with local MFT ketchup for the fries and all at only about $10 each.  (The price includes a large soft drink, but on those we passed.) 

THE OWNER:  Maybe it was seeing us lick our fingers that made the nice guy who owns this come out to ask us how we enjoyed the food.  It gave us a chance to talk about our shared perspectives on the importance of humane and sustainable practices in animal husbandry and learn more about his business.  With his adult son, Hoss, now largely running the ranch Shad has the time to run the kiosk and associated food truck.  He'd like to be able to expand for other kiosk locations in the area so that people don't have to eat bad food to eat convenient food.  And while his animals are currently dispatched and processed at the only USDA approved facility in the area, he would one day like to have his own on ranch facility to do that to have end-to-end control of his product.  (If he does that, I'm on board for one of those burgers too!)  He realizes a kiosk isn't ideal - no seating or loo for customers and all - but it was the affordable place to start.

THE DRILL:  Drive up to the window and a nice young 'un (on our day a delightful young woman who we assumed was a relation) will take your order.  Then if there is a car behind you, the same young 'un will go to that car to take theirs so the delay is minimal for waiting for food to be cooked (on our day Shad was doing the cooking).  But this is cooked to order eats, not McDonald's drive through, so set expectations for a little time being needed.  If you're planning on eating at the picnic tables, they'll offer to bring the food to you or you can walk up to the window to fetch your own (our choice) when it is ready. 

THE SCENE*: Sure, you know it.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ErRHJlE4PGI

PS:  God bless small ranchers and farmers who use sustainable agricultural models to provide good and healthy things for people to eat.

Yummyyyyy! 

For the first time ever I had to wait in line and had a chance to actually look at the menu. I've been fortunate that I usually get to order immediately and, because my eyes are bigger than my stomach, I get the first thing that looks amazing, which is everything here! 

I found out that I don't have to get a massive scoop, I can order a kids scoop which is probably a more appropriate serving for an adult. I also learned they serve "nachos" which are waffle cone pieces surrounding a massive scoop of ice cream topped with hot fudge. One of these days I'm going to order the farmhouse - 8 scoops and unlimited toppings!

I recommend the honeycomb, cookies and cream, and I recently tried rough seas (candied nuts with honey swirl and pretzel). I think some flavors are only available for a limited time because I didn't see my beloved cowboy cookie. 

The only thing I can (barely) complain about is that their handmade waffle cones are thin and fragile. They're delicious and sugary but the tips are not tightened so ice cream always inevitably drips out. I recommend the cone by all means, but ask for a bowl to hold it!

Finally I can eat something besides falafel, gyros, or cajun food at the Farmers Market!

I go to FM a lot for lunch because the other options in Metro Center are fast food.  Thus, you get options and, if you have a group, everyone is pleased.  So when I heard that Arnold Myint was going to open up a spot I was excited.  Real food, likely healthy, likely fresh, likely the tastiest thing in the place - what's not to love. 

So I showed up with some coworkers who weren't as adventurous as me and went to another place.  That's the great thing about FM!  Anyway, I perused the sides and decided I really wanted some curried quinoa.  The sides come in little small containers although I think you can order larger (like think large enough to take some home for the family).  I picked out a turkey sandwich and also got a bag of the homemade chips.  Verdict: loved the quinoa, wish I had gotten more.  Sandwich - ok, better than Subway of course, but still it was, in the end, just a turkey sandwich.  Will bust out with a different choice next time!  Chips were yummmy.  I also liked the iPad checkout station where you just sign your name right on the screen - a little oasis of class in the craziness of the Farmers Market.  I also got to see Arnold Myint himself which was cool because I totally rooted for him when he was on Top Chef!

Definitely give this place a try next time you are at FM having lunch.  You will leave pleasantly filled with healthy food and will be the only one not in a food coma at work later that afternoon!

Perfectly reasonable, perfectly normal Center City Starbucks. They're right across from a Target.

Normal amenities. Free Wi-Fi, they take credit cards, etc. Upstairs seating. Lots of natural light during the day.

Friendly service!

If you're staying, ask for a mug. And be sure to bus your own cups to the counter when you're done; there's no table service, naturally.

If this is your favorite spot, please bend your ears for a moment, or more let's say, skip this review :D

We'd settled on Thai for lunch. We called in our order, and were told it would take up to 20 minutes for our lunches to be ready for pick up. My friend Colleen, opted for healthy Fresh Thai Shrimp Spring Rolls for a waistline friendly starter. I'm in love with any thing ginger, so I got the Ginger Chicken. Colleen and I shared both. Also, we got Supreme Mango with Sweet Sticky Rice & Coconut Cream, one for each of us.

Upon my arrival, I was standing at the host desk for a good five minutes, no one came to help me. Then, the first person I saw, failed to greet me, and when I went to the desk to let the host know I was there to pick up my order, he totally did brushed me off, and was unpleasant!!!!  Have you just looked at someone and automatically felt annoyed? I did, and all what I'm saying is that host/hostess have to mind their p's and q's. 

My lunch came out after SIXTY minutes and I went "Ba Dum Tss!" 
Besides the bad customers service, the food was just okeyish. The fresh spring rolls were too healthy and tasteless, like fresh grass. Totally off-putting!
The Ginger Chicken I ordered, was described in the menu as ( Saut√©ed with cashews nut, onion, scallion, bell pepper, carrot in chili paste and light garlic sauce.)
The ginger had an overwhelming kick to it, and there was no sign of any spicy chili paste! Also, absolutely NO cashews in there, or scallion. There was no flavor, and no tongue's satisfaction in that dish whatsoever! 

How can anyone mess up a very simple dessert like sticky rice?!! My order of Supreme Mango with Sweet Sticky Rice & Coconut Cream  was a failure. The rice was incredibly sticky, stiff and hard to chew. Enough said!

Obviously I will not be returning, not only because of the below average food, but also because of the poor service and unpleasant staff.

Two Yelps!

I love me a good beignet, and what better way to enjoy a weekend than munching on some delicious, warm beignets at a park, with jazz music on a beautiful day. 

I'm so glad I was also introduced to this location as this had less of a line than the one at the French Market. It was also an added bonus that it was inside a beautiful park. 

The line on a Saturday morning wasn't awful. We waited about 10 minutes to place our order and was served almost immediately. It's a little bit challenging to find tables here, but you can definitely choose to enjoy the beignet on a park bench or on the grass if you'd like. 

The beignets are best when served warm and are worth it! They're the perfect treat for your weekend!

Been here many times throughout the last year. I came here once for karaoke night. Once on a Friday night and another time on a Saturday night. The Monday night that they had karaoke was actually one of the best nights I had there. The other two nights were just really loud and the bartender wasn't making the drink I asked for. The drink I wanted had 2 different types of liquor in it and he just changed it around so it only had the cheap liquor out of the spout. Was pretty disappointed with that, while it tasted okay it was only because there was so much excess juice! I'm giving it three stars, because they do have a cider in a bottle and the karaoke night was really fun! They had a live karaoke band that played along with you and then at the end of the night best show won some sort of cash prize.

Typical fast food restaurant. Order at the box, pick up at the window. 

My food tasted as expected; "Wendys quality"... Fries were ok, these weren't the best, but better than the ones that used to come in that little yellow carton 

All the necessary items were in the bag when I received it.  Good. Good 
Good, I didn't have to ask for napkins or ketchup!

I've been here several times before & a return visit will there be when I'm in the area (& am yearning for Wendy's... Lol)

This is a small hole in the wall in the African section of Woodland Avenue.  Though it might not look like much, there is some good food coming out of its kitchen representing Senegal and West Africa.  I enjoyed the national dish of Senegal - Thiboudienne - although note that here they do a version without the usual tomato sauce.  I also took home a Jollof Rice which is often called the mother dish of Jambalaya.  There are a few hightop tables inside for dining or you can order the food to-go.  Either way, service is friendly.

Why 2 stars? Because our experience was pretty poor.

   ---   ---   ---

After researching all of the pet resorts in Tampa Bay pretty thoroughly, we felt really good about leaving our dog at Camp Bow Wow while we left town for Thanksgiving. My girlfriend used to drop her old dog off at the Brandon location, and she loved it. Plus, the Tampa location is super convenient on our way to the airport. 

I asked the guy who checked us in, how much time is spent in their kennel, vs how much is spent out playing. He said that they are up at 6am to eat, and 90 minutes after eating, they are out playing all day long until dinner time in the evening. Making sure that our pop receives plenty of exercise, and is not being locked away in a cage all day was very important to us, and the primary reason we went to a "pet resort" over an old fashioned kennel.

One of our other favorite things about Camp Bow Wow, was that they have webcams in all of the play areas, so that you can check in with how your pup is doing all throughout the time that he is there. Well, we certainly did check on him a lot, and it was pretty alarming what we found over the course of his 4 day stay.

We checked out the cameras about 15 times, at all different times of the day. 8a, 10a, 1p, 3p, etc etc. The dogs were out playing twice out of the 15 times we looked. 

So when we picked him up Monday morning, I asked about that, and this is the answer I was given:

"Yeah... we had some new people working and a lot of dogs here, so we got a little behind on the schedule."

"Behind on the schedule" is definitely an interesting way of saying that the dogs were out playing maybe about 10-20% of what we were told. I could understand if instead of them being out at 8am on Thanksgiving morning, things were pushed back an hour or two. Or maybe an incident where a clean up pushed things back 30 minutes. But to tell us our dog will be out playing for 8+ hours a day, and in reality, he might have been out playing for 8 hours combined over 4 days.... that's pretty unacceptable, and I don't think I'm in the minority saying that.

And to make things worse, he acquired kennel cough at Camp Bow Wow, which was also lovely. That was not an inexpensive trip to the vet.

So needless to say, we had two upcoming vacations that involved our pup heading back to Camp Bow Wow, but those were immediately cancelled, as soon as we found alternatives.

I'd like to say it was an amazing massage but it wasn't. I was specific in what I wanted (not too hard but not a "fluff and buff." I definitely got the later,

It's a beautiful spa in a beautiful hotel. My daughters also got massages and loved theirs. I guess it's just a matter of what you want.

Still loving this place, but feel like I need to bring an extra container for the excess cream chesse. Not complaining that they give you a lot of product, but I also dont want to die from a cream cheese heart attack!!

I really like that they have an expansive breakfast, lunch, hot item menu that also includes an array of specialty donuts. The prices are great!

The food is okay at most, but for the bang for the buck, I think it's a pretty good deal. Next time I'm here, I think I'll stick to their donuts.

Happy I brought my Jeep here to get the windshield replaced. Feels like I have a brand new car since it got replaced. 
Scheduling the appointment was super easy online, plus I found a coupon code which saved me $60 off-which is a great deal! 
Other places were going to charge me $800+ to replace the windshield and it was under $700. 
I ended up dropping my car off early, and they ended up taking it earlier, so I was out of there in a good amount of time. It took about an hour for it to be replaced, and re-calibrated. 
The staff here are super friendly and knowledgeable and most of them are Veterans of the Armed Forces- which to me is a good thing! 

Along with the great price, customer service, they also give you a lifetime warranty on the windshield- which is pretty awesome. 
I would definitely recommend Safe Lite.

Warning: this review is a bit of an ode to my love for properly made grits. I may go overboard. 

The location is great. It is in the heart of downtown near the convention center and near the Hertz office where we rented a car for the day. 

Our server was so nice and helpful. As I have mentioned in prior reviews, I have a myriad of food allergies, most of which are at issue in Louisiana cooking: peppers, chilis, potatoes, and tomatoes. As a result, I could not order any hollandaise options off the menu because it is made with hot sauce but she walked me through the menu to show me what I could eat. I got a breakfast combo with eggs, grits and bacon; my husband got the omelette. 

The eggs were OK but the grits.... these are not run of the mill grits that are instant. These are the grits that I had when I first fell in love with them in September 2001, also in Louisiana (Shreveport). Fluffy yet smooth with a slight hint of butter. So delicious I ate my husband's portion. Diet be damned!

Service was very quick and just delightful. My husband left his camera on the table and she chased after us to return it. 

We will go back again later this weekend. I don't care if I should experience more of New Orleans. And I am going to buy a T-shirt. And yes, I am fan girling all over this place.

Ahhh I long for spring evenings, long summer nights and beak fall evenings so I can have an excuse to enjoy Bacchanal! 

I can't even tell you the countless wonderful days and nights I've spent here with friends! On cold nights I've sat upstairs which has a bar and feels like a beautiful lodge with the tall ceilings!

And on those warm nights I've sat around the mismatched tables listening to live music, relaxing with friends while trying a new white wine, cheese, and small plate. I really can't think of a better way to spend an evening besides relaxing by candlelight and various white lights with friends and loved ones around. If you know me well you know that I can be very territorial and if I like a place I will NEVER take a date there bc I consider it mine! And bacchanal is that kind of place! Hehe it feels like a little piece of heaven right here in NOLA. 

The people that work here really know their libations and will pair your tastes for the perfect cheese, tasting plate etc. I have brought various kind of friends and even the one that went to culinary school at Johnson and Wales and used to work at Emeril's was impressed with their wine selection. In fact we selected a wine that he said he couldn't find anywhere else in NOLA. Score one for bacchanal! He was also impressed by their small plates and the homemade concoctions in the bar upstairs!

So if you want to relax somewhere and be amongst friends then come over to Bacchanal. You won't regret it! As other reviews have said this is like being in a friend's backyard. It's eclectic, homey, and endearing like the Bywater always is!

Happy carpe noctum!

**GET YOUR RIVER FIX IN A QUIET PARK**

Grab a blanket.

Grab the Kindle.

If it's hot, grab the bikini.

Relax in front of the lazy river.

Watch the people: college kids, young couples, and older folks.

Frisbees, dogs, coolers, lawn chairs.

It was that kind of place.

Truly delightful.

RECOMMEND.

Dear Plain Jane,
I found you here. You were encased as a hard shell taco with chicken and ground beef. You screamed my name out and said you were $2 each on wed thru Fridays from 4-7. I said hell yeah, what a bargain.
You tricked me, though. You enticed me by showing me pineapple salsa and sweet black bean corn salsa and limes to fancy you up.
You simply were even over priced bc you didn't show your taste and your finesse.
You were not plain, just bleh. Sorry. Hope you have better days!

Why 5 stars? Because this is definitely a place I want to visit regularly.

   ---   ---   ---

Ever since missing the Yelp event hosted here, I have had it on my list to check this place out. My first experience was very brief as I found out he did not receive his shipments in due to the threat of a hurricane, so he was out of all fresh food from the deli. Of course, this was totally understandable, but I do wish there was some kind of posting on social media about that because I even checked their Facebook page ahead of time to confirm that they were open.

But I waited a couple of weeks and returned. There were a few sandwich options but I was told that the menu would be changing in a few days, so I'm not sure what's currently available as I type this out. I opted for a Cuban sandwich and browsed the products while I waited.

This Cuban was just a bit different than any other that I've had. I think the main difference is that it was only moderately pressed, which left some softness to the bread and did not completely melt the cheese to act as an adhesive to hold everything together. While I was a bit thrown off by that at first, I came to realize how much I enjoyed the sandwich as I continued to eat it. 

I also was able to buy a few local brews here. I love Pumpkin Beer and picked up some cans from Brew Bus, Big Top and Tampa Bay Brewing Company. They pretty much have every single canned beer made in the Tampa Bay area here, so you any beer lovers will be all set with this selection.

For all the delicious snacks in here, I do wish that there were some chips available. That was the only thing missing with my sandwich, but the sandwich itself was a home run.

On my next visit, I ordered a pizza with prosciutto and mozzarella, which was enjoyable, but I liked the Cuban Sandwich even more. There are a couple other sandwiches on the menu that I would like to try on future visits.

The Westbank theater offers recliner seating. That's the highlight, really, and it is legitimately more comfortable, though you really have to mash the buttons a bit to make it work. It's pretty sizable and has some movies that don't show everywhere. Parking is free out here, and there's plenty enough other things in the area to motivate the non-local to make the occasional trip across the river.

The seats are assigned, which has positives and negatives. It mostly irks me, though I think in crowded movies it's nice to be able to reserve in advance. That being said, if it was a big premiere I'd want to find a nicer IMAX theater, and for smaller indie films I stay in the city, so this place fills a small niche for me.

Nice little bar located at the very far end of Terminal E and Tampa International. The airport recently added several new restaurants with a "local vibe" and this is one of them. There isn't a ton of seating but it also isn't close to the TSA area so it's a bit hidden. Hey have TVs if you wanna catch a game while you wait for your flight. Food is very reasonably price for the portion size. Appetizers run from $5-$10 and majority of sandwiches are $12. I didn't order any food but it looked amazing! Drinks are tasty and Prices are not terrible. Think 22oz Jai Alai for $8.50. You cannot take alcoholic beverages into the terminal (Columbia does this I think). I had a Manhattan for $11 and it was very tasty. Staff is attentive and friendly. I know my new spot when I'm waiting on a Delta flight!

My mom is a fan of author Ann Patchett, and when she discovered that she owned Parnassus Books in Nashville she insisted we visit. When we walked in I automatically was drawn to their displays and all of the different book selections. I enjoyed their book display on local authors and books about Nashville, so I selected a book by a radio DJ in Nashville Bobby Bones which I really enjoyed and never would've thought to read otherwise. After all, that is what bookstores are great for is discovering new books! 

I came back to Parnassus with a coworker once I saw that they have book signing events.  I was shocked that a noticed a few authors of very popular novels had book signings here. I decided to come here to have Delia Owens sign my copy of her book 'Where the Crawdads Sing'. Although I know that some book signings are ticketed events, no tickets were required for this one. They do ask that if you come to a book signing that you purchase the book from their bookstore, which makes sense. I was definitely grateful they had two employees going around with post-it notes so that your spelling of the name would be corrected once the author got to sign your book. One of the employees also took photos of us and the author which was nice and efficient. 

Parnassus is a great local bookstore and I am so glad that I discovered it. They have a wide variety of books and hold events here which all ages would appreciate.

See's candies is California base bakery reach Florida. I know about this candies when my wife living in California. Their chocolate is very soft and tasty. 

In Tampa, the International Plaza Mall has this temporary store from Thanksgiving to Easter. They located very close to H&M clothing store. You can have samples before you buy it. I got the lollipop candies. I also bought one assorted chocolate candies. They are very good. The store clerk was kind enough to let us try their assorted chocolate other their typical sample candies. 

You can go with chocolate with nut, mint, toffee, milk, white or dark chocolate. All are good. Guilty pleasure with a touch at sweet side. Mail order through the web also available. If you close to the mall, just go to buy one without shipping.

Second stop for Center City Restaurant Week:  R2L, dinner for $35 each. 

On the 37th floor of Two Liberty Place is a very fancy-cool restaurant/lounge where you can get a bird's eye view of the city! Group of us went to dinner here together after a day of meetings. Didn't get one of the tables facing the windows, but still had great views of the sunset and city by night. Again, multiple choices for the three courses, but I chose to start with the crisp peas/ham/garlic risotto [balls]. Main course was the Butcher's Filet (braised short rib + Steuben bean chili, potato/farm veg slaw and basil), which was quite heavy since there was also meat in the chili as well. The dazzling dessert to finish it off was the milk chocolate + hazelnut pudding served with salted caramel and coffee to melt the chocolate, and candied almonds on the side. A bottle of wine for the table as well. Food was great, waiter was awesome (making sure to warn me that the risotto came in ball form rather than a bowl, for instance), very classy experience.
Got the regular roast beef. The beef is a bit dry. But the smoky flavor covers that up a bit. And with a lot of gravy it's still a good sandwich. The bread is soft and fluffy.

March 25, 2016 Friday - 5 PM for a drink
1 Adult

Atmosphere - 4 stars
Food - 5 stars
Service - 5 stars 

Background - Been here for the UYE Beer Club and time to get here on my own.

Atmosphere - It is part of a business park.  Just watch for the signs at the corners, probably 3 feet tall they will take you through the maze.  It is like going to a friend's garage with a few more taps.  Probably one of the smallest brewers in Reno and glad to be able to support them

Food
  Drinks - I want to try something I had not had before from Stoneyhead and the Honey Porter was calling me.  A solid choice.

Service - Brad was working behind the bar.  I placed my order he is wait I have a sample for you.  They rolled out their new beer Spring Fling.  A good ESB but was craving that porter.

Future - Sure.

I dream about Mr. B's BBQ shrimp! 

The brown sauce is delicious and savory! I have to say I was a little freaked out the first time I ordered this because the shrimp are served whole! It is messy! The good news is they give you a bib! They also serve the most amazing baguette to soak up all that sauce! I have to say I enjoyed getting my hands dirty...

The wedge salad is worth ordering! It has a wonderful lite dressing, blue cheese, bacon, and cherry tomatoes. Yummy! 

I also have to say they serve a mean Bloody Mary!

This is a friendly little shop in West Park Village. I haven't had the chance to try any other desserts or sandwiches here, but based on the reviews I came in to pick up a cake for my son's birthday. 

Based on cake alone I have to give it 3 stars. It's a decent cake, but I'm not crazy about these kinds of cakes. These cakes are gritty. I like my cake silky, if that makes sense. Being married to a Dominican he has a taste for these gritty cakes that's nostalgic to him because Dominican Cake (bizcocho) is gritty...as well as the merengue icing. Not that it's bad, I just prefer a soft, silky, moist cake. 

I will say that the cakes that I tried, lemon and guava were moist. The Lemon didn't taste as lemony as I would have expected it to. The guava was just okay. Again, not my style of cake. These were bundt cakes. I prefer the bundt cake from the popular chain over on Dale Mabry. In comparison those bundts are more my style.

Family owned and borderline ornate in spots, the Hotel Monteleone proved a welcome respite from the gushing skies of New Orleans this week. Sure, you're right there on the edge of the quarter, but if what you're really after is a few comfortable winks and one of the more unusual hotel bars going, this place has both in spades. 
Be careful where you set things down in the bar: it rotates ("a helluva trick to play on a man," the recent Esquire article said that name-checked this watering hole as one of the US' great bars). 

All in all though, my room was comfy, the amenities cool (if not expansive), and the staff was largely friendly and helpful. Worth noting that if you drive in, parking is thirty bucks a day...but I got such a deal on the room (they've been running a summer special during slow season) that it was easily still worth it to camp here. I'd definitely stay here again.

Completed in Montgomery County in 2015, Pennypack Trail is actually 16 miles long (5.4 mi. in Montco), and part of the much larger trail network in eastern PA. In fact, the section extending into Bucks County reaches the Delaware River and connects with the East Coast Greenway which runs 3,000 miles from Maine to Florida. So, if you want a long hike, you can have one. 

The portion I was on yesterday was the border of Lorimer Park that was historically the railroad right of way since the 1860s, when first the Philadelphia Montgomery County Railroad Co., followed by the Philadelphia Newtown New York Railroad and finally the Newtown Branch of the Reading R&R used it to transport people and produce before highways took their place. SEPTA had it last and suspended commuter transportation (Fox Chase - Newtown Line) in 1983, and donated it to the Rails to Trails Project. 

While we all love a scenic walk, it sure would be nice to have mass transit available to get us from our bedroom communities to the heart of the city more conveniently, and redevelop the termini and old stations along the route for small commerce, too. There should be a way to have both more green space and village like economies working in tandem to attract people. Vision and capital are all that are required. 

Still, the Trail is a beautiful route for nature and scenic lovers as it is, and can be enjoyed in almost any weather. Walking along the heights above Pennypack Creek and watching the water course through the steep ravine cut out by erosion over eons of time, is remarkable. In the 18th and 19th Centuries many mills were busy using water wheels to grind flour, which was transported by the nearby rails to cities for further production and consumption. Some of those old structures are still there (mostly in ruins), and the stone houses built near to them were often maintained and are lived in today. 

Hiking further, the Bethayres Swamp beckons, with Audubon designation as an IBA - Important Bird Area. The trail goes through the town of Bryn Athyn, where the original train station has been repurposed as the local post office. Just beyond that is the site of a major head-on train collision in 1921, that killed many passengers. Not all the trail is smooth for bike riding, nor easy strolling, but with effort, grit and good footwear, these places can be reached, explored and fancied.

The Pennypack Watershed is an ecological zone with long human history in the Philadelphia area. It is well worth sustaining and maintaining, even with reasonable respect for progress and our shared future.

This place is a hidden gem.

We ordered our food for take-out so we weren't too worried about the ambiance. However, our food more than made up for the place itself.

We ordered a  lobster tail platter (w/ fries and cole slaw), 2 orders of 15 clams (w/ butter), and 2 orders of jumbo steamed shrimp. Everything was huge (including the shrimp which were about the size of my fist!) and cooked quite well.

My grandfather's Maine lobster tail platter was well prepared and he said his onion rings were also perfect. (And he's a tough cookie to please!)

It definitely made their anniversary!

Welcome to Reno. Land of all-you-can-eat sushi, apparently. I'm told that's just how things work here, and this was my baptism into the religion of fish aplenty. Well--that's not entirely true. I once went to a Chinese buffet that served sushi. That ended not well. But I've never been to a place where you just keep ordering the things and they just keep making the things.

So we sauntered in rather late, and bellied up to the bar. The place was kind quiet on a Wednesday night, but when you want the attention of the dude making your bottomless sushi, that's a good thing.

First up, was a bunch of nigiri. Now, for me, this is where the genius of AYCE comes in. Nigiri is the bee's knees, but I don't often order it because it doesn't make the economical sense that a roll does, in terms of bangs and bucks. But if you get a roll here, you're saddled with all the pieces. Nigiri, though, is a couple of pieces of glorious simple sushi. And so the simple sushi began. They also have specialty nigiri, which is a little more fancy, but still one bite wonders. 

I'm not under any illusions that an AYCE can make their money on the toppest of shelf fish, but I'm here to say that my expectations were exceeded by their fish. Each one had its own flavor (holla at me, hamachi and escolar!) and the specialty pieces had enough razzmatazz to keep me interested but be true to the fish. Also, on a total side note, can you imagine my complete surprise just now when I wrote razzmatazz and it didn't get autocorrected? Apparently it's a real word. I digress...

I did try a few rolls, and I wish I could remember what ones. Good ones, I think? I know the Rainbow Roll was one, because I'm a little boring but it's a sure fave of mine. To end the night, I got the dessert roll with mango. I mean, it's all good stuff, but the disconnect between regular sushi and dessert sushi is a bit much in my mind; your mouth doesn't expect it and it tripped out my tastebuds.

The service was fire. I mean, the dude was RIGHT THERE and we just casually mentioned wanting something and boom, it appeared. I know this can't be the case on a hoppin' busy night, but whereas I had imagined slow service to slow your (sushi) roll, I couldn't have been more wrong. We were there well after closing and they kept serving. Sorry about that... but once everything was cleaned we skedaddled. Side note, skedaddled is also a legit word!

What a way to eat, Reno. I'm into it. And Kei does a fine, fine job.

What an AMAZING occurrence that we ended up here after another barbecue place ran out of food!

So yeah, we started out at another spot and they were out of food when we got there. Super bummed and still in the mood for barbecue, we started wandering around Mid City and my trusty Yelp app guided me to this place. We were greeted by the super nice woman working the counter and she explained the whole process.

I decided to get the one-meat plate with "wet" pulled pork, grits and potato salad, I also got a medium mac and cheese, because I can. My boyfriend got the two-meat plate with brisket and pulled chicken with potato salad and fries. The food blew us both away! It was delicious from beginning to end. The pulled pork was perfect and had the perfect amount of sauce without being drenched. I could tell that if I hadn't ordered it wet it still would have been able to stand on it's own. The mac and cheese was incredible, and after the pork, was my favorite part of the meal. The stone ground grits had a different type of flavor (almost smoky) that I enjoyed and the potato salad was served cold and had that nice crunch that I like in potato salad,

We both agreed that the food was excellent, and a good deal to boot, and that we would both make the trip back out to Earhart, just to have more of this delicious food. The owner himself was bringing the food out to folks and he was really friendly and made sure that we were happy with everything. I like when the owners take the time to make sure that everything is okay. The atmosphere is casual and comfortable and the entire process was a breeze. I will definitely return to LA Smokehouse and I'll be adding it to my "BBQ Favorites" list for future reference.

I stopped in because I was hungry for some snacks.  Browsed the store since I had some spare time and found it to be clean and well stocked.  Wide isles, good selection of bakery stuff, flowers and all your usual groceries. I like that they had some locally made snacks too like California Kettle Corn and Taco Works (out of SLO).  Found the semi-unusual chips I wanted that other stores don't always carry, grabbed a Diet Coke by the checkout and I was happy.  Convenient parking lot and the staff was friendly and helpful.  Thanks Albertsons!

Every time we host a large group of out-of-town guests here, we have an excellent evening! The service is always unhurried, friendly and professional. Our guests enjoy the lively and fun atmosphere combined with plentiful and tasty food!

We always head over the amazing adjoining bakery for dessert. Every item we've tried there has been delicious! Try the Greek Pastas or of course, the huge variety of baklava!

Got an estimate but went with another plumber as this was the highest quote of the 3 plumbers we interviewed for the job.
Very prompt communication though.

Will re-consider for future jobs.  Seems reliable (and often you get what you pay for!)

Amen to Andrew K!!  Finally someone else besides me recognizes the pure joy that is Imo's Pizza.
A St. Louis institution if there ever was one!!  

Imo's has been around for a long time and has only improved with time.  Their pizzas are a super thin, crispy crust and they use a creamy provel cheese (something that everyone else in the country doesn't know about...which makes me wonder, exactly WHAT is provel cheese???), regardless it's tasty.  I also usually don't eat much meat, but the pepperoni here is to die for.

You can even order this online & have it sent to you anywhere in the country.  Damn dangerous if you ask me.

When I made my 1st RETURN to New Orleans in OVER 20 years I searched and inquired from friends the best places to see, eat and drink... L√ºke (like a few other places) had popped up in many searches and recommended by many fellow yelpers).... 

On our flight from Florida I locked in a reservation for a rather late night dinner (enough time to travel to our hotel, unpack and grab a pre-dinner drink... On the flight I also checked out the menu and pictures online and was impressed but was not expecting find more than one article rating L√ºke as serving one of the best burgers in Louisiana... 

10 pm reservation on a weeknight and they were packed but our table was ready for us upon arrival.  The place is bright with impressive wood features like the eat-at bar and table partitions... the floors are should be for walking but they were drawing my eyes down to see the tile and wood inlay floors. The lighting fixtures and tin-ceiling tiles added to the charm. I also loved the way they displayed their seafood selection in a cold section at the bar.

I was very much in the mood to eat traditional New Orleans dishes like Shrimp 'N Grits or √âtouff√©e, but I kept thinking of that burger so I went for it.... 

The L√ºke Burger was legit.... bacon (glazed I believe), caramelized onions, tomatoes and emmenthaler cheese (I never heard of it either)... very pleased with my decision !

I also managed to steal a bite or two of their Shrimp 'N Grits (En Cocotte) which was absolutely spectacular !

Also enjoyed a Sazerac before dinner... they did New Orleans righteous with the city's signature drink

Yelp's own Andrea B wanted to have a UYE (unofficial yelp event) and this is where we ended up and we were treated (yes, treated, I say!) to our girl BELTING out Welcome to the Jungle.  Please do see the pic I posted, but really it doesn't do justice.  

Best of all, there was a random drag queen bake sale going on & I scored an excellent apple pie.  

No I wasn't brave enough to sing myself...maybe next time.

Being a native, St. Claude was the last place I expected to find such a great club, but it's an avenue that's turning around.  Seriously, a dragon (a real one not a costume) could walk into Kajun's and take turn on the stage and no one would bat an eye.

Minus 1 star for the billowing cigarette smoke.

Fresh food, artfully prepared . Really good for what amounts to an upscale fast food establishment. You order at the counter and it is delivered to your table or booth.
Really hip decor and vibe.
The LImeade was good as a beverage.
Friendly Service.

I've come here for drinks and brunch as well, and both times I feel like I was more impressed with the ambiance than the place itself. For drinks we were sat at the bar and had decent conversation, but the bartender was not very attentive, and sadly drinks were just poured ok, and for about $10-12 a pop, I expected more. 

For brunch, the girls and I came in to mend a bachelorette party hangover and were sat right away and thought, fabulous! Sadly our loaded grilled cheeses (bacon, avocado, egg, cheese on sour dough bread) took an ETERNITY!!! I literally had 2 cups of coffee and still nothing. Our waiter checked on us only one time and we had to flag him down to give us our check as well as to take it. Yes, I get that brunch is busy, but we got there when there was no wait at 10 am, and ordered really simple items....all three of us actually ordered the SAME thing!

Thankfully prices are not crazy,  very reasonable for brunch at about $10 a plate, we sadly were not even able to order a mimosa because our waiter was too busy, but alas, we did have a good sandwich with really fabulous potatoes. I would return, because the food was delicious, but most likely when I'm not starving.

Having stopped here before, but finally realizing its really about the spices they sell, the seafood is just blah!  The grilled catfish po boy was overpriced at $15, and just really a ton of bread!  The flavor of the catfish was good, but the French Roll is so thick that it completely takes away from the fish!

I came here recently for a work-related dinner.
I love that it is tucked far away in a little corner, which makes for quieter dining than another "innovative" sushi place in Santa Barbara.

Which brings me to my next point: Sakana is great for interesting roll and sauce combinations. There are more traditional rolls and sushi, but go for the unique menu items to appreciate what Sakana does best.

The Montecito roll and the Merry-go-round seemed to be the hot picks for the evening. Throw in a few others, add some hot tea and cold sake, and we were happy.

Presentation is really great. The sauces are beautifully presented on the platter. Definitely picture-worthy, if I'd had my camera with me.

There are no reservations here, it's first come, first served, and they would prefer not to seat you until your full party has arrived. Friends have happily waited an hour or two for their seats. But my group got lucky and were seated immediately. Good times.

Getting the car and dropping the car off is not an issue: great and fast check-in and check-out. I have been renting from National in the past couple of years, almost weekly ... and everything has been good as long you do not run into issues. I forgot a bag with some presents in the trunk of my vehicle and I realized that after I boarded the plane. I call the CS several times, I reached the national CS ... but nobody was able to help me in finding these items. Nobody seem to care even to call me back ... somebody did only after several emails and calls!

Pretty good food and if you eat a lot you can get your money's worth.

I'm usually not a huge eater.  Two rolls for me is normally more than enough.  So when I come here, I have to expect to eat more than I'm comfortable with to get my money's worth.  However, for my husband, who is a huge eater, this is a good deal.  Therefore, this is a place we'll come to when we are both super hungry, but otherwise I won't be able to eat enough to make it worth it.

At 7 p.m. on a Friday it was completely packed.  We got the last table!  By the time we left at about 8 p.m. there were tables open again.

Service is fast, which is great!  At the Saki in Tampa, it took forever to get more food.  Here, it came pretty quickly.

My husband started with the salad with ginger dressing.  He said next time he'd skip it.  There wasn't enough dressing.  I got the Crazy Roll and the White Dragon Roll.  I liked the Crazy Roll best.  Their rolls are on the small side, which is good since you'll want to try a bunch.  Both were pretty good, but I noticed the rolls tend to lack the sauce that usually take it to the next level at normal sushi places.  I also got the salt and pepper calamari.  It was perfectly seasoned.  I loved it, but since I had to eat the whole thing by myself, I found it a little greasy by the end.  I finished with the green tea ice cream.  It lacked a strong green tea flavor, but it wasn't bad.  My husband tried chicken, shrimp, and steak hibachi.  I found the meat dry, but he liked it.  The fried rice, wasn't bad, but you could see the bits where they missed mixing in the soy sauce.  

I enjoyed how you could get 8 pieces of sashimi.  I got salmon sashimi and it was good. 

This place can be very hard to find.  Luckily, I saw it off of US Hwy19 so I had a general idea of where it was.  My gps took us in the general area, but then left us to figure it out.  It sits off of US Hwy19.  As long as you know that, you should be able to find it.

It was alright. The staff were nice and accommodating, especially considering we were a large group who wanted the TV on convention coverage. And they were really nice about the fact that we showed up minutes before they closed. So 5 stars for all of that.

The food, however, was just mediocre. It was standard Americanized Mexican fare. And the packet of salad dressing was kinda creepy. Between 2 and 3 stars.

So we'll even it all out to 3 stars. It was an alright experience. If you're in the area and hankering for Mexican, why not.

This was a fun hike. It really isn't much, but there is some beauty to be seen. It's just nice to be able to leisurely stroll and take in all the greenery. I am sure during the Spring there are lots of wildflowers. We ran across very few when we went. It mostly was just very green. The trails are marked.

The people who run the nature preserve are very nice when we met them inside the air conditioned structure. We were shown a map and various other amenities.

I would just go during early Spring or Fall months. It is very hot and humid during the Summer, as Florida summers are sweltering. 

Make sure you bring lots of water and wear comfortable shoes.

A well-known University City food truck has gone brick and mortar in Brewerytown.  Hurrah!  That means you have even more opportunity to consume one of the tasty hamburgers from Spot Burger.  These are indeed excellent hamburgers ... and you have a nice wide choice of toppings.  I went with the eponymous SpOtburger and enjoyed its juicy meat along with hickory bacon, cheddar cheese and red coleslaw.  A side order of a SpOtroll completed the meal.  What is a SpOtroll?   Let me tell you ... it's a large egg roll stuffed with ground sirloin, cabbage, cheddar cheese, and bacon.  You're gonna like it .... don't know if your heart will ... but you will!  Spot Burger is a great addition to the roster of places to go in the revitalized neighborhood called Brewerytown.

I had been itching to come to Yards for a good long time now. I had heard that the brewery remakes, to the best of available knowledge, beers from the recipes of the Founding Fathers, and being a bit of a history nerd and a bit of a beer nerd, I found myself at the cross section of really needing to come down to Philly and trying the flights myself.

I got three flights of them. Thomas Jefferson's ended up being my favorite, but you know, he did have some good tastes! (he would eat macaroni in front of the other FF's and they were pretty much like WTF dude why are you eating that weird trash food... but little did they know...). I found out the Poor Richard's beer was Ben Franklin's but for some legal reasons they can't say it is him (his face does appear on the bottle). I don't know why my brain fried out and didn't make the connection between Poor Richard's Almanac (written by Ben Franklin) and the beer... Ben Franklin also had like 300 nicknames/nom de plumes so it makes sense.

I also ordered the saffron rice and lamb arancini to nosh on and not get overly drunk. Those were really unexpected (especially ata brewery) but I would so order them again. Really nice comforting flavor. 

Pro tip: It's a pretty busy place. Have your party arrive all at the same time because they don't let people in, even if you are sitting at a table. Everyone has to wait on the line.
