I wish we knew that beforehand because some of my friends had to wait a good 20 mins (we got there a bit earlier when there was no line). 

I definitely plan on making the trip again! They really need to distribute their beer closer to my home ;)
Really enjoyed the food from here! Their toasted raviolis are a good deal and tasty. Their salad with Italian dressing is great too!

After trying out a disappointing cupcakery in Orlando, I was happy to find this little shop in the strip mall near where I was eating lunch.  The cup cakes were fresh and lovely in her display case, each one marked with a Heart, noted a filled one. All cup cakes were $1.50 save for the canolli cup cake and that was $1.75 because it was real canolli filling and a bit more expensive to make. 

The shop smells wonderful upon entering. It is a bit no frills but over all, that's fine. It's the product that you're looking for. The cup cakes are small, but GOOD. Moist cake, good icing, not too sweet but very tasty. The husbeast had the blueberry filled one, and he said it was amazing, I opted for the Salted Caramel cupcake and it was DELICIOUS. 

I will come back when I'm by this way again. This is the kind of place that needs to be heard about. They're a little off the beaten path, but well worth the journey.

I am dithering on what to rate this UPS store as I had 2 dramatically different experiences on day apart.

The first day was horrible.
I actually came back the next day and even though the store was more crowded (the young lady in the back came out front to help after hanging up on a personal phone call), I had a better experience.

Do not come here if you are in a rush.

That said - they do know what they are doing and my packages were shipped without issue - please they stock inexpensive shipping supplies.

The Cochinillo Asado meal brought me back to Segovia in Spain where they are famous for the roast suckling pig. Mmm mmm I could taste it right now, the crackly skin and the tender juicy meat. This pig needs no sauce or additional seasoning.

We specifically went to Amada for the roast suckling pig and it was well worth it. At first I had reservations. About $200+ for a half pig... We could get a whole le chon for that price and feed a party of 30 from a Filipino restaurant. But once you try the roast suckling pig, you will find that there is absolutely no contest. I choose the Cochinillo Asado hands down. 

It arrived crispy and golden on a carving table complete with a personal chef who carved it away. I thought it looked tiny, it is baby after all, but after having a serving or two, I realized there was more to this pig than I had thought. Our table was left with a heaping mound of suckling pig and after six people had eaten one, two, three servings of it, a dent was barely made. Oh man your money stretches at Amada. We were all able to take home the leftovers. That's 16 lbs of pig for six people. It is no joke. I ate that pig for dinner the next day and it was just as delicious, juicy, tender, and tasty as it was the day before.

The sides are nothing to go raving about but made for a nice plate. I did enjoy the fingerling potatoes and Rosemary White Beans a lot. A tad salty and drenched with olive oil but definitely hit the spot.

We ordered the Paella Valenciana and I was gravely disappointed. The paella is a fake with strips of dry and flavorless chicken sitting on top along with toasted bread and saffron aioli. Huh? It didn't even have a crispy bottom. I am glad my request for lobster was denied. The paella is a waste of money. Stick to tapas if you feel that your suckling pig meal will be lacking. If not for the paella, I would have given Amada 5 stars.

The sangria was great. Have a drink at the bar while you're waiting and bring the pitcher to your table when ready. The atmosphere is young and hip, very lively. Definitely a fun spot for family and friends.

We actually closed down Amada and got kicked out of the restaurant for lingering too long. Ah, who said weekends in Philly are not fun?

If you have some time to spend in New Orleans - you might want to just spend all of April & May there - the place is full of awesome music festivals and it's really hard to choose the FQ Festival over Jazz Fest or vice versa.

The location & line up are always fantastic - and you don't have to worry about "in and out" privileges or such.  Taking away 1 star because they don't allow dogs - and well behaved dogs should be welcome everywhere in public spaces!

Big Ray's Fish Camp & Grille Riverwalk is located on the Riverwalk next to Sail Pavilion & the Convention Center in Downtown Tampa offering beautiful waterfront views and sunset views of Harbour Island, Davis Island, and the Hillsborough River. There is limited paid street parking available 8am-12am. Big Ray's restaurant is all outdoors with some overhead shade and is dog friendly. The overhead shade is not enough to shield from any rain. 

Big Rays Fish Camp & Grille Riverwalk serves Grouper Reubens, Grouper Sandwiches, 1/2 lb cheeseburgers, Cuban Sandwiches, Pulled Pork Sandwiches, Hot Chicken Sandwiches, Blackened Shrimp Sandwiches, Oyster Po Boys, Yucca with Blackened Shrimp, Lobster Corn Dogs, Shrimp Corn Dogs, Shrimp Po Boys, Fried Shrimp Baskets, Wings, Grilled Cheese, Chicken Fenders, smoked fish dip, U-Peel em Shrimp, Conch Fritters, Grouper Nuggets, Onion Rings.

Don't come if you are in a rush!  It took 20 minutes for a server to come to our table so we could place an order and it takes another 20 minutes to flag down a server to close out your bill when you finish the meal. It seems that Big Ray's Fish Camp is only willing to provide food runners while Sail Pavilion has to provide the servers and they're already short staffed and not known for speed of service. There were 8 tables of patrons and only 1 shared Sail Pavilion server and everyone was trying to get a hold of a server to order another drink, place an order, or close out an order and the server was nowhere to be found! After quite some time, by the time the server got to our table, the server said we have to walk up to the bar and close out our bill at the bar. When I got to the bar, there was a line of people waiting to order drinks and it took another 10 minutes to close out my order.

I got Big Ray's 1/2 lb Camp Burger medium rare with cheddar, lettuce, tomato, saut√©ed onions, camp sauce, with garlic parmesan fries. The burger was very large, the patty was thick and juicy, the burger was not overcooked, and it came with a large portion of fries.

My buddy got the blackened Grouper Sandwich with lettuce tomato onion tartar sauce with garlic parmesan fries and was also pretty pleased with his meal.

If you order any drinks, those are provided by the neighboring bar, Sail Pavilion. 

Big Ray's Fish Camp management needs to provide dedicated servers. The food runners are just standing around talking waiting for food to come out from the grill. I don't see why the food runners can't full-fill the role of servers taking orders and closing out bills while they are there. I really hope that management can improve the speed of service at this location because the food is actually pretty good and I wouldn't mind coming back again if it doesn't take forever to order and close.

This is a review of the highly regarded Townsend Restaurant during a Restaurant Week meal here.  I can certainly see glimpses in the food of why restaurant critics have been very positive but based on my experience I can only give it a middle-of-the-road assessment.  Basically the food quality is excellent - if only there were just a little more of it.  I know I am one that has often been critical of restaurants in America serving too much food but here is one that serves too little. I get it that Townsend is haute cuisine and portions are on the small side (or you won't be taken seriously as a gourmet restaurant) but you probably need to go outside Restaurant Week and spend even more money to enjoy their taster's menu of 5 or 6 courses to feel like you have had a meal here.  A lady at a table on the other side of the room was on her mobile phone and told whomever she was speaking with that she had stopped for a snack on Passyunk Avenue.  I had to laugh when a Restaurant Week dinner is called a 'snack' but that's what it kind of is.(An expensive snack though!) I have lived in Provence in the south of France and though I probably have never eaten in one of the Michelin's starred restaurants, of course I ate out many times and in many awesome places and I don't remember portions like this.  The first course was a Roasted Squash soup which I didn't know was soup when I ordered it because 'soup' was not written on the menu. One of the two girls at the table next to me also didn't realize she was ordering soup when she chose the roasted squash appetizer.  C'mon - is it some kind of trend that you can't write the word soup on a menu?  The soup was fine - all 7 or 8 spoonfuls of it. It reminded me of a roasted pumpkin soup in Vienna but it was not quite as tasty or filling. The bread course was good especially with the addition of a pepper dipping sauce. The main course was a vegetable risotto that was most delicious and very small.  It would have been such a nice gesture - especially during restaurant week just to increase the portion even by 50%.  A wonderful Huckleberry cobbler completed the meal.  Service was cordial and efficient throughout dinner although I didn't really need to re-hear the list of ingredients of each dish that I ordered when it was served as I had just read them on the menu.  

I can imagine Townsend would be a great restaurant to go to when money was no object and you could indulge in more courses than three and try out some of their wines. However if you're searching for an opportunity to try out a fine restaurant during Restaurant Week and getting value for money, I'd look elsewhere!

Tip - Be aware that an appetizer and an entr√©e on Townsend's Restaurant Week menu incur a surcharge leaving only two food choices in each category for the original $35 charge. Many Restaurant Weeks around the world prohibit upselling on their special menus but obviously the Passyunk Avenue Restaurant Week does not.

Why 4 stars?  Because it was a solid experience.

   ---   ---   ---

I knew that the fried pork sandwich was the main event, but I was too tempted by the Philly Cheesesteak with the picture of Geno's in Philadelphia on the menu next to it.  Luckily, my friend got the fried pork sandwich, so I was able to try both.

Both items were really great.  The cheesesteak did not taste like Geno's, but it was really good.  I expected it to be closer to the original cheeseteak king because the menu mentioned that included cheese whiz, but it seemed to be much greasier than Geno's. 

The fried pork sandwich was really good and definitely unique.  It came with a spicy sauce, that apparently had an even spicier version as an option.  We were told by our server that the fried pork sandwich was going to be on some kind of food network show for spicy foods.  My friend got the more mild version though, and it was delicious.

I will definitely go back to EATS!

I recently stopped in New Aston Palace for lunch. Chinese and Japanese food is served here, and the food is pretty good. I stopped in mainly for their sushi lunch. The interior won't overwhelm you, and I'd personally don't think that anyone is coming here to dine in unless they're having lunch while working. Even under those conditions I'd say order your food to go. It was down right cold inside when I decided to eat in. There are only a few small two seat tables there, which would be more convenient for the workers there than the customers...
On to the food. The spicy salmon roll was good as well as he sashimi lunch that I ordered. The sashimi was sliced on the thin side if you ask me, but it satisfied my craving. 
A decent local takeout sushi option that many small town don't have.

As Nashville continues its Los Angelesification, some things are inevitable.* Traffic will get worse. Home prices will increase. Ever more tourists will stop in to our friendly town in hopes of seeing famous people. More celebrity food/clothes shops will pop up. Sprinkles belongs to the last category (and sits next to another one). When Candace Nelson changed the cupcake world forever, she wasn't messing around. These cupcakes were huge, had interesting flavors, addictive icing, and managed to be gourmet, chic and accessible all at the same time. I don't know how she did it, but she did it. She created an empire.

I first discovered Sprinkles back when I lived in Chicago. When it popped up in the Gold Coast, I had some doubts but the first bite made me a believer. When it popped up in 12 South (again, great location scouting), I was thrilled to check out the opening and fill my belly with all sort of cupcake (and ice cream!) wonders. I was so so happy.

And then I developed a gluten issue.

For a fatty who loves cake, brownies and beer, this is definitely no bueno. There have been a lot of businesses I have had to say good-bye to in the time that's passed since my body revolted against Frankengrains. But of all the sacrifices, my dessert black hole hurt the most. The sweet cut is the deepest. But it came to pass that I had a guest in town and she wanted (needed!) to check out Sprinkles. Being the consummate host, I obliged but I was already jealous of the happiness she was about to experience while I had an air sundae. We walked in and were greeted by the typical cheery Sprinkles staff (kudos to whoever hires and trains). Off-handedly, I asked if there was anything available for someone gluten-free. I expected a 'oh, poor you' face, head tilt and a no. I received a 'yes.' Wait. What?? There was a gluten-free red velvet cupcake I could go to town on or I could avail myself of the chocolate chip cookies. Even better: I could get either (or, both) with ice cream.

Staahhhhpppp it. This changes everything. Sprinkles is back in play? Game on. I ordered a chocolate chip sandwich with peanut butter cup ice cream. What I received was a gargantuan hunk of sweet chocolatey goodness that may have changed my life. It absolutely raised my endorphins. The cookies were massive. Each cookie were much bigger than my hands and I can easily palm a basketball.** They were packed with chocolate chips, thick and had a chewy consistency that matched well with the ice cream. Not too hard. Not too soft. Just right. And the ice cream? Ridiculous. Between both cookies was a slab of creamy, rich, cup-laden peanut butter ice cream that stuck to the cookie and oozed out of the sides with every bite. To house the sandwich, it came in paper that had to be engineered by NASA. This paper never broke or wilted with the wetness of the ice cream. Nor did it leech cold on to my hand. The spoon I had to help each the sandwich came into its own once the cookies were gone and I could scoop out the leftover ice cream IN THE PAPER THAT HAD THE PROPERTIES OF A CUP. I'm telling you: NASA.

This gluten-free happiness changes everything. Everything. For those of you who can tolerate gluten without issue, you have no excuse. Sprinkles is your jam. Cupcakes, ice cream and cookies... what are you waiting for? 

*Can an increase in TV/film production be one of them?
**DM me.

Why 4 stars? Because I enjoyed my first experience and would like to check them out again.

   ---   ---   ---

My wife and I visited #HPM on the first day that it was open and after much deliberation, Hemingway's was one of the vendors we decided to patronize. While I was eye-balling the El Ultimo, my wife peer pressured me into getting a Cuban sandwich. I've pressured her into ordering what I want to try, many times in the past, so I obliged. Plus, I'm never upset when "forced" to eat a Cuban sammy.

But then I got a little crazy and also ordered chicarones and the guava & cheese empanadas. Not to mention, yuca fries on the side with my Cuban. I don't have a lot of self-control.

Ultimately, it was probably a bit too much fried food for one sitting. If I could have gone back, I probably wouldn't have ordered the chicarones. They were a-okay, but probably not worth ordering again. My wife loved the dessert empanadas, while I thought they were pretty solid. 

I think we shared the same opinion on the Cuban sandwich that we did on the empanadas. She seemed to really love it, while I thought it pretty tasty. I like when all of the meat in the middle is at least warm, rather than the outside of the bread being toasted, with a colder center. Maybe that violates some kind of traditional Cuban laws, but I just enjoy a consistency in temperature. Don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed it though! And I actually really loved the yuca fries!

While I'm still working to make my way around to every HPM vendor, I really want to return to Hemingway's for that steak sandwich!

We drove two hours round trip to dine at this place, so I figured it must be to-die-for.  We got there and was told the wait would be an hour.  That's fine, we can gamble in the meantime.  An hour later we returned and they split our group up into 3 different groups.  Um, I thought the point of the long wait was so we can all eat together.  Anyways, we were starving by this point, so I proceeded to order almost 2 of everything.  The (really young) waiter comes by, looks at the four of us, and said...I think that's too much food.  So fine, we cut it to one of everything.

When our food came out, we were so hungry we didn't care what it was on our plate.  I then realized, half of the stuff wasn't even what we ordered!

I think I'm just (still) super bitter about not being to get my hand roll.

I was lured by a friend to attend a singles mixer...had no idea it was in the private room in the back (behind double doors) and it was a speed dating event!  HAHA

I was late, happy hour ended at 6:30, I rushed to review the limited happy hour menu and was super happy to get a sangria and a carnitas taco and quesadilla pollo.

Luis, our server, was super nice, quick and attentive.  He brought me my sangria and it was lovely.  I ordered another later (just with less ice!).

My carnitas taco came and it was soooooo good......and the quesadilla was a lot larger than I thought it would be.  I think the food here, from the taste I had, was a perfect teaser for me to return because I enjoyed it all!

Besito also has an outdoor area, I think I would enjoy dining out there.... will return! Hopefully soon!

Great pharmacy to get some of the things that CVS doesn't carry, like omega acids, supplements and such.  They can be a little pricey, but sometimes you've gotta come out of pocket for the harder things to find.  Plus, the customer service is always quick and friendly.  It looks as if there is a rehab center that takes up about half of the pharmacy, so it can get pretty busy sometimes during the week around lunch.  I suggest hitting them up either early in the AM or after 4 PM.

Bad Stuff :  PARKING IS A NIGHTMARE. Weekends the line is out the door. for real!

Good Stuff:  Coffee, sandwiches and pastries, WiFi and a fairly big dining area.

I love everything about this non-profit. 1.) they're super organized (and professional-go figure); 2.) they offer training and skills that help women establish themselves in careers (financial planning, suits, resume review, personal shoppers to help select professional attire ranging from shoes and purses to jewelry and bras). They even have national partnerships with haircare products to send ladies home with all of the necessities. Their location on Meridian Street makes them easy to locate and parking alongside the building makes dropping off donations easy. Note: by appointment only. I highly recommend lending your skills and excess professional accessories/attire to this fantastic organization. Hoping I can find more time to contribute more to their work.

Reggie was awesome & friendly, served me a nice bubbly Ros√®.  Two days ago, also had excellent service & food!  Sometimes tho, I've noticed the bartender slow & gone for a long time w/ no one in the restaurant, won't name him.  The hostess is a sweetheart also.  

The Rotisserie Chicken Salad Slider was delish!!  Very nice roasted chunks of chicken, fresh lettuce, tomato & the perfect amount of Dijon Truffle Dressing on a soft Brioche roll.  Nice olive, cocktail onion & cherry tomato garnish.

Patatas Bravas w/ Pickled Jalape√±o were absolutely beautiful.  Firm colorful little tomatoes & jalape√±os w/ a nice dressing.  A must side dish! 

Lamb Stew Au Gratin was very hearty & a perfect Irish Signature Dish.  Loved it & soak up the bread mmm!

Tasso Hushpuppies comes in four.  Sweet & savory w/ sweet corn, pimento, cheddah fried w/ honey cane syrup. 

My driver told me that Public Service was where you'd pay your electric bills a long time ago.  Every where here has history & I love that you can walk to so many places.  The sidewalks suck & need help like the potholes in the roads, but the food has been delicious so worth it.

Next time will try the Crab Cake Rex which looks like a Scotch Egg wrapped in crab on top of Avocado, Roasted red pepper & corn w/ aged balsamic & hollandaise.  

BEST IN NOLA FOR: 
All three & possibly the Crab Cake Rex since about four orders go out.

I don't remember Meltkraft being here when I first visited Reading Terminal several years ago, but it's definitely a welcome addition to the market. Back at the opposite side of the 12th Street entrances (i.e. walk in from 12th Street and go straight to the back) and close to Arch, Meltkraft is part of Valley Shepherd Creamery, which makes some pretty solid cheeses (and does a bit of work on-site here as well). The ladies at the register were quite friendly and helpful in giving us advice on what to try. We ended up going with the Fresh Mozz, which, even though it's not grilled cheese, is still a phenomenal sandwich. Freshly-stretched mozzarella tastes really good with the Jersey tomatoes by itself, but definitely add the prosciutto - which adds a light meaty presence to the sandwich - and even more importantly, a dash of truffle oil, which really brings out the flavors of the whole sandwich along with its distinctive flavor. The baguette is fresh, so you're not stuck taking crunchy bites the whole time. The salt and vinegar chips served on the side are a good complement to the sandwich; they're lighter than your average chip, which is good considering you're eating a pretty thick sandwich.

While the price was a bit high - the sandwich itself came out to nearly $10, and the Fresh Mozz is relatively small (the two sandwich slices doesn't appear to take up an entire baguette) - it was really delicious. I'd definitely like to come back again and try out their grilled cheeses, which, at least on the menu, also look great. Highly recommended if you're hankering for a cheese-themed sandwich, grilled or otherwise!

Wow, this is the best Marshalls I have ever shopped. It was clean, well organized and had stuff I actually wanted to buy. The other day I went shopping at The Rack, looking for a short sleeved linen shirt and had no luck. I found it here and for only $20. What a deal. I hope they can keep it up. If they can, I will be a repeat offender. I mean, I will be a repeat shopper. 

I only shopped the Men's Dept., but the shoe selection looked huge as did the home area. 

Deer Creek Plaza has been totally redone, I'm looking forward to shopping the other new stores as they open.

This was my second time coming here. The first time I had halo halo and it was pretty good and super big. Definitely a cool sweet vibrant colored treat to have on a warm humid florida day.

Today a was a bit different.  Our first cold front for the season. I had no interest in a halo halo. I just finished slurping up some pho next door at saigon deli. We needed something sweet to balance out all the saltiness from our delicious pho soup.

There's a huge menu on the wall for pho and Boba tea and smoothies. Again, not interested.

What's for dessert I ask? They bakery case was there but empty. Not a fun sight to see when I want a sweet treat.

They said here's the menu.  Well I am not versed on filipino desserts. Growing up my parents would just buy it, & say try it. Like it or don't like it. Don't know the names of things. Help me. The guy was helpful.

Picked out an ube or purple yam cake w cream cheese frosting. Hubby was already to pre-judge  it bc he hates purple but he ate it up before I got a couple bites.

Happy we tried something new and I could recommend that. But if you don't know what anything is, don't just order from the menu. Make sure sure they show you or check out yelp pics.

Okay, I'll be that guy...you know, the first one to give the place less than 5 stars.  I applaud that the place is providing a need for the community and provides dairy free and gluten free products for those who have allergies or have decided they don't want those things in their food.  But as a guy who has been eating baked goods for nearly 60 years, I have to admit that the taste of some items came across as kind of funky to me.  

I bought a chocolate chip cookie and that was crisp and tasted pretty good.  I also snapped up a discounted day old lemon cupcake that had a delicious, creamy icing. The cake part was a tad dry, but that was kind of expected since the manager informed me about it being a day old before I made the purchase (hey, a cupcake for a $1 is a good deal!)

The peanut butter brownie was the one that I wasn't a fan of.  The brownie was very moist and gooey and the topping had large pieces of nut along with the creamier topping.  But the flavor just didn't come close to what I imagined in my mind.  Maybe it was an off batch, but it was probably more that some ingredients were substituted for those I like.  

Still, two out of three is pretty good.  I hope the place does well, it's just not the first bakery I would go to if I wanted to pick up something to snack on.

Review #945

WoooHooo. A Vietnamese / Thai place that offers a free pot of Jasmine tea!

Hungry and bored I took a 7PM Sunday night drive and I stumbled by Oriental Pearl before I hit the Delaware border. What a treat! What a delight! I was warmly greeted by an energetic hostess, seated and asked if I wanted a pot of tea. Hell yea!    The fun continued when I read the mission statement/greeting on the cover of the menu (pic). They truly want your experience to be good. And what a varied and exciting menu this was. Vietnamese and Thai. I settled on 
Curried Seafood :  A beautifully colored meal that contained  tender chunks of seafood in a fragrant and delicious red curry sauce with thinly sliced red and green peppers and various other vegetables.  Tasty meal when fresh. Very good leftover for breakfast. Yum!

Bin Bo Hue to go for a sick friend. Today he reports it's the best he's ever had. Kudos to the hostess for packing it extremely well to go without me asking. Happy to report a rare " no spillage in the car" event.

Oriental Pearl is BYO. This place is as good as any of the Washington Ave or Upper Darby Viet/ Thai establishments and the prices are right.  Can't wait to return, wine bottle in hand.

They have it all figured out.  Everything was terrific.

No reason to go overboard with details.  The Hotel Monteleone did everything right for our stay in NOLA.  Their location can't be beat.  Staff is friendly.  The room was terrific - updated, clean, with everything we wanted, including coffee maker and frig.  The room was not huge, but who needs that.  We had a king bed, a good TV, a desk, and a comfortable chair.  Closet and drawers for clothes and room to leave one suitcase out and accessible.  Famous bar and shop in lobby; rooftop pool to enjoy the sun.

Five stars all the way.

I guess you could say Good Karma left me feeling a little cold. Literally. The cafe is all adorable-like up front near the windows, but as you near the back, the charm pulls a fade faster than that one hot piece of man candy from freshman year.

This back area was drafty and chilly on a winter's day. Fortunately, my delicious latte helped keep me warm.

I could see possibly returning in order to get some serious work done; there wasn't much in the way of distractions, and the wood tables and chairs kept me from relaxing too much. If I want to grab a cuppa with friends, however, I'll head elsewhere.

I discovered Cafe Square One when I was in the neighborhood for a meeting and ran a Yelp search for salads. I was surprised that I had never heard of the place since it has great reviews and a lot of them! The cafe is small and has a few tables, but I've taken my orders to go. 

I've stopped by on two different occasions and have been very satisfied with my experiences. The menu is pretty comprehensive -¬†lots of sandwich, wrap and salad options. I've had their chicken caesar and southwest salads and both were great. Fresh ingredients, delicious dressings and super tender chicken (and lots of it!). 

The employees are so friendly! And I haven't had to wait more than a few minutes on each visit. I will definitely return whenever I'm in the area and need a quick, healthy lunch!

I give it to Ninki for being wise about their marketing strategy. Our recent Yelp's Cravin' For Asian Weekly Yelp (http://www.yelp.com/weekly?edition_id=wONFT-H307gq1Weu0g6nIg) informed me that Ninki offers 50% off an alluring assortment of sushi at all times. No kidding! Sounds too good to be true, right? 

This is precisely why I had to venture out to Belle Meade for my veg sushi fix... well that is until I saw the fantastic lunch bento box deal at $6.95. Everything from the 4 pieces of sushi to the salad, miso soup, tempura, and rice were excellent. The portions were just right but the standout was the miso soup! You may not think that miso is very exciting but I appreciated the big chunks of shitake mushrooms and robust flavor. Yum in the tum. 

Don't judge this book by it's cover either. From the exterior, Ninki is nestled inside a dated strip mall but when you walk through the doors, it is a spacious and dark place to relax and enjoy tasty but affordable Asian cuisine. 
If you're planning a dinner for a large group or a dinner party, the space has a couple of private areas that accommodate and there appears to be some flexibility in the layout of the space. 

I will definitely come back to Ninki but on my next trip, I will try the deeply discounted rolls instead. Definitely consider this spot for lunch or even a date too!

In honor of us tearing the Dodgers a new A-hole at the moment I may as well get the Citizen's Bank Park review that I had on the back burner over and done with. back in the day a few of Yelp's Finest got together to watch the Phillies decimate The Cubs (sorry Burger Assassin). And overall the game gave me the chance to enjoy and experience the bulk of what our stadium had to offer.

We were in the Nosebleed section which is something that I thought was going to be extremely awful. But in all actuality they managed to provide a much better view then I expected. And the jumbotron was especially exciting. I had a good laugh of the extent that some people went to just to get on it. the majority of the beer and food were what you'd generally expect from a ball park - $6-7 Budweiser and over priced chicken fingers. But it also did hook up a minuscule amount of better options if you looked in the right places. And it goes without saying that it hooked up an impressive amount of Phillies memorabilia. Overall it may never have the mystique that The Vet had. But it definitely has plenty to make it the new kind of classic.

Glasses of wine priced at $8 - $12 and a happy hour that consists only of reduced-price domestics? Playa, please. Public House no longer has the cool cred that warrants this type of inflation. 

I revisited Public House to meet up with some old friends from a previous job. It had been four or more years since the last time we all got together in the very same space. The crowd at the bar was smaller... much smaller. Gone were the lines at the door and, with that, the obnoxious bouncers. 

The bar food that some friends ordered looked pretty standard. I stole some housemade chips and a pickle from my friend's plate and the chips were solid but needed salt. After a few rounds, we all looked at each other for that crucial moment where you have to decide to either go home or make a move, the later of which will inevitably turn into a 2am rager. We decided for the safe option, with promises to meet up again before the end of the year, somewhere other than Public House.

Well, I'll first start off saying I do not like SPICY! Even though I'm black, I don't mess with HOTT, spicy foods. So I was turned off from this place. The reviews were GREAT, that's the only reason I tried them. 

Salmon - dry and tasteless. I'm not sure what they're seasoning their food with, but it's not not style. 

Brussels Sprouts- tasteless again and hard, but it leaves a spicy after taste. 

BBQ RIBS & Wings - The ribs fell off the bones, however the taste was of pepper and more pepper,  I thought it was the sauce so I rinsed them off and it still had that gross pepper taste. Even my eyes started to water. 

Mac & cheese was pretty tasty per my son 

Potato salad was DELICIOUS, my FAVORITE!! 

Baked beans were EXCELLENT ALSO. Finally a sweet flavor that wasn't spicy and it felt like the beans melted in your mouth, they were so GOOOOD. 

I wanted to like this place, but oh well ‚Äç. 

The two stars are for the potato salad and the baked beans, everything else was a disappointment. 

Maybe you guys should do a smoked sweet flavor. But to have it smoked AND peppery was not cool, I choked...BUT that's just me ‚Äç

I've eaten at Press'd twice since they've opened here and both times I appreciated the wide variety of choices in fresh toppings and cheese but left feeling underwhelmed.

For a place that's some purpose is to serve sandwiches, I feel like they're missing that something special.  I enjoyed my Golden Bear - Roasted Chicken, Brie Cheese, Roasted Apples, Spinach, and Sweet Fig Jam but it didn't meet my expectations of a similar sandwich at Earls.

Both my hubby and I found the Pollo Provo - Roasted Chicken, Basil Pesto, Provolone Cheese, Roasted Red Peppers, and Tomato lacking a real punch of flavour despite ingredients that should have really popped!


Staff were pleasant but not particularly informative or helpful on my visits here.  Price is a but high for such a casual joint - but check out your SUTP coupon book for deals ;-)

Overall, it's fresh and a nice option but not living up to what I had hoped for.  I'd rather pop across the street to The Tea Place for one of their fabulous, fresh, and customize able paninis.

Let's be real, who doesn't love cemeteries?!
Just me? Can't be! I'm a sucker for spooky places like this, and was determined to set foot inside its walls.

Itching to see the famous Voodoo Queen, Marie Laveau's tomb, marked with xxx's, and adorned with gifts brought by fans and admirers.
COME HERE!  (As she was a New Orleans hero - as she didn't practice "hoodoo", but good voodoo and helped to free lots of slaves! The most commonly left item left at her tomb - hair ties -which goes back to her days as a hair dresser.)

Interested in brushing up on your New Orleans history, learning of former plantation and slave days, and all about the archdiocese?
COME HERE! (Take a tour, which will fill your head with all the knowledge you need! Also stop by the visitor center, as it's filled to the brim with maps, pictures and artifacts!)

Wanting to feel like a VIP and have access not everyone has?
COME HERE! (The cemetery used to allow all visitors, but due to the amount of the vandalism, all visitors must be accompanied by a tour guide - unless you have family members inside the cemetery!)

Dying to see where Nicolas Cage will be buried?
COME HERE! (He purchased a plot of land for $250, featuring a HUGE white pyramid structure for his body to be laid to rest!)

Looking for a fun way to spend an afternoon and engross yourself with all things  tombs/cemeteries and voodoo.
COME HERE! (no really! people are dying to get in!) 

Let's face it, there is no better way to spend your afternoon!

Butcher & Bee is one of the best restaurants I've been to in Nashville. If you're a foodie and/or a hipster, forgo the meat and three and BBQ and meander over to East Nashville for a dining experience. Here's why I loved Butcher & Bee:

1) The food- It's a small plate concept with the majority of dishes being vegetable based (though they do have some meat options). My friend and I ordered four small plates and a dessert to share and we left content. A few stand outs: The whipped feta is their signature. It is good, but if you don't like feta to begin with, order something else. Avocado crispy rice- It's more salad with a whole avocado mixed in and crunch North Carolina rice. Butternut squash soup- Bold flavors with a pomegranate seed garnish. Meat balls- comes in a triad and has cheese and bread crumbs mixed in. The chocolate pot de creme with chili was good, but not sweet (In case you're obsessed with sugar like me).

2) The atmosphere- It's slick and the simple art around the restaurant is perfectly placed. We sat at the small table in front of their logo painted on the wall and several Instagrammers stopped by to snap a photo. Warning: The light is low so it doesn't make for the best photos.

3) The location- It's just off of Main Street in East Nashville within walking distance to other Nashville finds like Edley's BBQ and Family Wash. 

4) The service- It's the South so it was friendly, but not in a fake or annoying way.

If you want a good Nashville dining experience that's on the cutting edge of Nashville's food scene pivot, go to Butcher and Bee. Just don't Google it because you'll find it's NOT a local joint (It's from Charleston, South Carolina).
Hey look guys, it is above-grocery-store quality sushi at a bargain price that makes a good lunch.  There is nothing else you need to know about Jay's Favorite Sushi.

How could someone not stop in a barrrrrr called the Funky Pirate?!

Minus the shwag and the specialty grenade drink this bar feels like a Deep Ellum bar.  That might have everything to do with the bald headed, tattooed, pierced bartender that is from Dallas.  But this bar was a great stop from the crowded bars on Bourbon Street.  When in Rome...  we had to order the grenade drink which is some fruity electric green drink served in some ridiculous plastic glass with a tiny grenade on top.  Too fun!

We had a good time chatting up the bartender.  Then low and behold a great blues band came in and played.  I could have listened to those guys all night.

This bar is definitely on my places to revisit next time I'm in the big easy.

It was ok. Nothing wowed me, but it wasn't horrible. It was a quick check in process, the employees were friendly the whole time of my stay. My floor smelled like smoke though and my living area did too. I didn't like that at all. The pool was nice & clean. It had a bbq area too. That was the best part of the stay honestly. I would probably stay here again for a better rate. I think $185 is a bit much a night. The furniture in the rooms are dated. They definitely need upgrades.

These guys are awesome. I first used Wheel Tec November 2011, when I damaged my rims after riding into huge potholes. I called after hours and the owner, Jon told me to come on by and he waited for me to get there. It was dark out and he used my cell phone light to check out my wheels. Talk about dedication! We got a great deal on a new set of 22 inch rims for our SUV. 

I called back when I needed tires yesterday and one of the reps, Waldy was not only accommodating, but he also got me a great deal (my husband had already received quotes from several tire shops) on 4 tires. 

The honesty, customer service cleanliness and comfort of the waiting area at WheelTec is top notch and I highly recommend them!
Solid 'experience', and it's in the lobby, but blends in when not going through a sequence, so just grab a seat or stand in between.

Stumbled on this place after leaving Pats.  Cool bar..long and narrow.  Kinda hipsterish and cliquey but we had a blast!  Decent beer selection.  No reservations and no frickin valet parking...my kinda place!

Oh, Rocky's, how I once loved you.  Your delicious pizzas, your yummy salads, your interesting music choices.  But then you got sloppy; I would get a pizza with someone else's ingredients slopped over on one edge.  The service got...odd.

Then that whole Katrina thing happened, and you abbreviated your menu.  OK we all had to adjust but you never returned to your pre-K menu and you eliminated all my faves.  

Yes it is decent pizza but I go to Theo's or Reginelli's instead now.

The new remodel Gator Dockside looks a lot better than the old one. They have change the carpet floor to wood floor look more elegant. From the old projected TV to digital large screen TV. The renovation is welcoming the patron to the new football season. 

I like to come to this restaurant mainly is their chicken wings. First, select the way you want it - Grill, breaded, wet sauce, or boneless. Second, select number of wings. Third, select the flavor. Tonight we have tried 12 different flavors. My top three I like most are grill chipotle BBQ, grill Thai chili, and the grill Yucatan. If you dare, try their 4 alam wings. This wing is super hot that one of our friends tries it and burn the mouth. I also like the peanut butter flavor with unique taste. 

This sport bar is family oriented bar. Many families bring their kids. They have the children menu. The restaurant service is good and the food came out fast with 100 wings.

Main Street USA is alive and well at Alpine Lock and Key. 

What do I mean? Well, in small towns you could walk the Main Street and find everything you needed, products and services, and you probably knew all of the shop owners too. Shop owners legitimately cared for their customers, and made sure to take great care of each one, especially those  frustrated, in a bit of distress, or the obviously new faces coming through their door. We all know the image of the mechanic walking out of the service station to help someone broke down on the highway or the inn keeper that offers the room and hospitality to the downtrodden traveller, and that's what I'm talking about.

Well I was a new frustrated face when I walked into Alpine the first time. Id gone to three typical places to get a key copied in the last month only to come up empty handed each time. The thought occurred to me that visiting a locksmith would likely solve my problem. But who goes to a locksmith? To me, that's a mobile service I call in a pinch. Brick and mortar? It was my only option.

I'd remembered Alpine as a recommendation from a friend and as a nice shop I passed all the time on Ryland. Timing finally worked out, and I had the key with me and remembered to stop by Alpine while in the area. 

When I walked in I was surprised by all the retail goods they had, including safes, lock boxes, keychains and all kinds of hide-a-keys too. I honestly didn't know what to expect, but I can say that it exceeded whatever expectations I had, and I was really happy to be supporting this local business. Behind the counter the phones kept ringing, and you could see the pros coming from and going to jobs. 

I was greeted, told the gentleman my issues, handed him the key, asked for 4 copies, and watched as he quickly grabbed the blanks, turned the keys, and handed them back to me. When I went to pay, he just said "Thank You". 

I was blown away. This person legitimately just wanted to help me solve this problem I had, and now, any time I need a key or the like, I know where I'm heading. In fact I went back a month later and had a few more keys cut! 

I know key blanks are really cheap, but I also know it takes a while to learn this trade, and time is money. I wanted to pay, but he just wanted to help. I won't forget this experience or the way Alpine values their customers. It's truly nice to know there are still kind hearted tradespeople out there that just want to help.

Next time I'll come to Crescent City Cooks! for lessons.  My first time here was limited to browsing through the front retail portion of the store and ending up with a pair of really cool metal sweet corn pics in a signature fleur-de-lis pattern. We'll see how these go over in Iowa this coming summer!

There's lots of other stuff to admire of course, and the store is nicely laid out. The clerk was also friendly and chatty, as are a lot of folks in these parts.

The hot pot scene in Edmonton has been bubbling up over the past few years with several restaurants opening up in succession but things seem to have finally settled down. The main players, 97 Hot Pot and Asian Express Hot Pot, are located in Chinatown with Chili Hot Pot just off of Whyte Ave. Okay, Asian Express has a second location south side if you want to get all technical on me. Rounding things out, there's Kings Noodle & Hot Pot, Bangkok Restaurant and BoBo Hot Pot Restaurant.

I'm not the biggest fan of hot pot (AYCE once every 6-9 months is more than enough for me) but a sweet Groupon deal ($70.00 for 4 people) couldn't be passed up. After holding onto the coupon for a couple of months, we finally made our way over to Urban Shabu to use it with the deadline fast approaching. Always seems to be the case when you buy one, eh?

Three bros and I arrived at 7:00pm on a Thursday evening. It was L's first time ever having hot pot so we eased him into the process. The inside is spacious and what I really liked about Urban Shabu (besides their hilariously random signage) was their ventilation system. Yes, you will smell like hot pot before/during/after your meal but that's a given. Regular price is $27.95/person for all you can eat dinner, $2.00 extra for specialty soup broths (chicken broth is free) and $3.00 if you want half/half. They have a solid lunch deal ($11.95), which I believe is similar to 97's deal. There's even a parking lot in the back aka. two ways to get into the restaurant.

We each ordered a different broth - I went with the HK style satay. Not too satay-ish but it was good enough. I wasn't in a super spicy mood so it worked for me. The sauce station is pretty standard while the ordering system is guess, wait and see, which always seems to be the case when you go for hot pot. Just order more the next round to compensate!

- Good stuff: lamb, beef, enoki mushrooms, bok choy, fried bean curd (try it if you've never had it before. It soaks up all the flavours in your broth.), lamb mash, quail eggs and noodles.

- Meh stuff: beef brisket (weird odd looking pieces, not what we were expecting), green onion and spring rolls (dry, luke warm. Skip out on the fried crap).

- Japanese style sesame balls, mango tapioca, soft tofu, vanilla ice cream and osmanthus jelly cake - we were stuffed silly but obviously, we ordered dessert. There's five different items to choose from and we decided to try them all. Ridiculous. Mango tapioca was probably the best but the osmanthus jelly and soft tofu were close runner ups. The ice cream was pretty standard although I found it a bit too artificial tasting while the Japanese balls were luke warm and glutinous.

Don't be afraid to try something new. There's a ton of items to choose from so you might as well make the most of it! For the most part, everything was pretty good except for the fried items that we ordered. Price wise, it's pretty standard AYCE fare. My advice: go during lunch. Your wallet and belly will both be happy campers.

I have gotten pho to-go a few times here, as it's an easy stop on my way home from work. I have thought the pho was fine. Not amazing, not memorable, but it hit the spot when the pho craving grabbed me.

We ate in the restaurant on Saturday night, and again, it was just fine. We tried the B√≤ 7 m√≥n (7 Course of Beef Dinner).  I have had this at a restaurant in Pinellas County, and while that experience was definitely a 5/5 Star experience, this was only a 3/5 Star. When we arrived, we were the only people in the place, but service was still slow. They also forgot a drink we ordered, but we just ended up cancelling it.    

To start with, they brought out our burner of oil, the first course of beef, and the wraps - but not the vegetables to put into the wrap.  That took a good five more minutes to come out. Things did progress pretty quickly after that, though, with the other courses coming in a timely manner.  We did the meal for "3", and some of the courses I thought they were pretty skimpy for 3 people. Of all the courses, I would say my favorites were the grilled beef wrapped like a sausage, and the beef congee at the end of the meal.

They also screwed up my credit card payment at the end of the meal (and ended up hand-writing it in, which is sketchy at best).  I'm sure I'll be back for some to-go pho, but I'm still on my quest for a good B√≤ 7 m√≥n in the Tampa area.

Italian Affair has been around for a long time now. It was a favorite of my parents' when I was in high school and they've continued to visit together ever since. I couldn't remember the last time I tried it since I was never the biggest fan back then so I figured I'd go in with an open mind and see how they've evolved.

It's safe to say the space itself has not evolved. It looks exactly the same as it did years ago. But the food seemed to get better or perhaps my taste buds were just more refined..? I ordered a lasagna dish and it was pretty good, but my mom's bowtie something pasta (sorry I forget!) was the star of the table. It had spices and olive oil and it was just really nicely prepared all around. I ordered tiramisu to go, which was also a quality item.

In terms of Gloucester County's Italian restaurants, I'd say this is a good met for a nice meal. It's not outrageously good but it's satiating nonetheless.
A fun hipster gastropub in Seminole Heights. I especially like their grilled cheese sandwich with pear and honey.. Yum!

love that this is only 10 minutes from my house.  We try to go on a Sunday right before / after sunset, to avoid the long lines. They do offer a fast pass for an additional cost  ($15 I believe) but it's not really worth it, unless you are going right before Halloween. They also offer discount coupons locally or online.  Parking is usually $5.00. 

They offer a few attractions with your combo ticket, which is worth it. The hayride could be a little longer, but the scenes and actors are amazing. They have a few haunted houses/ walk thru's even a "Forrest" it's always a great time. 

I love that they offer snacks and drinks for sale, so you can sit and enjoy the live music and huge bonfire. They even offer a photo with a zombie and Valley of Fear as a backdrop. I usually think it's too much for one photo but we had a decent size group and I'm happy we got it!

Oh my, I was so happy to see The Bean Bar Co. parked in my neighborhood on a gloomy Saturday morning.

Wow, perfect timing! I walked up to their Coffee Bar/Truck and ordered a fun festive Xmas drink. Xmas Cookie Crumble Latte. That really made me happy and hyper for the whole day. 

They have many coffees and teas and breakfast danishes and breakfast sandwiches. 

They also love dogs and you can ask for a pup cup for your fur baby! 

They accept cash, credit, and Apple Pay for your convenience.

During the week, they are at Epperson Ranch Neighborhood in Wesley Chapel, and this weekend, lucky me,  they were right there where I live close enough for walking distance. I hope they are there every weekend. It probably won't be the case, but when they are, I'll be right there.  I suppose I can drive to Epperson Ranch, but walking is even more fun. The simple things, ya know!

HotBox Pizza is a 17-location Indiana chain of pizza joints that seems to flourish amongst the young adult and college crowd. As is true for most pizza joints, they offer in-house dining, carry-out and delivery within specified areas. They also offer catering and have some fund-raising options. As I don't live within the delivery range for any location, I've only experienced their dine-in option at a couple different locations. 

If you're familiar with Broad Ripple, then you already know the basics. HotBox Pizza is a "I'm drunk and need to sober up before driving home" kind of joint, because Broad Ripple has sort of a strong police presence and DUI's are more expensive than pizza pies. 

HotBox isn't and really doesn't claim to be "gourmet" pizza. I've never disliked a pizza from HotBox, but I've also never been blown away  by one. They offer the usual toppings, the usual options and fair prices. The decor is always, or at least for the places I've seen, in sort of a red/black interior that feels comfortable but doesn't really push any personality. 

As I recall, they used to offer pizza-by-the-slice at this location but I don't believe that's an option anymore. They do have a lunch special called The Lunch Box that ends at 2pm - a slice, a salad, or sticks (pick two) for $5.00. They also offer other pizza specials, but no real "individual" option after 2pm. 

I visited HotBox before the recent English Beat/Soul Asylum concert at the Vogue, hoping to grab a quick slice. Unfortunately, no "slice" was an option and I ended up ordering a small sausage pizza with a drink - the entire bill came in just over $11. They have a build-your-own option for pizza that is pretty reasonable as far as pizza goes, though I wish they'd have at least one option for an individual diner. I was not in the mood for an entire pizza, even a small one. 

I dined in. It didn't take long, which was the goal since I didn't have long before I needed to get in line for the concert. The crew was friendly, though I wouldn't say "welcoming." My order was taken and I took up a spot at one of their tables (NOTE: the window area is not wheelchair accessible, but the rest of the place is). I did have to move a chair, but that's standard. I ordered a drink and received one of their non-disposable cups you can take with you - as I was headed to a concert, I was bummed I had to toss it. 

One word of advice. HotBox only offers soft drinks other than a Hi-C fruit punch option through the fountain. As an avid iced tea drinker whose body rejects soft drinks, this is always a challenging situation. I kept with the fruit punch, but sure wish they had an iced tea option.

I was amused that HotBox appears to be a location for this new Pokemon craze going on. More than once, someone came in to tag their whatever it is. I'm old. I'm unhip. I have no idea and don't particularly care, but it was fun watching otherwise hipsters come in and make fools of themselves chasing some child's game.

Overall, HotBox Pizza continues to be a perfectly fine option if you're in the area. It's sure not a destination pizza joint, but it's a decent option if you're in the area and/or in their delivery area. The pizza is a fairly standard issue pizza and it's local as opposed to that godawful Papa John's crap. 

You like pizza? Support 'em. Just keep your expectations in check.

Our last FREE night, per my awesome Choice Rewards credit card offer (bonus points when $1000 charged within first 90 days of card use) over the summer. 

Gorgeous suite with lots pf perks. Two free treats from the little marketplace upon arrival and a really good hot breakfast the next morning. 

Lots of choices and even good coffee. 

No electronics, or ANY issues whatsoever. 

Nice staff, beautiful facility all around.

I love this open air mall. They have a lot of different options of stores. The usual that you would find at any mall. This mall is down the street for my house so I just love coming here to browse around, get some exercise, and bring my puppy for a walk. They have great events every so often, and they have a fresh market on the 1st and 3rd Saturday of each month. I love going to that. They have a lot of different fun crafty stuff, flowers, plants, dog stuff, and gourmet food selections, and most importantly fruits and veggies. They have the best xmas decorations and xmas tree at xmas time too. I am so fortunate that I live so close to here. 

They have a good amount of restaurants such as Yamato, Red Robin, Wood fire coal pizza, grillsmith, pagelli's italian food just to name a few.

Therefore anchor stores are JCPenney, Macys, and another store. Come visit if you have not been here before, you will love it!

Where do I begin?! This place is exactly what I've been looking for to take my children to play and burn off energy when it's too cold to go to an outdoor park. It's an indoor playground with so many things to do, including slides (some small for young kids, some gigantic!), rock walls, a trampoline, tunnels, a labyrinthine climbing structure, two basketball courts, hopscotch -- I know I'm missing something, because this place is huge and has so many things. 

There is also a quiet area with a hammock for kids with special needs who might become overstimulated and need some time to decompress. 

Food and drinks aren't allowed in the play area, but there is a room with tables where you can eat.

We went on a weekday at around 10 a.m. and it was crowded but manageable. By 12, though, this place was a zoo! Probably early morning and late afternoon sees the fewest crowds.

I almost forgot to mention the best part (well, two best parts): This place is free! It's attached to a church, which funds it. I asked the woman who was supervising the area if there was somewhere to donate money (because I like the idea of this place existing), and she said, "That's completely not necessary!" The other best part is that there is a drive-thru Starbucks just down the road. Score!

Yum yum, give me some . . . more!  I'm already looking forward to going back to Han Dynasty!  I LOVED the Dan Dan noodles (I'm a carb freak - esp pasta and noodles!) - the sauce wasn't sweet or too spicy - just uniquely perfect!  It was a really nice sized portion for an app too!  

Our host gave us a great overview of the place and menu and welcomed any questions.  Our server, Alex, was super nice as well.  Both seemed to really believe in their food and restaurant whole hardheartedly, which fueled my appetite!    

We shared the 'three cup chicken,' which was good, but not crazy good like the noodles or the dumplings that we got for appetizers.  

Looking forward to going back :)

This place was the cutest find in downtown St Pete! If you love wine, beer, happy hours, and chinchilla-themed anything, this is your place!

Meredith, our lovely purveyor of "great liquids", was awesome and friendly and informative about their offerings. 

They have a fantastic selection of madeiras, ports, and other wines. They also offer an array of draught beers. 

Be sure to check-in on the app for your free pour of their Rainwater madeira (if you are new to madeiras, this is a great one to start with). 

The chinchilla theme is so much fun! They have chinchilla vids playing on the TV, have the cutest shirts and masks and you can even play "chinchilla plinko" with a purchase of a bottle! 

They do have bottles for purchase to consume on or off premises. 

The inside is so clean, adorably and fashionably decorated, and there is inside, outside, and bar seating. 

A must-stop if you are in St Pete!

There's always a place or two that you can't find a good reason or heard of any to stop in...
Well, this place has fit that description for over 20+ years... Then a wings debate on my townships FB page gave me the alibi to finally stop in. With so many people naming MRI, I went in for a takeout order... I expected another false alarm. Another confirmation of my palate vs their pallet... Well, these wings were awesome!! Large, but not the biggest. Cooked perfectly. And the house sauce that they're tossed in is what made these wings a winner...
Thanks FB... I'm glad that I didn't skip over the poll. Otherwise I still wouldn't have found a reason to stop at this place... 
Guess who will be a regular from now on...

Here's my feedback regarding the recent 2 night stay at this resort.

1) I had called your hotel on 4/19/2020 and spoke with someone (did not get the person's name, but it was male) about whether your pool was going to be open, he specifically said that the pool at the hotel is open. This is mis-information that was given to customers, as upon arrival, I was informed that the pool had been closed for 1.5 months. I chose your hotel because I thought the pool would be open, but in fact, it was closed. What a disappointment.
2) Upon check in on 4/28/2020 morning, Michael assisted us with finding an ocean view room. When we arrived at room 30X, the ocean view is really NOT an ocean view because right outside our balcony - is the largest tree ever that blocks our entire view of the ocean. Please also note that when we arrived to our room, the floor was covered with at least 5-6 pieces of dog kibble. Makes me feel like the room was unkept and unclean. Is this how a 4-star hotel should be?
3) I had to contact the front desk and spoke with Anna to request a room change. This was not an easy request to satisfy either, because she gave me some options such as moving over the to Eucalyptus building 2nd floor, and would not provide a specific room number. I had to personally walk over to the 2nd floor of that building, and look out at the view and realized that there were again multiple trees blocking the ocean. I had to go meet her at the front desk to request for another 3rd floor room near room 30X, and she gave me some excuses such as your hotel doesn't allow people to move rooms during their stay, and that she can't find any other rooms available on the 3rd floor, etc. Honestly, it's just a bunch of excuses and you guys are making it MORE DIFFICULT THAN IT SHOULD BE. Customers are here to enjoy, relax and spend time in a soothing environment, but all I get is a room with a partial ocean view, and NOT what I had paid for. I informed Anna to please note in my reservation that for the next morning, I would like the front desk to find me a room near 30X that doesn't have an obstructed view. I was hoping that I could at least have 1 day where my view was truly unobstructed.
One hour later, Anna calls me back and offers Room 30Y, which she said is open and available now. I had to go downstairs and get the keys from her so that I can FINALLY move into a true ocean view room around 4 pm. What makes this situation so odd is that Michael told me that you guys are at 20% capacity, so how can there be no rooms for me to move into with a proper ocean view room?!
4) On 4/29/2020 morning, I am told by the front desk lady (and also Michael said the same thing at check-in) that I am able to redeem my free wine for a juice / milk at the Java corner. The Hispanic lady at the java corner (did not catch her name) refused to give me a simple milk carton, because she said she can only do "coffee". Then she proceeded to say that I did not have a mask on and cannot serve me. I told her that I only needed her to point out where the milk was located, and that I am NOT needing any "serving" by her. She was quite curt, rude, and just very poor service. I finally retrieved the milk carton on my own, and placed the wine card at the counter. This leaves a distaste in my mouth after interacting with her. Why does every interaction with your staff have to be so difficult?
5) I am currently a Gold member with Hilton Honors, but because I used Capital One points to book this reservation, I am not awarded any Hilton Honors points, and I don't get credit for staying here for 2 nights, which don't count towards my Gold status nights accrued. This is rather disappointing. I also offered to NOT have my room serviced during my 2 nights, so that I can earn 1,000 Hilton Honors points for being "eco-friendly" but was told by Anna that I am not eligible. Again, a disappointment. I feel no sense of appreciation from Hilton, even though I have a Gold member status. What a joke.

I really wanted to enjoy this hotel and gave it a chance, even though your reviews on Yelp are so low. But now I feel like I understand why the reviews are only 2.5 stars overall on Yelp. 

Some things I did enjoy about your hotel are:
- 2 hour bike rental, but this was basically covered by my resort fee
- the fact that your location is across from the beach with easy access, but your hotel does not offer any beach umbrellas
- there are charging ports for electric vehicles, which is essentially paid for by parking fees

I caught up with this truck at a food truck rally in Broadmoor after work one day. The chefs were hustling to keep up with the crowd. I had the mac-n-cheese and a crawfish pie. The crawfish pie was tasty and a bit small. The mac-n-cheese was rich and delicious. I appreciated that they do have vegan options since those are hard to come by with most food trucks and veggie friendly red beans n rice. 

If you're trying to hunt this truck down... well good luck. It looks like he posts to his FB page once he arrives at a location, but no schedule seems to be available. And his website still lists him as being in the Northeast. I did notice that his phone number is now NOLA local, so I guess that means he's relocated back to home.

My dog and date found a table outside, while I went in to order and grab some drinks. I ordered the Cobb salad with half an avocado, chicken, sprouts, veggie baco bits, and tomato with lemon herb dressing. Very crispy and refreshing lunch! My date ordered the tostada salad with chicken ranchero (marinated chicken in spicy sauce). The salad was packed with brown rice, black beans, guacamole, sour cream and all the veggies - equipped with a whole wheat tortilla underneath. I love that the salads came in wooden bowls, reminded me of my mom, she has the same bowls - so cool. We sat outside on a super windy day, but we had the pup so it wasn't that bad.

Oh Tips, I can say I definitely miss you!  You have quite the reputation of being a bit of an institution in New Orleans and its well deserved.  

I can't quite remember the amount of times I've been here, but it was always for local artists or free shows.  By the way the free shows during the summer = WIN.  i can't think of a better way to lure people away from their usual ho hum routinized evenings for a rollicking good time.  

Sure it can get disgustingly overpacked at times, but if you stow away to the upstairs area, it's usually a little more bearable.  Plus nice aerial view of the band and crowd mashing about below.  As other Yelpers have stated, unforgivably bad dancing can usually be observed, but hey, you're probably a part of it!

I recall the drinks being pretty decent and strong, the bartenders as prompt as can be expected with a packed venue.  

It's not the "classiest" place, but it's definitely some place that tucks away nicely in the very essence of New Orleans.  I can honestly say this is one of the few places I very very much miss.

It's a small Au Bon Pain branch but the service is friendly and they do have all of the essentials, such as bagels, croissants, salads, and sandwiches, for the same prices at any other location.  While you can't order accustom sandwich or salad, there are enough choices here that you will find something.  All I can say is that my Thai chicken salad was infinitely healtheir and better tasting than anything offered on the plane, and, for this, I was extremely thankful. This is the location in the F terminal near US Air.

Fabulous selection. Eclectic and one-of-a-kind! Customer service was so inviting and here I was just walking through on my way to the coffee shop next door LOL 

So yup... I started holiday shopping a bit early as I stayed at the Holiday Inn hotel next door to this place and was on my way to have some tea or coffee on a winters day. Walked out with banging silver earrings and ring (mexican crafted - the good heavy silver) and also a cute heavy sweater for my Tiny bit Christmas gift. 

Jewelry, blankets, dresses, bags, purses everything speaks crafted with care. The 3 lovely shop owners that I encountered were so delightful and absolutely NO HELP WHAT-SO-EVER for convincing me to tread softly hahaha I ended up staying longer and speaking with them about shipping items if I needed them in the future. I had vowed not to purchase jewelry here again, I had been spoiled by Oaxaca jewelry, yet this place has changed my mind I eagerly anticipate buying from them come Little Bit's Birthday and Mother's Day.

Respectfully Reviewed

I hesitate to downgrade my review for this place because it's a decent bar with a lot of good beers and decent food but the service my last visit is a good reason to do so. The chipotle hummus was good, a nice spiced spread with pita chips, carrots and celery. I really enjoyed my blue gouda stout burger with the horseradish a cool, creamy spread with a bit of kick and I love the sauteed mushrooms and onions in it. 

Our server though was really slow and I swear there were times that she just out right ignored us. We waited on her to give us menus and then she walked away and it took time for her to come back for drink orders and she was about to walk away before she took our food order-she gave me enough time to figure out what I wanted. She went around the area twice before she even came back with our beers and the food did come out all at once but waited and waited for our check to come and get my cc and then return with my check-enough that I was concerned for a little bit that my identity was being stolen.

Might check out the other bars in Nashville before coming back.

5 STARS x 2! 10 STARS! And a HUGE KUDOS to Chef Lisa & her very friendly Army veteran brother Brian, the co-owners of this exceptional casual eatery that opened its doors in June 2020 in the midst of Covid restrictions. TRULY AMAZING fresh flavors & textures! 

Everything you'll eat here is prepared on site, & the blue crabs are flown in weekly. Prices are somewhat higher than you may find elsewhere, but I can pretty much guarantee you will NOT get the same level of flavor and quality elsewhere as you will here. 

I am almost beyond words; this restaurant SERIOUSLY SCREAMS QUALITY! The menu is jam-packed w/ so many delectable offerings-- seafood appetizers, entrees, soups, salads, sandwiches, along w/ wings & sides. There's even dessert on the menu (such as Banana Pudding & Pound Cake, providing you'll still have room in your belly).

After much time staring at the downloaded menu (& practically drooling over the many choices), we ordered the North Ave Crab Balls (4) @ $16. They were by far the BEST CRAB BALLS (or cakes) we've ever tasted! Unlike others, upon every bite we saw & tasted fresh crab-- very little breading. SEE THE PICS! Seriously, GREAT CRAB BALLS! Our Prince George Shrimp Tacos @ $15 were Very Good-- light & flavorful (see pic). Yummy. 

According to very friendly Niki, the following menu items are extremely POPULAR: North Ave Crab Balls (Yes, ma'am!); Crab Cakes; Blue Crab Seafood Pizza; Blue Crab Nachos; Catfish Sandwich; & the Salmon Philly Cheese sandwich. 

The soups sounded amazing, & we were privileged to taste samples of the daily Maryland Crab Soup & the Rockville Shrimp & Corn Chowder (available only on Saturdays). Both were EXCELLENT, although we both preferred the creamy & rich texture of the chowder. We shall have to return to order the Crab & Corn (Fridays only) & the Cream of Crab (available only on Sundays). Niki also brought us a basket of warm, fresh Blue Crab Chips to try. A simple, yet wonderful, $4 appetizer -- SEE PIC! 

Not into seafood? There are wings on the menu in quantities of five ($7), ten ($12); fifteen ($18) & twenty ($22). 

Additional items that piqued my interest & not previously mentioned: Fish Tacos; Grilled Salmon; Crab Cake Sandwich; Soft Shelled Crab Sandwich; Blue Crab Shack Salad; Fried Shrimp & Fried Fish dinners; Shrimp Quesidias; Shrimp Po Boy (regular or spicy); Shrimp & Grits (Sunday only); & Fish & Grits (also Sunday only). I'm quite sure I omitted others that sounded & looked INCREDIBLE. (Download the menu to enjoy the vivid menu pics!) You, too, may experience great difficulty deciding what to order.

Interested in taking Blue Crabs home? WEEKLY, Brian & Lisa have 200 to 400 lbs flown in from the Chesapeake area. Customers must pre-order & pay for their Crab on Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday to receive them Thursday thru Sunday.

Have you checked out this business's webpage? It's bright, organized, & easily navigated. Patrons may order online for easy pick-up. Catering is available. This seafood restaurant participates in fundraising; Brian & Lisa select one organization monthly to receive 15% of all net sales; use the online form to have your organization considered. 

Due to the small, sparse, very casual dining room (see pics), this restaurant may not be where some would want to take a love interest on a first date; however, if s/he were wanting to impress a guest by feeding him or her SUPERIOR seafood cuisine, this is the place to come-- hands down MY FAVORITE SEAFOOD EATERY IN MY FIVE YEARS ON YELP! 

Chef Niki may not be professionally trained, but this woman can run circles around the Best of the Best! 

I have driven up to Nashville 3x over the past nine months. I shall drive up again-- & EACH AND EVERY TIME I will stop in to try more of Lisa's remarkable creations. Born & bred in Maryland, but here via Atlanta, she is Madison, Tennessee's (& our) win!

We were really excited to come here to try some authentic seafood. We were starved from the drive and noticed a long wait to be seated.

We opted to utilize the to-go window and eat at one of the open tables on the pier. [Watch out for all the flies!!!] We ordered the bread bowl clam chowder,  the crab cake, and small soda. Total came out to be about $27.

Clam chowder: Disappointed with how watery it was. I always compare my chowder to the best chowder I have ever had, and that's at Pike Place Chowder in Seattle. This is nothing compared to Pikes. 

Crab cake: 1 cake and lacked the taste and flavor. In fact, it was rather bland. Luckily, it came with a lemon, and the lemon gave it some flavor. There were 2 onion rings that accompanied the crab cake, and the batter was the same - flavorless. Cole slaw was decent, at last.

No free refills on soda, unfortunately.

There's a parking lot on the pier, but you have to get your ticket validated. Otherwise, you have to park in the neighborhood, and walk the pier. 

Should you decide to eat inside, place your name immediately on the list. It may seem long, but people get antsy and leave. Be patient.  

Great view and you definitely can't believe the scenery!!!

Ughhhh... I'm going to sound like President Obama when he talks about the economy here for just a moment: 

Look, the fact that City Dogs exists and is in place for future considerations is something we're pleased to see, but there are many avenues that need to be discussed before any further elated ventures. 

It's true. I'm on the fence here -- big time. I love this place. I love that it exists. I love that they opened a location basically in our neighborhood -- East End of Mass Ave -- and they serve as downtown's only choice for organic, healthy full-supply pet food. I love the owners. I love the food they have. I love the toys, the treats, the conversations, the knowledge, the location, the service, the food options, the openness to give out samples to see what our dog likes. So what is it?

The Hours. 

I had no idea this is what 'the hours' meant when Virgina Woolf writes to Leonard -- her husband -- "To look life in the face. Always to look life in the face. And to know it for what it is. At last to know it is. To love it for what it is. And then to put it away. Leonard always the years between us, always the years. Always the love. Always the hours." 

Yeah, I'm the yelper that quotes Virginia Woolf. 

Hopefully I'll also quote Virginia Woof who says, "please extend the hours of City Dogs as closing so early and opening so late leaves dog owners high and dry when in need -- especially in a pinch. Maybe just one day a week where they can rely upon the longer hours to accomplish all tasks. I mean, hey, maybe it'll create a Friday frenzy of pet owners who come to your store to hang out, purchase and party. First Fridays, even?"

2.5 star seems about right. 

Been here twice on my layovers. Since they accept priority pass, I decided to get my $28 per visit allowance's worth. 

Everything about this place screams mediocrity. Service, food, and ambiance. It's plain boring. Portion is huge though. And the toasted ravioli is actually pretty good. 

It is certainly not a place I'd dine if I didn't have priority pass. But for a free meal, I'll  give it a 3 star instead of 2.

We stayed at the Courtyard by Marriott Philadelphia Plymouth Meeting and really enjoyed our stay. Everyone at the hotel seemed nice, especially Kim, the lady who checked us in. Kim set the tone and was really welcoming and affable. The hotel and amenities were nice considering the tier of hotel and price paid. We were part of a wedding block and were charged $119.90 per night after taxes. Not bad.

If you're not familiar with Philadelphia, this hotel is located in the suburbs northwest of town. There's plenty of free parking and the hotel is located within walking distance of a big shopping mall, Plymouth Meeting Mall, that is anchored in part by a Whole Foods. Aside from the mall, if you don't have a car, you're going to have to Lyft/Uber to get anywhere.

This Courtyard by Marriott is four stories. Our room was 335 on the 3rd floor. It was a "KSOF" (king with sofa bed) room with a view of the parking lot and office building to the north. The hotel is surrounded by several office buildings so I suspect a lot of business travelers stay here to work at those buildings.

From the outside, the hotel looks like your standard Courtyard by Marriott. Inside, it looks like some renovation work has been done. The place was clean and looked fairly modern. While there's no full-service restaurant or shop, there is a fast-casual counter where you can order made-to-order food and drinks, a small retail corner with grab-and-go items, some dining and lounge-like areas, and a business center of sorts. There's also an indoor pool, hot tub, and gym. The gym is tiny. Outside in the back is a little courtyard with nice landscaping and additional seating. It's worth exploring and checking out.

When we checked in, Kim handed us two bottles of water and two Peanut Chews, delicious candy bars that are manufactured in Pennsylvania.

Our room was clean and comfy, and contemporary in design. The toiletries, such as the shampoo, conditioner, and body wash, were Paul Mitchell Tea Tree brand. The bathroom had a standard tub and shower with a floor that was tastefully tiled. The bed was very comfortable, from the soft-yet-firm mattress to the silky-smooth and smell-good sheets. There was an artsy-looking couch (sofa bed) with a conveniently-angled end table. The office desk was extendable which was great for more surface space. The TV was a smart TV with apps like Netflix and YouTube installed. There was a coffee maker, iron and ironing board, luggage rack, and hair dryer. The Wi-Fi was free and fast enough.
