And there was free, self-serve, tasty coffee and fruit-flavored ice water in the lobby.

Standard check-in time is 3pm and check-out is 12pm. I used the Marriott Bonvoy app to keep track of my reservation and make an early check-in (12pm) request. The hotel (Kim) was quick to respond to my chat messages in the app and she remembered me from our chat conversation when I showed up in person to check-in. I like how they stay on top of that. Saturday night, when the lobby was used for the wedding after-party, I called in a request for additional toiletries and housekeeping was reasonably quick to respond despite the craziness going on downstairs. I appreciated that.

Overall, I think this is a very good mid-tier hotel. I recommend it.

Mexican food in Indy that impresses FOUR women from Los Angeles?!?!  Yup, truth!

This review is past due but much deserved to Adam and the crew at Livery for impeccable service, WONDERFUL food, and FANTASTIC tequila and mescal drinks.

Adam knows the menu!  Trust him.  He'll take care of you and pamper your whole group like your family (family he likes, that is!).  He even gave a tiny sample of dolce de leche sauce to go because I felt in love with it.  I took it back to my hotel and rubbed it on my naked body -- it was THAT good.  

Try sitting up on the patio outside upstairs.  Nice weather and an arts-district soho noho vibe.  

Beautiful decor.

Extensive menu but I'll highlight several things...

You must try the cauliflower starter.  Oh my!  A total hit with the table.  And the cheese empanadas were divine!  

For entrees --
My colleagues and I also loved the Mahi mahi tacos and skirt steak but by far the winner for dinner entrees was the Portobello Tostada.  I am noooooo where near a vegetarian, but this thing was BURSTing with flavor and a hit with everyone.

For dessert--
Get the same platter.
Beautiful chocolate flan.
Yummy tres leches cake.
And for 4 women from So Cal --- unanimous vote for best churros ever!  It was a surprise to all of us.  The dulce de leche sauce was lick-the-plate fantastic!  

Also try their version of The Cadillac Margarita - boozie and yummy!

So surprised to have such a great dining experience in the middle of Indy, but we loved it and highly recommend it to locals and travelers alike!

Non appetite!

It's hotel food - and usually I might give a place like this 2 stars - but I am giving 3 due to VERY nice service and we lingered a very, very long time.  The main dining room was nearly empty (but the bar was hoping for happy hour) on the week night we went.

A good friend of mine who is vegetarian got the pasta with goat cheese which looked very good.

The female server was superb!  Very attentive and brought us apples and nuts (with a nut cracker) to snack on.

While there are far better choices nearby - this was a warm safe place to kill a few hours on a bitterly cold afternoon.

This park is huge, well planned out, gorgeous and has something for everyone.  Driving through I saw people fishing, renting canoes, having pinics and just enjoying the beautiful weather.

The art museum, sculpture garden, botanical gardens, small kids amusement park, pond etc are all here.  They also had a nice running/bike trail.

We were attending the seafood festival and I am so glad we kicked off our shoes and walked barefoot through the grass for a while.  

The next time I come to NOLA I will spend more time here relaxing!

We had another restaurant in mind on Frenchmen St. After a so-so vibe at the place we were considering -- I honestly don't remember its name -- we bailed and went with a recommendation from the bartender (bah-tenduh) at Hermes Bar at Antoine's.

The place was pretty low-maintenance with a lot of cool-looking servers in hats. It seemed like a mix of tourists and locals.

Since we never got the hang of ordering properly -- us Californians are used to smaller portions -- we asked for an ungodly amount of food. An enormous basket of fried okra, fried chicken, mustard greens, collared greens, mashed potatoes, and cornbread. Though the fried okra was pretty good (also seems hard to mess this up), and the sides were fantastic, the fried chicken stood out for me. That batter is insane. We didn't talk the whole way through the meal: a sign of a good one! Pralines to go made my day later on.

I'd love to spend more time on Frenchmen St. -- for food, music, and bars -- next time we're in town. Nicely out of the way from Bourbon Street madness.

My husband and I were walking in Ybor city  just to see what's around and stopped by this place for a dessert.  

We ordered a crepe with strawberry, banana, Irish creme and Nuetella.  The guy who made our crepe was really unfriendly and pissed off for some reason.  The crepe had too much Nuetella sauce and not enough of fruits and definitely overpriced!!  I am from Japan and they sell crepes as a street food for $4-$6.  And they are usually packed with fruits.  The crepe I had here was $10 and lacked everything I was looking for in a crepe.  

I did not have any non-sweet crepe here so I cannot say anything about those.  However, I have traveled the world and this place is definitely definitely not the best crepe I had.  Not even close at all.  This place could not fool me!

The office went again, sans the vegetarian. We all got the strip steak . . . lucious steak, a little fatty on the outer rims, but isn't that what gives it flavor? The outside grill crustiness was divine, and the steaks were all done beautifully medium rare!!

Salads were great . . .various dressings: creamy Italian, bleu cheese and the Biggie's White French (similar to Thousand Island).

Sides: baked potato with sour cream was a massive missile of carbs, which he loved; I got lots of broccoli perfectly cooked, can't remember the other diner's side.

I got a to-go vessel of the fried chicken dinner: $10 for half a chicken, and I got two sides instead of a side and a salad -- at the recommendation of our server. Evidently, Thursday and Sunday are fried chicken days! And I had that lovely specimen for dinner!!! Sadly, though, it was underseasoned . . . so, while crunchy and juicy, it was rather bland.

Beyond that, I had a wonderful to-go vessel of half of my broccoli and more than half of my steak for another day! That salad was filling. Not to mention the bread!

And I must mention that everybody is so nice here! Greeting you! Happy you're there! Fabulous service! Saying goodbye and come again! It's nice to know your patronage is appreciated!

We got a large wagyu cheesesteak from Capriotti's and ate it here.  We are glad we tried hangman Brewing. Fun Goth Decor and live bands, not my thing but everyone else seemed to really like it. Fun story about Hangman Brewing, live bands and me.

In my best Jeff Foxworthy voice: You might be a Westbanker if... you're excited about the new Wal Mart.

Okay, so I won't say I am excited per se, but I am pretty happy that there is a Wal Mart in the 'hood that is an actual grocery store and not a super gigantic "if you need it, we got it" Wal Mart that they all seem to be these days. If you remember the Wal Marts of yesteryear- when life was a little simpler and you couldn't buy a gun in aisle 6, then this is the place for you.

Today was the opening day, so you know I had to be first in line. Not really, but I was there at 11 to beat the impending crowd. There was still a crowd, mind you, but it was manageable. They have a nice selection of things here and it's new and clean, so I enjoyed that while it lasted. I was most impressed with the bakery section, as they had a nice selection of breakfast pastries that were well priced. I scooped up some rolls, just to say I helped the cause (does Wal Mart need my help? Nah.) The beer section isn't anything to write home about, but they do have a pretty impressive wine selection.

The lines were short, even though there was a bit of a crowd and all of the employees were working fast to get everyone in and out. Ample parking and a big parking lot made navigating the parking area a breeze. It's everything that you would expect from a typical grocery store, and while it's no Rouses, it's a nice addition to the area.

My husband and I visited Steak 33 and had a remarkable time. My husband really likes steaks, so I thought this would be the perfect place for our date night. First things first,we selected and enjoyed the sparkling wine. For appetizers, we chose the Jumbo Lump Crab Cake and Baked Oysters. Both were delicious, but I really enjoyed the crab cake. Remember, MAMA LOUISIANA!!! My husband got the Filet Steak. He was highly impressed with the quality. He says it was one of the best steaks in the city. I chose the poultry, which was the Daily Fish. I have photos below of the (seasoned to perfection) fish. I love, love, love the sauce on the fish. For sides, we got potatoes au grautins and creamed spinach. Even though I am a foodie, I still like to incorporate veggies when I can. The Au Gratin menu at Steak 33 is pretty extensive. You can get anything Au Gratin from Spinach, Cauliflower, Potatoes, Peas, Crabmeat, Lobster and Broccoli. We topped off our date night with a Rum Rasin bread pudding. That was just the 'creme De La creme'.  Magnificent!! 
‚Äã
The restaurant is located on Bourbon Street. Perfect for getting out there then grabbing a good dinner to soak up all of the drinks! The waiters were extremely helpful and accommodating to us. We will be back for the Fried Chicken Brunch in September.

Pacific Counter is a fairly new poke and sushi burrito shop in Downtown St. Pete. Prices are fair and will run you about $12 for a bowl or burrito. Portions are more than sufficient.

I had a Golden Hour sushi burrito which is mainly made with salmon and krab. I really enjoyed the taste of the nori (seaweed) wrapper and the vibe of the place is very Polynesian with a touch of surf. I like the branding of the place. Ambiance is something places don't always get right across the bridge.

I also tried their Dole whip dessert and that was also great, I'm not much of a dessert guy - but I would order it. Overall, I recommend Pacific Counter and think its a great option when that poke or sushi craving strikes in DTSP.

I made my first trip to this buffet after having lived in town for over six years and I will say that the food is pretty good, at least it's as good as the stuff you can buy prepackaged at the grocery (from the freezer section.)  I was surprised at how large the dining area was and how many buffet lines (five in total) were available to choose from.  But I found the staff a bit difficult to communicate with and maybe it's just a cultural thing, but they don't interact with the customers any more than the minimum.

When I entered and let the hostess know I was by myself, I was directed to follow a server who showed me to a table.  She provided my napkins, utensils, and asked my drink order.  After bringing my drink, she then disappeared.  I have been to restaurants that have buffets as an option, but also allow you to order from a menu.  No menu here.  I've also been to buffets where they charge you by the weight of your purchase.  No scales here.  And in almost every case, the server/hostess has directed me to help myself when ready or at least asked if I had any questions.  I tried talking with the server and she thought I was asking her to get the food for me.  Again, difficulty in communicating.

So, I helped myself to one of the five buffet lines.  I started with a salad.  When I finished, I left my used plate on my table and grabbed another plate to try some Chinese foods, including the egg drop soup (help yourself to additional plates and bowls as needed.)  By the time I got back to my table, my old plate was cleared.  Yeah!

What surprised me was that none of the other reviews have mentioned that there are quite a few American dishes to eat here:  pizza slices, fish, chicken wings, Texas toast, and a separate line devoted to desserts.  Who knew?  It appears that you can continue going to get more food until you pop or decide you've had enough.  All for under $10.  Just amazes me how people think it's too expensive. 

Anyway, now that I know they have a wide variety of food options and that you help yourself whenever you are ready, I would probably have a better experience on a return trip.  

Oh, I also recommend flagging down your server when you are ready so that she can bring your bill.  You pay at the front desk when you are finished.

Review #1992

I don't know how I haven't reviewed Buddy Brew before!

Their COLD BREW is one of my favorites in the state. Super smooth and flavorful. I've unfortunately never tried the food - but every time I see it being brought out I wish I was hungry. I imagine it's a pretty great lunch stop from the looks of it.

The ATMOSPHERE at this location is great. There is tons of seating and it's super trendy inside. Good for groups, for working, or just stopping in to have a coffee with friends. There are comfy couches and a big table / work space.

The SERVICE: the people aren't overly friendly but they're not the coffee snobs you'll find at a lot of other great places around the nation. I imagine I haven't had the chance to talk to the people behind the counter much because they're always super busy.

If you've never had Buddy Brew coffee and you like cold brew I'd definitely recommend stopping it to try! It's delicious and really well done. And who doesn't love a great local coffee shop?!

Such a cute place, I'm disappointed in myself for not coming here sooner. 

I thought this was only a place where you ordered cakes for special occasions. I didn't realize you could get small desserts and coffee and eat it here! It's a really cute concept. There is very limited seating, but when we came we were the only ones in here so I think most people take stuff to go freeing up space for people who want to stay! We ended up being like most people and grabbing and going.

We went with the chocolate pound cake and a chocolate chip cookie. Both were good and satisfied my sweet tooth. The cookie was like a puck and more crunchy than soft. It had giant hunks of chocolate in it. Every bite was full of chocolate. At $3.99 it isn't an inexpensive cookie, especially because it isn't that big, but the amount of chocolate somewhat justifies the price.

The chocolate pound cake was delicious. At $5.99 that is the price I expect it to be. It was covered in a chocolate frosting. It was very moist and decadent. I almost ate the whole thing in one sitting, but I had to save some for my husband. 

Overall I like this place. I think it is cute and definitely worth stopping at if you have a sweet tooth and are in the area.

Came to Scully's on the first night down in Florida. It's a half indoor/outdoor restaurant right smack in the middle of John's Pass on the west coast. It's located right off the gulf and overlooks the water. Honestly, I prefer indoors especially during the humid weather but that night in particular was great for eating outside. 

As you can probably guess by the name as well as the location... this is a seafood establishment. The menu consists of items such as: shrimp, fish fillet (salmon, tilapia, mahi mahi), fish and chips, scallops and more. They also have non-seafood dishes like burgers and such. So if you're not really into seafood, you'll have options. We sat outside in a wooden deck/patio which was nice. There are these big bells that if you see a dolphin swimming in the water you have to ring it! I thought that was a cute touch. And luckily enough, we saw a few! 

For dinner I got the shrimp scampi (lightly sauced) and it was pretty good. I'm not sure if they cook things different down there but the sauce was heavy for my liking. The shrimp and pasta was cooked well. It was just that scampi sauce. I'll try this place again and update when I got back to good ol' FL.

I hate the guy who wrote the song "Sweet Home Alabama".  

Cafe Bosna has a big list of "Chef's Specials" that are subject to limited availability throughout the day.  Our server, the son of the owner/cook, said that they guy who wrote the penultimate southern rock anthem likes the food so much that he goes in and buys up all the food to last him through the week.  This infuriated me because it's selfish and it's bad business.  They need to come up with a plan with that guy because it could anger customers like me.  

Then there is the decor.  First, the tables are metal with metal chairs like the social hall at the VFW or your local church.  The tables are covered in vinyl white table cloths.  We sat next to some shelves that had a DVD player that wasn't plugged in, excess glasses, books and paperwork that looked like mail that was open and it was left on the shelf.

In the front was a small stage and there was a guy playing guitar and one playing mandolin who are supposedly there every Thursday through Saturday.  They played easy listening hits from the last century.  They played very well.  The music isn't very loud but there is something strange about hearing an instrumental version of "Mr. Sandman".  

There were a few specials left.  I tried the beef roulaten and it was very good.  It was served with mashed potatoes and red cabbage.  I also had the cabbage soup and it was some of the best soup I've ever had.    My sister had the Wienerschnitzel and my mom had the Jagerschnitzel.  I tried both and both tasted like they came straight from the Fatherland.  Everything was expertly prepared, fresh and flavorful.

Please note that this restaurant does not serve any alcohol.  The menu says "BYOB" so I assume you can bring your own portable potent potable.  I don't know if there is a corking fee or not.

The food is the only reason that I would return.  I think this place could easily be translated to an upscale eatery.  However, as it is now, it's not the most comfortable place to enjoy a meal.

Bobbie was really sweet and gave me a great haircut. I know I'm difficult but I really appreciate that she took her time with me and gave me the exact cut I was hoping for. They use Paul Mitchell hair products which made my hair silky smooth and the haircut was only $35 and they take walk ins. Unheard of! I'm definitely a fan.

The Yellow Submarine has been serving up sizeable sandwiches with a side of sass, sense of humor, and sarcasm for almost 40 years in the Reno-Sparks area! The story is a sweet one, and one I love to hear in our community. 

The original owner had grown the business from one successful shop to three in about 20 years. When he decided to retire, he sold two and was approached by an employee who'd been there for almost 20 years who was interested in buying the original business. He told her to make an offer, so she did and, in response, he cut her number in HALF and said the place is yours! Rumor has it he's now off sailing the world, not in a submarine, but a photo of him on his boat sits up on a shelf watching over everything. I was told he still calls to check in and give the new owner a hard time, and I'm sure that's how this place has kept up the witty and gritty sarcastic vibe and spirit all these years. 

Under that tough exterior is a business run on dedication, love, and camaraderie and you feel that as soon as you walk in. I showed up a little after 7 (they close at 8), and there was one other customer there picking up, what I learned was her usual Thursday order. The nice gal behind the counter made me feel right at home, and said she'd be with me ASAP. I went ahead and explored the shop a little more, which was when I noticed the half priced beer on Thursdays ($1.50!). I grabbed one and started looking at the fun trinkets, crafts, signs and photos all over the walls, including a large collection of Wizard of Oz memorabilia, all of which really give you a sense of who runs this place. 

When it was my turn to order, I was excited, and asked her what's good. She said the Yellow Sub was the way to go. This thing sounded like a monster with ham, salami, and pastrami, provolone and swiss cheese, lettuce, tomato, onion, sprouts (I didn't get these), mayo, oil & vinegar, and parmesan cheese. I came in hoping for an Italian sub, so I asked to sub capicola for pastrami, which she was happy to do, and she even offered to sprinkle some oregano on for a little more Italian flair! I had seen the 12" sub go home with the other lady, and it could feed 4, so I opted for the 6" and it was massive! The bread was fresh and had that chewy texture I look for in a sub roll, the meat plentiful (at least 1/2lb!), and the veggies crisp and delicious with just the right amount of "dressing" from the oil & vinegar, parmesan, S&P and oregano.

I'm amazed it took me almost 7 years to find it, but I'm so glad I took Yelper Amanda M's suggestion and went in last night. I will be back soon and I'll be bringing others to meet this institution face to face.

Parking can be a bit troublesome to find 

The wait on a Saturday afternoon was about fifteen minutes. Once you order, the food is out in just minutes. We were checked up on twice. 

The ribs were tender, moist and fall off the bone. I recommend buying a half rack of ribs plus two sides to share between two. 

I loved their vinegar out of their four sauce. The pork skin isn't greasy and the seasoning is tasty. The deviled egg potato salad was creamy and delicious. Heavy enough to put me in a food coma. Lastly their sweet tea is a must to wash down all the delicious bbq meat.

I popped by Luke for the simple reason of hitting them for their HAPPY HOUR SPECIAL - $0.75 oyster, $1.25 fried oysters and half off drinks 3-6pm Everyday.

I just wanted a couple of the fried oysters, but was told that they come by the half dozen.  Okay, that's fine.

They arrived in a cute fry basket, and down they went way too easily.

Our group of gals headed over to Tavern for a brunch while visiting Nashville for a bachelorette party. We were a party of five, and while we waited for a table, we found a back bar that was quieter than the main dining room chock-full of brunchers and bach parties ( I literally had no idea that Nashville was such a bach party destination). At this little back bar was one of the most chill bartenders, Rebekah, who took care of us with delicious bloody marys and bellinis (and much needed waters). During brunch, there is a two-for-one on their Brunch Libations which includes bloody marys, mimosas, bellinis, and sangria. Definitely worth it. 

We opted to sit outside since the weather was pleasant. The prices are really fair especially since some of the dishes were massive. I split the Singapore Stir Fry with another gal, and my own dish seemed like one serving. I also got avocados to mash into it!  I do feel like this dish could've had more oomph of flavor, but maybe its toned down for the hoi polloi so ask for some hot sauce!  

The Maple Fondue is great to try a little bit of everything on their menu, and I love savory and sweet flavors together. Standout was the grilled spicy chicken sausage. Great for the whole table. 

Not sure if it was because we were outside, but our waitress (not Rebekah, but a different gal) was a bit MIA at times. Note to folks wanting to eat outside during the summer, at some point it will get warm, haha, so maybe bring a fan 'cause what's brunch without a cute fan. 

I'd definitely suggest this as a great spot to bring a group for brunch, and would be interested to check them out on a return visit for other eating hours and to peruse their beer selection! 

$11.50 SINGAPORE STIR FRY
#1 short-grain rice / sunny side up eggs / bacon / scallions / sweet & spicy soy / wok-flavored

$17 MAPLE FONDUE ( FOR THE TABLE)
warm maple syrup / fresh fruit / red velvet waffle / grilled sausages / pain perdu
I got the cheesesteak.  Good old school pizza shop.  Good roll, good amount of meat and the cheese was melted in nicely.  The employees razzing each other made for good background noise.

We love this place.

We have had a membership here for over 10 years.   it's clean and everything is in a big oval so you are not missing major parts of the zoo.  

They are always updating and making the zoo better.  The childrens zoo is new and very well thought out.  My son loves going to this area.

They have plenty of parking. The staff is helpful.

For the money the membership is an amazing deal.  We are here all year.. Covers parking and discount in the shop/food areas.   

We visited Santa and he was awesome.  Prices for pics were very reasonable (cheaper then the mall).

We will DEFINITELY be back.

[780]

The large Starbucks location is located at the Gloucester Premium Outlets.

No drive thru as it's part of the outlets.

It's a busy location but they were able to work the line quickly and prepare the order correctly.

Plenty of indoor and outdoor seating.

We actually spilled our coffee outside before taking a sip and the staff replaced it with a smile.

We will definitely be back.

I will rate the surrounding areas a 5. This is some of the best of the best of the desert. The city itself is a 2. The place has so much potential, and you can find small gem areas in town, but for the most part, it is a let down. We were here for a few weeks and tried hard to find things we liked. We found some, but actually found may more things we didn't like here.

I stayed here for a weekend while visiting Philly.

PROS:
Location- Nice view of Broad St all the way down to City Hall, depending on where your room is.
Beds are NICE and COMFY.

CONS:
-Ice Machines are NOT on every floor, but on every other floor. Some don't even work and you end up looking for one that works.
-Pool is SMALL
-No FRIDGE
-NO VENTS in the bathrooms. Feel like dropping a bomb, don't forget the Febreze.

All in all it was a great stay, just with a few minor setbacks.

Popped into Ben's the other day to kill some time while we were getting a Thule Roof cargo carrier installed just down the block at Racks For Cars.

First of all, why on earth did I not visit here before?!? I used to work just down the block from here 1 day a week.  Even back then, office peeps would frequently go to Ben's for a quick sandwich to-go! 

The small store is filled with all kinds of Dutch goodies and treats ranging from wooden shoes to the largest bulk display of black licorice I've ever seen (try salty)!  Even check out their website to get the run down on the treats!  http://www.bensmeats.com/dutch-candy-shop/

The butcher shop is awesome and you can even watch them do their magic while you are in shop!  They offer all kinds of deals/options for freezer packs of meat!  Special Orders?  You bet, Ben's Meat has you covered here, too!

They offer hot items made to order such as Croquettes (GO TRY ONE NOW), gluten free chicken & fries, and various sandwiches/subs!  Don't forget custom orders for holidays such as their Gluten Free Pumpkin Pies!

Be sure to take a jaunt around the whole store to get a feel for what they offer as well as taking in their generational picture wall back by the coffee and bistro table section (you might even find a shot of Dave with Gordon Ramsey).  Owened and operated by the same family in Edmonton, since 1953 - not something you find everyday!

And above all, remember they are closed on Sundays so you best be getting there no later than Saturday for your Sunday BBQ needs!

This spot is unlike many coffee shops in town. It's nestled in a residential area. It serves various coffee and tea drinks. And wine. 

A great use of an old brick building with simple furnishings. Plenty of tables throughout the space. Yet when full doesn't seem loud, you hardly notice any others around you. Free wifi-Giuseppe. 

Two large cases of pastries, sandwiches and other treats. They even warm them up for you. I enjoyed a wonderful large breakfast bacon calzone with a little salad for $6.50 and a tea latte for $2.50. My friend had a Caprese salad that filled her plate. 

In good weather there are a few tables outside in the yard. 

Last month I stopped in and they had a great wine sale going on. Couldn't believe the selection of wines they had and the sale prices $10-40. 

Just a nice place to hang out and enjoy with friends

This is not my favorite Goodwill location but it has some good points.  They have a nice drive-thru donation area and the store itself is very large.  However, about half of the store is dollar store junk.  

It's like a dollar store was going out of business and donated their entire stock to the store.  And it's not just a small section of the store...there is a literal warehouse at the back of the building and the crap is allllllll over the store.  These are not the type of items that I hope to find at a Goodwill.  I want a velvet painting of Elvis...not a tube of hemorrhoid cream or a plunger.   

The departments are VERY loosely organized.  For example, all the childrens clothing is in the same area but none of it is separated by size or gender.  All of the shoes are in the same area but not separated by gender or size.  The racks of womens clothing are separated by type and have tags along the racks indicating they are separated by size but they are not.  You are just as likely to find a size 2 in the "XL" rack as you are an XL.  I really wish they would put all the plus sizes in a certain area like every other f*cking thrift store...it would make my life so much easier.  

Coming from a larger town with many very organized and shoppable thrift stores this place is dissapointing.  You really have to dig and it's a bit of a treasure hunt to sort through all the dollar store items.  

I will say it's pretty clean for a Goodwill.  They keep the items picked up off the floor for the most part and the employees are all very friendly.  But honestly if there was a different Goodwill in town I'd go to that one instead.  Time to check out the Salvation Army!

For years I've driven by this place,
Which just looks like some dump. 
But now that I've eaten here,
I feel like a chump.

This is the best pulled pork
That I've ever had. 
The ribs and potato salad were great
The baked beans were not bad. 

The pork was pink with smoke
But not the least bit greasy!
Smoking meat takes time
But they make it look easy!

The ribs were so tender 
The meat fell off the bone. 
The potato salad tasted 
Just like what I make at home!

They have many sauces 
I tried the vinegar based sweet. 
And the mustardy Carolina hot
Which only had a mild heat. 

The place is pretty small 
But they sure know their meat. 
I'll be back there soon
I live right down the street!

Don't shoot me...but....I'm not a pizza girl. Yeah - it's almost like saying you don't like rainbows or butterflies. But, in comparison to the general population, I don't get half as excited as ya'll do when it comes to the savory pie. It might be even better to describe me as a pizza snob. The kind of person who gets all razzled for pizzas that have toppings like prosciutto, arugula or sun dried tomatoes. Snob. You won't find me knocking at the door of Pizza Hut or Pizza King. However, if I'm in Italy - I'm eating pizza. And, if I'm in Indy, I'm eating Bazbeaux (conveniently located in my neighborhood).  

I think it's the wide variety of available veggies that makes me love Bazbeaux so much. Last night, I opted for the new "Fresh Pizza" - pesto/olive oil in place of pizza sauce, arugula, roasted tomatoes, mozzarella (sliced), basil with added garlic and proscuitto. I was a little bummed that I didn't opt for the larger size because by the final slice, my friends and I were passing it like a pipe...just oneeee moooorrreeee bitteeee... The cherry on top? BP carries H20 Sushi's soheartyitsgottabehealthy,right? Shagbark cookies. If you haven't had one, stop waiting. Make it happen. 

Their new location in the 3Mass building seems to suit them well - spacious with a sidewalk cafe. The only bummer is that the old location is still sitting empty in one of Downtown's primest of prime locations.

The host hotel for the Legendary Haunt Tour. My room was up on the 5th floor, the quiet floor. It was for the most part.  The bed was comfortable, the shower was nice, but there were a few housekeeping issues, such as: a few stray hairs on the tile of the shower floor.  Odd things on the carpet that were missed by the vacuum - like food or something. Not sure what they were. One coffee mug was NOT clean, but had been "Wiped out and put back."

*drum roll please*

I will be the very first to confess that I am not a coffee drinker. I never got used to the taste of coffee, although I do like the smell of freshly-brewed coffee. What I do enjoy is a place to visit with friends, sip a beverage of my choosing, and relax in a comfortable "homey" environment.

Sips Specialty Coffee House is just such a place, located along Gunn Highway near Citrus Park. You'll find Sips in a little strip mall out in front of Super WalMart and down the block from an Amscot financial center. It's right at the intersection of Gunn and Henderson Road.

Walking in the front door I had to do a double-take because I thought that I'd stepped back into my mother's kitchen. You could smell all of the wonderful scents of baked goods, along with the flavors of coffee and toppings. There were people sitting at tables, sipping their drinks, playing cards, board games, laughing, and chattering away. The decorations were definitely right in line with what my Mom would have placed around her kitchen.

I had the opportunity to meet the owners, Caryn and Ken Reed, and learn a bit about their journey from Michigan to Florida, and the idea for their coffee house which opened six months ago. Very nice, down-to-earth people who are looking to provide that comfy neighborhood gathering place for people to meet up, play a game of Jenga or chess, and do a bit of networking. 

Oh yes, and enjoy that coffee - hot, iced, blended, frozen - you name it. The house special is Sips Mocha which is made with white chocolate, swirls of caramel, steamed milk & espresso. They have lattes and mochas and cappuccinos and espressos, fruit smoothies, hot teas, iced teas, and your regular ol' cup o' Joe. There's also a refrigerated case with fruit juices, soda, and bottled water.

They have a baked goods counter with bagels, muffins and pastries, and these AMAZING homemade dark chocolate cupcakes with Reese's cups inside.  YUMMMMM!!!!

For those who are on the go and don't want to climb out of your car, then Sips has a drive-up, full-service window. You can get a single-serving cup, or pick up one of their containers of coffee for the office.

Now one final treat -- especially for us Yelpers. Sips happens to employ the very lovely and sweet Ms. Cece C. as a barrista, and I highly encourage you to stop in and say Hi to her.

Yes, I understand, there are a lot of places where you can stop for coffee, but not many places offer this type of cozy atmosphere. It is worth the time to stop and make some new friends while enjoying a great cup of......well, I was gonna say tea, but y'all would probably like the coffee a whole lot too.

Really a great Salon! I got my hair cut by Jessica, and she is the sweetest stylist you will ever meet. I got acquainted to the salon via Yelp, and was definitely willing to try it despite the distance from my house based on the reviews and positive comments. 

Once I got there, I parked on a side street (free, 2am-8pm for 2 hours only) which was  no trouble at all and walked a block to the salon. The area is different from what I was expecting, seeing as this was my first time in this part of town, seemed a little...grubby. However, the salon was presentable, and almost had a little bit of a hipster vibe (it IS organic, anyway) which I was comfortable with. They dont have state of the art decor and furniture, but I liked the homey feel and their vintage pieces and the ease at which the clients and hair stylists moved around. I was offered a drink, and sat to get my hair washed, cut and dried, all for $35. Very affordable, especially for me! She listened to all my concerns and then gave me a nice trim and updated my current cut for the look I wanted. Nothing bad to say about the entire experience. I loved the little scalp massage during the wash too!

Definitely a good experience and I'd likely come back in the future to get my hair cut again, but do wish it was a little closer to home.

I have been going to Psychosomatic Fitness since January. I don't have any experience to compare to. I just needed to change things, and with the help of Matt, Arnold, Josh and sometimes Brad I'm getting there. Initially I started with a 3week trial package and I then signed up for more permanent membership. Since there are always membership drives for the group classes I've signed up for, the classes can vary in size from 5-16 people. Psychosomatic Fitness offers classes as early as 5 am and as late as 6:30pm during the week and two sessions on Saturday morning at 8 and 9am. They are closed Sunday.
It's not at all easy but overall if you are willing to do the work, they provide the tools to help you reach your goals. No two sessions are the same, it is always a mix up of various things. 
I started out with a right foot injury and a left knee strain. So when it's time for certain sets, like box jumps, which pretty quickly hurt my knee, I tell them I need an alternative and they find alternatives to make sure I'm working what I need to without hurting myself. As hard as some sessions have been, I haven't injured myself and I've had success in losing weight and getting into better shape.

Johnson's is a smaller Linvilla on the Jersey side of the river. Tucked in Burlington County, the farm's lands are situated across from Lenape High and a short ride from both Routes 70 and 38. It's not a hidden treasure. It's well-known among the locals and acts as much more than just simply a farm.

There's the market with quality goods at high prices; the hayrides -- of which I once rode alongside a pack of tots for an article I was writing; a cutesy farm-inspired play area for the kiddies; happy little farm animals all ready to be fed and pet; special event nights in the summer; holiday-infused events this time of year; an array of fall activities ... you get the idea.

I used to frequent the place when I wrote about Medford happenings at another time in my life, so it turned out to be a nice and nostalgic trip back today for a chicken salad sandwich and blueberry crumb bars.

Certainly the best place to drink a pint in Dunedin, and quite possibly the best place north of Tampa. 

Friendly service, amazing selection of beers (if you don't find what you like in the main room, try the smaller side room that features beers from other breweries).

Good food when you can get it, but oh jeeze, the wait for food can be glacial.  As in, pack your own jerky, because it's gonna take forever on some nights.

U of A was cool when I went to U of A but now...wow!! Between the newly revamped University full of shops like Paradise Bakery, saki bombing, an Irish Pub and shopping to the Union equipped with a movie theater and more restaurants than you can even think to the new dorms...I kind of wish I could do college all over again!

In February, I adopted an Irish Setter puppy and so was in need of a veterinarian and was hoping I could find an office relatively close to my home.

Enter Hendrick's Veterinary Hospital. 

The entire experience from making the appointment to finally wandering in (with one very curious and excited little puppy in tow) was excellent. The lobby area is large and impeccably clean. The size of the lobby is particularly nice when you're bringing in your healthy dog/puppy/pet, you needn't sit too close to potentially ill animals (and obviously, the reverse as well--as I wouldn't want my sick pup exposing healthy doggies).

Dr. Davis was thorough, kind, and patient with my many questions. 

Because, here's the thing--I'm a bit of a researcher. I adopt a puppy and books are borrowed from the library, research is done online, and friends who have dogs are faced with a litany of questions (How long did house training take for your dog? How did you balance the need to socialize your puppy with the need to keep them safe and healthy prior to their full range of immunizations?). And, if you're also a bit of a researcher, you know--you are incessantly faced with conflicting data (never get upset with a puppy when they mess in the house, just patiently bring them outside--or--If you catch them *in* the act, definitely firmly say no--or--??? So much information!).

So, in short? I need a veterinarian who is going to cut straight through my new-puppy-mom-crazy. Dr. Davis absolutely did this, calmly and without judgement, which I very much appreciated.

Since then, I've had occasion to bring her back (she had a UTI). They were able to get us in quickly, diagnose her, and we left with medication in hand (the entire process took less than a half hour--and that's with a urinalysis).

Wonderful!

Get to it!

This place is awesome! Just recently went there for the first time but it has automatically become my Chinese food go to. The inside is very clean and not run down or anything.  The food is tasty. Service is fast and the people are friendly/ efficient. And the food is cheap.  And they have long/ late night business hours! My only complaint is that they don't do delivery but they do have the option to order online for pick up. It's by far the best Chinese food in the franklin/ cool springs area. Also, there's an abundance of parking and seating inside is comfortable.

Took advantage of the free doughnut coupon from Krispy Kreme ...so with all the signage and hype for the pumpkin flavored fall doughnuts.. I chose the Pumpkin Cheesecake... and it was very very good.... especially the FREE part

I had just gotten my haircut and was feeling Reckless so I wanted to try the Philly-rrito burrito at The tattooed pig.  This place is very cool and the Philly-rrito burrito is pretty amazing. Dear hip, amazing and talented people from the tattooed pig, I am just trying to help when I say, 'My Philly-rrito burrito was wonderful but I don't think you need all of the french fries stuffed in there.  At least not well done french fries.  The 1st half of my Philly-rrito burrito was overpowered by the taste and smell of well done fries.  For the 2nd half, I took out the french fries and the meat was amazing and the sauces were stupendous complements.  I do love how you decorated the place.  This was a very good overall experience.

This is a nice hike, I"m not sure exactly where the trail gears off too the only sign of it is at the entrance.  I crossed the tracks and headed to the beach, they have a sign posted it's where the sea lions gather between December and May and they close the beach access off between those months.  You would be able to see the sea lions from the cliff with their pups.  The day I went hiking we just walked along the ocean as the little ones gathered their shells and we walked from one end to the only other way out and hiked back along the bluff from the parking lot (no sign posted)  the trail is surrounded by chrub.  It eventually goes along side a rail road track and we saw the train twice while hiking.  When we came back I saw people walking on the other side of the train track in a field which I thought was private property but I"m guessing where the trail head actually is.  Either way, both sides of the track is a nice hike.  It was empty when we went exploring the area. Saw some people hang gliding above us.   I loved the quietness and I only saw one jogger when I got to the train area.  The beach access itself is empty just a few joggers and at the parking lot entrance at the far end of the beach is where some people gathered but it's a nice quiet beach area over all.  Total distance we did was 6-7 miles.

For as many times as I've been to Moriarty's, I've never had the wings! Inspired by a trip to Wing Bowl, in which I consumed zero wings myself, Moriarty's seemed like the perfect spot to help that craving.

My group was seated at a table upstairs. I had never been upstairs before and thought it was only for private functions. It had the same cute Irish pub vibe as downstairs but much more spacious. To our disappointment, the upstairs bar had a very limited draft and bottle list as compared to the fantastic selection downstairs. We made do with Allagash White drafts and obviously ordered the wings! For good measure we decided to split an order of nachos supreme with chili too.

The wings weren't everything I had imagined but they were pretty darn good. They could have been a little warmer when they came out but they'd probably cool off eventually. The wings were huge. As our waitress described, they had a joint on them. The sauce wasn't super spicy but it a great buffalo flavor. 

The nachos were pretty bland. They almost seemed over cooked. Perhaps too many beans and not enough tomatoes or jalapenos. The cheese was overly melted as well.

Overall, good atmosphere, good wings, good beers, good friends and good times.

Those that know me well are quite aware of my low aptitude for beer. Sure I know my wines, but now, I'm thinking it's time to really understand beer. With the beer boom going on in the old pueblo, I don't tire of seeing more breweries hop on the scene, and Ten Fifty-Five Brewing is doing many things well! This small operation started out in a home kitchen and has wowed locals since it's debut in Tucson. They have four beers in constant rotation and plan to have six by November. And so far, so good! Actually, great! What I find especially great is the variety. They really make beer for many palates to enjoy. I typically steer away from IPAs, so lucky for me, the Lazy Duck (American Wheat) and Leap Pale Ale are light and crisp. The Leap Pale Ale is their flagship brew and in my humble opinion, a perfect beer for those that don't want a super hoppy beer. It's just the right amount! I tasted two other beers in my flight, which are not necessarily going to always be available in their rotation. The XOXO Coffee Stout (made with coffee beans from EXO Roasters) and the Pukka Bitter (British style Ale). I enjoyed both. They also make a double IPA, the Two Sons Citra, which was sold out. As mentioned earlier, this operation is quite small and carefully run by two owners, John Vyborny and Chris Squires. Both are super passionate about their craft and they're pouring some mad love into their nano-brews. Tasting hours are limited, so make sure to visit them Thursday and Friday 4pm-7pm and Saturday 2pm-7pm. They've recently expanded their space and now have more seating, a huge chalkboard menu and a tasting bar. Stop by and have flight! Meet the owners and have a chat. While small, it's cozy and welcoming and all beer drinkers-beginning or expert will be in a hoppy (pun intended) place upon first sip. Prices start at $2 for 6oz pours, growlers are $8. If you can't make it into the brewery for a visit, you can find their beer at several local restaurants including Playground, The Good Oak, La Cocina, Tap & Bottle, Zona 78 Hacienda del Sol, Pasco and Wilko. Cheers!

NOT SURE IF CAFE.......................................

..........................................OR APPLE STORE

When you walk by and look inside, you see a row of people by the window, and almost everyone is using a MacBook.  (Wow, did I really try to pull off a meme in a Yelp review?!)

Consistent with previous reviews that have complained about service, this caf√© is hipster--unfortunately, the snobby and arrogant type of hipster.

Coffee is above average, but why people rave about store-made French press baffles me.  Althogh it does taste better because it is made to order, French press is the frickin easiest way to make your own coffee at home.

Quite good sushi and service here at Sushi Cafe. Quite busy for a weeknight, but busy generally means that it's going to be solid. Rather than wait for a table, I made my way through the crowd and took a spot at the sushi bar. I was the only person who seemed to have this idea.

I had a squid salad to start and it was a solid portion on a base of julienned cucumber. Tasty.

Then I ordered the "Rocky Mountain Roll" (which is a rainbow roll topped with shredded crab) and a Hawaii Roll. Both were very good and more than full size. About half of each of the rolls went into a box and came with me to go.

Great service, reasonable prices. Well done, Sushi Cafe.

It's time for an update.  We went to the new location to check out just how well they did in the move.  We hit them right in the middle of a 12:30 lunch rush.  Michael T. was coming to join us at about 12:45 so we wanted to get there a little early to get our names in for the bar.  It didn't really help much, they only have like 8-10 seats at the bar.  I haven't heard of a restaurant reducing their size on a move to another location.  But these guys did just that.  Probably a reduction of up to 5 seats.  

So we walked in just as a group was being sat.  When we finally were seated...we sat in their seats!  Yep the bar is that small.  But that was ok...we didn't have any push for time.  When we sat, Michael T is well known in these parts and the Chef remembered my name too, we were started on a quick regimen of goodness.  And my goodness it was good.  Usually we focus on the raw because that is just what we like...but the new Menu has so much new baked stuff and cooked stuff we had to try as much as we could.  

The baked section was good, but these rolls might be harder to share for groups that aren't super comfortable.  The rolls are cooked and the stick together and fall apart.  This is NOT a complaint, it's just a warning.  They were all very good.  I especially liked the Pizza roll.  The best thing I had this time was the yooki, yuki, uke, I have no idea how he spelled it.  But it was salmon with some ginger and some sort of sauce on top.  Just wowfreakingawesomeamazing for my mouth.  I could just eat a whole batch of these.

I was able to get a nice bottle of cold unfiltered Sake.  Exactly what I needed and it hit the sport perfectly.

We walked out full and happy. 

So a few notes...
Don't go right at peak time and expect them to set you at the bar.
We didn't sit at a table so we don't know how well the tables are served.
If you can wait til 2ish you can probably get in pretty easily.
When you do go...you will probably see 20 people you know.  We did.
Parking sucks compared to their old place.  This mall probably has the worst parking lot in the city.
Still easily top 3 sushi places.

See you there!  Yes, that's me sitting there waiting for the bar.

The Quick: Go for the view alone. You are right on the water with gorgeous view of Palm trees, blue waves, and even actual pelicans! 

The details: In terms of food, the lobster mango salad was great, I would highly recommend. I also had a side of brussel sprouts which was prepared with a generous amount of bacon and olive oil (just the way I like it). My co-worker ordered the grouper and wasn't overly thrilled by his meal. 

The Rusty Pelican was very good. There are better seafood restaurants in Tampa, however the tropical view and friendly staff are worth many repeat visits.

Oh look it's 5 years later  and it's time for an update. The owner has transitioned from father to son in the last few years, so there have actually been some changes at this venerable restaurant. The dining room looks the same, only spruced up...same for the bar. The menu has some different items on it and some of them are actually healthy. I know it's a shock.

I recently enjoyed a Tales of the Cocktail lunch at Tujague's. It was 3 courses and a Sazerac for around $25. And it was delicious. I had a lovely salad, a beautiful piece of fish and then bread pudding, of course. Oh and I almost ate an entire loaf of french bread by myself because it was warm and tasty.

The staff was great and even let me charge my phone near their station (no plugs in the antique dining room). I'm glad to see them still going strong.

HISTORIC RECIPES, some centuries old; Bor√© would be a regular!
WHITE ALLIGATORS are great gifts; they even box & shrink wrap your selections;
BEST pralines and candies in the region. And free samples!

When I lived in the Pontalba one of my most successful parties was the night of the 2006 "Caroling in Jackson Square".  This tradition was canceled the previous year because of Katrina.  To celebrate their return our own Ellen Degeneris came down to throw the switch and light up the Square.  I decided to have an Open House with champagne and candies all made from traditional New Orleans or Louisiana recipes purchased from Southern Candymakers.  Given that New Orleans' first mayor, √âtienne Bor√©, invented the sugar granulation process in 1795, Southern Candymakers was the only appropriate choice. The ladies at the counter got really excited about the concept too and arranged a huge variety as well as the history of the recipes.   These are the best pralines and candies in the region.
Nice and moist, great flavors!

I don't think there are any outstanding restaurants near Union Station, but this one gets three stars for some fresh veggies and decent dishes.  I had the angel hair pasta with shrimp, scallops and mussels, and I wasn't looking for anything heavy in the hot weather, so it was about what I needed.  Also had a side of asparagus, which they rocked - it was perfect.  The shrimp and scallops were a little too chewy.  I should probably just consider scallops an advanced maneuver food that is only to be had at places that don't serve Beringer White Zinfandel and/or have children's menus.  The mushrooms were huge and slimy - reminded me of Pizza Hut.

The husband's red fish was good.

The server was stretched pretty thin.  I got annoyed when it took 15 minutes to place our order, then, upon a moment's hesitation while reading a line in the menu the server was urging us on ("Ok...whoever's ready...speak up now) as if he was doing us a favor by stopping at our table to take our order.

Overall?  Nah.

No brainer...best dive bar in South Tampa. Kasey, Mike, Dave, and the rest of the staff are always entertaining and the beer is always cold. PBRs are only $2.50! 

Leave the credit cards at home because they only accept cash at this establishment. Also - it is only beer and wine here. 

Usually the perfect bar to end your night, but you will leave smelling like cigarettes so be prepared to take a shower when you get home.

Nope.  Now we go tot he Giant in Aston which is far better - albeit more crowded.

This Giant has out of date dairy products (have seen that twice now - so READ THE DATES!!!) and a picked-over produce department.

Step up your game, Giant in Brookhaven!

After not coming to the Aston diner in years, our party of 6 had a very nice lunch (specials are a good value and come with soup and dessert) for under $70.  Service by "Barb" was great and we enjoyed the food.

Burgers, grilled cheese, Chicken Caesar salad, Cobb Salad with shrimp (instead of chicken) [$14.95] with mammoth portions (took some home).

Glad things have improved.
We'll return,

You are never too old for video games... especially the kind that let's you reminisce your childhood! Plenty of old school games here along with new ones. Pinball machines, joystick and driver games, air hockey, and pool. Plus, as an adult, you might be down to enhance the experience with alcohol! Bar serves some of the basics -- a few beer taps along with a selection of their signature cocktails. Change machines take different paper bills to exchange for quarters. Most games seemed to ask for 2 quarters/ 50 cents. Street Fighter, Pac Man, Ninja Turtles, Power Rangers, Mortal Kombat, Mario Kart... the gaming machine selection was endless. Come with a group of friends or on a date. Some of the pinball machines are free to play and they're always pretty fun, so get your game on without mindlessly slipping in quarters. Jukebox machine is top-notch with all the best hits! Fun environment for the young at heart!

Stopped in after reading the reviews to give it a try. Restaurant had been opened for well over an hour. Heard and smelled someone cooking (Pans shuffling around) in back, said Hello several times but after 5 minutes gave it up. Started to worry after I got home that maybe the person was in trouble and drove back to find customers coming in and out so I relieved. Unfortunately I'd already eaten by that time. I'll try again in the near future.

Saki AYCE sushi and hibachi restaurant really offers you a lot for your money. I highly suggest this restaurant if you're looking for a fresh variety of rolls, sashimi, and hot plates.

I ate here Saturday for dinner, and the restaurant was packed. I'm not sure if they take reservations, so be prepared to wait during peak hours. The way the AYCE works is the server takes your order and brings your food, but you can order anything from the menu, as all foods are included in the price. Saturday dinner was $18, which I felt was more than reasonable, considering that you have appetizers, soups, salads, hibachi, sushi rolls, and sashimi to choose from.

I had the miso soup and hot and sour soup, which are single cup serving sizes. Both were tasty and flavorful.

My table shared appetizers, like saut√©ed string beans, fresh wakame (seaweed) salad, krab Rangoon, fried dumplings... All of which I do recommend. They were freshly prepared and very tasty. We also had the fried scallops, which were just okay. They were very doughy, so I suggest saving your appetite for other menu items.

The sushi rolls were all delicious! They each come with 4-6 pieces. My personal favorite was the Rock N Roll, which had shrimp tempura, cream cheese, and eel. They have like 30 different rolls to choose from, so all palettes will certainly be catered to.

The only downside is that each order takes quite some time to arrive to your table. If you order too much but spaced too far apart, you might find yourself getting full before the rest of your order arrives. This is bad because they will charge you for any piece of sushi left over. I do suggest the table eating family style and sharing, and you'll have a great dining experience!

While looking for a brunch to attend, I came across this one. It is by the same company that owns Island Way in Clearwater, so I didn't think it could be too bad. It runs from 10-2 on Sundays and is $19.90, which is an easy price to swallow.

When we arrived, what used to be a Melting Pot is now a very open seating place, comfortable with plenty of tables. The food was laid out on different tables, and while the selections were decent, they were kind of picked over by the time we got there at 1pm. There were an assortment of breakfast foods: Eggs, bacon, sausage, pancakes, blintzes and even hand made omelettes. There were stir fried items, beef and chicken and there were oysters and shrimp on ice. 

The buffet also includes 2 drinks in the price, either a Mimosa, screwdriver or a do it yourself bloodymary. It's a pretty good deal.

To add to the other review. Also limit on napkins and and likely limited toilet paper.  lol.  Every place like this in high crime areas or low income areas are like this.  Too many people walking home with anything they can carry.  Has to be expected.

Considering the location not too bad.

What a wonderful novel addition to the crowded Philly sandwich scene!  Nick Filet on Lancaster Avenue in Paoli serves up genuine Filet Mignon sandwiches - yeah you read that right - Filet Mignon sandwiches!  These tasty creations can also have many toppings and I chose crumbled bleu cheese, cooked onions mushrooms & peppers, and the Nick Filet Sauce. The Nick Filet Sauce is a flavorful mixture of Worcestershire, mustard, and mayo.  And amazingly all this came in under ten dollars!  

Now for a side note - Everyone knows Philly's beloved Super Bowl winning quarterback Nick Foles so I had to go here before the big Eagles playoff game this Sunday versus the Saints. Well of course there's the Nick sandwich, then there's the Big Nick sandwich, and finally there is the gigantic Mount Saint Nick.  (If you eat the latter, you'll be on their Wall of Fame!)  Well all these names were devised without thinking of Nick Foles but it's an amazing coincidence - no? 

Anyway, Nick Filet is worthy of a destination to Paoli ... and maybe even St. Nick Foles will eat here sometime!

We all really enjoyed Pho Street. We didn't plan our visit, but were happy to have happened about this place. It's casual with plenty of seating and you can order at a kiosk, which is much appreciated.

I did a quick scan of the reviews to know not to order the pho. I ordered the grilled pork vermicelli bowl (bun thit nuong with cha gio), my sister had the Vietnamese hoagie (banh mi thit nuong), and my brother-in-law ordered the broken rice (com tam) with a cha gio side. Everything was excellent. The pork was super flavorful and there were tons of fresh vegetables and herbs in my bun. My sister said the bread on her banh mi was great. And my BIL loved his perfectly cooked and delicious com tam. We all appreciated the crispness of the cha gio. Even my baby niece enjoyed the vegetables we gave her. I love that they have a house-made fish sauce, which add depth to everything.

I'd stop here again if craving Vietnamese in Center City.

If you like beautiful things, you'll like the IRT. The interior is gorgeously elaborate and is packed full of history. You could stare at the decor for hours. It's a grand place and therefore makes for a fun and regal evening. 

There's a full bar and they sell The Best Chocolate in Town truffles as well (holy yum). The staff is very kind and accommodating. I had a bad cough and several staff members gave me cough drops when I asked around. Very sweet! 

I saw the Great Gatsby and it was an incredible show. The IRT makes their own costumes and props in house. I got the pleasure to go on a tour and saw where they create everything. Very cool that they truly create the entire production. Great experience.

ok, i gave it an extra star just for asking for my id!  

this deelio gets jammed up the wahzoo with college kids.  loved reading about all the ghosts that haunt this joint but i didn't see any activity.  one likes to play with the bar's music if he doesn't like the tunes.  most roam along the 2nd floor.

the cafe is a chill spot to grab some late night grub.  part of history. part of the night action.  no frills. just good ol fun people watching.

When in a pinch and not in the mood or don't have the time to run to ShopRite, Murphy's Fresh Markets in Medford delivers. Although at times their prices are higher, there are products that Murphy's carries that I cannot find at the local Medford ShopRite. I always like to support local stores or smaller local chains and find I am there more often than not.

The only negative is I wish they would keep their herbs stocked more. I cannot rely on Murphys for herbs and fresh herbs to purchase and am stuck with going to ShopRite for my fresh herbs. 

Otherwise, I am happy that Murphys is located between Medford Lakes and Medford as I am always stopping there 2-3 times per week.

I go here so often and after work this week was just another trip. But THIS week, Dierberg's has specific meats on special for $5 a package (you have to buy at least 3), no matter what the label says.

So, I set about finding the heaviest packages of ground round, chicken thighs, beef stew meat and boneless pork chops. I saved $31.

The bagging gentleman mentioned that a previous shopper that day got a pork roast for $5 that was labeled $18. Bargains galore!

I must return before this sale is over!

A stones throw off the Monon Trail within the proximity of Main St., Bub's Cafe is the perfect spot to tie up the bikes and pull up to a table of homemade goodness. 

Breakfast stems from eggs Benedict, quiche, giant pancakes with churned butter, smoky thick bacon, and unbelievable biscuits and gravy (both sausage or elk). And their famous donuts in three ooey gooey flavors. Or choose from their lunch menu including special soups and sandwiches made from freshly baked bread from the local bakery. Thirsty after the long bike ride? Sit back on their patio sipping on a mimosa or cold ale. And, don't forget to join their loyalty program.

My one beef is the price of one pancake: $6.50. Seriously? I didn't see a kids size pancake on the menu to suit the little guys appetite. Consider splitting an order if you're feeding young ones. The hot cake is huge. 

Looking forward to stopping in again for a coffee to catch the sunrise. One of my favorites.

This RaceTrac has great prices that rival some of the cheapest prices I see in Tampa - often much cheaper than competitors and the gas station itself is very clean and modern. I refuse to shop at the BP across the street after the oil spill - and I will not be surprised if RaceTrac drives them out of business again. Employees are always friendly inside and there is plenty of options. Agree with Camaron A. as well with the no charge for credit, I hate gas stations the lure you into their stations with prices and then raise them unless you have cash.

New Day has been serving meads and ciders in Fountain Square for about seven years.  So, I thought it about time to stop in and see what I was missing.

The shotgun style shoppe has a serving room in the front and a gathering place/gallery in the back half.  The serving room is lined with tables on the left.  The right side is made up of a display area for merchandise and a long bar area that has blackboards for upcoming events, beverages, and menu items to enjoy while sipping your drinks.

Since it was my first time here, I went with a flight (6 selections for $8).  They hand you a flyer that you can fill out and indicate your selections.  On the back is a listing of custom cocktails that are available made from the house beverages.

Okay, I will admit that I had no idea what mead was other than something knights and commoners drank while roaring about their conquests.  So I asked.  Basically, it is similar to wine, but made with other fruits instead of grapes.  They can also use honey instead of sugars.  However, like craft beers, the drinks can have a variety of ingredients that can take them into a wide range of flavors.

My flight had three hard ciders and three meads.  The Gold Rush (6% ABV) is a dry, champagne like drink.  The South Cider (6%) is more of a gateway beverage for someone who is used to commercial apple ciders sans alcohol.  It is sweet with the taste of apples and honey.  I also tried the seasonal Barrel Aged JC (Johnny Chapman) that is deep in flavor due to the black strap molasses (12%).  This is a drink for those who like their drinks to kind of slap them in the face with flavor!  Surprisingly smooth, it is very complex and somewhat herbal in aftertaste.

The meads I tried had a variety of flavors.  The Washington's Folly (6%) is a cherry mead with fresh tart cherry notes.  The Shelby Blue Ribbon (6%) is made with Strawberry and Rhubarb.  The aroma of rhubarb adds to the enjoyment of this one.  My final selection is another seasonal selection called Breakfast Magpie (8%).  This is a black raspberry mead with a strong coffee (espresso) infusion.  The coffee taste is strong and dominates the raspberry flavors.

As for the rest of the business, the staff seems friendly and well informed.  The merchandise ranges from t-shirts to glasses and growlers.  There are several selections available year round, but the seasonals come in roughly each quarter, but last only as long as the supply lasts.  

Overall, I really enjoyed my beverages and the experience here.

Review #251

While Sobeys isn't my go to for the majority of my grocery shopping, I most definitely appreciate their meat and cheese deli areas and the customer service I receive when asking for suggestions or help in selecting items.  There are usually samples available or if requested.

The store is always clean and I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes to check out.

They don't charge for bags - Yay and they don't make you use a stupid discount card to get a "club" price which makes me BONKERS!  They have recently started awarding airmiles here; if you collect them, it's worth grabing your flyer for the week to get the coupon for bonus airmiles.

Oh and you don't need a LOONIE for a cart - Double YAY!

Not my usual Dierbergs Market, but I wish it were. I stopped in with a friend who was doing some serious grocery shopping. I was amazed at how much nicer this location is compared to the one closer to my house. It's true when they say in retail, "Location, Location, Location." It does make a difference. 

What impressed me, was the produce and meat departments. WOW! very impressive. I'm not even Jewish and I was also impressed with the Kosher section. So impressed, that I grabbed a few items that were on sale.

One section that was sort of a disappointment was their discount section. I guess everything really gets bought up here, because the variety of items was not as impressive as at my regular market and I do love a bargain. 

When checking out, I had to change lanes. The cashier was so rude and mean to the two people ahead of me, I was afraid of what I would say, if he crossed me. So I politely went to the next lane and waited my turn there. Some folks are not made for customer service, especially old curmudgeons. 

Will I return? - I would if I still lived in STL, but I've moved. 

When: September 17, 2020
Why: Power Grocery Shopping with a friend.

Once again, Eyesite and Gene have gotten me a WINNER!!!

I am in love, love, LOVE with my new glasses.
They are from Belgium and very unique looking.
They make me feel like a butterfly when I wear them.
They are so light and comfortable - and GORGEOUS.

I absolutely love to shop for eyewear - and I go to lots of higher-end shops, but EYESITE is where I purchase my frames and lenses.

Simply the best.

Oh DSW, you kill me with your rewards certificates and affordable prices.

I have to watch how often I actually step foot (pun) in the store, lest I use up my monthly budget in shoes! Often times, I'll stop into this DSW to find shoes for special occasions. Most recently, that was a job interview a couple weeks back. After perusing the shelves for a few minutes, I found the most perfect shoes -- and landed the job, though I can't say for sure if there was any correlation!

My only very minor complaint is how quickly the freebies go. A clerk said that after the mailers for free items (with a purchase) are delivered, usually the stock is emptied within a few days. Granted, I really didn't need a free tote, but still.

Can't say enough great things about Maki Motors.  Maki did a complete interior detail on my old vehicle and made it look like a new car inside.  Amazing.

Not cheap but to me, well worth it.

He was prompt, polite and thorough.
I will call him again when it's time for an exterior detail.

Great work!

Okay, this is an edit after just dining there tonight:

They have snow crab legs now, along with sauteed dungeness crab and mussels, which is a major plus in my book.  The sauteed crab was pretty good imitation of the ginger and scallion style crab you would get in Chinatown, except with less starch, which is a good thing.  Still missing the crayfish, though.  The sushi is still pretty much the same as before, but the seafood is definitely better.  Thus, I'm upgrading to 3.5 stars.  If you're in the area, it's worth it to stop by, especially since they still have the 20% discount.  I would do so on a weekend night, because that seems to be when they bring out the best dishes. 

Original:
 
This used to be Star East Buffet, but reopened about 2 weeks ago.  What can I say?  It's your typical Chinese buffet, but without snow crab legs, at least on the night that I went.  They do offer steamed sea bass, which was quite deliciously flavored with ginger, scallion, soy, and sesame oil.   The sushi wasn't too good, and they had a very limited offering of nigiri, sadly.  I was able to request a spicy tuna roll, though.  The salmon wasn't the freshest, either.  There is a small hibachi station next to the sushi arena, and you can get a custom-made stir fry, but honestly, if you want a REAL stir-fry go to International Buffet in Bustleton, not here.  The salad buffet was very clean, and they do offer a generous variety of cold salads, including pasta and chicken based ones.  Probably my favorite item was shrimp dumplings, although only a few are brought out every 15-20 min.  In terms of the hot entrees, they are your typical take-out dishes, and none truly stood out in either direction.  The crystal dumplings filled with mung bean custard were amazing - you have to try them!  I'll probably head back and get a box of those to go.  

Overall, not somewhere I would go to, save in forced situations.   The prices are a bit cheaper than King Buffet, but it is not its competition, by any stretch.  They were offering a 20% discount, and have ads in Clipper.  The owners have another buffet (Jim's in North Wales), which does offer snow crab legs at the same price.  If you're in the area, head to King's, where you can happily eat your weight (or double) in crab legs, nigiri, and oysters.

Lunch: 6.99
             3.99/lb
Dinner: 10.99 M-Th
              11.99 F-Sun
               4.99/lb
               7.99/lb sushi and seafood

This place looks like a real bagel place, but those hard round things were not real bagels.

No complaints about the service or the prices.

This restaurant is experiencing the same problems as the 3-4 previous Chinese restaurants at this location.  They can't maintain a consistent quality.  The lamb burger was so spicy that you can't taste other flavors.  The pork burger was still pretty good, but there were no cilantro and scallions like last time.  The beef burger was flavored with cumin, but had a too mushy texture.  The steamed noodle wasn't as fresh this time as some of the noodles were hard and dry.  Lastly, the chili oil noodle consisted of 2 very long strands of noodle served with chili oil.  Whatever happened to vegetables, scallions, and cilantro?

I've been here before... not sure which trip. (I remember the loo being in a courtyard out back.) 
I'm being quite generous with 4 stars. We sat upstairs on the balcony over looking the street. The wait staff all seemed to have to run up and down rickety stairs to deliver food and drinks which may have contributed to the lackluster service. 
We only saw our actual waiter initially taking our order then when the bill came. A couple of other folks were also taking orders and delivering food and drinks around us. 
We ordered a Yuengling and appetizer of fried gator along with ice tea. The gator was as tough as a marine drill Sargent with hemorrhoids.
But because it came decades after we ordered it, one of the waitresses (maybe manager?) comped the gator. So we never bothered to tell her it was like eating fried dinosaur ass. 

So why 4 stars? Because this place is set up to be one hella great venue for Mardi Gras. And you can tell by the set up that theirs bars and service facilities to take care of upstairs patrons. 

Bring plenty of beads or a easy access shirt or blouse to flash your junk to collect some. Because from the upstairs vantage point you will have a solid perch to let it all hang out!

The Tampa Theater is on the National Register of Historic Places, and is a must-see.  The inside of theater is stunning.  It was built in 1926, saved from demolition in 1977, and has gone on to be one of the most successful theaters of this type in the country (according to their webpage). Before every show, an organist plays tunes on a Mighty Wurlitzer Theatre Organ to entertain the audience, and then it is lowered below the stage.  The organ is a remnant from the days of silent movies when it provided the musical accompaniment.

The theater shows mostly Independent Films, but in the summer they have a Summer Classic Movie Series - this year some of the movies offered were All The President's Men, Casablanca, A Raisin In the Sun, and The Wizard of Oz.  They also hold some concerts here, as well as lecturers.  One of their big selling points is to have someone speak after a movie that was either involved with the movie, or an expert on the movie, who provides extra insight into the movie, which is always fun to hear.

There is a small concession stand at the front which serves standard movie fare - but also wine and cocktails. The main bathroom is also pretty cool, so make sure you visit.  The theater's seats are small and squeaky, and for whatever reason, every movie I see here has people chatting during the movie, but except for those two negatives, this theater is a great spot to have a memorable night.

Oh brother...

So I grew up in the South and it was ritual to have Sunday dinner with family and church folk after church every single Sunday.  That, my friends, included dessert:  Pecan Pies, Sweet Potato Pies, Chess Pies and Bundt cakes... almost every Sunday.  EVERY.  SUNDAY.  Do you hear what I'm saying?  I was tired.  

I told myself growing up that when I got big, no more of this.  Absolutely not.  I didn't WANT no more Pecan Pies.  I didn't WANT no more Sweet Potato Pies.  I didn't WANT no more Bundt cakes!!!  So I passionately ignored this place.  I was allergic to the word Bundt.

Until one day, I had a sweet tooth.  I was running an errand in the area and decided awwww fuck it, let's just see what it's about since it's everywhere.  I walked in, thought maybe the strawberry one, but decided on white chocolate raspberry.  Opened it up in the car...ate it...and almost started crying.  Lol

So so sooooooo soo soo damn good.  SO GOOD.  Oh my god, you guys!  Cupcakes be so dry.  We all are over here on Yelp (all of us) searching for places with the most perfect, moist and flavorful cupcakes, while we SHOULD BE at Nothing Bundt Cakes.  

Lost souls, all of us.  
Searching for what's right in front of our faces.

Well, let me guide you.  Everything you are searching for in a cupcake is found HERE with these Bundt cakes.  No more searching.  Stop the searches.  Come here.  Thank you to this place for making me Woke.

MMMMM... they have dark chocolate covered candied orange peel by the pound.  Really I could just stop there and be done.  But they also have fun gift items, a variety of jelly bellys, sugar free items and are super nice.

They do wonderful gift baskets for showers or corporate events.

Fantastic Bloody Mary.

I had to update my review to give them props on their Bloody Marys. I made my own at Gaspar's Grotto's Booze Cruise Brunch earlier that day, so maybe that's what made the difference so jarring. I have to admit, I enjoy drinking Bloody Marys, but I wouldn't say I'm adept at making them. When I found out they had a $5 special on Bloody Marys, I was sold. Boy, am I glad I tried it. It had the perfect amount of spice and they even had Bloody Mary spiced salt around the rim! That kicked it up a notch for me.   

I had a chance to appreciate the d√©cor since it was the middle of the day. I really enjoy the bright colors of the tables. It reminds me of Key West. They also had live music playing on a Sunday. You can tip the guy and request a song. It's a very low key hang out spot that just screams Florida. This is one of those places you bring an out of state friend to on a boozy Sunday.
