This elegant yet plain bakery boasts some of the best baked goods I have EVER had bar none! 

You are greeted by a very clean store & friendly staff with minimal decor - none is needed - the beautiful baked choices are art in themselves! 

After oooh'ing and aah'ing, we decided on a Butterfingers brownie bar that was so decadent, a perfect giant slightly sugared peanut butter cookie and a mini densely delish cheese cake. 


Although I cannot frequent this gem too often as I 
Value fitting in my clothes, I will periodically treat myself here, spread the Devine word and surprise family at Thanksgiving with yumminess!!!!

    YOU HAVE TO TRY THIS BAKERY!!!

Drive through today, specifically because of contributing to Carson Wentz's terrific charity - the AO1 Foundation.

My co-worker and I went - I got my usual "Chick-Fil-A Deluxe" but made it a meal (#1 specifically) so I can donate the $1.  My other co-worker benefitted from the waffle fries and Lemonade that it came with.  

Our drive thru server was very nice and chipper.  We complimented her on her special Eagles-themed tee (it really was super cute - too bad that I didn't get a pix of the back of it).

Heaven, I'm in heeeaaavvven
And my mouth gasps so that I can hardly speak
And I seem to find the sugar cream I seek
When I'm eatin' pies from My Sugar Pie

Yes heaven, I'm in heaven
And the slice that was handed to me one eve'ning
Seemed to vanish into this Yelper's mouth real quick
When I'm eatin' pies from My Sugar Pie

Oh I love to nosh on cupcakes
And order fudgy brownies
But it doesn't thrill me half as much
As eatin' My Sugar Pie

Oh I love to go to bak'ries
Samplin' bread or a cookie
But I don't enjoy it half as much
As eatin' My Sugar Pie

Now pie slice come to me
I want my fork dug in you
That filling inside you
Will carry me through

To Heaven, I'm in heeeaaavvven
And my mouth drools so that I can hardly speak
And I seem to find the sugar cream I seek
When I'm eatin' pies from My Sugar Pie

My cousin was in town this week and she was dying for a pedicure while she was visiting. We had a hair appointment booked at a salon on Whyte for later in the afternoon, so we went to the nearby Kool Nails. What a terrible name for a nail salon, I thought. But we tried it anyway.

The booked us in for about an hour later, so we grabbed some lunch and went back for 1:45 PM. They were just finishing up with another client and there were only two staff members, so Emily began her pedicure first and they started on mine about 5 or 10 minutes later.

It was nice to see them clean the foot soaker thing (I have no pedicure terminology knowledge) before I got in, and they polish was neatly applied. They didn't have an amazing selection of colours, but I did find a purple one I liked. For $30, it was just alright.

But I leave you with one question, yelpers: why did they have to pumice the entire bottom of my feet? I don't have dry skin on the middle of my foot - just ticklish nerves. Yikes!

What's my favorite food?  BARBECUE!  What's my favorite sound to listen to while eating my favorite food?  VROOM VROOOOOOM!

That's right, ladies and gents, this backwoods gem is straight out of Easy Rider... you half expect to turn and see Dennis Hopper and Peter Fonda eating at the table next to you.  Not Jack Nicholson, unfortunately... although he's all of our favorite character, George Hanson was beaten to death in his sleeping bag.  Ah, and so went the leftist movement.

Anyways, back to the review.  You drive up the highway past Santa Barbara, and wind up a beautiful hill and into the wine country.  Turn off on an easy to miss left turn, and then go right down into a heavily-wooded canyon.  

Cold Spring Tavern originated as a coach stop in the mid-1800s, and the buildings all (at least) appear to be original.  Water damaged wood structures with the clear evidence of termite infestation.  Now it's a hot spot for motorcycle riders (both the original gangsta freebird riders and also the rich dudes with a bike or the crotch rockets), old guys with really sweet cars, and also the everyday Joe who just wants some damn good barbecue.

If you go on a day that isn't Sunday, you will have the option of a variety of reasonably-priced sandwiches, ribs, chicken, and pork.  Sunday afternoon is really the time to go, however.  A MASSIVE Samoan guy manning a barbecue, and piling huge sandwiches full of beautifully cooked tri-tip.  The barbecue sauce has a little kick and is delicious.  Even the horseradish (of which I am not usually a fan) is a perfect compliment to this sandwich.  Get two of them, trust me, and for $6 or so a pop this is a deal that can't be beat.  Sloppy, tender meat, perfectly complimentary sauces, and fresh rolls that are other-worldly.

And then sit around, gorge yourself, have a few drinks and enjoy the live music.

This is a place where you go to be yourself... no one is judging you, because everyone is there for one reason and one reason only... great food and a unique atmosphere.

If you're going for dinner, make sure to bring a full wallet, because the prices escalate quickly.  Gone are the rib and tri-tip deals.  Arriving are the interesting dishes (rabbit, duck, venison, etc.) with prices to match.  I haven't eaten dinner, but I have looked at the menu, and it looks like a very special spot... I will be going, and I will add to this review when I do.

I can't say enough good things about this place.  It is one of my favorite restaurants anywhere.  I have driven up the coast from LA (about a 1 1/2 hour trip) just for lunch.  5 stars without any hesitation.

I had the pleasure of spending many, many nights at the Roosevelt during my year-long commute to NOLA prior to moving to the city.  This is truly one of the finest hotels anywhere in the country.  The guest rooms are all unique, luxuriously appointed, and amazing.  The Sazarac bar is my favorite in the city.  Dominica is fantastic.  The pool area is best in class.  The gift shop is top-notch.  Even the on-site business center is extremely well run and super friendly.  

Absolutely everything about this hotel will leave you wishing you could live here, but where the Roosevelt really shines is in their world class service!  Everyone you encounter, from the bellmen, to house-keeping, to front desk to concierge, will make you feel like family.  

The Roosevelt is my top recommendation for friends or business associates visiting New Orleans, and I've never heard anything but rave reviews from everyone I've sent there, without exception.

Getting tired of all of that craft beer or looking for something new to add to your drinking menu? Look no farther than New Day! Some of the best mead I've ever had is here. What is mead? It's made from fermented honey! 

New Day does an excellent job at it too! The owners (a married couple) are so passionate about their works and it's great to see them out and about at local events throughout the city! 

Not sure what to try? Order the flight. It's moderately priced and you get quite a bit for the samples! Always ask the bartenders/staff for suggestions as they know best! 

Not only is their product great, the branding is also amazing. Keep up the good work New Day!

So excited that Uncle Maddio's is in the area. There are options for the whole family including traditional, whole wheat, and gluten free crusts for small, medium, and large custom made pizzas and foldwiches, as well as salads.

Toppings are fresh and there are an abundance of toppings. They also have a chart of what is gluten free as well as vegan which is good for those that do not eaten some things.

The service is great, friendly, and helpful, as well as the owners.

Grand opening weekend is now and there is still time to try their pizza for free or $1. It's a great and I'm excited to come back!

P.s. Sign up for their emails for deals and a free birthday pizza!

Cute atmosphere.  Yummy drinks. (Order an Amaretto Sour to finish, trust me.) Friendly service.

The mystery of the "how" of the place is part of the charm - so I won't reveal too much.  Text for your reservation. If you don't get directions, text and ask.  They are very responsive.

I'll be back the next time I'm in town.

I am giving this buffet a RAVING review because relative to all the other buffets and types of food in this city, Toucan Charlie's buffet is fantastic. They are typically known for having a great selection of seafood and their shrimp and crab are delicious. They were a little skimp on the prime rib offering for NYE but regardless it was tasty.

They had champagne for NYE dinner and I've honestly never, even in Vegas, tasted such delicious champagne! For $24.99 this place kicks ass for me even though I have been to many of the Las Vegas buffets which cost more.

The staff is very helpful and seating is quick, they are friendly and my drink was always refilled. A+ indeed!

Seafood does not get more fresh and tasty than the food at Drago's!

Oysters, oysters, oysters. People from all around come here just for their oysters and now I truly understand. Their oysters are so fresh and they have the best texture. If someone has never eaten oysters before, I recommend trying them here so you'll be sure to have a good experience. Their raw oysters are amazing and their charbroiled oyster are even better! TRY THEIR OYSTERS!!!

Some of their other dishes are just as amazing. They Lobster Marco is to die for! It's a whole lobster stuffed with angel hair pasta with shrimp for only $27. The gumbo is really good with lots of flavor. The spinach salad is good but doesn't really stand out to all their other amazing dishes. Their Spicy Andouille Ravioli was beyond good, I highly recommend this as an entree.

Aside from the food, the parking lot sucks when this place is crowded. The restaurant can smell really fishy sometimes, but that just proves how fresh their seafood is. The service here is absolutely exceptional. I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone who loves seafood!

This place is two for two with me!

I went once for lunch and had their specialty Farmhouse Burger - a burger with an egg on top, and their specialty mustard on the side. It was a surprisingly excellent burger. Very juicy and full of flavor. Service on this particular visit was extremely slow, and with all the televisions showing college football plus the music blaring, the place was pretty loud.

My second visit I met a friend for happy hour.  Much lower volume level this visit, and the server was much more efficient.  Great deals for happy hour - I went with the lemon drop martini, on special for $6.  All the appetizers are discounted for happy hour also, so my friend and I ordered a smorgasbord of items.  

Duck wings are mentioned in every review, and they were great - nice and crispy, with a bit of a bite from the sauce. I also loved the drunken meatballs - they too were in a spicy sauce, and cooked perfectly. The big surprise of the night was the Kobe Brick Pizza - thin crust, loaded with wagyu beef, cheese, caramelized onions, roasted tomatoes, bacon and arugula, it had a fabulous flavor - I would definitely order this again. 

The only appetizer I didn't love was their version of the Seven Layer Dip: white bean pur√©e, harissa, yogurt, oven roasted tomatoes, smashed avocados, smoked cheddar & chopped olives served with grilled naan.  Even with all those ingredients, it just did not have much flavor.  It was still good, but not great.

I will definitely be back to explore their drink and food menus further, and to take advantage of their excellent happy hour.

Stayed here during my stop in Boise during my Kanan Across America (http://KananAcrossAmerica.blogspot.com) and was satisfied with my stay.  As I've stated before, most Motel chains have decided to do away with shampoo, and the fact that nobody has complained says more about its clientele.

What makes this Motel 6 so special is the fact that when I went to the front desk to ask for shampoo, the clerk apologized and gave me a brand new, full size bottle of Suave shampoo!  This was the shampoo I used during the rest of my trip, righ on Boise!

Unanimously, a drop dead gorgeous park.

Located in what seems to be the heart of in Downtown Tampa (I'm not too familiar with the area) you'll find a park for all seasons here. By the looks of other reviews, everything from festivals and concerts take place at Curtis Hixon throughout the year. 

There are vast patches of fresh-cut green grass, playgrounds for the young ones, and a brick-lined waterfront walkway by the river. The views are remarkable. You can tell a lot of time and effort went into the construction (and a hefty chunk of change). 

Without a doubt, as good as it gets!

This is my go to place for take out because they honestly have anything you are looking for. One night I was like I really want chocolate cake, and surprisingly they had it! It's now an ongoing joke. 

The food is almost always warm & cooked to our wants. There has been a few times, I ordered cheese whiz, I never got it with the order & they had charged me for it. I wasn't going to call and complain over a dollar but it's still frustrating but like I said it's only been a few times & there are times we order from them multiple times a week.

I would recommend getting sauces on the side of your sandwiches or wraps, because sometimes it's a mess or way too much on it. 

I love that the drivers use square reader & you can just pay for it at your door when it gets delivered. 
They do charge $1.50 for delivery. 

They always have weekday specials, everyday specials & amazing lunch deals. And depending on how much you spend they will give you a free 2 litter of soda. 

If you are looking for a new place to try this is it :)

Well, usually I just drive through here for a dollar soda but last Saturday I actually went in to buy some oatmeal too.  I ordered and the guy at the register asked me if I wanted brown sugar with that.  I've ordered oatmeal dozens of times at different McDonald's and never been asked that so I thought maybe he meant... if I wanted something different than the usual oatmeal.  I politely declined.  

Well, brown sugar is definitely something that's normally in the oatmeal.  I found that out when I tried mine and it was plainer than plain.  Okay, so he asked and I declined. I'll take the blame for that, but the oatmeal also wasn't mixed properly and had several pockets of uncooked dry oatmeal.  Bad.  

I had purchased 2 soft drinks and filled them myself at the soda machine.  I got a Diet Coke for me, and a Coke for my friend.  She took one sip and said, "This is Dr. Pepper."  I know I filled it correctly... she mentioned that this is not the first time she has had this happen at this location.  Thankfully Dr. Pepper is among her favorite sodas so she was fine with it.  My Diet Coke tasted a bit watery/thin.

But seriously... 

The women's restroom was fine.  The food was not very good and the soda was the wrong kind.  Overall not a great visit.

Pros: Bathroom was clean and usable.  Staff was polite.  Restaurant was clean.

Target is one of my favourites and this one was good.

I needed to print some photos not long after they opened.  I managed to figure out things, not realising that their photo person wouldn't arrive until 11 a.m.  However, I had them printing directly, so it wasn't much of a problem.

The shift supervisor went into the photo area, retrieved my photos, and rang them up.  She was quite friendly and we had a conversation about a few things.

After that, I browsed the store but didn't really find anything else, which is unusual.  The store seemed quite neat.

Surf and turf is located in the new beautiful Armature Works building. To my understanding this is a rotating stahl so get by there soon if you want to give it a try. 

The line was decently long but they were taking orders in line and alas my lobster roll and truffle fries were ready when we got to the counter. $23 for lobster roll with fries and additional $1 for truffle fries. 

The roll was piled high with glorious lobster and we had the option for warm or cold. We chose the cold option with mayo. It was delicious. The roll itself was crisp and buttery on the exterior and chewy within. I would skip the truffle fries, nothing special really. But the rolls was yummy. I was very impressed with the amount of lobster. Unfortunately the last bite lent a bit of lobster shell which was unappealing but nonetheless still good.

How many Peco Energy lineman does it take to turn on a lightbulb?.... 

This is the year 2009 and yesterday a huge tree fell across a main, two lane road and knocked down power lines. Eighteen and 1/2 hours later, we finally had our power restored. 

From 4AM to 10:30PM I watched as Peco trucks traveled down the road, along with firetrucks and police cars. The road was totally blocked, for most of the day. 

This is what ultimately irked me... Asplundh arrived shortly after 4AM, with trucks for removing this huge tree and two flatbed trucks with new poles. 

The Channel 6 news crews were there and the police stayed on the scene to direct traffic turn around. Peco workers were spotted having breakfast at the local eateries and or just sitting in their trucks in the nearby shopping centers. 

From what I have witnessed, this is atypical of Peco, Verizon and Comcast, to sit in their trucks and eat hero's and drink coffee. When will you be my hero guys? 

The Channel 6 news trucks came, Peco flew down the road to the scene. Later when the helicopters starting pouring in around 5PM and 6PM, the Peco workers again flew down the road to the power outage site. 

Now, I know I do not have all the reasons as to why they were not at the scene to restore power, but I do know, as sure as I am typing this Asplundh did their job, early on and left and the news was right on top of this story. 

Peco is the major electric and gas power providers in the Philadelphia and surrounding areas. Their generation and transmission charges have gone through the roof. We pay, we can't bitch, because they are the major game in town. 

I was off from work and did paperwork by candle light, okay this is cool and I know how they felt in Colonial times, all I needed was a quill pen and ink. I could not cook, do laundry or vacuum. It was a dismal day with the rain pouring down, my sump pump, dehumidifier and laundry pump not being able to assist me, so my basement flooded. 

I am hoping the food in both of my refrigerators and freezers is good. 

But, eighteen and one half hours, with no power, TV, computer and Yelp in this day and age, because a tree fell, is inexcusable.

If you're reading this update in isolation (not in the sense that you're in solitary confinement, but in the sense that you're not reading it along with my Penang update), I recommend you go to phillymonica.yelp.com.

Now, as part of my morning goals for the day, I promised I wouldn't drink or eat carbs, but would instead opt for a salad and go to the gym.

While I did go to the gym, I failed to "not drink." At lunch, I downed 2 margaritas (one with Canton Ginger Liqueur instead of tequila) and a Canton-bourbon-'arita. They were all so delicious I couldn't help but allow one to follow the other. 

I did order a taco salad though. Great food, but unsuccessful day, folks. Better luck tomorrow.

So excited about this new location. Whenever I'm in Clearwater,  I often go to the location in Clearwater which is a challenge because of where it's located on 19. I've also been to the one in Port Richey, but didn't realize how up there that location was. 

This Oldsmar location is my favorite. It's brand new. The area looks pretty nice. The parking is easy, and the store is clean.  They for the most part have all the usual stuff I am looking for, and the service was friendly and quick.

As always, bring your bags, or look for empty boxes in the store. Bring your quarter for the cart. Bring your cash or debit card. They have upped their advertising, so check out their sale papers, their seasonal sales, and their recipe brochures. They are pretty nice too.

Looking to find a intimate spot for a special dinner, I found Bistro Romano compliments of Open Table.  When we walked in and were quickly seated downstairs, I realized Open Table knew what it was talking about.  The lighting really set the mood, while the seating arrangement ensured privacy.  One minor point is that the lighting is all electric instead of candle lit, however, it didn't take anything away from environment.

We started with a pair of apps: the Suppli al Telefono and Artichoke Hearts Capri.  The Suppli was lightly breaded and cooked to a crispy perfection while the Hearts were covered with a nice creamy cheese.  Portions on the Hearts were good, but the Suppli seemed a bit small.  Regardless, they were both delicious.

Next up, our mains.  The evening special was a perch with grape tomatoes and capers.  I've never had perch so had been a little concerned, but it turned out to be my favorite of the night.  JJ had the lobster ravoli (8 pcs), which was covered in another smooth cream sauce.  The portions on both entrees were more than fair and we ended up boxing up a bit of both for later enjoyment.

Finally, you can't come to an Italian place with trying the tiramisu.  Again, the portion was very fair and the favors top quality.  It tasted extremely light, making it a perfect way to end the evening.

The only other thing worth mentioning is they do some type of parking validation.  Wish I knew ahead of time, as I ended up parking on the street blocks away.  No biggie, now I know for next time, and based on my experience, there will be a next time!

Great dive venue with some interesting characters frequenting it.  They sometimes have some good music and always cheap drinks.  I've rarely been here when it has been crowded but it is ALWAYS smokey (which I'm not a smoker and find smoke disgusting but almost everybody in this joint seems to be a chain smoker).  I can only endure this place in limited visits due to the intense smokiness so it isn't on my regular rotation but I still end up here several times a year.

One of my favorite sushi / Chinese places when I was in college. I would stop by at least once a month. The lunch specials were cheap and delicious. I am honestly happy to see they are still doing well and all these yelpers are fans!

Blue Duck is a surprising find hidden in the vastness of Northeast Philadelphia.  It's def worth seeking out.  First of all the atmosphere is bright and cheerful with varied seating that ranges from a counter by the open kitchen to a large communal table near the entrance.  For my first visit I went with the blue duck sandwich.  (Who makes duck sandwiches besides this restaurant?)  It was great.  The shredded duck provides both a sweet and savory taste sensation. I could have used a bit more Swiss chard and a little extra of the blueberry bbq sauce but it was still totally tasty. The menu has much of interest to try on future visits now that I know how to get there.  Blue Duck is a worthy addition to the Philadelphia culinary scene!

Stake out the door starting around 7pm if you're hoping to see the 8pm show, or just purchase in advance. Excellent performances..and There should be no interior photos posted here, per their request!

Because of its history and its reputation, I really wanted to give it more stars. I wish I could, but then I wouldn't be true to Yelp. The venue is old school and they kept it that way...staying true to its name. Seating is first come, first served, but there's not much seating at all. Being four-feet-eleven-inches, I couldn't see anything from the back. I had to squeeze in and sit at the side door. It turned out to be a pretty awesome seat. That old jazz vibe was the intention and that's what I got out of it. I enjoyed myself, but there were moments that were a bit slow for me. I understand they're hustling on that platform, but the silence when no one jumps up to tip, eh, you've lost me. Since I paid admission, I expect to be entertained the whole time.

I have to agree.  Carrie, our "minder" Jen and the staff of Monster Minders are, indeed, pros.  Sure, they cost more than having your neighbor do it, but they walked our 14 year old pug every morning for about 6 months prior to our move to the burbs.

I am very thankful to Monster Minders for being there when we needed them.

Being able to book online is great, too.
And automated billing to your credit card is super-easy!

Thank you, Monster Minders!  Woof Woof!

Went here for dinner Friday night and was not that impressed. The meal started off with a cup of shrimp and corn bisque which was the highlight of the night. Excellent soup, rich with big shrimp. The entrees were a 1 1/4 pound lobster and grilled black drum with what was supposed to be a crabmeat topping that wasn't anything that I expected. The lobster was extremely small to say it was 1 1/4 pound but very tasty, me meal (black drum) was grilled scales down which is normally excellent but the fish thin that scales were almost as thick as the meat of the fish. The sauce was excellent but strangely enough put on the side and not on top of the fish and the so called crabmeat was a bready crabmeat stuffing that had mostly bread and little crabmeat. Interesting that I didnt see many people order char broiled oysters which is supposed to be their biggest seller.

I am normally not really a fan of Academy. I find A LOT of their pro team related things over priced ($60 for a "licensed" Saints shirt?? No thanks.), but I do realize that the place serves a purpose.

Well, this place saved my life recently when I ended up here on the hunt for a birthday gift for my favorite Saints fan. Do you know how HARD it is to find anything "football team" related during the off season? It's real hard, y'all. It's darn near impossible. I was SAVED when I stopped in and found an awesome gift that is sure to be treasured forever (one can hope!). Needless to say, I was a happy camper.

I looked over some of the team jerseys that they had for women and I was a little less than impressed with the selection. I think once the season gets underway, they will be packing the store with goodies.

Another quality location for this chain in the Tampa Bay Area that I first discovered in San Antonio, Texas almost two decades ago.

The vast selection of items speaks for itself and the spuds put them ahead of most other "sandwich and more" fast casual dining concepts.

Over time, the spuds have become almost a must have on every visit because they are very filling and a great choice on the Choose 2 menu.

Their selection of soups also stands out to me over similar spots and I haven't found one yet that wasn't worth putting next to my spud of choice for that particular day.

I will say that if you're in the mood for a sandwich, order it as a full size and not as a half or part of the Choose 2. Besides, you get a side item with the full size sandwich and the half is just not large enough on its own even with soup or salad in my opinion.

Another reason I like McAlister's is how the employees seem very relaxed and competent when taking orders, while also very open to questions and special requests. I've always liked the overall attitude and they don't sweat small details and seem to want to make people happy with their orders. 

Maybe it's just me, but I seem to rarely get the forced "Suggestive Sales Tactics" from cashiers at McAlister's. And if they do ask if I want a drink, it is like they're just making sure rather than really trying to sell it to run up my bill.

Oh, and about half of you hate pickles, so you can be gone now. For the rest of us, don't you love how McAlister's has a huge bucket of pickles cut into quarters that customers can just take as they wish? I find this at a number of various places in Texas (Such as Twisted Root), which brings me back to where I first went to a McAlister's in 1998. It was really good on that San Antonio trip and still is now as they've expanded into Florida.

I couldn't be happier with recently joining. I'm delighted with a faculty and the staff. They lease there equipment so it's always new and current, three different weight rooms and with just everything you can imagine and more. The classes they offer looking exciting and from what I've observed the instructors are very prospective. Highly recommend this club, money will spent

As a rule, I loathe chain eateries and especially those with order counters.  As exception, I love MOD which is a chain with that ordering set up.  As a rule, I dislike flash fired pizza joints that offer 'all the toppings you want' formats.  (I'm talkin' to you Blaze.)  As exception I love MOD which has this very format.

I'm a MOD fan based on multiple good experiences with MOD outlet in Oregon and my first at this newly opened (roughly mid November) location near Boise Towne Square Mall reinforced why that is so.

That this MOD was "lightly customered" on a weekday at the height of lunch time suggests many mall and Nordstrom Rack shoppers may be unaware this is now open since both are nearby.  But it is.  So here you are.  Now you can go.

THE DRILL:  Menu for pizzas (salads too) is posted on the wall if you want to choose one of their recommended creations.  Or you can choose to create your own with any toppings in any amount as you talk to the nice people behind the service counter and they move you on down the line from crust type to sauce type to cheeses to toppers.  Pay at the end. Stand aside or take a seat.  They'll call your name at the pick up counter when your eats are ready. (You can also order online and pick up at this same counter.) Bus your own. 

EATS & PRICES:  Pizzas in small (feeds 1), MOD (11" and for us easily feeds two) and a larger one.  Crust in standard thin, thick and I think they have a vegan or GF one too.  Price for MOD size with any toppings = only $7.97.  Top that for good deal!  On the topping topic, all of MOD's (unlike some competitors) are top shelf quality.  For what it is - this is a convenience food chain after all and not a hand thrown Neapolitan pizzeria - the crust is pretty darned good too.  

DOES GOOD SERVICE MAKE FOOD TASTE BETTER?:  It seems the people who work at any MOD are friendly and efficient in moving through people in line, even those who are MOD newbies and need a little extra help for the first visit.  True here too. MOD was started by a former Starbuck's Exec and leverages what works well at that chain too for friendly people serving customers.  They're still working out new place wobbles here but headed in the right direction.

LIBATIONS: Help yourself fountain drinks like real lemonade (Marionberry is a fav), iced tea (one with pear too), sodas in bottles, floats, draft beer and new learning for us today - MOD has milkshakes.  Not that I'd choose one with pizza, but maybe one day I'll order a salad with MOD-est calorie content and pair a shake with it.  No coffee service it seems.

OTHER EXTRAS:  Another reason to love MOD is their No Name cakes.  These are, as you might guess for the way they are wrapped in silver foil, MOD's riff on the Hostess Ding Dong.  But in the case of the MOD, No Name it is a tender really good chocolate cake with luscious vanilla kissed cream filling and enrobed in chocolate ganache.  I know...I thought cake as dessert chaser to a pizza was an odd idea too.  But carried out to eat later with a steaming hot cup of coffee it is "splendelicious".  

SPACE WITH LOTS OF SEATING & NOT TOO MUCH NOISE:  As a rule, I'm not such a fan of eating in MOD's spaces just for the noise level created by hard surfaces, high industrial ceilings and really loud, head banging music mixes.  But at this location the music was not turned up too much over the top and I got to listen to the likes of Eric Clapton and CSNY so what's not to love?  Lots of seating in 3 separate indoor areas and looks like outside set up for nice weather.  And a BIG woohoo that among the options of booths for 2 or 4 people, lots of tables with chairs or benches and maybe seating for 80 in total, only 8 of those seats were high chairs at high tables.  Very nice. They get it that standard height seating works for everyone.

PARKING: Private lot but it was packed as there are several convenience food eateries in the complex.  Like a Zupa's next door.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Accessible (aka ADA) spaces in lot, level in the door and throughout the eatery, the cattle chute order line could be difficult for a wheelchair user but payment counter is at standard height, standard height seating tables.  Loos are accessible but the door opening weight far exceeds ADA and Idaho code maximums of 5lbf and so near impossible for mobility disabled person to open. Easy for management to adjust  - it should have been called out as violation by city of Boise building inspectors.

PS:  There is another MOD that opened a month or so ago on Capitol Boulevard near Trader Joes.  I do not know if the two are franchised by the same entity or corporate owned.  MOD allows both as part of their business MOD-el. This small chain launched @ 2008 by a former Starbuck's exec ensures controlled expansion is quality centric by having stores either corporate owned or franchised to a select set of applicants with XX years of documented success in food service enterprises and $XXX,000 in cash on hand.

Love the concept and luckily when we walked into this small, quaint little place on the pier, there was seating available at the bar.
We had great service and our waiter was busser and the bartender. The food was just OK. It meant a lot to me that it was fresh and cooked to order.
The clam chowder did not have a lot of flavor whatsoever. I had to add the crackers,salt, tobasco and luckily I carry my own little stash of cayenne pepper. I have had clam chowder all over the world and sadly, I cannot recommend this once. It needed some creaminess butt hat could be personal opinion. Get a cup if you are unsure like we did, a bowl of it is a big commitment. There were a lot of people working and things came out very quickly. 
Hubby had a local beer which he enjoyed and I had a glass of wine. A glass of wine here means a GLASS, loved it. No frills here, wine right to the top of a glass you would get at your granny's house.
We split the fried platter with calamari, shrimp and scallops for $13. Not a ton of food  (3 pieces of each maybe) but the coleslaw complete with raisins and pineapple was a treat and they also throw on about 3 large onion rings. This was a nice dish to split so we did not ingest TOO much fried food. There is also the option to have fried oysters on it which we skipped. I imagine the more you order on the plate, the less you get of each.
I would for sure come back here. Unpretentious and even a little gritty. Come as you are.
If you want fine dining, there are other options on the pier.
They will validate your parking if you park on the wharf.

This started out GREAT! The place smelled wonderful, and the food, Pretty darn tasty. The price was good, and food was plentiful and hot. 

When we arrived there was one table of a mother and daughter, and our table.  After we arrived another couple arrived. There was 1 waitress.  While I can't say it ever got truly busy, I can say that she never checked back with us after the initial "How's everything?" never asked us if we wanted more water. After we were clearly finished with our food, she never came back to see if we needed boxes. 

At this point 2 more groups came in, one group of 4 and one group of 5 and they sat at the back of the place, those seemed to take up her time. This was about 6:30. My friend and I were done by now, we were looking at our watches, commenting that it was relatively early. By 7pm, though we were still talking, the waitress still hadn't checked on us, when we would try to get her attention, she never did seem to make eye contact with us, she simply ghosted to the back areas of the eatery. 

At 7:15 we had to verbally signal her to get us boxes, and to ask for the check. She then didn't remember them for another spate of time, we finally got out of the establishment at 7:44.  The times are known because I made note.   I would come back for the food, but the service was pitifully slow. Need more help in there.

I can't imagine a better place to find specialty care for my wee li'l munchkins.

Usually I admit that I'm biased due to having worked for a place I review.  But in the case of CHOP, I think it makes me more informed as does having my niece as a regular patient at CHOB and an ocassional patient at CHOP.

Due to the various interactions I've had with CHOP over the years, I've been privileged to see their inner workings.  I've never witnessed an employee who wasn't empathetic if not sympathetic to the needs of every child they treat, both in the exam room and behind the scenes.  This same courtesy is extended within their own ranks.

Their dedication to quality extends down to the cut-throat process for choosing the best interns and med students and are truly dedicated to giving them the best education as possible.  They truly have one of the most competitive programs in the country.  I don't know about you, but that's the kind of program to which I want to entrust my child's health.

And you'd think cleanliness goes without saying in a hospital, but not so.  Fortunately every area of CHOP is kept impeccably clean and as sterile as possible.  

Every staff member on every level works their best to make sure the parents feel understood and confident while the children feel secure.  All of these things make CHOP, hands down, worth whatever length you have to go to in order to travel here.  Your child's well-being and your peace of mind are guaranteed to both be fulfilled...and you can't put a dollar amount on that luxury.

I'm giving them four stars, even though I didn't actually use them.

I needed a pair of shoes stretched just a tiny bit - the right shoe was hitting a part of my heel that made them uncomfortable to wear. I had the brilliant idea of bringing them to a shoe repair shop in to get them stretched out.

The lady at the front was extremely nice and after looking at the shoes, politely advised that the way they stretched shoes would not work well for this particular type of shoe, it worked best for leather shoes. She told me sadly that I would be wasting time and money to even have them attempt it, but perhaps if I had leather shoes with the same problems, I could try them another time.

I much appreciated her honesty and help.

I wish I could give a more thorough review of Kajun's, but I really can't.

I got here expecting to be able to do a little singing and jamming. It wasn't late at all, but I was told that they were done with Karaoke for the night. Bummer. It was a decent crowd, although it was kind of packed. People seemed friendly enough and the bartenders had a nice beer selection and were fast despite the crowd.

I would love to go back and actually sing some karaoke. Hopefully I will find myself in the area again, soon.

Good, greasy, basic pizza - a little expensive for what it is.
Plus they sell gelato, subs & salads. 

I had a single slice with spinach (very good spinach topping by the way) for $3.25 to go.

BIG parking lot and a large bar.

Came to Miller's Ale house to wish a friend off to better pastures. We've been here once and had a good time. So I am glad that we got to go here again.  We hung out in the Bar area, sipping on Martini's and passing stories back and forth. 

The service was good, but for some reason my $2.00 vodka martini was actually $5. *shrug* not that it's terrible, but I didn't quite understand the explanation.

I love coming here.  It's such an adorable, quaint, and friendly cafe that serves great sandwiches and amazing truffle fries (crisped to perfection with a light topping of shredded Parmesan).  I love the Cape May panini (turkey with strawberry mustard, cheddar, and slaw; the mustard gives it a nice twist.  The corned beef reuben is tender and not sinewy or tough, and the blt with turkey is the perfect balance of mayo, crispy bacon, turkey, and lettuce/tomato on lightly toasted, smooth white bread.  Anything on their breakfast menu is good, but I'm a huge fan of the breakfast sandiwch.  One bite of this and you will NEVER be able to go back to McDonald's or Burger King's (or even Wawa's) sad excuses for the most important meal of the day.  I'll be back for more next week.

Named for its owner, this isn't a bad place to eat (decent-to-good food), and is a fun place to drink (full bar, cool bartenders).

I've been here for a few happy hours and in the late evening to grab a bite. During dinner, our party will take advantage of their bar, ordering beers, wine, and of course, shots. Their appetizers are average (though some folks judge a place just by their appetizers, I'll turn a blind eye), and the entrees are good. It's a large space for any kind of gathering and the restaurant is smack-dab in Chinatown, which means street parking, garages, or lots if you have a car. Prices are slightly higher than what I expect to pay for in Chinatown, but I guess I'm paying for the cool decor and service (always fine for me).

For those living in/near the suburbs or who want to venture there, check out Fuzion near Skippack, PA - it's owned by the same guy and the food is outstanding.

I heart hoagies!  I meant to review Cucina Italiana the last time that I passed through 30th Street Station, but it slipped my mind... cuz, well, it's not really -that- memorable.

Regardless, it's as good eats as it gets in 30th Street Station, as far as I'm concerned.  When your other options are Mickey D's and Cosi (which I abhor), having the yummy and filling option of Cucina Italiana is a wonderful thing.

For roughly $7, you can score a "regular" sandwich on fluffy bread with a huge amount of meat.  Y'know how Subway uses one of those paper-wrapped prepackaged cuts of deli meat?  My traditional Italian sandwich at the Cucina came with -two- of those.  And they're not messing around.  Then topped off with fresh, crispy lettuce, tomatoes, and thin translucent rings of onions, sweet peppers, and a generous squirt of oil and vinegar, the resulting monstrosity is easily enough to be filling for two people (or in my case, two meals for one and a half people).

Can you think of any better train food?  I'm gonna go with... no.

Tucked away in an almost forgotten industrial corner of town (until Ikea came to Philly, that is), this little landmark is a city gem, a place that you gotta make the extra effort to find.  Yes, lines are long, tempers are short, and seating is near impossible, but one bite into any of their offerings and you will stop for a second and think, "AAAAAH, this was SO worth it."

Everytime I come here, I waver hungrily between the roast pork sandwich or a cheesesteak.  Sometimes the decision is too hard for my addled brain, so we get both.  Either way, the juicy sandwiches are hearty, filled with flavor, and unforgettable.

Man oh man.  This has to be one of the neatest spots in New Orleans.

I got to check this place out, thanks to a friend who is "in the know".  This is basically an exclusive club type place that is located right above the House of Blues.  It's dimly lit, sofas are everywhere, they are cozy corners with tables that you can sneak off to and it's decorated like only a super secret hideout can be, with cloth on the walls and interesting art everywhere.

I totally "get" why membership to this place is so expensive ($1,000/year for just the "Bronze" package).  This is one of those places where the New Orleans elite come to relax without fear of being bothered or harrassed.  Also, there is naturally no photography allowed inside.

I didn't get to experience any of the food...maybe one day.  It's just neat that I can say that I have actually been inside this "inner sanctum".

I've been to The Bistro twice recently, but this review is centering on my visit from last Monday.

I was fighting a cold and really should not have been out of my house, let alone working, but alas, as an adult, sometimes being in public while sick is unavoidable.

Soup was necessary and The Bistro is right across the street from my job. While my voice was hoarse and my face likely as pale as a sheet of ice, my server was SO sweet. She really SHOULD have treated me like the plague, but didn't, providing amazing chicken soup and prompt service. I'm usually not a big soup person, but The Bistro's is quite good.

I'll be frequenting The Bistro more often. And likely while healthy!

this is some serious southern cajun NOLA style food.

the beignets are little fluffy sugary pillows of heavenly warm dough! come here for these yumms on wednesday and sunday, the only days they serve them.

hidden in the middle of the bustle of reading terminal, this is a great fast, different foodery.

A big ol' Super WaWa in a great (but super busy) location on the Black Horse Pike in Runnemede.  

It's next to El Tequila (very good Mexican - the guac varies and isn't the best at times?) and Cook's Florist, which is a gorgeous floral shop with beautiful selections.  

I parked my car for a fill up then went inside for my favorite (spinach & cheese) panini.  When I went to pay, the cashier noticed that the gas purchase wasn't showing (not "hung up" or something she radio'd out?).

So I got a couple of free items (I didn't complain a lick) to offset the inconvenience for me, so of course I was happy.  

What can I say?  I stinking LOVE WaWa!  With or without the freebies.  The coffee, the hoagies, the paninis, the gas, the free foutain waters, my bank's ATM and a big, clean potty if I need to!

If you're looking for a great wedding venue, this spot is a top pick! I'm not a member, but I attended a wedding here in early September and the space is absolutely gorgeous. There's lots of natural light coming in the big windows that surround the room and overlooks the golf course. The sunset was stellar and the backdrop is ideal for photos. Additionally, the food catered was quite delicious for a buffet setting (the chicken was still tender and juicy!). I really liked the mac and cheese too (smart menu picks!).

One thing that did surprise me was that the seat covers were all wrinkled. I would think a venue like this would take better care to notice those details. (I pay closer attention to those things than most because I plan events, but still). I'd like freshly steamed seat covers if I were paying for a venue as nice as this for my special day. Keep that in mind when planning your event!

It was a long ass line but the food was not bad.  Now compare that to King Taco and well that place would be crap against them. But in a white boy town and everybody white boyish yeah the food aign't that bad. I ordered the maranaded pork taco and it was a little bland. I also ordered a chorizo quessadilla which was not bad and a bacon butter cheese something that was actually pretty darn good.  Though I should have eatten it first because it bacame all gooey buy the time I got to it. 

My companion ordered the pork soup that was filled with greesy stuff was okay except I myst be careful because too much grease can give me the thumbs down for the day if you know what I mean. Also ordered was I think a carne asada and a veg tamale.

Friendly peeps in line. We met a cool Apple blogger/ photographer/ reviewer guy and his son who where on there way to the Apple's developer speech thingy.

A Home Depot review is almost like a McDonalds review no, it's almost like a Starbucks review.   The stores are basically all the same.  The employees are all pretty much the same.  And the value of a review is almost nil.  So why should I take the time to write a review?

Well I have been there dozens of times so why not give them a little Yelp love.  They have been there every time I've needed them.  Not a ton of expert help, like the "good old days" but people have always been friendly and pointed me in the right direction for whatever items I have needed.

For work I've been able to get some last minute stuff that would have taken days to order through the more specialized shops in town.

Parking lot is littered with the WORST speed bumps.  Not really a reviewable item, but a nice heads up for anybody using Yelp to decide where they need to go and get their home supplies and hardware.

No bad experiences here for 8 years.  Yup.  A-OK.

Spiro's is an experience. In a glorious way!

I was so sad to hear from Harry that their business has declined with the move of 141. It's happened before, with the strip mall a bit south that houses Hot Wok and Dave's World Famous Bar and Restaurant, among other businesses.

This highway move thing just works a bugger on the businesses in the area. And especially for Spiro's, because they're now relatively on a dead-end road. It's not really dead-end, but quite local.

But just a tad south of Olive at what is now called Woods Mill Road and used to be 141. By the Dierberg's Four Seasons.

The International Supper Club selected Spiro's for its monthly repast. What a fun group.

The food was terrific. Service was spectacular. The company was tremendous.

And Harry came by numerous times as the host-with-the-most to see how we were faring.

I got the lovely house salad (Athenian Salad - $4.75 -- Lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, Feta cheese) and Veal Piccata - $18.99 -- Veal cutlet sauteed in garlic, white wine and lemon sauce, served with pasta and white cream sauce.

The veal was perfectly cooked, quite tender and very tasty. The pasta was a perfect accompaniment.

Harry came by at the end of our meal to offer ouzo shots and baklava! What great desserts!

Thanks to Sarah S. and Mallory W. for organizing this fabulous dinner.

And thanks to Sarah S. for the artistic chocolates from RJ Chocolatier!

I had a hefty recyclable to-go vessel of more than half of my entr√©e.

Nice little hang out spot in the middle of downtown Tampa. I forget about this perfect little spot surrounded by the water where you can enjoy the fresh air and sunshine when it's not summer time.  It's next to the Tampa Convention Center, and it is connected to the Tampa River walk.  

You can bring your dog here too, and that's always a bonus. Grab a beer, or a mixed drink, or a wine, and just chill out, and be happy. That's all there is to the place, plain and simple good time. There's bar food, and there are food trucks.  Stop by from hanging out downtown, park your boat, stop by from your bike ride, whatever you may choose.

There are also water bikes, and boats you can rent in the back by the water.

We parked under Jackson's and walked across the bridge.

Every bit as good as Sprinkles in NYC (and Beverly Hills but I'm not driving from the Palisades to Beverly Hills for a cupcake unless it removes 10 pounds and 10 years and makes my stomach into a washboard and no cupcake to my knowledge possesses these magical powers) and far lighter than Crushcakes in SB! 

I tried Ali's spectacular St. Patrick's Day cupcakes at Corks and Crowns and they impressed me so much, I brought half a dozen home for my boyfriend. 

My favorite was the Shamrock Shake but the Bailey's frosting on the chocolate cupcake was tremendous too. 

Sugar Cat Studio cupcakes can be found at Corks 'n Crowns many Sundays and I plan to me C and C a regular thing when I'm in town

I came in close to the start of the lunch rush, the only seating available at the time was counter seating. It was my first time sitting at the counter. Someone took my drink order of coffee within a couple of minutes. When they brought my coffee I made my order of the DeLuxe Scramble with sausage, onion and extra cheese as the third ingredient for $8.00 , I also ordered the Black-eyed Peas and Collard Greens for $6.00. It took quite a while to get my food. But I was not surprised because it was very busy! While I was waiting there seemed to be a couple of mix-ups with who was to be seated next, also not too surprising because of how busy they were. I totally enjoyed my scramble and would order it again. I had enough left over for another meal! Well worth the $8.00! I ate the Black-Eyed Peas and Collared Greens for my dinner. They were both perfectly cooked and very tasty. The black-eyes peas were tender and a little bit spicy and the collards were very tender and not at all bitter. I hope that I will be able to have them again sometime this year! For as busy as they were I think that they did a great job! I will be coming back and I would recommend  others to try them! Happy New Year!

We came to Tea Magic and enjoyed a pair of fruit smoothies.  I had a strawberry-coconut smoothie with strawberry bubbles (i think they called it a Summer Love, but I can't quite remember).  JJ ordered a Kiwi smoothie. 

After a bit more than a 5 minute wait, both were neatly presented.  With plenty of seats, including a sweet looking couch, we stayed to relax and enjoy our smoothies.  Both were awesome!  The Kiwi was thick and full of fruit while the Summer special was smooth and exactly what I was expecting.  

Unfortunately, despite the very comfortable seats, it was a bit difficult to relax as it can get very loud in the seating area.  Honestly, it didn't seem that crowded, so I think it is just how the sound carries.  Otherwise, I have no complains.

Tea Magic also happily accepts credit, which is a plus considering the number of businesses in Chinatown that don't.
We love it here. Every time I pass through it makes me want to move here. Love the architecture and the plethora of things to do in this neighborhood.

Take out for lunch - I ordered a (naughty) chicken calzone (no sauce).  I should have read the description better - NO RICOTTA ?!!!   WTH?!!!  

The chicken was good and the dough was thick and good.  Lots of mozzerella but it still didn't offset the fact that there was no ricotta :(  

For $9.95, I expected two day's worth of food, but nope.  Too pricey!!!  

I've had bigger and better for sure.  

My co-worker said he likes their pizza alot; however, the other reviews I just saw are so mixed.  I don't think I'd go to be the tie-breaker. 

There are too many delicious tried and trues to return to.

First time over the new expanded bridge today! Wow! It's so nice. Gone are the memories of the super narrow scary bridge where a breakdown (or even slow truck) could ruin a whole trip. 

I do still need to get accustomed to the on and off ramps since I was so familiar with the old ways but small price to pay to sail across.

I ordered the Hip City Ranch, supposedly their best seller, and it was not good at all. The sauce was off-putting and did not taste like ranch. The fake chicken wasn't flavored well either. I tried this place a few years back and didn't like what I had at the time but thought I'd give the restaurant another shot.  Not worth it.

I've rarely have had a fun time at the bar here but there have been a few moments that were enjoyable.  The food here used to be much better and they once had a great turkey burger BUT the food has gone WAY downhill and now I just refuse to eat here.  The last terrible meal I ate here was around Mardi Gras and two of the cooks got into a huge fight that spilled out into the street and there was all sorts of great blood and gore everywhere (this is probably an extra star for sheer entertainment).  Of course due to the fight it took three hours for us to get our food.

For outdoor, it's $11.95/ day.  But I got a groupon (3 days for $15) + had to pay a 4th day at $11.95 + airport tax + sales tax = $16.88 + groupon was about $30 for 4 days.  It was a better deal than parking lot B, not really that much better.  It averaged almost $8 a day while Lot B is $9/ day.  Both are not covered parking but secure.  The difference though is that Flight Park valet's the car.  You don't have to look around for your car like in Lot B and they carry the bags for you.  Its a little bit less worrisome but you need to be able to take into account extra time for Flight Park whereas Lot B is at the airport. Personally, I prefer Lot B over Flight Park, but I can see why people would use this business.


Outdoor valet is $12.50/ day and indoor climate control valet is $15/ day.  Its secure, well lit and monitored 24/7.  They're 4 minutes from the airport and you're driven by one of their Mercedes fleet vans.

They have a holiday Groupon right now:
$20 for 3 days of outdoor parking
$42 for 7 days of outdoor parking 
$61.99 for 10 days of outdoor parking


Rating (out of 5- 5 is the best)
Competitive price: 4 (Executive Travel and Parking and Longterm lot B are cheaper)
Proximity to airport terminal: 4.5 (google maps- 1.1 miles, 3 minutes)

Offers covered parking: Yes! (indoor and climate controlled)
Free shuttle Service: yes

I love Br√º!!!!  This place is the definition of cool.  Came in for a quick beer around 2 in the afternoon on Saturday and the place was quiet.  I figured it was just a low key place to grab a decent microbrew and lunch.  The beer selection was HUGE.  The place is sleek, modern and just really original.  They have picnic table-esque seating by the window which was different.  Decided to check this place out again later in the night and by midnight it was HOPPIN.  I couldn't believe it was the same bar, place was packed.  They had about four bartenders staffed so although the place was crowded, I didn't find myself waiting to get a drink for more than 30 seconds.  They open up the front windows at night so you can see right across the McGillins.  You feel as though you are outside its an awesome setting.  The music they played was spot on.  Overall, awesome bar, must check it out if in the area.

Ok I went here after hearing from several girls I know about how great, fresh, and wonderful it is.  I'm sure the food is fresh, light, and delicious to some people but I have to totally disagree with anyone that calls it "healthy" as it certainly isn't.  They do offer lots and lots of nice looking desserts but everything on the menu, other than the soups, seems very heavy on the carbs, fats, and sugars here so I think some girls delude themselves that they are eating "healthy" here just to justify being able to order the super desserts as a "reward" for their "healthy" eating (if I ate this kind of food ratio often I would be huge!).  The menu is also a bit on the expensive side for the small portion sizes.  

They really didn't have anything I liked (I love meat but don't eat pig) but the soups were decent but not good enough for the price.  This is definitely a place for a "light" lunch.  Il Posto really just reminds me of a coffee shop that decided to throw in some sandwiches (but use some quality ingredients to make them a bit fancier).  The seating area is TINY and has very little space.  

I just find this is a place for dainty girls to eat and not men so I will never be back as it just isn't my type of food.  If you like this type of food and like light lunches this is certainly a place you might want to check out.  If I'm in this area I will be going to Pascal's Manale or Charlie's Steakhouse instead for my healthy food :)

In a word, disappointed. I attended a Christmas party at the Sutton Place last night; we were in the Vintage Room.

Definite pros: the room was quite nice, the acoustics were good, I liked the lighting, and....y'know, I just can't think of a fourth.

Here's the list of cons: the food wasn't great, the plates were smaller portions than I expected, the bathrooms were down a hallway and you had to use a keycard to get in, the food came out very slowly, I didn't like the wine, and the coat room was very difficult to maneuver into. I hope it doesn't come across as though I'm complaining, but there were quite a few disappointments to the night.

Of course the night was enjoyable (as Christmas parties always are!) but I hope the organization moves to a different venue next year.

So pleased with the service and beverages (hot coffee drinks, iced lattes and smoothies).

They also have free (but very slow internet) computers to use.

The (male) owner is very kind to us and my 9 year old loves the hot cocoa in winter and pina coloda smoothies.

This review comes from someone that despises oysters. First night in NOLA and we are told by a staff member at our hotel that Drago's has some of the best oysters we will ever eat. I'm a bit skeptical but as soon as I hear that they are grilled and are cooked with garlic and parmesan, I am sold. We walk over from our hotel and are seated almost immediately. Our waiter was incredibly friendly and attentive and quickly took our drink order and put in our app request. 

We started off with their crabmeat au gratin, which came served with Zapp's potato chips and then split a dozen of their charbroiled oysters. This meal was a great foreshadowing of the food to come in New Orleans. Not only were these the best oysters I've ever had, but they are the only oysters I've ever liked and one of the best meals I had on my unconventional road trip from New Jersey to Colorado. 

Drago's wasn't incredibly busy on the night we visited, but it seems like the kinda place that can definitely fill up quick on a busy night. As others have mentioned, the only thing you should be getting from here are their oysters. The crab meat was certainly tasty but didn't match the $16 price tag. Also be prepared to spend some dough here as a dozen oysters will run you $20. Still not bad for some of the best you will ever have.

[463]

This new Wawa is a perfect addition to Media.

Tons of gas pumps and plenty of parking.  Inside is roomy and made to orders are prepared quickly.

About 6 picnic tables out back so you can eat outside on a nice day.

I'll definitely be back.

I lost my beignet virginity to Caf√© Beignet. And they set the bar high. 

Before my trip to NOLA, I heard that Caf√© Beignet was better than Caf√© du Monde. Luckily on my first morning in town, I walked past this location and got to discover this myself. Also luckily, there was no line at the time of my visit; we were able to walk right up and order. 

Despite the lack of crowd, it still took a little while to receive our beignets. I'm mentioning this as a positive! Boy did they taste fresh. There was a light crisp to the outside and they were filled with heaven on the inside. I can see why they are referred to as heaven's pillows. 

The small coffee was still a fairly decent size and it was strong. If you like strong coffee, this coffee is good. 

It had been raining a little earlier so my friend and I ate at the bar. The bartender was very friendly and chatted with us most of the time. 

This caf√© was set back in an adorable courtyard. There was even a live musician. 

I did go to Caf√© du Monde later in my trip, however I know that Caf√© Beignet will be my beignet headquarters for all future trips to New Orleans.

If you absolutely need breakfast on the Causeway, this place will do.

Things that bother me:  canned mushrooms and low-grade Swiss cheese, and this place delivers on both.  

Homefries are on point, and the service is stellar.  Outside of that, it's just a-ok.  There is a 100% chance that I will not return though.  3 stars for cost effectiveness. My meal was only 8 bucks and change.

Everything is indescribably delicious! But I'll try! The vast space is decorated Japanese-style with dim lighting and friendly, prompt service. Pretty little Japanese dolls are perched beautifully at the foyer entrance, along with the Lucky Cat, who is waving "hi" to you ;). Seating inside is a large sushi bar, pub tables, hibachi and regular tables, as well as a few booths running along the outskirts of the restaurant. Cozy.

I'm in this restaurant a lot! You could say I can't live without this one, and this sushi is always in my regular rotation. The rolls here are always made with very fresh fish/seafood and all the accompanying ingredients of fruits and vegetables are super-fresh as well. 

I've tried quite a few rolls, and so far, my favorite on the menu under 'Chef's Special Roll', is a fancy roll at $15, called "The Lobster Dynamite Roll" - with each piece having a nice big chunk of lobster, it is wrapped in seaweed with a piece of mango, avocado, sushi rice, then covered with spicy tuna, and drizzled with sweet chili sauce to top it all off. Delicious! Akira's rolls are comprised of 8 pieces, and range in price from $4.95 to $18.00 for special rolls.

Lunch Specials are always a good way to go. Hibachi Meals come with Onion Soup, Hibachi Vegetables, and Fried Rice. Starting at $9.95 with either Chicken or Vegetable, a lunch with Filet Mignon as your protein is $13.95, and a 'Combination' of two items (Scallops, Salmon, Shrimp, NY Strip), can range in price up to $15.95. Bento Box Specials can be had for about $10, and will include Miso Soup or Salad with Ginger Dressing, White Rice (Fried Rice is $1.50 extra), and a choice of California Roll or Spicy Crab Roll. Two really good lunch deals! Akira also will will pack it to-go for you on some of the lunch specials (obviously not the Hibachi).

The cooked Dinner/Ala Carte/Appetizer items are very good also. I've tried the Crab Rangoon, filled with sweetened cream cheese. The Katsu Chicken is always excellent; with crunchy and lean white-meat chicken, it is always fried in fresh oil. Chicken Teriyaki and a number of similar proteins are offered ala carte. Sashimi, Yakitori, and even Fried Oysters are just some of the appetizers to get you started on a great meal journey.

If there is any complaint, it's a very minor one. That is, for to-go rolls, Akira should package the rolls with high-domed lids. This is because with some of the larger rolls, it sometimes becomes necessary to have to scrape part of the toppings off the lid. I was going to dock a star for the price point being a little bit high. However, I'm not going to, because the fresh ingredients, the friendly staff, and the clean and spotless space of this restaurant make their food well worth the money. 

I highly recommend Akira Hibachi and Sushi Bar! 

Don't be late!

FIVE FABULOUS STARS!!!!!

Besito Mexican Restaurant is located in Westshore Plaza Mall off Westshore, north of Kennedy Boulevard next to Maggianos Little Italy, PF Chang's Chinese Bistro, and Michelle's Fish Market. Besito's happy hour runs Monday through Friday 4PM-630PM and includes $5 chicken tacos, mushroom squash blossom quesadillas, shrimp tamales, organic wild mushroom empanadas with goat cheese and fish tacos. For Happy hour, Besito also serves a $5 pomegranate tangerine house margarita, classic blue agave blanco Margarita, Johnny Walker Red, Tanqueray, Cruzan, Smirnoff, Jim Bean, Dos Equis Amber, Cigar City Jai Alai, Agave Wheat, Negra Modelo, Sangria, and Sycamore Lane wines. We sat at the bar and our server took a little longer than average to greet us. We were almost going to leave but our server greeted us after about 8min. After that, our server was pretty quick and courteous. The food, chips and salsa, and parting gifts all came out in a timely manner. Besito's serves complimentary chips and salsa for an appetizer, a churro for dessert, and gives you a parting gift. Our parting gift, the Mexican worry doll, was supposed to absorb all our worries away which is a nice thought.  Maybe it can pay my bills for me too lol. I was dissapointed with the salsa as it was bland and not smokey like Catrinas or oregano spiced like Miguel's or even mild jalapeno spiced like Green Lemon. There was absolutely no kick, flavor, jalapenos or hint of any hot sauce in the salsa. Our table shared the guacamole which I thought was a bit of a rip for $10, but when I saw a server freshly preparing it table-side and tasted it, it was definitely worth a try. I have to admit, it's a bit of a gimmick and gets everyone's attention and so everyone else orders it who's around someone that does. Ive never been a huge fan of guacamole with chips. I'd rather have it on a Taco or have a decent salsa with my chips. For the entree, I ended up getting the 3 grilled fish tacos and they were pretty good portion size for $5. However, unfortunately Besito's only has one kind of hot sauce and its a home-made scorching-hot habanero that is so hot it burns your tongue and lips. After the 20 second delay for the spice to kick in, the tacos were not easy to put down. I really wish they had a larger variety of mild, hot, and nuclear sauces to match the home made scorching hot habanero. Do I really need to bring a decent hot sauce from home to a Mexican restaurant to enjoy their Mexican food or get their food to go to adequately enjoy it?  The decor of the place is rustic and dark with dark wood floors, cool pirate of the carribean style light fixtures, high table tops in the bar area, and comfy booths in the main dining area. There is plenty of parking available in the mall parking lot although it can be a challenge to find parking near the restaurants. 3 fishes tacos for $5 is a hell of a value at less than $2 a Taco that can't be overlooked. So if I do come again, it will be to get the tacos to go but I'm not sure if their special is dine in only.  Management, for the love of God please stock some basic green and red cholula hot sauces like any self respecting Mexican restaurant has lol.

Nice hangout at John's Pass village. They have good food and do a booming bar business. You can come by land or sea, they have a dock and dock master to moor boats. The place picks up at night, this is a very popular night spot. It has a great view of the waterway, and there is usually a breeze to cool you off.

the Kamehameha nachos are possibly the best nachos I've ever had.

dear lord.

can be a bit of wait with a group but WELL worth it.

i don't know anyone in our group who didn't walk away stuffed.

Along the mountain ridges,
¬† ¬† ¬† Across the desert floor;
¬† ¬† ¬† Arms like verdant armor,
¬† ¬† ¬† Stalwarts guard our door.
Shading for the lizard,
¬† ¬† ¬† Haven for the wren,
¬† ¬† ¬† Source of inspiration,
¬† ¬† ¬† For past and present men.
‚Å†--Earl Bloss, "Saguaros," in¬†Arizona Highways, March 1973



This should be your first stop when visiting Suguaro National Park WEST. It's a typical NPS Visitors Center with all the usual amenities and a nice bonus feature:

-Rangers to help guide you to the hikes you want and pick-up maps of the park. 

-Gift shop

-NPS Passport Stamp location

-Pay your entrance fees here (see below)

-Amazing orientation video on how the Native people see the saguaro‚Å†--this is a must-see! Seriously. Well worth the 15min if your time. 

-Water refill station that pumps out cool water

-Clean restrooms


Entrance Fees:

Saguaro National Park Vehicle Weekly Pass¬†-¬†$20.00
Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle or RV and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.

Saguaro National Park Individual Weekly Pass¬†-¬†$10.00
Admits one individual when entering by foot or bicycle. Individuals 15 years or younger are admitted free of charge.

Saguaro National Park Motorcycle Weekly Pass¬†-¬†$15.00
Admits one motorcycle and its riders.

Habits are difficult to break but during a stay in Marigny I one day chose to walk out my front door and bear left rather than right.  This decision would take me further from the French Quarter and deeper into Marigny.  It would take me into Bywater as well, and I'd stumble upon places that felt almost magical, as they were so unexpected.  

Crescent Park was discovered when I scaled a steep, staired arch off Chartres.  It led me not only to a captivating view of the Mississippi, but also to a moody, grey relic: a wooden pier, the shell of a building.  Amongst all this cool grey sat two Milennials, staring not at their phones but engaged in a  game of Yahtzee.  The whole place felt like now but also like long ago; I'd opened a portal to the past.  

Crescent Park, if entered from the Piety Street Bridge (aka Rusty Rainbow), is one special experience, but it's not always entered from here.  It's actually a park with a walking path that hugs the river for 1.4 miles with many points of entry.  None will be quite as magical as this but the Piety Street Bridge, if you can scale it, is the optimal point of entry if you appreciate drama and history.   

Done, I scaled the arch back out of Crescent Park and rolled into Euclid Records (cool place) then to the biergarten which sits beside it.  Every portal to the past should sit beside a German biergarten and a vinyl record store but only one does.  If you're in NOLA I urge you to enter Crescent Park from this spot.  It borders on magical.  

*  For more on the park and the bridge, enjoy this article from 2014, when this area debuted:  https://www.nola.com/arts/2014/02/crescent_park_on_new_orleans_r.html

Well, I guess this might make going to court a bit easier, for work, jury duty, any worse and you might not appreciate it quite as much.
Beautiful, everywhere you look it is amazing, the views stunning, Santa Barbara is magical and the courthouse a must see while visiting.

Ok.

Now I know I better not try and "Review" a place with a few drinks on board and my iPhone in my hand.  What a crappy review.  So here is a new one.

We have been to a number of shows put on by Reno-Tahoe Comedy.  Justin Rupple was the best of the shows we have seen.  Funny club comic that knows how to work a crowd.  The shows are all run pretty well, think locally run though.  Not all slick and smoothly ran.  In fact last night they had a "Bachelor" back out at the last minute and someone from the audience stepped up.  It made for a great show, but might seem a little hokey to some.  I love the home grown feel of the place.  Rubbin elbows with funny people and passionate people makes me feel more connected to the community and the people in it.

The space they use at the Pioneer Underground is cool.  Everyone can see and there is even a small row of "comedy show" tables as well.  The bar prices are good, I just never seem to have an alcohol appetite when I am catching a show at the Underground.

I did love how they bumped a handful of loud girls talking back to the comedian last night.  They wouldn't shut up and the house was on it pretty quick.  They still wouldn't shut up so they were asked to leave.  So many people come to these shows expecting it to be about them.  Good on Reno Tahoe Comedy for knowing where to draw the line and holding that line.

If you aren't a stair person, you may want to check ahead of time by calling someone because it seems the only way in is down a huge set of stairs.  

All in all, friendly local people running this and giving us some good flavor to our nights in downtown Reno.  I will be back often.

I'm glad we chose to meet up with friends here at Bricks for our only night in Ybor. Frankly, because every other bar in the surrounding area seemed fairly sketchy. However, Bricks is as cool as the other side of the pillow!

Bricks has it all. Upon entering there's a coffee bar to the left, followed by a grown up bar. To the right there's ample seating containing booths and tables. And towards the back of the bar, it looks as if they have enough room for live music. Obviously, there are brick walls - score! It's dark inside, hence no picture uploads from me. Bricks is a place to be seen in downtown Ybor. I really dig this type of atmosphere.

The Tuesday special was $3 cans. About ten very good beers to choose from: Uinta Hop Nosh, Red Brick Laughing Skull and Founders All Day come to mind. The ten drafts on hand contained mostly local offerings which had my approval. Our friend asked the bartender to "surprise him" with a whiskey cocktail. We all sampled it and were instantly impressed. It even had a frothed egg!

Overall, we really enjoyed our experience here. The bartenders were friendly and cool. They didn't pressure us to order more rounds. Unfortunately, I didn't get to try any of the food. By the looks of it, I'd definitely take a crack at it. If I'm in Ybor again, you'll find me here!

A very modern hotel located near the Convention Center. Stayed here for 3 nights in room #237. 2 Queen Beds and an elegant sofa bed from West Elm.


The lobby is very open and welcoming. The front desk is filled Chupa Chups lollipops! My favorite is the chocolate/vanilla. It's free! It was one of the kind treats that makes you feel so welcome. 


There is also cold water in the lobby and hot coffee by the elevator.


One of the best things that I enjoyed here is the breakfast that served. I don't know what time they start serving but I do know when they end. One the weekends they stop serving breakfast at 10am. Weekdays 9am.

It's free. It's part of the perks for staying here. 

Breakfast Food as follows: 

Waffle Station: whipped cream, strawberries, and syrup. Get creative, they have nuts and fresh fruit like bananas and single serving of Nutella!

Egg Bowl Station: scrambled eggs, spinach, salsa, cheese, and various hot sauce!

Meat: I think they alternate it daily from sausage to ham. Hot Oatmeal Bar with plenty of choices for toppings: raisins, cranberries, pecans, walnuts, brown sugar, granola.

Bread station: croissants, bagels, wheat bread, pastries... They have a toaster for you too! What to top your bread: cream cheese, peanut butter, Nutella, butter, honey.

Drinks: House Coffee, Dark Coffee,with a selections of various creamers. Hot Tea from Earl Grey, Lemon, Green Tea, English Breakfast, and they are gourmet choices.

Dairy Bar: theres fridge stocked with Greek Yogurt, Activia, Milk, and Soy/Almond choices.

Juice Bar: apple, orange, cranberry. 


Considering that breakfast his is part of your room fee, so worth the stay! The staff that is running the breakfast stations are all very friendly and will even offer to clean up and take used plates from your table.


The room.... The bed is spacious considering it's a queen. The extra bed in the room is a sofa. You can easily make the couch a sleeping area and right below it... it's a trundle bed. Ask for extra twin sheets, pillows and blankets. We had 5 girls on this trip. We only came back to the room to sleep and took advantage of exploring the city!


One issue we had was the late night party room in the street facing room #237. It's expected. We are in New Orleans. It barely sleeps. Alot of parties here!


The lobby also has a gift shop and they sell alcohol, ice cream, chips, and other good stuff to snack during your stay.


Definitely recommending this place for anyone staying in New Orleans!

We went on a nice bike ride on Bayshore and decided to just take it all the way and head over to Ballast Point Park. We tied our bikes up and took a nice walk on the pier. Very nice view of downtown from the pier. There were also a ton of people fishing on the pier. I noticed that they had the tables to clean the fish off but the hose on each of them was broken unfortunately. 

There is a restaurant with outdoor seating and tons of fresh fish options on their menu. I look forward to checking that place out next time.

There is also a park for small children.

Is it the best diner in New Jersey, Land of Diner Enchantment?
Maybe not, but it certainly has history and local color going for it.
Oh, and a great breakfast if you fancy overflowing plates, unlimited coffee, and a Greek Omelet that is a wonder of the world.
