What is it about feta cheese and eggs that moves me so?  Don't know, but when mixed with sausage, potato, onion, peppers, all wrapped up in an fresh egg case, they become an amazing sensory explosion.  
Trenton may have seen better days (we have been waiting for its resurgence since it was "Americas Town" in the 60's), but Pat's carries on.
Diners are only partially about the food, and the rest about the concept, design, and lustful loyalty they inspire. 
Pat's is a worthy contender for the Urban Diner List on Yelp* (If there is one). 
Give it a try. 
Sit at the counter and watch professionals do their thing. Sit at a window and see a worldview that captures the past-its-prime city, the capital of the Garden State, remind you that... We Are Still Here.

Zero Stars.

Believe every review below mine when you are booking through a partnered site (Expedia in our case). At the time we booked months ago, it was a Ramada and Expedia noted they were pet friendly, and the Ramada website noted they were pet friendly. We even called to confirm.

Then they became a Quality Inn. A Quality Inn by some housing projects and a stadium. When we checked in,we noted we had a dog and they weren't pet friendly so we promptly checked out. The staff wasn't exactly nice about it. They said we should contact Expedia to get our money back, because they had a long line of people looking to check in and wanted us out.

In a matter of seconds, we booked at the Aloft in town. 

On our way out we had to take a different exit, cause two housekeeping staff were fighting in the hallway and had it blocked. When it came time to ask for our money back from Expedia, the hotel told Expedia we had not checked out and stayed the whole weekend. Now the charges are being disputed on our credit card.

The only thing this hotel has got going for it is the guitar shaped pool. The staff is unwelcoming, the hotel is in a crap location. If you're looking for a great hotel and travelling with a dog, I suggest the better located Aloft downtown.

This is not the original location in the French quarter, it is the Metairie location on Vets Blvd. I am very disappointed in the caf√© au lait coffee. 

Unlike the other coffee chain here in Metairie that has been around for a hundred years, this place gets their Cafe Au Lait out of a machine and whoever poured my drink put too much milk to Coffee ratio.

It was like drinking a hot cup of warm milk instead of the normal super dark coffee and chicory with a little milk like one third of the cup. It absolutely ruined my experience. I think this is a franchise of the French Quarter location. The Beignets didn't even taste as good.

Do yourself a favor and skip this location for either the French Market original Stand or this other Coffee Company behind the mall across the highway. You know the name.

 I did buy a can of coffee and chicory
 here and I'm drinking it at home and with the right ratio of boiling milk to strong coffee, it is absolutely delicious and the same as what you get at the original Stand in the French Quarter.

I had Chapterhouse Cafe bookmarked for years. Years. I honestly don't know what took me so long to visit.

During Thanksgiving weekend, I was in the city about to meet a friend for brunch but was feeling fairly sleepy so I googled nearby coffee shops. Chapterhouse was only a block out of the way, so I re-routed myself and walked over.

The inside is calm and inviting. Loads of people were studying or doing work. I took a quick look at the menu and was drawn to the black and white latte. 

They whipped it up within ten minutes and it was seriously delicious. I walked down the street so much happier after having that drink -- and I'm still craving another.

I know exactly where to go next time I'm in South Philly and craving a specialty coffee drink.

The Cochinita Pibil is marinated and slow-cooked until it is wonderfully tender and full of flavor.  I get this every single time and will probably continue to do so.  The accompanying rice is nicely seasoned and fluffy, although I'm not a fan of the fried plantains.  The crab and shrimp empanadas are a nice diversion from the usual beef, pork, and chicken, and the guacamole is very fresh.  The service is very friendly and the sangria is great.  If you're a margarita person, they have pitchers of those, too.  The menu isn't very extensive but they do a good job on the dishes that are offered.  A nice place to grab some Mexican food and ritas.

The actual entrance way is not from Providence, but instead from a side street. The parking is in an open unsecured lot. The front, facing Providence is a blank, vacant, "has been" of what may have been a store front. Whatever it was, the smell is of business failure is distinctly in the air. There is but one elevator serving all four floors which, during my stay, broke down trapping several occupants inside but only for a matter of a few minutes. However, they found the experience unpleasant and made everyone in the lobby aware of just how upset they were by it. 

There is a self serve, sort of a Hampton Inn copy of a breakfast from 8 until 11 o'clock, which are far better hours than found in most places and the dinner are is large enough, spotless and well positioned on the ground floor.

The rooms are large spacious and rather well appointed. Their ice machine is located on the second floor, so get ready for a journey if you are on another floor.

I've stayed at a lot of Best Westerns, and most of them are better. The only reason this one even exists is nearby Widener College, otherwise I'm certain it would not be here. The staff, however, is some of the best, particularly their shuttle drivers, some of whom are students at Widener. 

Also, a downside of being a college hotel is that you can expect a lot of noise and college partying, not only from the students but even more from some of their elderly but ever partying their alumni; particularly from those left or still surviving from the days in which Widener was known as Pennsylvania Military College. LOL!

These are the best tacos i've ever had!!!!
will update asap.

I must take pics next i go up to Santa Barbara!

What a terrific new addition to Chinatown.  This new restaurant is nice on the eyes and great on the tongue.  The food is Shanghai and Taiwanese cuisines .... and a good idea is probably to order something from both of these Chinese culinary traditions.  The one appetizer you must try without a doubt are the incredible beef scallion pancakes from Taiwan.  With beef, scallions, and an oyster sauce inside - you will not want to share them with anyone else at your table.  You want to eat them all yourself! 
And to add to the great dining experience at this restaurant, the service was extremely attentive and friendly.

With the current Korean chicken craze in full flame, I'm planning on coming back to Shanghai 1 to try their Taiwanese lightly salted chicken.  Everyone tells me it is really tasty.  Judging by what I've already eaten at this restaurant, I believe it!

A couple of friends of mine ate here and we enjoyed what basically was a shrimp bahn mi and the roast beef poboy. Both were great particularly the shrimp poboy. Combined with a great frozen irish coffee for dessert you have one of the best combos you can get in New Orleans.

We went here for a nice dinner and the place was very busy as it is small inside with not a lot of seating. The food was very tasty and priced right. The wait times were long but it was busy. The service was friendly. The food arrived hot and looked good. This eatery is located in an older sort of run down strip mall, and you have to look for it as its off the side road not the main hwy in front. The serving sizes were plentiful, and overall things went well. I will eat here again.

This is a quick review of the Valrico post office. I stopped in today to get some stamps and to my surprise the post office was actually open on a Sunday. Apparently they had special Sunday hours last week and this week to help people get packages mailed in order to hopefully get delivered by Dec 25. They even had put out already folders mailing boxes to help people just stuff their items in the boxes and head right to the check out counter. This office has an automated postal center as well if you like self service or need to mail something after hours. I was also surprised to see that they had a copying machine  just in case you needed to make copies of whatever you're mailing before you mail it. They also have tape that you can use to seal a priority mail packages. This has got to be one of the few post offices that still offers free tape, even if it's just for priority packages.

Some friends brought me and my family here for lunch.  Walking in, it looked and smelled like any old bar, but the food here is amazing!

Our orders ranged from a strawberry salad to catfish.  I didn't hear too much conversation during lunch, which means (at least with my family) the food was so good, they couldn't stop eating to talk.

My buddy Jay told me during the Football season, this was the place to be if your a Pittsburgh Steelers fan.  I'll take your word for it Jay.

Highly recommended.  A+ food and service.

PRIME RIB! Make sure you time the pick up of your prime rib RIIIIIGHT in the center of the prime rib slab, otherwise your meat will be overdone. Eh, I'm not complaining for $18 I got all you can eat! 

There are parts of the buffet that were pretty good (e.g. marble tiramisu, ribs, custom salad, prime rib), but the majority of the food was pretty mediocre buffet style. What differentiates Toucan Charlie's from the rest of the Reno buffets is variety - even more than some Vegas buffet's. I would never put Toucan Charlie's in the same boat as The Buffet @ The Wynn or Bellagio's, but it was definitely better than places like Treasure Island.

So if you're really hungry and looking for some prime rib like me, then stop by Toucan Charlie's. I would recommend coming in on days that they feature steak and seafood to get your money's worth!

We were looking for a casual spot to have lunch in Newtown and noticed King of Falafel and their slew of great Yelp reviews. I've never been to Newtown, so I wasn't sure of what to expect from a falafel joint located in an Amish Market, but yeah, the quality of the food was very good! 

We got a grilled chicken platter and a vegetarian falafel platter and both were delicious. My only gripe was that there wasn't very much meat on the chicken plate. For $12 bucks there were only 5 small pieces of chicken amid the sea of salad, hummus and pita. But, what was there was definitely memorable.

I should also note, for families coming with small kids, there is only 1 high chair for the entire food court dining area. We got lucky and snagged it right away but I can see how this could be an issue on busy days. I would definitely recommend bringing a stroller with a tray just in case.

Not bad!  I went here for lunch today with an old friend and colleague of mine who loves it here.  She had a 4 star Chicken Parm (1/2 order - was huge) and I had a really small, but tasty piece of Lasagna - the $6.00 lunch special.

Lunch for 2 with tip was $26 - can't beat that!

I will definitely be back.

We received two free tickets, so we had our out of town guest and the hubby enjoy the VIP tent with AYCE !!

I'm glad I was able to spend time with my youngest son.
He was very patient, while going to three booths and standing in the hot sun!

I bought the half a rack at each booth so I could try a few ribs (and before my son hauled them back to Ca)!

Everything went smoothly, the quick drive on Veterans, parking in the garage and picking up the tickets.

I didn't get to buy our ribfest t-shirts, but next year for sure!

Casino with a motel quality inn on the east side of Sparks off the highway. It mainly attracts locals. Western Village is a fairly cheap place to stay. Many people come for the casino. The place isn't anything upscale so know that before you go and it will be okay. 

It just needs to be cleaned. Maybe because it's a locals casino they don't care as much. The floor is pretty dirty and it smells ominous in there. Even with these issues it's not that bad of a casino. Lots of fun table games like blackjack and roulette. Has a few restaurants inside. They have a steakhouse and some smaller cafes to get things like coffee and sandwiches. It amazingly doesn't smell bad everywhere. The restaurants are pretty clean compared to the rest of the casino inside. 

As for the hotel it looks pretty old, but many people have said it's not bad. It has a few decent places to eat. The casino is the main thing.

Setting expectations may be a key element in outcome for diners here.  This is not a Korean restaurant with grill for meats.  This is a Korean noodle house.  There is a difference in format for a noodle house and a full tilt restaurant whether in South Korea (says my hubby who spent a week there) or in the US (says both of us who have visited both in cities like Oakland and San Francisco).  This is also a true "Mom and Pop" owned by a  Korean couple who also own a Boise sushi restaurant.  All of the cooks in the kitchen, who include the owner on some days, are Korean.

Whether that makes this truly authentic for purists I do not know because while I enjoy the flavors of Korean food it is not a cuisine about which I know enough to have any validity as food critic.  But I'll share that on our first visit at late lunch hour, among seven diners were young men of Korean heritage in casual business attire and sporting ID badges who seemed to be very much enjoying their bowls of noodles as they spoke in native language. 

I offer up the above as counterpoint to the food criticism offered in other reviews.  And for our experience at lunch which leads to four star outcome by putting all of this in the context of noodle house in Boise Idaho, the details follow.  While the location of this makes it unlikely that we will return often, when we're craving a good bowl of Korean noodles we will certainly go back.

VIBE
Serene and pleasantly disjointed.  As in the counterpoint of big white paper lanterns hanging from the ceiling and traditional silkscreen art on the walls against two big, flatscreen TVs with sound off (thankfully) showing a sporting event.  As in the spartan tables and chairs in the room and booths lining the wall (seating was comfy) against the backdrop of calming music on the sound system, both classic and classical with strings and keyboard.  We liked it.  It fit in the way it might if a screen writer were setting the stage.  From our view, they could lose the televisions but different strokes.

HOSPITALITY & SERVICE
We were greeting warmly by a beautiful young Korean woman, given our choice of seating and immediately brought menus and water.  Our server was friendly and efficient and knew the menu very well to answer our questions.  Food was prompt out of the kitchen and served nice and hot, separate dishes were offered to use for sharing even without our asking for them and she checked in with us about our meal at the just right interval.

MENU
A large format menu of multiple pages, maybe six, with libations (several beers by bottle, a few options of wine and soft drinks) in front and food following.  Choices include condiments (yep, kimchi - $2 -  and it is house made), wok style noodles dishes and soup like noodle dishes (ranging from $9 - $13), rice options and entrees.  Lots of seafood choices on the menu and several dishes are vegetarian or can be made so.  Good options for omnivores and vegetarians alike with gluten free choices shown as well.

FOOD & VALUE
We selected Anger Management noodles. (We have been wrestling with having a house designed and we needed some intervention but that's a long story of a "First World Problem".)  This is a wok styled noodle dish made with gochujang, a Korean fermented hot chili paste that is one of my favorites in Korean food, and we selected the vegetable option (other options include beef, pork and chicken).  It was delicious, the noodles and veggies both perfectly cooked and fresh jalapenos on top were a nice touch.  It was an ample size to be shared at good value price of $9.  We also shared lettuce wraps from the appetizer menu, offered in option of chicken or tofu priced at $6.  This is an entirely different flavor profile than that of Asian chicken lettuce wraps more familiar to most at Chinese food restaurants.  It was delicious but the rub is the iceberg lettuce leaves were served dripping wet and we had to pat them down with our paper napkins on the table.  A pet peeve of mine.  We also ordered kimchi to go ($2) to enjoy at home.  Total lunch for two at $17 seemed like a good deal to us for the quality and quantity.

THIS N THAT:

1) LOCATION & PARKING: Boise seems full of these ugly and poorly designed (for traffic flow in parking lot) strip malls like the one in which Noodle Korea is located.  Don't hold the location against them.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Lot has two accessible parking spaces.  Path of travel on sidewalk between them and Noodle Korea is blocked by chairs and sign of next door yogurt shop.  They are moveable.  Level in at Noodle Korea and throughout.  All standard height seating and booths are also transferable.

3) HOURS OF SERVICE TIP:  If you enjoy "linner", late lunch as dinner, a note that they are open for lunch from 11a to 2:30p then close until dinner service at 5:00.  Not open straight through.

I believe this spot has been open for about a week now without advertising. And at 5 pm was filling up pretty good. 

Note the entrance is on the Lakeside of the building so you don't have to walk around the entire building to find the right door- like me. The interior is very nice- rustic painted cement floor and walls that look like various reclaimed boards. I like the over all appearance. 

Being the first time there, the only server I can comment on was Charlotte. Damn that girl is a perfect server. Subtle  suggestions - a drink from the bar, "we have a great bartender."  Or an appetizer or two while looking the menu over. She saw my indecision and said take your time, I'll bring the drinks. For a new restaurant she seemed to know the menu pretty good and made a couple of suggestions. One two sided menu has sandwich, burger $10-14, salad $9-15 and small plate choices $9-14. The second menu had more of a dinner selection - ribeye $20, pasta $13, and lamb chop $18. The food arrived on, my personal favorite, HOT plates. My three tacos were so stuffed you couldn't fold them in half and tender beef, fresh crisp cabbage and a creamy cool cilantro sauce. Hubby enjoyed the rigatoni with mushrooms and chicken in a cream sauce.  

A nice variety of wines from $5 to $11 a glass and also available by the bottle. Also a reasonable beer list. 

Of coarse Charlotte returns with a final suggestion and tease of some decadent sounding desserts. Next time, we were just too full. 

Will  absolutely be returning there were several other items we really wanted to try.

Wine tasting without having to worry about getting any where!!

That's right.. no need to limit your intake of tasting a variety of wines because Wine Edventures will provide you with your travel arrangements. And these travel arrangements includes picking you up from your hotel, driving to the Santa Ynez Valley, visiting 4 wineries and a stop by Solvang!!!

Thanks to Shawn, we got picked up at our hotel in Santa Barbara and got a lovely scenic ride to Santa Ynez. We visited four wineries and got discounted deals on wines with most of them just because of our tour with Wine Edventures!
1. Koehler's which was simply gorgeous, despite the grape vines not in bloom quite yet!
2. Buttonwood
3. Presidio which is at Solvang! AKA I was able to stop by a nearby bakery, Mortensen's, to get some goodies!
4. Shoestring: which so happens to also have horses by their vineyard!

I LOVED that we didn't have to worry about driving and finding wineries to visit. And the lunch provided was between a Veggie Sandwich or Turkey Sandwich, which came with chips, a homemade cookie, and pasta salad. I felt quite full. And don't fret, water was provided given that we'll be consuming quite the amount of wine! 

Shawn, our tourguide, was very funny, saracastic and very informative. I loved his pop quizzes and that he pointed out Michael Jackson's home, which was far off in the distance. I must say, Wine EDventures was definitely an EDucation!

Also, the ride in the tour bus was quite comfortable and spacious. I especially loved the scenery of the Pacific and Santa Ynez hills! GORGEOUS I tell you! 

If you plan to go on a wine tour.. do it with WINE EDVENTURES!!! If you don't want to do it in a big group (there was a total of 17 of us in the tour I went on), then you can definitely have a private tour too! CHEERS!

Today is Lynne's last day in business and the health(ier) food segment of the Nashville food scene is poorer for it. I don't know the details behind the closure but I know that this was the Chad's decision and not something that was forced. Whatever the reason, I will miss coming here.

In addition to the delicious food/juice options, I'll miss the good conversations and vibes at the store. In the four years LL was in East End, it became a meeting place for neighborhood folks. I met/made friends there and would find myself engaging in all manner of conversations ranging from politics to music to events. LL became a neighborhood staple and somewhere I truly loved patronizing. Add to this, there's no other business like it in East End. None. In East End. It's odd, right? What's going to fill the vacuum? Lockeland Springs' The Post East is a coffee shop that sells packaged juice but it's not a juice shop. Edgefield's The Turnip Truck sells made-to-order juice but doesn't sell acai bowls, avocado toast, etc. It's a grocery, not a juice shop. One would think, given the demographic of the area, something would rush in to fill the void. Not so much. Not now. Until then, I big LL a fond farewell. Thanks for helping me to eat better and to stop and take some minutes to engage with real people in real conversation face to face. There were levels to this health thing, y'all.

Went to Jackson's Bistro for lunch. I loved half of my meal and hated the other half. Started of with the miso soup which was horrible. The tofu in the soup was of low quality and the soup was overcrowded with shitake mushrooms and white scallion strips that were impossible to eat in the soup. I appreciate the attempt to give the soup a modern twist, but it just didn't work.  

The sushi was good, but I have had better in Tampa. We ordered the Spicy Tuna roll, the Lava roll, and the Ying Yang roll. The spicy tuna roll was as expected, very fresh tuna.  The Ying Yang roll was pretty good also, but I probably wouldn't order this one again because I find white tuna bland. The Lava roll was tasty with the exception of the baked dynamite on top. I would have preferred a lightly seared fish on top; the "dynamite" tasted a like warm canned tuna...yuck!

For dessert our table split a very disappointing piece of chocolate cake. (I see why it was removed from the menu.) We considered the strawberry dessert we saw a waiter carrying, but I changed my mind when our waiter informed us the strawberries weren't fresh.

Our waiter was attentive at first; always pouring refills before our glasses were empty.  At the end of our meal our waiter disappeared to wait on another table so we had to wait 20 minutes before he finally charged our credit card. This would have been understandable if the restaurant was busy, but the restaurant was dead quiet.

Overall the food was hit or miss, but at least we got to enjoy a pretty view of the water and downtown Tampa while we dined.  Due to the lackluster food and high prices I would not go out of my way to dine here again.

Carrollton Market has become a date night staple for us. There cocktails and wine list are small but well done. The place has been refreshed since it was "One," with a light gray Nantucket feel with open kitchen. I've been here 6 times and each has been a hit. The complimentary Parker house rolls are divine and dishes are seafood-centric but don't forget about the steak frites which has become a favorite with my husband. My favorite dish this far is the gnocchi with meat ragu, pine nuts, raisins and peccorino. Sometimes there are complimentary truffles and don't forget the "Oysters Goodenough."

"...fish don't fry in the kitchen...beans don't burn on the grill
'took a whole lotta tryin' just to get up that hill
Now we're up in the big league, getting our turn at bat
As long we live, it's you and me baby
And nothing wrong with that...."


Aaaah yes... that theme song from The Jeffersons.  It's time for a bitch to careen like a magic carpet on her second wind. Heading into a quieter, older woman kinda life, I can begin to live my retirement dreams.  The excitement about this venture is unexplainable. 
However my huge kitchen complete with a pizza oven, huge yard with tress in a city that is also country....I've  taken to the sky on a natural high.

www.Pods.com

I got too much to think about.  What to move? What to sell? What to giveaway?  Should I have a yard sale?  The Recycler?  The Penny Saver.   Of course that's for shit I want to get rid of.   For the stuff that is headed to Georgia, other than me and Daisy....it's Pods.

Pods is a moving and storage company, for which if you got the cash...they store, they move it for you.  I'm not trying to pull a U-haul trailer or drive a U-haul to the ATL.  The shit I decide to move; business, studio and photography equipment, my bars, and  some other keepers.  The rest is for sale BABY!  Art, furniture, fixtures...and kinds of shit. 

And I'm gonna be a tote-bag, glass ware, art selling bitch this summer,  as Pods ain't cheap.  I may have to pare it down.  But my estimate to store and ship my shit  to the ATL is gonna be somewhere around 8 grand.  And that's for the stuff I want to keep

Letting them worry about getting it to me....priceless.  

I will have to post an update once I am happily romping through 'Hotlanta" , but hey....I'll be Yelping from the ATL!  How cool is THAT??!!

Five stars because if works like they say they it does, it makes it one less thing to worry about.

Seriously gorgeous.  I wish it wasn't November so I could've sat outside and enjoyed it - you locals are lucky come summer.  The only downside is that there doesn't seem to be an actual view, which you usually expect from a rooftop bar.  It was a Thursday night, so it was pretty quiet - just a bunch of well dressed couples and small groups lounging about.  I'm not a Philly local, so I guess I can't pick up on the "typical" or "coke den" vibes coming from this place - I just thought it was great.  Plus, anywhere that'll make me a spicy margarita is alright in my book.

Absolutely love this venue. I think it's gorgeous with all of the wood and brick industrial look.

The place can hold around 2,000+ people when there is a sold out show. It's very open and easy to navigate around even when there is a huge crowd. Just be mindful that the crowds are dense and contained in this big open area in the bar and bathroom hall which is separate from the concert hall.

Good food and drinks are offered at reasonable prices without breaking the bank. I was very content with this considering this was not what I expected going in.

Overall experience was solid. Best piece of advice I can give and be prepared to wait in line outside and do not bring too much with you. They'll screen you before entering and turn you away if you've got something they'd authorize not fit for their venue.

My new go to place for all things shoe and repairs! I took my husbands boot here and my vintage Louis Vuitton handbag because both zippers needed to be replaced. They did such a great job! I literally went to 8 other places who said they could fix my handbag but when I brought it in they said they couldn't. Dom's fixed it with no problem! The items were ready the day they quoted me, too. The zippers looked great, especially the one of the Vuitton which I was really worried about. Thank you so much!

After a busy Sunday of giving massages, I decided I wanted to meet with a friend for some Girl Time.  Since she's starting down the road of veganism and Me, I'm a meat eater, we decided that Thai food was the best middle ground.   And since I was working in Dunedin and she was coming from St. Pete, she spun the urban spoon and this is where it landed. 

The outside of the place is fine, looking a little brash with it's neon lights, but inside, there is a soft glow of serenity.  The floors were all neat and clean and the table set up, while tight was comfortable.  We were sat in the first alcove and waited for our waiter.  

Here is where things took a not so pleasant turn, when he came to the table, it was from the outside, as if he was called in from his smoke break, and took our orders; for Jasmine tea and Thai Coffee with ice water.  It was returned quickly enough but he forgot the ice water.  Any question we asked was answered almost snappishly, and almost unintelligibly. 

Our orders were placed, mine is what I always order, Chicken Sateh & Combo fried rice, she placed an order for curry puffs and some vegetable dish.  As if to prove that he wasn't listening, he had to come back out and get my order a second time. This did not fill me with confidence.  And when our starters came out, I did not get the chicken sateh, but rather, beef.  I did not complain, but ate it. I'd never had beef sateh, and it was OK, but it was NOT chicken, which is by far a more lovely dish. 

When our mains were served, I noticed that my combo fried rice was served, not with the traditional beef, chicken and pork, but with scungili and shrimp. Apparently the seafood that he'd told her would be in her vegi dish, wound up in my rice. It was terribly confusing.  I don't eat seafood, but I ate around it, because I didn't clarify what was in their fried rice, this was on me. 

Now, their food is fresh, it is tasty and it comes out fast. My only fault with this place was our waiter's inattentive attitude and the fact that he really didn't pay attention to what he was doing. It was clear he would have been any other place than serving us at our table, and it showed. 

The high point of our meal? The Thai custard and sticky rice with coconut sauce, it truly was delicious and we thanked him for recommending it to us to try. It brought both of us back to Hawaii.

I've had really good meals here, and pretty bad ones so I'm giving 3 stars.

My family and I always stop here for the buffet. We've been where everything is fresh and full and other times where things are dried out and have obviously been sitting for awhile. I just like the basic stuff: chicken and broccoli, fried rice, egg drop soup, and noodles with duck sauce. My mom will always ask for fresh salmon because usually it's either gone or been sitting for a while.

Dishes are usually taken promptly and we got our hot tea and drinks pretty quick, so no complaints there! Don't forget your Yelp Check in discount!

That's it Epic, you are getting another star! Today I had lunch--a rosemary chicken sandwich on a wheat roll with a bag o chips. I don't know what else to say, but yum! Not too heavy on the mayo, but big on flavor, I dug the big chunk chicken although probably a bit messier than a traditional chicken sandwich. Why have I never eaten at Epic before? More importantly, what should I eat at Epic next time I go?

One of the prettiest malls from the outside however there aren't many stored there that I frequented when I went to UCSB.  Now State street has had an Extreme Makeover.  Tons of brand names stores right on State like Juicy (but who really shops there now? even though I think there stuff is adorable), surf shops galore and Betsey Johnson.

Delicious food! The chorizo burrito is fantastic. They have a great coffee bean selection and drink menu. There is something for everyone, from the coffee novice to the snob. The staff is always patient and friendly.

Amazing & custardy French Toast

Chose the special - Local Strawberry French Toast.  Fresh strawberries were macerated so that the yummy sauce that formed was then poured all over the thick slices of frenchie.....no fake strawberry-jam-action going on over here!

Bread was thick but not too thick to soak up all the eggy goodness & get all puddingy & custardy!  Huge props!!!

Buddies got the Banana Walnut Buttermilk Pancakes & said they were fluffy & tasty as could be - very high marks.  I tried a bite & thought they were dense & cakey & that is my highest compliment!

But we all agreed my Frenchie was the best out of the bunch!  :-)

Coffee was smooth & strong - multiple cups appreciated!!

Waitstaff was super friendly & the wait to get in on a busy Saturday was around 20 min....can't get better than that!

Yyyaaaasssss!!!! The streetcar stop was conveniently located in front of the hotel I was staying out, but the stop was closed due to construction. After a short walk we got to the Canal street station. It's near the Aquarium of the Americas. 

It's $3 for a day pass called Jazzy pass or $1.25 for a ride. They only accept cash and it must be exact fare. Come prepared.

Some of the stops have a code you can text to get streetcar updates which was convenient so you won't have to stand in the sun to wait. There is not much shade at the stop and it's not covered.The streetcar definitely felt great while we were moving since there was a breeze from the windows and it was so humid there.

We rode the streetcar to get to the French Market and the French Quarter. Super convenient and cheaper than Lyft/Uber. Check out their routes by downloading the RTA app or pulling up their website.

Wow! I'm seriously impressed with how delicious the food was. Not only did an impressive amount of people come in for a Thursday night, but I loved learning more about Indian food in this casual environment and witnessing other people learn the same (and then LOVE their food).

I'll set the scene: we snagged a seat in an Indian-style 'cart-themed' booth. So fun. Then you go up to the counter and order your food, fast-casual style. You can choose either a rice bowl, naan sandwich or naan pizza (how cool are those combos?!). I got a rice bowl, added tandoori chicken, saac curry (blend of leafy greens), tomatoes/carrots/cilantro, and mango chutney. WOW - that mango chutney really added a next level to the dish (highly recommend). The saac curry was the least spicy option, yet I still thought it was pretty spicy so couldn't finish my entire dish but.... man I wish I could handle spice better because it was delicious. 

I saw other people with a naan sandwich and the naan pizza and it looked incredible. Can't wait to try the pizza. They also sell mango lassis and ice cream. 

I also heard that this restaurant started with a kid who had the idea to start the restaurant while in college. Very cool story and I'm happy that it truly was so good so we can continue to support this place!

If you've not been to Versi Vino yet - get there now!

South Jersey NEEDED a place like Versi Vino for a LONG, long time. Stopped by with my husband recently and was thoroughly impressed with the design of the location, the extensive wine list, the flexibility of tasting options, the welcoming staff who is very knowledgeable and excited to give their guests the best experience possible, and the delicious menu items available for purchase.

You can stop by here for light bites and a glass of wine, an extensive tasting where you can choose the volume of the tastes you want, can order a flight of wine (try the sparking wine flight) or a bottle or two to go. With regards to picking up a bottle or two, this is a great place to pick up wine bottles on your way to dinner at a family/friends house or to a local BYOB and why not have the opportunity to taste it before you buy it! We will definitely be back and look forward to trying their wine lists as it continues to change with new additions and exciting wines to try.

You can also purchase a Wine Card, load it with a dollar amount of your choice, and purchase sips by the glass at their wine tasting machines - note this is on hold for the safety of the customers due to Covid-19. Love this idea and can't wait for it to be fully available when safe to do so.

Highly recommend making reservations but walk-ins are accepted as well. Check out their Instagram page to stay up-to-date on specials, virtual tastings, and in-house wine classes as well. Cheers!

MENU: To-go, host gave me a thick paper menu to look at. I was surprised not to see any pizza on the menu. I'm from CA, and the one we have has pizza unless it was a recent thing where they no longer serve pizza. Ordered the chicken marsala (which was yummy) and a new entre cannelloni Bolognese (which I wasn't a big fan of, I thought it would have more meat, but it was basically a cheese and spinach Italian cheesy omelette with some meat sauce spooned on top). Salad to-go was room temperature, lettuce was soft and limp and not fresh and crispy. 

PARKING: outside parking shared with a big outside shopping area across from Petco and a Brewing Co. 

OUTSIDE: location itself is nice in a well developed shopping/restaurant area. Your typical look of a Macaroni Grill. Lots of outside seating on their wrap around patio. Refer to my photos. Nobody was sitting outside though, which was too bad since the weather was nice. I like how to the right of the front door there are nice benches and shade in case you need to wait for a table or for your to-go food. 

INSIDE: like all Macaroni Grills, darker ambiance, but setup and d√©cor was the same. Bar on the left. Hostess counter straight ahead of you. Double door entrance as you come in with a second door to open. 

OVERALL: A-OK. Nice that they have to-go option and curbside to-go option. I was disappointed about the cannelloni, but even more disappointed about the salad. Usually salads are chilled.

What a beautiful theatre! If you're into old architecture, you need to visit the Indiana Repertory Theatre just to check out the beautiful terrazzo flooring and the art deco-style touches that are in every corner of the building. I point out the terrazzo flooring because I love a good terrazzo floor, so when you're at the theatre, look down to admire the beautifulness. 

We visited the Indiana Rep to see a children's play, and all the kids were invited to sit on the floor. Even though I'm not a kid, I sat on the floor too, and it really made me feel a part of the action. The actors were jumping, dancing, running and singing from every part of the room, so we were constantly turning our heads to see what was going on. But that's a good thing, because I felt like it kept the kids (and me) involved in the story. For all the floor-sitters, the theatre provided us with seat cushions, which made the sitting a lot more comfortable.

My children loved their theatre experience here at the Indiana Reperatory Theatre, and I'm hoping to come back soon to see another children's performance!

A friend of mine shot me a text saying I had to eat at Acme Oyster House since she knew I was in the Big Easy. Of course I looked it and found the other location in the French Quarter. The line was out the door. No thanks. I parked my car at Harrahs and found this location. It was meant to be I suppose.

I kind of figured that no matter what, this location would be a little subpar to whatever was going on at the other location since this was inside of the casino, but I figured I'd still give it a try.

I ordered a lot because I wanted to really see if I liked it here. For starters I got the half Po-boy with fries and a side of coleslaw. The sandwich only comes with one side so the slaw was extra. Then I ordered six charbroiled oysters, because this was the main reason I was to come here.

The service was alright. One girl working the register and one cook. The poor girl was ringing people up and delivering food as well which delayed things.

I sat down and waited for my food. First came the Po-boy. The half was huge. It looked more like a whole to me, and thank goodness I didn't order the whole because it would have been entirely too much food. The fries and slaw were great, but I didn't love the Po-Boy. It was ok, but just that- ok.

I was finished with my meal and still didn't have my oysters and finally they arrived. Wow. Now looking back on it, I should have just ordered these. The oysters were amazing; cheese and lemon- yum! They were absolutely delicious. They were hot and still bubbling when they arrived and I ravaged the plate.

Next time I'm in town I want to go to the real location and order the same thing to see how the real place stacks up against this version. I'm sure it's even better.

I work less than 8 minutes walk from the Italian Market.  Probably could make it here in 5 minutes, but I walk like a sloth - S  L  O  W.  I like to blame this pace on my penchant for stopping to take random photographs, but no, I'm just  S L  O  W.  A blind 89 year old man in a wheelchair with only 1 arm to propel himself could outpace me, but I digress.

My friend Michael T, the Reno Yelp CRM, has been on my mind lately as I've noticed a few places claiming to have the best roast pork sandwiches in Philly.  Thought I'd give this place a shot and I'm glad I did. It's a tiny tiny divey shop, obviously run by a tight knit gang who have to juggle doing everything within 6 inches of each other.

My sandwich was promptly delivered to me 3 minutes after I ordered it. I sat on the tiny counter on a tiny stool and ate my giant sandwich which was around $7.  It could've been 2 meals! Of course, I loved the bread and the juicy pork dripping with flavor. Skipped the rabe (sorry!) and shoulda added provolone cheese, but a girl's gotta watch her already curvy curves.

I got an "in house" groupon deal with Leslie. The secretaries were very friendly. And Leslie was nice enough.  Aside from the great price, I also enjoyed the interior.  It was a pretty cool salon.  They had lots of hair products but also makeup and accessories.  I didn't quite like my haircut or the deep conditioning results, but I would try Leslie again. Overall, everything was pretty good.

Review visit: 04/18/2015
This has always been one of our favorite Hooters and we've visiting several from Florida to California. Last night we were there and we had Reese; she was awesome. She was slammed and they were working short, but she still made sure we had a good time. She had us so preoccupied and laughing that as we left we forgot to leave her the rest of the cash we meant to leave her. So Reese, don't think we stiffed you on a better tip, you were literally just that good we forgot we had cash for you. So next time we got you even if you aren't our server.

Eating outside Santa Fe on a nice summer night with my boyfriend reminds me of a great R&B video. A love story, with a couple sitting outside wooing each other. The candles are dimly lit, but the mere sight of them makes you melt. The salsa dip is..NO WORDS..that great. I like cilantro. No, I love cilantro. Santa Fe does a great job of preparing the salsa dip with just enough cilantro. Careful with the chips & salsa, the 2nd round is on you ha!ha!

I am a margarita, mojito, lemondrop diva! The margarita was so refreshing. I can't think of any other adjective to describe it. The drink did not disappoint Elle. Eating outside around people from all over the world makes me feel good. My boyfriend swears by the softshell crab taco. It lit him up. I did enjoy it as well. There are so many obvious choices when viewing the menu. I would challenge you to try something new. I love trying new stuff at magnificent restaurants like Santa Fe. If you don't like what you order, SWALLOW it..LOL no seriously, you will definitely enjoy it.

My sad update....

DG and I drove 30 miles from where we were staying to rent jet skis on the Saturday that I told Stuart we would be coming up.  We didn't have reservations, but he had said that he would be there so it wouldn't be a problem.

I called Stuart as we were leaving, and left a message saying we were on the way.  I was a little concerned when I didn't hear back from him, and it was drizzling slightly when we got close to the area.  But he was so friendly and positive when I talked to him the day before, that I figured it would be fine.

When we got there, two girls were scheduling whale watching boat trips, and were very friendly, but told me that Stuart wasn't there.  They tried to call him on the number I had, as well as his partner, and couldn't reach either of them.

We left and figured we would come back the next day, and that we would get a call back at some point.

Unfortunately, Stuart never called me back.  : (

I'm open to trying him out another time, and raising the stars - but it would have been nice if he would have returned my call - especially after being so friendly on the phone and surely hearing my message that we were heading out to him.

The upside:  we took an AWESOME ultralight flight along the coast from Sky Rider Ultralight in Camarillo instead!!  Woooohooooo!!

Say adios to Mangroves, and hello to Sunova Beach, which is the newest addition to the SoHo/Courier City bar and restaurant scene.  Why replace a bar/restaurant with another?  I'm not sure what the answer is, but just by walking into Sunova Beach, I think I know the answer; Fresh and new and beach bar, mostly beach bar.  It's the one vibe SoHo doesn't provide in it's many bars and eateries.  WoB is beer snobbish, Cheap is pseudo-swanky, Drynk is douche-baggish, MacDinton's is a fake-ass Irish pub, SoHo Saloon is small and the Lodge is a little bit of everything.

I really like what they've done with the place.  It seems more open now, and the place has definitely been brightened up.  As for the staff, we saw two people who rolled over from Mangroves at the bar, but everyone else was new--and you can tell.  A lot of the staff was lost somewhere between friendly and "I don't know what I'm doing."  They just opened a few days ago, so it's gonna take some time for the rookies to get settled in, I suppose.  

The bar is full liquor with beer.  In this day and age of craft beerism, I was hoping that they would have a better selection though.  I think they had about 10 lines on their rail, and they were what you'd expect to see at perhaps Applebee's.  My suggestion would be for them to rethink their selections and try to specialize in more craft beers to set themselves apart from all the other bars in the area.  I skipped the beer and had Nathan whip up an old fashioned for me.

As for the food, it was decent.  There were 4 of us and we ordered nachos and a burger to split.  The nachos were pretty good, but small.  We ordered half chicken, half steak for sampling purposes.  I think we all agreed that the chicken was better due to how well-marinated and seasoned it was.  The burger though was pretty good.  It might be the best burger in SoHo.  10 ounces of flame-grilled deliciousness.  James Joyce is still the best in town, but the burger here is a good alternative if you don't feel like traveling to Ybor.

Happy hour for drinks is daily from 3-7 PM.  As for the food menu, all but two shrimp dishes are under $10, so you won't break the bank chillin' out here.  The new indoor/outdoor bar area is great and I really like the atmosphere change to the area.

Talk about a convenience store. This is more like a smoker's post-toke dream. 

If you're looking for smoking paraphernalia, this store comes stocked with pipes, hookahs, grinders, screens, papers, loose tobacco, flavored cigars, all sorts of snacks, and even "Irish" food. Not sure what really constitutes as Irish food since all I really found we items to satisfy the most serious munchy craving. 

You'll also be pleased to know they take credit cards with a reasonable $5 minimum. I'm pretty sure this store knows its niche.

Why, hello, there, Pelican Bay, newest restaurant on Elysian Fields, purveyor of the absolute best frozen daiquiris in the city, not to mention fresh & delicious food prepared & served with much love. Check me out - FTR (First To Review) and first to set a 5-star precedence, I'm sure.

Stupid me, I didn't bring an appetite, just a thirst for a pi√±a colada because I knew here they have it in the machine so I wouldn't tempt the stink eye from a bartender (I was that bartender once, I admit). Here, you can order any kind of frozen concoction you want because they have a wall of frozen drink machines glorious churning up the colorful sweet stuff. You might feel like a kid at buffet where you can mix & match Pepsi and Mt. Dew and even Dr. Pepper (I was that child once). They have all these varieties and then will do something outrageous like a Pi√±a Colada/Hypnotiq parfait. I stuck to the classic pi√±a and wow, it even tasted like it wasn't filled with that obvious artificial flavor that some daiquiri places typically use (Gene's version is not drinkable, I'm sorry). It's true that I normally shun the sweet boozy stuff but there's something about a hot New Orleans day and the way these days practically beg for frozen cocktails. I'm a believer now. And this is where I'll be getting my fix. Sunday fundays, here's looking at you! 

Despite not bringing an appetite, I wanted to try their veg black beans (perfection-- just the right texture and seasoning) and oh, I can never say no to homemade tortilla chips. So, yes, I ate. It's kind of impossible not to at Pelican Bay. Know that if you're a vegetarian there are options for you (and how cool is it that they have a separate fryer for veggies?) and they note what isn't vegan on the menu, too. When asked by chef/owner Tanzanika what they could do to make the menu more veg-friendly, I suggested having some tofu options, maybe (I just love tofu. I know it's crazy). She laughed but seems like she's open to the idea. It's not even really necessary and if you're open to dairy, they have pizzas that look really great, too. Their emphasis is on FRESH food and yes, they shop daily. My guy had a burger that he said tastes just like "Mom's burger," which for him is a big compliment (for me, not so much. My mom's burgers possibly turned me off meat forever. Please don't tell her I mentioned it, K?)

Service is fantastic from the moment you open the door and are warmly welcomed. Our waiter couldn't be sweeter or more attentive and a special shout out to bartendress extraordinaire, Paris!

It's a slice of pure Southern comfort, friends. Get thee here immediately.

PS. There can't be a better place in the city to watch Saints games and other sporting events. TVs galore!

According to the Audubon Institute website, "Audubon Tea Room is the most prestigious of [their] venues, with gleaming wood floors, soaring ceilings, silk drapes and an impressive series of double doors leading to the lush Tea Room Garden. Beauty and elegance is always waiting to welcome you and your guests." Overall, this is a pretty accurate assessment of the space. (Which I guess is good, since it is the information they provide on their own website...)

It's a large, circular room that's host to all kinds of events, but I've mostly been there for luncheons and weddings. This is a magical (if, I presume, insanely expensive) place to have weddings (though the imaginary weddings I've attended at NOMA are prettier and more fabulous), and it's a good place to rest for a bit during Zoo to Do, if you get tired of wandering around in search of food, booze and music, or whatever it is that other people do at this event. 

This is totally a venue I'd use for an event someday. In the meantime, I'll continue to enjoy attending other people's events in the Audubon Tea Room, and perhaps I'll see you there.

Is this the best Italian restaurant in Newtown? I think so.

Is it the best in Bucks?  I could make an argument for it, but the real point is that it is so good that people who love Italian should give it a try. Back in the day I returned to Trenton to satisfy my Napoli needs, but those days are gone, and we all must find alternatives closer to home.

Pasquale is the owner/chef/creative genius of Vecchia Osteria.  He takes great pride in his cuisine, and oversees the details between being on the floor checking on his customers and making everyone feel welcome.  He can be generous.  Complimentary glasses of wine and cannoli are not uncommon.  In between, the courses are excellent and each taste follows on upon the one before building into a crescendo of taste, texture, and subtle overlay.  Maestro, please continue. 

Last week, VO was one of several local eateries to donate dishes a for large dinner in town.  They provided Chicken Cacciatore (white version), and Rigatoni Vodka, enough for 60 people.  The Chicken was dark meat with lots of Rosemary covering everything.  The meat and bone were easily parted, leaving a succulent light wine and vinegar sauce to bathe the dark chicken flavors.  It was superb.  The pasta was the larger rigatoni, which held the creamy tomato gravy in its grooves and ridges like they were born together.  It was a subtle tone so as not to compete with the more robust cacciatore.  Great combination.  I was sure to take some leftovers home to enjoy the next day, as Chicken Cacciatore becomes even more satisfying with age. 

I have eaten in Pasquale's house several times, and always wondered why I waited so long to return.  

It always exceeds my expectations.

It's an arena! 
It's usually cold so bring a sweater. 
The food is overpriced and so is the liquor...because y'know it's an arena. 
But other than that it's pretty nice. The seats are comfy and everything is well marked so you can actually find where your seat is. And it is clean...including the rest rooms so yay for that.

Parking costs extra, so see if you can park on the surface streets (a couple of blocks away on Loyola is a good bet) which may only be metered until 6 pm.

PLUS last time I was with brother #4 and he knows all the best routes and we were out of there in no time and beat the crowds.

Anthony's Coal Fired Pizza is one of my go to places when I am craving pizza. I consistently have great dining experiences here. The staff here is very friendly and attentive.

I have had several of the pizza pies on the menu and have never been disappointed. The pizza is cooked evenly and the dough and the crust come out perfectly. 

While the pizza is fabulous here, the Oven Roasted wings are ridiculously delicious! It is a different take on wings, and they always come out so flavorful due to being cooked with the carmelized onions.

All beers and wines are half off during Happy Hour. Anthony's also has great lunch specials.

While Anthony's is best known for its pizza, they also have some salads and sandwiches, I wouldn't mind trying on the menu. I will definitely be back.

Ginger turmeric tea blows me away. 

I'm going to be honest, I had thirty minutes to kill, I was in the area, and I needed to use a restroom. The Blind Tiger had a restroom for me to use and I could sit and do work after. 

My neighborhood Blind Tiger is in Westchase and I had the ginger turmeric tea there. It was amazing, so I ordered it here as well. I watched them steep the tea and got it sweetened with agave. The employee put in the perfect amount of sweetener - it was delicious!

It is such a unique tea and it hits the spot every time. There were a couple people sitting inside working, so this is the type of place I would feel comfortable spending hours getting things done. It's not huge, but there are plenty of tables and chairs. There are tables and chairs outside too.

The employees are always very hip looking and friendly. 

Anytime I need coffee or a place to work in Ybor, I'll come here.

They aren't lying when they say the milkshakes here are to die for! We had the pleasure of dining here during a visit to the Ritz and I am very happy we did! This is a part of the country club portion of the Ritz, so it's along the golf course and a little drive from the hotel itself. They are known for their savory burgers and mouthwatering milkshakes. We dined on the patio as the sun was setting and the weather was just about perfect. It's such a serene environment and they do an excellent job of creating a similar ambiance in the restaurant.

While sitting by the fireplace, we both ordered burgers. I went for more of a classic burger with cheese and avocado and then we split the fries. Typically, you think, well a burger is a burger anywhere you go and so I wasn't expecting anything much different. However, there is absolutely something different about this burger. It had the perfect flavor and was just the right amount of juicy inside the brioche bun. It was hard not to gobble up every bite! For dessert, we splurged with their famous milkshakes. They come out in a glass, along with the metal milkshake container with extra shake. I ordered the peanut butter chocolate and loved every minute of consumption. 

If you're in the area or staying at the Ritz, I highly encourage you to stop in for a visit.

What comes after happy hour (at the hotel) and dinner (where they recommend you run to Safeway for liquor)? Karaoke, obvi.  

One of the coworkers knew this place.  There's a large bookof songs, and I was able to find ones that I liked.  There didn't seem to be much rhyme or reason to the order, but there were 2 good sized groups who tended to rotate back and forth.  I appreciated that they had a huge screen and portable mikes, so you could just sing from your spot in the bar without having to really walk up to the front.

I heard stories later from others about the folks that they'd talked to at the bar... interesting crowd.  I recommend you bring your own group of friends for your performance.

Passero's morning (and 3 PM - 4 PM ish) crew is wonderful - they move the line quickly and get my order (which varies0 correct easch and every time.

I love the iced coffee, cafe au lait and teas here.

Such a world of difference here vs Charbucks.
I also love Old City Coffee - but Passero's is right in Suburban station so I can stop there to (and from) work so easily.

Love it here!

Surprised that they no longer have grilled chicken available.  Is that all stores or just small ones?  Just checked KFC.com and it's still on their main site so I guess it's just small stores.  Anyway I'm not a fan of fried chicken so I wanted grilled.  Came in here and they don't carry it.  Was hungry so I ordered a couple of sides instead.  Mac n Cheese, cole slaw and some biscuits.  Staff was very helpful and friendly.  5 stars for them.  Location is tiny, with just a few tables.  minus a star for no grilled chicken and I didn't see a bathroom or indication of one either.  Tables could have been bussed faster.  The store was pretty dead when I stopped in but the table I wanted to sit at wasn't clean.  I brushed the crumbs off and sat at it anyway.  Parking is okay - has a parking lot but this strip mall is super busy so it's easy to get into a fender bender pulling in or out.  Be wary for the excess of cars.

We went to Spice Finch, located inside the Warwick hotel, for brunch recently.  

I love Shakshuka which is generally a hearty combination of spiced tomatoes, onions, and peppers. We decided to get a large order, which was designed to be split by 2.  It was definitely tasty, although not quite as hearty as other preparations I have had. The accompanying flat bread was fresh and delicious. 

Although good, here's where I think this entree offering had some shortcomings. If it's designed to be split by 2 people, including 3 poached eggs doesn't quite cut it. Does sharing 1 1/2 poached eggs per person really make sense? Same with the flatbread; it was one piece that was to be shared. We could have easily each ate our own piece. I've ordered Shakshuka at other restaurants and an order typically comes with 2 eggs. We left feeling a little underwhelmed. Fortunately, we weren't too hungry. Otherwise, this entree designed to be shared by two would have left us feeling under satisfied as well.

I'm one lucky cat that AJs is literally a 5 minute walk from my house. AJs is so fabulous that I'm pretty sure people just cruise in there for an "escape" into all that is gourmet, specialty, delicious and downright picture perfect. It's hard to go to AJs with out making some unnecessary purchases. The flower displays alone bring out the "Martha Stewart" in me. If you make it passed the flower shop make sure to check out the fresh fish and phenomenal beef counters. Here you can definitely buy high quality  choice and prime beef that will never disappoint. They even have grass-fed beef! 
Don't be discouraged by the high prices, because AJs has crazy good sales on the reg. For example, you can buy PRIME New York Steak for like $12.00/lb on sale versus the normal $28.00. 
TIP: Sales usually fall on holiday weekends.

Beyond the beef counter is their delectable cheese section (my personal heaven), which has more than just your average triple cream bries and Manchego Cheeses. I've been lucky enough to score a truffled Pecorino! 

Hungry while shopping? No Prob! You can munch on all kinds of house-made goodies like grilled veggies, grilled fish, rotisserie chicken,  potato salad, pasta salad, Orzo salad and more.

or

Stop in an eat some fresh Sushi at the Sushi Bar. You know you're getting #1 sushi grade fish, with out a doubt!

Like Pizza? check out the Pizza and Deli counter where you can order a custom sandwich or grab a slice. Then cruise over for some Illy coffee and sweets. 

AJs even has an outdoor grill, open daily until 3pm. They make a GOOD hot dog (with Brats) YUM!

It's best to go to AJs when you are not starving or without a game plan, because it can do a number on your wallet!

Love you AJs!

For St Pete's sake, when you're on the Gulf Coast you must check out the St Pete beaches. They're nothing short of amazing.

Absolutely spectacular beaches in St. Petersburg Florida and some of the best beaches in the whole state. I don't love them as much as I love Sarasota's Siesta Key but I still absolutely love them and most of them are Public Access, and you can't ask for much more than that in the Flo Rida.

These are indescribably gorgeous beaches and massive fancy hotels with dolphins on some of them - which I love - and they are almost exclusively caucasian, which is a shame, but you can't have everything. I look forward to the day when the St Pete crowd is more diverse... and the Gulf Coast in general.

The one thing I hate about vacation is when I find a spot that is "the one!" This restaurant is worthy of that title. "Khyber Pass Pub" was on a list of places to eat at in Philadelphia, so I made it my business to get here. From the outside it looks like a small bar, that if you walked to fast you may not even see it. But heading inside, judging by the loud music upstairs, I knew this is a very hip spot. It's low lit, with a comfortable vibe. It has two floors and a bar on each. Downstairs is the restaurant, where you can eat and socialize. Upstairs is where they have a live band, where you can dance the night away. But dancing would wait because I was hungry. When I got to the hostess stand, I was told to find a seat and I did. My waitress, Mikaela, came over and she was amazing. She was friendly and recommended all the best food. She joked about not knowing about them being on the best spot list. But after a short conversation I ordered the Mac & cheese to start. Those Mac balls were incredible! The were placed on a home made sauce that seemed to bring all the flavor out. I asked for a side of the sauce for my sweet potato fries it was so good. I told her I wanted the burger because it came highly recommend. That recommendation was on point. I didn't change anything about the burger, I got it according to the menu. I'm so glad I did. The beef was sensational, the bacon crunchy, and the dry cheese complimented the entire burger. Topped off with the pretzel bun and saut√©ed onions, and you got the best burger in Philadelphia. I will make it my point to come again. Atmosphere, food, and service! Who can beat that?

Escape the real world and come and have a drink at the Tiki bar.  The roof is thatched and with the lights and decor, you can actually believe you are in the Caribbean, for at least an hour or so.

Jimmy Buffet has brought the Caribbean to us with his inspiring menu that is so diversified and somewhere along each line, there is Caribbean spice in a lot of dishes, which makes them different, even though they are also famous for their cheeseburgers. They also serve turkey burgers & veggie burgers at no extra charge. 

I had the fried pickles and the BBQ pulled pork sandwich and both were good.

The menu has a wide variety of appetizers, from fried pickles to ribs, quesadillas, mini burgers or chili dogs to wings, shrimps, homemade sweet potato chips and much more.  

The wide variety of entrees, wraps, salads, seafood, and sandwiches could take me all day to mention.  Or for dessert, how about chocolate nachos or real Key lime pie. 

Check out their menu @ http://www.cheeseburgerinparadise.com/menu/oxfordvalley.pdf

When you want something a little bit different and a cold beer served at 32 degrees in a great atmosphere with Jimmy's music playing, try them out!

Service is pretty good :)

For some reason I didn't love this place. I ended up at this restaurant unexpectedly with a group but I must say that I had already planned to go to the original location in the Gulch the following day with family and that meal ended up being much better.

Since the menu stated that the East Nasty was the best sandwich in America, we had to get it. In addition to multiple orders of that, we tried the biscuit and sausage gravy, chronic bacon, bonuts, hummingbird family reserve, cheese grits, and Alma's potatoes. 

We started with bonuts, which were their biscuit donuts served with lemon mascarpone and blueberry compote. Ehhh...these didn't hit the spot for us. Although sugar was on them, they were not sweet. Hoping for better with the biscuit that was topped with similar ingredients used in hummingbird cake, we dug in to our other starter. The biscuit was covered with a pineapple and banana jam, along with cream cheese frosting and pecans. The description was definitely better than the taste. I think the drop biscuit just didn't work for this. Their sweet biscuit may have worked better.

The East Nasty was a biscuit topped with fried chicken, aged cheddar, and sausage gravy. The portion was huge so I was glad that I'd planned to share it. It was presented with the advertised ingredients but the gravy was just smothering the biscuit and chicken, making it very difficult to taste any of the components of the dish other than the gravy. The person who got the biscuit and gravy had a very similar issue. Had I known that they were so heavy handed on the gravy at this location, I would've asked for it on the side.

The small parts of the chicken that were peeking out from the gravy of the East Nasty had such thick fried skin, almost like tempura battering. I ended up with a half plate of skin that I removed to try to taste the chicken. I was also disappointed with the potatoes which needed some salt and pepper or some type of seasoning.

This meal was a miss for me until I tried the bacon that was sweet and sprinkled with a little pepper. I washed it down with the fruit tea. You can't go wrong with southern sweet tea and they added lemon, pineapple, and orange juice, which made it even better.

My advice is to go to the original location in The Gulch. I found the food to be better there and the chicken and biscuit wasn't so overwhelmed by the gravy.

I remember when these apartments were horrid. 

Now they're kind of passable. I had to drop a friend off here after she stayed the weekend with me. Gated entry and exits keep this from being the suitcase city of old.  (and yes, way back when, I used to .. well not live here exactly, but spend a LOT of time with my then boyfriend, now ex husband - ahh good ole college days..AHEM)

They've done a lot to clean up the place, given it a complete over haul, even though the apartments still look like boxes on the inside.

I had been asked to accompany my boyfriend and his company with free passes to the Dinner/Jazz Cruise. I had heard the history of the Natchez before, definitely worth learning about whether you're a tourist or a local.  

I was pleasantly surprised by how good the buffet was, and our server was extremely sweet. The dining room has this sepia-toned feel to it, with the band playing at the far end away from the diners. The band, Dukes of Dixieland, were seriously jamming so Robert and I took a spin on the empty dance floor. Though our dance fever didn't seem to be contagious, we received an applause at the end of the set. I don't suggest dancing RIGHT after you eat, but definitely get out on the floor. 

There are a few levels that you can visit, and the Engine Room on the bottom floor is pretty cool, though I have a fear of touching what I'm not supposed to and crashing the boat. 

There is an air of romanticism to leaning over the side of the boat while watching mammoth shadows of barges pass by in the night ever so closely. Though the ride stretches a little long, the view of the city on the way back is magical and definitely worth a few snap shots. Something to do at least once or twice as a local with friends or a loved one to reconnect with the Mighty. :)

Romantic and scenic gondola ride through the waterways of City Park.

Seeing the park's buildings, bridges and greenways from the water provides an advantageous viewpoint.  As much as we desired to sit back and soak it all in for the memories and enjoy being together, we did take a few pictures.  We couldn't resist.

Robert provided an excellent experience from beginning to end.  There was cheese and crackers for us to nibble and he provided an umbrella for sun shade.  He will provide wine glasses and a corkscrew if you bring a bottle of champagne or prosecco.  His choice of music was perfect.  Hearing Andrea Bocelli's voice swell over the water in this setting was magical.

Advance reservations are required.  The online reservation system is quick and easy.  

Tip:  Try to make a reservation during a cooler period of the day.

Final Assessment:  Robert is friendly and professional.  The gondola ride was fun, romantic and will be a great memory from our vacation for years to come.  5 Stars

Cafe on the Square has good food, but may be a little expensive for lunch.

Located next to Lafayette Square, it is easy to miss this restaurant. In fact, I passed it hundreds of times and never noticed it. 

The dining area is nice. The walls are decorated with local art which is all for sale. Service was very prompt, and friendly throughout the meal, but the prices seemed a bit high for CBD lunch.

I started with the soup special which was corn and crab bisque. It was excellent. While not loaded with a huge amount of crabmeat, the soup was very rich and flavorful. It was fairly priced at $5 for a cup.

I ordered a burger as an entree with grilled onions and cheese. The burger alone was $11, and each additional item added another $1. The burger was perfectly cooked and very good, but $13 seems a bit high for a cheeseburger. The side of fries appeared to be hand cut and were very good. 

The total bill was close to $45 for two people with the tip and no alcohol.

Stopped here for lunch. It wasn't busy at all, so our food was made very quickly. 

This location is not at all like the other location I've visited in Tampa, but it is quite nice. The food came out hot and fresh.

An interesting tour of New Orleans with a great guide. We did the afternoon tour of four neighborhoods, a cemetery, and a distillery. 

We booked through one of the tourist spots in the French Quarter. The woman there was able to give us availability, book, and give us meet up information. Since our tour was on a holiday and the parade closed many downtown roads our meet up spot was an arbitrary intersection. Normally the bus can pick up and drop off at hotels. The tour was about two and a half hours with a stop for bathroom breaks in the middle.

The driving portion of the tour was great, especially since it was very cold the day we did our tour. Our guide was Rene and he gave us city information the entire time we were driving around the city. Some of the information was historical and some was interest like pointing out homes of famous residents. He kept the tour interesting.

The cemetery portion of the tour was interesting as well. It seems odd to go to a cemetery, but it is an important part of learning about the city. We were given about 10 minutes to walk around after Rene gave us information about the cemetery. 

The last part of the tour was a stop at Seven Three Distillery. The distillery gave us a quick tour of the facility as well as a taste of their vodka or gin which in total lasted about 30 minutes. It was a nice distillery and a nice enough tour, but it didn't seem to fit in with the rest of the tour. It would definitely be fun as part of a separate drinking themed tour. Maybe a new tour option idea that goes to local distilleries and breweries? 

Overall, a great way to see and learn about the city on a day too old to walk!

We don't buy a lot at Whole Foods but if we are looking for something special or hard to find this is our go to place.  On this particular Saturday we had decided to stop in and wander a bit since this is something we really haven't done in the past.

We had never realized that they have a tap room at the front of the store!  We made our way back to the bakery area and the breads looked so delicious!  The bakery employee was assisting another customer and we heard her ask to have the bread sliced.  We thought that sounded like a great idea and decided on the wheat bread - we asked to have it sliced a bit thicker too, which he has happy to do.  Needless to say we are going to have some yummy sandwiches this week at work :)

We also appreciate that because Whole Foods is now owned by Amazon, sale items are an extra 10% off when you are an Amazon Prime member!  *We did learn that the 10% off does not include alcohol.

Overall the store is beautiful and fun to look around.

This is my local movie theater so I come here frequently. They have been upgrading the theaters, so they do have IMAX and Dolby Theaters with reclining seat for an up-charge. Tons of parking, but it does get busy here so I hope you like walking.

One of my favorite things about this location is that there is a TGIF in the center, which makes it perfect for a drink and movie. This location has $5 showings on Tuesday and matinees for under $6. If you like coke products they have 6 large coke product dispensing machines, which is pretty awesome... I usually get the cherry Vanilla Coke.

I was excited to find a highly rated Mexican restaurant in Tucson near my hotel.  El Charro has been in business since 1922 so they must be doing something right.  

I sat at the bar and ordered a margarita while I perused the menu.  Carne seca looked interesting.  I've read about it but never tried it.  It's sun dried beef that's then shredded and cooked with onions, peppers and tomatoes; something like jerky reconstituted for tacos.  I have a rule for Mexican restaurants though which is "I will judge you by your chile relleno."  What to do?  No worries.  I found a combo with both and made my request.

Chips and salsa were fine, with a nice little kick.  When my food arrived I was puzzled.  It was the carne seca plate and not the combo I ordered.  Okay, I'll take that, rather than send it back and wait.  My server apologized and comp'd the relleno I had been expecting.  She handled the mixup perfectly well.  

Carne seca was described as a flavor explosion.  I definitely sensed a little bit of a pop.  It was flavorful and good in tacos.

My chile relleno was just okay.  Lots of cheese, not much of the crisp exterior I usually expect.  Red sauce was good.

House margaritas; Pretty light.  No buzz.  No Bueno.  

Overall, pretty good but I was disappointed with the margarita and relleno.

BRUNCH.

Kind of overpriced and the waiter was pretty condescending, but you cant beat the location, view and food.

The bread alone is worth going for. 

Brunch cocktails. MM.

Got the smoked salmon terrine and it was DELISH.

They get really busy around brunch time and sometimes don't take reservations, but if you go later (2pm brunchish) you won't have to wait as long.

I am so pleased to have found a spot to get my dog groomed, and the staff at Woof Gang was so pleasant and friendly with my dog and with me that I will definitely come back.

I drive by Woof Gang all the time, so of course I looked this place up on Yelp and was pleasantly surprised to find it has such a high rating!

I called ahead of time to book an appointment for my goldendoodle, who has to have extra special time and care when getting groomed due to his coat being more susceptible to mats. I was running a little late and made sure to call Woof Gang, and they said it would be no problem at all.

When we arrived, my dog was very overjoyed and everyone was very welcoming and friendly. He went straight to the groomer and I could already tell he was going to have a great time. The groomer began shaving my dog down (since that's how I prefer him to be cut) and she was very gentle and sweet with him. I was even able to watch him get groomed and he looked very relaxed and happy.

Around two hours later, I received a call that my dog was ready to be picked up. I could see he was having the time of his life with the other dogs and was just really happy, and his hair looked clean and wonderful.

One of the girls there even gave us a little goodie bag of their specialty treats to take home.

Really friendly staff, and they did a great job. I'll definitely be coming back to get my dog groomed and to buy some of their special treats!

My husband and I went to The Green Pheasant for dinner before attending the symphony this past Saturday, and we were both impressed! 

We had a reservation and were seated in the upstairs area of the restaurant after we walked in. Our waitress was LOVELY. She walked us through pretty much the whole menu as well as explaining some of the drink options as well. 

I started with a sake that the restaurant had on tap, which was wonderful. my husband tried one of their cocktails and then stuck with his favorite Manhattan after that. 

We started with the okonomiyaki (a Japanese pancake, at Green Pheasant made with ham, bacon, scallops, potatoes, and various traditional okonomi toppings). It was good, but not my favorite thing we ate. Next we tried the shumai (at Green Pheasant, made with lobster and spot prawn - and served with clover ponzu) - these were okay, but definitely my least favorite thing we ordered (they had a slightly strange flavor to me, but that may be because I'm so used to shumai made with shrimp only). 

Next we had the spicy crab noodles (with crab butter, sweet red crab, and tobanjan), which were very good. Lots of crab on the dish, and it was just the right amount of heat! 

But the Ikinari steak was my favorite of the appetizers or entrees we ordered!
