The steak was American skirt steak with corn and onion and miso brown butter and j sauce, served in a hot hot hot sizzle plate like is traditional at the Japanese steak restaurant chain Ikinari (picture a fajita platter at a Tex Mex restaurant). The steak was great (perfectly cooked); the corn and onions were charred where they had touched the hot sizzle plate; and the miso brown butter was just the right richness for the steak. I'd come back to Green Pheasant just to eat this again. A great dish.

But we didn't stop there. We ordered two of the desserts as well. I ordered the ginger creme brulee which was SENSATIONAL (I might be back at Green Pheasant again soon - I want to sit at the bar, order some sake or shochu, and eat the Ikinari steak and the ginger creme brulee. Quite simply one of the best desserts I've had recently. The ginger flavor was amazing, and the creme brulee was so smooth. I LOVED IT. My husband has about 10x the sweet tooth I do and he ordered the tempura fried slice of chocolate cake. I tried a teeny tiny bite, and it's just WAAAAAAY too rich and sweet for me, but he enjoyed it (definitely for people who love sweet, rich desserts only). 

We had a couple more drinks (including a shochu cocktail that was DELICIOUS). The service was excellent, and the restaurant pretty nice (I do think sitting downstairs is probably nicer, because upstairs is pretty sparse compared to the decor on the main level). We thoroughly enjoyed our meal. I think we'll be back.
I love Target.  That said I actually prefer the Metairie location.  I think the westbank store might be larger, but I find it's layout confusing.

I have a problem. I am a poor student, but I love fine dining. It's an issue that consumes my soul and is constantly hanging over my head, and gives me great unrest. But I find ways around it, and Sbraga's been on my to do list for a while, so I made it happen. I was saving my $50 gift certificate from Opentable (after months of making reservations for everything, finally, a payoff!) for a long time, and after careful consideration, decided on Sbraga for my birthday dinner (with a 9:00 reservation on a Monday that would get me another 1000 points, obviously).

I had extremely high expectations... and they were exceeded, starting with the birthday card from Chef Sbraga that graced my table upon my arrival. The service was impeccable and everything we ate was incredible (I'll get to that later).

I wasn't going to review Sbraga, but I recently revisited (free dinner courtesy of Opentable...it pays to read emails!) and realized I just can't stop talking about it or recommending it to people, so I should weigh in on the ole Yelp.

THE FOOD. 
OMG the food. Here are the highlights from my two visits.

--The Foie Gras Soup. 
Perfect combination of richness and spice, and just awesome. I still think about this. I don't care if you don't like foie gras, never had it, or are iffy about. You should order this, and you will like it. I promise. 

--Pork Belly in Chili Oil
Very thinly sliced, but great combination of flavors and not too spicy at all.

--Gem lettuce...with other stuff.
Basically a deconstructed Caesar salad. The red peppery looking things were really the highlight. Very good.

--Steak tartar 
Also awesome, can't remember specific details.

--Octopus in Piri Piri sauce
Not as spicy as other Yelpers led me to believe, so fear not; also excellent.

--Papardelle was really good too.

--The Lamb was very good but a bit salty for my taste.

-- "Key Lime Pie"-kind of a deconstructed delicious take on the classic, and the Pistachio Bread Pudding with Olive Oil Ice cream (super interesting flavor, and my roomate who hates normally ice cream loved it!) Not a huge dessert person, but places like Sbraga change me...

--Special shoutout to the popovers. I would like for them to pop over to me anytime.

--Also had a very interesting spicy cocktail last night involving jalapenos. Very odd but very interesting. The Peach Cobbler inspired cocktail was also great, but a bit too sweet for me.

If you're trying to impress a food snob date/parent/sibling/friend/client/boss, have a special occasion coming up, or $50 4 course meals are your thang, by all means run to Sbraga now, and be ready to be amazed. 

HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

Give me a bottle of red wine and a backyard, throw in some good company and/or good music and I really can't really be much happier. Hello, Bacchanal!

Oh, but there's more! See, what you're doing is buying the bottle at the price you'd get it at the wine shop (essentially because you *are* at a wine shop), so there's no bar/lounge mark up, then hitting up their glorious back garden space, filled with trees, fairy lights and all kinds of magic. And wait... there's more! They have a fridge with cheese wedges, and you pick one or more out, bring it up to the counter to pay and within minutes, they'll whisk a huge cheese plate to your table that's overloaded with toast, some fruit and nuts. 

In the days of super lounges and other such nonsense when you're paying high covers and then $$ drinks as well, it's kind of hard to believe Bacchanal can be so generous. Maybe it's due to the city of New Orleans honoring the spirit of Bacchus on a regular basis? The god is giving back...

Kinda makes me want to move in... or next door or even upstairs. I won't complain about the live music, either...

Walking around our first night in town on a Wednesday we decided to check this place out, for a Wednesday it was pretty packed. 
Multi level below they offer live entertainment, cool looking bar area. we made our way upstairs after a few. 
Top level they have a DJ playing a decent mix of music good variety, big open space & roof top area. 
Drinks, first tried the Fat bottom beer, good beer I stuck to this, later had some Fireball shots & my company later tried the My kind of party punch, not terrible but I thought it was too sweet. 
Upstairs is a bit of hot mess, floors are super sticky & bathrooms are a mess (the dirtiest of all that I noticed). 
Service could be better bartenders did not really pay attention to u, we had to keep waving them down to get drinks.  
I gave it the 4 stars because of the roof top area & the fact that they have a DJ playing regular music, It's good to have other options of music & not be forced to listen to just country breaks up your night much better.

Staying at the hyatt regency. My boss and I stopped by with one other coworker to grab some food. Let me just say the service is extremely slow. I ordered a grilled chicken salad, he ordered seared tuna on seaweed, a spicy roll, and my coworker a steak wrap with homemade chips. So we are all waiting for our food and my stomach is growling. It finally came and the presentation of my salad was bland. The seared tuna salad and roll was beautifully displayed in a pretty bowl and platter. He enjoyed the food as well, but said it was a bit spicy after he had informed the waiter not to make it hot. The steak wrap was ok. He stated the homemade chips were extremely salty. So overall it was nothing special

Considering we were only heading up to Reno for some golf and gambling over the July 4th weekend, stumbling into the Biggest Little City Wing Fest was a welcome surprise!  I'd been to the Rib Fest over at the Nugget about five years ago and had an awesome time, so I was both excited and hopeful that the Wing Fest would be just as good.  After all, who wouldn't be excited about the prospect of eating copious amounts of delicious wings??

Although it's not as large as its meatier, more well known cousin, Wing Fest isn't exactly small either.  Stretching through the heart of downtown Reno (from Circus Circus to Harrah's, as well as onto some of the cross streets off N. Virginia), the festival featured nearly a dozen wing stands, along with a mix of other eateries, as well as a number of vendors selling various merchandise and crafts.  Also, like Rib Fest, it's free to enter; you just pay for what you want to eat/drink/buy.

While there were also a couple of areas for people to take in different musical acts, we didn't really explore much beyond the different wing contestants.  Or at least, tried to.  From hot to buffalo to sweet & spicy, a wide range of styles and flavors were accounted for.  However, with long, glacially slow lines at nearly every stand, trying one or two types of wings was challenging enough, let alone all of them.  Fortunately, my buddy was able to snag some wings from a stand with a short line at a quiet edge of the festival.  Outside of that one basket we shared though, we gave up on waiting to try any others (too hungry to wait!).

(For the record, the wings we had were deep fried and lathered with a sweet, fruity glaze that packed a sharp punch of heat.  Interesting flavor combination, but pretty overcooked.)

Now, to be fair, the day we were there definitely wasn't a normal one, given the shooting that happened before we arrived (there was an area still cordoned off with police tape).  When we passed through the festival the night before, it was A LOT easier to maneuver around.  Granted, we were also there a little later, when they were about done for the night (most of the vendors were already closing up), but still, there were far fewer people to weave through.

Although I'd be lying if I said the Wing Fest was even half as awesome as the Rib Fest was, I wouldn't rule out possibly coming back, as the potential is there for a better experience in the future.  Since they've only been around for a few years, perhaps they're still working out the kinks (lack of organized lines, the narrow vendor layout).  At the very least, I'd like to think (hope?) that a shooting won't happen again.  Plus, maybe an entrant will add some kick ass Korean fried chicken wings to the lineup!

For now, TWO AND A HALF STARS rounded up.

What a phenomenal resort.  My Joel room was spacious with a large bathroom with shower and jacuzzi tub.  Shower had two water heads.
Decor of whole premises was tastefully done.  The casino floor was separate from restaurants so you did not have to walk in casino to eat.  Checkin was great by using kiosk that printed your room key.  View from my room was spectacular.  Only had a regular room and it was great . For $50 more per night could have received a 550 square foot room.
Will return!

[931]

6/10/2019

This Misconduct Tavern is located right in the heart of Center City Philadelphia.  

I saw this place featured on FYI Philly so I had to try it 

My burger was ok and my fries were very skinny (not the pictures I saw on yelp)

My friend enjoyed his burger. 

My son enjoyed his chicken 

They have a nice bar area which looks like it can be a nice happy hour place. 

Our waitress was really nice 

I'm not a fan of the burger or fries.  I would come back if someone else was coming but prob not on my own.

Such a fun spot and worth the door fee for music but OMG we didn't stay longer than 30min because it was SO cold in there!!! 
Awesome band and atmosphere.

I am finding that my reviews are getting more selective as I am getting tired of writing them. ha! But this was a nice large fuel center with an excellent car wash, so what the heck I will give them a boost.

Issue going on in the area is construction, so be aware of this. However, don't let it stop you from pulling in as the location is on a corner with as light to pull out and avoid current construction.

No issues at the pump and it generated a paper receipt upon request which you cannot always take for granted. Pumps were clean and the trash cans not over flowing. Fuel prices were on the lower end too.

The car wash was one of the better things about Rally. They offered four different levels and since I had bugs embedded in my bumper guess what I went for. So the ultimate it was and it did not get 100% off as I thought. But the fact it got 80% off was impressive, I am talking 800 miles of bugs from Virginia to Florida.

I assume this is a chain fuel joint and unsure if they are all as good. I cannot comment on the inside convenience area since I did not go in.

I was really pleasantly surprised by The Pint Room. After biking from downtown to Carmel, the tasty beers on tap and a la carte side dishes really hit the spot. Located along the main street in downtown Carmel Arts & Design District, The Pint Room boasts plentiful indoor/outdoor/bar/hightop/you name it seating. We kicked things off by enjoying $2-$4 small pours from their enormous tap list. Our group was able to enjoy pineapple cider, chile cocoa stout, IPAs, bourbon barrel, and so on. For those of us who 1.) love to sample a little of this and a little of that; 2.) are not hard core beer drinkers - the small pours are PERFECT! I could sit there for hours working my way down the menu. Rumor has it they're great at rotating the offerings so regulars can always find something new. Customer service during our visit was a-okay during our visit and I was happy to see a diverse audience of patrons. 

Beyond the drinks, I ordered a side of the chili topped with onion, cheese and sour cream along with a small side salad. It was nice to have some light-ish options to pair with the beers at affordable prices. If you find yourself along the Monon or strolling through the Arts & Design District, pop in The Pint Room.

Oh, how I love my Tria. There is little else I love in the world more than tasting different, unique wines. Tria affords a wonderful venue for this activity, and has a pretty romantic, trendy vibe. My man and I enjoyed a lovely evening here recently working out way down the wine list and sampling some delicious cheeses as well.  And possibly since everyone looks better in candlelight and after a few glasses of wine, we had a wonderful night and really enjoyed each other's company. 
The waitresses are always sweet, knowledgable, and willing to impart their well-informed suggestions. There's nothing not to love here my friends!

Their sushi's marginally better than what you'd get in a supermarket.

I ordered two rolls: a Philadelphia roll ($6; which I should know better than to order, even as comic relief) - and a spicy tuna roll (7), which wasn't anything worth writing home about. Presentation, flavor, composition, all disappointing, especially since my friends have been hyping this spot up for some time.

On the bright side, my tea was hot and perky, my miso soup was savory, and parking was easy. The decor's pretty trendy, and I wouldn't be opposed to bringing a date here.

But entrees will cost you - they've got tom yum soup on the menu[1] for *$7*, and shrimp pad thai for *$18*. I guess we're not THAT far from the Main Line, but really? Thank goodness they're a BYOB, at least.

[1] FYI The menu is more a fusion of dishes, not of cuisines. You're not going to get drunken noodles with fish sauce and a side of kimchi. Not that you'd want that. Right?

I have to go against the grain here.  The staff was super friendly and the restaurant was nice and clean (new).

Really gotta say I would give staff five stars.  Throughly described the menu and some newer options I haven't tried that this establishment offers.  I've had pok√´ on many occasions. I typically know what I like.  I enjoyed that they were fairly generous with their proteins but I didn't like either I tried. I had octopus which was super tough and the spicy salmon was really, really fishy.  I didn't even eat it and pushed it aside.  With that being said the sides and others were delicious.  I loved the pickled onions and jalapenos.  The sauces were quite creamy and could probably back off a bit on the mayonnaise.  

I would give it another shot if in the area, just would pick different proteins.

I stopped by Brentwood Cleaners recently to drop off some fall/winter clothes that had just come out of winter storage. During COVID, they're operating as a drive thru only, which was actually really convenient and fast. Their prices were reasonable, and my clothes were perfectly clean when I picked them up. Everyone was very nice too! Definitely very satisfied with the dry cleaning services I received here!

Yummy Yummy Yummy Yummy Yummy Yummy all six treats I got were gluten free and delicious. I was so happy to find this place. I can't have gluten but I love bread and cake...a lot. I have never been so excited to be able to eat monkey bread. I used to eat it as a kid and then I found out I can't and it was like my world collapsed around me. This place is amazing! My husband even bought a few things for himself and he enjoyed them (he doesn't generally like gluten free). I highly recommend!!!

I'm not a vegan but as a food lover, I found my place at Charlie was a Sinner. I think the only sin about my experience was that I didn't sample more of the small plates! 

Hearing rave reviews, my friend and I decided to check out Charlie was a Sinner for dinner. Based on reviews I read, it looked like the happy hour menu was served at the tables. Please be advised that it's only available at the bar and lounge areas. I was a little disappointed to not be able to receive happy hour pricing on the food; however the items on special weren't to-try list anyways, so it worked out for the best. 

The first few minutes of my visit were spent at the bar waiting for my friend to arrive, so I was able to enjoy the Troublemaker beverage as part of happy hour. The Troublemaker was made up of titos, dolin sweet, cucumber, strawberry and club soda. It was mixed very well and I couldn't taste any of the alcohol. It was refreshing almost in a health juice type of way. It was enjoyable but to be honest, I would not have wanted to pay full price for another one. I made the switch to the Stoudts, Fourplay IPA. As an IPA girlie, I was delighted that it was on draft and for only $5. 

So my friend and I decided to order a few small plates. Still a bit hungry we ordered an additional small plate and finally a dessert. Each one was enjoyable in a different way and I'll talk about them in order of favorite to least favorite:


*Spiced Cauliflower: Would have it been wrong to just order 5 plates of this? Omg, wow. It was packed with flavor and good to the last bite. This might be my first lovefest over a faux meat but the royal trumpet steak was out of this world. It was flavorable and had a great texture/consistency. 

*Fava Beans & Gnocci: The dish was made up of pine nuts and had a very pesto like flavor as a result. The gnocchi was light and fluffy. Very, very enjoyable. 

*Charlie's Chocolate Cake: It reminded me of a flourless cake and was packed with chocolate in every bite. The raspberry sorbet was light, refreshing and had pieces of actual fruit. 

*Bucatini & Meatballs: While I loved the meatball, there were only three on the dish. I absolutely loved the one and a half I tried but I would have liked to see more or a large meatball dish. They were a bit spicy, very well textured and overall had a great flavor. The bucatini was just a little bland and I didn't think it was anything special.

*Tofu & Bean Sausage: If you blind folded me and told me I was eating sausage, I would have believed you. It was good from the standpoint that it tasted like meat however simply put, it just tasted like a standard sausage. The parsnip mash was fine but a little too mashed for me, and the pesto was faint.  

*Broccoli Rabe: This was the first dish we picked but sadly my least favorite. The broccoli was tough and a challenge to separate and cut. It was prepared with garlic and chili but it wasn't super flavorable to me. I'd pass on this one in the future.


All and all, to have absolutely loved three of the dishes (and one component of another) is a win in my book. 

You can add service and atmosphere as a reason to visit. The dining room was trendy and dark, depending on the brightness level of the projection screen. The service was attentive and professional. Our dishes were served as they became available which paced out our experience nicely. 

I'm not adopting a vegan lifestyle anytime soon, but I can certainly count on Charlie Was a Sinner for an overall good restaurant experience.

So happy to discover a great, dog-friendly restaurant in Indy. My mom and I came a few weeks ago for brunch and shared the deep dish strata and a slice of macademia nut berry tart. Both were excellent, as was the iced coffee I ordered. The service was very friendly, although there was a bit of a wait for the food. The lovely outdoor patio has a lot of shade and the staff doted on my pup and brought her a bowl of water. I will definitely be back.

I came in to try to exchange some slippers that I got for Christmas that were the wrong size. The selection of slippers was almost non existent! I really needed new slippers so I really did not look at anything else. 

When I went to return them since they had been bought with a charge card I had to either take a store credit or put it on my card. I would have rather had cash but oh well.

The employees that I dealt with were nice and the store was clean. This store has always felt like a thrift store to me.

The New Orleans Jazz National Historic Park is a unique place. This park is run by National Park Service. I definite like the ranger position here. They are located in the big easy and the work is much easy - no forest fire to worry, big animal attack tourist. The park has ranger program free tour around the French Quarter to the Old US Mint. Now I think more of it, I like the ranger assignment here. May be I should be apply for the special language tour guide. 

The park hosts the indoor and outdoor concert. Some concert in the Historic Park, some in the Old Mint, Some in the French Market. Today they have listed two concerts, one in the Historic Park and One in the Old Mint. We have gone to the Historic Park since our time has conflict with the parade for the other concert. 

The historic park is hosting a Cajun children Jazz concert. The performer is Johnette Downing. She is author for the children book, children jazz song, and performer of children jazz. It was rewarding that the song actually from food of the children eat in a week. Song like Monday red bean, Tuesday Po-Boys, Wednesday Gumbo, Thursday Jambalaya, Friday Cat Fish, Saturday Crawfish and Sunday Beignet. She also has song like Mississippi River, Cajun Dance Bonjour, Chef Creole, and Crawfish Song. It makes you think about Louisiana Cuisine.

Please check at the park for the schedule of the day with variety of free concert and location.

I was struggling with what was going to be review #1500. Would I go try a new place? Would I seek out something unique and fun to celebrate? I contemplated it. But I decided I'd rather review Wat Mongkolratanaram, a Buddhist temple in Tampa that offers a lovely Thai market on Sunday mornings. It's not something you come across too often.

I had been looking for cool things to do in Tampa, which are hard to come by, as I left the city somewhat indifferent about it. Luckily, before I left, I had found out about this place on the Tampa talk threads. From what I can tell, you need a car to get here.

I agree with much of what has been said: come here early (parking is rough and food runs out), bring plenty of cash, and plan to grab some small items to eat while you stand in line for the noodle soup. I missed out on the noodle soup because of poor planning. Do not let this happen to you. Also, come with people that like to eat and understand waiting in line for food.

Food wise, we tried various spring rolls and dumplings, beef satay, pumpkin curry, and chicken basil. Everything was great, and I'm fairly obsessed with the spring rolls. I also tried the papaya salad, and that was the only thing I did not really care for, and normally, I love it.

The grounds are idyllic, and the temple is gorgeous. There's really no other way to describe it. Ideally, when I return, I'll return alone, and be able to stay for services, which all are welcome to join. 

As a visitor to the area, I definitely recommend finding a way to get here. It was a highlight of my trip.

Fantastic. For me, this was a destination dinner and well worth the wait. I came in and sat at the bar with two others. We all ordered various sliders on a recommendation from someone who had been there before. Let me just say, the sliders, especially the filet ones, are fantastic and you must try them. The filet sliders are cooked to your preferred temp and will be better than any sliders you've ever had. 
I also sampled the crispy chicken sliders, and while they were quite good, they couldn't compare to the filet ones. 

Also, request the bread prior to your meal. It is delicious and worth every single calorie when dipped in their homemade butter. I want to come back and try more, maybe next time I'm in Indy.

I was traveling through the area for business and had some time before my appointment and decided to grab some breakfast and thought this little caf√© looked interesting. It's seems to be a local's favorite judging from the interaction between the staff and the few tables that had customers seated. The atmosphere is laid back and the restaurant was very clean and organized, I was greeted and told I could sit anywhere I liked. The staff here is very friendly and the service attentive, I was given a menu after taking a seat and my server returned immediately ready to take my drink and breakfast order.

My breakfast arrived after only a few minutes and looking at my plate it appeared to be just okay, the ham looked a little disappointing and after taking a few bites I decided to focus on the rest of the meal. I don't feel there is anything terrible here except I really didn't care for the ham, the rest of the food was just average at best. I don't know if I would go out of my way to stop in again but with the options in the immediate area pretty limited I might give them another opportunity if I'm in the area.

Such fond memories of coming here back in the 90s. My dad would bring my brother and I here almost every Friday night. Their pizza is pretty kick-ass. Although I don't have a concrete favorite pizza place in South Jersey, they are definitely within the top 3. I would definitely recommend getting the sausage pie! Their sandwiches are also very good and their fries are always blazing hot! Oh and how can I forget their wings? I'm always a little skeptical getting wings from a pizza place, but the King's wings share the throne! We don't go to King as much as we used to, but we do order take-out every now and then. For some reason, it always tastes MUCH better when you eat it there. KIng of Pizza truly does live up to its name.

I was never a fan of the Cheesecake Factory so I was a bit hesitant to try this place, but I'm so glad I did! I've been here numerous times and the service has always been wonderful! Everyone I've encountered have friendly and welcoming faces that make it coming here an enjoyable experience. The kitchen can be seen through some select seats and the cooks taste test each entree before they deliver it, which I've never seen any other restaurant do before. That just shows how much they care about their customers and how they strive for perfection. One time, I ordered a side of marinara sauce and not only did our waitress notify us that it was on being warmed up, but a few minutes later another cook from the back came to tell us that he's warming it up and it will be out shortly. So kind! 

Their food is also delicious. I'm a vegetarian so I typically have limited options at restaurants, but they have a good variety. Their pasta was one of the best pastas I've ever had. The pizza is a must because their bread is just so fresh and tasty! Same goes for the hummus, very filling for an appetizer! They also have an array from desserts to choose from, some of which they make especially for you! If you're thinking about getting dessert, check out the desserts page when you're ordering because some of them need up to 45 minutes to make. Overall, everything I had was very fresh and appetizing. Every time I'm in Cherry Hill I have to stop by here, even came here with my family for graduation dinner and they loved it as well!

I've been to Mojito Cuba Caribe twice, both times under different ownership. The first time was under a funny dude name Mickey. He was great and had wonderful stories to tell. The food then is a different story. Portions were a tad bit small for the prices they charged. I came back last week with family and under the new owners, the food has improved drastically in my opinion.

We started off with some mango mojitos and beers. They have a few select IPA's on special and their mango mojitos were amazing. We ordered a sizzling grilled chicken fajita and Pan de Lechon which consist of roast pork, mojo cilantro mayonnaise and grilled onions on pressed Cuban bread. The roast pork sandwich was very juicy and tender. The cilantro mayonnaise along with the onions went really well on that toasty Cuban bread. As for the fajitas, they sure came out sizzling. Many other patrons ordered it because it smelled so good whenever the waiter passed by with it. It was really worth it. Served with grilled onions, bell peppers, rice and beans, guacamole, sour cream and warm tortillas. It was very filling and one of these best things to eat in all of Main Street in New Hope.

Verdict - Mojito Cuba Caribe is a nice cozy fancy little joint. There's outdoor seating and the service here does not disappoint. I miss the Mick but the food under the current owners is way better than before. Everything is speedier and tastier. Job well done!

This is not the fanciest or most authentic Italian but the patio more than makes up for the average food. With a water fountain, twinkling hanging lights, draped plants, and children laughing and playing, it's very romantic and charming. Feels a little bit like being in someone's backyard for a fabulous dinner party. I think it's only worth coming here for the garlic bread and lasagna, which is a large enough portion that I've never seen anyone finish it. Just classic, homey, rich, red-sauced food.

This might just be the saddest liquor store I have entered to date.

No baskets were in sight. This left the following options: Either go back outside and grab a cart, or cling on to your items and hope they don't drop. Because that would be costly and unfortunate.

Beyond the cart/basket situation, Maro Brothers' (AKA: the old Joe Canals) manages to have fairly terrible selection. You'll walk in to florescent lights and wines hanging out in carts rather than on shelves. I didn't bother to browse the wine.

I headed over to the beer section, and they were severely lacking in the craft department. But hey, if you're looking for a case of Rolling Rock, this is your place!

Just make sure you have ID on you and ready to present for analysis. I've never seen one store display SO many signs about the fact that you're going to get carded. Like, cool, congrats, you're following the law? But how about investing in something other than signs?

Like.. say, baskets?

CHEAPER THAN BK: for much fresher, higher quality food!
CLEAN: large dining room and maintained bathrooms;
GREAT QUALITY: even ordering the splittable double meal it's just $11.

Of the three new hamburger places that have opened uptown (Charcoal, Company Burger and Smash Burger) this is by far my favorite.  Yeah I know, its a chain and favoring it is shuddersome, but I think its the best value for the money.  Smash Burger has generous portions, a nice large dining room, and a very friendly staff.  In fact I was finishing a long run one day and stopped in somewhat sweaty.  The chatty cashier was so welcoming she even gave me a bottled water!  My one mistake was ordering the double smash, it was huge so I took half of it home.  I got the spicy Baja burger with a flavorful chipotle mayonaise, a fountain drink (yep! free refils) and freshly battered haystack onions rings: $11!

So we originally hired TKO DJs for our wedding because the DJ was an old friend of my husband... but then he up and got another job in another city and that was that.  That obviously doesn't affect the rating of TKO, but honestly, I was not hugely impressed by Lance, the DJ who replaced our original guy.  He was very nice and kind enough to let my neurotic self give him a detailed list of what we wanted played--accompanied by a CD of songs we didn't think they'd have... and I know we checked the "NOT over-the-top DJ" box when selecting what type of DJ we were interested in, but a *little* personality wouldn't have killed the guy.  

So the wedding reception had good music, but I didn't think the sound quality was that great--this could have been an acoustics problem with our venue and not the blame of TKO, but Lance could've turned up the volume a bit.  And been sort of energetic.  Maybe smiled a little...  Yeah, he was kind of a dud.

Three stars.  Maybe 3.5 because they had to contend with a semi-neurotic bride and *that* they did with finesse...

One of my favorite meals in New Orleans so far!

Here's what we had:

Braised Shrimp/Calabrian chili butter- This was messy but had so much flavor and a hint of spice.

Smoked tuna tartar- Another great dish. The fish was so soft it almost melts in your mouth. The avocado creme was smooth and went well with the fish. 

Goat curry/sweet potato gnocchi/cashews- Wow. This dish had a lot of stuff going on. We asked for the spice level to be kicked up a bit and it was so good! The goat was so tender it was falling apart. The cashews added a nice crunch. I liked the contrast in texture.

Banana rum zeppole?- not sure about the name but M really loved this. The caramel sauce was amazing and the balls were stuffed with chocolate. 

Coconut Tres Leches- Yum! I loved the smooth layers of cake and the homemade whipped cream. 

Everything was amazing from the food to the drinks. Our server, Mario, was also very good. He had great recommendations. 

The only hiccup was when I ordered a mocktail and was served a regular cocktail. I took a sip and told M, "Wow! It's really good it tastes like a regular cocktail" and a few seconds later Mario came running to the table to take it away. Apparently the person who dropped it off was new.. Not really a good enough excuse for me for such a big mistake but what's done is done.

Overall a great dining experience. Will definitely be back.

After several visits to Santa Barbara, we finally made it around to visiting the mission. Not very accessible today due to the 12 0'Clock Mass, and the cemetery was closed to the public. The garden gate was also locked, so other then the mission artifacts and indoor displays, not really worth the $9.00 each we paid for the self guided tour. Probably my least favorite mission experience that have also included San Fernando, San Diego, San Juan Capistrano, San Luis Obispo, and Santa Ines. And no, we're not Catholic, just visitors of prominent landmarks.

This place makes me channel my inner Julia Stiles circa Save the Last Dance, wishing I was more Center Stage than awkward white girl koreshing ... and burning. Had to. 

WARNING: THEY HAVE MOVED! Just checked out their new studio for a free class yesterday  (located at 20th and Rittenhouse) and LOVED IT. Hated myself for being an uncoordinated mess, but whatevs.

I don't know that the new studio itself is that much more spacious (although the area to hang out in pre-class is, and there is now a small locker room) Then again the huge crowd that turned out for the free class probably did not help...

HIP HOP CLASSES
I've been to Sammy's beginner (intro $5 class-print the coupon off their site!) and intermediate (lol I know, but it was free) hip hop and he is amazing. He is a hilarious, fierce, fast dancing, fast talking, AWESOME teacher, and he will make you wish you were as cool as him and make you want to be a hip hop dancer. His classes are basically some warm ups, then he teaches you a routine, and then halves of the room alternate doing the routine. Everyone is very supportive and claps and doesn't give you death stares even if you suck and can't get the steps and are always in everyone's way because you are 5 beats behind.

CAVEATS: 
1. If you are not a dancer and just want a workout class, like me, this will be challenging, but you'll get a workout for sure.
2. The prices. They are high. $20 is steep if you are not a dancer.

Recommend for dancers, and to everyone who has $5 and could use a laugh/sweat/pick-me-up!

Great service, drinks were good and the food was good. I liked that there was $5 valet available and that there was indoor and outdoor seating available. We decided to sit outside with the pretty fountain. The guacamole was AMAZING, so tasty!! I'd go back just for that lol. The decor is cute and there's a nice ambiance. 

I loved the detail of giving you a worry doll at the end as well as churros, nice touch!

Every time we visit New Orleans this is our first place we go to for our Po-Boy fix! They have the absolute best Po-Boys out of most restaurants I've gone to that claim to be world's greatest! The french bread is fantastic and made fresh and the fries are top notch. You must try the frog legs and turtle soup if you've never done so before. However, if you plan to consume the frog legs/turtle soup make sure you don't bring along company that remind you of your own pet turtle "Squirtle" back at home or give you detailed pictures of how one might extract a perfect frog leg from the characters in The Princess and the Frog. Either way they are good! The restaurant is a hidden gem in the Convention Center district with plenty of roomy seating. I would have given this restaurant 5 stars but every time I come the waiters act like they don't want to serve you, are rude, and actually treat people like tourists. For once I would like to go in knowing that I'll have pleasant service.

'Crazy Tony' is the best & does designs!  They accept walk-ins, have many stations & pedicure massage chairs to accommodate.  Very clean, organized, comfortable atmosphere, tons of polish to choose from & they offer you a drink, even wine & mimosas.  Referred by a regular & they had many regulars.  Everyone was super friendly & work together like family. 

Tony did a beautiful design exactly as I envisioned my nails & better.  I highly recommend Love Nails as a person who has been going to the same manicurist in Vegas for a decade.  I will be back when I'm back in Tampa.

I've only been to Red's - erm, I mean Ed's - for bowling, but it was a mega-blast.

On a Friday night, the alleys are all lit up with neon and black lights for the ultimate nighttime bowling extravaganza experience. Prices were pretty reasonable, too, and staff members went through the line-up really quickly.

Our lane kept having problems. The computer shut our game down too early, and pins kept getting stuck. (Which, at least, allowed me to sneak in a few practice bowls!) The staff were very friendly and helped us get everything sorted out quickly. I would go back here again, but I hope I can explore the rest of Ed's next time, too!

3.5 Stars

A pretty cool music store with a great selection of used & new CDs, vinyl, and DVDs.  The workers there are very friendly and helpful.  I always feel like I can't go with something specific in mind to buy, because odds are they won't have it (Lumineers CD?).  Instead, I do better when I just randomly go through piles - that's when I have found a few gems.  

I'm sure they have a system, but pricing seems very random. I saw the same CD in the 3 for $5 rack and also in the main storage area for $3.99.  I also wish there was some kind of order (alphabetical, at least) to the endless sale CD shelves.  My back & eyes gave out long before I found CDs I had to have.  If you go, plan to spend some time!

The Chinese food here is nothing comparable to legitimate fare.. I ordered the bbq pork appetizer, stir fried asian green, and the fried tofu with spicy salt. Nothing there was prepared the way it should be but that wasn't too shocking to me because it is Tucson.. The bbq pork comes in a brown sauce which was strange to me because I was expecting just the meat with maybe some honey glaze. The vegetables were alright but slightly overcooked and therefore soggy.. and the fried tofu was inadequate as far as the amount of tofu goes, and barely had any flavor to it.. The best fried tofu with spicy salt by far is from San Francisco.. definitely not from Tucson haha.. Probably the only thing I did like from this place is the free crab puff appetizer I received for spending over $10-15 on takeout I forget which it was.. Anyway that's the only reason I would go back haha

JAMAICAN fast food! i hear D's used to be a truck but they're now a brick and mortar

my plate of oxtail to-GO was $12, a bit pricier than the jerk chicken that yelpers also seem to like, but i was happy with my choice
---oxtail plate: the meat=tender goodness! the plate comes with rice & beans, cabbage slaw, and a fried bread that had a subtle sweetness but good crisp

NOTE: it was hard to locate the restaurant via yelp directions but it's actually on the south side of the intersection in a plaza!

Everyone (?) talks about the coconut pie. . .well yeah, it's excellent, but how come no one talks about the home-brewed teas which are also in a class by themselves? 

Yes, the seafood is very good. The place / menu are Korean/Asian-inspired, as is the decor. Weird, in a strip mall way, where they've apparently been located for a long long time. Nonetheless, the servers are super nice, the food's delicious, and the only downer is they're a tad pricey (but pro'lly worth it)  for strip mall calories.

I love coffee. I will throw down a skinny mocha like no ones business. When I walked into La Columbe I almost considered moving to Fishtown to take advantage of this place. Large variety of barista favs, beautiful decor, cool urban vibe, and delicious pastries. Did I mention they have alcohol to mix in if needed? It's a must or bust in Philly.
Full service ear, nose, and throat specialists located In Sunset Hills in a strip mall next to Jimmy Johns.  They also do voice therapy.  Professional staff.  Clean office.

Let us have a moment of silence, please.

Thank you.  That is to mark a monumental event in my decades-long search for the best East-coast style pizza here in Northern Nevada.  

It took us awhile to find this place within the maze of the Legends outlets and Scheels complex, but here it was, and it was worth every moment of being fried alive as we walked around at high noon in search of Grimaldi's.

By the time we walked in, we were hot, sweaty, and hungry.  We kept it simple, and ordered a large pizza with sausage and mushrooms.  With 1 soda and the pizza and tip, total came to just under $30.  A bit pricey, but hey, it was nice in there (loved the wine bottles recycled as lighting fixtures), air-conditioned, great service, and yes, the pizza was beyond excellent.  Just the perfect crust (my fingers were left slightly blackened by the wood-fired crust), the perfect amount of toppings, and the perfect sauce was slightly sweet with a good tiny bit of kick and basil.

I would have taken a picture, but the two of us devoured the entire large pizza and nothing remained, not even crumbs, to prove its existence.

An adorable little village located on the third floor of Macy's Center City in the old Wanamaker Building as many of you know. It's a permanent fixture here in Philly and is also a family tradition for many. A visit here is FREE and works perfectly when combined with Macy's iconic light show viewing. Make sure to leave appropriate time for both and of course for some impromptu shopping! 

You'll first walk through a room of gorgeous holiday decor, giant nutcrackers and some nutcrackers and ornaments for purchase. We actually added one from here this year to our every growing, beloved collection! 

The village is modeled after London in the 1900's and done so well! The journey begins with Charles Dickens reciting the first passage from his iconic "A Christmas Carol". You then walk through Christmas Past, Future and Present, but of course. The details are super sweet and get you feeling nostalgic and certainly leaving in the holiday spirit. 

At the end of the village you will have the option to visit Santa or just walk through. Staff is on hand to take professional photos free with an option to purchase or you may take your own. They cannot however, take photos with your camera or phone so come prepared. 

At the exit you will enter an area for Build A Bear Workshop complete with fashionable and seasonal outfits. This year there was even the oh so popular Troll accessories available. 

The staff, clad in appropriate period garb were all so kind. They kept the line moving and chatted with all of the kiddos, even handing them all a Santa keepsake pin with the year on it. 

I say it's an absolute must! Really wee ones may get scared of Jacob Marley shaking at his grave or at the ghost of Christmas Past hanging above. They may also throw a fit for you to purchase something. Come with these things in mind and you'll be fine. Stroller space is also a tad limited. Consider leaving it at the exit as you would for an amusement ride. 

My husband and I both really loved it! The kiddos of course, loved Santa! And hey, it's FREE! Why not?!

It was cold, wet, and a windy night in Chinatown Philadelphia. We were all hungry after visiting the Christmas Village for the holidays and with several restaurants across from us, we decided to choose this place for their decent reviews.

I ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup and beef scallion pancake for appetizer. I am fortunate enough to be living in Las Vegas for nine years where Asian soup from different parts of the world is not hard to find. I would have to say that the beef soup here was less than satisfaction. I prefer my meat cut smaller rather than large chunks, but the meat was very tender. The broth overall was good, but I prefer the Taiwanese  beef noodle soup at Noodle Pot in Vegas.

As for the beef scallion pancakes that seems to be very popular here, is not so popular with me. The sauce was too sweet for me and the pancake was a little bit chewy. The temperature was almost at room temperature that may had contributed for being a little bit chewy. Liang's Kitchen in Vegas has awesome beef scallion pancakes served warm and is seasoned well.

The ladies were great and service was super quick. However, when in Chinatown, I would try other places before coming back here again.

3 1/2 stars

This expertly decorated Italian Restaurant is located in the heart of Media.   
Plenty of street metered parking (50 cents an hour ... Free after 6pm).   There seems to be two main dining areas.  We had an early dinner reservation and were seated near the window which was great.  

They make ordering easy by having the number next to the meal (which is more for a Chinese restaurant not a nicer restaurant like this).

They have a few outside tables for fresh air seating.  Inside is very cozy and comfortable. 
It's a BYOB so don't forget your bottle of wine.

The waiter was really nice.

Appetizers
We started our meal with tasty bruchetta and fresh bread.
Ordered the Mozzarella Caprese which is explained as mozzarella and tomatoes but I was disappointed in this dish.  2/3 of the plate was filled with olives, roasted peppers and onions (see pic).  The 1/3 contained thinly sliced tomatoes and very VERY small pieces of mozzarella.  Don't bother with this dish.
Cuz - Had the Caesar salad which he enjoyed as he ate every single bite.
I had the Port Wine Mushroom Soup (daily chef special) which looked weird but was really good.   Looked like puree mushrooms.  I'm glad I ordered it as it was super tasty.

Dinner-
Hubby - had the veal parmigiana which he said was good.
I had the Petto Di Pollo Alla Melazane which was chicken breast with a slice of eggplant on top.  This was a really good meal and I would definitely order it again.
Luckily they offered a kids meal so my kid had chicken tenders and potato chips.

No desserts this time.

Yes I'll be back but I'll stay away from the appetizers.

So much fun...the Rinard Gallery has actually been traveling around a bit. They are no longer in the 700 block of Royal, a sign redirects you to the 800 block BUT the gallery employee told me that they'll actually be moving to the 600 block as soon as their space is ready...probably April.

Once I found their great new space, I was able to acquire my 2014 Barkus poster (Dogzilla). The gallery also carries a number of other animal oriented artists. I've only ever purchased cards and Barkus posters from them but the staff has always been lovely.

If you are a pet person, checking out this gallery is a must.

On each trip there seems to be a place or food that makes you dream about how you would do anything to go back just one more time. This is that place. It was recommended to us by some locals as we wanted to get a little bit off the beaten path and boy was it some kind of recommendation. We actually went for po boys but looking at other reviews it looks like there are many memorable dishes at this establishment.

We were seated at the bar, greeted immediately by the bartender, had a drink and got a grilled and fried catfish po boy. I'm not expert but I've had my fair share over the years and this is by far the best one I've come across. It's the one dish I'd like to have one more time! In fact, that was the plan but I overlooked the closing time of 3PM on Sunday so I guess I'll just have to come back to NoLa to get my fix! Absolutely delicious!

Its very casual and definitely is going for the "country" feel.  They have a massive selection of delicious pies and treats and I absolutely adore their meatloaf dish.  This is a really fun hangout.  They have plenty of parking.  Their patio lights with seating in the back is really cute.  The only problem for me is that its a bit of a drive to get to and its not really near many other businesses.  Thats not their fault though.  This is a solid 4-4.5 stars.

According to my friend from Maryland, this is the best pizza ever. A franchise based out of Maryland, they focus on flat crust, Sicillian-style, which makes my week of pizza eating unique in that on Sunday I had Cappys Chicago-style deep dish, and now this.

There were 5 of us eating after a long day of outdoor activity and we got a large pepperoni and pre-cooked bacon ("bacon" is on the menu, but is actually Canadian Bacon). They cut it in half and serve each half on a large rectangular tray. This makes consumption is groups easy. The pepperoni is thick cut, so one per square is perfect.

Fortunately we were pretty exhausted so the large filled us up, but had we been more ravenous, we probably would have gotten something else. Thin crust is tasty, but not really filling.

Came here to watch my Clippers get killed by the Hornets.  I am a bit spoiled by Staples Center but this arena is pretty decent.  The club level has tables and many options of food.

BTW the girls in the photo dancing are the Honeybee's, the Hornets cheerleaders.

We stopped in for a beer but saw they had a Northern Liberties cheesesteak.  We got to Northern Liberties cheesesteak.  Spoiler alert: it is a roast beef panini.  It is a good roast beef panini.  Nice place.  Very helpful people.  Huge Beer selection.  $7.  There are a lot of reasons to love the Foodery in Northern Liberties.

This La Colombe outpost just steps away from Rittenhouse Square is super busy, welcoming a stream of visitors almost all day long. Although the line can stretch out the door, everything moves along reasonably quickly, and the staff are super sharp and proactive.

Most people get their joe to go, which means that even on a busy weekend morning, you might be lucky enough to snag a seat at a table or at a window-side counter if you want to linger for conversation or for some reading. Just remember not to loiter *too* long if you've already finished your drink and people could sure use a seat.

In my case, I got my oat milk black-and-tan (half oat milk draft latte, half cold brew) very quickly, and it was darn delicious. I had to resist gulping it down all at once, so savoring it slowly while banging out a few Yelp reviews on my laptop made for a nice start to a weekend morning. ;)

Life is sweet with a box of Macarons. It's a little cute kiosk inside of Cherry Hill Mall and I couldn't resist the temptations as I walked by. Pretty little yummy delectables cookies. My boyfriend is a picky eater and insisted they were indeed good. Better than the ones I've normally go to buy out in Philly. Despite the bad review upon customer service, I was treated great. They were helpful and patient as I procrastinated on what flavors to pick. My only concern was the price. $2.50! I'm not used to paying more than $1.50 for a single macaron. Non the less, they were satisfying.

Stayed here for one night over the weekend and thought it was completely satisfactory. We arrived late that Friday night and had no issues checking in. The staff was very nice from the beginning to the end of our visit.  The over facility is great, up to date. Our room was fairly large with a really good king sized bed. The pillows were just okay,  they were a little too plump for my liking. They have a small fitness room with 4-5 treadmills, a few bicycle machines, free weights, a multi-purpose machine, foam rollers and exercise mats. It wasn't too much but at least the equipment was fairly new and everything was very clean.

I would definitely consider staying again. The shower scrunchy was huge plus!
Got a vanilla cold brew and it was amazing! Seriously one of the best iced coffee I have ever had. If it were closer to our hotel, I would have been here every day.

I simply loved Saint Somewhere! Located in a completely unexpected old Victorian house on Tarpon Avenue. You'll need to park on the street or in a nearby parking lot which is relatively easy. The bar is not large. Order and move out of the way for others to order! I ended up here on my birthday on a Friday afternoon. The bartender was extremely friendly and knowledgable about the beers on tap. Prices are good and the beer is wonderful. I honestly loved the rustic Victorian interior and seating choices. It almost feels like a church with a small shrine in the main bar and pews as seating. There is also outdoor seating. I really enjoyed to ambiance of the building and the experience overall. Worth a visit for sure!

My review is honestly between three and four stars but I'm going with four stars because of the fact that just an "a-okay" rating seems to be a little low especially when you take into consideration the hotel nightmares I've had the past few weeks with traveling in connection with a move.  (Feel free to scroll through my past reviews to laugh at my expense for that).

The pros:.

1:  The hotel is conveniently located near the airport and offers free shuttle service.  The shuttle runs every 15 minutes and when I used it this morning, it arrived on time and was quite helpful.
2. The front desk staff is AMAZINGLY helpful.  I am staying at this airport (in an out) for a few days in conjunction with a move overseas and had several questions upon my initial arrival.  The staff went ABOVE and BEYOND to help me get my answers and made multiple stressful situations for me go smoothly.
3. There is a restaurant on site that has a variety of price point meals.  Its good if you don't feel like venturing out.  The food is pretty good quality.
4. The gym and pool were also top notch.
5. My room was CLEAN (thank you travel gods) and spacious and well stocked.  The bed was also very comfortable.

The Cons:

1. There is some nickel and diming with the having to pay for wifi...come on now its 2013?
2. Walls are pretty thin and at some times it seemed like I could hear anything and everything yet I never heard a plane.
3. Paying for parking...meh.....just another annoyance but not the end of the world.


In the end, I'd definitely go back to this hotel should I find myself back in the area without hesitation.

Looking for a greasy Mexican spot? Or like me and my homegirl, are you looking some big ass tacos at about 10pm on a Friday night? Look no further. I definitely dug the divey atmosphere with a menu full of your tex mex favorites along with hot dogs. Say what?

Their salsa bar was large and had some odd toppings. It took me a hot second to comprehend why the hell a salsa bar had mustard and shredded cheese, but then it dawned on me... the Sonoran hot dog. This isn't your average salsa bar, because it also happens to be a hot dog bar.

I went for the al pastor and the chicken tacos and I've had better. They were large, but super greasy. The guac was extremely creamy, but definitely didn't taste the freshest and it was that dark green hue that comes from maybe some of the avocados a little past their prime. It was also topped with like a parmesan style cheese which didn't help. 

The sonoran hot dog? A few bites, but it was more bread than dog. Womp womp.
The margarita? Sugary, but strong!

Service was great, it was pretty cheap and definitely has a divey, locals scene. I think there's probably better out there, but for some late night eats, not so shabby!

Wow, Greek Lady's upgraded their location. Much bigger, much cleaner since my last visit.

Food's still just as tasty and probably just as unhealthy for you, but at least it's still the same goodness that was there for years.

Definitely big portions still.... though it is a tish more expensive now but still under $10 with a drink and a gyro.

3.5 stars rounded up 

We hadn't had a proper meal all day so we decided to head to Atlantis' buffet as soon as they opened at 4:30pm. We took our place behind about two dozen other parties who also had their hearts set on the Friday Seafood buffet ($36.99/person), but the line moved quickly. 

The boys went in on the crab (hot Jonah claws, steamed snow crab, cold snow & Dungeness crabs) & made several trips to the carving station (the meats were too well done for their liking, quality subpar.) 

I tried: 
- SHRIMP! Fried shrimp (I can eat my weight in shrimp, but especially good fried shrimp, which these were), shrimp scampi, shrimp cocktail, & a chef's special which was scallop & shrimp in a buttery, cheesy sauce served in a shell 
- chicken potstickers & chicken & corn soup (both very good) 
- hard shell tacos & chile relleno (both not so good) 
- mini caprese salad 
- cotton candy (rest of dessert selection did not appeal to me, & I didn't notice the chocolate fountain until we were leaving. The one piece of rice crispy square dipped into white chocolate I tried was heavenly!)  

Huge selection. Wish I had room for pho from the make-your-own bar. 4 stars in comparison to other Reno buffets; 3 stars compared to decent buffets in Vegas.

So begins our New Orleans vacation and boy did we come out of the gates swinging.  We landed around 6:30 am, checked in at the hotel and went straight for food. 

What should I eat at 7:45 am?  You guys have a burger? I'll take it!  Man was this a burger. Brought out on a cutting board alongside a cup of crispy seasoned fries, this burger blew me away. 

The patty practically melted away and barely stuck together. Inside it was topped with a fat slice of cheese, huge and juicy tomato, semi-crispy bacon (just the way I like) and deliciously sweet grilled onions. 

Without expecting it, I think I found a rival to the Father's Office burger. 

The girl went for a more traditional breakfast item and ordered the Grillades and Grits. Yeah, they were pretty good, but I couldn't waste more than a bite because I had that huge burger to work on.

I got the cobb salad here. It was average, nothing special. 

My friend got the tiramisu ice cream, it was delicious!

I'd come in for the ice cream but not for the regular food.

Located at the former Zachary's location on Oak, Squeal is a great place for real pit BBQ in Nola. Remembering that we are not Memphis so comparisons cannot be made, this place hosts some of the best fall of the bone meat. The meat is rubbed and sauced with spices a feature I love and the sauce is unique. Like most New Orleans BBQ places the sides leave much to the imagination. I had the grits that weren't bad but didn't seem to compliment the meal well and the greens were good but have had better elsewhere. Next time I'll try the standard beans. But overall you come for the meat and the meat is top notch. Btw the service is fantastic also.

Wine and beer tastings!

Nice and small tasting room. Limited seating. There is also an outside patio area where you can taste too. Servers were really nice and friendly.

Gold Flight - $6 - 3 wines
Beer Flight - $ 6 - 4 beers

I enjoyed both flights. Great place to relax and drink some beer and wine.

Looking for something different for a date night or girls night out?  Check out Mimosa & A Masterpiece!!   Get online, go to the website, click on the calendar, pick a painting that strikes your fancy, sign up, and GO!  I believe they also offer private events for bigger groups.  SO FUN!   Located in the heart of the arts district off Mass Ave, enter through the door by the Stamp Shop on the corner to get here!


What makes it fun:
Twana -- AKA "the Hostess with the mostest" was awesome!  So friendly!   Our glasses were never empty nor did we have to ask for anything.  She was hilarious, personable, and anticipated our needs.  Sweet.  

Alan -- our instructor for the evening.  Provided great guidance while encouraging individual creativity.  He was very willing to hop in and help where needed and was funny to boot.  He even did a great job of diffusing the awkwardness of some "difficult" painters and made us laugh in the process.

$5 "liquid courage" -- Red and white wines, mimosas... very generous pours and quality product for just $5 a glass.


What sets them apart:
They let you customize your color palate so your painting can complement your decor -- which was really nice.  Other similar places already have your stuff set up and colors are predetermined when you arrive.  Not at Mimosa & a Masterpiece.  They will even give you a quick overview of which colors look good together to ensure you are on the right track.

You are encouraged to "make it your own" -- meaning they will provide a loose guide and framework, but not a step-by-step on how to make your painting look EXACTLY like theirs.  This is great for the creative or rebel painter...and it's all in fun anyway, right?  

So yes.  We will return to Mimosa & a Masterpiece again.  SO. MUCH. FUN.

Cool, modern brewery located in Ardmore. The space is quite large and they have the beer stills displayed in the rear of the room. There are tables to sit at which utilize waitress service, or you can sit in the bar area at one of the high top tables. The bar area fills up quickly and it's first come, first serve. By around 6pm all seats are full. You may even have to wait to get a table in the dining room. This place is very popular! As for the beer here, the house Saizon was very tasty. They have a wide selection of different types of beer that will satisfy all palates. As the food goes, the menu is pretty limited. Focusing on sandwiches and tacos. My Chicken Taco's were just ok, I found them to be a little bland. But I have to say, the hand cut french fries were finger licking good. They were great to munch on while we sampled our brews. The service was excellent, our server was super attentive, knowledgeable and friendly. I can't wait to return for another round of beers.

Such a fun and open space! Situated right off of Tchoup you can easily find parking throughout the streets. Here are a few scenarios where USB would make sense to check out:

Have a family? Bring them here and send them off to the video arcade area!

Have a snobby beer friend? Come when they have brewery tours and keep them entertained for a bit!

Need more Holy Roller in your life? Come to their taproom and grab a six pack and have a beer in-person as a thank you to yourself!

Dog Friendly? Hell Yea!

Beer and Food? They feature different food vendors and simply give them a call ahead of time to see whose there.

A/C? They just got it installed this summer. Screw you humidity!

Beer? Well yea... it's a brewery!

Drink options for non-beer drinkers? They have fresh lemonade on tap, kombucha, ginger something something, and water on tap!

Come hang out and bring the squad because there is plenty of seating space.

Pirate themed drunken chaos and mayhem with beads and floats. We liked the dance party on South Howard on Bayshore. Everyone was pretty friendly. Our pooch enjoyed the food scraps. The crowd density snd intensity was a lot for this old man so we road bikes to the back of the parade and saw the garbage trucks and street sweepers. Parrrrttttttyyyy. Some good costumes.and crazy peeps for sure.

They have a plumbing supply business and also a retail display store with bathtubs, sinks, faucets, lighting and other associated home decor items.  They seem to mainly carry higher end items in the retail store but some things can be ordered in a cheaper configuration.  They want you to sign in when you first walk in the retail store and the wait for a salesperson can be a much longer time than you would expect so they use the sign in list to determine who gets the next available salesperson.  The plumbing supply business can get really busy especially in the morning as they carry one of the largest selections of plumbing supplies in the area.  I have been given some incorrect parts before but they have always been easy to work with to exchange them.

The Newtown area has an embarrassment of riches when it comes to fresh, homemade ice cream.  At last count, there are at least four shops making their own cold creamies, and each has something special going for it. With February weather reaching 80 last week, climate change now makes ice cream an all year delight. 

Uncle Dave's is located in the main store on Shady Brook Farm off Stony Brook Road and the Newtown Bypass. They offer an interesting selection of their ice cream with the ability to accessorize with sprinkles, fudge, caramel, etc. Prices are about right for the competition. Under $4 for the "Kids" size; $5 for the "Medium," and $7 for the "Large." In my experience, that Kids size with three scoops of up to three of your favorite flavors was enough. Don't let the description of "Kids" deter you from getting only what you can lick in one serving. 

I went with two scoops of butter pecan and one scoop of the seasonal pumpkin. They were both creamy and tasted as they should. Not too sweet, not under-flavored. Both were pretty much what I expected. My friends and their young kids opted for more varieties, including cappuccino, strawberry and peanut butter with a side of peanut butter sauce.  They were all happy with their choices. 

Was it the best ice cream in greater Newtown? That's a matter of personal preference.  But, given all the alternatives, it represented Dave's well.  Their offerings were more standard that some other parlors, so if exotic and romantic taste is your thing, you might find this place a little uninspired.  For you folks, OhWowCow in Wrightstown is the only way to go. Of course, it also costs more for premium. 

Lick on!

CONSISTENCY!!!
There's a reason why my friends and I always rank Mr. B's as our top Quarter restaurant for a "Christmas Bell" lunch: it's always good.***

That may not sound like a sexy reason to choose it over the myriad new bourgie alternatives, but it's been my experience that while most of these newbies may provide a comparable menu it's at a premium price for an experience that is unsatisfactory half the time.

STANDOUTS TODAY:
1. The smoked buster crabs in meuni√®re were among the best dishes I had in 2015.
2. This afternoon's gumbo yaya roux was the darkest and richest that I've lapped up in years.
3. The 2 course pricing is still aggravating but the bloodies remain just fitty-cent.

***CAVEAT:
Mr. B's is a lunch spot, perhaps our best lunch spot; but I would never go there for dinner. It doesn't translate.

Grubhub Philly to the rescue. They deliver Korean food until 2200!!! 

They're most known for their BBQ and koagies (hoagies), but we went for something else. Too cold to wanna button and scarf/hat up to go into Rittenhouse. It was getting late. What should we do to keep from being hit by the cold? Opted for this instead.

Omg delicious. Sooo awesome, our room service meal just a mile away. Ordered: fried pork/veg dumplings, very spicy salmon veg fried rice, and Korean jajungmyun. Great food, so happy with the portions.

Banchan was scant and small, but appreciated that there were any at all! Goljujang cukes and cabbage, macaroni salad, green beans.

Deliv:$2

Scheels is one of my favorite stores to visit when I'm in Reno . I was rolling around with my Bro Big Mike - The Irish Enforcer in his 4 Wheel Drive Whip . We decided to roll by Scheels because they have a Huge Inventory of Outdoor Equipment. They also have a Huge Parking lot  . So parking the Whip was easy . Then we rolled in . They have a huge Fish Aquarium  in the entrance . There's even a Ferris Wheel in the Middle of the store .  

But I love their Gun Department its HUGE!!! They have a great selection of Firearms and Accessories. I also like their BBQ and Smoker selection . They have a Huge Cutlery selection also. 

Their a one stop shop for Everything Outdoors and there  Baller On A Budget Approved !!!

Plus they have great sales on occasion .

I've gotta give it to them..consistent, great price and friendly service. This is our local go to when we're looking for an affordable, quick dinner.  We have had a great experience everytime with this location and they now offer delivery!! You know what you're getting with Hungry Howie's and I can't say a darn thing bad about this location.

I won a $50 gift certificate from tattoo artist JJ Ortiz in the Santa Barbara Public Library summer reading challenge. I've never had a tattoo before so I was excited to get one!

Golden Eagle is nice and clean and fairly approachable. JJ was professional and friendly and gave me the tattoo that I wanted exactly as I wanted it. I loved working with JJ. He was extremely helpful in ways I could place my tattoo and the design. When I walked in, I was pretty confident that I knew what I wanted but after meeting with JJ, I appreciated his knowledge and help. I didn't feel that he changed anything about my vision for my tattoo, but enhanced it. 

I would highly recommend working with JJ Ortiz.

Isn't it great to see the Yelp community do its job!  Every once in a while you see a place with a couple of reviews that make no sense.  Not crazy enough to filter but odd enough to making a thinking person say "huh!"  That's the case with Saffron Kitchen.  I can only think that two Yelpers were hung over from the night before or just temporarily incompetent!  As you can see from the ratings the majority of "us" love this place and for good reason.

Let's start with the beautiful contemporary atmosphere.  Nice tablecloths and place settings.  This place feels classy.

How about the wait staff?  I've visited several times for lunch and twice for dinner.  In each case I've had friendly, competent and reserved waiters.  They have all been a pleasure.

The food is wonderful.  All the Indian staples are here but the dishes are better executed. They are fresh, colorful, and tasty.  A great experience!

Came here because of the highway signs.
Good food, good price. The guys working back there perhaps seemed a tad nicer than other places that I've been to in Northern Virginia , but maybe it's the water in Delaware that makes people nicer.

Nice big parking space!
Tasty BBQ!!! The combo platter is fun and enough to share. And the hot caramel topped bread pudding is yummy. The smells walking past are great too!

Carrollton is a solid day parade on the first weekend of carnival.  The riders throw a good amount and the floats are full, especially since this is a small organization.  The floats are pretty good, but nothing super fancy.  Most of the good high school bands march in this parade.

Pretty busy today for the grand opening. To be expected though.  A lot of these folks have probably never shopped at an Aldi.  This was evident by the amount of people trying to use credit cards, who obviously didn't know that Aldi is DEBIT ONLY.  There were actually so many folks there for opening that they had no carts available because they were all in use.  So to compensate,  they were giving away free Aldi bags. They were also handing out $5 off coupons. So yeah it was a little crazy.

The store was fully stocked, as you can imagine.  The one thing I couldn't find though was the fit n active section where all of the healthier options are. Perhaps it was just too busy. I'll snoop around next time since the joint is only a few miles down the road. Much closer than the less-than-stellar Town & Country locale.

This Aldi is pretty large as well.  It seems very close in size to the one on US 19.

If they have the chicken sausage links, pick them up! They're seasonal, delicious and versatile. Use them in gumbo, pasta dishes or just on a bun. I've had the chicken sausages from Publix and Trader Joe's, but Aldi reigns supreme. No joke. I stockpile them. La Chica makes fun of it and calls it my "sausage collection," but trust me, she ain't laughing when I cook dinner. 

Lastly, try the 16" take and bake pizzas; they're damn near pizzeria quality.

Oh, and to the grocery store snobs, Trader Joe's parent company is Aldi :)

Ordering is an art form. Seriously. Before I became a semi-adventurous eater, I was attracted to any dish that involved chicken or beef. Lame, right? Anyhow, last night at Chifa, my friends and I gorged on some crazy awesome dishes, and I proudly ate outside of my comfort zone. We sat in the back room where I felt like an extra on the set of Eyes Wide Shut...you know, in the scene with all the naked women and creepy monk-men with masks? Chifa totally has that vibe. The booth was cozy and I got to lounge on the pillow that cushioned my lower back. Nice touch.

The food: Everything was brought out in smallish bowls, but there was so much food, we were totally pleased with the portions. We had the lomo (beef and veggies), caldo (seafood bisque type soup), bbq ribs (there were no bones!) and chicken wings (no bones either!). There wasn't an unsatisfactory thing about our dishes. You'll also have to ask for more bread. It's unreal.

As for the cocktail, I got the Black Tea Sidecar. I'm a big fan of Courvoisier cognac (random, I know), but trust me, you can drink a gallon and you won't have a hangover in the morning. Promise. Anyway, I had to ask for an extra bit of simple syrup because the cocktail felt a little lacking in the sweet dept. I also think it could have used more lemon...I'm not sure if lemon was used at all.

Overall, outstanding time and great food.

Part of the Brennan's Restaurant group and in business for over 40 years, Mr. B's Bistro is one of the best and most popular eateries in New Orleans. It's located on Royal Street and very near the Hotel Monteleone and usually open 7 days a week for lunch and dinner but during Covid is closed Monday and Tuesday. Mr.B's is an upscale table service establishment with a full bar but doesn't require a coat for gentlemen. 

I had dinner here a couple of weeks ago for the first time in many years. It was a Saturday night and the restaurant was full so reservations are important especially on weekend nights. I ordered the Bistro Salad for $9.50 and the Wood Grilled Fish for $31 and added the jumbo lump crabmeat for another $12. Within 5 minutes a loaf of warm french bread with butter and the salad came out. The salad had baby greens, pecans, grape tomatoes, Padano cheese with an herb vinaigrette. I loved that salad. It was so fresh and delicious and was a perfect mixture of ingredients. The bread loaf came in a bag to keep it warm and was soft and fresh.

About 20 minutes later the entree arrived and it was one of the best grilled fish dinners that I have had in a long time. First of all, the wood flavor in the fillet was so pleasing. It was perfect in taste and a large piece to boot. The fish was over a mound of pecan popcorn rice that was delicious too. It was a perfect side to the fish and with the grilled green beans made me very happy. The jumbo lump crabmeat on top of the fish was also a delight. I mean how can you not like crab meat like that? Honestly, this meal would have still been excellent without the crabmeat and if I ordered this again, I might skip the crabmeat and save the $12 for dessert. I was stuffed after this meal so I skipped dessert. Table service during the meal was very good.

It's restaurants like Mr. B's Bistro that make New Orleans the great foodie town it is. If you come here to eat, you made a good choice. My experience a couple of weeks ago was a 5.

Decided to go here today with a friend. Now I'm kind of sorry we did.  The food was OK. At least they got our -special- orders right.  So why the 2 stars?  Our waiter was S-L-O-W.  And I don't mean slow.. I mean, he took our beverage order and then disappeared for the next 10 minutes.  He didn't come back to take our order for a long while. It was quite frustrating. Here we were, ready to order, but we had to wait... and wait.. and wait. 

When we did order, the food came out fast enough, and it was just how we ordered it, but the service just took away from everything.

Are you ever in the mood for a really big, messy burrito? I recently had that kind of craving, so David and I headed over to El Gato Negro, home of one of my favorite burritos.

We were here somewhat early (7 ish) on a Friday night and the crowd was non-existent, but we were greeted with a friendly "hello" and shown to our table right away. Joseph was our waiter and he was great- super friendly and attentive and full of personality. We started with an order of queso and I got my carnitas burrito smothered in their delicious tomato sauce. As always, the burrito was perfect and packed with goodies. I was pretty pleased. I also had a tasty frozen margarita that was a great "cool down" on a warm summer night.

The atmosphere of this place is pretty laid back and I imagine that they do a good lunch crowd and I'm sure that business picks up when there is a show at Howlin Wolf or Republic, so plan accordingly. I will definitely go back for more of their deliciousness.

Tapas! Small portions, that's a given. 

Get the duck salad. 

$5 happy hour. Pretty good wine. I approve! The cowmilk cheese went very well with the white wine they had tonight. 

Service is top notch.

Beautiful bridge~ if you are up for a nice walk, a mile and half distance (less than an hour walk). This bridge is connecting between Philadelphia & New Jersey. 

If you are taking hop-on hop-off bus tour, you definitely will pass by this bridge. If you are on any of the observation deck, definitely look for this bridge.

My iced almond milk caramel latte was fine, as was my friend's cortado and bagel. Four stars for the overall atmosphere, decor, and service, but three for the coffee. I've had better, and I've had worse. I prefer a strong coffee/espresso flavor, and my latte was missing that. It was more milky than anything, so the overall balance was off. Pastries (not bagels) looked tasty, and if I did happen to stop in again, I'd grab one.
