Outback is decent - it gets really packed in Brandon though so be prepared to wait if you do go. I personally enjoy their blooming onion and their blooming onion burger. The service has been pretty decent in past visits, although some waitresses were a little awkward. The rest of the menu is your casual fare and there honestly isn't much worth talking about once you pass the blooming onions. If you want a real steak I would recommend heading to some great venues in South Tampa instead, such as SideBern's. If you want some real BBQ though there are better options in Brandon like First Choice on 60 and Jaymer Q-BBQ in Valrico near Bloomingdale and Lithia Pinecrest. For some great chicken head to El Puerto in Ybor City.

A divey place that serves great seafood in South Philly. This hole in a wall is close to my gym, so I usually stop in here to get some high protein seafood kebobs before my work out. I've never tried any of the other items because I'm trying to avoid fry food, but the grilled items are fabulous. I don't care for the soup because they are cream based, but the other dishes on the menu looks delicious!

EVERY time I come here to refill a growler, I feel like I'm stepping into Cheers or some other friendly place where everyone knows your name. (Except they don't know my name here. But, like, they treat me as though I'm a friend.) My sole experience of Upland consists of refilling growlers, but one day I hope to visit and sit in their dining room or on their patio and eat their food.

I highly recommend their Champagne beer -- it is pretty awesome and pretty much the only kind I get. When I find something I love, I stick with it!

One great thing about this place is that they give you a free 12 ounce glass of beer with every growler refill. It's nice to just sit, chill and take your time sipping free beer while a person readies a giant jug of beer for you to take home. It warms the cockles of my heart just thinking about it.

So, first the first time in a long time (long time), I had time. Read that again so that it makes sense. What does one do after finding time after such a long time of not having time? Good question. I began to remember the things that I enjoyed doing (before I lost the time to do them) and set about trying to do them again. I slept in. I hit the gym. I cooked. And, I decided to read. Books. I was going to read books.

As much as it pains my librarian friend, I don't have an active library card and despite the community and environmental benefits of libraries, if I think too much about them, they sort of gross me out. But (to make him happy), I am not much of an e-reader. There's something about the tactile quality of books that adds so much to the reading experience. Perhaps it's a function of age and habit but I have never felt quite comfortable curling up with a tablet. Give me a book every time. 

Tactile intentions made, I just had to decide where to shop. That wasn't a very hard choice. In Nashville, if you're buying a book, you come to Parnassus. I'd written about Parnassus. I'd given directions to Parnassus. I'd never been or patronized the store. Ergo, I made some mistakes. 1.) I showed up looking for a non-local book. Don't do this. Go online. Search for the book. See if it's in stock. See if there's a signing at the store. Proceed accordingly. I arrived to a packed house. There was a lecture/book signing and all hands were on deck. I looked around, made eye contact with an employee and asked if there was a kiosk for searching. She smiled and whispered she was the kiosk and asked for my title. I gave it to her and... not in stock. But, she could order it for me and have it in store in two days. Cool. I gave her my info, tiptoed out and braved the Green Hills traffic back to my home.

After some early morning appointments, I made my way back to Green Hills and... closed. This leads me to point 2.) Verify hours. Just because other stores open at certain times does not mean this store does. Independent store. Independent hours. Again, I left Green Hills harrowed and sans book. The third time was the charm: I arrived, asked for my book and a book I received. Both of the employees with whom I chatted were pleasant and knowledgeable. Not only did they know my book and author, they gave me information about upcoming lectures/signings of said author (and similar authors). It was at this moment that it hit me that this was a bookstore owned, operated and (wo)manned by people who love books. The comfortable, bright design showcases said love and makes one want to spend more time loving on all the ink, spines, paper, and words that change opinions, open hearts, transform worlds, and comfort souls.

I'm happy to have some time back.* I have a whole list of books to buy/read and I look forward to doing so with the help of Parnassus. I'll just abide by the rules going forward.

*Reclaimed.

I love the name of this new vintage store located in the Funk Zone, Santa Barbara. What is waiting for you behind that blue door? It could be a mystery. You can unlock it by opening the blue door and by checking the store out. It's a big (it takes up 3 floors) store, full of cool vintage, antique items, one of a kind. The place is clean, well organized, not the dusty, cluttered type. They do have cool paintings, furniture, lamps, so if you're looking for unique, interesting things for your house, this place is worth checking. Nothing is cheap here, but the condition of the items they sell is good and a lot of items are more unique. I enjoyed passing behind the Blue Door and discovering what's inside.

Not a lot of selection to be honest, but it's nice to have a corner market in the neighborhood for basic items. Stopped by here to get a few snacks and toothpaste. They have a deli in the back of the store and a soup bar. It would be a nice if they'd run a meal deal like the ones in England or Ireland. Mark & Spencers, Sainsbury, Tesco, Lidl, Dunnes....They all offer some sort of meal deal which includes drink, sandwich, and chips! This store is very basic. I didn't see anything good on sale either.

Cool local business that specializes in handmade glass pieces.  The studio is incorporated into a house - so you enter through the garage doors, walk past the work area, and then there are separate sections in the backyard with merchandise for sale.  Parking is on the street in front of the house.

Once you pass through the garage, there is an enclosed small 'gallery' where unique and interesting one-of-a-kind pieces are for sale.  Then, next to that are two outdoor areas that have items for sale like ornaments, vases, glass flowers, and their specialty items - spirit weights and cast glass paper weights.  I went during the holidays and picked up some unique ornaments, a vase, and glass "kisses".  There is even an oops shelf which had some pretty interesting mistakes at discounted prices.

I will definitely stop here again.  Plus, I would love to go back to attend their glass blowing classes.

My go-to spot while waiting for a plane. 

This restaurant was started by a top chef and the food resembles that. It's your best bet at a quality meal before taking off. 

What should you order? Let me tell you about the Turkey Club. Probably one of the best I've had recently. The bacon was crispy, there was a good amount of turkey, the wheat bread was soft and the avocado was plentifulllll. You can snag fries, chips or a salad as your side. 

The flatbreads are delicious and there are about eight different options. The BBQ chicken flatbread has avocado and sounded amazing, as did the margarita and mushroom flatbreads.

Service has always been kind and efficient, no frills. Find this spot in Terminal B!

Visited Tanya & Matt's for some  homemade ice cream. The space is quaint with clippings of newspaper articles & accolades pasted on the walls. There were live musicians - a guitarist & a singer that brought a cheerful vibe to the space. I had the rum raisin ice cream, it was flavorful & didn't have too many raisins which I loved. I enjoy supporting local businesses & I look forward to visiting again.

Thank you fellow Yelpers in helping us find a good ramen shop in Philly!

ATMOSPHERE:
Contemporary Asian decor. Clean and newer looking shop. Counter & table seating. 

FOOD:
Gyoza 
5 pieces of pork & veggie dumplings fried to perfection, with a delicious dipping sauce. 

Mini Tokyo Fried Chicken Curry  
What a great deal at only $2!  Small bowl of rice topped with the crispy chicken & curry gravy.  Delish!  I wasn't a curry fan but my taste buds are a-changin'!

Mayu Ramen 
When I ordered this, both the chef & server acted surprised and asked me if I've ever had ramen before, and told me what the broth was made of and that its the same broth that's in the Terakawa signature ramen but a step above it. Come on now, what Asian do you know who hasn't eaten ramen?  I know they meant well.  I just said yes and that I was sure that's what I wanted.  Ok, the broth is made from a pork bone base so the color is a milky brown but they also add in mayu which they tout as a dark roasted leek & crushed garlic oil mixture, which adds a layer of black oil seasoning that floats at the top.  The broth is mild in flavor and is very rich and filling.  Some reviewers mistake it as bland but I don't think it's meant to be an overpowering flavor.  The toppings of char siu, red ginger, mushrooms, scallions, and egg all compliment the broth nicely.  I've never had anything like this so I'm glad I tried it. It's definitely not for the average ramen eater - you've got to be a fan. 

Tan Tan Ramen 
My spouse added a hard boiled egg to his dish. I tasted the broth only.  It's a bit sweet for a tan tan base and not spicy.  Our favorite version resides at at Goma Tei in Honolulu which is spicier and more savory. 

SERVICE:
Walked in at 3pm on a Monday afternoon and got seated immediately as the place was empty.  Our female server was very friendly but disappeared after our order was taken.  Someone else brought over our food. She didn't check on us or refill our waters.  The chef was very engaging and cared about what his customers were eating as he consulted with us while ordering. 

OVERALL:
Nice & clean ramen shop in Philly's Chinatown with great food and average prices. Definitely a come back spot!

Dan of DTS Performance loves his job and is great at it! After getting quotes from several local Tampa Bay area installers, I choose to go with Dan as he seemed the most knowledgeable, was fair on his prices, and could get to me quickly. 

Dan will come to your home or where ever your vehicle or boat is that you need professional stereo, alarm, wiring, amps, speakers, lights, marine electronics, and other low voltage type accessories upgraded or added. Everything will look nearly factory installed when he is done. Very clean install job, with no loose wires showing.

He is professional, respects your vehicle and equipment, and knows how to install it all correctly. I had several items installed; Bluetooth, touchscreen head unit, power converter, Viper alarm system with extra mods, bull bar, LED light bar, Sirius XM radio, GPS navigation, extra power outlet and USB ports. 

I highly recommend Dan and his company and will use him again for any future modifications.

Mr. Baja Fish was a-ok for a quick bite. While I haven't been to the other locations, this one seems to have a smaller menu and is order at the counter.  Everything was served in either to-go containers or styrofoam plates. Our group of five ordered different items so I was able to see a variety of dishes. I ordered the chicken bowl which was served with pinto beans, rice, shredded lettuce, sour cream and some sort of pseudo guacamole. I skipped the pico de gallo. I enjoyed my bowl for the most part. The Chicken had a nice char and it was cooked well. I found the beans and rice to be salty- but I have a low tolerance for salt
Others ordered bowls as well- carne asada and barbacoa. There was also an order of shrimp tacos- one grilled one battered. They looked good but I can't report on them as I didn't try them myself- I did post a photo for reference!

What you should know:
I didn't see too much on the menu that aligned with "Baja Fish"-standard items on menu- chicken, carne asada, barbcoa, plus fish tacos and shrimp cocktail. 
It's order at the counter
You can eat fast
You can order takeout easily.

It's been a couple of months since I returned to the Bay after visiting friends on the East Coast and I really, really miss Sabrina's Cafe.  And my friends.  Yes, definitely my friends, too.  

When I was in Philly, my friend, Joyce, took me to Sabrina's.  We got there at around 10 AM and were seated immediately.  The place was absolutely packed on a Sunday morning and after finishing my meal, I knew exactly why.  

They had a really punny, dating-themed portion of the menu, but I opted for their classic stuffed challah french toast (11.29) and a large orange juice (3.99).  

The challah toast is delightfully thick and chewy, and the cream cheese whipped stuffing in between is not too heavy.  I'm not sure what they mix it with, but it has just a hint of the sour cream cheese flavor without giving off the sense that you're eating a block of the stuff.  The bananas and berries sprinkled generously all over provide some tartness and fiber, haha, in between bites of carb-y, sugary- goodness.  One thing I will note is that they pour syrup over everything and it pools at the bottom of the plate.  If you're not into soggy parts of toast by the end of your meal, try asking for the syrup on the side.  

Oooh, child.  That was the absolute best french toast I have EVER had.  So good, in fact, that the very next morning, my friend, Jacque C., and I went to the Sabrina's Cafe on 910 Christian Street and ordered the very same thing.  If you're looking for a great breakfast spot, look no further than Sabrina's!

I'm sold. 
2 days in one week sent me scrambling to Taco Son for lunch because it was just so good. I couldn't stay away. 2 combinations later, I can safely say my days of Taco Bus are done if I have a choice. 

Everything tastes incredibly fresh, flavorful. 
I'm a happy girl.

Folks, there's a reason we trust Yelp. 

We ended up here for sheer curiosity. And because I really wanted pasta/pizza/cheese/more cheese and if you're going to eat pasta, pizza, and lots of cheese you also need some wine. And if you're going to have some wine you might as well be somewhere swanky. You know so that the world shines extra bright once you've had too much of it (wine). 

The food is delicious. Completely faultless. The menu is interesting the dishes are unique. I got to try rabbit for the first time and it was super tasty! It was a big hefty portion with a tangy creamy wine sauce and I frankly could have eaten the whole thing. Thankfully I was sharing it, so I couldn't. 

The wine list was underwhelming, however the prices were pretty reasonable (as far as markups go). 

The reason this tasty dinner only gets 3 stars from me is just as you will read in every other review...the service is BRUTAL. Not rude, not mean, just really unpolished. I'm fairly certain the only criteria to being hired here is being attractive and young. Our server was totally personable, and totally good looking and that's where it stopped. They put a carafe of water on your table but never once topped the waters off for us. They "auction" food. They look stressed. I mean it's not bad they're not bad people. They just aren't experienced servers. There's a reason being a professional server is a distinguished career! It takes practice, skill, and passion. 

This restaurant is 5 stars but it's operating at 3 stars because they're not putting the time or effort into service. It's kind of a shame.

Came in to get my tire patched after I found a nail in it. I was told the service would be done in about an hour since they were pretty busy, but that was okay since it was lunchtime. I just got something to eat while I waited.

The service was actually completed in less than an hour (about 30 minutes) which was surprising but pretty great. I left the tire store with my tire all patched up and was pretty happy with the speed of service.

The people here were really nice and the price tag wasn't too hefty. It was $30 to get my tire patched. For buying tires and miscellaneous service this place seems pretty good.

We had a ton of fun sampling various Greek pastries and cookies. We are not experts but we can assure you, they are delicious! This was not the standard baklava spread! Instead, there were sweet and savory phyllo-based pastries which included feta cheese, spinach, fruit, etc. The definitely Greek proprietor kindly and patiently answered our questions but we ended up trying five items. 

They also had multiple kinds of fresh bread but we didn't get a sandwich, instead focusing on the pastries. Our espresso drinks were ok but I wouldn't say they were the best. They also didn't have soy or almond milk. I guess in Greece, it's go cream or go home.

As for the selection, we arrived in the afternoon so some items were sold out. On one hand, this was a bummer. But, it's great to know they are made fresh every day! There is a simple solution I suppose... Go earlier!

As for the location, it was truly spotless. We sat inside in air conditioned comfort while the local Greek population sat outside chatting, smoking, and enjoying the day!

I am SO glad that I waited for Origami to get settled in before I tried it.

On the night that we went it wasn't crowded at all and the service was great! We were seated at a booth and after looking over the menu, we decided to order the salmon sashimi, the tiger roll and the margarita roll.

The salmon sashimi was really fresh and cut thick. This might sound silly, but I liked that it was cut into an even number of pieces so that each person gets their fair share. The margarita roll was excellent was reminiscent of the margarita rolls I had had at other sushi places. By far the star of the meal was the tiger roll. I can't find a menu, so I can't find the exact ingredients, but it was SO GOOD.  Like... so good I might order two the next time I go. I could have eaten the entire thing on my own!

Origami is a little more expensive than other sushi places, but the atmosphere and service was great and the food was excellent. I will definitely be back!

This spot is one of me and my man's regular haunts, as he is an avid bowler. It's not as showy and sophisticated as the North Bowls of the world but for us it's close to home and has everything we need. I've never had to wait for a lane here either so that's a plus. 
Brunswick has a nice bar with reasonably priced drinks. We usually get a pitcher of PBR which runs us about $15. 
Also on site is laser tag and an arcade. I've never participated in either of these attractions but people who do always look like they're having fun! 
There's also a fire pit with cozy looking chairs around it which is a nice touch. 
You can almost always bowl at a discounted rate if you sign up for their emails, by the way. 
This spot is more than adequate for our bowling needs and comes recommended by this yelper!

In the way of word association, when host/owner DK Kelly asked "How was everything?" as our party of four departed, the single word that popped to my tongue was "Extraordinary!".  Wiith that exclamatory emphasis.  Each element of this little jewel of a French bistro created by husband DK, who manages front of house, and wife Sara, who is the Chef running the kitchen, adds up to perfect.  Being fans of the Kelly's earlier Boise venture, remarkable sandwich eatery 'bleubird', we arrived at Petite 4 with lofty expectations.  Expectations were exceeded on every level for charming hospitality, artful ambiance, splendid service and wonderful food.

BOTTOM LINE:  The English noun restaurant is derived from the French verb restaurer - to restore.  As in to restore the spirit.  And so it does to dine at Petite 4.  It is joy filled.  Go!

 A TIP:  reservations are essential if you want table seating and they take calls for reservations only between 3-5pm on Tu-Sat.  

HOSPITALITY:   DK makes gracious hospitality seem effortless.  It is a gift.  The charm of "all are welcome" starts from the time reservations are made and continues through being greeted at the door as if you are the special ones they have been waiting for as you are escorted to your table.  Lovely to be made to feel welcome like that.

FOOD: Ooh-la-la!  Each bistro-inspired dish is a feast for the taste buds and delightfully plated in feast for the eyes.  Portions are ample.  Something we learned on our first visit when four of us shared two starters and each ordered a seafood dish individually followed by two shared desserts is we would have been better to share a couple of those seafood dishes between us because we were full to the gills. Whether you like to order dishes to share or prefer your own dish to savor, this is the place.  From my seat I could see Chef Sara Kelly and her kitchen team working to create fabulous food. Imagine the skill needed to be able to produce this kind of excellence five days week!

SERVICE:  EJ made wonderful food taste even better through the quality of her service in striking the exactly right balance of professional, knowledgeable and friendly.  She clearly loves her job and made us love our experience there.  She could answer our questions about the restaurant, the menu and also those we asked about ingredients in various dishes.  Her timing of plates to the table was perfect.  Her handling of the wine service for both bottles was expert (and she was gracious when some was spilled by us and needed cleaning).  We felt extremely well tended but never rushed or hovered over.

MENU: Cleverly and logically arranged at the same time to make it both fun to read and easy to follow for understanding all a-la-carte options.  The only difficult thing is choosing among excellent alternatives and leaving room for dessert. (Lemon meringue pie has true French meringue!)   Daily specials offered separately.  Prices run @$3 - $22 regular menu and specials.  See menu link here.  http://eatatpetite4.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/DinnerMenu_FINAL.pdf 

LIBATIONS: Good wine list with several by glass (@ $8-11) and many by bottle (@ $30-78) from both domestic and European vintners.  We chose bottles but noted the couple next to us received generous by-glass pours.  Top quality stemware is used.  Being old winos...umm long time oenophiles...we appreciate these things.  There are also creative house made sodas, some beers and French Press coffee.  

DESIGN DETAILS:  Every element, from interior to table settings to menu format, is perfectly woven together in the sophisti-whimsy hallmark style of the Kellys with ambiance that nearly says "Bienvenue!" right out loud.  This is loving care translated to the visual.  From the green ceiling, with an artichoke painted on it over the open kitchen, to the gold-colored upholstery on tufted banquette backs and high chairs at bar, to caf√© chairs at tables, to gold and white geometric wallpaper, to round mirrors, to patterned floors, to mismatched flatware, to quality dishware, to bistro cloth napkins, to the pinstriped aprons worn by servers, it is all "aaahh..."somely done.  

SEATING:  9 or 10 standard height two-top tables with banguette backs and cafe chairs on the aisle side that seat maybe 18 - 20.  Another 7 or so upholstered high seats at the bar.  A few backless metal stools tucked at kitchen counter.  Kitchen counter seating is for walk ins.  If you need standard height seating, be sure to ask for a table when you reserve.  

ACCESSIBILITY: ADA parking near front door.  Level in the door and all on one level.   Ample aisle space from door to tables.  Looks like wheelchair space for seating on aisle side of tables. (I have MS so notice.)

LOCATION & PARKING:  Bench neighborhood.  Private lot.

SPECIAL EVENTS:  Introducing monthly European brunches and monthly prix-fixe Sunday dinners. See web site.

Seven Things to know about the Feast of the Seven Fishes Christmas Eve Dinner here:

Uno: Acqua e Farina (Water and Flour), owned by the same owners as Vecchia Osteria, is usually a pizza place, but for Christmas Eve, they transformed into a seafood lover's dream, and like, the number 7, we were lucky to be able to attend!

Due: The menu was small (7 dishes, and actually 10 fishes!) but everything was delicious (yep, we ordered the whole menu for 4 people, and had a LOT of leftovers). Gluttony is clearly my family's favorite of the 7 deadly sins.

Tre: The menu included a calamari and fried smelts appetizer and two gigantic salads (arugula, shrimp, and octopus, and a salted cod and cauliflower salad), lobster ravioli (so good it was the only dish we didn't have leftovers of), a heaping portion of linguine de mare (clams, mussels, calamari, shrimp in spicy red sauce), lastly, a branzino with sauteed spinach and Chilean sea bass with tomatoes and toasted bread to dip (both incredible). For dessert they were out of cannoli but we had a delicious (and surprisingly light) limoncello vanilla cake (tiramisu and a chocolate cake were also available). We were so full, but basically in 7th Heaven.

Quattro: The service was amazing- they coursed out the dishes for us since we were eating family style (definitely recommend doing so), and our waitress told us all about her family's Italian roots and traditions. We started with a complimentary roasted veggie appetizer, and finished with housemade chocolatecello on the house!

Cinque: It wasn't too crowded but they could accommodate parties as large as probably 7 at one table, maybe more. The restaurant can probably seat about 50 max. We called ahead to make a reservation.

Sei: The ambiance was lacking a little bit (bright lights and a pizza place with a big oven...) but we still had such a good time! 

Sette: Don't forget to BYOB!

If you're looking to change up your Christmas Eve traditions (we're not actually Italian) or just trying to avoid cooking for your family on Christmas Eve, I highly recommend it! Buon Natale!

Great service (atypical for Korean restaurants, in my experience) and outstanding food with lots of banchan (small plates) available. I shared BBQ kalbi and bulgogi with a friend. Gas grills are built-into the tables and the prices are average for Korean BBQ. There are specialty dishes that are worth getting like the tofu soup. Spacious interior but dark and cavernous.

I'm more of a Walmart fan. Can't help but notice that both interiors look very similar. Only difference is Walmart is somehow cheaper and friendlier. I only came here because target carried Bose speakers and Walmart doesn't and I wanted these speakers late in the afternoon in a Sunday when the Bose outlet was closed. Overall, this place was ok. They had some expensive stuff like the coolest speakers, soundbars, headphones, quality TVs, cameras, iPads, etc, etc. other than that stuff, I wouldn't come here when I have good old Walmart that's cheaper, open 24/7, and usually carries the same stuff!

NICER THAN SUBWAY FOR BREAKFAST
A much needed cafe to complement lunch at "Cochon Butcher" 2 blocks away. The AM menu is pretty extensive and priced from $7 crepes to $8.50 Eggs Benedict with a Creole hollandaise. The staff is bubbly and hard working; and the the build-out is surprisingly bright (for a parking garage).

THE NEGATIVES:
- lunch is pricey (all sandwiches after tax are over $10, the crab melt will run you $17) and "Two Chicks" can't compete with "Butcher's" price/quality (see my $13, unimpressive 11-shrimp doughy poboy photo);
- it's not counter service! Most caf√©s serving conventioneers/office workers with short windows of time, smartly cut out the server to reduce waits and it eliminates the tip.

75% OF THEIR 5-STARS ARE FROM SPORADIC REVIEWERS
20 of "Two Chicks'" unprecedented 26, 5-star reviews (as of 10/6/15) were from people with less than 10 write-ups. Just sayin...

Bummer. Seriously, it totally bums me out that Half & Half is closed on Monday. Monday is one of my days off, so that is one day less that I get to go enjoy the delectable delights at H&H. I feel so cheated, but once I do get to eat breakfast or lunch here, I'm thankful for my other days off. I'd be hard pressed to choose which meal I like better; breakfast or lunch. I love them both so much. Their famous Bloody Mary with a Fried Pickle garnish goes perfectly with either meal. 

One of my favorite vegetables is Brussels Sprouts and until I came to Half & Half, I would have never thought to put them in a omelette. Now that I have had one, it is so logical. A fresh vegetable, served up with Cheddar cheese creates a delicious overstuffed omelet. The sprouts were saut√©ed perfectly and as a side they served up a side of breakfast potatoes that were fried crisp. I couldn't resist, I had to add a side of bacon. I think next time I'll have them add the bacon to the omelet. This is by far my favorite omelet of all time.

When it's lunchtime at Half & Half, it's time for a burger. I love jalape√±os, on my Mexican food and I love'm as a topping on my burger. H&H slices fresh jalape√±os and mixes them up with caramelized onions.  Then they top the entire burger with cheddar cheese and place it on a  brioche bun with aioli. The final result is a thick and juicy burger with a side of house cut fries. 

Whether it is breakfast or lunch, you cannot go wrong at Half & Half. Just remember, they are closed on Monday and are only open for the first two meals of the day. No dinner is served.

These last two visits I've been seated at the bar and I will say the service was better then when I have been at a table or booth. If you are dining alone or just two of you, I highly recommend that you belly up to the bar. 

When: May 24 & June 8, 2016
Why: Lunch & Breakfast

I was on my way to grab a bite to eat in the Garneau district and I happened to walk by the Seven Drawers. Many a time I have peered in their packed windows while stuck in traffic along the busy and congested 109th St. So for once I thought I would poke my head in. 
What I thought was going to be a jam packed store full of vintage junk and oddities and trinkets, turned out to be a very cleverly purchased store full beautiful wood furniture, and smart decor. There were some exquisite reclaimed wood tables that were huge over sized pieces. Iron decorations, beautiful real Teak candle holders (that are at the top of this girls Christmas list for Santa) but the coolest thing was all the amazing clocks! Old fashioned fans/phones/planes/movie lights (etc) with clocks attached to them. I think I could have found something neat for everyone in my family at this store. I have to say, I was impressed. Oh, and the lady that helped me out was quite lovely (even though she mentioned she hates yelp!) Ha ha, can't win 'em all!

I finally made it to Khyber Pass Pub on a non-beer event day. However, with that draft list, every day is informally a beer event in my eyes. Not to mention, they do have a knack for hosting some pretty killer events, especially surrounding Beer Week in June. 

The bar area was pretty full but not packed so my husband and I were able to find two adjacent seats immediately. We had already staked out our brews on Philly Tapfinder and just needed a quick confirmation from the bartender that they were still available. We were in luck, they were! 

The draft list will obviously vary, but during the time of our visit there it was a total sour-palooza. Jackpot!  US breweries I've been longing to try in addition to some European brews were well represented. I was not disappointed. 

Needing a little snack, we also ordered bowls of the brisket chili and chicken gumbo. Having recently been to NOLA, it wasn't quite the same southern flare, but tasty in its own right. The chili had heaping portions of meat in addition to sour cream, jalapenos and some toasted bread on the side. Likewise, the gumbo had hearty pieces of chicken and didn't skimp on the rice. Neither were super spicy but had a nice flavor. 

The bartenders were efficient, in addition to promoting a chill atmosphere. 

The only thing I didn't enjoy about my experience was the price tag. But that is the price to pay with a stellar, and fairly rare-to-Philly beer selection.

Khyber is amongst the Philadelphia brew scene's finest for sure.

Came here during a recent trip home from FL.  Parking is off street or you can take your chance in the private lot across the street.  The shop was busy with tourists and students but that is to be expected since it was featured on Diners, Drive Ins and Dives.  

There is no "line begins here" sign. You just push in wherever there is space, get someone's attention and place your order. I noticed they had unique flavors like Mexican hot chocolate and lavender honey. After requesting a few samples, I went with a scoop of salted caramel. Creamy and good.  The service wasn't exactly warm and friendly . More like blunt with no personality. The girl hurriedly took our orders and directed us to the cash register. Not exactly tip worthy.  

Overall, a cute little spot to stop in for a snack if you're in the area.


WARNING:
Make sure you bring cash as they do not accept debit and/or credit cards.

You can tell this place is spankin' new. And it really brings the swank. We loved the live music on saturday night. We didn't like the suuuper slooooow service near the bar. The hostess was kind enough to track down our server. But man...crappy service sucks. The pizza tastes great and the bronzino dish was delicious. The ambience in here is completely gorgeous. Perfect date night spot.

Soulard Pet Sitters is a great pet care service located in Soulard.  I have used them on several occasions to walk and care for my dog w.hen I travel or when I'm not home enough to give my dog the attention he needs.  The prices are reasonable and I love the photos they text you of your dog on a walk or involved in different activities.  Nice touch and nice people.  I'd trust them with my dog any day!!

Homemade & gluten free (less the strawberry shortcake flavor), locally owned business... So here's the SCOOP (shameless pun).  

Recommended in a review/post by Jen L, we journeyed over here for a much needed post-Saints vs Falcons Game loss treat.  Much to our delight, the ice cream selections, we tried 80% of them, were truthful in flavor & quite palatte pleasing.  

My choice was the sweet potato flavor, as I'm a loved of the vegetable.  The portion size was generous enough that I had half left once I arrived home, hello that's a 15 minute drive at 'bat out of hell' speed.  

Michael, I guess the owner, nosey me didn't inquire this time, I was too entranced by the mouth full of flavors & my upcoming decision of which ONE to get, was quite pleasant & accommodating as we tasted all but a few of the ice cream treats.  

I'd like to see more signage, as what's there now is swallowed by trees & ALL of Freret Street.  Oh and a square reader or other POS tool for checkout, as of my visit mid-December it was CASH ONLY.

Quick Note: Be mindful of Mr Black Cat that guards the entrance, he's madly friendly & would love a quick rub if you would.

Egg & Cheese Biscuit Sandwich! Get it! The biscuit might be the best biscuit I've tasted. Fluffy, doughy inside, crisp, glaze outside. There has to be some browned butter or grass fed butter involved. So good! The egg is served slightly runny and it's creamy yolk is the perfect compliment to the tomato jam. Heavenly! 

If you want a grown up take on the classic McDonald's Sausage Biscuit. Walk over to Rebar Coffee and Kitchen across the street, order a side of their house made (amazing) sausage patty, then head over to Helena Avenue Bakery and order the Egg & Cheese Biscuit Sandwich. Once you get your sandwich, pry it open, careful not to mess up it's yummy contents and place your Rebar sausage patty inside. Re-wrap and voila!...You have an incredible gourmet, adult take on a childhood favorite! 

I also highly recommend any of their quiches. The crust is legendary! 

Great customer service. Order at the counter and wait for them to call your name or number. Self-serve water, napkins and utensils. Plenty of seating amongst the long farm-style tables and chairs.

I'm really happy to witness the evolution of Helena Avenue Bakery. It started out small, with a very limited menu. Now it is bustling! I love the addition of the glass wall giving eyes to the exhibition bakery. I am excited to try their fresh baked loaves and rolls. It's great to have a local bakery so close to home!

Outside of Old Nelson in 30th Street dishing out a satisfactory cup of La Colombe, Passero's hooks up the best train station cup of coffee hands down. Of course when it rivals the likes of Dunkin, Fourbucks, and Saxby's as competitors that does only say so much at times. But it does help that Passero's provides a good variety, tempting baked goods, service with a smile, and a friendly hipster vibe.

The best deal is by far their flavor and coffee of the day. But they do have a good share of lattes and other drinks to go with the change of the seasons. Really the only flaw to (at least this) Passero's by my book is that its severely limited by being a kiosk in a train station as random and disjointed as Suburban is. Because with the exception of the atmosphere of its environment, and as far as being able to chill and get some work done coffeehouse style from within, Passero's delivers every key thing that I look for when getting my cup of Joe better than most other coffeehouses do.

Every summer my little daughter (who's now 5) and I "play tourist".  Even though we live in Philly - we had never tried the duck boats - and she really wanted to.

We reserved for a Wednesday tour at 4 PM.  It lasted lust over 70 minutes and was GREAT fun.  Our Captain (Crash) was funny and the tour woulda been great for a tourist or someone unfamiliar with Philly.

There were tourists from Brazil, Arizona, Iowa and Florida on our boat.
And since it was not packed we each got our own seat.

Yes, it's pricey, kitschy, touristy and those quackers can me MOST irritating - but if you have little kids this is a fun way to show them the city.

That said - my kid also loved the Double-Decker bus tour.

I have to do a quick update of Edgehill Cafe because after hosting several meetings here, this spot is definitely my favorite coffee shop/cafe in Nashville. Here's the Cliff Note's version:

The location is fairly central for most parties to meet

I HEART the veggie & hummus sandwich ($6) which comes with a fairly large size bag of tater chips

Prices are reasonable for coffee and other refreshments

Not only is the interior spacious, but it offers up many nooks and a plethora of table/desk settings that can accommodate an afternoon of writing or host small or larger size meetings

Love, love, love the furniture 

Music playlist is a nice mixed bag of genres

Staff has ALWAYS been sincerely nice and helpful

If I didn't call East Nashville my home, I would be that annoying girl who lives at the coffee house complete with loud phone conversations, laptop, and my Snuggie.

The Fishin Chicken is possibly my new favorite food truck!

I tried the Fishin Chicken Food Truck for the first time last night. My husband and I split the Crispy Asian Tuna Tacos and the Crab Cake Sliders. Both were mind blowing good and I would definitely order these dishes again. The tuna tacos were served on crispy shells and were packed with fresh ahi tuna, seaweed salad, sesame seeds and an aioli sauce. The crab cake sliders were seared in garlic butter and were served over soft slider buns with Parmesan  coleslaw and  massago. The two sliders aren't super filling so I'd recommend ordering a side of fries for a more filling meal.

The quality of the seafood was so nice and so unexpected for a food truck. The sliders and the tacos set me back $18, but I felt that I could have easily paid double at a sit-down restaurant. 

Hopefully I will cross paths with The Fishin Chicken food truck very soon!

Sundial St. Pete is a great open air dog friendly shopping district in the middle of St. Pete. I love what they have done to it. Previously, it was Bay Walk, which was nice, but needed to be modernized. It also had few remaining open stores. Now it is an upscale, beautiful open area where everyone can just shop, eat, and socialize.  

Locale Market is located here if you want to pick up some food to make, or to eat. They are also opening up a seafood restaurant called Sea Salt, as well as the Ruth Chris Steakhouse.  The movie theater is also located here, as well as some boutiques where you can browse, and have fun spending money.  Here is a listing of what they have to offer - http://www.sundialstpete.com/centerdirectory/

This is a nice addition to downtown St. Pete. Just think, you can paint a perfect Saturday visiting the Downtown St. Pete Farmers Market, strolling the downtown parks such as Straub Park, or taking in a festival at Vinoy Park, visiting the Dali Museum, or Chihuly, and then heading out here for some food, and shopping. What a perfect day!

An expensive, cash-only experience that left me wanting... while the food was good, the service left something to be desired... took twenty minutes to get our drinks, and my rose water was far too strong. But at least they started with the hand-washing, and assumed we wanted (as a large group) the price fixe 7-course meal.

You do best with the lamb here, I think, and the vegetable courses. Everything else, chicken, etc. was... less than enticing. Perhaps it was the messiness with our fingers, but the belly dancer stopping by distracted all of the guys in our group that weren't busy slopping up the food with the bread...

The seats can be a bit crowded for a group larger than 10, but hey, you're here for the food and the ambiance, not the seating, right? ;D

I've encountered Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis (IUPUI) on many occasions throughout my adult life. 

It all began, I suppose, not long after my high school graduation. I'd won a scholarship to University of Indianapolis, but it was obvious the scholarship paled in comparison to the actual tuition. It simply wasn't going to happen. 

Then, I briefly tried going to Indiana University in Bloomington. Let's just say I partied a bit too much. 

Finally, I returned home. 

I don't want to say it has been a long time since I was a student at IUPUI, but back then they were called the "Metros" not the Jaguars and my theater classes were in the Mary Cable Building - an old elementary school with no elevator (and yes, back then it was acceptable). 

While IUPUI was really birthed in 1969, it still hadn't really found its presence in Indiana despite already being the premier urban research college in Indiana. 

I was a theater major and it was at IUPUI where I really discovered my creative voice and even won the collegiate state forensics championship. I was even in the first round of IUPUI trying to have frats (Go Delta Sigma Phi!). 

I enjoyed the campus, though at that time it was entirely a commuter campus. A good amount of the current growth was non-existent. If I remember right, the Mary Cable Building was where the law school is now. 

I was on the Sagamore, the school paper at the time, and even that's gone. 

Over the years, of course, IUPUI has grown astronomically in numbers and influence. It remains the primary urban research college in Indiana and actively teaches a good majority of the residents who work at Riley, IU, and Methodist Hospitals. 

There are over 550 academic study options between IU and Purdue at IUPUI. The school has a much more active sports life and the National Institute of Fitness and Sport is acclaimed and has amazing options for those of us with disabilities. 

IUPUI is also one of the city's premier employers - I've worked here a couple times with it usually being either temporary or contract work. 

I ultimately left IUPUI - partly because I still partied too hard and partly because I just didn't blossom in such a large setting. I ended up transferring to a smaller private college where I truly blossomed, though I really appreciated my time at IUPUI and have enjoyed opportunities to return several times to speak to nursing classes, social work classes, and medical classes about disability. 

I have been a guest speaker at their "Take Back the Night" events and continue to be impressed by the school's growth including building campus housing. 

IUPUI is ideal for someone who wants a more affordable degree here in Indy. The campus is quite beautiful, though it's certainly grown up since my student days. 

I was on campus recently to speak to a class and was amazed that the food options continue to be a bit weaker than you might expect. I also still tend to find parking abysmal, though typically the parking garages work for both campus and the hospitals. 

I'm also a chaplain now and occasionally visit the hospitals and always have a good experience. 

As a fun fact, there are tunnels underneath the hospitals that are very old school. They are generally quite safe, but still kind of creepy in a fun way. 

IUPUI also offers a really good counseling center and I'd rate it second, to Ball State, in terms of accessibility for students with disabilities.

Inside the Food Court of International Plaza and Bay Street (Mall), this sandwich shop delivers a great sandwich worthy of the name. What more can you say other than if you like sandwiches (like Joey from Friends), then definitely try this place.  I tried the LTO "The Feast" which had a mix of meats and toppings and was just delicious.  The guy taking my order answered my question on what was a better choice and he didn't make a mistake.

Promote the Earl of Sandwich to Duchess/Duke, Princess/Prince, or even Queen/King of sandwich.  It's worthy of the new title.

You know how every town has an Italian restaurant that consistently churns out awesome food and is your go-to staple?  That's Bruno's.  There are three main parts to this establishment; a BYO restaurant where you can have a nice dinner, a take-out type section where you can also enjoy a quick slice and a liquor store.  

Take-out is probably my favorite option.  You can call ahead to place your order, run into the liquor store to grab the perfect bottle of red or white, then pick up your dinner.  Dinners come with a roll and a pretty large side salad, and the entrees are huge (without compromising on quality) and delicious.  I highly recommend the pasta with clams and red sauce.  The red sauce is homemade with plum tomatoes and fresh garlic.  Soooooo good!

The food is great but the portions are silly small.  Everything is very high quality and the service is perfect(my drink was refilled within seconds of completing it).  The atmosphere is small, quiet, and rife with people celebrating various milestones and intimate special occasions.

I'd recommend the spinach Gnocchi and any of their pasta dishes.  I tried the goat dish and it delivered a unique texture that I'd say is somewhere in between high quality lamb and duck.  Sadly, I left a little hungry after an appetizer, entree, and dessert(but that's to be expected at gourmet establishments).

A-OK! 

At first glance this place looked like a Goodwill. 
An upscale Salvation Army. 

Racks and racks of clothing and more clothing made Scholarshop appear a bit cheap and items a-dime-a-dozen. As i began to browse i was quickly drawn in by the garments. Beautifully made clothing, and name brands hiding inside the numerous racks. 

The dressing rooms were plenty though a bit on the uncomfortable side, with hospital lighting and no real tact to style, but hey, you can't have it all. 

I tried on a handful of things, only one of which was a keeper. A Nick Cave type top (Nick Cave the visual artist by the way, not the singer, i hear there is more than one famous Nick Cave), anyway this top was full of sequin and color. A bit overpriced at $25 but i liked it enough to bite the bullet so i caved (pun intended).

It was cold so i also bought a pair of black gloves with elegant black beading ($10), made me think of the 1930s though they were obviously modern and in brand new condition. 

I checked out the jewelry on the case by the register and saw some pieces i really wanted, but again, overpriced and didn't need them. 

They have a large selection of Brand Names, including a whole section of St. John's clothing at relatively reasonable prices. 

A little chaotic to browse. So much stuff you can become overwhelmed and not sure where to begin, or where to end, or when you've seen it all. 

Parking lot for customers is a plus!
Ladies behind the counter were patient and friendly, though service was a bit slow.

Note: Don't come here expecting authentic vintage garments from the ages, but do expect to find quality brand named items at slightly above average prices in great condition.

This was, by far, my favorite restaurant experience in New Orleans.  I came for dinner and man oh man did I feast!  I'm so glad I looked at Yelp's pictures for this spot prior to my visit, otherwise I would've totally overlooked the flammenkuchen appetizer.  It's BACON PIZZA.  Get it, eat it...ALLLLLLL.  Best thing on the menu.  The fried brussels sprouts are pretty bomb too, and as for the pate, it can easily feed four people and it's so buttery and delicious, it'll be gone in a flash!

Now, no trip to New Orleans is complete without having some good ol' shrimp n' grits, and they were good indeed!  What was really nice is that I was splitting this dish with someone, and the kitchen served us two plates!  Great gesture!

You need to get the steamed chocolate dessert.  It's kind of like a mousse, but thicker and a bit more cake-y, and for someone who isn't the biggest fan of ice cream...SALTED CARAMEL FOR THE WIN!

Visting my best friend, Sandy, we decided to hit up a spot for brunch before heading back to Miami. The place is a casual and welcoming place. Walking in you immediately see the buffet set up. The brunch buffet comes with an omelet station, carving station, ice cream station that has a freshly waffle bowls. Also, there was another station with, scrambled eggs, sausage, bacon, french toast and much more yumminess. Basically there was a little bit of everything including some delicious brie, oysters and peel and eat shrimp. My inner fatty took over and I basically tried a little bit of everything. The buffet also comes with your choice of 2 mimosas, bloody marys, or screwdrivers included in the price. After 2pm they are just 2 bucks! The quality isn't like oh my gosh out of this world, but I love the fact that you have so much to choose from, it is yummy and the price is fantastic for what you get. The only slight complaint I would have is that I had to hunt down the waitress for our check. We ended up waiting a while to get her attention. Other than that, I really enjoyed the place. They have a large bar and the outdoor area look cozy and fun to hang out at for maybe a sunday sunday of sports watching.

This hospital is GORGEOUS...the parking is free and they offer free valet parking. The staff at the information desk are friendly and helpful. The Pre Registration staff is very friendly and helpful. If you pay your co-pay up front they will give you a 20% discount. Which was awesome. 
The hospital has a beautiful Atrium area that looks like the interior of a fancy hotel. The staff at the registration area was very quick and helpful, and friendly. We had to go for a spinal tap or lumbar puncture and they were so informative. They took the time to explain the procedure and what  to expect, they answered our questions and we didn't seem rushed. I would definitely go to this hospital again. 
I loved this hospital, it is gorgeous and peaceful...

My steakhouse experience and meal at Butcher and Singer was one of the best steakhouse experiences and dinners I've had in a long time, if not of all time. It was restaurant week as well, so let's squash all of those "bad service" and "small portions" thoughts out the gate. 

Let me start with service. Ricky was an A-list server for sure. He was upbeat, professional and attentive. He had a knack in customer service, which stood out in his interactions with my table and the tables around us. I felt like he played to my group, but in a good way; a way that made us feel like he understood a little bit about us as customers. 

The food was also on it's A-game. My husband and I wanted to split everything except for our entrees (where we both opted for the same thing), but had to deal with my pesky cough and a fear of spreading germs. No problem- Ricky accommodated our appetizers by splitting the butternut squash bowl of soup into two smaller cups. For the dessert, he provided sharing plates and a knife so we could divide and conquer. 

The butternut squash soup was rich, creamy and delectable. The maple glazed bacon was packed with flavor, and had very little fat for bacon, so it was meaty. The meat, oh the meat. The filet was by far one of the best filets I've ever had. It was cooked to a perfect medium rare, but still had a warmth too it. I go to a steakhouse for the meat and was not disappointed. It was 8 perfect ounces of melt-in-my-mouth enjoyment. The lemon tart was good, but the chocolate torte was where it was at. 

The ambiance of this steakhouse was top notch with class with the high ceilings and majestic d√©cor. We couldn't help ourselves but to look at the grandiose chandeliers from time to time.   

We were happy from the moment we entered Butcher and Singer through our final bites and departure. Every aspect of our experience and meal was excellent, and something I would consider as perfection.

I went out of my way to visit this store and I am so glad I did! Philadelphia Independents is a small maker shop located in Old City near a few other stores and maybe a block away from Old City Coffee. The shop features a vibrant selection of local artisans, handmade makers and more. The owners have curated a small but mighty collection of jewelry, artwork, candles, home decor, baby gifts, accessories, greeting cards, and more.

The shop is small but filled with lots of great treasures. I absolutely loved their selection of local gemstone jewelry. I purchased a beautiful quartz crystal necklace made by a Philadelphia artist that is just beautiful! Shopping local is so important, and you can never beat the quality of something handmade with so much love. Supporting local is the only way to shop.

The shop owner was present (I feel bad I forget her name) but very excited to talk about her store. They also had a great selection of unique cards and baby gifts. If you needed to assemble an impressive gift, you could absolutely do it here with ease! If I lived in the area, this would be my go-to spot for original and thoughtful gifts that sparkle. They also carry Philadelphia-branded items like pillows, mugs, etc. You can also shop their items online with shipping, which is amazing! You're going to love this shop.

Popped in last weekend and was very pleased with their facility. The lounge and office area was very clean and the staff that I dealt with were all friendly and to the point.

They saw me very quickly, I think I had to wait about 5 minutes before getting to speak with the nurse and from there it took about 15 minutes to see the doctor. No complaints with their assessment or treatment. The only thing that sucked was that they didn't send the prescription directly to the pharmacy. Instead, I got a paper copy. Unfortunately, when I arrived to CVS St around 845pm, the pharmacist couldn't read it so they had to call back and clarify everything. Luckily, Premier was still open and they were able to catch the doc. If they hadn't been open, I probably would have been a bit pissed off since I wouldnt have been able to get my meds for another 12 hours.

Anyway, everything worked out well and I'm thankful there's such a nice urgent care option in this part of Bucks. Four stars.

My favorite thing about Carnival is costuming, and my least favorite thing is being hit in the face with beads by a drunk rider that thinks they're the next Nolan Ryan. 

Chewbacchus combines my love of epic costuming and throws, that aren't hummed at my head but given to me as if it were made just for me, whether it's a spray painted peanut or a small baggy of multi-colored "Unicorn Bacon" (can someone verify that this isn't a drug?). You will go home with the most unique, weird, best trinket-y treasures that'll rival any set of beads you'll catch at the float parades. 

This intergalactic krewe meanders past my friend's house in an area where not many step out to watch this band of misfits, so it's like we're watching our own parade of wookies, Na'vi, zombies, and unicorns. The makeup and costumes were amazing, and I think the fact that this parade runs at night gives it that much more mystique than if it were during the day. My krewe also had easy access to a bathroom and drink refills fo' free! Sorry I'm not revealing this specific location.  

Even with the lack of crowd, we were still given quite a show with my favorite "floats" being a Falcor wagon and a bubble/smoke/light show mobile. The groups were pretty spread out occasionally, but I think this gives you time to take in the different sub-krewes and really enjoy them. 

I can't wait to see this parade again next year. I need to bring a little purple Crown Royal bag to put all my treasures in! Till next year, IKOC!

After a bunch of hype we had heard that Chef Ron's has the best gumbo ever, we were SUPER excited about it. As we approached closing time on a Thursday night, we decided to try our luck at a table for 6. However, it was so busy and the restaurant is pretty small so we ended up ordering to go. 

The gumbo was not bad. But it also was a bit underwhelming. After perusing the menu, we settled on ordering just two of the three gumbo options - seafood and the Mumbo Gumbo. We also got an order of boudin balls, two orders of jambalaya, a side of Mac and cheese and a bread pudding. 

The boudin balls were great! Even after taking our food to go, they were still hot and fresh and crispy. It didn't come with the sauce that it usually comes with, though, per the pictures on Yelp. Even so, they tasted pretty good. However, the classic seafood gumbo was underwhelming and lacked the flavor we were expecting. The mumbo gumbo had a bit more flavor, thanks to the addition of some andouille sausage and chicken. A big mistake was getting our food to go because our gumbo didn't come with enough rice. We got two large servings of gumbo, we thought we would have gotten a little more rice than two small containers. The jambalaya was the biggest disappointment. I wouldn't recommend. It was not the right consistency, a little wet, although maybe it was due to us taking it to go. It wasn't flavorful and the pictures were definitely better than the taste. The Mac and cheese was just Mac and cheese, nothing special. But the bread pudding! We should have gotten 5 orders of this, and 86'd the jambalaya and mac and cheese. 

Overall, Ron's was a pretty underwhelming experience. Maybe the way to go is to eat in the restaurant - reviews have been raving about service, which may complete a 4-Star dining experience.

I am not much of a fast food eater - and I don't touch hot dogs, but on a whim I ordered a (nearly $10) patty melt here - a calorie bomb for sure - but it was tasty.  Just too greasy for me.

I skipped any fried sides and dared not order a (1000 calorie) shake.

I think my cholesterol quotient for 2021 has been achieved.

Pizza and Chinese food - weird combination, but it works.

My husband was furious at me for not taking him here earlier. To be honest, I had no idea this place existed until a coworker, Jonathan T., visited and myself and Brett N., my boss/last Tampa Bay CM, came up with places to take him. The email exchange went like this:

J: I'm planning to eat healthy while in Tampa.
B: We need to go get Chinese pizza.
J: Hell yeah we do.

When I brought up the ridiculousness of this exchange, I was basically met with, but it's Chinese pizza! Who was I to argue, I wasn't planning to eat healthy, so we put it on our list to check out. 

Saturday afternoon, about 12:30 p.m., and we are the only table in the restaurant. If you have little kids, they only have one high chair. I was victorious in getting it and I heard families after me ask and be told there were no more high chairs. It's a small place, so the one high chair thing isn't the most ridiculous thing ever, just a little surprising. 

It's in a strip mall and the restaurant itself is a little jank, but the food is legit. They make fresh dumplings on the weekend so we had to try that. We also got a scallion pancake and this stuffed with chive dish that I could never understand what the waitress was calling it. Then we finished this order with a Mapo Tofu pizza, Chicken Terriyaki pizza, and General Tso pizza. 

I couldn't try the dumplings because they had pork, but everything else was amazing. Admittedly, the Mapo Tofu pizza was everyone's least favorite, but it was still good. I wasn't a fan because I don't like spicy food. The Chicken Terriyaki and the General Tso pizza were amazing. It has a sweetness to it, even in the crust. The combination just works. They also do not skimp on the cheese. The best part, these pizzas are only $10! For 7 people we walked away paying $70 not including tip and we were stuffed. We basically took home over half of the Mapo Tofu pizza. 

For the price, quality, and novelty, this place cannot be beat. I'm lucky it is about half an hour from my house or else my husband would easily be 10 lbs heavier.

This is a highly shopped store.  The ratio of employees to shoppers does not seem to equate.

That being said, there are reasons to stop in at this Marshall's.  If you can find your size...the prices on SHOES are some of the best around.  Name Brand Men's Athletic Wear is abundant.  Adorable Pet Items and Pet Gifts can be found year round.  Purses seem to be stocked regularly.

You can purchase Gift Cards for Marshall's, TJ Maxx, and Home Goods at this store.

Deanna's is a bit off the beaten path in Lambertville, so the casual tourist may overlook it. But that's okay. Even on a cold, wintry weeknight the place was jammed at 6:30 pm (okay, it was ALMOST the weekend).
Had dinner at the bar with a good friend, and Armand -- barkeep extraordinaire -- took good care of us. Nice selection of wines by the glass here, and 4 beers on tap, in addition to excellent cocktails. The wine is a generous pour, unlike some Princeton eateries I could name. The ambiance at the bar here is very cozy, friendly, and a nice blend of old, rustic Lambertville, and hipster Lambertville.
The menu is mostly skewed toward Italian fare, and they do offer gluten free pasta options if you wish (or need, like moi). I ordered chicken & escarole over GF pasta, with a red sauce. For some strange reason the pasta came out very underdone (almost "crun-chewy") which was a disappointment since the dish looked so delicious, and I was hungry! No problemo, Armand whisked it away, and back to the kitchen it went. I was worried this would cause a long delay, but thankfully, it only took a few minutes, and my dish was back, properly cooked.
A less hungry person might easily have taken half this dish home for the next day, but I scarfed it all down, and left happy & full. 
The prices here are not cheap, for either drinks or food, but you do get a very nice meal, and professional service. As I noted, if something does go awry, they fix it quickly. 
Make the effort to stray off the main drag next time you're in town, and find Deanna's. It's worth the hunt.

So. .. this place is like totally bitchin. 

I've been dying to check this place out because I'm a big fan of Sbraga's but I just couldn't get excited about the dinner menu. Then when I saw they were doing brunch AND there was going to be complimentary champs AND there was going to be live jazz it was basically all I could think/talk about. 

Service was excellent,  the decor was great and the food was well executed and delicious. We split the eggs benny with roast beef and the whitefish/lox bagel.  Both simple, but just delicious.  The champagne and live jazz really took the experience up a notch,  especially the adorable old couple who decided to show off their dancing skills. 

Highly recommend for brunch/a great start to a Sunday afternoon. Go ahead, tease your hair, put on your shoulder pads and check it out.

Hands down the best tasting and most unique espresso I've had. The place may be on the tiny side, but it's such a cool place to hang out, people watch, read a book and just take in the moment. The menu is simple and the drinks are craft. You won't be disappointed with this neighborhood gem.

Not a very large convenience store, but it's an easy stop when traveling the I-4 route from Orlando to Tampa or vice versa.  

You'll find the usual snacks, sodas, beer, cigs, etc. here.  

Gas is a bit on the high side here, but that's expected just off the interstate in the middle of nowhere.

Restrooms (the reason we stopped) are large and clean.

Crap.  I'm still wiped out from being sick all weekend and now it's Sunday night.  I just don't know what I want to eat.  I do know that I want fast, cheap and NOT greasy burgers or lame sammiches.  

"Hey lets try Hong Ko.....no, that food just was not right the last time."  Oh wait, we liked Panda Express the last time we went, and we do have that cool little coupon for a free "entree".  Alright.  Let's do that.

Vroom.

I dunno.  Maybe I just have really low expectations from Chinese places because this place does it pretty good.  The food all seems to be slathered in sugary substances..but hey, it's fast food.   However the thing that puts these guys on a four star is their chow mein.  It's got like 30% cabbage and veggies!  It's also not "spaghetti" but real nice chow mein noodles!

Right now they are serving some sorta Thai Chicken.  Good for fast chinese food standards.  NO MSG!  Also they have decent egg rolls.  Clearly they are mass produced but again.  Low priced chinese fast food.

They serve Pepsi products.

Service.   Hmmm.  It's a little weak, but really.  It's FAST chinese food, like what you get at a mall.  But a little better.  I also like that you can actually see all the food being made behind the counter.

So would I go back?  Definitely.  Dinner for three people for less than $20!

Would I recommend them to a friend?  Yep.  In that category (low priced chinese fast food) I can't think of anyone better.  Can you?

Not too long ago, I began volunteering to help feed the homeless.  The rule of thumb is you make it / buy it, you serve it yourself.  It's very gratifying and humbling, so much so that I recently convinced a bunch of my friends and co-workers in helping me do this on a monthly basis.

In December, we held our first ever Team Sparkle feed and for whatever reason, we decided that we'd do hot dogs and side dishes.  After checking out various Wal-marts and other "cheapie" grocery outlet type stores, we found out that this Win-co had by far the best prices, beating over everybody else by a few cents.

And a few cents is a lot when you are buying 300 hot dogs and hot dog buns!

Humm....So if some of you would remember my check in's on my many SF nites and wonder if I had a problem, well I know some of you we're suprised to realize I didn't, and in fact I worked in a club or two at one point of time. For some of yous..this is your first time hearing about it. Now lets skip forward and let me tell you the tale of the "Gentlemans Club" with two names. Is this place "Platnum Dolls" or is it "Peppermint Hippo?" well it forsure is the other mint and a whole different animal if you get my drift..only some will get what I ment about that statement lol. But the entertainment here was indeed on a different level and I have to say that for birthday festivities, on a "bronze, silver, or gold" scale this one is definitely "platnum" status. Seeing I don't venture to these establishments too often anymore, (Not that we could even if we wanted too in the last year or so) but this time was a celebration and I needed some.."therapy" yet let's just run with that. Now let me tell you why "Peppermint" with always be a cool "Hippo" in my book..

"Peppermint Hippo"
Location - Reno, Nv
Price - $25.00 x5
Entertainment - Well, let's just say money was spent :)

Peppermint Hippo Reno:
The "Peppermint Hippo" is a fairly newer brand in the nightlife industry. The cartoon "South Park" did parody the name in reference to the Deja Vu owned "Spearmint Rhino" (my pun from earlier) and this club is new to Reno..kinda. Even the staff here is getting use to the new moniker and the comparisons to the other minty animal club. Reno has it's options for Gentlemans Club/Cabarets in the area, but this one was a no brainer from my initial call to check on accomodations for my homies and I. The hostess on the phone here was a lot more friendly as compared to two other similar establishments I called and they were nice enough to make sure my party had a spot reserved for our visit upon arrivial.

We arrived and received some of the best service I've experienced in a while in this type of establishment and we even were given a cocktail waitress to tend to our table. The main thing about "Gentlemans Clubs" is making sure the patron is happy, the drinks are good and the entertainment aspect of the establishment is top notch. I would step out on a limb and say they knocked it out of the park in every area. Like if I lived in Reno, this would be a place I would definately like to work for....not for the reasons that some may be thinking. The DJ wasn't annoying as some could get and the..entertainment for the night was indeed entertaining. The lighting matched the overall theme of the club although outside....it goes back to that little tale of two clubs thing (Signage still says Platnum Dolls). I will say at the end of my visit, I was satisfied and the impression left was pretty good.

Overall:
"Peppermint Hippo" is a pretty nice establishment. It's got everything you would expect for the type of business it is. The service was supurb, the venue itself was very well kept and classy, and the overall vibe is just what I was looking for being a visitor to a establisment that is similar to ones I've worked for in the past. I would recommend this club to anyone looking to have a good evening out with friends. If you're a creepazoid however....don't go here killing the vibe. I would be visiting this club of two names again in the near future.

Costumes right next to a giant liquor store? All within 5 miles of my house? Life is good...

Johnnie Brocks is the go-to store in St. Louis for all kinds of holiday attire. On my most recent trip, I came here for some St. Paddy's accessories and a pinup costume. Random, I know! When you work a lot of events, you tend to have a need for strange things... 'tis my life!

During Halloween season, the costume selection is much more expansive. But you can still find most of what you'd need here all year 'round. Found some fun green sunglasses for March 17 and a cute little sailor getup for a burlesque show tomorrow night. 

The gals who work here don't mess around - they will get you in and out quickly. Just be careful and don't feel rushed because they don't refund your purchase, it's store credit only.

This is the best restaurant in Lansdale.  Their red curry is fantastic.  Their green curry is fantastic.  Their coconut soup is fantastic.  Their $8.95 lunch special is fantastic, as it gets you a soup, appetizer(or salad) and entree.  I love Nadia Thai.

So why the 2 stars?

Because today I got a takeout order for myself and two coworkers.  When I arrived back at the office to display the bounty of my lunch run, I noticed there was no rice.  I called them up and the interaction went something like this:

NADIA THAI WORKER - Hello Nadia Thai.
BRAD - Hi.  I just got a takeout order from you guys.  Two people here got the red curry lunch special and there was no rice.  I'm a 20 minute drive away and won't have time to come by and get it before work starts again.
NADIA THAI WORKER - Oh I'm sorry about that.  If you'd like, I can give you two free orders of rice the next time you come in.
BRAD - Really?  I don't really think I will want two extra orders of rice with lunch next time.  Lunch comes with rice anyways.
NADIA THAI WORKER- Well, how can I keep your business?
Brad - I'll take two free lunches to compensate for the two that aren't acceptable currently.
NADIA THAI WORKER- Hang on I will get a manager
(Hold)
MANAGER - Hello.  I don't think I can give you a free lunch.  I can give you free rice.
BRAD - Look, this is my favorite restaurant in Lansdale.  I definitely want to come back, but I don't think extra rice is sufficient for customer satisfaction in this case.
MANAGER -  The rice is cheap.  It is like a dollar per order.
(the conversation continued and in the end I got 5 bucks off my next lunch after arguing for a while).
--

Thai red curry without rice is like a sandwich without bread.  Let me repeat this because it is the point of my entire review - 
Giving me Thai Curry without rice is the equivalent of giving me a sandwich without bread.

If you give me a sandwich without bread on a takeout order, then I don't want extra bread when I order another sandwich the next time I come into your restaurant.  I want A NEW FREAKING SANDWICH.  The first sandwich was defective.

This problem was compounded by the manager's statement that he's OK giving me extra rice because it was cheap.  This is awesome because it allowed him to articulate the exact cost of what he believed to be my customer satisfaction - 2 dollars.

Let's say I did take him up on his asinine peace offering.  OK, so there we are, two people with a full lunch combo, each with an extra mound of rice that we aren't going to eat because the lunch combo alone is ample food for an adult.  Since we don't eat the extra rice, it ends up being thrown out.  What a waste.

There was a huge discrepancy between Nadia Thai's view of the problem and mine.  They thought I was mad because I did not have two orders of rice.  I thought I was mad because the lunches of myself and my coworker were made less-than-awesome.  They did not owe us rice.  They owed us a great lunch.

The real problem with Nadia Thai is that I freaking love the food and even if they do start spitting on my order, it is probably still the best damn lunch in Lansdale.

Maybe I'm kind of a dick for asking for two lunches, but we are living in a world where Pizza Hut sends out a new delivery driver with a free pizza when they mess up one topping.  I would hope that Nadia Thai would show more class than Pizza Hut when they screw up.

We came on a Sunday night and the place was packed.  The service was great though. We had many different people talking to us and serving us. We loved it!

We ordered the seared tuna salad, cream shrimp pasta penne and
corn and cheese grits.  The tuna salad was very good. The shrimp pasta was creamy and delicious.  The corn and cheese grits actually tasted really good.  I usually dont like grits so I was surprised I enjoyed this dish. It must have been all the butter in the food. Yum!

To be honest, I never knew that this was actually a park.  Because it is mainly concrete and brick structures with a few plants.  Not typically what I would consider a park-like atmosphere.  More like Ybor Centennial Square?

I always thought this location was a central bus hub, or something of the sort.  Mostly due to the amount of homeless folks hanging out here, asking for change, and living out of the public restrooms.  There are some covered areas, maybe where someone living in the area would want to sit and rest under the covered plaza, or a place for teenagers to gather in groups and harass the crap out of people at night.  Live chickens also live in this square, and you will see them walking around from time to time.

The space is ideal for festivals and outdoor events, that is probably why the market sets up here every weekend.

Across the street, there are parking lots that are free and open to the public during the days on the weekend.

Like most urgent care centers, your experience depends on whichever doctor is there that day. One time, I was explaining to the doctor about my cold and cough, and he said, "So, do you have a cough?" 

?!?!?! 

But then there was another time when I saw a doctor here who really listened and explained things to me. Like I said, it just depends on who you get. It's a mixed bag. 

I never really have to wait too long to see someone. The last time I visited, I was in and out in about an hour. That sounds like a long time, but considering I didn't make an appointment, it could have been worse. The facilities are clean and there is a lot of seating. I've never seen more than maybe five people here at one time, though. It's a decent urgent care to visit.

Burger Up didn't disappoint again as the fantastically delish Marathon Burger ($10) satisfied my hunger! The blend of black bean and quinoa is a textural home-run (which isn't always the case with veggie based patties) with toppings that include the basics lettuce, tomato, and red onion. For non-vegans, the cilantro lime creme fraiche is a nice touch. 

TIP: You may request any toppings such as jalapenos or other sauces to customize your burger! 

I opted for the steamed spinach ($1 extra) due to my current health kick but was salivating over the french fries that the rest of the table ordered. 

Service was great as they accommodated our impromptu birthday party of nearly 12 and even moved seating to make it work for us. Food was efficiently served too.

Keep in mind that you are paying a bit of a premium for a quality experience made from quality ingredients. If you're seeking a quick and dirty burger, proceed to drive-thru a fast-food chain. 
Burger Up is for consumers who adore food!

***This is a nice National Car Rental that has two great pluses that are not available at every National Car Rental--a convenient location that is directly attached to the terminal (no need for a shuttle like most airports) and an interesting selection of vehicles in their Executive Aisle (standard National selection like Nissans, Chevys and Hyundai vehicles but also Toyota Camrys and even VW sedans and Buick SUVs); there was very friendly service at checkout; the staff at rental return was friendly (FYI, she thoroughly checked out the vehicle)***

I do not believe this rental car agency has any parking spaces available if you just need to stop in.

Reading Terminal Market was the second stop my boyfriend and I made on our first day at Philadelphia. We were starving and it was lunch time so we decided to grab lunch from Beck's Cajun Cafe. 

The women behind the counter were very nice and were willing to let you sample some of their foods. I sampled the Blackened Chicken Alfredo which I really liked so I decided to order that. The Blackened Chicken Alfredo was creamy and tasted like your usual pasta with Alfredo sauce. Half way through the Alfredo, it became spicy because they sprinkled a tad of red pepper powder. I couldn't handle the spice.
