My boyfriend really liked the sample of Jambalaya so he ordered the a Cajun Meatloaf Platter with Jambalaya, and Corn bread, I was able to try a little bit of everything. The Jambalaya was quite spicy, couldn't handle it. The meatloaf was moist and tasty. I really liked the corn bread because it was moist, not too sweet, and had a great taste to it.

I didn't feel too well throughout the day after having the food. I'm sure the other foods here are very good, but maybe Cajun food isn't for me.

I always hate to be a debbie downer, but I'm not sure if you other folks are out of your mind or if I just happened to visit on a really bad day.  It was busy as fuck and the food came out super duper slow.  First I asked for 1lb of crawfish, but those bad boys are out of season. Not J's fault so no worries. Instead I went with fried crab claws and a soft shell crab boat, which is really just a soft shell crab on a buttery toasted po'boy roll split in half.  Verdict on my food- salty as sailor who's been at sea for years and years.  Not good.  The crab claw portion was fairly small and the crab taste got lost in the batter.  The soft shell crab didn't fully get eaten since I couldn't handle all that salt. 

The other bad news was my friend who first ordered the jambalaya (I think).  Dude told her they were out, so she ordered a shrimp wrap (why the fuck would you order that when in New Orleans for a weekend, I have no fucking clue). 5 minutes later dude came back to our table to tell her they were out of that as well. He said the only things available were shown as samplers on the counter.  Not good, since the samples look unappetizing as hell. Whomever thought that was a good idea is sorely mistaken. She settled for BBQ shrimp.  6 or 7 shrimps with the heads on.  She said it was decent. 

All in all, I will not be recommending this place to friends.  Not worth the time it takes to get your food nor the food that is delivered.

Yum! I love a good bowl of Pho and this place does it right!

I met a friend here for lunch and was excited to add another place to my "NOLA Pho" list. We started with a plate of the pork tacos. The pork was tender, tasty and delicious. It was cooked in a typical Vietnamese fashion and it was quite tasty.

I also decided to the "combo" pho which comes packed with New York strip, brisket and meatballs. WOW. This was such a delectable bowl! They were not stingy with the meat at all and the entire serving was huge! The broth held a lot of flavor and didn't leave the meat to do all of the "flavor" work (as it sometimes does).

The atmosphere here is pretty casual. We stopped in late on a Saturday afternoon and there were only a few other people in the place. Unlike some other Vietnamese places, Mint serves alcohol and even has a happy hour Tuesday through Saturday.

I will definitely return to Mint for a tasty bowl and some apps!

I went in to Big Lots real quick to pick up some laundry detergent because Big Lots usually has  competitive prices on laundry detergent and other household items. The store was very clean an organized. Every employee had masks on.  All of the staff, from the people stocking the shelves to the cashier, were friendly and professional.  As I walked around the store, I was asked several times if I needed assistance. They had markers on the floor indicating  where 6 feet apart would be and had signs all around the store on the shelves with friendly reminders that we should socially distance to keep ourselves and others safe. You can buy online and pickup curbside and that's really helpful since we're going through this pandemic. The one thing I would say is you should bring your own sanitary wipes because they don't wipe down the carts or the little carriers so you can social distance all you want but if you touch that surface where somebody else was sick then those germs now belong to you too :-) So just give yourself some added protection, keep those wipes on hand. Which by the way,  you can buy at Big Lots! Big Lots has everything. I even picked me up some more Cafe Bustelo, cereal, and sarsaparilla :-)

Note:  No credit cards.  Also they close at 10 or 10:30 on weekdays.

I stopped in after the place I wanted to go to was closing at 8 PM.  It was 7:40 PM and I needed dinner and a quiet place to take a 1 hour conference call.

The young peppy (gorgeous) server was attentive and kind.
I did not get the $3.89 breakfast (served all day) deal - but that is alot of food and I will consider it when I want breakfast.

Mashed potatoes are from a box (so the server said) so I got a baked potato, ffrozen green beans and a surprisingly OK steak dinner.  Plus a large diet coke with Vanilla syrup in it.  (They can also put cherries in your soda).

Very reasonable CASH only prices.
Dated decor - but I bet it's fun when you are wasted on a Friday or Saturday night.

It's been here for YEARS.

There are so many options in the area to grab lunch and I think you need to step up your game. I ordered off of grubhub and maybe you should get that menu updated as well..

What I ordered:
Susie's Deluxe Salad
Baby spring mix, grilled chicken, bleu cheese, craisins, glazed pecans & green apple slices (sounds delish!!)
and to meet the $10 min I also got the garlic knots.

What I got: some sad spring mix with mostly romaine, barely there not good bleu cheese, maybe a piece of a squished avocado?, dry chicken that wasn't grilled today, a bland egg quartered, grape tomatoes, and the Italian dressing is a thick glob.

The sauce with the garlic knots is pretty good. The knots themselves are decent, but why are they swimming in a 1/2 inch of oil?? 

Usually restaurants around here say 30 to 45 mins for delivery. I ordered at 11:20 and delivery came around 12:25. I was so hungry and I'm still hungry because I can't eat this salad.

Would I order here again? I'm sorry, but no.

***********************update
I appreciate the owner reaching out to me. It shows he really cares about his business.
I did have two co-workers mentioned they had gotten takeout within the past two weeks and thoroughly enjoyed what they had, so maybe today was an off day for them.

The best time to visit Bahama Breeze is definitely in the afternoon. While they have call ahead seating, peak times still mean waiting a long time for a table. Going in the afternoon is just more relaxed in my opinion.

I've been to this location a handful of times and have never had a bad experience. The buttermilk chicken sliders dish is my go-to, as I'm not a big fish eater, but my boyfriend loves the fish tacos.

Hoping to visit again soon!

I love me some Philly. 

Sure, we've got gogo dancers here in NYC. And yea, we've got bacon mac 'n' cheese. But then again, I don't know where I can eat that and watch a bare ass jiggle and keep my appetite. Love the 60's inspired throwback dancers shakin' what their mama gave 'em on the lit stage blocks here. Throw in some awesome music, fans blowing everyone's hair back and it is instant music video time. 

And then I find out that drinks are $4 and I figure that I'll have to make a pilgrimage here at least every few months. Yep.

Remember when you were younger, and all of the time you had ahead of you was yours, and you would go to bookstores and CD shops and just walk around and browse for hours? Half Price Books is like that place of your youth, except everything is discounted, and the books and the CDs (and DVDs, and games, and other things) are all together in one store. 

This particular Half Price Books is neatly organized, and it's easy to find what you're looking for. They even have an entire section just for kids toys and kids games. The prices for these things are really good, so I'm going to have to remember to visit when I'm looking for a birthday gift for a kid.

They also have a moderate section with graphic novels, most of which look new or almost new.

Because we are in the midst of a pandemic, I should mention that masks are required when you're inside the store. They also have signs on each aisle that suggest that only one person stand in the aisle at a time.

I've been a fan of Num Num Boba since I first learned about them from a dear friend. The business owner and her story are awesome, and they make a damn good boba drink too! 

They've got a wacky menu with some awesome combinations. If you're a fan of these drinks, you'll literally never get through it all because she keeps adding to it! Customers make requests and they often end up on the menu. Staff dream something up and it tastes great, it ends up on the menu. 

I mean, they have a mango sticky rice boba drink! Come on!

I am a purist snd I don't love my drinks too sweet, so I'm thrilled they've got the basics covered and make them great! For boba, I like the Okinawa tea. It's got a slight toffee flavor, and at 50% sweetness it's perfect. My kiddo tried the strawberry milk tea with popping strawberry and was in heaven. I also tried a fruit tea with different coconut jellies in it and it was also super refreshing and incredibly beautiful too! 

Best of all, they serve Honey Bakery bao AND HK Egg waffles! 

So stoked a location is open closer to my house because it's just a lot of fun to be there.

The Great Southern Gun and Knife show is the "big show" that is held at the Pontchartrain Center several times per year. I have been going to these shows off and on ever since I was old enough to own a gun.

The shows haven't changed in years. The way it works is vendors rent tables from the show and sell their wares. You can find guns, ammo, knives, patches, beef jerky, survival gear, etc. at this show. The problem is that there are so many tables, it is easy to become bored. If I am just there to browse I usually only make it three or four aisles before boredom sets in. There are only so many overpriced pistols I can fondle.

if you are looking for something specific, the show may be a good place to start, There are hundreds of guns on display so you can actually handle them prior to purchase. Many of the vendors are very knowledgeable as well so you can gain valuable insight into particular weapons. prices have always seemed high to me so I suggest internet research before purchasing a gun here.

At the most recent show, I did not find what I was looking for, but I did find a bunch of antique firearms. Many were very expensive, but it was cool to see guns that helped win the west and many different wars.

In summary, the gun show is entertaining, but once every few years is enough for me.

The word "serene" encapsulates my experience at the Indianapolis Museum of Art, despite visiting with several young children who wanted to touch everything. (You'd think, instead of "serene" it would be "serenity now!" But, I guess, thus is the magic of the IMA. Even with a gaggle of children in tow, the peace and beauty of the museum wraps itself around you.)

The Richard Wentworth exhibit that is suspended above your head as you walk into the entrance ("False Ceiling -- Indiana") is pretty amazing. It consists of hundreds of donated books hanging from the ceiling. Everything from cookbooks to romance titles to gumshoe crime novels were used to create the dynamic piece. 

The museum has all styles and periods of art, but my favorite installation is on the third floor (I think? Maybe 4th floor.) It's the only artwork you are encouraged to touch! In a dimly lit room, you stand at the entrance to the room and observe what looks like a gray square painted on the wall. But as you walk closer to the square, with your hand outstretched, you soon realize that the artwork is not what it seems to be! I won't give away the surprise -- go see it for yourself! Kids get a kick out of it. (Heck, I got a kick out of it, too.)

There is a cafe on the first floor of the museum with lots of fresh, healthful food options. I got a sandwich and a bag of chips -- not too original, but both were really good! (They sell the fancy chips with seeds and stuff in them.) My meal was a little pricey (about $9), but I guess that's to be expected from a lunch at an art museum.

On a nice day, you can take your food outside and sit at one of the concrete planters just outside the museum -- that's what I did. In the grass just beyond this area are huge metal art pieces, as well as a big piece that spells LOVE. 

You should be aware that the IMA does not allow backpacks to be worn inside the museum! I made the mistake of packing all my personal whatnots and kid-related stuff in a backpack and didn't bring a purse, so then I had to leave it in my car and just carry my wallet. It's kind of a bummer if you don't know this rule beforehand, so if you didn't know, now ya know!

Saki Endless Sushi & Hibachi Eatery is a great spot to fill up on "All You Can Eat" sushi, teriyaki, and hibachi-style meals for one low price. I didn't know what to expect, but a business associate assured me that the sushi was made fresh to order, and the $11 price tag for lunch is hard to beat.

Saki is located along US 19, right at the intersection of Gulf to Bay Boulevard (Route 60). This corner is known as the Clearwater Mall, and Saki can be found facing US 19, behind Michaels, and in between Lowe's and Costco. It's a bit tricky to find, but well worth the effort.

At lunchtime the restaurant fills up quickly, so plan to get there before the lunch rush. Once seated they hand you the menu and explain that you can order ANYTHING on the menu for the one flat price. Yes, anything.....and as much as you want. The only kicker is that if you leave food, or rice balls on your plate that you'll be charged a "piggy fee" and made to wash dishes for the rest of the afternoon.

So let's say that you check out the menu and decide to order a cup of Hot 'n Sour soup, or maybe some gyoza dumplings, and then a couple of pieces of traditional sushi, and maybe a maki roll or two -- and it's all one flat rate. Your dining companion might choose eggrolls, chicken wings, hibachi steak and some teriyaki shrimp -- and it's also one flat rate.

You can order sushi and sashimi either a la carte or on a platter, along with a surprisingly good variety of basic rolls and signature rolls. If you prefer the more traditional Americanized-Asian entr√©es you'll see sweet & sour pork, General Tso's chicken, beef with broccoli, etc. From the hibachi grill they have steak, shrimp, chicken, salmon, veggies and more. Then finally they have teriyaki steak, chicken, shrimp, and salmon. That's right -- everything for one flat price, so mix 'n match to your heart's content.

I saw at least five different chefs behind the sushi counter slicing up the fish and making rolls as fast as their fingers could fly. I'm sure there were equal numbers of folks back in the kitchen preparing soups, salads, appetizers, entr√©es, and desserts. Plus there was a large staff of servers checking in on each table to see if you wanted to order more food, refilling drinks, and whisking away empty plates. It was all operating very fast and efficient.

The lunch price is $11, and the dinner price is $18 for all you can eat. There's also a $16 Endless Sunday price. According to the menu you can order individual rolls and entr√©e items priced per item. I can only conclude that these are to-go orders since everyone else seems to be oinking their way through the AYCE deal.

Heads up little porkers, if you like Asian food, and you're willing to strap on the feedbag and eat like there is no tomorrow, then you need to make a beeline to Saki Endless Sushi and Hibachi in Clearwater.

A must see when in New Orleans! It's walk-able from the French Quarter, but I would recommend getting on a hop-on, hop-off tour bus so you get some background on what you are looking at.  
Lots of beautiful houses, a haunted property or two, and lots of cute boutique shops and restaurants. I would love to explore it more.

Never disappointed at VW - especiallyy when I split a burger with a friend (the kitchen will gladly cut it in half) so I can indulge in a 1/2 order of lobster mac & cheese.  Decadence!


No room for anthing else - except for a $14 shot of whiskey.

Mmmmn Mmmmn good!

The hotel is set in the center of St. Louis near the original St. Louis Union train station. The hotel is a historic AAA Four-Diamond DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel. It is within walking distance to Union Station MetroLink station, which I took for about 20 minutes from the Lambert International Airport. 

The hotel features their recently restored impressive "Grand Hall" as a lobby lounge area with its sweeping archways, gold leaf detailing, mosaics and art glass windows. Transport back to a time when travel was truly extraordinary. The Grand Hall has a 65-foot tall ceiling. The historic beauty helped achieve a top Railway Themed Hotel rating by Cond√© Nast.
The Union Station railway offers several restaurant options, including Hard Rock Cafe, Landry's and a variety of food court choices and nearby local restaurants.

My room was a recently upgraded part of the newer hotel wing #5004 for $159 or $186 with taxes. As a Hilton gold member I had access to their very nice Honors lounge, which included complimentary breakfast and evening snacks. The lounge staff service here was very friendly in the morning and evening.  

Check out my other St. Louis reviews and pics.

I totally agree with Jenn. I would never go back to this cupcake place even if the cupcakes were free. I went here around Christmas to collect from the Groupon; they were closed. Then  I asked my friend to pick up the cupcakes around 3PM and they sent her away saying that they ran out of cupcakes. I finally went this Saturday to pick up the cupcakes; the selection was pretty limited. From what I got, I wasn't impressed with the icing or the flavoring of the cake.

This five-star review is focused on the main dish that is most important to my existence: the chicken salad and bacon club.

On Friday, I was craving it all day. Granted, I crave chicken salad and bacon clubs all day every day for all of my life, but on Friday, the craving was extra strong. Deciding to try a different place, I called in an order to Westmont Diner. Ironically, I used to drive by this place each day when I worked in Haddonfield, but never stopped for some reason.

I'm glad I finally did. When I walked in, they said, "Chicken salad?" before I gave my name. I carried my take out to my car, opened the container, and it was beautiful. It was just.. the perfect diner-style chicken salad.

I realize you all probably think I'm insane now, but please, try the chicken salad and bacon club and try to have a different opinion.

No time between classes for a knife-and-fork kind of meal, but require something to keep you going? Beez is where it's at.

The name says it all - fast food that's healthy, too. A selection of fruity shakes to keep your energy levels up on your walk to class, or a choice of hearty salads if you have a few extra minutes to spare.

I love that the staff here let you choose which veggies go into your salad. Want to enjoy a healthy Caesar salad that has more than just lettuce? Add tomato, cucumbers, peppers...the works!

December 26, 2018 Wednesday - 7:15 PM for dinner
2 Adults and a teenager

Atmosphere - 4 stars
Food - 3 stars
Service - 2 stars

Background - Taking my daughter out for sushi.

Atmosphere - In the corner a strip mall.  The space is laid out in a strange manner.  A mix of tables and sushi bar counter.  All three of us agreed the height at counter is a bit off.

Food
  Drink - Sapporo beer.

  Dinner - With AYCE, all you can eat, we had a good variety of rolls.  The one that we ordered twice was the Mariner.  The rest of the rolls were forgettable.  

Service - Slow, very slow.  Three chefs working today was not enough for a full restaurant.  

Future - Probably not.

Quaint bookstore by USF. They have a Starbucks type cafe that serves good coffee. It has a lot of USF themed apparel and I assume they sell relevant course material for USF St. Pete as it sits on the campus. There is a nice parking garage next door to the store. Plenty of inside and outside seating.

Wow! This place was fantastic! It was like walking into a Haunters paradise. 

From the goat person mannequin out front to the myriad bones, costume bits and books that lay about here, I was in heaven.  What can I say, I like ODD. 

If you're looking for pieces for your Gothic decor, this would be a place to look. Do you need bits and bobs for your Mad Scientist display? You'll find it here. Do you need a cage to keep your captive? (only for a scene, not for real, folks) It's out in the back porch.   Be sure to check out the Rope Snake, that's a piece of art. 

I especially liked the Christmas Ornaments made with Sage and sea horses, those were being made by the Cashier and quite unique. 

There were some "objectionable" pieces near the register, but they are historical. There is a market for them, and thus I must mention them, but not what they are, after all, they do have antiques here. 

Also, there's a Gorgeous Jeep out front that was for sale, with AMAZING spider web doors on it. LAWDY! The Haunter in me wanted this for myself. 

I'll be back, this is a place that I could see visiting frequently.

When the plate was laid out before me the first words I uttered were, "Now that's what chile rellenos are supposed to look like." 

And they were good. Could have used more cheese, but good nonetheless. 

Beans and rice were good. Chips and salsa were good too. It's all good. 

Except for the fresh flour tortilla they gave me. That was GREAT. Especially when tearing it up and sopping up the sauces.

We stayed at the Sonesta on our first trip to New Orleans. Considering that this is a four star establishment we received a fantastic deal through Expedia when we combined the air and hotel. Newbies that we were, little did we know that the August heat had a lot to do with that incredible deal!

We came straight here from the airport and even though we were a little early for check in, we were given our room keys right away. The hotel lobby is beautiful and bustling and the reception/check-in was very friendly and expeditious. The fresh flowers everywhere were gorgeous. 

Our room - a basic King bed room was okay. Nothing overly special but clean and efficient.  There was no real siting area but it was okay for what we needed... a place to sleep and shower off midday after walking around town in that sticky humid heat. 

Poolside was a happening place. Always really busy. 

The best thing about the Royal Sonesta is it's location. Right smack dab in the middle of Bourbon but the rooms are insular enough not to be effected by all the noise and wonderful debauchery going on outside.

It is a great authentic Salvadorian restaurant. Food is definitely made to order. You must order a Banana milkshake. Yummy!! The pupusas are the best. Cheap good eats. What more can you ask for? Street parking on the side of the restaurant. 

It is packed with locals all the time. 

Cash Only.

This my neighborhood Chili. Very Caliente. When we walk out at 8:30 pm, there are people waiting to get a table. Popular for the local resident.

I always like chili fajitas. But lately they have change about the meat cut. The seasoning is still there. Today the flour tortilla is about a bit dry. Which mean they have not steam it completely. This just need a few second more and they will be ok. My wife have the chicken pasta. It is good taste. 

I always start with strawberry lemonade with my soft drink. At the refill, I am asking to change to blackberry ice tea then change to mango ice tea. Sometime they have watermelon lemonade. I have 3 different drink in one order. The strawberry lemonade also dilute down. They use to have the strawberry seed. Now they don't. 

The service at the bar area is quick.

Desi Chaat is one of those places that I have enjoyed time and time again over the years. But with the larger spot that Mood Cafe offers, Hassan and his crew have really managed to kick things up a notch and do some of the traditional and innovative recipes that their previous area couldn't maintain.

Mood does have a lot of the same menu offerings as Desi. But the larger food prep space does allow them to engage the customer with a lot more presentation when they put together the many ingredients that goes into their chaat recipes. This can make for a good interactive show of sorts that caters to your customization; especially when you factor in the number of spices, nuts, fruits, and other ingredients that you can add. Add in some chaat recipes variations that take on influences from other cultures, and things really start to get interesting.

Another plus to Mood is that its menu puts much more emphasis into the lassi, ice cream, and hot beverage side of the menu, making it a great spot to go to please your sweet tooth and grab a beverage on the go. Namaste!

Sbraga was the restaurant my boyfriend selected for his birthday dinner. I had been anxious to get back since our first visit in December, and when I checked out the current menu I was even more stoked. We went all out and opted for the beverage pairing, but I started things off with a glass of sangria, which was super fruity and flavorful. 

The first course really set the bar high. Housemade mozzarella with local tomatoes and fried clams appealed to all my Jersey girl senses. This was the perfect summer dish. 

Next up was parsley risotto with escargot and prosciutto. I love Sbraga's risotto. Art raved over his scallop and pork belly, but the plate that got the most attention was the tempura fried lobster tail that was sent out from the kitchen. Lobster has never been more tender. 

At this point we were feeling pretty full and it was only halfway through the meal. Fortunately, the third course was presented in a smaller portion. My plate consisted of barbecue chicken confit, pickles, cole slaw and onion rings. Tasty and fun. 

The dessert course at Sbraga is not an afterthought, but a vital part of the meal. I wasn't walking out of there without the mascarpone/coffee granita dessert from my previous visit, which was thankfully still on the menu. The boyfriend opted for a cherry coke dessert that was totally unique and really well executed. The kitchen sent out the strawberry rhubarb streusal, which was served hot with a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top. So delish. 

Our second Sbraga visit was really pretty flawless. Service was excellent and everyone seemed to be working in harmony. The restaurant was also packed, which was awesome to see. I'm looking forward to our next visit, most likely after the menu changes up yet again!

We were pumped to try this infamous Santa Barbara uni, but they were out less than half and hour after opening!  

- Oyster shooters:  Yay!  They weren't the huge suckers that I abhor.  Easy going down and I  enjoyed the cocktail sauce.  
- Abalone: Very tender (one of the guys in front was hard at work pounding them as we walked in.  We had four little abalone, which looked even tinier atop the delicious tomato rice, but I get it...seafood is expensive.  The only complaint about this dish is it was seriously swimming in butter.  We left a good layer of tomato rice on the bottom of the bowl as a makeshift "drain" so we wouldn't be eating 75% butter 25% rice.
- Local Spiny lobster 1.5 Pounds:  This day, it came in either 1.5lb or 2.5lb.  Meaty, tender, but honestly kinda flavorless.  I didn't think it was worth the $63 and change.  It was so well presented, though, that immediately after setting ours down, our neighbor pointed to it and said "I want one of those!"

Cute local joint.  Love the tanks with all the fresh sea creatures.  

No reservations.  We arrived at 11:30am on a Saturday, wrote our names down, and got seated at the bar in about ten minutes.  Note that the bar seating is also via list.  Several people tried to snag the bar seats and were told they needed to sign up.  They also have a small outdoor seating area and a to-go window with a long line as well.  

By the time we left (12:30ish), the waitlist was crazy!

Embarrassed that I waited so long to try The Independent. My husband and I rarely find ourselves in Seminole Heights, but last year we bought an annual zoo pass so we would stop by The Independent on our way home.

The beer selection is excellent and the food is pretty good too. I'm more of a wine drinker, but so far I have really enjoyed every beer I have tried. The bartenders are super friendly and always have great suggestions. My husband loves unique or hard to find beers and always manages to find a new beer to try.

We usually split a few appetizers. The charcuterie and soft pretzel are our go-to dishes. We have also ordered the brats and sauerkraut which are great. Need to try one of the sandwiches, but we always seem to visit between meal times when I am not that hungry.

My favorite thing about The Independent is that it is kid friendly. We usually visit during the afternoon when the bar is quiet. It is so nice to be able to grab some food and an adult beverage without paying a babysitter. Our toddler loves the food and enjoys sitting at the picnic tables instead of his usual high chair.

This place is totally reminds me of a restaurant that should be located off of some beach in Southern California. It has a light aura and a very breezy feeling to it. Not casual beachwear, but more like the spot reserved for a romantic post-beach jaunt.

Lovely. Light. Airy. Decadent.

I'm met a colleague here for lunch. Arriving slightly early I found the service was uber attentive. I felt almost like a celebrity walking in. When I arrived, the hostess seemed genuinely happy for me to be there. It wasn't that awful pink, sugarcoated type of welcome that feels somehow sour. I might have guessed that she was the actual owner of this establishment. Same with the server. Very complementary and very helpful. 

I ordered the tri-tip sliders. This is a sizable order for lunch. I wasn't able to finish the meal, but I enjoyed it well. 

The sliders are served in the form of a glorious cheesy biscuit. The biscuit has a wonderful herb flavor. Reminded me of chives and cheddar with a hint of saltiness.

The sliders were served with a sampling of potatoes which had a nice flavor of onion and red bell peppers. Nice accompaniment to the sliders.

I will have to give this place another go. I was happy to see that you can order breakfast items up until 3 p.m. Also, they serve mimosas and they have duck confit.

Great location for a business meeting and, I'm sure, a lovely place for a romantic date.

There are two main areas here at Jason Aldean's:
1. Main level - a band playing with a dance floor in front surrounded by loads of big tables; feels like a Vegas concert in a spacious room. More of an older crowd.
2. Rooftop level - more top 40/hip-hop/EDM music and a really big dancing area. Rooftop outside doesn't have enough seats but has a fair amount of space. More of a younger crowd.

Drinks come in a bigger cup than at Honky Tonk or Whiskey Row for the same price so that was a plus.

This place just opened up a few weeks or months ago but I think it will do pretty well considering our group had such a good time here.

I found Big Red on Yelp during a stay in Indy a couple weeks back. Conveniently located in the heart of downtown, and right across the street from our hotel, Big Red was the perfect place to stock up on beverages for the room. This place is your typical old school, mom and pop liquor store. While prices are a couple bucks higher than your average big box store, you just have to expect that. Plus you're #supportinglocal. They've got a large selection of all types of beer, wine, and liquor. And that staff was welcoming and polite. They've got a huge valut in the basement, which was cool and worth a visit, if just for that. If you find yourself in downtown Indy and in need of booze, check this place out.

This is a nice addition to the expanding Vietnamese restaurant scene of Magazine that I have been eating at for several years now. ¬†This is a nice spot for a quick and delicious meal with their offerings of a variety of rice dishes, noodle dishes, spring rolls, pho, Vietnamese po boys/banh mi, Vietnamese tacos/sliders/banh gap and many other delicious items.  Their stir fried beef banh mi is one of the best beef po boys in the city!

My video review of Pho Cam Ly is here:

https://youtu.be/E2TfP_bLwBg

I love this location as the staff are so sweet and kind to us and our fur babies.

Today, we came in to get our dogs ( terrier mix and almost 14 year old Dalmatian) pawdicures. My terrier is always excited to come in as he gets so much loving and personal attention while my old Dalmatian does not live it as much. The staff is always understanding with the Dalmatian's old bones as she moves slow. Today was the first time she left with a smile. The staff must have taken extra care of her when giving her a tail trim, nail grind, ear cleaning, teeth cleaning, hair brushed, pad smoothing, cologne, and super cute Halloween bandana for just $23. She likes to dress up. She was really strutting her stuff when we were leaving. The terrier fell in love with his tech when she was doing his nails. The tech was getting so many kisses I was kinda getting jealous. They both looked great and had a good time. Thank you for your patience and loving care with my fur babies. We will definitely be back for more pampering.

This is a good bar to hide away from the nearby madness on Bourbon Street that is far enough away to be an escape but near enough to return if you need to.  They also seem to have several tour groups that use this bar as a meet up spot.  Flanagan's serves food and although I've never eaten here what I've seen other folks eat looks decent.  There typically seems to be a mix of tourists and locals here but during tour times the place can get really crowded with tourists and the line for food often gets long at those times.

I stumbled onto this roadside eatery while in the area, and I was completely blown away by how good the food was! We sat at one of the many outdoor benches and ordered the smoked mullet and smoked salmon with German potato salad and cole slaw on the side. This also came with tartar sauce, and slices of onion, tomato, and lemon. The smoked mullet and salmon were both absolutely amazing (though my pick goes to the smoked mullet). The fish had an extremely deep, smoky flavor, and you could really taste the essence of the fish itself. Parts of the fillets were a little dry, making the tartar sauce a perfect light and refreshing complement. The potato salad and cole slaw were also excellent. The potato salad had chunks of bacon, which imparted a great smoky flavor and textural contrast, while the cole slaw wasn't too heavy and gave the perfect, refreshing crunch!

I'm in Nashville for a few days. After a few days of not being home, there is no fridge to grab a little snack. The guys I'm with are into going to all these different clubs. I had to put the breaks on the party when I saw Mike's Ice Cream.

Walking in, it's not giving off an ice cream vibe. It's a dark space and in the back is where the ice cream and coffee (?) is happening. 

A few years back, I was in a Chicago suburb and I found an ice cream shop that used a local dairy to make their ice cream. I was looking for something similar for Mikes Ice Cream. Their website has an apartment rental?? Ok, so Mike is a little quirky. Does he make good ice cream?

Walking up, I see "Blackberry Cornbread". Sold! One scoop cone please.
I grab my ice cream and sit up front. Wow! Mike, you did good. The ice cream is creamy, and the blackberry is dreamy. The corn bread is nice but it didn't allow the ice cream to stay together. A big hunk of ice cream fell (I caught it in my hand) at a piece of corn bread. 

I appreciate the fact that Mr. Mike made an interesting flavor. Total fan of Mike's Ice Cream, if your in town and want to cool off then come to Mike's Ice Cream. They're also serving coffee!

We had such a FUN Digital Date Night with a Free Online Class offered by Picasso & Wine.  We found the painting class via Social Media for a Friday date night option with all of the instructions posted.  You had the option to order painting kits from them with or without brushes (here's a link:  https://squareup.com/store/picasso-and-wine/item/complete-art-kit) or you could even paint along with your own supplies, talk about easy - now that's AWESOME!  There was a deadline to order the kits from them as their hours are limited, understandable with everything happening currently and they even offered delivery for the area around the studio.  With us living in Carson City we were limited on time with our work schedule for pickup but not to worry Picasso & Wine also shared another outlet for ordering additional supplies for the online class - they ROCK!  We opted for the online supplies and they arrived on time for the our digital date night.

Painting was LIVE on Picasso & Wine Facebook page at 7pm PST with Jen giving detailed instruction that was a FUN pace.  We never felt like we were falling behind or not able to understand her, although she couldn't hear us we were able to give her thumbs up and hearts or type messages to her in the chat section of the live feed as we followed along.  My hubby and I truly enjoyed Jen and her husband as they playfully bantered back and forth, laughed, painted and successfully guided us through a GREAT date paint night.  Look forward to our next at home paint date night!

HIGHLY recommend the online virtual painting classes ~ the instructors and painting are great FUN!!  Be sure to check out their upcoming classes, they have FREE ones for not just date night but for the kids and some that are only $10 - now that's AWESOME!!  Here is the class that we did for $10 (https://squareup.com/store/picasso-and-wine/item/happy-campers)  We also had the option (which my hubby and I took advantage of) to 'Donate To Our Artists Fund' by showing your appreciation to the artist that instructs the online paint class by going to the Picasso & Wine page here:  https://squareup.com/store/picasso-and-wine/item/donate-to-our-artists-fund - please let them know you appreciate them!

Below is the list of supplies we used for this class:
Art Supply List: 
2-12x16 canvases
Paints-Red, Lemon Yellow, Cobalt Blue, Ultra Marine Blue, Burnt Umber, White, Black
Brushes-1" Flat Brush, 1/4" flat brush, #6 round brush

Yo Philly! This is what a cheesesteak should taste like. On a break between the day and night sessions for Grey Lodge's Friday the Firkenteenth, my group recently ended up at Joe's. I've only heard about Joe's but I was really excited to give it a try, especially the way a few of my friends were hyping it up. 

I had my large cheesesteak with onions and American cheese. It was perfection. The roll was fresh with a light crispness. There was just the right portion of onions. The meat was chopped but not too fine and not to thick. The cheese melted in perfect union with my steak, onions and roll. 

I also got a small order of the crinkle fries to split with my husband. My only complaint was that the order was too small (or maybe we were just too hungry to have been sharing fries). 

We sat at the booths and I felt like we were in some sort of time warp at an old school diner. 

I'm only in this part of the northeast for the Firkenteenth, but I think I have myself a new tradition.

Reviewer No. 100!!!! 

5 stars! As good as it gets. 

I haven't been to too many candy stores, but this one tops all others that I have been to. Located in Boise's Northend near downtown, surrounded by a small row of restaurants, bars, and the like in a residential neighborhood, sits this cute and nostalgic candy store. 

Once you walk in you'll be greeted with many yummy smells. To the right of you is the candy corn area and to the left is many plus animals and toys that you can purchase-- there is also one of the penny flattener machines in this area, too. 

Once inside you can get your choice of many different pieces of candy from chocolates to gummy bears, or even get yourself a banana split or brownie sundae (see my photos). If you're in the mood for espresso they've got you covered, too! 

I can only imagine warm summer evenings at this place. I've been twice and both times were after having dinner with my friends in nearby restaurants. I can't wait to take my kids here!

The staff is friendly and welcoming. The prices are fair, better than the candy shop in the mall. The name says soda fountain and I didn't really pay attention to any sodas or notice them.

Numchok Wilai, where have you been all my life? This is an awesome place to go if your craving Thai food. Went here on a late Thursday evening and both of us were starving. Place has a nice Thai-style d√©cor to it but man, when we first walked in, the place was hot! Also, there were only a couple of tables occupied...which I thought was pretty surprising. 

Anyways, for the food, like I said, we were starved so we ordered a couple of dishes to share:

- 2x coconut rice ($2 each) - nice and fragrant. Coconut rice was da bomb.
- Pad thai ($14) - noodle with shrimp, chicken, egg, bean sprout, green onion and crushed peanuts in a separate tiny side bowl with a lime on the side. Super tasty, slightly on the sweeter side for what I've had pad thai-wise.
- Stir fried eggplant ($11) - awesome delicious. Make sure you order this dish! I'm a big fan of eggplant and these were perfectly coked.  Came with garlic, carrot, red pepper and basil leaves.
- Green curry chicken ($14) - came with bamboo shoots, green and red peppers and basil leaves. Green curry is my fav and this one was excellent. Nice bit of heat to it (maybe it was slightly more spicy than I thought - that's what my friend said) and perfect compliment to go with the rice.

I can't stress how good Numchok Wilai is! The front of the restaurant is very deceiving (meaning you'll pass it without even noticing if your not on the lookout for it). And did I mention how fast our food came out? Not even 10 minutes and everything came out piping hot and all at once.  Wish I worked nearby so I could get their super cheap lunch deals! 

GO GO GO. Good talk.

Different Cheesesteak #904.  This was a great stop and night to be the cheesesteak guy.  Guest Eater Vic Cusumano, KP class of '84.  The staff, led by Mallory, was awesome, fun, helpful and knowledgeable about everything Bridgeport Rib House.  We saw Cheesey Garlic Bread on the menu board.  After a brief consultation with Mallory we got a Cheesesteak on Cheesey Garlic Bread.  I wish I had a bigger vocabulary so I could properly describe the abso-freaking-phenom-enalness of this cheesesteak!!

[597]

I stopped in to see what this TRU has to offer and I was not disappointed.   Every aisle was clearly marked.  If you want Legos then you will an entire section.  If you want puzzles then there is an entire section.

Tons of items to choose from including a baby store which has strollers.  Kid beds assembled to choose from.  Bikes galore.

Tons and tons of options.  Not what I expected from the outside.  So glad I went in to shop.

Customer service could use some work although I figured out my cashier was bit distracted by the shoplifter :(   She did apologize and thanked me for visiting.

I'll definitely be back.

This is really an experience, one not to be rushed or be in a hurry to get out of. Let's begin with the fact it is a BYOB with that in mind please pace yourself, not coming from my own experience or anything. The meal starts with a rose water hand wash and towels. You are given a large towel which i chose to just lay across my lap 1. I am clumsy 2. i was drinking 3. you use your hands to eat. Knowing this ahead of time I was a little scared being repulsed by double dipping (as I'm sure most people are) and finger licking but overall its not hard to use your pita in a hygenic way. By the time the fruit bowl came out we were all about to burst but made some room for feeding grapes off the vine. I really had a great time.

I love herbs but was a little nervous that everything would be entirely over seasoned, I was pleasantly surprised because each plate was delicious and I even find myself craving it here and there. This was my first experience with Moroccan food so I had no idea what to expect. My favorite was the baked chicken with the spicy sauce which we ordered on the side just to be safe. Also, the baklava was what dreams are made of. Overall, the food, service, and experience were amazing and super fun. I think this would make an amazing first date. The belly dancer was so fun and friendly. 

I suggest ringing the door bell versus knocking because I kept knocking and knocking and no one could hear me, i rang the door bell once and they opened the door immediately. It is CASH ONLY so plan accordingly.

Love the entire store. The entire concept of eating healthy begins here. Quickly became a huge fun if there food bars. For all three meals, oh my. There cookies are simply yummy, just Mom used to make. They got it all, including the nickname of Whole  Paycheck. As it's not exactly a discount super market, But the quality is in the food you get. Which is excellent

An American classic!

My rooms here have always been fresh, clean, and bright, and the guest service here is consistently beyond reproach.

The hotel itself is just off Canal Street, so almost everything worth doing or seeing in The Big Easy is right at your fingertips. (Yup -- location, location, location!)

The bar downstairs is exceptionally handsome, by the way. Very well decorated.

While this is an active courthouse, most people set foot inside or on the grounds because it is so pretty.  Very well manicured grounds, lots of green grass and foliage, not to mention the courthouse itself, make this one of the major tourist attractions of Santa Barbara.  We came here on a Saturday, and while the building was open, obviously court was not in session, and we couldn't see inside the courtrooms.  We came too late for the 2pm tour, so we just walked around on our own.

Gets the job done.

If you're looking for a weekend getaway in SB and won't be in your hotel room often but still want somewhere that will do more than leave the light on for you, this quaint hotel is just the spot.

Likes:
-dispensers for soap and shower products that are squeeze bottles (I have recently discovered a pet peeve of hotels that use bars of soap or the twist off cap style dispensers
-comfy bed
-spacious closet
-complimentary parking
-location (walkable to state street, right across from the pier, and a stone's throw away from the little street that has a couple wine tasting rooms)

Appreciate:
-complimentary coffee/tea station available at any time
-complimentary wine and cheese in the evening (I believe 5-7pm). While it may just be cubes of cheddar and pepper jack and carafes of what I assume to be cheap wine, it's a lovely gesture and a nice way to accompany the getting ready for the night process

Not a fan of:
-the bathroom window was at street level (facing the alley that other guests had to take to their room) but provided no proper blockage so we had to time our bathroom visits just so as to not give a peep show to any passersby 

Staff was nice and the rate was economical given that we shared the rate between three people.

I came here tonight with my best friend and we had a great girls night out! The happy hour menu is amazing here. We each had a drink and we split 3 of the happy hour starters and it was plenty for our meal! We split the bill and all that, with tax and tip was only $16! It was a steal!

I had their draft cider, which was Angry Orchard cider and on happy hour for $4. I love Angry Orchard and it was great on a Fall night! We split the Mac and Cheese bites, margherita flatbread, and chicken tacos. I loved the Mac and Cheese bites! The sauce they came with was a little spicy and so addicting! We ended up pouring some of it on our chicken tacos because we couldn't get enough of it! The chicken tacos were great as well. I thought the margherita flatbread was just ok. The other two were definitely better and next time, I would probably try something other than the flatbread.

Overall, I definitely recommend this restaurant for happy hour! Their deals are amazing and the food and drinks are great as well.

I wouldn't really call Mena's a palace, per se, but I'm kind of guessing that if it came right down to it and they found themselves cross-examined, they probably wouldn't term it that either. What this place is, definitively, is a local diner, teeming with regulars, and good cheer and some storytelling mixed in for good measure. 

Maybe in that order and just perhaps, maybe not. 

Either way you shake it, I ended up here when another lunch timed out due to a characteristic New Orleans squall, and I soon found myself face first into a plate of fried chicken. They do specials by the bucket load here, and it's pretty likely that you'll encounter a room full of locals. I sat next to a six top that included one gentleman so advanced in years that you could have watched him sit via time lapse photography. This, of course, didn't deter the cheery hostess who knew him by name. That table showed one another lots of photos, told all sorts of stories, and I soaked up what I could. 

Prices a pretty cheap and you're a salt shaker away from the Monteleone, so if you have business there like I did, doesn't take long to get back. In a pinch, a hearty bite I needed.

I brought my 8 year old to Plaza Bowling today for an impromptu afternoon mother son date. 

The staff were helpful and fabulous!  We met Trevor towards the end who's the grandson of the original owners from 1959!  Plaza is celebrating their 60th Anniversary this year and they even have cute merch to celebrate! 

We selected a Plaza T-shirt sticker for $1 to go on our Thule.  Every time I see it I will be reminded of today's fun date! 

It's a Tuesday afternoon so bowling was on special for just under $5 a game/person.  I enjoyed an adult bev and my son a Mountain Dew.  Our total for 3 games, 2 drinks, and shoes was just shy of $45.  It was a fabulous date!  (Oh and they have bumpers - thankfully!)

The washrooms were clean and funky with b & w tiles AND both the mens' and ladies' has changetables - two thumbs way up! 

Plaza Bowling is located along 118th Ave in a basement so if stair mobility is an issue, this might not be the place for you. 

Next time I'd like to try some of their food but today we continued our adventure by walking next door to Lan's. 

5 stars all the way - Can't wait to come back. 

PS Be sure to check out the cool memorabilia ranging from posters to vintage records held in 5 pin!  Oh and the COOL pins for turkeys (3 strikes) and the Britney Spares!  Yes, you read that right!!!

As you can tell by the ridiculous number of check-ins I have here I love coming to this restaurant.  It feels more like being invited to eat in someone's family kitchen instead of a standard restaurant visit.  Grandma is making making food in the kitchen while Grandpa and their son handle the dining room.  The family that runs this establishment is so friendly and welcoming.  

The menu is very simple and has standard Italian classics.  Everything is very reasonably priced and you get so much food for your money.  They start you off with bread and warm marinara sauce to dip it in.  The first time we came here we were all really confused when they brought out the salad because half of the plate was taken up by a huge veal cutlet (which is delicious and I am now completely addicted to).  It is included with every entree.  I've tried the stuffed shells, lasagna, eggplant parmesan, and ravioli.  It's all delicious and I've never been disappointed with a meal here.

My only complaint (and it is minor) is that they don't have chicken parmesan on the regular menu.  Sometimes they have daily specials, of which chicken parmesan sometimes makes an appearance.

This is my favorite place for Italian food in the Tampa Bay area.

Staying in Indianapolis for the first time gave me a great excuse to do some research on the best brunch places. Milktooth came up on a few lists I found and I discovered it was within walking distance from our Airbnb! My boyfriend and I stopped in on a Sunday morning at 9 am and most of the tables were already full. We snagged a couple seats at the very long counter and got to watch the food being made, which was really fun and a bit mesmerizing. They've got it down to a science there and everyone is in a constant state of motion. I watched one cook make like 5 grilled cheese sandwiches while we were there.

Anyway! The atmosphere is bright and bustling, with a modern hipster diner feel. The menu is very unique and interesting, which drew me to Milktooth. This isn't a typical eggs and toast type place -- their menu ranges from Asian inspired to oysters to fancy homemade poptarts. I ordered the mushroom Dutch baby with a side of regular bacon, and my boyfriend got the sourdough waffle. Our food didn't take too long to come out and it was delicious! The Dutch baby was savory, super cheesy and rich, with a bit of red cabbage (listed on the menu as baby chard) to cut through all the goodness. The bacon was okay (regriddled previously cooked) but I wouldn't get it again. The waffle was delicious as well! Light and fluffy with a sweet and salty combo of honey, parmigiano reggiano, a thick slab of butter, and flaky sea salt. Definitely using that topping at home in the future.

Service was polite and quick, prices were a little high but worth it considering the quality of the food. Go early and get a spot at the counter!

I can not say enough great things about Gene and his staff.

My frames that I bought 2 years ago still look good as new.
Plus he adjusts them for me whenever I drop in.

The next time I need glasses (probably next year) THIS is where I will go.

It's GREAT.

Why 4 stars? Because all of my beers went down easy!

   ---   ---   ---

Crooked Thumb was one of many Pinellas breweries that I've had on my to-do list, but I don't find myself in Safety Harbor too often. We actually were in the area to check out another brewery, and figured we'd swing by here as well.

I had a flight, and every beer was solid, but none were spectacular. I would absolutely order any of them again: Tangelo Wheat, Vortex Swirl, Harbor Fest, Dubbel and Mixed Berry. I did wish that the vortex swirl was a bit thicker, but it had the same texture as the others. The Tangelo Wheat and Harbor Fest were my favorites in the group.

One interesting thing - their flights are served in giant glasses, that are about 25% full. The good thing about this is: more beer! Duh. Bad the bad thing is that it's definitely not convenient to carry from the bar to the table you're sitting at, as you can really only carry two of the glasses at a time. Also, if you don't like a beer, you're kind of stuck with a pretty decent amount. 

I would definitely love to visit Crooked Thumb again - add another awesome brewery to the Tampa Bay list!

Mixed thoughts on my experience at Sam's with three of my girlfriends on the last Saturday in February...  for context, our weather has been very hot lately, with comfortable nights in the low 70's. I'll start with the things that are really out of their control, but worth noting so other diners are prepared. First, parking was a challenge! Having never been to Hudson, I circled more than once just to figure out where the public parking was available, then another round and a lot of waiting in line in two different lots before I finally found an open but very tight spot (I found small scuffs & scratches on my door the next morning, possibly from people getting into their car next to me). Then, our wait for a table was nearly an hour and a half (which was not terrible for us; more on that later), but once inside I noticed they really didn't have many tables due to social-distancing. 

Upon joining the wait list & issued a pager, the hostess advised that we could not order drinks while we waited. However, my girl was not accepting that situation on our girls night! After walking through the parking lot toward the beach, she spotted a bus boy and asked him to find a server so we could order drinks. A few minutes later, a friendly server leaned over the railing to get our drink order (no specialty drinks on the sly), and brought them back very quickly with a payment device. We took our adult beverages to a picnic table at the adjacent public park to chat. Time flew by and then we were buzzed.

After we were seated, I had to wander to another part of the restaurant to find the chalkboard list of beers on tap for my beer flight, which wasn't ideal, and then not all were available. One of my friends & I had substituted a side with our meals but we both received the fries AND the grits. Not a big deal, especially since neither of us were charged extra, but noted. Service was relatively slow, but it WAS a Saturday night and we weren't in a rush. The 80's music vibe was great and overall we enjoyed a fun night!

Oh man. Another tasty sugar cream pie under the belt....err, on the bottom. 

This places is cute as a button. From the small shop space off of Zionsville's main drag to the smell of pies wafting down the street, My Sugar Pie is the kind of business you take out-of-town friends to give them a taste of Hoosier flavor and hospitality. 

Not only are they loved in the Yelpisphere but in large-scale magazines like Midwest Living and beyond. 

Now you're asking about the flavors?
Well, I say go for the sugar cream pie (what they're most famous for), but there's also Dutch Apple, Lemon Meringue and seasonal fruit pies. Important note: they ship! Great option for the holidays and birthdays. I plan to send one to a few of my coworkers in the near future. 

Last, but not least, pies are sold whole and by the slice. Expect to pay $3-$4 per slice. Oh! And you'll find My Sugar Pie on the menu at St.Elmo Steakhouse downtown (for those of us downtown dwellers who can't wait for our next visit to Zionsville).

Same great Sabrina's food you can get in Philly in the charming suburban Jersey town of Collingswood. The location is much more spacious compared to its city counter parts.

The high ceilings are lovely to look at but make the dining room very echoey. I had trouble hearing the person next to me and wasn't able to converse with the others in my group of 8 on the other side of the table.

Brunch all day is clutch. BYOB is a Collingswood mandate and Sabrina's staple.

I wouldn't recommend this location again for a group but it's probably great for a couple.

Lamberti's Tutti Toscani is almost like a hidden gem. It has the quality of Caffe Aldo Lamberti, with the smaller restaurant charm. It blends in with the shopping center Italian restaurants, but has the food that propels it above the rest.

It's been a special place for my family, with many special occasions being spent there. Its a favorite for even the toughest of critics. 

I recently also discovered they have delivery via certain apps; that's almost dangerous for me. 

Start by saving room for their pizza bread. It's like a tomato pie sliced into small pieces. That could be a meal alone. Their pasta fagioli is another must-have. 

From their pastas to veal dishes, there are so many great options. I can't wait to dine-in person again to order some of their specials. 

I'm glad places like this exist. There aren't good places in the middle of the road from pizza shop to fancy. Lamberti's Tutti Toscani is that sweet spot.

BAB also means punching bag?!  Well than...welcome to the Punching Bag Cafe.  BC has been a welcome addition to come across here in Downtown!  

My first time just happened to be on a monthly #meatlessmonday.  So tofu bibim-BAB it is with extra kimchi and with comes with a nice cup of miso soup.  

It was delicious.  Lots of flava and filling.  Gojuchang sauce in the self serve pump was gojutastic!!!!  Pump it up!  There's plenty here.  

The interior is modern and well thought out.  Seating arrangement is great for groups.  

If your sensitive to MSG.  Just know their kimchi, japchae and certain sauces do carry MSG.

I'll definitely back with my carnivorous eating ways next time.  There is a nice dog park across from here to work out your food coma problems with your furbabes.

Well, the pho here isn't bad, but the best part of this restaurant is the spring rolls - fresh, hot and totally worth a trip to eat. But, everything else here, unfortunately, was only normal, and that meant I often stopped here for an order of spring rolls to go, and little else.

They do have a decent waiting space as it does get busy here, but they are certainly swift in clearing up tables and clearing you out as you finish up. Drinks here are a bit on the weak side, almost cloyingly sweet.

They have always taken excellent care of our dogs.  And when our last baby had to be put down they were incredibly caring and sweet.  Our current girl loves to go there; she doesn't care about the shots because they give her enough treats to make up for it.

While exploring my home city, I stumbled upon Eat Greek Kouzina. I gave a shrug and took a chance, an BOY am I glad I did.  This place was fabulous.  Inside it's small, intimate and cozy.  There's a section that you access by a staircase, and seating beneath, along with seating along the window and seating along the wall. That's it.. Small. 

The owner is the chef and it's clear that he love his food. The first thing that we were introduced to was an olive and pepper tepenade, spicy yet so tasty.  We ordered an appetizer of cheese and spinach, not your typical spanokipita, but in any case it was absolutely delicious. 

Our main courses were brought out quickly: I ordered the pork chops and french fries, my friend ordered a Gyro, both were amazing, and the fries were seasoned very well, with a dill and feta sauce. 

Would I come back? You're damned straight I would.

The Roosevelt Hotel is a magical place. It's like being transported to another life, one where everyone is fabulously wealthy, steeped in luxury and oozing old world charm. It's got a long, gorgeous atrium/corridor that will take you from Barronne St. to....whatever's on the other side. I've never actually stayed here, but for some reason I've spent a lot of time here and have seen several of the rooms. Most are normal hotel rooms, but the business suites on the second floor are un-freaking-believable. Probably 1000 square feet, two enormous bathrooms, five rooms total. I would've been happy to sleep in the walk-in closet. I now understand why people live in hotels.

Came here a few times during my visit in Nashville. This is a bar, so if you can't stand smoke, then you won't like it inside. But for those that don't smoke but can endure....You will be ok..If you can hold your for a while...lol. 

The first time I came here, I had Lemon Pepper wings and a basket of fries. Both were really good. The wings were naked with the lemon pepper dry rub seasoning. I would definitely get these wings again. The cook did a great job. 

The second time I came here, I got a to go order to take back with me to the hotel. I ordered a simple bacon cheese burger with fries. This was one of those home made old fashioned hamburger. It wasn't thin nor too thick (which I don't mind). It had great flavor, and my taste buds was doing the MC Hammer -  hammer time dance in my mouth. I should've ordered 2 more burgers. 

I would come back - For TAKEOUT if I was in the area.

#DJEATSFLA

Updating my review to 5 stars as The Indie has become my favorite hang out.

Aside from the fact that I can walk here (and frequently do so), there are many reasons that I love this place.  The outdoor atmosphere is a great place to spend an afternoon.  They have a huge selection of craft beer and have recently started adding more and more wines so I can have whatever I am in the mood for.  The food has really stepped up a notch, as well, and I really enjoy their many sandwiches and salads.  The Spinach and Feta Grilled Cheese is excellent!

What I like most about this place, though, is what a friendly atmosphere it is.  I often find myself sharing a table and chatting with complete strangers.  The bartenders are always very nice even when I am being indecisive.  I've had a lot of good times at The Indie and am excited for more to come.

Pop in yourself on a Sunday night for Sundays for Sinners - a really great night for live music and fun!

Another epic night at Epic Pizza.

I really like the joint. As previously stated in my first review, the concept of beer joint and a pizza joint right next door to each other is a pretty solid idea.

Things I like about the place:

- The staff are friendly.

- You receive your order in a very timely manner.

- Prices are just right.

- Overall quality fits the bill just as a whole.

I appreciate a good pizza place with some personal character to it. I think they've got the menu and everything down pact. Now if only other new businesses would hit it off just as well as this one.

I first discovered the joys of World Market when I moved outta NYC (where there are none) and into the KC area. Look, I cannot stand chain anything for the most part, but Cost Plus World Market is like a cheaper, bigger, better version of Pier One Imports. It's a smaller, more boutiquey, more *worldly* Bed Bath and Beyond. And the grocery section, while small, is just so much cheaper than Whole Foods. So sue me. I cannot resist WOMA's charms.

I used to live quite close to one in KC and I was there an average of 2 times per week, picking up wine, candles, incense, seasoning, imported snacks, storage baskets, towels, outdoor lighting, bath products, hazelnut biscotti and more. Not to mention wickedly discounted Halloween decorations on November 1st. 

It just has all of my favorite things in one store. Even the decor is right up my alley (though admittedly, too expensive when you consider some, not all, is made in China). I move a lot and tend to stop in here for things like rugs, curtains, bamboo mats etc. 

Want to read about my purchases made on Saturday? Too bad, you're going to have to! Wine glasses, pot holders, olive oil, incense, champagne, amber colored soup bowls, pink Himalayan salt aaaaand the coup de gr√¢ce, black truffle oil. For roughly 12 dollars, the bottle I bought is twice the size of the one I bought at Whole Foods for 18 dollars (I was desperate). 

What stops it from the fifth, elusive star. I'm a member of the World Explorer club (far too many emails) and yes, I may print the coupons out, but I always forget to use them. Why not just make it a given if you, as a member (who suffers through opening and deleting all those emails) are shopping there, that you get the 10% off without having to go to the trouble of printing and remembering? One other extremely annoying thing: they sticker just about every damn item, including all the wine glasses in a box of 6! These are a bitch to remove and it makes me ballistic to have bits of sticker left on glassware. WTH? This has to stop. 

Otherwise, WOMA, I just can't quit you.

This is a lesser known tourist attraction to the locals in Tampa. The Yuengling Brewery is located down the street from Busch Gardens and is the second largest Yuengling producing brewery in the US. Tours are FREE and all ages are welcome. On most weekdays, tours are at 10am,11am and 1pm. On Saturdays, the tours are at 10:30am and noon. If you want to get the full experience, visit on a weekday because there is no production on Saturdays. 

The tour guides are phenomenal (I've been on this tour so many times that they recognize me when I return)! They walk you through several parts of the facility including the production line (which you can view through windows from above) as well as the chemistry room (no pictures allowed in here). The brewing process for Yuengling is extensive and quite impressive than other breweries in the area that you may have visited. There is a rail line that ends at the brewery to transport supplies by train. At the end of the tour, you are welcomed to sample the beers and hang out in the cozy lounge. There is also a gift shop with reasonably priced souvenirs. 

If you like beer, or just enjoy seeing how beer is made, you must visit the Yuengling Brewery. It's a great free tour and they teach you so much about the Yuengling brewing process. I'll continue to return!

Parking can be a pickle here as the lot is puny and  the neighboring roads all have signage specifying no brewery parking. They do have a bonus lot down the alley a free businesses away that had spots available when we visited.
It was our great fortune to happen to stop by when Krampus was available in their small fridge of to-go bottles (our visit was in December, lest I accidentally get anyone's hopes up).
Our Floridian beer junky friends spend a lot of time in line here for release parties for dinner of their rate beers. We're especially fond of the German Chocolate Cake 
We've been treating ourselves to a few special treats each week from our cellar during the Covid-19 crisis and enjoyed our Krampus this weekend. 
This is an absolute must-stop trip on a Florida beer tour, especially if pastry stouts are your deal. Once we can travel and socialize again, I recommend visiting this Tampa treasure.

I have tried and tried to like this place, and in the end, I just don't.  My fiance' LOVES Three Coins and always suggests it for breakfast.  I've just really never had anything that I have liked a whole lot.  And I've had hair in my food, more than once.  I don't usually consider myself a picky eater...but I'm just not into this place.

We had such a blast finally checking this spot off our bucket list. When Heartland Film Fest came to Tibbs, we couldn't not check it out. We bought our tickets online, arrived five minutes before we started, and had our tickets scanned on our phones at the entrance. The man working the ticket stand was so friendly and pointed us to the correct screen. He also gave us a slip of paper with the radio/sound info on it.

We easily found a parking spot at our screen (if you have a ticket beforehand, then there will be a spot for you) and ran into the snack bar. It reminded me of being a kid and getting to order at the school cafeteria for the first time. They had every type of junk food: pizza, fried chicken sandwiches, tenderloin sandwiches, fries, nachos, popcorn, pretzels, soft drinks, candy, cookies, or chips. None of the food was very good, but it was a good time to go all in. 

We caught the "A Call to Spy" movie about women being recruited as spies in WW2 (true story). It was super interesting and the sound was good when we tuned into the radio station. The only problem is that we were kind of nervous that our battery would die the whole time, so had our car running for most of it. The car next to us had their battery die mid-way through the movie, so the Tibbs staff came over with their car jumping equipment. I'd feel a bit more comfortable returning if there were little speakers next to each car that let you just roll down your windows and turn off your car. 

Nonetheless, we had a fun time and were pleasantly surprised by the wonderful staff, the large amount of cars at each screen and the ease of getting tickets.

I simply could not wait to get on Yelp and rave about my experience at Carrollton Market. The food and service were top notch and it was one of the best dining experiences I have ever had.

We made reservations so we were seated immediately upon arriving. I had been  in this space previously when "One" was here and I have to say I like the decor of CM much better. It's brighter and feels new and fresh.

The menu here is pretty simple, which I can definitely appreciate. We started with the Oysters Goodenough which is 4 grilled oysters topped with a cream sauce and bacon. If you are an oyster lover you MUST get this dish. It was incredible and I couldn't get enough. I almost wanted to order another plate for myself and just call that my meal. Check out my close up picture of the oysters and get ready for your mouth to start watering.

For my entree I got the potato crusted drum, which was served on a bed of brussels sprouts and other vegetables. The fish was perfect. The potato crust added a nice flavor and the fish itself was flaky and delicious. I've been on quite the seafood kick lately, as I've been eating out a lot, and this is perhaps some of the best I have had.

We skipped desert, but we did decide to get coffee. Even though our dinner was late (we arrived 30 minutes before closing- a usual "no no" in my book), we didn't feel rushed at all and the waiter was kind enough to let us take our time and chat. At one point I joked that we could take our coffee to go but he said he was happy to have some company as he cleaned up for the night. What a sweetie!

This place is fantastic and I will definitely return. I am so excited to bring friends here in the future.

This is it. Today was the day that I gave Starbucks one more chance and they failed me. I really never buy iced coffee anymore. David gave me a very nice coffee maker, so I can make iced coffee at home, but I was in a pinch today so I thought I would stop in here and grab a quick cup. Big mistake. Huge. 

Time and time again they fill the entire cup with big chunks of ice and then put in the coffee. The result is a cup of coffee that I finish before the ice even melts. My grande was probably a quarter cup of actual coffee. Last time I asked them not to do this and they did it anyway. This time I totally forgot to mention it, but I feel as if it's common sense. 

Just for the record: I don't blame the employees- I know they are only doing as instructed. I blame Starbucks HQ for being stingy with their coffee. As much as they are charging, they should be willing to be a little more accommodating.

Bacchanal Wine is one of my new favorite spots in New Orleans! Some friends and I recently spent an entire afternoon here and had the best time. We started by entering through the wine shop, and choosing a lovely bottle of ros√©. We then exited through the back of the shop into the outdoor courtyard. There's plenty of seating, and they have ice buckets and ice for your wine. There's also a stage and live music, so you know it's a great time! 

We ordered the Pickled Vegetables, Gulf Shrimp, Bacon-Wrapped Dates, and created our own charcuterie board by choosing meats and cheeses from inside the wine shop that they cut and prepared for us along with bread. Everything was wonderful! And they actually gave us a ton of bread with our meats and cheeses, which I am such a fan of! I cannot stand a charcuterie with tons of meats and cheeses and then two slices of bread. So, thank you for that Bacchanal Wine! 

We sat outside listening to music and drinking wine long enough to make it through two bottles, but then it started to rain. Luckily, they have an upstairs bar area that's indoors. We were lucky enough to grab a table and some cocktails to continue our conversation. I tried the Bumfuzzle which was a bourbon cocktail, as well as the Violet Spritz which was blueberry and vodka. Both were delicious! 

I so enjoyed my time spent at Bacchanal Wine and I hope to make it back really soon. I highly recommend this spot if you're looking for a leisurely (and tasty, and entertaining) afternoon or evening.

This place is super quaint and quiet. I love how clean and inviting it is. This is a B.Y.O.B and there is a beer distributor next door and a Shop-rite not too far down the strip mall that now sells beer and wine, incase you forget to bring wine or you randomly decide to go there for dinner. 

This place opened up about 6 months ago and I did get a menu in the mail but always forgot about it when playing the whats for dinner game. After running errands in the same location, I suggested trying this place out. I'm sad we did not try it sooner. They only have booths and tables, there is NO hibachi grill or show. 

We were greeted and sat right away, by the owner who us super sweet. She asked us for our drinks as we looked over our menu. I love that they bring out a tea pot for the table. A lot of places only bring you a cup and you need to ask for refills. 

I decided to try the garden salad with ginger dressing and a few sushi rolls off the 50% off menu. I tried the spicy tuna roll, sweet potato roll, pumpkin tempura roll and the Boston roll, which was lettuce, mayo and fresh shrimp. Hubby got the seafood hibachi meal. You could really see and taste a difference in this food versus other places. It was very fresh and delicious. You were not rushed and they really were attentive to our table and refills on drinks. 

They also offer a rewards program, where you earn credits based on your total bill. They save the amount you earned to be used next time or save it up for when you have $10 or more in credits. I believe its 5% of your total bill before taxes. 

I highly recommend this place!

I really enjoyed the variety they have at this farmer's market.  I guess July is peach season, because they were plentiful.  Here are some cool things that I discovered while at SB Certified Farmers Market:

There are clingstone and freestone peaches, flesh that clings onto the pits and freestone that just cuts open nicely without the flesh clinging to the pits.  

Did you know that pink blueberries exists?  Yeah, they're light pink in color, taste is subtle but it's definitely a smaller and cuter version of the blueberry.

Artichokes flower if they're not cut.  Yeah, it's pretty cool and you can use it as decorative center pieces.  

The green onions have big onion bulbs that they grow out of.  I didn't know that!  At the supermarkets, the onion bottoms are pretty tiny.  

Pistachio nuts were also in abundance, so if you're feeling nutty, you can purchase your own baby tree to start it off.  

It's a beautiful market, filled with flowers, fruits, plants and vegetable shown at it's rawest stage.  Vendors will advertise 4 square for credit card usage just in case cash  is not convenient for you.

Since we were visiting, I bought myself a jar of tapenade, bagful of roasted peanuts to take home with us.  This beautiful 80+ degree weather during the the 4th of July weekend can only allow you to buy so much.

What a cool place seemingly right smack dab in the middle of a town.  It's part aviary, part nature trail, part education center, part awesome place!  That's the 4 P's you should look for anywhere you go in life.  Ok, maybe that's extreme, but it checks all the boxes for a great outdoor activity.

Although the visitor center was closed due to COVID Precautions, there was still plenty to see and do.  There's an exhibit with a bunch of birds and information about such birds.  There was a bald eagle which is always fun to see and he didn't seem to mind the name calling.

There's a pretty nice hike that is part easy to walk and part somewhat wet and flooded over in areas, so I'd recommend hiking boots if you plan on venturing past the small inner loop areas.  There was so much wildlife, even wild parrots (not the 80's hair band, but actual parrots).  I wish they'd take care of some of the pathways where flooding happens as you may get stuck having to turn around.
