There was a volunteer handing out some cool cloth masks with the St. Petersburg logo sewn in.  Pretty sweet deal.  The take donations so have some singles ready if you go.

If you're looking for an awesome way to kill a few hours and experience nature, then this is definitely a go-to place.  I would return!

We ate here twice in two days because it was just that amazing. Food is kinda pricey but hey you're paying for some fresh and quality seafood with a great view am I right? 

The steamed clams in wine sauce are just divine...I got them twice. The oysters are amazing as ever- SO fresh and tasty! The clam chowder's a nice side to have but it runs you about $5 for a small cup so it is quite expensive, but definitely nice to try at least once. Lots of clam meat and the soup had such a bold seafood flavor! If you can't already tell..I'm a total clam hoe 

Seating is inside or outside but I definitely prefer the outside for the amazing views of the ocean. Just watch out for the seagulls cause they're fearless and I almost got attacked for my food..it was pretty scary. Other than that this is a great spot to get food on the wharf and the wharf itself is a must-see spot when in SB. There's free parking for the first 90 minutes and like $2 after that. So stress-free and different from LA...love it here!

Obsessed!! Not only with the insanely gorgeous space that showcases impeccable attention to detail and so many stunning ways to honor and highlight the culture... in the decor, market goods and dish-ware, but with the food too. And I haven't even tried half of the traditional Lebanese offerings! 

 I'm going to go bold here and say Suraya dishes up the best falafel I've ever had...and I've eaten falafel in the Middle East! It's pretty darn fantastic!! Unbelievable, actually. Crispy fried golden exterior, perfect warm interior. Perfect crunch to soft ratio. So incredibly delish! If you want to save the carbs or just eat a smidge lighter, go for the balls themselves, and not the platter. Not listed, just ask! 

To date, I've tried two of their hummus flavors... the mushroom and the crispy chickpea. They're both uber creamy, totally flavorful, loaded with toppings, and just excellent. Up there as my second favorite hummus in ALL of Philly! 

I've also tried their baba ganoush complete with pomegranate seeds! What a lovely, crunchy, colorful addition to the dish. This smoked eggplant dip has just the right amount of smokiness and garlic! Great texture too! 

Their rosewater lemonade is just beautiful and refreshing. I absolutely love it! Tart and sweet. A must! 

The clementine ginger beer with cardamom served in a copper mule mug is also fantastic! 

The beet salad, and Man'oushe (Lebanse flatbread) are up for me next! Oh, and the tehina hot chocolate! Yessss!! 

Make sure to leave some time to walk around the entire space. It's just gorgeous! The cafe is super sweet with fresh deep jewel tone blooms on each table and bright light shining through the big windows. The bar is gorgeous and inviting. The dining room is spacious and candle-lit, and the back porch will transport you to another country!! I can't wait until it's officially open back there! I'm in love with the patterned pillows, wrap around bench, wood-burning fireplace and tiled floor!! Oh, and definitely take a peek at the goods for sale. Most of them, if not all, are straight from Lebanon. Spices, oils, body goods, and textiles too! It's like perusing a shuk! 

The only things that bum me out are the fact that they're closed on Mondays. There have been several, several Mondays I've wanted to go. Also, the fact that they don't take ressies for brunch. I really wanted to bring my mom and our fam here for Mother's Day. Perhaps a dinner soon will be better? Those cocktails and even the Lebanese beer are calling my name. I hear Open Table is starting to accept reservations for that time frame!

I cannot say enough good things about Suraya!! It's such a pleasure for all the senses to dine here. I'm so in love! I heard 'Suraya' is the name of the owner's grandmother. They are certainly making her proud. 

I honestly can't see me ever tiring of this gem! It's really worthy of all of the hype it's receiving!

*There's street parking which is easy to find during the day, but also an entire lot across the street!

What a gorgeous, new location of the IMCPL on Michigan Road! I recently came here for a work meeting and we used one of their rooms that was good for sound proofing as we were doing recordings for a video. 

It's much smaller in size as compared to my normal downtown Central library location I go to, but there was lots of parking for the size of the library. There is tons of natural sunlight which is always a positive and everything was so fresh and new. 

I don't find myself in this area often but it's great to see another location added to this neighborhood. Support your local public library everyone!

I like Flying Pie's pizza. They have great sauce and they load on the toppings. I mean LOAD them on. The crust has decent flavor, though it is a bit thick for my preference. I love all their unique combinations. The Habanero is incredible but wowsa... it is hot! I really liked their garlic chicken. Great flavor and the white sauce was not overpowering. 

I love that we can get draft beer or wine DELIVERED right to our front door. It doesn't even seem legal, but I'll take it! 

Even though I like their pizza, it remains at 3 stars for me for a few reasons. It is really expensive. They always send out coupons, which are a must for us to be able to afford them. They are also a bit slow. It takes maybe 15-20 minutes for the pizza to arrive to your table. And be sure to plan ahead if doing delivery or carry-out. We have waited 1.5 hours to get our delivery. Also be careful using their online ordering system. We completed an order once for carry out at their Meridian Location and when we went to pick it up...they didn't have our order in their system and said that online ordering wasn't even an option for their location? Totally could have been user error...but I don't know. Lastly, we tried to use their Yelp Check-In deal (20% off when you check-in on Yelp!), but after waiting through 2 employees who had no idea what to do, we couldn't wait any longer and had to leave without our discount. That was a bummer.

Great hidden treasure in the Riverside Heights area of Tampa. Garagiste is located down a small brick paved alley between Hidden Springs Brewery and Foundation Coffee (but the building itself is located on Florida Ave). It's a small meadery but there are plenty of places to sit, including a small kids table with crayons if you want to bring your family! There is not a designated parking lot, but my best advice would be to park on the street if you can find a spot or park in the Hidden Springs lot (free) and stop there too!! 

The meads here are absolutely delicious and priced so as to not break your bank. They average around 14% ABV, run about $6-$7 per pour and Garagiste serves a nice portion in a wine glass. I enjoyed the Reboog Razz (Raspberry PB&J) which was SPOT ON. So much flavor and utterly sippable. I also tried a couple of others that my friends ordered and the flavors were on points. The beertenders are freaking awesome and clearly love what they do! This is a must stop for any beer lover or anyone who isn't sure if they like beer yet...you probably will after trying these meads. They sell some chips and other snacks, but you are welcome to bring your own food here to enjoy (Hall on Franklin and Armature Works are within walking distance). Garagiste has grown substantially in popularity for beer connoisseurs so if they have a bottle release, you may want to visit on another day. I can't wait to go back :)

We came here for my brothers birthday. I had never been here before and parking can get tricky. We stayed in the bar area, the bartenders were amazing. They do not have a fancy drink menu but they will make you anything you want. I loved that they had decent specials throughout the week. Mondays are $1 clams casino and $6 cheeseburgers. 

We ordered the clams casino, chicken tenders and fries, buffalo shrimp. The clams casino were huge and breading mixture on top was delicious. They do keep the clam whole. I really enjoyed the buffalo shrimp, they were colossal sized and the sauce had a very nice kick to it. The fries were crinkle cut. 

I would definitely come back and try some of their other food options.

We stayed at the Grand Hyatt overlooking Tampa Bay for a long weekend of golf and sun in mid-February. 

It turned out to be a perfect location with a great view of the bay, a pool with water of a very inviting temperature and even a chance to sample their room service.  Overall, a very enjoyable stay.

A new favorite spot in South Jersey!

My husband and I have dined at Valente's a few times now and always look forward to our return visit. Love how they keep a few fan favorites on the menu but also update the menu with seasonal ingredients and dishes.

They have two main dining options: "High Top" and "Standard." High Top is seating in the kitchen where you can enjoy watching the kitchen staff preparing the dishes/working in action. It is also a quieter spot if you want to have some "privacy" or quiet setting. "Standard" is the Main Dining Room which has a lively atmosphere. Outdoor Seating is also available on the courtyard in front of the restaurant.

In addition to the a la carte menu, they offer a Chef's Tasting Menu (Reservations Made in Advance), which we have not done yet but that is next on our "to-do" list.

Excellent Service. Food ingredients are top notch. Dishes are composed with great flavors and textures.

BYOB. Public Parking/Street Parking.
Reservations made on OpenTable.

As an adult with a disability who also happens to be a homeowner, I thrive on being as independent as humanly possible. That said, I've learned the hard way that certain tasks are beyond my ability and mowing my nearly 1/2 acre lawn happens to be one of them. 

Trust me, I've tried. I've tried with a push mower. I'm already without feet and I had this weird feeling if I kept going that I'd eventually lose 1-2 more limbs. 

I tried with an old school manual-type mower. I broke it in one humiliating and failed attempt at mowing my lawn. 

I haven't  tried it with a riding mower because, well, most require that you actually have feet to use the gas. 

I've gotten by through the generosity of friends and church members, though as I get older so do they and in the last couple of years it has become increasingly hard to track down folks who want to come over on a regular basis and mow my lawn. 

Last year, it got ugly. I think most of my friends were torn between "I'm tired of mowing Richard's lawn" and "I don't quite want to ask him to pay me to mow his lawn." So, the lawn got really, REALLY long before one dear neighbor complained (sarcasm noted) and my dear friends at the city served notice that perhaps I ought to mow it before it got taller than the house. Fortunately, in a critical pinch I had some friends come over and rescue me from the situation before it turned into an overly negative situation, but it finally made me look at how I'd been living from week-to-week in terms of lawn care for far too long.

So, I set out to find someone who was honest, fair, reasonably priced and conscientious. 

Enter Larry Poe and HALL Services. The "HALL" stands for Handyman and Lawn Landscape Services. I used Thumbtack to put out for bids to mow my lawn and received several responses. The prices ranged from "so cheap that I don't trust the quality" to "beyond my reach." Poe was pretty much in the middle. I directly responded to three and found myself impressed with Poe's honesty, thoughtfulness, reasonable price and willingness to give a fairly clear schedule. 

I've now used HALL and Larry Poe for the entire mowing season and I've been consistently happy. From what I can gather, it's a small operation and he primarily focuses on the Eastside of Central Indiana but will consider other areas in the right situation. From what I've seen, he is careful to not overly commit himself and won't take a job he can't fulfill to the utmost quality. I happen to live in practically a perfect area for him to serve. 

HALL doesn't necessarily have all the razzle dazzle equipment of some companies, but what he offers in personalized service more than makes up for it. I received a timely quote, follow up on that quote, an agreed upon day with an awareness that it may flex from time to time, and a way to contact him with any concerns. He prefers to submit billing via e-mail, but will also invoice monthly. He does not ask for and actually will not do long-term contracts. He accepts payment by cash, checks and Paypal and from what I've seen typically bills within 24-48 hours of the last agreed upon service for the month. We agreed that my lawn would be mowed every other week. During one week, he missed due to some personal issues BUT he followed up with those impacted and explained everything and explained how he would be addressing it. Personally? I thought it was perfect and conscientious. 

The quality has been stellar on a consistent basis. I've never questioned if he would arrive and I've never seen a finished job and thought "I wish he would have done this." In fact, there's been more than once I thought "He did more than I expected" in terms of trimming, etc. 

I've only actually met him in person once this season and found him to be friendly and helpful. He also offers, as you might guess, handyman services ranging from fencing, decks, Christmas light installation and other services. From his website, it notes that he tends to avoid roofing type work. While I haven't used him for handyman type work so far, given how happy I've been with his care of my lawn I'm already considering other possible jobs. 

If you really want to hire someone trustworthy, local, truly indie and who does quality work I'd definitely recommend Larry Poe and HALL Services.

"Me sell'em smokes!"   That's what the wooden Cigar store wooden Indian would say if he could talk! Really? Well, he might also say, "I'm a native American and think smoking is bad for your health!"  Who knows what he would say?????

I've heard very good things about Trip's diner and I've been told several times by different people to try the grits, which is exactly what I ordered paired with the breakfast Cuban and a mango sweet tea.

Let me just tell you this -- be prepared to become an addict because these grits are out of this world good and I believe the cooks who prepare them have hands blessed by Jesus Christ himself! I've never had a glass of sweet tea that I did not have to add extra sugar into until visiting Trip's diner. My friend who is extremely picky when it comes to breakfast items enjoyed the "Mr. crabs omelette", and was amazed at how fresh her food was. Everything was perfect all the way down to the genuine customer service we received from our server.

This will not be the last time Trip's diner sees my face. I'm pretty sure if i lived closer I would be a regular here!

Have you ever heard the old story about the moron who tries to stick up a tavern filled with off-duty cops?  Pretty sure I witnessed the Yelp equivalent of that colossal screw-up last night...except we were "under cover" because a good Yelper never throws around the Yelp name in an attempt to influence an establishment. 

I was dining with a large group of fellow Yelpers and had what was literally the second-worst experience in my STL dining career.  The owner made an unreasonable demand of us (one that most likely would have inspired us to not come to his establishment) pertaining to meal selections; fed us a line of BS about guacamole costing twice as much as the price on the menu due to an increase in the cost of avocados that clearly hasn't manifest itself in the grocery stores; and then berated us after he most likely instructed the kitchen to make the food for everyone else in the restaurant before ours.  He actually had the audacity to show up at our table just to make an "I told you so" comment that painted him as a complete ass in the minds of all present.  He also wanted to argue with those at the table who tried to offer their thoughts on the experience and had the balls to suggest some of us could go back and help out in the kitchen if we didn't appreciate the fact that the meals for our table trickled out over a period of about an hour. 

Guess what, pal...you picked the wrong crowd to screw with!  

About the food:

Best bite of the night was the chicken croquette that Mark P shared. I wished I had ordered a plate of those as an appetizer because they would have made a great side dish. Explanation for those not in attendance: the appetizers showed up with the entrees. 

Worst bite was most certainly the carne asada.  The meat was horribly tough and over cooked. The minuscule amount of chimichurri in the cheezy little plastic thimble was a complete afterthought and tasted like it was out of a can.  Given your Caribbean/Spanish theme, I would have expected the chimichurri to have been something spectacular instead of an afterthought. 

The Ropa viejas was uninspired as well. The meat was supposed to be shredded but there were so many large clumps that it was obvious they took some serious shortcuts in the kitchen. The soffrito was severely lacking in the dish as well and that lead to the overall impression of blandness. 

Note on their cocktails: we arrived early and ordered drinks. I observed the bartender mixing up frozen concentrated juice as he worked on my drink. If you're going to serve a $10 cocktail that includes fruit juice, you damn well should take more pride in it than using frozen concentrate communicates to your patrons. 

Note on the service: adding a mandatory gratuity for a large party does not excuse you from the basics of taking care of a table of GUESTS in your establishment. There was no excuse for bringing someone the wrong drink, putting sugar on the rim of someone else's margarita instead of salt, forgetting included side dishes, failing to take drink orders, ignoring appetizer orders, hiding from your customers instead of paying attention to them, allowing the pitchers of water on the table to run dry or any of a myriad of other shortcomings I witnessed. 

Really the only high point of the evening was the company of some of my Yelp friends. I always thoroughly enjoy hanging out with you folks!

Dinner for two that took over 3 hours, mediocre food and a bill for about $60 all adds up to OH, HELL NO!!!

[440]

This newly built Whole Foods Market is huge compared to old one down the street.  

This store was well thought out as all the aisles are HUGE which allows for more then one cart to walk past without worrying about squeezing by.  The main aisles are not cluttered with stand alone displays.

The produce section is large along with the bulk food sections.  It was nice having so many choices.

We picked up produce, bulk foods, seafood, deli items, grocery items and bakery items.  Well pretty much the entire store except meat.     It's not cheap but many of the items are made with higher quality ingredients and most are organic.   It is great finding all we need in one spot. 

Wish the store was closer but I will definitely visit here often for new items.   I should add that hubby enjoyed the visit and store that he wants "One whole food meal per week if possible"..lol

Fun times with fun people.

Have you seen the short, bright green buses around town that says "Indy Brew Bus"? You can choose an excursion based on starting area and check out four different breweries. Yes, the bus is no frills (we saw other buses that looked a bit more swanky), but at $30 a trip, it is well worth it. Also, it is locally owned and operated and was the first brew bus in Indy. Support local!

We did the Broad Ripple bus, which hit Bier Brewery and Tap Room, Indiana City Brewing Co. Metazoa Brewing Company, and Centerpoint Brewery. The bus basically goes to the furthest brewery and works its way back, so if the first and second legs of the trip seem long, don't worry, it gets shorter as you move onwards. 

You can see my reviews for the actual breweries on their Yelp pages. 

35 minutes at each brewery is a little short. It worked pretty well if there wasn't a line to get beer, but at Metazoa, since it was busy with regular patrons, we basically got our beer and then had to shoot it, because it was time to leave. You can bring beer back on the bus with you, but we got a flight (can't take the glass flight glasses) and we didn't want to take the time to transfer it to plastic cups. Most of the time I ended up drinking part of my beer at the brewery and then the rest on the bus going to the next brewery. I noticed a lot of other people were doing this too.

Just a heads up, four beers in three hours plus samples may not seem like a lot, but it was enough to get us pretty buzzed (and by pretty buzzed one of my friends says she hasn't been that drunk in a while). I sat out drinking at one brewery, which saved me. 

My favorite brewery just in terms of experience was Metazoa. I was predisposed not to like the place, because I'm not a fan of dogs - I'm a monster, I know - but they really made our day when they had us play flip cup. I've never seen a group of adults be more excited to relive their college days (no judgment, I loved it too). 

Our bus driver was fantastic. Being three beers deep I expressed my frustration to him at Metazoa that we were rushed to drink our beers. He gave us ten more minutes at the fourth stop after that. He seriously didn't have to do that, but I'm really glad he did. 

This was such a fun way to experience part of the Indy brewery scene. I would highly recommend it.

Get in the zone?

I have no idea why they chose that as their slogan, but this is a good place to get automotive supplies.

This location used to be my go to spot when I lived in the area, but now I just pick up miscellaneous items. Since this location is next to my favorite car wash, I usually stop to get some interior cleaners and tire foam on my was to the wash.

The parking area is dirty, which is to be expected. People buy parts then change them in the parking lot so it is not uncommon to see someone wrenching. 

The staff is very helpful and will help with advice on how to do repairs. I have seen them helping people remove batteries on several occasions.

If you need parts, this is the place.

I wandered in on my last day in NOLA looking for souvenirs that didn't revolve around alligators and voodoo dolls and was pleasantly surprised to find 100% soy candles made by a local artisan. 

They were reasonably priced and smelled wonderful. There were so many scents that it was hard picking but I immediately grabbed the Green Tea Lemongrass and Coffee Beignet. 

Very cute clothing was also on display and I tried some on. However a quick Google search in the dressing room revealed that I could get the same clothes for half the price online so be sure to double check the brand if you see something you like!

Modesto is my hands-down favorite restaurant in St. Louis. It's a warmly hip, high-spirited eatery that is a far cry from the typical Italian sleepers that have long defined "The Hill".  It's somewhere you can go for a big girls night or conversely, come for a catch-up dinner with friends you haven't seen in years. Every year since they opened in 2001, I meet my high-school best friend and her husband as they visit from Boston over the holidays. One year I made the mistake of 'changing it up' by selecting a Pan-Asian restaurant and I deservedly heard about my error until the next year. Never again.

I live for tapas and sangria, so it's no surprise that I try the most highly-recommended Spanish restaurant in any city I visit or have lived in. From NYC to DC, to Miami to L.A., to Boston to Chicago, I have not tried a better sangria than Modesto's. It's authentically-crafted with Brandy and simmered with sugar before cooling. It's pricey at $24/pitcher, but worth the praise you'll receive for suggesting it as well as the laughs that will soon ensue.

You really can't go wrong with the food. While the paellas are fantastic, the small plates are just more fun. The smoked trout with Serrano bacon and lemon is delicious, and the grilled baby octopus with fried potatoes and the sherry vinaigrette is stellar. The grilled lamb skewers are to-die-for and the Serrano ham cups with avocado, goat cheese and basil with a beet vinaigrette is another can't-miss.

Don't take my word for it, you better show up before I drink them dry of that sangria.

This is a hotel.

I would probably never have stayed here if I hadn't caught it on Priceline, and if we weren't in town explicitly for a dance competition being held at the Hilton just a block away that started at 8am Saturday morning (BELIEVE ME, I would never stay in Kenner [brah] for another reason).

The rooms probably haven't been updated in twenty years.

My bed was missing a slat right under my butt so I slept like this: \ /

There were definitely some colorful characters at basically every turn.

Parking was limited because as others have mentioned, the lot's also rented out as long-term airport parking.

HOWEVER--here's what was positive: the front desk staff was pretty nice; I have the world's crummiest internet at home so this seemed like the zippiest connection ever; and it was $120 for tax, room and EVERYTHING for two nights.

If you had to catch a flight reeeeeally early in the morning, it would be a really convenient stop, because it is literally across the street from MSY.

That said, next time I'm in town staying in the Quarter.

I was hesitant going into dinner here. Two stars on Yelp? And I mean, you guys know your stuff. But I was hoping that this time, collectively, you would all be wrong. But I won't doubt you again.

The Two Rooms Cafe was host to a Girl Geek Dinner, so it was for a big group event that I first came here.

I thought the tri-coloured fusili was actually better than my fellow diners did, but it didn't seem like a dish that would be too difficult to make at home, which always bums me out at restaurants. The chocolate cake for dessert really, really tasted like it was finished off with canned frosting - that kind of synthetic, too sweet kind of taste. Even if it wasn't Betty Crocker, it didn't taste great.

I'll give point for the homemade bannock for the starter, which I loved. I probably could have eaten the whole bowl myself. Still, as a carbophile, I know that impressing me with a baked good ain't all that impressive.

Even if the food wasn't all bad, the price hurt. $30 for bannock, pasta and coleslaw, and a small slice of cake for dessert? Regardless of portion sizes, the quality wasn't there.

It's a great patio to sit on during the summer with a glass of wine, but that's about it.

This place is so cool!  VERY EXPENSIVE, like $300-$700 per hat, but awesome to walk around.  This is now the 2nd time we've been, in fact, we looked all around the place to try and remember where it was b/c we enjoyed it so much.  It's like a hat museum, there's just so many to look at. 

If you need an Easter Bonnet [with all the frills upon it?] or a Derby hat [man I wished they had one in Vegas when I needed a kickass Derby hat] A+ place. They will also custom make you a hat.  I have never seen so many awesome hats.

And over the entrance they have a bubble machine, that puts bubbles out into the street. How cool!

I really liked Clarkson Eyecare when I lived in STL and would be very happy if they had one in Chicago.  I saw Dr. Margit Craig for about 2-2.5 years and she was a great doctor.  She was always helpful and answered any questions I had.

The only problems I ever had were with some of the ladies in the front office about appointments/billing/etc, but I wasn't about to switch doctors because of that.

Before getting our tickets to the Tampa Brewer's Guild Beer Fest, my friends and I had just driven into Ybor and needed something to snack on and be able to absorb the copious amounts of beer we were soon to consume. I suggested we forgo the pizza and try to get something with the flavor of Tampa. Coincidentally, Sulas was directly across the street from the line to get tickets.

Two of my friends went with Cubans, while I went the Gyro. Everyone spoke highly of their food. My Gyro was overflowing with thick slices of meet, had the right amount of onions and tzatiki sauce, and the pita was warm and fluffy. While we didn't try it, they also have serve ice cream and have a more varied menu.

Due to their location, they hit it well on Saturday the 6th, with a steady stream of beer festival goers walking in and ordering.

I see Sulas as a great spot to grab a nice lunch while walking through Ybor, or as a spot to relax after a night out, depending on how late they are open.

This tour was fun and good, but not great.  

I really appreciate all that the tour guides have to put up with in this city - talking back from drunk people in the crowd, random questions, dealing with traffic and pedestrians, and many, many other tour groups all dealing with the same subject and visiting the same locations.  

My tour guide, Randy, was well spoken and discussed everything as part of the tour.  I appreciated that he did not oversell or overexaggerate anything, and provided a skeptical point of view and was very "matter of fact" about the happenings described. 

Somehow I thought the "Five in One" tour would be five different tours, or perhaps five tour guides, combined in one tour.  But this tour has one story each from five supernatural factual histories from the French Quarter, including Vampires, Zombies, Ghosts, Voodoo, and "Magic".  

At the end, our group was all given a "magic spell" to do at home to attract love into our lives.  Eye roll, but fun none the less.  

I don't know how this compares to other tours.  Our group was large and the tour was fun and interesting.

It is hard to review the Princess...

Pro- It is so cool to be in a real, old fashioned theater, that has barely changed in 50 years.
Con- It sucks paying $10.50 to be in a super old, non-HD, tiny screen theater. 

Pro- They play amazing art-house films and documentaries that are usually so so good, and that no other theaters picks up.
Con- Sometimes the film I want to see is gone so quickly and replaced with the next film, I don't get a chance to see it!

Pro- Best movie popcorn in the city!
Con- The skittles are usually stale and old. And I love skittles!

Pro- It is smack dab in the middle of Whyte Ave so you are always surrounded by great coffee shops, restaurants and lounges to go to, before and after the show. 
Con- It is smack dab in the middle of Whyte Ave so you are always searching for somewhere to park, and freezing your butt off half of the year going to and from your car.

Pro- They have $6 Movie Monday.
Pro- Sitting up in the Balcony.
Pro- I just love this place!!! 

Ok, 4stars it is!

Well, what can I tell you that hasn't already been said?  I have visited twice on a Saturday late morning after visiting the farmer's market downtown.

Upon first visit, I only visited the market with food.  i picked out a small batch of sausage and cheese homemade raviolis (for the hubby), an Italian breadstick, some biscotti, a couple of apricot filled cookies, a cinnamon babka!, a meat stick (for the hubby), a couple of cheeses (one happens to be my favorite triple cream brie), a block of parmesan, a honey clover gouda and......that might have been all.  WOW what a variety of things.

It can be a little daunting at first, so many little nooks and crannies, make sure you look in them all.

The wine and cheese room is large, I haven't been through all the wines, but I have looked through all the cheeses....
I haven't been through all the desserts but I am in love with the walnut/cinnamon biscotti and apricot filled cookies.
I haven't tried any other bread but the Italian stick and it's the best bread on the planet! (Italian bread, that is)...
I didn't yet try any of their pastas, but I heard it was fantastic!

I have not yet checked out their sandwich counter, the meat counter or their produce but the pricing on the produce is a bit high.

This place has it all.  Pricing really isn't too high on most goods.

Speaking of goods.....the other building, the home goods....WHAT A FABULOUS PLACE FOR GIFTS (FOR YOURSELF!).  It has some of the cutest things, everything from your own pasta cutters, bowls, whisks, kitchen towels, measuring stuff, dish ware, BBQ stuff, cards, candles, cheeseboards, utensils of EVERY sort....and guess what - they are ALL very reasonably priced.  Check it!

I will definitely be back.  I would not make a trip strictly there, but whenever I am in the area, it will be a MUST STOP THERE on my way home!!!  Great place.

A1 service. Impeccable waiting area. Free refreshments. Knowledgable staff. Nice waiting area. Loaner vehicles if needed. Hands down this place is top rate. 

Ok so I didn't say anything about the prices, but you know what to expect, it's Mercedes Benz.  ANYWHO...

Although I can hardly ever catch my service advisor at her desk on the moment I call, Jessica normally returns the call before the day ends. And when she calls back, I'm receiving answers to my questions & queries of ways she can help. 

I love the new uniforms the staff wear, very modern & classy. 

Curb side service & addressing you by your name as you exit the car, I mean really, who wouldnt like this attention. Assistance with transferring your belongings to the loaner vehicle... Yes & yes. Having an Enterprise rental facility on-hand makes for a plus in my mind. Normally they can get you back in a Benz, but sometimes they can't, but the loaner is normally another premium/luxury vehicle. 

All in all, I'm totally satisfied with this business && if you have a Mercedes, I recommend this facility.

This is the newest location for Plato's closet in the area.

Pros:

Lots of brand names (especially Bebe, Free People, Juicy and more not just Aero and Hollister like most places)

Cons:
Prices here are slightly higher than other locations  (I've been told anyway)

I do feel like it's more worth it to come here though, just because you'll find items that you do want without having to search through all the preppy, Aero/Hollister/AE stuff. (It is there but doesn't overwhelm the inventory like Springfield)

Needed Gas on the way to my MOM's house before leaving for my trip to Alabama. The price was right at $1.69.  This racetrack is neat on the outside and neat on the inside with quick service and clean pumps.  

If you can avoid the Pasco County yahoos who drive through here as a cut through to avoid the light at 19/fox hollow, you'll do just fine. Otherwise, someone might try to take your bumper off.

Bought a second Hyundai Sonata from FB (A 2012, we also have a 2006).
Got about $500 in "credits" for buying a second time (whoopie!).
So far, so good - we've had the car about three minutes.

Dos Amores (Two Loves) Mexican Cuisine is a strictly take out stall in the Village of Newtown Farmers Market. Along with the rest of the shops it is only open Thursday through Saturday, so there is only a small window for getting in/out with a good sampling of their south of the border offerings. Most are of the self contained variety, like enchiladas, quesadillas, empanadas and chile rellenos, that can be prepared in advance, kept cool and then heated at home in the microwave or oven. You can also eat in the market within the common dining area at the back of the store. 

That is what I did. I ordered beef and chicken empanadas, and asked them to be heated for consumption in the market. That took all of 3 minutes. They were handed to me in a paper boat with small containers of salsa and sour cream. Other sides were available, but as it was my first dive into their delectables, I opted to forego any additions. 

Both empanadas were very good. The dough was crisp and strong enough to stay together as I bit through them. The chicken and ground beef were both nicely spiced, and I was also able to pour more salsa inside through the bite hole, and keep it contained until next munch. The beef was cooked with more chili powder, and had a warmer profile than the chicken. Still, I enjoyed them both for their freshness and authenticity. Like everything else in this market, prices are high. You pay the same as if you were dining in a full service restaurant. 

The atmosphere of the farmers market is entertaining with all the Amish/Mennonite vendors dressed in their traditional garb and speaking colloquially. That is certainly worth the premium paid, as it is the only place in town where there is a real cultural exchange. Admittedly, Dos Amores lacks the Pennsylvania Dutch accent, but their Spanish makes up for that. 

I really should come here more often just to step away from modern times for a little while and enjoy all the interesting grub.

We attended a corporate party at the DuPont country club and it was great.  The club itself seems as though it has been around for-eh-ver.  Old school ballroom decor.  Nice restooms, dancefloors, place for a band, terraces.

Good for weddings, parties and large events.

Food was surprisingly good - pasta station, carving station, crepe & dessert waffles with BIG fresh berries.  Also a sushi bar brought in by Okura in Hokessin.

Good stuff!

Loved Tuna Bar! Upon entering I was so impressed with the modern, trendy space and impeccable attention to detail every where I turned. So many decor pieces and architectural aspects I love here! They had me at wrap around banquet seating in a pop of turquoise. I had a feeling I was in for a good meal from the interior design alone. I was...

First visit was for a casual, lighter lunch with my daughters and an old girlfriend which it was just perfect for! We did make ressies on Open Table which wasn't necessary for a mid week lunch, but I would suggested for dinner. 

While we stuck to some basics, they were pretty great! California, California with real crab made crispy, cucumber roll, peanut avocado (the kids' favorite!), seaweed salad, edamame, and incredible Brussels! Must order! Everything was super fresh and came out in a timely fashion. 

Service was fantastic! 
Prices were fair. 

I can't wait for my next visit perhaps for date night when I can taste some of those delicious sounding cocktails and dig into some entrees. 

I love having Tuna Bar as a new option in the Old City area just a bit away from the hustle and bustle, whether that be for lunch, happy hour (which sounded really great!), or dinner...with the kiddos, or without. It will be be on my radar for the next First Friday or after a movie at The Ritz!

I actually found it a tad difficult to spot from the street. It's the door just to the left of United Blue. Not a huge sign. It's there, trust me :) 

*Limited kiosk meter parking.

Dive bar- seriously. 

To start with its in a not so great area of town and parking is slim. The building is divided- right side is the bar area and left has a decent sized low stage area that holds about six people and a small dance floor with a few high top tables. 

It's one of those places that if I drank beer it would be from a bottle here. So no drink ordered at this trip, I watched my friend's drink for tampering. Yes I feel it's that kind of place. And the bathroom situation is odd and unique- two toilets that face each other. Now I don't know how guys act in the bathroom but I can tell you the ladies don't sit there facing each other and chat up a storm. I will pee before coming back here again and be the designated driver any time you want to check out this "nightclub "

If you have to spend the whole day on and off of Mass Ave, it's certainly not a bad thing to spend much of it at Henry's. While I didn't grab any food from this adorable little cafe, I sampled many a beverage and took in the overall ambiance of the place as the day rolled on! 

If it's a gorgeous day, grab a seat on the patio. The shady trees and variety of seating makes it a lovely place to sit and enjoy your latte. Be aware, though, the street can get super loud with multiple buses coming through! Inside, Henry's (at least in the morning hours) is like a library. So. Quiet. As in so quiet I felt like I was being too loud. But that's neither here nor there. 

As for the drinks, I was quite fond of my hazelnut latte. It was made with the right amount of foam and neither too sweet or too dull. A lovely way to start the day, if I do say so. Both prices and staff were friendly and I have no doubt I could wedge myself into a corner and get a ton of work done.

Sometimes smaller is better!  Not too many guys say that but we'll stay on the subject of hoagies!

If you sell something for over 35 years and survive you've gotta be doing something right.

4 1/2 stars influenced a coworker and I to visit this postage stamp sized place for lunch this week.  It's off the beaten track about two minutes from Lancaster Ave. Street parking was easy and a breath of fresh air.  No meters!

Wonderful aromas were spilling out the door as we walked in.  All the usual hoagie suspects were there including hot roast pork or roast beef.  Hoagies come in either 6" inch or 12' sizes and that is very much appreciated.  Sometimes when I'm working and need a quick lunch I don't need a sandwich that will feed a family of five for a month.  So I ordered the 6" Italian.

I was stunned by what happened next.  The lady that was making my sandwich proceeded to cut all my meats TO ORDER!  I'm so used to seeing them pulled off a pre-cut stack I think my mouth dropped open.  Now that is FRESH!

I grabbed my sandwich and a can of soda from the cooler, paid about $7 total and headed back to the office.  

As you can see from my pic is was a fine looking sandwich and tasted damm good. Even better I could actually finish it without needing an afternoon nap, So for lunch, 6" really was better than 12"!

I could eat a dozen of these donuts in one sitting. Probably one of the best donut places I have ever been to.

I tried the strawberry lavender, brown cinnamon sugar, and the lemon with the marshmallow on top. I had them as soon as they hand rolled it. It was so warm and perfect touch to the wintry weather we experienced while purchasing these.

I would definitely want to come back to try the other flavors.

I like this place for date nights, they don't have high chairs so it's a great excuse to get a babysitter and enjoy alone time with my husband. I also took some friend here who were visiting from out of town and they loved it. 
Having been there a few ties now I've pretty much ate my way through the entire menu and I would recommend the chicken rotissarie. It comes with spicy potatoes and yummy salsas to try. This is a sharing platter but if you are feeling hungry get a couple of sides too. The cauliflower is so goooood. Usually I hate the stuff but here it is cooked to perfection with loads of garlic and cilantro. 
Always get the churros. They will offer dessert after your meal, even if you are full, get them to share. It's only three donut sticks of delight. Yum.

Check in to save $5 off a $25+ order. Miss MARY was phenomenal-- friendly, attentive, fast, & professional. She was so sweet; she brought me extra blue cheese because she was worried that my special order wings might be too dry. Whenever we needed her attention, she was at our table quickly. 

The wings were really good (not dry) & our catered entrees of pasta, Greek salad, chicken tenders, Shepherds Pie, & Cuban sandwiches was very good as well...or so I was told by six table mates who laughed @ me for taking pics for Yelp:) 

This Irish pub has an excellent staff (everyone was very friendly), there's a live band (unsure of the nights, but definitely Friday & Saturday), & the food is quite standard pub fare (& good). There are six TVs on the wall. If I lived in the area, I'd definitely stop in for booze & finger foods on a regular basis. Just a comfortable atmosphere. 

If you need a venue to hold a work or sports related (etc.) event, the staff here puts out a great spread & follows up w/ excellent, friendly service. Kudos to everyone! 

Go rainh maith agat!

If they can get their delivery time to under 60 minutes, and FOR SURE under 90, they will get bumped up a star. Because their food is excellent! But man, they have always taken forever to deliver. Granted we may be a bit far for them, but they never objected so I figure it must be acceptable.

E really likes this place and he always hates on Chinese food when that's what I want. Which is often. He gets the lo mein and is always pleased by how non-greasy and fresh it is. They also put in a ton of veggies. I have gotten the general tso (probably would have been better hot and fresh instead of 90 minutes old and a bit soggy) and the sweet and sour chicken (really good!) dinner combos. The fried rice is also fresh and tasty, not oddly yellow and hard like some places, and prepared sans onion as requested.

Don't get the popcorn chicken app. It has cinnamon sprinkled all over it. Don't ask me why, but it wasn't good at all. The dumplings were decent and seemed house made, but the filling was a little on the mushy side. Good dipping sauce. Also greatly enjoyed the bang bang wings.

My only beef with them, other than the delivery issue, is that they don't have hot and sour soup on the menu. It's usually the dish that makes me want Chinese food, so that's a little bit of a bummer.

I love the turkey on challah. The meat is shaved and not overly salty; the bread is soft inside with a great crust. Plus the portion of meat is very generous. Prices are very good and the service fantastic. If you need catering trays, the assorted sandwiches option is inexpensive and will feed 10+ easily.

5 Star service from Vera (hostess) and our amazing and attentive server, Kaitlyn.  Wow - we were seated outside on a hot, sticky, humid Father's Day and Kaitlyn was just on point!

Our party of 6 truly enjoyed the sweet potato fries and fried brussels sprouts (sans bacon) which we all shared and wolfed down.

For entrees we enjoyed a variety of burgers (brioche buns), flatbread, "power bowl" and a "healthy" salmon on pita called "The Edinburgh".  I would totally come back here.

Great place for families at lunch and a different, noisier crowd at night.

Spiders are creepy, dark water is scary but the dentist... the dentist is TERRIFYING. The dentist is my biggest fear and my most painful childhood memory. I would rather retake the SAT, every college final AND my driver's test before going to the dentist. Unfortunately for me, dental hygiene is not exactly ~optional~. 

At this point in my life I have been through so many dentists desperate to find one that could possibly maybe make the experience not as traumatic. And you know what, I have finally found that dentist in fact I found that dental team. Everyone at the Pezzella Family Dentistry Office has done wonders to change my perspective of the dentist. 

Dr. Pezzella, Eileen and Sherry are some of the kindest most patient souls I have ever met. They do not shame me for my fear nor do they make me feel embarrassed about the amount of work my teeth need after years of avoiding the dentist! Sherry goes above and beyond to connect with me and my husband on a personal basis, she will call my cell and sometimes even text me if I request in regards to scheduling etc... I still try to avoid the dentist but she has made it impossible with her consistent efforts to help me take care of myself! Bless that woman for her patience. 

This is called "Family Dentistry" a dentist for the whole family, yes. But what I think they might secretly mean by that is "Family Dentistry, because we are going to make you a part of our shiny teeth family". I still hate the dentist, but I love this dentist.

Henry's has been open for about three months now.  This fourth version of the chain opened just along Keystone Pkwy and 31.  As those know, construction has been impacting businesses along the corridor.  So that was why we decided to stop for lunch today and support the restaurant.

I didn't know anything going in except the rave reviews by other fellow Yelpstas.  While I've found many reviews "off" comparing my personal experience since being in Indy, this case proved spot-on and left me with wanting more.

More of the personal greeting by the hostess.  More of the views and the shooting fountain from large viewing windows.  More of Laura who was by far the most incredible server I have had in.... well, probably in my entire life.  More of Mark, the General Manager, who you could tell was proud of his establishment, staff, and position- to make people feel good.  More of the most incredible cod fish tacos layered in ingredients most couldn't mimic let alone create.  More of the pool tables and shuffleboard right in the middle of the restaurant.  More of the small touches that leave a lasting impression like mouthwash in the restrooms.  I could give you more, but I want you to experience it for yourself.  

I have to throw in a summary of Laura's service.  This is what every single restaurant should model if they want to create a competitive edge.  Service in Indy lacks.  Laura- you should start a consulting business on the side.

She came to our table.  Her very first sentence was "Are you under any time constraints that i should be made aware of like catching a movie?"  Impressive.  To even take the time to tailor the experience to my needs--- that never happens.  Laura knew her menu inside and out.  She was so passionate about each and every ingredient and how it contributed to the overall dish.  We decided to play shuffleboard.  She brought us a glass of wine to the game floor.  Another nice touch that relieved us from going back to the table.  She was prompt.  Informative about the rewards program, which by the way you get 100 points equal to $100 when you confirm your email, and applied our spend to today's total.  

I can't wait to go back.  It's my place for football games.  Plenty of flat screens allow you to watch games outside of the bar area and take in a game of pool.  Top notch service and truly a solid choice whether it's with your family during an afternoon lunch, a dinner date with your mate, or a night out and drinks with friends.  The audience morphs throughout the day and night and Henry's adjusts with them.  Now I need to adjust my plans so that I'm back at Henry's sooner than later.  What an incredible experience!

I didn't actually buy anything here, but that's partly why I'm giving it 5 stars: because I tried so much stuff and got my fill of sweets from just perusing the amazing variety of abundant samples available.

Maybe I was just on a sugar high and didn't notice it like some of the other people are complaining about, but I was treating the place like my own kitchen and sampling anything and everything sweet I saw, and the woman at the counter didn't bat an eye. It could be that they were about to close and she was sick of it after a long day, but whatever the case, the candies here are great.

You should definitely stop in here to sample (or buy I guess) the pralines and the Mississippi mud pie in particular, which were some of the best of the several things on display.

Mediocre at best is how my husband described the lunch we just had at Montana's. Our server was nice and the atmosphere was pleasant enough but that is where the warm fuzzies stop.

I ordered steak fajitas for $18.99 and they were basically flavorless. The salsa lacked anything resembling spice and I don't think the veggies and steak were seasoned either. The sizzling platter wasn't sizzling and my food was lukewarm at best.

My husband ordered the Texas BBQ Beef Brisket Sandwich for $11.99. We have been watching a lot of Diners Drive-Ins & Dives on the food network lately so this sounded really good... Unfortunately, that is where the similarity stopped. The meat was lean but was boring and I swear missing BBQ sauce! For side, my husband chose Sweet Potato Fries which tasted like they had spent the last hour under a lamp - also lukewarm.

The meal was boring...  The food lukewarm at best... And the price? $40 plus tip.

No Drive-Thru and not very well stocked food wise, had to wait for rangoons and chicken.
Food was ok, but service was slow and the girls behind the counter seemed more interested in talking to their co-worker than interacting w/customers.

4.5

The folks in Donelson have been trying to tell us for a while: spend some time here. Things have changed. While natives and transplants alike were focused on this and that 'upcoming area,' Donelson slowly and surely raised its profile, added the businesses and waited for people to catch up.

It worked.

A day or errands caught me in Donelson. I'd planned on eating lunch at a relatively unhealthy spot when I saw the line was long and I rebuked it!* Looking down at my tight-around-the-belly t-shirt, I reconsidered my foolish notion to eat a bunch of fattening stuff and thought that I might have a salad. Or, air. Then I thought to see what was nearby. Genius, I know. 'Nectar. Hmm, let's give it a try.' It had been on my radar for a little while but I was confused by the 'Mexican on one side, smoothies on another' thing they had going on and I put it off. That was a mistake. Y'see, some days you're in the mood for tacos. Other days you want a smoothie. Nectar just figured out that putting both under the same roof (but different spaces) just.made.sense. Points to them.

I parked in front, chose the healthy side and walked in. Wow. There's an entire wall full of menu options and pre-made juices (if you want to grab and go). Since I was committing to eating healthy, I decided to slow it down and eat there (on the cafe side). Since it was hot as the dickens (thanks, climate change), I opted for a cold bowl. To my delight, I discovered that the granola was gluten-free so I ordered the Almond Brothers. Ridiculous. It was so ridiculously good. The large bowl came out cold, creamy and with the stamp of being my server's favorite. It has a base of blended almond milk, bananas, cacao, maca, protein powder, and peanut butter. Then, it's topped with granola, honey, chia seeds, pecans, MORE cacao, and bee pollen. With every spoonful I nearly broke my arm patting myself on the back with how healthy I was being -- and healthy tasted delicious!! I tried to savor the bowl but I wanted to eat it as fast as I could. Luckily, the portion was so large that despite my greed, it took me a while to get through it. To pair with my cold dish, I ordered a hot latte. Staying healthy, I went for the Golden Chai Latte, which starred a good amount of turmeric. 

Leaving Nectar, I was so so happy. Seriously. Like, my endorphins were activated or something. There's something to putting healthy fuel in your body. Without a doubt, if I lived closer I would be here regularly. As it is, I am figuring out a way to stop by each time I am spending time in Donelson. I need to go down that smoothie menu. Middle Tennessee folks, if you haven't been here yet, you're wasting time. You are.

*Something like that.

This isn't a furniture store IT'S A COMPLEX! 

Wowzers...I finally made it by this infamous IKEA and I must admit the rumors have done no justice. This place is amazing. Offering everything your life needs:

Daycare for all the baby mama shoppers 
Lockers for safekeeping 
Groceries 
Full restaurant 
Kitchen d√©cor
Dining ensembles 
Bathroom necessities 
Children's rooms 
Closest assortments 
Living Room furniture 
Bedroom furnishings 
Accessories such as rugs, lamps, dishes, flatware, mirrors, storage consoles, appliances, throws, accent pillows, lighting, knobs, cooking utensils, glassware, desk, house slippers, luggage, teddy bears and so much more I'm just fresh out of typing energy.

Plenty of lot parking with easy signage to navigate you through the complex. There's also a parking garage so you don't get wet on rainy days (we all know sugar melts). 

Customer service reps are readily available throughout the entire store to answer any questions (I noticed you don't even have to ask for assistance) if you stand still and look slightly puzzles an IKEA rep comes to you and ask if you need help. 

I love this place...can't wait until the recession is over so I can go shopping on all 3 levels. 

~Christy

Cozy townhouse converted into a resto.  Dined here and it was lovely/intimate.  Shared a Hamachi and bay scallops then the duck for me and the seabass for him. 3 or 4 appetizers for 2 people as they are smallish but delicious.  The wines were great and the souffle along with the passionfruit buttercake were the perfect finish!

*WARNING*
These donuts are sickly addicting. Consume at your own risk.

Once upon a time in a not so far away place there was a chain donut shop. This chain donut shop had been around for a very long time. Not knowing how long a long time was, patrons of all sorts would pass through the drive thru when they saw the "hot donuts now" sign lit up from the road.

Glazed, sour dough, chocolate, sprinkles, and so much more would be readily available for people to buy! The assortment was delectable and the warmth of the donut was like Heaven. It was so good that it would almost melt in your mouth.

This is the kind of excited I get from Krispy Kreme. It's like a guilty arousal that I shouldn't admit to anyone. Ooops...I just did. Who would have thought I would have just randomly stumbled upon my "happy place" in South County!

Every time my family would go on vacation to The Smoky Mountains, we would make the 7 mile trip from Gatlinburg where we were staying to get our Krispy Kreme fix in Pigeon Forge. Think of it like this -- we drove through winding mountains, dealt with traffic and a bunch of unnecessary stop lights just to get these damn donuts! I have never gotten them outside of Gatlinburg until today. 

I'm very happy for finding my beloved Krispy Kremes! I did indeed spend a $1.08 on a hot, fresh out of the oven glazed donut, and I will make a 10 mile trip down I-55 South just to get my fix again very soon.

Went here today for lunch with an old, old friend who I haven't seen for about 15-18 years.  (Really.)

We both had lunch specials - He got a 3 roll for $13 and I got a 2 roll for $10.  Both came with a choice of soup or salad and we both had a good (albeit generic) fresh salad with tasty dressing.

The Ginza roll was excellent - cooked salmon, mayo, oinion and tempura flakes.  Crunchy and very Americanized - but good.  My yellowtail roll was just OK.  I can tell the quality of this place is not high end - but for a cheap sushi lunch I would, in fact, go back.

Service was unassuming and prompt - the large dining area was not even close to busy - maybe 4 tables occupied.

I would never waste my money on all-you-can-eat sushi (or all-you-can-eat anything for that matter) since I don't go for quantity - I need quality.  This place is OK - but no holy grail.

Tony loves this place and claims the BEST BBQ in the Nashville area. Noel had never been here before so we opted to take her...The place was not very busy. So we were seated immediately, then the waitress took our drink order..Tony Bud in a bottle, myself Soda and Noel wanted Rootbeer.  The waitress served Bud Lite ..ugh she messed up that quickly...so we had to send her back.

Tony and I opted to share a BBQ platter of Brisket, Ribs and smoked Sausage with sides of green beans and mac n; cheese and a slice of Texas Toast.  The food was good...but not the best...but definitely good. We went to celebrate the fact Tony as a new job with a construction company...

Noel ordered a burger with fries..and OF COURSE I had to try the fries...KILLER !!!
We will definitely return. The food was good.  I would recommend to everyone if you are in the area...GO !!!! Eat some BBQ and leave a review to share your opinion !!!!

I personally have not had a very good experience with this train station - they close down their escalators and do not open them up until 5-10 minutes before boarding which only makes the boarding line EXTREMELY long when they make the announcement that we can board.  As a first-timer, there was NO sign detailing this so I spent about a half hour searching for stairs leading downstairs (so thankful I arrived early) and lugged my 50-lb suitcase down 3 flights of stairs only to find that I had to lug it back up those stairs to get in that stupid line. 

There is a very active and bustling food court area, Doc Popcorn is a pretty unique find (try their sinfully Cinnamon and Poppin Jalapeno flavors).

Andrea's advertises itself as "Northern Italian" to distinguish itself from the largely Southern Sicilian tradition that is prevalent in New Orleans.  The advertisement, however, doesn't seem to translate into the actual food as the dishes seem very similar to other NOLA area restaurants.  

For full disclosure I need to admit I've only eaten here at lunch so dinner could be a different story.  The food is good basic Italian and the chef has always been making the rounds in the dining room and has always asked me how my food was (so extra kudos for that).  I've always had good service and the food has been consistently good (just not outstanding).  If you are in the area and craving some Italian food this is a good place to sample.

We got the "E" here for the crawl. A soft spoken 
Mixologist welcomed us and brought us our sidecar and marvelous craft cocktail. Good taste comparison.

Lots of good ingredients and items to make ones whim of a drink.

There has been  about 3 or 4 bars before in that spot, but they really improved the bar area and bottle presentation. A beautiful dark and warm ambience. Enjoyed watching "Barbarella" on the multiple tv's.

This is a new sushi restaurant in the Target shopping center... They have done a good job decorating the interior. Their specials all day everyday is 50% off selected sushi and hand rolls. It's actually a large list of items to choose from at 50%.. I've been in a couple times since they opened a few weeks ago and think this place is definitely worth a try. It's also a byob with the Beer Center just two doors to the left. 
It'll be one of my late lunch spots from now on..

This is the type of Cuban sandwich that you can't stop eating. If you think that you are going to eat half now, and the other half later, well, I got bad news for you: it's not going to happen. If you want something for later, buy another sandwich. You won't regret it, these Cubano sandwiches are so good. The combination of amazing bread, well portioned ham and pork, good and plentiful Swiss cheese, and the right heating point make this sandwich an amazing dish. There are not many places in Florida that make amazing Cuban sandwiches, and this is definitively one of them. Tops for me at least.

On my first visit here, I only wanted to try the Cubano sandwich. I have tried them at other restaurants in Tampa, and Tampa had nothing on other rival cities that claim to have the best Cuban sandwich. After trying this sandwich, I have changed my mind and I must say that Tampa has a great sandwich, and MIchelle Faedo is one of two places that you need to visit. I did not try anything else, although many things looked good. I will surely come back, despite the cafeteria vibe of this place, not judging, just saying.

I maintain my MUST TRY recommendation... Brisket is still so tender and yummy...mmmm
The wings are very good and the ribs are very tasty as well.
Looks like I'll be stopping here again when in the area

Going with what the Yelp consensus said, we made reservations for the rooftop area on a Saturday night ahead of time. The temperature was just chilly enough to sit outdoors so I was excited. Located right on Bourbon street, we walked right in and told to wait a few for our table to be ready on the roof top. When we proceeded to the third floor, the area is divided and only a few tabes are truly on the rooftop area (meaning that overlook Bourbon street) The table that they gave us was not one of those and the host explained that those were not for regular reservations only deposit reservations. Since I was not aware of any of that and they didn't clarify at the time of reservations, I pleaded for what I thought we had reserved. A rooftop table. After a little snag from the host, she finally gave us a great table at the end. Honestly I think it was fuss that could've been avoided. We were going to eat and drink, I don't get it. Anyways, away her vibe and in come our waitress for the night!

Can I tell you that the vibe completely changed when our Maddie waitress took over? Wow she was great we had such a fab night. We took her recommendations for the dishes and had a fantastic first dinner in New Orleans. The music was playing, the weather was cool, the Cajun fried catfish and shrimp over penne, the mambo oysters delish! Wow my mouth is watering remembering those oysters right now. And the warm rum bread pudding? I think it had praline sauce. If you're in the area, give Mambos a shot. I recommend upstairs if you can.

Based on the outstanding reviews of crab fries, I hustled my ass here to try what people said was a must have.

Ah... I've had better and wouldn't waste my money or time trying to do this again.  Sorry Y'al, but the fries reminded me of seasoned fries you can get anywhere, and the cheese dipping stuff, while decent, was no where near a repeat in my book.  Definitely not something to write home about.  

Give me Garlic Fries at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles ANYDAY over these puppies.  The crab fries left me wondering what I missed.

Yes! I've taken everyone who's come to visit me here and I've only gotten good responses...from me! Okay, from my loved ones too. My last visit, a late Friday night and I was surprised to see an open table as well as all their food still available. Their special that day, pulled pork with egg and pimento cheese and two sauces. I think a lot of their specials are sandwiches and like the last one I had it was a solid, showing a flair for using their on hand ingredients and making something slightly off the path.

My sis loved the bbq nachos so I assumed my gf would but her rib platter took precedence especially since the nachos took some time Friday-they had to make more cheese. The ribs were slightly smoky, had a nice char but still had some juiciness to it. The nachos came and we were so stuffed from our food that we saved them for later. Solid outings each time. Probably my favorite BBQ in Nashville so far.

Why 4 stars?  Because it's a well-run mom and pop coffee shop.

   ---   ---   ---

I have to admit, the coffee itself from Buddy Brew is not my favorite, but I do like their style. 

-Placing your order on an iPad
-The industrial ambiance inside
-As mentioned in the preamble, the mom&popness.

They have done a great job of being on the top of mind when I am driving around Kennedy and feeling like I could use a boost.

Old Glory is a fascinating 1920's boiler room that was converted into a speakeasy. If you are wandering around the alley behind Taco Mamacita in Edgehill then you are not the only one lost (I must have walked back and forth a few times scratching my head). There is no sign letting you know that you have arrived. Go up a couple steps to a black door with a large golden triangle framing the wall around it. As you walk in, you will again wonder if this is where you think it is. If this thought enters your mind then yes, you're here! You will find yourself on a balcony where you descend a curved stairwell then be met with the scene of a cool bar area, the large boiler and a dark, moody ambiance. What is so interesting about this space is that they clearly did not change the original elements of the building but built around the features. There are a few small seating areas that are very cozy looking as well as another staircase past the bar which led up to additional seating (more spacious) on a balcony area overlooking the bar. There are few other spots I've discovered that has the same artistic quality as Old Glory. 

I came here for a networking event in the evening and I felt like I was squinting at people to try and see who I recognized. Give it a few minutes and your eyes will adjust. The bar area was very crowded so I waited patiently for a drink and attempted to squeeze around multiple people. I perused the specialty winter drink menu for 30 seconds then fixated my eyes on a drink called the Velvet Frost. The bartender put ice in a gimlet glass to chill it then started the artful mixing of  the elements of the drink which included gin, coconut and pineapple. This frothy, fruity drink was topped off with a spring of some type of herb. Although on the pricier side for a cocktail I thought "when in Rome" so I went with it. It was delicious. Later on in the evening I got a Moscow mule which was made very well (although not served in a copper cup). The drinks were worth the wait. 

Overall, a must-have experience for any residents of Nashville. While dive bars are more my scene it is nice to dress it up a bit and have a classier experience. The ambiance is incredible, the drinks are amazing and it is a win!

If you're a hat lover, cowboy, cowgirl or simply curious about hats- Arizona Hatters is a must. They have fairly wide variety of hat styles, although they are primarily known for their selection of Western cowboy hats, aka- Stetson. But you can find non-Western styles such as fedora, large sun hats, traditional, contemporary and event golf caps! You'll find straw, felt, wool, leather, and surely more materials. They carry other accessories such as belts, bolo ties, hatbands, (check out their selection of the hand beaded bands, they are beautiful!)

They are true experts in all things hats and are specialized in hat renovations/repair, maintenance and custom fitting/shaping. Full-service hat cleaning is also available in store. The store manager Chuong is an expert seamstress too! She has been working with AZ Hatters for over 30 years and is highly skilled in repairs, fitting and shaping. 

Buying a hat is like buying anything else that should be properly fitted, like shoes, a suit, denim, etc. Arizona Hatters will not let you leave with an ill fitting hat, you can count on that! The customer service is excellent. They are super friendly and knowledgable. Arizona Hatters is where many ranchers and cowboys from Southern AZ go to purchase hats and or/get them re-blocked. Arizona Hatters started out serving ranchers with Western ware, so they know their stuff! 

On our visit we got to meet and chat with the owner, Mark, and he's the nicest person. Super passionate about his store, providing great service and he really does love hats! You can't get this service and attention from an online retailer.

In town for business once every quarter and Ron's is usually a stop for the team. It is a solid bar and grille with an expansive menu ranging from Stromboli to pesto covered rib eye and asparagus. With a menu so large you would think the execution would be flawed on the food and while the food was nothing extraordinary, it was certainly tasty and filling. Each of us ended up with 2 meals as the portions are definitely on the generous side. I personally had the chicken parm, while my cohorts all had pizzas and Stromboli's. None of us had any complaints relating to the food, service, ambiance or prices. Overall, Ron's is a great spot for the local or visitor. We will continue to do our group dinners here when in town!

Mercy! Mercy! Me! In My best Marvin Gaye voice. Such a fun spot to have some drinks and muster up energy to SPILL IT, BLAME IT, CONCEAL IT..then have a REFILL.  I love the ambiance in this bar. Watching bartenders stir and shake makes my night MAG. I wish there was a happy hour here. The location is perfect a perfect start to the night.. Say hi to Victory, Indulge, Windsor Cort, W, maybe the Hyatt if you are prepared. I much prefer this part of the Downtown area because it doesn't have the city congestion.

Can confirm..this is probably the best hotel to stay at in wilmington. Super clean and brightly lit compared to the others. Staff is friendly and accommodating Trust me...I have stayed at most of the spg properties in the area!

Nothing like writing a baseball park review weeks after the season ends.  Whatever - Citizens Bank Park deserves some post season lovin'.  

Fact: I am not a Phillie's fan.  But that doesn't mean I can't appreciate a nice ballpark when I see one.  CBP is convenient to get to from city center, has a ton of parking, clean, easy to navigate, and I don't think there's a bad seat in the place.  And the view of downtown Philly over the outfield wall, while small, is pretty spectacular.

Oh and the bell in the outfield that lights up and dings after each home run is totally kitchy but I loved it.

Portillo's is fine, but I just don't get all the hubbub surrounding this chain. Maybe someone who loves it can explain it to me, and fill me in on what I should order. Because every time I eat here, I'm always like, "That chili dog was alright" or "I guess I'll just eat these fries because they're sitting here." I don't especially like my food, but I don't not like it -- it's just fine.

This Avon Portillo's is huge inside, with lots of seating. The dining room kind of reminds me of a restaurant that you would see in Disneyland or something: the area where you stand in line to order is big and snakes around to accommodate a large crowd. Fortunately, when we visited, it wasn't crowded at all and we were able to just step up and order right away. After you order, they call your number and you pick up your bags of food. (For some reason, they put our food in a bag even though we were dining in.)

Another thing about the dining room: The music they play in the restaurant is about three notches too loud -- it's at that annoying level where it's just loud enough to make talking and hearing difficult. This might not be a good place to sit and eat if you want to be able to carry on a conversation.

I guess we get to do a new review because they changed their name?  OK.

A while back ago, they were running a special we couldn't refuse.  An XL thin crust pizza (28''x9'') and 12 wings for $20.  One the pizza, we went with Italian sausage and mixed peppers, very tasty!  Love the sauce here.  It's chunky, semi-sweet and tastes amazingly fresh.

As for the wings, we went with the blackened garlic.  The wings were also great, and they're baked.  Not as crispy and delicious as fried wings, outstanding nonetheless.  Would recommend.  

On our most recent visit, we stopped in to take advantage of a free cheese pizza coupon we got in the mail.  This time, we sampled the hand-tossed pizza, and added mushrooms.  I've gotta say, it was damn good.  So good, in fact, that I ate the last two take-out slices within an hour of getting home.

We also had an Caprese salad, which was alright.  The cheese and dressing were fine, but the sad little plum tomatoes they served us were pale, not quite ripe and tasteless at best.

Lastly, the new decor is great.  The Tampa theme with its paintings and pictures represent our little city well.

I have to update my review now that the downstairs part is also open.

Even though it's like a third of a floor, opening the downstairs part really makes a huge difference. Now, on the first floor, there is an area for the 3 and under crowd, a huge water table play station, and a "sandy" area. 

Can we all just agree that 3 and under should stay 3 and under? This isn't the museum's fault and it probably isn't worth the money to staff someone to watch this, but there is a young baby/toddler section so they don't get run over. My son almost got jumped on by children who looked over 5 years old in the mini ball pit. All the young children were just hanging out there barely moving and some older children came jumping. Maybe they were kids with younger siblings so the parents wanted them all in the same place, but it was in no way ideal. I'm still happy that they have this little section, I just wish it was policed more. 

The "sandy" area is pretty neat. It's not really sand, but more like super tiny rubber pieces. You don't have to worry about your kids being covered in the stuff. The only reason we stayed out of that area is I'm sure my son would try to eat it. 

The giant water table is pretty cool too. They have outfit covers for kids to wear to try to stop them from getting soaking wet, but there are few and disappear quickly. If you have a splasher it might be worth bringing your own poncho. I can say that because I have a million Yelp ponchos. 

On the weekend, upstairs can be quite chaotic. The Publix is a free for all where the kids are grabbing all the goods and one museum staffer is halfheartedly trying to reshelve them. However, the other areas, although somewhat crowded, never felt overly so. 

It may be that now that my son is walking I enjoyed it more because he could explore, but I definitely think for the price this place is worth five stars.

August 1, 2015 Saturday - 1:30 PM for lunch
3 Adults and a kid

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - 3 stars
Service - 5 stars

Background - Just finished up at Yelp Coffee event nearby and need lunch

Atmosphere - Part of a gas station complex at a busy intersection.  The place is small but a very modern feel, which I liked.

Food
  Drinks - I could see the beers in the refrigerator behind the cashier.  I noticed a bottle of Dos Equis that I had never seen so I had to get that.  It was the blue label, Azul, which had Agave nectar.

  Lunch - I order the Habanero Burrito with steak.  It had plenty of steak in the burrito.  The issue was how they made it if you say Habanero I expect some heat being brought.  For me the heat index was a zero.  I do not expect restaurants to serve food that will burn your face off but a zero on my scale is too low.

Service - You order with the cashier and pay like any fast food place.  What makes them different is that they bring the food too you.  It was not busy but they did not even take our names or had numbers on the table to find you.

Future - I would to try some more items.
Nice station with lots of restaurants. Amtrak is here. Very close to metro and other bus stops like Megabus and Bolt bus.

AJ's is definitely one of my favorite stops in Tucson! It's usually always on our trip schedule when we head down each year. 

AJ's opens early 6am, so it's become tradition to get there slightly after they open, enjoy some breakfast, and then browse. They have an excellent selection of baked goods and bagels, but my favorite is their hot bar. I love going for their egg concoctions and potatoes.

We will grab our noms, head to the pre-outdoor patio (usually it's already getting too hot for some of the party to eat outside). This is a more air conditioned "outside" seating. You will be surrounded with those doing the same; sipping coffee and munching - many doing it before work starts.

Then, comes the exploring! The wine and alcohol section is one of my personal favorites. There is a vast selection, and so much to try (and just look at from afar, because the prices are REAL).
