On top of the alcohol, AJ's also has an exorbitant amount of specialty goods: this is specifically what AJ's is known for.  This makes it extremely fun to browse and explore. 

On top of the groceries, specialty items, alcohol, hot bars, flower section, and gorgeous produce display, AJ's also offers an area catered to those looking for gifts. This ranges from clothing, candles, kitchen goods, stuffed animals, body health, etc. etc. The exploring can go on for a while. It's honestly hard to spend less than an hour here.

Another thing about AJ's is... it tends to be on the pricier side. But for goods you can't easily find elsewhere? It's worth it. 

If I lived in Tucson, this would be a daily-before-work stop for me. AJ's is most definitely an Arizona gem.

The cutest tea room I've been to in Canada. A wall full of shelves, packed with tins and vessels to display the wide variety of tea they sell. Cally herself was walking around the store talking to all of her customers, making sure they enjoyed their meal, recommending tea and generally being a delightful host. There are lots of tea pots, cups and other tea related items for sale. 
The overall vibe is granny-chic, which suits me to a tee (see what I did there?) because that's how I describe my fashion sense.
I ordered an English Breakfast tea which came in mismatched crockery set, exactly how I wanted it. I didn't order the scones but they come highly recommended by the ladies at the next table.

The Barge Seafood Plate is always filled with perfectly fried goodness. I don't know that the Onion Rings are worthy of the best in America title, but they too are pretty good. The bartenders are friendly and work together well to provide attentive service. The drinks are a step above dive bar quality. If you're looking to indulge in fresh fried seafood, Mahoney's is one of the best in New Orleans.

Bring tissues...because the baklava napolean WILL MAKE YOU WEEP!!!

So good!  One of my top spots in TS!

This is probably the best option in Orleans Parish other than their location Uptown on Tchop.  They usually have some supplies but not always a full selection of supplies but far better than the St. Charles Ave. location that seems to usually be out of many things.  This location rarely seems overly busy so you can usually get in and out in a reasonable amount of time.

I stopped in on a whim and I must say I expected more.  

The outside seems to entice some locals to hang out, especially since there's a convenience store (and it's truly convenient) adjacent to the diner.  Not unsettling, just noticeable.  Once inside the diner, the cooks & order takers are located behind the bar and are happy to give you a menu, or you can peruse the chalkboard to review the daily menu.  I caution you to look at the paper menu as there is a wide variety of soul food choices.  Not too pricey & relatively quick with the preparation.  

I ordered hot sausage with eggs on french bread and a side of mac n cheese.  I know these two things don't go together, however they're two of my favs!!!!!  AnyWHOOOOO, the temperature of the food was good as was the taste.  

There maybe a repeat visit in the near future, buuuuuuuuuuuut in the not-so-near future.
One of the great venues in the city to gaze upon contemporary art or watch a small live action play.

BEST LUNCH: bistro in the Quarter; gumbo ya ya; appetizers; chocolate brownie;
CLUBBY: cozy and festive dining room, packed with locals;
GREAT VALUE: especially the daily 3-course prix fixe menu!

By far, the best place for lunch, business or just social, in New Orleans. Like the Drake in Chicago it's comfortably "clubby" with requisite dark paneling, diffused lighting, impeccably tuxedoed front and back waiters, gentile management and an interesting mix of local metropolitan leaders, well-advised tourists, and local celebrants!  Why lunch?  In addition to the food quality, impeccable service and ambiance, the reasonably priced prix fixe 3 course menu with $1.50 bloody marys and martinis is incomparable.  When going, we always splurge and get the catfish fingers, duck spring rolls and/or coconut beer shrimp as starters.  As to its signature dish, I always compare any gumbo to my maw maw's first, then to Mr. B's "Gumbo YaYa" second.  All desserts are excellent but the white chocolate brownie is a must. Because it is so beloved by locals, make reservations!

2013 FAVORITES:
- Sandwich: MILK BAR, "Shrimply the Best"
- Appetizer: M BISTRO, "Jambalaya Tempura Fritters with Chipotle Remoulade"
- Salad: CARMO, "The Brazillian"
- New Cafe: MISTER GREGORY'S,"Traditional Croque","Pain Perdu Cupcake"
- Breakfast: JIMMY J'S, "Monte Cristo & Home Fries"
- Cheap Meal: MOJO LOUNGE, "Thai Wrap with potato salad, $7.50"
- Burger: COWBELL, "Cheeseburger with an Agogo/Ketchup mix"
- Best Restaurant:  COQUETTE

First off, it should be known that I'm not a fan of Chinese food generally. When asked to eat Chinese, I tend to get the same thing: Chicken Fried Rice. Jade Spice's dish tasted perfectly fine.

My boyfriend and I visited on a Saturday night, and, despite being located on a busy section of Route 73 in Mt. Laurel, the restaurant was eerily empty.

Our server was prompt, the Groupon was a plus and the decor was vibrant.

There are just dozens of other restaurants I'd rather try before visiting Jade Spice again.

My visit to Riverside Park was less than glamorous but it opened my eyes to a local treasure for the neighborhood. I was visiting the community center for a Park Board meeting and found myself taking pictures of the park both before and after my meeting. 1.) this park is easily accessible from 16th street on the east side.; 2.) Riverside Park is home to a NFL Colts Playscape and outdoor workout area; 3.) The gorgeous Parthenon-looking remains stand in this park (which I believe Indiana Landmarks is currently trying to save/preserve/raise funds); 4.) The Community Center is home to a large gym that was conveniently hosting a lunchtime workout class with at least 20-30 folks working out and dancing while I was there. I found myself smiling and soaking in their fun lunchtime energy and the fact that the park was being used for what it was originally created.

Royal Chef is much bigger inside than it appears from outside. There are actually ten tables for dining in, so it is more than just a takeout joint. I stopped in for a late lunch and ordered from the lunch menu (General Tso's Chicken, Fried Rice, Broccoli with a bowl of Wonton Soup).

The soup was actually the strongest part of the lunch. The chicken consume base was tasty, and the wontons, although somewhat thick skinned, actually had a decent flavor, too. The general's chicken was a large mound of amber glossed bird nuggets. About half of them were the right texture and taste, while the others were either too thickly skinned, or too crunchy to enjoy. Could not always taste the meat within. The fried rice was a large helping with adequate veggies to keep it interesting. Of course, the broccoli florets were there for decoration more than consumption. 

The meal was just okay overall.  I appreciated that there was a dining room where I could sit and eat lunch.  It would have been even better if they used real plates and flatware, rather than styro and plastic, and a take out container for the soup.  Service was provided by the cashier who was attractive and pleasant to all customers.  

The sign out front is worn and faded, and could use a little TLC to keep the shop from looking worse than it is. A little fresh paint and relettering would make China Chef a more upbeat place to chow down (no pun intended).

I've been wanting to try Bun Bo Hue, #23 here, for quite some time. Traditionally Bun Bo Hue is a spicy Viet noodle soup that has a richly flavored spicy broth with the odd cuts like tendon, tripe, flank, etc. along with cha lua (Viet meatloaf), and blood cake! I'm an adventurous eater, and all for the authenticity, but some of those things have kept me away from this for far too long. Thanks to some great photos on another social network and gentle nudging from friends, I saw that Pho, by Target, was serving a "Spicy Noodle Soup with beef or pork" that turned out to be their version of Bun Bo Hue, and the most approachable version that I've seen to date. 

While this soup is similar to pho, it varies in numerous ways. The broth was dark, rich, spicy, and full of flavors, very different from the clear, delicate consomme style pho broth we typically enjoy. The noodles were thicker, rounder, and had bit more chew than the thin vermicelli style in pho, and the soup included rare beef, flank, brisket, and cha lua (Viet meatloaf), which has more texture than flavor. I added in some lime juice, bean sprouts, jalapenos, basil and cilantro. The lime juice and herbs really made the soup come to life, and the bean sprouts added that much needed textural element to the dish. 

I will definitely be back for this dish again, and I'll be sure to try Bun Bo Hue all over thanks to Pho. But my fiance and I have ordered other dishes here, including a stir fried noodle dish with cha lua, and the veggie pho, and found them to just be ok. I have no doubt there are some other stars hiding on that menu and I'm looking forward to trying them soon. Pho has made the rotation and I'm looking forward to going back.

I still can't believe I have to give this place a Star.

This company represents the scum that is often found between fecal matter on a rats ass! WOW, that's descriptive, but true.

I became a sucker to these idiots, or who's the idiot, as they are a door to door, food sales business, and I was outside talking to my neighbor when the CRACK HEADS showed. since they can't be the most reputable company, hence they hire people who look as if just released from prison, only after enjoying the beatings and occasional rape.

The CRACK HEADs work as a team of Mr. Scum and Mr. Open Sores. they gladly show you pamphlets, tell you there customers and how clean there finger nails are!

OK, apparently me and the neighbor were weakened by the smell of meth and went in half for NY strip steaks. My first thought was to kill myself before the actual purchase. I regret that now. But, experiment is the name of the game. and I had a money back GAR-UN-TEE (sound hillbilly enough) as it said so on the pamphlet.

I took two frozen steaks from the box and defrosted them. once defrosted I cut the plastic cryovacted seal and went to pull it out. What followed were like entrails in an autopsy. A slimy gelatinous goo, with a distinctive chemical oder. Was it formaldehyde a common preservative for lab rats, in your 7th grade biology class, or was t an embalming fluid used to prepare you for your final windowless condo? 

My senses hit me like a European speed train, yes I was taken.....DEE DEE DEE, I know I should get back on the small bus.

Once realized that I was taken there were two things I had to do! One contact the pamphlet company and get my money back just as they said I would, two experiment with this alien meat (alien as in outer space, not illegally entered in the United States).

I pan cooked the steak, as if I were going to make any NY strip. When done I thought it even smelled normal, but I had the smell of formaldehyde in my nostrils. So I stuck my noise in a coffee can (swear) to burn away the remnants of lab rat! 

The steak still had a funny oder as if this cow had a heart attack in the field and the cow hands came by a few days later with a chain saw to butcher dear old (very old) Bessy!

I had to continue, maybe the fear of a meth laced high was over whelming me, causing me not to think straight. So I needed to bite into it. I didn't even have a red wine reduction or a cream sauce on it. a cut a small piece and bit down!

The chewing began. it almost had a texture of steak, it almost had a texture of the sole of my shoe too! I chewed and chewed and chewed and chewed, then gave up and swallowed. the taste was now recognizable, SALT! and a whole lot of it. I didn't even salt it. it was as if this was a pre salted cow, I hear there all over Europe and the communists swear by them.

The gelatinous ooze was a liquid salt solution, used to preserve this disgusting piece of meat! The experiment continued. I got NY strip number two, and removed it from the use and washed off the steak. When I did that the steak instantly went grey! literally went grey. My steak was a mood ring, that was edible, well edible to a maggot!

I didn't salt the washed grey looking steak and tossed it into the pan. The result was the same, except the memories of watching this steak turn grey!

Lastly, I called the number on the pamphlet, and it rang and rang and rang, I even walked away from the phone cleaned the living room and came back to rings. The 1-800 to know where! I then went to the internet (the greatest invention ever) and googled them! I number of similar complaints popped up! What a scum, bile eating, slime sucking company. I would like to thank Mr. Scum and Mr. Open Sore, for delivering me back to reality, I don't think they will be treated as kindly next time! 

PS, when I spoke to my neighbor again, he said wasn't it terrible, I gave mine to the lawn man, well neighbor, I threw mine away!!!!

$5 for a pint and a slice is one of the best deals in the city!!!  I would rank them higher except they have recently been inconsistent with their closing times.  This used to always be my go to place for some late night food but of late they have been closing much earlier so it is hard to judge when they may or may not be serving later at night.  They do tasty pizza, lasagna, and everything else I've had has been very good.  Not my favorite pizza in the area but at $5 for a pint and slice you are losing money if you don't eat your slice!!!

We went on the Steamboat Natchez tour. Tickets were pretty expensive for roughly a two hour trip. My in-laws, hubby, and I were disappointed. This is a tourist trap and is filled with adults over the age of 55. The band was not very good, the food was literally a buffet (who knows how long it had been sitting out), and the actual steamboat was older and needed some TLC. I would not take this tour again if I were in the area.
